{"brucellosisnum_articles": "382", "brucellosis": [{"archive_id": "8159688", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Brucellosis - USA: (AK) caribou", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=8159688", "date": "2020-05-16 22:18:51", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS - CHINA: (GANSU) VETERINARY INSTITUTE, 2019\n*******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 27 Dec 2019\nSource: China News Network [in Chinese, trans. Rapp.DS, edited]\nhttp://www.chinanews.com/sh/2019/12-27/9044618.shtml\n\n\nOn the night of 26 Dec 2019, the Gansu Province Health Commission posted news on its official website that the positive brucellosis antibody event at the Lanzhou Veterinary Institute was caused by exhaust gas from the nearby China Animal Husbandry Industry Co., Ltd.'s biopharmaceutical plant. As of 25 Dec [2019] at 4 p.m., the number of people testing positive for brucellosis had reached 181. Aside from one person with clinical symptoms, all the others did not have clinical symptoms and were not ill.\n\nThe official website stated that this event happened from 24 Jul-20 Aug 2019. China Animal Husbandry Industry Co., Ltd.'s biopharmaceutical plant produces brucellosis vaccine for animal use. Because disinfectant [used in the fermenter] had expired, exhaust gas containing vaccine strain was insufficiently sterilized. As the Lanzhou Veterinary Institute is downwind from the biopharmaceutical plant, [the exhaust gas] was inhaled or made contact with mucous membranes causing the positive brucellosis antibodies event.\n\nInvestigation found that from July to August 2019, winds in Lanzhou are mainly southeastern at windspeed level 2 to 3. Waste gases containing pathogen released by the biopharmaceutical plant were aerosolized and carried by the wind to a limited distance. Exposure levels were very low. So there would not be large numbers of people with positive antibodies. Thorough investigations led to the official conclusion that this was an accidental event.\n\nChina Animal Husbandry Industry Co., Ltd.'s biopharmaceutical plant's brucellosis vaccine production plant stopped production on 7 Dec 2019.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Dan Silver\n\n[An explanation of the 2019 event. - Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nGansu Province, China: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/333]\nSee Also\n2019\n----\nBrucellosis - China: (GS) veterinary institute, RFI 20191209.6831365\nBrucellosis - Italy: (MH) dog", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=8121439", "date": "2020-05-16 22:18:51", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS - CHINA: (GANSU) VETERINARY INSTITUTE, 2019\n*******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 27 Dec 2019\nSource: China News Network [in Chinese, trans. Rapp.DS, edited]\nhttp://www.chinanews.com/sh/2019/12-27/9044618.shtml\n\n\nOn the night of 26 Dec 2019, the Gansu Province Health Commission posted news on its official website that the positive brucellosis antibody event at the Lanzhou Veterinary Institute was caused by exhaust gas from the nearby China Animal Husbandry Industry Co., Ltd.'s biopharmaceutical plant. As of 25 Dec [2019] at 4 p.m., the number of people testing positive for brucellosis had reached 181. Aside from one person with clinical symptoms, all the others did not have clinical symptoms and were not ill.\n\nThe official website stated that this event happened from 24 Jul-20 Aug 2019. China Animal Husbandry Industry Co., Ltd.'s biopharmaceutical plant produces brucellosis vaccine for animal use. Because disinfectant [used in the fermenter] had expired, exhaust gas containing vaccine strain was insufficiently sterilized. As the Lanzhou Veterinary Institute is downwind from the biopharmaceutical plant, [the exhaust gas] was inhaled or made contact with mucous membranes causing the positive brucellosis antibodies event.\n\nInvestigation found that from July to August 2019, winds in Lanzhou are mainly southeastern at windspeed level 2 to 3. Waste gases containing pathogen released by the biopharmaceutical plant were aerosolized and carried by the wind to a limited distance. Exposure levels were very low. So there would not be large numbers of people with positive antibodies. Thorough investigations led to the official conclusion that this was an accidental event.\n\nChina Animal Husbandry Industry Co., Ltd.'s biopharmaceutical plant's brucellosis vaccine production plant stopped production on 7 Dec 2019.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Dan Silver\n\n[An explanation of the 2019 event. - As of 25 Dec [2019] at 4 p.m., the number of people testing positive for brucellosis had reached 181. Aside from one person with clinical symptoms, all the others did not have clinical symptoms and were not ill.\n\nThe official website stated that this event happened from 24 Jul-20 Aug 2019. China Animal Husbandry Industry Co., Ltd.'s biopharmaceutical plant produces brucellosis vaccine for animal use. Because disinfectant [used in the fermenter] had expired, exhaust gas containing vaccine strain was insufficiently sterilized. As the Lanzhou Veterinary Institute is downwind from the biopharmaceutical plant, [the exhaust gas] was inhaled or made contact with mucous membranes causing the positive brucellosis antibodies event.\n\nInvestigation found that from July to August 2019, winds in Lanzhou are mainly southeastern at windspeed level 2 to 3. Waste gases containing pathogen released by the biopharmaceutical plant were aerosolized and carried by the wind to a limited distance. Exposure levels were very low. So there would not be large numbers of people with positive antibodies. Thorough investigations led to the official conclusion that this was an accidental event.\n\nChina Animal Husbandry Industry Co., Ltd.'s biopharmaceutical plant's brucellosis vaccine production plant stopped production on 7 Dec 2019.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Dan Silver\n\n[An explanation of the 2019 event. - China 20071206.3936\n06 Aug 2007 Brucellosis, human - China (Hong Kong) 20070806.2553\n24 Dec 2004 Brucellosis - China (02): Hong Kong 20041224.3396\n22 Dec 2004 Brucellosis - China 20041222.3371\n.................................................ds/ll/tw/jh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "brucellosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2019-03-15 00:00:00", "2019-03-15 00:00:00", "2019-12-15 00:00:00", "2019-03-15 00:00:00", "2019-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-07-15 00:00:00", "2019-08-15 00:00:00", "2019-12-07 00:00:00", "2019-03-15 00:00:00", "2019-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2017-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2017-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2007-03-15 00:00:00", "2004-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2004-12-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Macau", "country": "Macao"}, {"location": "Hong Kong", "country": "Hong Kong"}, {"location": "Lanzhou", "country": "China"}, {"location": "China", "country": "China"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "Micronesia"}, {"location": "Gansu Province", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Hong Kong 20041224.3396", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "7789740", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Brucellosis - China (02): (GS) 2019", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=7789740", "date": "2020-05-16 22:18:51", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS - CHINA: (GANSU) VETERINARY INSTITUTE, 2019\n*******************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 27 Dec 2019\nSource: China News Network [in Chinese, trans. Rapp.DS, edited]\nhttp://www.chinanews.com/sh/2019/12-27/9044618.shtml\n\n\nOn the night of 26 Dec 2019, the Gansu Province Health Commission posted news on its official website that the positive brucellosis antibody event at the Lanzhou Veterinary Institute was caused by exhaust gas from the nearby China Animal Husbandry Industry Co., Ltd.'s biopharmaceutical plant. As of 25 Dec [2019] at 4 p.m., the number of people testing positive for brucellosis had reached 181. Aside from one person with clinical symptoms, all the others did not have clinical symptoms and were not ill.\n\nThe official website stated that this event happened from 24 Jul-20 Aug 2019. China Animal Husbandry Industry Co., Ltd.'s biopharmaceutical plant produces brucellosis vaccine for animal use. Because disinfectant [used in the fermenter] had expired, exhaust gas containing vaccine strain was insufficiently sterilized. As the Lanzhou Veterinary Institute is downwind from the biopharmaceutical plant, [the exhaust gas] was inhaled or made contact with mucous membranes causing the positive brucellosis antibodies event.\n\nInvestigation found that from July to August 2019, winds in Lanzhou are mainly southeastern at windspeed level 2 to 3. Waste gases containing pathogen released by the biopharmaceutical plant were aerosolized and carried by the wind to a limited distance. Exposure levels were very low. So there would not be large numbers of people with positive antibodies. Thorough investigations led to the official conclusion that this was an accidental event.\n\nChina Animal Husbandry Industry Co., Ltd.'s biopharmaceutical plant's brucellosis vaccine production plant stopped production on 7 Dec 2019.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Dan Silver\n\n[An explanation of the 2019 event. - Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nGansu Province, China: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/333]\nSee Also\n2019\n----\nBrucellosis - China: (GS) veterinary institute, RFI 20191209.6831365\nBrucellosis - China 20071206.3936\n06 Aug 2007 Brucellosis, human - China (Hong Kong) 20070806.2553\n24 Dec 2004 Brucellosis - China (02): Hong Kong 20041224.3396\n22 Dec 2004 Brucellosis - China 20041222.3371\n.................................................ds/ll/tw/jh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "brucellosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2019-03-15 00:00:00", "2019-03-15 00:00:00", "2019-12-15 00:00:00", "2019-03-15 00:00:00", "2019-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-07-15 00:00:00", "2019-08-15 00:00:00", "2019-12-07 00:00:00", "2019-03-15 00:00:00", "2019-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2017-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2017-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-16 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-14 00:00:00", "2021-03-11 00:00:00", "2021-03-10 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2007-03-15 00:00:00", "2004-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2004-12-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Macau", "country": "Macao"}, {"location": "Hong Kong", "country": "Hong Kong"}, {"location": "Lanzhou", "country": "China"}, {"location": "China", "country": "China"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "Micronesia"}, {"location": "Gansu Province", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Hong Kong 20041224.3396", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6995511", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Brucellosis - USA: (MT) elk", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6995511", "date": "2019-06-15 19:35:45", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS - USA (03): (DELAWARE) MEXICAN UNPASTEURIZED DAIRY PRODUCTS\n***********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 14 Jun 2019\nSource: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/raw-milk-brucellosis-infection-prompts-health-warning-from-delaware-officials-61474/\n\n\nDelaware state health officials are reminding the public to avoid consuming raw dairy products as it announced a confirmed case of brucellosis caused by _Brucella melitensis_ in a 46-year-old Sussex County woman.\n\nThe illness is a bacterial infection that primarily affects those consuming, or coming into contact with, contaminated animals or animal products. The most common source of infection is through the consumption of raw, unpasteurized dairy products. Prior to becoming ill, the patient in this case had consumed unpasteurized homemade dairy products from Mexico. No other risk factors have been identified.\n\nThe individual was hospitalized and is recovering after being treated for the illness. A 2nd, related case of brucellosis is also pending confirmation by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC).\n\n\"Cases such as this one can serve as an unfortunate reminder that we are vulnerable to certain bacteria and should take precautions to protect ourselves,\" said Department of Public Health (DPH) Medical Director Dr. Rick Hong. \"Delawareans are encouraged to avoid purchasing and consuming unpasteurized dairy products. Consuming questionable food items is not worth the risk to your health.\"\n\nBrucellosis infection is most frequently transmitted by eating or drinking raw/unpasteurized dairy products such as milk and cheese, yet can also be contracted through inhalation or physical contact with infected animals or animal products. When sheep, goats, cows or camels are infected, their milk becomes contaminated with the bacteria. If the milk from infected animals is not pasteurized, the infection will be transmitted to people who consume the milk and/or cheese products. Brucellosis is not common in the USA. Nationally, the average is fewer than 200 human cases each year. Person-to-person transmission is rare. Prior to this case, the DPH has confirmed 3 cases since 2010; those cases occurred in 2010, 2017 and 2018. The case in 2010 was associated with consumption of unpasteurized milk while the nature of exposure in the 2017 and 2018 cases is unknown.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Although these cases are related to unpasteurized dairy products from Mexico, cases of infection from US dairy also occur. In the March 2012 issue of Emerging Infectious Diseases (Langer AJ, Ayers T, Grass J, et al. Nonpasteurized dairy products, disease outbreaks, and state laws -- United States, 1993-2006. Emerg Infect Dis 2012;18(3):385-391; http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/18/3/11-1370_article), the authors report on 121 foodborne outbreaks (with 4413 cases of reported illness) caused by contaminated dairy products, and 73 (60%) were involved with unpasteurized dairy products. A total of 65 (54%) involved cheese (42% made from unpasteurized milk) and 56 (46%) involved fluid milk (82% involved unpasteurized milk). In these outbreaks, _Campylobacter_ spp. were responsible for 54% of the outbreaks, followed by _Salmonella_ spp. (22%), enterohemorrhagic _E. coli_ (13%), _Brucella_ spp. (4%), _Listeria_ (4%), and _Shigella_ spp. (3%).\n\nClearly, pasteurized milk can also transmit disease, and 48 outbreaks were reported. The source of contamination was reported in only 7 (14%), of which at least 4 resulted from post-pasteurization contamination by an infected food handler.\n\nThe reader is directed to the article for additional information and discussion.\n\nClassical zoonotic organisms such as _Brucella abortus_, _B. melitensis_, _Mycobacterium bovis_, _Salmonella_ species, _Listeria monocytogenes_, _Campylobacter_ species, _Yersinia_ species, _Coxiella burnetii_, and _E. coli_ O157:H7 are associated with the ingestion of raw milk. Non-zoonotic organisms such as _Streptococcus pyogenes_, _Salmonella_ Typhi, _Corynebacterium diphtheriae_, _Shigella_ spp., _Salmonella_ Paratyphi A, _Salmonella_ Paratyphi B, enterotoxins from _Staphylococcus aureus_, and hepatitis A have also been associated with the ingestion of raw milk. - Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nDelaware, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/211]\nSee Also\nBrucellosis - USA (02): CDC, sale of unpasteurized milk across state lines 20190219.6325115\nBrucellosis - USA: sale of unpasteurized milk across state lines 20190128.6280591\n2018\n----\nBrucellosis - USA (08): (PA) bovine, human 20181227.6223249\nBrucellosis - USA (07): (WY) bovine 20181122.6158858\nBrucellosis - USA (06): (WY) bovine 20181116.6148746\nBrucellosis - USA (05): (Greater Yellowstone Ecosystem) elk, bovine 20181031.6122576\nBrucellosis - USA (04): (WY) bovine 20181012.6088330\nBrucellosis, canine - USA: public health risk 20180818.5974044\nBrucellosis - USA (03): (OR) B. abortus vaccine infection, needle stick, 2017 20180705.5890072\nBrucellosis - USA (02): (MT) elk, 20180326.5711704\nBrucellosis - USA: (TX) unpasteurized milk, B. abortus vaccine strain, 2017, CDC 20180308.5674369\n2017\n----\nBrucellosis - USA (07): (MT) bovine 20170826.5275885\nBrucellosis - USA (06): (TX) unpasteurized milk, alert, recall, RFI 20170816.5253834\nBrucellosis - The most common source of infection is through the consumption of raw, unpasteurized dairy products. Prior to becoming ill, the patient in this case had consumed unpasteurized homemade dairy products from Mexico. No other risk factors have been identified.\n\nThe individual was hospitalized and is recovering after being treated for the illness. A 2nd, related case of brucellosis is also pending confirmation by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC).\n\n\"Cases such as this one can serve as an unfortunate reminder that we are vulnerable to certain bacteria and should take precautions to protect ourselves,\" said Department of Public Health (DPH) Medical Director Dr. Rick Hong. \"Delawareans are encouraged to avoid purchasing and consuming unpasteurized dairy products. Consuming questionable food items is not worth the risk to your health.\"\n\nBrucellosis infection is most frequently transmitted by eating or drinking raw/unpasteurized dairy products such as milk and cheese, yet can also be contracted through inhalation or physical contact with infected animals or animal products. When sheep, goats, cows or camels are infected, their milk becomes contaminated with the bacteria. If the milk from infected animals is not pasteurized, the infection will be transmitted to people who consume the milk and/or cheese products. Brucellosis is not common in the USA. Nationally, the average is fewer than 200 human cases each year. Person-to-person transmission is rare. Prior to this case, the DPH has confirmed 3 cases since 2010; those cases occurred in 2010, 2017 and 2018. The case in 2010 was associated with consumption of unpasteurized milk while the nature of exposure in the 2017 and 2018 cases is unknown.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Although these cases are related to unpasteurized dairy products from Mexico, cases of infection from US dairy also occur. In the March 2012 issue of Emerging Infectious Diseases (Langer AJ, Ayers T, Grass J, et al. Nonpasteurized dairy products, disease outbreaks, and state laws -- United States, 1993-2006. Emerg Infect Dis 2012;18(3):385-391; http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/18/3/11-1370_article), the authors report on 121 foodborne outbreaks (with 4413 cases of reported illness) caused by contaminated dairy products, and 73 (60%) were involved with unpasteurized dairy products. A total of 65 (54%) involved cheese (42% made from unpasteurized milk) and 56 (46%) involved fluid milk (82% involved unpasteurized milk). In these outbreaks, _Campylobacter_ spp. were responsible for 54% of the outbreaks, followed by _Salmonella_ spp. (22%), enterohemorrhagic _E. coli_ (13%), _Brucella_ spp. (4%), _Listeria_ (4%), and _Shigella_ spp. (3%).\n\nClearly, pasteurized milk can also transmit disease, and 48 outbreaks were reported. The source of contamination was reported in only 7 (14%), of which at least 4 resulted from post-pasteurization contamination by an infected food handler.\n\nThe reader is directed to the article for additional information and discussion.\n\nClassical zoonotic organisms such as _Brucella abortus_, _B. melitensis_, _Mycobacterium bovis_, _Salmonella_ species, _Listeria monocytogenes_, _Campylobacter_ species, _Yersinia_ species, _Coxiella burnetii_, and _E. coli_ O157:H7 are associated with the ingestion of raw milk. Non-zoonotic organisms such as _Streptococcus pyogenes_, _Salmonella_ Typhi, _Corynebacterium diphtheriae_, _Shigella_ spp., _Salmonella_ Paratyphi A, _Salmonella_ Paratyphi B, enterotoxins from _Staphylococcus aureus_, and hepatitis A have also been associated with the ingestion of raw milk. - Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nDelaware, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/211]\nSee Also\nBrucellosis - USA (02): CDC, sale of unpasteurized milk across state lines 20190219.6325115\nBrucellosis - The most common source of infection is through the consumption of raw, unpasteurized dairy products. Prior to becoming ill, the patient in this case had consumed unpasteurized homemade dairy products from Mexico. USA (03): (DE) Mexican unpasteurized dairy products", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6522381", "date": "2019-06-15 19:35:45", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS - USA (03): (DELAWARE) MEXICAN UNPASTEURIZED DAIRY PRODUCTS\n***********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 14 Jun 2019\nSource: Outbreak News Today [edited]\nhttp://outbreaknewstoday.com/raw-milk-brucellosis-infection-prompts-health-warning-from-delaware-officials-61474/\n\n\nDelaware state health officials are reminding the public to avoid consuming raw dairy products as it announced a confirmed case of brucellosis caused by _Brucella melitensis_ in a 46-year-old Sussex County woman.\n\nThe illness is a bacterial infection that primarily affects those consuming, or coming into contact with, contaminated animals or animal products. The most common source of infection is through the consumption of raw, unpasteurized dairy products. Prior to becoming ill, the patient in this case had consumed unpasteurized homemade dairy products from Mexico. No other risk factors have been identified.\n\nThe individual was hospitalized and is recovering after being treated for the illness. A 2nd, related case of brucellosis is also pending confirmation by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC).\n\n\"Cases such as this one can serve as an unfortunate reminder that we are vulnerable to certain bacteria and should take precautions to protect ourselves,\" said Department of Public Health (DPH) Medical Director Dr. Rick Hong. \"Delawareans are encouraged to avoid purchasing and consuming unpasteurized dairy products. Consuming questionable food items is not worth the risk to your health.\"\n\nBrucellosis infection is most frequently transmitted by eating or drinking raw/unpasteurized dairy products such as milk and cheese, yet can also be contracted through inhalation or physical contact with infected animals or animal products. When sheep, goats, cows or camels are infected, their milk becomes contaminated with the bacteria. If the milk from infected animals is not pasteurized, the infection will be transmitted to people who consume the milk and/or cheese products. Brucellosis is not common in the USA. Nationally, the average is fewer than 200 human cases each year. Person-to-person transmission is rare. Prior to this case, the DPH has confirmed 3 cases since 2010; those cases occurred in 2010, 2017 and 2018. The case in 2010 was associated with consumption of unpasteurized milk while the nature of exposure in the 2017 and 2018 cases is unknown.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Although these cases are related to unpasteurized dairy products from Mexico, cases of infection from US dairy also occur. In the March 2012 issue of Emerging Infectious Diseases (Langer AJ, Ayers T, Grass J, et al. Nonpasteurized dairy products, disease outbreaks, and state laws -- United States, 1993-2006. Emerg Infect Dis 2012;18(3):385-391; http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/18/3/11-1370_article), the authors report on 121 foodborne outbreaks (with 4413 cases of reported illness) caused by contaminated dairy products, and 73 (60%) were involved with unpasteurized dairy products. A total of 65 (54%) involved cheese (42% made from unpasteurized milk) and 56 (46%) involved fluid milk (82% involved unpasteurized milk). In these outbreaks, _Campylobacter_ spp. were responsible for 54% of the outbreaks, followed by _Salmonella_ spp. (22%), enterohemorrhagic _E. coli_ (13%), _Brucella_ spp. (4%), _Listeria_ (4%), and _Shigella_ spp. (3%).\n\nClearly, pasteurized milk can also transmit disease, and 48 outbreaks were reported. The source of contamination was reported in only 7 (14%), of which at least 4 resulted from post-pasteurization contamination by an infected food handler.\n\nThe reader is directed to the article for additional information and discussion.\n\nClassical zoonotic organisms such as _Brucella abortus_, _B. melitensis_, _Mycobacterium bovis_, _Salmonella_ species, _Listeria monocytogenes_, _Campylobacter_ species, _Yersinia_ species, _Coxiella burnetii_, and _E. coli_ O157:H7 are associated with the ingestion of raw milk. Non-zoonotic organisms such as _Streptococcus pyogenes_, _Salmonella_ Typhi, _Corynebacterium diphtheriae_, _Shigella_ spp., _Salmonella_ Paratyphi A, _Salmonella_ Paratyphi B, enterotoxins from _Staphylococcus aureus_, and hepatitis A have also been associated with the ingestion of raw milk. - Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map:\nDelaware, United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/211]\nSee Also\nBrucellosis - USA (02): CDC, sale of unpasteurized milk across state lines 20190219.6325115\nBrucellosis - USA: sale of unpasteurized milk across state lines 20190128.6280591\n2018\n----\nBrucellosis - USA (08): (PA) bovine, human 20181227.6223249\nBrucellosis - USA (07): (WY) bovine 20181122.6158858\nBrucellosis - USA (06): (WY) bovine 20181116.6148746\nBrucellosis - USA (05): (Greater Yellowstone Ecosystem) elk, bovine 20181031.6122576\nBrucellosis - USA (04): (WY) bovine 20181012.6088330\nBrucellosis, canine - USA: public health risk 20180818.5974044\nBrucellosis - USA (03): (OR) B. abortus vaccine infection, needle stick, 2017 20180705.5890072\nBrucellosis - USA (02): (MT) elk, 20180326.5711704\nBrucellosis - USA: (TX) unpasteurized milk, B. abortus vaccine strain, 2017, CDC 20180308.5674369\n2017\n----\nBrucellosis - USA (07): (MT) bovine 20170826.5275885\nBrucellosis - USA (06): (TX) unpasteurized milk, alert, recall, RFI 20170816.5253834\nBrucellosis - USA (05): (TX) human, unpasteurized milk, alert 20170815.5251979\n.................................................sb/ll/rd/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "brucellosis", "hepatitis a"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2010-03-15 00:00:00", "2010-03-15 00:00:00", "2017-03-15 00:00:00", "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "2010-03-15 00:00:00", "2017-03-15 00:00:00", "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "2012-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2017-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "WY", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Delaware", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "Micronesia"}, {"location": "Mexico", "country": "Mexico"}, {"location": "US", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Sussex County", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6514716", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Brucellosis - Algeria: (TR) unpasteurized dairy", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6514716", "date": "2019-02-19 17:22:27", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS - USA (02): CDC, SALE OF UNPASTEURIZED MILK ACROSS STATE LINES\n**************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 8 Feb 2019\nSource: CDC, Brucellosis Homepage [edited]\nhttps://www.cdc.gov/brucellosis/exposure/drug-resistant-brucellosis-linked-raw-milk.html\n\n\nRB51 -- Exposures to drug-resistant brucellosis linked to raw milk, 19 states, USA\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nOverview:\n\u00ad The CDC and state health officials are investigating potential exposures to _Brucella [abortus_] strain RB51 (RB51) in 19 states, connected to consuming raw (unpasteurized) milk from Miller's Biodiversity Farm in Quarryville, Pennsylvania. One case of RB51 infection (brucellosis) has been confirmed in New York, and an unknown number of people may have been exposed to RB51 from drinking the milk from this farm. This type of _Brucella_ is resistant to first-line drugs and can be difficult to diagnose because of limited testing options and the fact that early brucellosis symptoms are similar to those of more common illnesses like influenza.\n\nThe New York case is the 3rd known instance of an infection with RB51 associated with consuming raw milk or raw milk products produced in the USA. The other 2 human cases occurred in October 2017 in New Jersey and in August 2017 in Texas. Those cases reported drinking raw milk from an online retailer and a Texas farm, respectively. In addition to these 3 confirmed cases, hundreds of others were potentially exposed to RB51 during these 3 incidents.\n\nSymptoms of _Brucella_ infection (brucellosis)\n----------------------------------------------\n- Initial symptoms of brucellosis can include fever, sweats, loss of appetite, headache, fatigue, muscle and joint pain, and potentially more serious complications.\n- In pregnant patients, _Brucella_ infections can lead to miscarriage.\n- Symptoms can start anywhere from 5 days to 6 months after exposure.\n- People who are infected but are not treated can go on to develop more serious complications like arthritis; heart problems; enlargement of the spleen or liver; and, in rare cases, nervous system problems, like meningitis.\n\nAdvice to consumers\n-------------------\n- Raw milk and raw milk products are those that have not undergone a process called pasteurization that kills disease-causing germs.\n- RB51 is a live, weakened strain used in a vaccine to protect cows against a more severe form of _Brucella_ infection that can cause abortions in cows and severe illness in people. On rare occasions, cows vaccinated with RB51 vaccine can shed the bacteria in their milk. People who drink raw milk from cows that are shedding RB51 can develop brucellosis.\n- RB51 is resistant to rifampin, one of the antimicrobials that would typically be used to prevent or treat brucellosis. CDC recommends that anyone who may have been exposed to RB51 go to their doctor to see if they need antibiotics to prevent infection and symptoms from developing.\n- People who consumed raw milk or raw milk products from this dairy farm since January 2016 may have been exposed and should talk to their doctor.\n-- People who are still within 6 months of the date they last consumed the raw milk are at an increased risk for brucellosis and should receive antimicrobials to prevent an infection and symptoms, and should monitor their health for possible symptoms for 6 months. If symptoms develop, they should see their doctor immediately for testing.\n-- People who last drank raw milk from this dairy more than 6 months ago and have had symptoms of brucellosis - but not been treated - should see their doctor immediately for testing that can determine if they are infected and need antibiotics to prevent long-term health problems caused by brucellosis.\n- Discard any leftover or stored raw milk or raw milk products from this dairy farm.\n\nInvestigation details\n---------------------\n- A New York resident, who drank raw milk purchased from Miller's Biodiversity Farm in Quarryville, Pennsylvania, was diagnosed with brucellosis in November 2018.\n- Milk samples from Miller's Biodiversity tested positive for RB51. A cow that tested positive for RB51 has been removed from the milking herd.\n- As of 22 Jan 2019, investigators have determined that people in 19 states have bought or consumed raw milk from the implicated farm. The states are Alabama, California, Connecticut, Florida, Georgia, Iowa, Maryland, Massachusetts, Michigan, Minnesota, Mississippi, New Jersey, New York, North Carolina, Ohio, Pennsylvania, Rhode Island, South Carolina, and Virginia.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Kunihiko Iizuka\n\n[In the March 2012 issue of Emerging Infectious Diseases (Langer AJ, Ayers T, Grass J, et al. Nonpasteurized dairy products, disease outbreaks, and state laws -- United States, 1993-2006. Emerg Infect Dis. 2012; 18(3): 385-91; http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/18/3/11-1370_article), the authors report on 121 foodborne outbreaks (with 4413 cases of reported illness) caused by contaminated dairy products, and 73 (60%) were involved with unpasteurized dairy products. 65 (54%) involved cheese (42% made from unpasteurized milk) and 56 (46%) involved fluid milk (82% involved unpasteurized milk). In these outbreaks, _Campylobacter_ spp were responsible for 54% of the outbreaks, followed by _Salmonella_ spp (22%), enterohemorrhagic _E. coli_ (13%), _Brucella_ spp (4%), _Listeria_ (4%), and _Shigella_ spp (3%).\n\nClearly, pasteurized milk can also transmit disease, and 48 outbreaks were reported. The source of contamination was reported in only 7 (14%), of which at least 4 resulted from post-pasteurization contamination by an infected food handler.\n\nThe reader is directed to the article for additional information and discussion.\n\nClassical zoonotic organisms such as _Brucella abortus_, _B. melitensis_, _Mycobacterium bovis_, _Salmonella_ species, _Listeria monocytogenes_, _Campylobacter_ species, _Yersinia_ species, _Coxiella burnetii_, and _E. coli_ O157:H7 are associated with the ingestion of raw milk. Non-zoonotic organisms such as _Streptococcus pyogenes_, _Salmonella_ Typhi, _Corynebacterium diphtheriae_, _Shigella_ spp, _Salmonella_ Paratyphi A, _Salmonella_ Paratyphi B, enterotoxins from _Staphylococcus aureus_, and hepatitis A have also been associated with the ingestion of raw milk. - Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map of the United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106]\nSee Also\nBrucellosis - USA: sale of unpasteurized milk across state lines 20190128.6280591\n2018\n----\nBrucellosis - USA (08): (PA) bovine, human 20181227.6223249\nBrucellosis - USA (07): (WY) bovine 20181012.6088330\nBrucellosis, canine - USA: public health risk 20180818.5974044\nBrucellosis - USA (03): (OR) B. abortus vaccine infection, needle stick, 2017 20180705.5890072\nBrucellosis - USA (02): (MT) elk, 20180326.5711704\nBrucellosis - USA: (TX) unpasteurized milk, B. abortus vaccine strain, 2017, CDC 20180308.5674369\n2017\n----\nBrucellosis - USA (07): (MT) bovine USA\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nOverview:\n\u00ad The CDC and state health officials are investigating potential exposures to _Brucella [abortus_] strain RB51 (RB51) in 19 states, connected to consuming raw (unpasteurized) milk from Miller's Biodiversity Farm in Quarryville, Pennsylvania. On rare occasions, cows vaccinated with RB51 vaccine can shed the bacteria in their milk. People who drink raw milk from cows that are shedding RB51 can develop brucellosis.\n- RB51 is resistant to rifampin, one of the antimicrobials that would typically be used to prevent or treat brucellosis. CDC recommends that anyone who may have been exposed to RB51 go to their doctor to see if they need antibiotics to prevent infection and symptoms from developing.\n- People who consumed raw milk or raw milk products from this dairy farm since January 2016 may have been exposed and should talk to their doctor.\n-- People who are still within 6 months of the date they last consumed the raw milk are at an increased risk for brucellosis and should receive antimicrobials to prevent an infection and symptoms, and should monitor their health for possible symptoms for 6 months. Rico"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Florida", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "New Jersey", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Connecticut", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Minnesota", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "Micronesia"}, {"location": "Ohio", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6465729", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Brucellosis, canine - USA (02): (IA) dog", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6465729", "date": "2019-02-19 17:22:27", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS - USA (02): CDC, SALE OF UNPASTEURIZED MILK ACROSS STATE LINES\n**************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 8 Feb 2019\nSource: CDC, Brucellosis Homepage [edited]\nhttps://www.cdc.gov/brucellosis/exposure/drug-resistant-brucellosis-linked-raw-milk.html\n\n\nRB51 -- Exposures to drug-resistant brucellosis linked to raw milk, 19 states, USA\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nOverview:\n\u00ad The CDC and state health officials are investigating potential exposures to _Brucella [abortus_] strain RB51 (RB51) in 19 states, connected to consuming raw (unpasteurized) milk from Miller's Biodiversity Farm in Quarryville, Pennsylvania. One case of RB51 infection (brucellosis) has been confirmed in New York, and an unknown number of people may have been exposed to RB51 from drinking the milk from this farm. This type of _Brucella_ is resistant to first-line drugs and can be difficult to diagnose because of limited testing options and the fact that early brucellosis symptoms are similar to those of more common illnesses like influenza.\n\nThe New York case is the 3rd known instance of an infection with RB51 associated with consuming raw milk or raw milk products produced in the USA. The other 2 human cases occurred in October 2017 in New Jersey and in August 2017 in Texas. Those cases reported drinking raw milk from an online retailer and a Texas farm, respectively. In addition to these 3 confirmed cases, hundreds of others were potentially exposed to RB51 during these 3 incidents.\n\nSymptoms of _Brucella_ infection (brucellosis)\n----------------------------------------------\n- Initial symptoms of brucellosis can include fever, sweats, loss of appetite, headache, fatigue, muscle and joint pain, and potentially more serious complications.\n- In pregnant patients, _Brucella_ infections can lead to miscarriage.\n- Symptoms can start anywhere from 5 days to 6 months after exposure.\n- People who are infected but are not treated can go on to develop more serious complications like arthritis; heart problems; enlargement of the spleen or liver; and, in rare cases, nervous system problems, like meningitis.\n\nAdvice to consumers\n-------------------\n- Raw milk and raw milk products are those that have not undergone a process called pasteurization that kills disease-causing germs.\n- RB51 is a live, weakened strain used in a vaccine to protect cows against a more severe form of _Brucella_ infection that can cause abortions in cows and severe illness in people. On rare occasions, cows vaccinated with RB51 vaccine can shed the bacteria in their milk. People who drink raw milk from cows that are shedding RB51 can develop brucellosis.\n- RB51 is resistant to rifampin, one of the antimicrobials that would typically be used to prevent or treat brucellosis. CDC recommends that anyone who may have been exposed to RB51 go to their doctor to see if they need antibiotics to prevent infection and symptoms from developing.\n- People who consumed raw milk or raw milk products from this dairy farm since January 2016 may have been exposed and should talk to their doctor.\n-- People who are still within 6 months of the date they last consumed the raw milk are at an increased risk for brucellosis and should receive antimicrobials to prevent an infection and symptoms, and should monitor their health for possible symptoms for 6 months. If symptoms develop, they should see their doctor immediately for testing.\n-- People who last drank raw milk from this dairy more than 6 months ago and have had symptoms of brucellosis - but not been treated - should see their doctor immediately for testing that can determine if they are infected and need antibiotics to prevent long-term health problems caused by brucellosis.\n- Discard any leftover or stored raw milk or raw milk products from this dairy farm.\n\nInvestigation details\n---------------------\n- A New York resident, who drank raw milk purchased from Miller's Biodiversity Farm in Quarryville, Pennsylvania, was diagnosed with brucellosis in November 2018.\n- Milk samples from Miller's Biodiversity tested positive for RB51. A cow that tested positive for RB51 has been removed from the milking herd.\n- As of 22 Jan 2019, investigators have determined that people in 19 states have bought or consumed raw milk from the implicated farm. The states are Alabama, California, Connecticut, Florida, Georgia, Iowa, Maryland, Massachusetts, Michigan, Minnesota, Mississippi, New Jersey, New York, North Carolina, Ohio, Pennsylvania, Rhode Island, South Carolina, and Virginia.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Kunihiko Iizuka\n\n[In the March 2012 issue of Emerging Infectious Diseases (Langer AJ, Ayers T, Grass J, et al. Nonpasteurized dairy products, disease outbreaks, and state laws -- United States, 1993-2006. Emerg Infect Dis. 2012; 18(3): 385-91; http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/18/3/11-1370_article), the authors report on 121 foodborne outbreaks (with 4413 cases of reported illness) caused by contaminated dairy products, and 73 (60%) were involved with unpasteurized dairy products. 65 (54%) involved cheese (42% made from unpasteurized milk) and 56 (46%) involved fluid milk (82% involved unpasteurized milk). In these outbreaks, _Campylobacter_ spp were responsible for 54% of the outbreaks, followed by _Salmonella_ spp (22%), enterohemorrhagic _E. coli_ (13%), _Brucella_ spp (4%), _Listeria_ (4%), and _Shigella_ spp (3%).\n\nClearly, pasteurized milk can also transmit disease, and 48 outbreaks were reported. The source of contamination was reported in only 7 (14%), of which at least 4 resulted from post-pasteurization contamination by an infected food handler.\n\nThe reader is directed to the article for additional information and discussion.\n\nClassical zoonotic organisms such as _Brucella abortus_, _B. melitensis_, _Mycobacterium bovis_, _Salmonella_ species, _Listeria monocytogenes_, _Campylobacter_ species, _Yersinia_ species, _Coxiella burnetii_, and _E. coli_ O157:H7 are associated with the ingestion of raw milk. Non-zoonotic organisms such as _Streptococcus pyogenes_, _Salmonella_ Typhi, _Corynebacterium diphtheriae_, _Shigella_ spp, _Salmonella_ Paratyphi A, _Salmonella_ Paratyphi B, enterotoxins from _Staphylococcus aureus_, and hepatitis A have also been associated with the ingestion of raw milk. - Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map of the United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106]\nSee Also\nBrucellosis - USA: sale of unpasteurized milk across state lines 20190128.6280591\n2018\n----\nBrucellosis - USA (08): (PA) bovine, human 20181227.6223249\nBrucellosis - USA (07): (WY) bovine 20181122.6158858\nBrucellosis - USA (06): (WY) bovine 20181116.6148746\nBrucellosis - USA (05): (Greater Yellowstone Ecosystem) elk, bovine 20181031.6122576\nBrucellosis - USA (04): (WY) bovine 20181012.6088330\nBrucellosis, canine - USA: public health risk 20180818.5974044\nBrucellosis - USA (03): (OR) B. abortus vaccine infection, needle stick, 2017 20180705.5890072\nBrucellosis - USA (02): (MT) elk, 20180326.5711704\nBrucellosis - USA: (TX) unpasteurized milk, B. abortus vaccine strain, 2017, CDC 20180308.5674369\n2017\n----\nBrucellosis - USA (07): (MT) bovine 20170826.5275885\nBrucellosis - USA (06): (TX) unpasteurized milk, alert, recall, RFI 20170816.5253834\nBrucellosis - USA (05): (TX) human, unpasteurized milk, alert 20170815.5251979\n.................................................ll/mj/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "brucellosis", "hepatitis a", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2017-10-15 00:00:00", "2017-08-15 00:00:00", "2016-01-15 00:00:00", "2018-11-15 00:00:00", "2019-01-22 00:00:00", "2012-03-15 00:00:00", "2012-03-15 00:00:00", "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2017-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "New York", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Alabama", "country": "United "BRUCELLOSIS - USA (02): CDC, SALE OF UNPASTEURIZED MILK ACROSS STATE LINES\n**************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail [edited]\nhttps://www.cdc.gov/brucellosis/exposure/drug-resistant-brucellosis-linked-raw-milk.html\n\n\nRB51 -- Exposures to drug-resistant brucellosis linked to raw milk, 19 states, USA\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nOverview:\n\u00ad The CDC and state health officials are investigating potential exposures to _Brucella [abortus_] strain RB51 (RB51) in 19 states, connected to consuming raw (unpasteurized) milk from Miller's Biodiversity Farm in Quarryville, Pennsylvania. One case of RB51 infection (brucellosis) has been confirmed in New York, and an unknown number of people may have been exposed to RB51 from drinking the milk from this farm. This type of _Brucella_ is resistant to first-line drugs and can be difficult to diagnose because of limited testing options and the fact that early brucellosis symptoms are similar to those of more common illnesses like influenza.\n\nThe New York case is the 3rd known instance of an infection with RB51 associated with consuming raw milk or raw milk products produced in the USA. The other 2 human cases occurred in October 2017 in New Jersey and in August 2017 in Texas. Those cases reported drinking raw milk from an online retailer and a Texas farm, respectively. In addition to these 3 confirmed cases, hundreds of others were potentially exposed to RB51 during these 3 incidents.\n\nSymptoms of _Brucella_ infection (brucellosis)\n----------------------------------------------\n- Initial symptoms of brucellosis can include fever, sweats, loss of appetite, headache, fatigue, muscle and joint pain, and potentially more serious complications.\n- In pregnant patients, _Brucella_ infections can lead to miscarriage.\n- Symptoms can start anywhere from 5 days to 6 months after exposure.\n- People who are infected but are not treated can go on to develop more serious complications like arthritis; heart problems; enlargement of the spleen or liver; and, in rare cases, nervous system problems, like meningitis.\n\nAdvice to consumers\n-------------------\n- Raw milk and raw milk products are those that have not undergone a process called pasteurization that kills disease-causing germs.\n- RB51 is a live, weakened strain used in a vaccine to protect cows against a more severe form of _Brucella_ infection that can cause abortions in cows and severe illness in people. On rare occasions, cows vaccinated with RB51 vaccine can shed the bacteria in their milk. People who drink raw milk from cows that are shedding RB51 can develop brucellosis.\n- RB51 is resistant to rifampin, one of the antimicrobials that would typically be used to prevent or treat brucellosis. CDC recommends that anyone who may have been exposed to RB51 go to their doctor to see if they need antibiotics to prevent infection and symptoms from developing.\n- People who consumed raw milk or raw milk products from this dairy farm since January 2016 may have been exposed and should talk to their doctor.\n-- People who are still within 6 months of the date they last consumed the raw milk are at an increased risk for brucellosis and should receive antimicrobials to prevent an infection and symptoms, and should monitor their health for possible symptoms for 6 months. If symptoms develop, they should see their doctor immediately for testing.\n-- People who last drank raw milk from this dairy more than 6 months ago and have had symptoms of brucellosis - but not been treated - should see their doctor immediately for testing that can determine if they are infected and need antibiotics to prevent long-term health problems caused by brucellosis.\n- Discard any leftover or stored raw milk or raw milk products from this dairy farm.\n\nInvestigation details\n---------------------\n- A New York resident, who drank raw milk purchased from Miller's Biodiversity Farm in Quarryville, Pennsylvania, was diagnosed with brucellosis in November 2018.\n- Milk samples from Miller's Biodiversity tested positive for RB51. A cow that tested positive for RB51 has been removed from the milking herd.\n- As of 22 Jan 2019, investigators have determined that people in 19 states have bought or consumed raw milk from the implicated farm. The states are Alabama, California, Connecticut, Florida, Georgia, Iowa, Maryland, Massachusetts, Michigan, Minnesota, Mississippi, New Jersey, New York, North Carolina, Ohio, Pennsylvania, Rhode Island, South Carolina, and Virginia.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Kunihiko Iizuka\n\n[In the March 2012 issue of Emerging Infectious Diseases (Langer AJ, Ayers T, Grass J, et al. "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Quarryville", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Georgia", "country": "Georgia"}, {"location": "Texas", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Pennsylvania", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "North Carolina", "country": "Puerto Rico"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Florida", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "New Jersey", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Connecticut", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Minnesota", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "Micronesia"}, {"location": "Ohio", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "6374217", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Brucellosis - Mexico: (SLP) unpasteurized goat cheese", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6374217", "date": "2019-02-19 17:22:27", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS - USA (02): CDC, SALE OF UNPASTEURIZED MILK ACROSS STATE LINES\n**************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 8 Feb 2019\nSource: CDC, Brucellosis Homepage [edited]\nhttps://www.cdc.gov/brucellosis/exposure/drug-resistant-brucellosis-linked-raw-milk.html\n\n\nRB51 -- Exposures to drug-resistant brucellosis linked to raw milk, 19 states, USA\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nOverview:\n\u00ad The CDC and state health officials are investigating potential exposures to _Brucella [abortus_] strain RB51 (RB51) in 19 states, connected to consuming raw (unpasteurized) milk from Miller's Biodiversity Farm in Quarryville, Pennsylvania. One case of RB51 infection (brucellosis) has been confirmed in New York, and an unknown number of people may have been exposed to RB51 from drinking the milk from this farm. This type of _Brucella_ is resistant to first-line drugs and can be difficult to diagnose because of limited testing options and the fact that early brucellosis symptoms are similar to those of more common illnesses like influenza.\n\nThe New York case is the 3rd known instance of an infection with RB51 associated with consuming raw milk or raw milk products produced in the USA. The other 2 human cases occurred in October 2017 in New Jersey and in August 2017 in Texas. Those cases reported drinking raw milk from an online retailer and a Texas farm, respectively. In addition to these 3 confirmed cases, hundreds of others were potentially exposed to RB51 during these 3 incidents.\n\nSymptoms of _Brucella_ infection (brucellosis)\n----------------------------------------------\n- Initial symptoms of brucellosis can include fever, sweats, loss of appetite, headache, fatigue, muscle and joint pain, and potentially more serious complications.\n- In pregnant patients, _Brucella_ infections can lead to miscarriage.\n- Symptoms can start anywhere from 5 days to 6 months after exposure.\n- People who are infected but are not treated can go on to develop more serious complications like arthritis; heart problems; enlargement of the spleen or liver; and, in rare cases, nervous system problems, like meningitis.\n\nAdvice to consumers\n-------------------\n- Raw milk and raw milk products are those that have not undergone a process called pasteurization that kills disease-causing germs.\n- RB51 is a live, weakened strain used in a vaccine to protect cows against a more severe form of _Brucella_ infection that can cause abortions in cows and severe illness in people. On rare occasions, cows vaccinated with RB51 vaccine can shed the bacteria in their milk. People who drink raw milk from cows that are shedding RB51 can develop brucellosis.\n- RB51 is resistant to rifampin, one of the antimicrobials that would typically be used to prevent or treat brucellosis. CDC recommends that anyone who may have been exposed to RB51 go to their doctor to see if they need antibiotics to prevent infection and symptoms from developing.\n- People who consumed raw milk or raw milk products from this dairy farm since January 2016 may have been exposed and should talk to their doctor.\n-- People who are still within 6 months of the date they last consumed the raw milk are at an increased risk for brucellosis and should receive antimicrobials to prevent an infection and symptoms, and should monitor their health for possible symptoms for 6 months. If symptoms develop, they should see their doctor immediately for testing.\n-- People who last drank raw milk from this dairy more than 6 months ago and have had symptoms of brucellosis - but not been treated - should see their doctor immediately for testing that can determine if they are infected and need antibiotics to prevent long-term health problems caused by brucellosis.\n- Discard any leftover or stored raw milk or raw milk products from this dairy farm.\n\nInvestigation details\n---------------------\n- A New York resident, who drank raw milk purchased from Miller's Biodiversity Farm in Quarryville, Pennsylvania, was diagnosed with brucellosis in November 2018.\n- Milk samples from Miller's Biodiversity tested positive for RB51. A cow that tested positive for RB51 has been removed from the milking herd.\n- As of 22 Jan 2019, investigators have determined that people in 19 states have bought or consumed raw milk from the implicated farm. The states are Alabama, California, Connecticut, Florida, Georgia, Iowa, Maryland, Massachusetts, Michigan, Minnesota, Mississippi, New Jersey, New York, North Carolina, Ohio, Pennsylvania, Rhode Island, South Carolina, and Virginia.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Kunihiko Iizuka\n\n[In the March 2012 issue of Emerging Infectious Diseases (Langer AJ, Ayers T, Grass J, et al. Nonpasteurized dairy products, disease outbreaks, and state laws -- United States, 1993-2006. Emerg Infect Dis. 2012; 18(3): 385-91; http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/18/3/11-1370_article), the authors report on 121 foodborne outbreaks (with 4413 cases of reported illness) caused by contaminated dairy products, and 73 (60%) were involved with unpasteurized dairy products. 65 (54%) involved cheese (42% made from unpasteurized milk) and 56 (46%) involved fluid milk (82% involved unpasteurized milk). In these outbreaks, _Campylobacter_ spp were responsible for 54% of the outbreaks, followed by _Salmonella_ spp (22%), enterohemorrhagic _E. coli_ (13%), _Brucella_ spp (4%), _Listeria_ (4%), and _Shigella_ spp (3%).\n\nClearly, pasteurized milk can also transmit disease, and 48 outbreaks were reported. The source of contamination was reported in only 7 (14%), of which at least 4 resulted from post-pasteurization contamination by an infected food handler.\n\nThe reader is directed to the article for additional information and discussion.\n\nClassical zoonotic organisms such as _Brucella abortus_, _B. melitensis_, _Mycobacterium bovis_, _Salmonella_ species, _Listeria monocytogenes_, _Campylobacter_ species, _Yersinia_ species, _Coxiella burnetii_, and _E. coli_ O157:H7 are associated with the ingestion of raw milk. Non-zoonotic organisms such as _Streptococcus pyogenes_, _Salmonella_ Typhi, _Corynebacterium diphtheriae_, _Shigella_ spp, _Salmonella_ Paratyphi A, _Salmonella_ Paratyphi B, enterotoxins from _Staphylococcus aureus_, and hepatitis A have also been associated with the ingestion of raw milk. - Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map of the United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106]\nSee Also\nBrucellosis - USA: sale of unpasteurized milk across state lines 20190128.6280591\n2018\n----\nBrucellosis - USA (08): (PA) bovine, human 20181227.6223249\nBrucellosis - USA (07): (WY) bovine 20181122.6158858\nBrucellosis - USA (06): (WY) bovine 20181116.6148746\nBrucellosis - USA (05): (Greater Yellowstone Ecosystem) elk, bovine 20181031.6122576\nBrucellosis - USA (04): (WY) bovine 20181012.6088330\nBrucellosis, canine - USA: public health risk 20180818.5974044\nBrucellosis - USA (03): (OR) B. abortus vaccine infection, needle stick, 2017 20180705.5890072\nBrucellosis - USA (02): (MT) elk, 20180326.5711704\nBrucellosis - USA: (TX) unpasteurized milk, B. abortus vaccine strain, 2017, CDC 20180308.5674369\n2017\n----\nBrucellosis - USA (07): (MT) bovine 20170826.5275885\nBrucellosis - USA (06): (TX) unpasteurized milk, alert, recall, RFI 20170816.5253834\nBrucellosis - USA (05): (TX) human, unpasteurized milk, alert 20170815.5251979\n.................................................ll/mj/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "brucellosis", "hepatitis a", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2017-10-15 00:00:00", "2017-08-15 00:00:00", "2016-01-15 00:00:00", "2018-11-15 00:00:00", "2019-01-22 00:00:00", "2012-03-15 00:00:00", "2012-03-15 00:00:00", "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2017-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "New York", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Alabama", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Maryland", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Virginia", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Michigan", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Rhode Island", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Massachusetts", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "WY", "country": "United States"}, Rico"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Florida", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "New Jersey", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Connecticut", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS - USA (02): CDC, SALE OF UNPASTEURIZED MILK ACROSS STATE LINES\n**************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 8 Feb 2019\nSource: CDC, Brucellosis Homepage [edited]\nhttps://www.cdc.gov/brucellosis/exposure/drug-resistant-brucellosis-linked-raw-milk.html\n\n\nRB51 -- Exposures to drug-resistant brucellosis linked to raw milk, 19 states, USA\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nOverview:\n\u00ad The CDC and state health officials are investigating potential exposures to _Brucella [abortus_] strain RB51 (RB51) in 19 states, connected to consuming raw (unpasteurized) milk from Miller's Biodiversity Farm in Quarryville, Pennsylvania. One case of RB51 infection (brucellosis) has been confirmed in New York, and an unknown number of people may have been exposed to RB51 from drinking the milk from this farm. The other 2 human cases occurred in October 2017 in New Jersey and in August 2017 in Texas. Those cases reported drinking raw milk from an online retailer and a Texas farm, respectively. In addition to these 3 confirmed cases, hundreds of others were potentially exposed to RB51 during these 3 incidents.\n\nSymptoms of _Brucella_ infection (brucellosis)\n----------------------------------------------\n- Initial symptoms of brucellosis can include fever, sweats, loss of appetite, headache, fatigue, muscle and joint pain, and potentially more serious complications.\n- In pregnant patients, _Brucella_ infections can lead to miscarriage.\n- Symptoms can start anywhere from 5 days to 6 months after exposure.\n- People who are infected but are not treated can go on to develop more serious complications like arthritis; heart problems; enlargement of the spleen or liver; and, in rare cases, nervous system problems, like meningitis.\n\nAdvice to consumers\n-------------------\n- Raw milk and raw milk products are those that have not undergone a process called pasteurization that kills disease-causing germs.\n- RB51 is a live, weakened strain used in a vaccine to protect cows against a more severe form of _Brucella_ infection that can cause abortions in cows and severe illness in people. On rare occasions, cows vaccinated with RB51 vaccine can shed the bacteria in their milk. People who drink raw milk from cows that are shedding RB51 can develop brucellosis.\n- RB51 is resistant to rifampin, one of the antimicrobials that would typically be used to prevent or treat brucellosis. CDC recommends that anyone who may have been exposed to RB51 go to their doctor to see if they need antibiotics to prevent infection and symptoms from developing.\n- People who consumed raw milk or raw milk products from this dairy farm since January 2016 may have been exposed and should talk to their doctor.\n-- People who are still within 6 months of the date they last consumed the raw milk are at an increased risk for brucellosis and should receive antimicrobials to prevent an infection and symptoms, and should monitor their health for possible symptoms for 6 months. If symptoms develop, they should see their doctor immediately for testing.\n-- People who last drank raw milk from this dairy more than 6 months ago and have had symptoms of brucellosis - but not been treated - should see their doctor immediately for testing that can determine if they are infected and need antibiotics to prevent long-term health problems caused by brucellosis.\n- Discard any leftover or stored raw milk or raw milk products from this dairy farm.\n\nInvestigation details\n---------------------\n- A New York resident, who drank raw milk purchased from Miller's Biodiversity Farm in Quarryville, Pennsylvania, was diagnosed with brucellosis in November 2018.\n- Milk samples from Miller's Biodiversity tested positive for RB51. A cow that tested positive for RB51 has been removed from the milking herd.\n- As of 22 Jan 2019, investigators have determined that people in 19 states have bought or consumed raw milk from the implicated farm. The states are Alabama, California, Connecticut, Florida, Georgia, Iowa, Maryland, Massachusetts, Michigan, Minnesota, Mississippi, New Jersey, New York, North Carolina, Ohio, Pennsylvania, Rhode Island, South Carolina, and Virginia.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Kunihiko Iizuka\n\n[In the March 2012 issue of Emerging Infectious Diseases (Langer AJ, Ayers T, Grass J, et al. Emerg Infect Dis. 2012; 18(3): 385-91; http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/18/3/11-1370_article), the authors report on 121 foodborne outbreaks (with 4413 cases of reported illness) caused by contaminated dairy products, and 73 (60%) were involved with unpasteurized dairy products. 65 (54%) involved cheese (42% made from unpasteurized milk) and 56 (46%) involved fluid milk (82% involved unpasteurized milk). The source of contamination was reported in only 7 (14%), of which at least 4 resulted from post-pasteurization contamination by an infected food handler.\n\nThe reader is directed to the article for additional information and discussion.\n\nClassical zoonotic organisms such as _Brucella abortus_, _B. melitensis_, _Mycobacterium bovis_, _Salmonella_ species, _Listeria monocytogenes_, _Campylobacter_ species, _Yersinia_ species, _Coxiella burnetii_, and _E. coli_ O157:H7 are associated with the ingestion of raw milk. _Staphylococcus aureus_, and hepatitis A have also been associated with the ingestion of raw milk. - Mod.LL\n\nHealthMap/ProMED-mail map of the United States: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/106]\nSee "6280591", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Brucellosis - USA: sale of unpasteurized milk across state lines", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6280591", "date": "2019-02-19 17:22:27", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS - USA (02): CDC, SALE OF UNPASTEURIZED MILK ACROSS STATE LINES\n**************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 8 Feb 2019\nSource: CDC, Brucellosis Homepage [edited]\nhttps://www.cdc.gov/brucellosis/exposure/drug-resistant-brucellosis-linked-raw-milk.html\n\n\nRB51 -- Exposures to drug-resistant brucellosis linked to raw milk, 19 states, USA\n----------------------------------------------------------------------\nOverview:\n\u00ad The CDC and state health officials are investigating potential exposures to _Brucella [abortus_] strain RB51 (RB51) in 19 states, connected to consuming raw (unpasteurized) milk from Miller's Biodiversity Farm in Quarryville, Pennsylvania. A cow that tested positive for RB51 has been removed from the milking herd.\n- As of 22 Jan 2019, investigators have determined that people in 19 states have bought or consumed raw milk from the implicated farm. The states are Alabama, California, Connecticut, Florida, Georgia, Iowa, Maryland, Massachusetts, Michigan, Minnesota, Mississippi, New Jersey, New York, North Carolina, Ohio, Pennsylvania, Rhode Island, South Carolina, and Virginia.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Kunihiko Iizuka\n\n[In the March 2012 issue of Emerging Infectious Diseases (Langer AJ, Ayers T, Grass J, et al. "6278984", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Brucellosis - South Africa: (LP) unpasteurized milk, fatal", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6278984", "date": "2018-10-29 22:39:47", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS - BOTSWANA: (CHOBE) BOVINE, OIE, REQUEST FOR INFORMATION\n********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 23 Oct 2018\nSource: OIE, WAHID [edited]\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=28367\n\n\nBrucellosis (_Brucella abortus_), Botswana\n------------------------------------------\nInformation received on [and dated] 23 Oct 2018 from Dr Letlhogile Modisa, Director, Veterinary Services, Ministry of Agriculture, Gaborone, Botswana\n\nSummary\nReport type: Immediate notification (final report)\nDate of start of the event: 7 Aug 2018\nDate of confirmation of the event: 27 Aug 2018\nReason for notification: Reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: June 2017\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: _Brucella abortus_\nNature of diagnosis: Clinical, Laboratory (advanced)\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country.\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nOutbreak location: Parakarungu, Chobe West, Chobe\nDate of start of the outbreak: 7 Aug 2018\nOutbreak status: Resolved 23 Oct 2018\nEpidemiological unit: Village\nTotal animals affected:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / killed and disposed of / Slaughtered\nCattle / 50 / 6 / 0 / 0 / 0\nAffected population: Cattle grazing in communal set in a village\n\nOutbreak statistics [rates apparent, expressed as percentages]:\nSpecies / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nCattle / 12 / 0 / 0 / 0\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction and/or slaughter\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: Unknown or inconclusive\nEpidemiological comments: Heifers were reported to be aborting in different kraals in the same extension area. Samples were collected for testing, and all the 6 animals returned positive results. Animals aborted in the space of one (1) week. Surveillance has not detected any more cases of abortion since the 6 cases in August 2018. Vaccination for brucellosis is not practised in the country.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: surveillance outside containment and/or protection zone; surveillance within containment and/or protection zone; traceability; vaccination prohibited; no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: No other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nBotswana national veterinary laboratory (national laboratory) / Cattle / complement fixation test (CFT)) / 27 Aug 2018 / Positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is resolved. No more reports will be submitted.\n\n[The location of these outbreaks can be seen on the interactive map included in this OIE report at the source URL above.]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[According to the 6-monthly and annual reports (2016 and 2017) sent to the OIE, brucellosis caused by _B. abortus_ is reported as a disease present in certain zones in the country, but no quantitative information is available.\n\nAlthough this current event occurred 2 months ago, and Botswana has communicated it as resolved, it would be important to learn whether all the susceptible animals were tested. As is mentioned in the epidemiological comments, the 6 animals that aborted were positive to the disease. However, it is not clear whether all the susceptible animals on the premises were tested. As is mentioned in the OIE Terrestrial Manual: \"The disease is usually asymptomatic in young animals and non-pregnant females. Following infection with _B. abortus_ or _B. melitensis_, pregnant adult females develop a placentitis, usually resulting in abortion between the 5th and 9th months of pregnancy. Even in the absence of abortion, profuse excretion of the organism occurs in the placenta, fetal fluids and vaginal discharges. The mammary gland and associated lymph nodes may also be infected, and organisms may be excreted in the milk. Subsequent pregnancies are usually carried to term, but uterine and mammary infection recurs, with reduced numbers of organisms in afterbirth products and milk. In acute infections, the organism is present in most major body lymph nodes\" http://www.oie.int/fileadmin/Home/eng/Health_standards/tahm/2.01.04_BRUCELLOSIS.pdf.\n\nIt would also be important to know whether modified stamping out was or will be used as a control measure, given that this disease is pathogenic for humans.\n\n\"_Brucella abortus_, _B. melitensis_, and _B. suis_ are highly pathogenic for humans, and all infected tissues, cultures, and potentially contaminated materials must be handled under appropriate containment conditions\" http://www.oie.int/fileadmin/Home/eng/Health_standards/tahm/2.01.04_BRUCELLOSIS.pdf. - Mod.CRD\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map available at:\nChobe, Botswana: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/2809]\nSee Also\nBrucellosis - Algeria: (TO) unpasteurized cow's milk 20180710.5896040\nBrucellosis - Nigeria: (BA) butchers, serosurvey 20180214.5626680\n2015\n---\nBrucellosis - Botswana: (SO) bovine, caprine, OIE, RFI 20150913.3639980\n.................................................crd/msp/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "brucellosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2018-03-15 Botswana\n------------------------------------------\nInformation received on [and dated] 23 Oct 2018 from Dr Letlhogile Modisa, Director, Veterinary Services, Ministry of Agriculture, Gaborone, Botswana\n\nSummary\nReport type: Immediate notification (final report)\nDate of start of the event: 7 Aug 2018\nDate of confirmation of the event: 27 Aug 2018\nReason for notification: Reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: June 2017\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: _Brucella abortus_\nNature of diagnosis: Clinical, Laboratory (advanced)\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country.\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nOutbreak location: Parakarungu, Chobe West, Chobe\nDate of start of the outbreak: 7 Aug 2018\nOutbreak status: Resolved 23 Oct 2018\nEpidemiological unit: Village\nTotal animals affected:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / killed and disposed of / Slaughtered\nCattle / 50 / 6 / 0 / 0 / 0\nAffected population: Cattle grazing in communal set in a village\n\nOutbreak statistics [rates apparent, expressed as percentages]:\nSpecies / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nCattle / 12 / 0 / 0 / 0\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction and/or slaughter\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: Unknown or inconclusive\nEpidemiological comments: Heifers were reported to be aborting in different kraals in the same extension area. Samples were collected for testing, and all the 6 animals returned positive results. Animals aborted in the space of one (1) week. Surveillance has not detected any more cases of abortion since the 6 cases in August 2018. Vaccination for brucellosis is not practised in the country.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: surveillance outside containment and/or protection zone; surveillance within containment and/or protection zone; traceability; vaccination prohibited; no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: No other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nBotswana national veterinary laboratory (national laboratory) / Cattle / complement fixation test (CFT)) / 27 Aug 2018 / Positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is resolved. No more reports will be submitted.\n\n[The location of these outbreaks can be seen on the interactive map included in this OIE report at the source URL above.]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[According to the 6-monthly and annual reports (2016 and 2017) sent to the OIE, brucellosis caused by _B. abortus_ is reported as a disease present in certain zones in the country, but no quantitative information is available.\n\nAlthough this current event occurred 2 months ago, and Botswana has communicated it as resolved, it would be important to learn whether all the susceptible animals were tested. As is mentioned in the epidemiological comments, the 6 animals that aborted were positive to the disease. However, it is not clear whether all the susceptible animals on the premises were tested. As is mentioned in the OIE Terrestrial Manual: \"The disease is usually asymptomatic in young animals and non-pregnant females. Following infection with _B. abortus_ or _B. melitensis_, pregnant adult females develop a placentitis, usually resulting in abortion between the 5th and 9th months of pregnancy. Even in the absence of abortion, profuse excretion of the organism occurs in the placenta, fetal fluids and vaginal discharges. The mammary gland and associated lymph nodes may also be infected, and organisms may be excreted in the milk. Subsequent pregnancies are usually carried to term, but uterine and mammary infection recurs, with reduced numbers of organisms in afterbirth products and milk. In acute infections, the organism is present in most major body lymph nodes\" http://www.oie.int/fileadmin/Home/eng/Health_standards/tahm/2.01.04_BRUCELLOSIS.pdf.\n\nIt would also be important to know whether modified stamping out was or will be used as a control measure, given that this disease is pathogenic for humans.\n\n\"_Brucella abortus_, _B. melitensis_, and _B. suis_ are highly pathogenic for humans, and all infected tissues, cultures, and potentially contaminated materials must be handled under appropriate containment conditions\" http://www.oie.int/fileadmin/Home/eng/Health_standards/tahm/2.01.04_BRUCELLOSIS.pdf. - Mod.CRD\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map available at:\nChobe, Botswana: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/2809]\nSee
