No more reports will be submitted.\n\n[The location of these outbreaks can be seen on the interactive map included in this OIE report at the source URL above.]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[According to the 6-monthly and annual reports (2016 and 2017) sent to the OIE, brucellosis caused by _B. abortus_ is reported as a disease present in certain zones in the country, but no quantitative information is available.\n\nAlthough this current event occurred 2 months ago, and Botswana has communicated it as resolved, it would be important to learn whether all the susceptible animals were tested. As is mentioned in the epidemiological comments, the 6 animals that aborted were positive to the disease. However, it is not clear whether all the susceptible animals on the premises were tested. As is mentioned in the OIE Terrestrial Manual: \"The disease is usually asymptomatic in young animals and non-pregnant females. Following infection with _B. abortus_ or _B. melitensis_, pregnant adult females develop a placentitis, usually resulting in abortion between the 5th and 9th months of pregnancy. Even in the absence of abortion, profuse excretion of the organism occurs in the placenta, fetal fluids and vaginal discharges. The mammary gland and associated lymph nodes may also be infected, and organisms may be excreted in the milk. Subsequent pregnancies are usually carried to term, but uterine and mammary infection recurs, with reduced numbers of organisms in afterbirth products and milk. In acute infections, the organism is present in most major body lymph nodes\" http://www.oie.int/fileadmin/Home/eng/Health_standards/tahm/2.01.04_BRUCELLOSIS.pdf.\n\nIt would also be important to know whether modified stamping out was or will be used as a control measure, given that this disease is pathogenic for humans.\n\n\"_Brucella abortus_, _B. melitensis_, and _B. suis_ are highly pathogenic for humans, and all infected tissues, cultures, and potentially contaminated materials must be handled under appropriate containment conditions\" As is mentioned in the epidemiological comments, the 6 animals that aborted were positive to the disease. However, it is not clear whether all the susceptible animals on the premises were tested. As is mentioned in the OIE Terrestrial Manual: \"The disease is usually asymptomatic in young animals and non-pregnant females. Following infection with _B. abortus_ or _B. melitensis_, pregnant adult females develop a placentitis, usually resulting in abortion between the 5th and 9th months of pregnancy. Even in the absence of abortion, profuse excretion of the organism occurs in the placenta, fetal fluids and vaginal discharges. The mammary gland and associated lymph nodes may also be infected, and organisms may be excreted in the milk. Subsequent pregnancies are usually carried to term, but uterine and mammary infection recurs, with reduced numbers of organisms in afterbirth products and milk. In acute infections, the organism is present in most major body lymph nodes\" http://www.oie.int/fileadmin/Home/eng/Health_standards/tahm/2.01.04_BRUCELLOSIS.pdf.\n\nIt would also be important to know whether modified stamping out was or will be used as a control measure, given that this disease is pathogenic for humans.\n\n\"_Brucella abortus_, _B. melitensis_, and _B. suis_ are highly pathogenic for humans, and all infected tissues, cultures, and potentially contaminated materials must be handled under appropriate containment conditions\" Botswana\n------------------------------------------\nInformation received on [and dated] 23 Oct 2018 from Dr Letlhogile Modisa, Director, Veterinary Services, Ministry of Agriculture, Gaborone, Botswana\n\nSummary\nReport type: Immediate notification (final report)\nDate of start of the event: 7 Aug 2018\nDate of confirmation of the event: 27 Aug 2018\nReason for notification: Reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: June 2017\nManifestation of disease: clinical disease\nCausal agent: _Brucella abortus_\nNature of diagnosis: Clinical, Laboratory (advanced)\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country.\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nOutbreak location: Parakarungu, Chobe West, Chobe\nDate of start of the outbreak: 7 Aug 2018\nOutbreak status: Resolved 23 Oct 2018\nEpidemiological unit: Village\nTotal animals affected:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / killed and disposed of / Slaughtered\nCattle / 50 / 6 / 0 / 0 / 0\nAffected population: Cattle grazing in communal set in a village\n\nOutbreak statistics [rates apparent, expressed as percentages]:\nSpecies / Morbidity rate / Mortality rate / Case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nCattle / 12 / 0 / 0 / 0\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction and/or slaughter\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: Unknown or inconclusive\nEpidemiological comments: Heifers were reported to be aborting in different kraals in the same extension area. Samples were collected for testing, and all the 6 animals returned positive results. Animals aborted in the space of one (1) week. Surveillance has not detected any more cases of abortion since the 6 cases in August 2018. Vaccination for brucellosis is not practised in the country.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: surveillance outside containment and/or protection zone; surveillance within containment and/or protection zone; traceability; vaccination prohibited; no treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: No other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nBotswana national veterinary laboratory (national laboratory) / Cattle / complement fixation test (CFT)) / 27 Aug 2018 / Positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is resolved. No more reports will be submitted.\n\n[The location of these outbreaks can be seen on the interactive map included in this OIE report at the source URL above.]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[According to the 6-monthly and annual reports (2016 and 2017) sent to the OIE, brucellosis caused by _B. abortus_ is reported as a disease present in certain zones in the country, but no quantitative information is available.\n\nAlthough this current event occurred 2 months ago, and Botswana has communicated it as resolved, it would be important to learn whether all the susceptible animals were tested. As is mentioned in the epidemiological comments, the 6 animals that aborted were positive to the disease. However, it is not clear whether all the susceptible animals on the premises were tested. As is mentioned in the OIE Terrestrial Manual: \"The disease is usually asymptomatic in young animals and non-pregnant females. Following infection with _B. abortus_ or _B. melitensis_, pregnant adult females develop a placentitis, usually resulting in abortion between the 5th and 9th months of pregnancy. Even in the absence of abortion, profuse excretion of the organism occurs in the placenta, fetal fluids and vaginal discharges. The mammary gland and associated lymph nodes may also be infected, and organisms may be excreted in the milk. Subsequent pregnancies are usually carried to term, but uterine and mammary infection recurs, with reduced numbers of organisms in afterbirth products and milk. In acute infections, the organism is present in most major body lymph nodes\" http://www.oie.int/fileadmin/Home/eng/Health_standards/tahm/2.01.04_BRUCELLOSIS.pdf.\n\nIt would also be important to know whether modified stamping out was or will be used as a control measure, given that this disease is pathogenic for humans.\n\n\"_Brucella abortus_, _B. melitensis_, and _B. suis_ are highly pathogenic for humans, and all infected tissues, cultures, and potentially contaminated materials must be handled under appropriate containment conditions\" http://www.oie.int/fileadmin/Home/eng/Health_standards/tahm/2.01.04_BRUCELLOSIS.pdf. - Mod.CRD\n\nHealthMap/ProMED map available at:\nChobe, Botswana: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/2809]\nSee event pertains to a defined zone within the country.\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nOutbreak location: Parakarungu, Chobe West, Chobe\nDate of start of the outbreak: 7 Aug 2018\nOutbreak status: Resolved 23 Oct 2018\nEpidemiological unit: Village\nTotal animals affected:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / killed and disposed of / Slaughtered\nCattle / 50 / 6 / 0 / 0 / 0\nAffected population: or inconclusive\nEpidemiological comments: Heifers were reported to be aborting in different kraals in the same extension area. Samples were collected for testing, and all the 6 animals returned positive results. Animals aborted in the space of one (1) week. Surveillance has not detected any more cases of abortion since the 6 cases in August 2018. As is mentioned in the epidemiological comments, the 6 animals that aborted were positive to the disease. However, it is not clear whether all the susceptible animals on the premises were tested. As is mentioned in the OIE Terrestrial Manual: \"The disease is usually asymptomatic in young animals and non-pregnant females. Following infection with _B. abortus_ or _B. melitensis_, pregnant adult females develop a placentitis, usually resulting in abortion between the 5th and 9th months of pregnancy. Even in the absence of abortion, profuse excretion of the organism occurs in the placenta, fetal fluids and vaginal discharges. for humans, and all infected tissues, cultures, and potentially contaminated materials must be handled under appropriate containment conditions\" As is mentioned in the epidemiological comments, the 6 animals that aborted were positive to the disease. However, it is not clear whether all the susceptible animals on the premises were tested. As is mentioned in the OIE Terrestrial Manual: \"The disease is usually asymptomatic in young animals and non-pregnant females. Following infection with _B. abortus_ or _B. melitensis_, pregnant adult females develop a placentitis, usually resulting in abortion between the 5th and 9th months of pregnancy. Even in the absence of abortion, profuse excretion of the organism occurs in the placenta, fetal fluids and vaginal discharges. The mammary gland and associated lymph nodes may also be infected, and organisms may be excreted in the milk. Subsequent pregnancies are usually carried to term, but uterine and mammary infection recurs, with reduced numbers of organisms in afterbirth products and milk. In acute infections, the organism is present in most major body lymph nodes\" http://www.oie.int/fileadmin/Home/eng/Health_standards/tahm/2.01.04_BRUCELLOSIS.pdf.\n\nIt would also be important to know whether modified stamping out was or will be used as a control measure, given that this disease is pathogenic for humans.\n\n\"_Brucella abortus_, _B. melitensis_, and _B. suis_ are highly pathogenic for humans, and all infected tissues, cultures, and potentially contaminated materials must be handled under appropriate containment conditions\" Botswana: (SO) bovine, caprine, OIE, RFI 20150913.3639980\n.................................................crd/msp/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "brucellosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2018-03-15 00:00:00", "2017-06-15 00:00:00", "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "2018-03-15 00:00:00", "2018-08-15 00:00:00", "2016-03-15 00:00:00", "2017-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": []}]}, {"archive_id": "5974044", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Brucellosis, canine - USA: public health risk", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5974044", "date": "2018-03-26 18:29:26", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS - USA (02): (MONTANA) ELK\n*************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 21 Mar 2018, 12:05 PM EDT\nSource: ABC Fox Montana [edited]\nhttp://www.kfbb.com/story/37776738/latest-test-results-show-brucellosis-positive-elk\n\n\n[Montana] Fish, Wildlife, and Parks released their test results for Brucellosis in Elk and out of the more than 140 animals tested, 7 came back positive.\n\nOf the 100 elk sampled in the Tendoy Mountains [a mountain range in Beaverhead county Montana - Mod.TG], 1 was found to have Brucellosis. This is the first time an elk has tested positive for exposure in the Tendoys. A total of 30 elk in the Tendoys were outfitted with radio collars to learn more about movement patterns and understand how the disease may spread.\n\nIn the southeastern Madison Valley, 6 elk tested positive for exposure out of the 41 sampled there.\n\n\"The discovery of an exposed elk in the Tendoys emphasizes the importance of elk surveillance near the boundary of the DSA [designated surveillance area - Mod.TG]\" said Montana State Veterinarian Martin Zaluski. The goal of brucellosis surveillance operations is to evaluate the presence and understand the movement of Brucellosis in Montana's elk populations.\n\nBrucellosis is a bacterial disease that infects cattle, bison, and elk and can result in abortion or the birth of weak calves. The disease is primarily transmitted through contact with infected birth tissues and fluids.\n\nMore information about Brucellosis and the Targeted Elk Brucellosis Surveillance project can be found online at:\nhttp://fwp.mt.gov/fishAndWildlife/diseasesAndResearch/healthPrograms/brucellosis/.\n\n[Byline: Ricky Blackburn]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Brucellosis is a zoonotic disease, and in many places around the world, it still causes severe infections in humans. Brucellosis also causes decreased milk production, weight loss, abortion, and infertility in cattle. For these reasons, beginning in the mid-1950s, great efforts were made to eliminate the disease from all livestock within the United States. While these efforts were successful at eliminating transmission within cattle nation-wide, sporadic transmission from wildlife to cattle in and around the Greater Yellowstone Ecosystem has been on the increase. Brucellosis can result in serious financial burdens to cattle producers, potentially resulting in quarantine of a herd, increased testing and vaccination costs, and possible difficulty in trade with other states and countries.\n\nAlthough the disease can cause abortions in elk, measurable population effects on population size or trend due to brucellosis have not been documented. However, the potential for transmission to livestock results in decreased acceptance of elk on private property which, in many areas, constitutes a large proportion of elk winter range. Historically, rates of exposure in elk (measured by blood tests) have been very low (below 2 percent in the early 1990's) and limited in distribution. Recent research and surveillance efforts have indicated that the prevalence and geographical distribution of the disease in elk is likely increasing. Brucellosis now exists in elk populations outside of the Greater Yellowstone Area. Hunters and game processors should take precautions (gloves and good hygiene) when handling reproductive and/or fetal material from hunter-harvested elk and bison.\n\nPortions of this comment extracted from: http://fwp.mt.gov/fishAndWildlife/diseasesAndResearch/healthPrograms/brucellosis/.\n\nThis map provides and aerial view of the Tendoy Mountains https://mapcarta.com/23709406, and a HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Montana, United States, can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/228.\n- Mod.TG]\nSee Also\nBrucellosis - Austria (02): (OO) B. melitensis, OIE", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5936608", "date": "2018-03-26 18:29:26", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS - USA (02): (MONTANA) ELK\n*************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 21 Mar 2018, 12:05 PM EDT\nSource: ABC Fox Montana [edited]\nhttp://www.kfbb.com/story/37776738/latest-test-results-show-brucellosis-positive-elk\n\n\n[Montana] Fish, Wildlife, and Parks released their test results for Brucellosis in Elk and out of the more than 140 animals tested, 7 came back positive.\n\nOf the 100 elk sampled in the Tendoy Mountains [a mountain range in Beaverhead county Montana - Mod.TG], 1 was found to have Brucellosis. This is the first time an elk has tested positive for exposure in the Tendoys. A total of 30 elk in the Tendoys were outfitted with radio collars to learn more about movement patterns and understand how the disease may spread.\n\nIn the southeastern Madison Valley, 6 elk tested positive for exposure out of the 41 sampled there.\n\n\"The discovery of an exposed elk in the Tendoys emphasizes the importance of elk surveillance near the boundary of the DSA [designated surveillance area - Mod.TG]\" said Montana State Veterinarian Martin Zaluski. The goal of brucellosis surveillance operations is to evaluate the presence and understand the movement of Brucellosis in Montana's elk populations.\n\nBrucellosis is a bacterial disease that infects cattle, bison, and elk and can result in abortion or the birth of weak calves. The disease is primarily transmitted through contact with infected birth tissues and fluids.\n\nMore information about Brucellosis and the Targeted Elk Brucellosis Surveillance project can be found online at:\nhttp://fwp.mt.gov/fishAndWildlife/diseasesAndResearch/healthPrograms/brucellosis/.\n\n[Byline: Ricky Blackburn]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Brucellosis is a zoonotic disease, and in many places around the world, it still causes severe infections in humans. Brucellosis also causes decreased milk production, weight loss, abortion, and infertility in cattle. For these reasons, beginning in the mid-1950s, great efforts were made to eliminate the disease from all livestock within the United States. While these efforts were successful at eliminating transmission within cattle nation-wide, sporadic transmission from wildlife to cattle in and around the Greater Yellowstone Ecosystem has been on the increase. Brucellosis can result in serious financial burdens to cattle producers, potentially resulting in quarantine of a herd, increased testing and vaccination costs, and possible difficulty in trade with other states and countries.\n\nAlthough the disease can cause abortions in elk, measurable population effects on population size or trend due to brucellosis have not been documented. However, the potential for transmission to livestock results in decreased acceptance of elk on private property which, in many areas, constitutes a large proportion of elk winter range. Historically, rates of exposure in elk (measured by blood tests) have been very low (below 2 percent in the early 1990's) and limited in distribution. Recent research and surveillance efforts have indicated that the prevalence and geographical distribution of the disease in elk is likely increasing. Brucellosis now exists in elk populations outside of the Greater Yellowstone Area. Hunters and game processors should take precautions (gloves and good hygiene) when handling reproductive and/or fetal material from hunter-harvested elk and bison.\n\nPortions of this comment extracted from: http://fwp.mt.gov/fishAndWildlife/diseasesAndResearch/healthPrograms/brucellosis/.\n\nThis map provides and aerial view of the Tendoy Mountains https://mapcarta.com/23709406, and a HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Montana, United States, can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/228.\n- Mod.TG]\nSee Also\nBrucellosis - Mod.TG], 1 was found to have Brucellosis. This is the first time an elk has tested positive for exposure in the Tendoys. A total of 30 elk in the Tendoys were outfitted with radio collars to learn more about movement patterns and understand how the disease may spread.\n\nIn the southeastern Madison Valley, 6 elk tested positive for exposure out of the 41 sampled there.\n\n\"The discovery of an exposed elk in the Tendoys emphasizes the importance of elk surveillance near the boundary of the DSA [designated surveillance area - Mod.TG]\" said Montana State Veterinarian Martin Zaluski. The disease is primarily transmitted through contact with infected birth tissues and fluids.\n\nMore information about Brucellosis and the Targeted Elk Brucellosis Surveillance project can be found online at:\nhttp://fwp.mt.gov/fishAndWildlife/diseasesAndResearch/healthPrograms/brucellosis/.\n\n[Byline: Ricky Blackburn]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Brucellosis is a zoonotic disease, and in many places around the world, it still causes severe infections in humans. The disease is primarily transmitted through contact with infected birth tissues and fluids.\n\nMore information about Brucellosis and the Targeted Elk Brucellosis Surveillance project can be found online at:\nhttp://fwp.mt.gov/fishAndWildlife/diseasesAndResearch/healthPrograms/brucellosis/.\n\n[Byline: Ricky Blackburn]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Brucellosis is a zoonotic disease, and in many places around the world, it still causes severe infections in humans. Brucellosis also causes decreased milk production, weight loss, abortion, and infertility in cattle. For these reasons, beginning in the mid-1950s, great efforts were made to eliminate the disease from all livestock within the United States. While these efforts were successful at eliminating transmission within cattle nation-wide, sporadic transmission from wildlife to cattle in and around the Greater Yellowstone Ecosystem has been on the increase. Brucellosis can result in serious financial burdens to cattle producers, potentially resulting in quarantine of a herd, increased testing and vaccination costs, and possible difficulty in trade with other states and countries.\n\nAlthough the disease can cause abortions in elk, measurable population effects on population size or trend due to brucellosis have not been documented. However, the potential for transmission to livestock results in decreased acceptance of elk on private property which, in many areas, constitutes a large proportion of elk winter range. Historically, rates of exposure in elk (measured by blood tests) have been very low (below 2 percent in the early 1990's) and limited in distribution. Recent research and surveillance efforts have indicated that the prevalence and geographical distribution of the disease in elk is likely increasing. Brucellosis now exists in elk populations outside of the Greater Yellowstone Area. Hunters and game processors should take precautions (gloves and good hygiene) when handling reproductive and/or fetal material from hunter-harvested elk and bison.\n\nPortions of this comment extracted from: http://fwp.mt.gov/fishAndWildlife/diseasesAndResearch/healthPrograms/brucellosis/.\n\nThis map provides and aerial view of the Tendoy Mountains https://mapcarta.com/23709406, and a HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Montana, United States, can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/228.\n- Mod.TG]\nSee Also\nBrucellosis - Netherlands: B. suis, epidem., raw pet food ex Argentina", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5813060", "date": "2018-03-26 18:29:26", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS - USA (02): (MONTANA) ELK\n*************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 21 Mar 2018, 12:05 PM EDT\nSource: ABC Fox Montana [edited]\nhttp://www.kfbb.com/story/37776738/latest-test-results-show-brucellosis-positive-elk\n\n\n[Montana] Fish, Wildlife, and Parks released their test results for Brucellosis in Elk and out of the more than 140 animals tested, 7 came back positive.\n\nOf the 100 elk sampled in the Tendoy Mountains [a mountain range in Beaverhead county Montana - Mod.TG], 1 was found to have Brucellosis. This is the first time an elk has tested positive for exposure in the Tendoys. A total of 30 elk in the Tendoys were outfitted with radio collars to learn more about movement patterns and understand how the disease may spread.\n\nIn the southeastern Madison Valley, 6 elk tested positive for exposure out of the 41 sampled there.\n\n\"The discovery of an exposed elk in the Tendoys emphasizes the importance of elk surveillance near the boundary of the DSA [designated surveillance area - Mod.TG]\" said Montana State Veterinarian Martin Zaluski. The goal of brucellosis surveillance operations is to evaluate the presence and understand the movement of Brucellosis in Montana's elk populations.\n\nBrucellosis is a bacterial disease that infects cattle, bison, and elk and can result in abortion or the birth of weak calves. The disease is primarily transmitted through contact with infected birth tissues and fluids.\n\nMore information about Brucellosis and the Targeted Elk Brucellosis Surveillance project can be found online at:\nhttp://fwp.mt.gov/fishAndWildlife/diseasesAndResearch/healthPrograms/brucellosis/.\n\n[Byline: Ricky Blackburn]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Brucellosis is a zoonotic disease, and in many places around the world, it still causes severe infections in humans. Brucellosis also causes decreased milk production, weight loss, abortion, and infertility in cattle. For these reasons, beginning in the mid-1950s, great efforts were made to eliminate the disease from all livestock within the United States. While these efforts were successful at eliminating transmission within cattle nation-wide, sporadic transmission from wildlife to cattle in and around the Greater Yellowstone Ecosystem has been on the increase. Brucellosis can result in serious financial burdens to cattle producers, potentially resulting in quarantine of a herd, increased testing and vaccination costs, and possible difficulty in trade with other states and countries.\n\nAlthough the disease can cause abortions in elk, measurable population effects on population size or trend due to brucellosis have not been documented. However, the potential for transmission to livestock results in decreased acceptance of elk on private property which, in many areas, constitutes a large proportion of elk winter range. Historically, rates of exposure in elk (measured by blood tests) have been very low (below 2 percent in the early 1990's) and limited in distribution. Recent research and surveillance efforts have indicated that the prevalence and geographical distribution of the disease in elk is likely increasing. Brucellosis now exists in elk populations outside of the Greater Yellowstone Area. Hunters and game processors should take precautions (gloves and good hygiene) when handling reproductive and/or fetal material from hunter-harvested elk and bison.\n\nPortions of this comment extracted from: http://fwp.mt.gov/fishAndWildlife/diseasesAndResearch/healthPrograms/brucellosis/.\n\nThis map provides and aerial view of the Tendoy Mountains https://mapcarta.com/23709406, and a HealthMap/ProMED-mail map of Montana, United States, can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/228.\n- Mod.TG]\nSee Also\nBrucellosis - USA: (TX) unpasteurized milk, B. abortus vaccine strain, 2017, CDC", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5674369", "date": "2018-01-04 16:58:08", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS - PARAGUAY: (ASUNCION) VETERINARY SCHOOL, FATAL\n***********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 4 Jan 2018 09:58 UTC\nSource: Merco Press [edited]\nhttp://en.mercopress.com/2018/01/04/brucellosis-outbreak-at-paraguay-vet-school-triggers-alarm-bells-for-the-industry\n\n\nAn outbreak of brucellosis at the Veterinary School of the Asunci\u00f3n University in Paraguay, FCV-UNA [San Lorenzo, Gran Asunci\u00f3n], has cost the academic center its international certification, and has become a shameful experience for a country which is among the top world beef exporters. The National Agency for High Education Assessment and Credits reported in a release that the Mercosur certification, ARCU-Sur, of the Asunci\u00f3n University Veterinary School had been suspended. The sanction stands until the school has implemented the effective and efficient biosecurity mechanisms of the practical components in grass root work, and academic tests.\n\nThe release adds that once the academic year begins next February 2018, the agency will visit the Veterinary School and reconsider the certification. The process will count with the coordination of the Asunci\u00f3n University, which has been supportive all along.\n\nThis is the 1st time such a drastic action has been implemented in one of Mercosur member and associate countries, Argentina, Brazil, Paraguay, Uruguay, Colombia, Peru, Chile, Ecuador, and Bolivia, particularly since the 1st outbreak was first reported last October 2017 when a student and a professor reported positive to brucellosis. This followed what is believed to be contagion from a goat flock at the Veterinary School which subsequently were diagnosed positive.\n\nIt is believed that one of the persons who developed brucellosis died in late December 2017. This triggered the immediate removal of the Veterinary School dean Azucena Cabrera.\n\nFor Mercosur, and particularly Paraguay, an outbreak of brucellosis is extremely serious since the region is the world's main producer of beef and Paraguay is among the top 10 exporters, with an annual overseas sales of USD 1.7 billion dollars.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[It remains unclear how many of the diagnosed and suspected cases of brucellosis had symptoms consistent with clinical brucellosis and how many were asymptomatic but had positive brucellosis serology in this outbreak of _Brucella melitensis_ infection. The last ProMED-mail post noted 15 documented cases under treatment but did not note the fatality. It is not known how the fatal case was exposed to the goats and if the case was a student, a faculty member, or otherwise.\n\nThe symptoms and signs of brucellosis may develop from days to months after the initial exposure to the organism. While some individuals may develop mild symptoms, others may go on to develop long-term chronic symptoms. The signs and symptoms of brucellosis are extensive and they can be similar to many other febrile illnesses, so recognition of potential exposure -- from ingestion of unpasteurized milk or cheese, employment as a veterinarian or veterinary student, in a slaughter house or meat processing plant, or working in a microbiology lab -- is vital.\n\nMaps of Paraguay can be seen at http://www.nationsonline.org/maps/paraguay-administrative-map.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/4191. The City of Asunci\u00f3n, Ciudad de Asunci\u00f3n (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Asunci\u00f3n), is an autonomous capital district, not a part of any department. The metropolitan area, called Gran Asunci\u00f3n, includes the cities of San Lorenzo, Fernando de la Mora, Lambar\u00e9, Luque, Mariano Roque Alonso, \u00d1emby, San Antonio, Limpio, Capiat\u00e1, and Villa Elisa, which are part of the Central Department. The Asunci\u00f3n metropolitan area has around 2 million inhabitants. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nBrucellosis - Paraguay (04): (AS) veterinary school 20171120.5454707\nBrucellosis - Paraguay (03): (AS) veterinary school 20171031.5415585\nBrucellosis - Paraguay (02): (AS) veterinary school, RFI 20171023.5397373\nBrucellosis - Paraguay: (AS) veterinary students, RFI 20171022.5395742\n2015\n---\nBrucellosis - Uruguay: (CA) swine, OIE 20151105.3768335\n2014\n---\nBrucellosis - Brazil: (PR) slaughterhouse workers 20140219.2287605\n2013\n---\nBrucellosis, human, bovine - Panama: (PN) 20131214.2116241\nBrucellosis, bovine - Panama: (PN) OIE 20131014.2001918\nBrucellosis, human, abortus - USA: (NY) ex Ecuador, cheese 20130111.1492801\n.................................................sb/ll/mj/sh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "brucellosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2018-01-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2013-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "\u00d1emby", "country": "Paraguay"}, {"location": "Ecuador", "country": "Ecuador"}, {"location": "Bolivia", "country": "Bolivia"}, {"location": "the City of Asunci\u00f3n", "country": "Mexico"}, {"location": "Uruguay", "country": "Uruguay"}, {"location": "Limpio", "country": "Paraguay"}, {"location": "Argentina", "country": "Argentina"}, {"location": "San Antonio", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "San Lorenzo", "country": "Paraguay"}, {"location": "Brazil", "country": "Brazil"}, {"location": "Colombia", "country": "Colombia"}, {"location": "Peru", "country": "Peru"}, {"location": "Mercosur", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Chile", "country": "Chile"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5634787", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Brucellosis - Oman: (JA) caprine, ovine, bovine", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5634787", "date": "2018-01-04 16:58:08", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS - PARAGUAY: (ASUNCION) VETERINARY SCHOOL, FATAL\n***********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 4 Jan 2018 09:58 UTC\nSource: Merco Press [edited]\nhttp://en.mercopress.com/2018/01/04/brucellosis-outbreak-at-paraguay-vet-school-triggers-alarm-bells-for-the-industry\n\n\nAn outbreak of brucellosis at the Veterinary School of the Asunci\u00f3n University in Paraguay, FCV-UNA [San Lorenzo, Gran Asunci\u00f3n], has cost the academic center its international certification, and has become a shameful experience for a country which is among the top world beef exporters. The National Agency for High Education Assessment and Credits reported in a release that the Mercosur certification, ARCU-Sur, of the Asunci\u00f3n University Veterinary School had been suspended. The sanction stands until the school has implemented the effective and efficient biosecurity mechanisms of the practical components in grass root work, and academic tests.\n\nThe release adds that once the academic year begins next February 2018, the agency will visit the Veterinary School and reconsider the certification. The process will count with the coordination of the Asunci\u00f3n University, which has been supportive all along.\n\nThis is the 1st time such a drastic action has been implemented in one of Mercosur member and associate countries, Argentina, Brazil, Paraguay, Uruguay, Colombia, Peru, Chile, Ecuador, and Bolivia, particularly since the 1st outbreak was first reported last October 2017 when a student and a professor reported positive to brucellosis. This followed what is believed to be contagion from a goat flock at the Veterinary School which subsequently were diagnosed positive.\n\nIt is believed that one of the persons who developed brucellosis died in late December 2017. This triggered the immediate removal of the Veterinary School dean Azucena Cabrera.\n\nFor Mercosur, and particularly Paraguay, an outbreak of brucellosis is extremely serious since the region is the world's main producer of beef and Paraguay is among the top 10 exporters, with an annual overseas sales of USD 1.7 billion dollars.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[It remains unclear how many of the diagnosed and suspected cases of brucellosis had symptoms consistent with clinical brucellosis and how many were asymptomatic but had positive brucellosis serology in this outbreak of _Brucella melitensis_ infection. The last ProMED-mail post noted 15 documented cases under treatment but did not note the fatality. It is not known how the fatal case was exposed to the goats and if the case was a student, a faculty member, or otherwise.\n\nThe symptoms and signs of brucellosis may develop from days to months after the initial exposure to the organism. While some individuals may develop mild symptoms, others may go on to develop long-term chronic symptoms. The signs and symptoms of brucellosis are extensive and they can be similar to many other febrile illnesses, so recognition of potential exposure -- from ingestion of unpasteurized milk or cheese, employment as a veterinarian or veterinary student, in a slaughter house or meat processing plant, or working in a microbiology lab -- is vital.\n\nMaps of Paraguay can be seen at http://www.nationsonline.org/maps/paraguay-administrative-map.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/4191. The City of Asunci\u00f3n, Ciudad de Asunci\u00f3n (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Asunci\u00f3n), is an autonomous capital district, not a part of any department. The metropolitan area, called Gran Asunci\u00f3n, includes the cities of San Lorenzo, Fernando de la Mora, Lambar\u00e9, Luque, Mariano Roque Alonso, \u00d1emby, San Antonio, Limpio, Capiat\u00e1, and Villa Elisa, which are part of the Central Department. The Asunci\u00f3n metropolitan area has around 2 million inhabitants. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nBrucellosis - Paraguay (04): (AS) veterinary school 20171120.5454707\nBrucellosis - Paraguay (03): (AS) veterinary school 20171031.5415585\nBrucellosis - USA: (NY) ex Ecuador, cheese 20130111.1492801\n.................................................sb/ll/mj/sh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "brucellosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2018-01-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2013-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "\u00d1emby", "country": "Paraguay"}, {"location": "Ecuador", "country": "Ecuador"}, {"location": "Bolivia", "country": "Bolivia"}, {"location": "the City of Asunci\u00f3n", "country": "Mexico"}, {"location": "Uruguay", "country": "Uruguay"}, {"location": "Limpio", "country": "Paraguay"}, {"location": "Argentina", "country": "Argentina"}, {"location": "San Antonio", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "San Lorenzo", "country": "Paraguay"}, {"location": "Brazil", "country": "Brazil"}, {"location": "Colombia", "country": "Colombia"}, {"location": "Peru", "country": "Peru"}, {"location": "Mercosur", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Chile", "country": "Chile"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5626680", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Brucellosis - Nigeria: (BA) butchers, serosurvey", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5626680", "date": "2018-01-04 16:58:08", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS - PARAGUAY: (ASUNCION) VETERINARY SCHOOL, FATAL\n***********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 4 Jan 2018 09:58 UTC\nSource: Merco Press [edited]\nhttp://en.mercopress.com/2018/01/04/brucellosis-outbreak-at-paraguay-vet-school-triggers-alarm-bells-for-the-industry\n\n\nAn outbreak of brucellosis at the Veterinary School of the Asunci\u00f3n University in Paraguay, FCV-UNA [San Lorenzo, Gran Asunci\u00f3n], has cost the academic center its international certification, and has become a shameful experience for a country which is among the top world beef exporters. The National Agency for High Education Assessment and Credits reported in a release that the Mercosur certification, ARCU-Sur, of the Asunci\u00f3n University Veterinary School had been suspended. The sanction stands until the school has implemented the effective and efficient biosecurity mechanisms of the practical components in grass root work, and academic tests.\n\nThe release adds that once the academic year begins next February 2018, the agency will visit the Veterinary School and reconsider the certification. The process will count with the coordination of the Asunci\u00f3n University, which has been supportive all along.\n\nThis is the 1st time such a drastic action has been implemented in one of Mercosur member and associate countries, Argentina, Brazil, Paraguay, Uruguay, Colombia, Peru, Chile, Ecuador, and Bolivia, particularly since the 1st outbreak was first reported last October 2017 when a student and a professor reported positive to brucellosis. This followed what is believed to be contagion from a goat flock at the Veterinary School which subsequently were diagnosed positive.\n\nIt is believed that one of the persons who developed brucellosis died in late December 2017. This triggered the immediate removal of the Veterinary School dean Azucena Cabrera.\n\nFor Mercosur, and particularly Paraguay, an outbreak of brucellosis is extremely serious since the region is the world's main producer of beef and Paraguay is among the top 10 exporters, with an annual overseas sales of USD 1.7 billion dollars.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[It remains unclear how many of the diagnosed and suspected cases of brucellosis had symptoms consistent with clinical brucellosis and how many were asymptomatic but had positive brucellosis serology in this outbreak of _Brucella melitensis_ infection. The last ProMED-mail post noted 15 documented cases under treatment but did not note the fatality. It is not known how the fatal case was exposed to the goats and if the case was a student, a faculty member, or otherwise.\n\nThe symptoms and signs of brucellosis may develop from days to months after the initial exposure to the organism. While some individuals may develop mild symptoms, others may go on to develop long-term chronic symptoms. The signs and symptoms of brucellosis are extensive and they can be similar to many other febrile illnesses, so recognition of potential exposure -- from ingestion of unpasteurized milk or cheese, employment as a veterinarian or veterinary student, in a slaughter house or meat processing plant, or working in a microbiology lab -- is vital.\n\nMaps of Paraguay can be seen at http://www.nationsonline.org/maps/paraguay-administrative-map.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/4191. The City of Asunci\u00f3n, Ciudad de Asunci\u00f3n (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Asunci\u00f3n), is an autonomous capital district, not a part of any department. The metropolitan area, called Gran Asunci\u00f3n, includes the cities of San Lorenzo, Fernando de la Mora, Lambar\u00e9, Luque, Mariano Roque Alonso, \u00d1emby, San Antonio, Limpio, Capiat\u00e1, and Villa Elisa, which are part of the Central Department. The Asunci\u00f3n metropolitan area has around 2 million inhabitants. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nBrucellosis - Paraguay (04): (AS) veterinary school 20171120.5454707\nBrucellosis - Paraguay (03): (AS) veterinary school 20171031.5415585\nBrucellosis - Brazil: (PR) slaughterhouse workers 20140219.2287605\n2013\n---\nBrucellosis, human, bovine - Panama: (PN) 20131214.2116241\nBrucellosis, bovine - Panama: (PN) OIE 20131014.2001918\nBrucellosis, human, abortus - The National Agency for High Education Assessment and Credits reported in a release that the Mercosur certification, ARCU-Sur, of the Asunci\u00f3n University Veterinary School had been suspended. The sanction stands until the school has implemented the effective and efficient biosecurity mechanisms of the practical components in grass root work, and academic tests.\n\nThe release adds that once the academic year begins next February 2018, the agency will visit the Veterinary School and reconsider the certification. The process will count with the coordination of the Asunci\u00f3n University, which has been supportive all along.\n\nThis is the 1st time such a drastic action has been implemented in one of Mercosur member and associate countries, Argentina, Brazil, Paraguay, Uruguay, Colombia, Peru, Chile, Ecuador, and Bolivia, particularly since the 1st outbreak was first reported last October 2017 when a student and a professor reported positive to brucellosis. This followed what is believed to be contagion from a goat flock at the Veterinary School which subsequently were diagnosed positive.\n\nIt is believed that one of the persons who developed brucellosis died in late December 2017. This triggered the immediate removal of the Veterinary School dean Azucena Cabrera.\n\nFor Mercosur, and particularly Paraguay, an outbreak of brucellosis is extremely serious since the region is the world's main producer of beef and Paraguay is among the top 10 exporters, with an annual overseas sales of USD 1.7 billion dollars.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[It remains unclear how many of the diagnosed and suspected cases of brucellosis had symptoms consistent with clinical brucellosis and how many were asymptomatic but had positive brucellosis serology in this outbreak of _Brucella melitensis_ infection. The last ProMED-mail post noted 15 documented cases under treatment but did not note the fatality. It is not known how the fatal case was exposed to the goats and if the case was a student, a faculty member, or otherwise.\n\nThe symptoms and signs of brucellosis may develop from days to months after the initial exposure to the organism. While some individuals may develop mild symptoms, others may go on to develop long-term chronic symptoms. The signs and symptoms of brucellosis are extensive and they can be similar to many other febrile illnesses, so recognition of potential exposure -- from ingestion of unpasteurized milk or cheese, employment as a veterinarian or veterinary student, in a slaughter house or meat processing plant, or working in a microbiology lab -- is vital.\n\nMaps of Paraguay can be seen at http://www.nationsonline.org/maps/paraguay-administrative-map.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/4191. The National Agency for High Education Assessment and Credits reported in a release that the Mercosur certification, ARCU-Sur, of the Asunci\u00f3n University Veterinary School had been suspended. The sanction stands until the school has implemented the effective and efficient biosecurity mechanisms of the practical components in grass root work, and academic tests.\n\nThe release adds that once the academic year begins next February 2018, the agency will visit the Veterinary School and reconsider the certification. The process will count with the coordination of the Asunci\u00f3n University, which has been supportive all along.\n\nThis is the 1st time such a drastic action has been implemented in one of Mercosur member and associate countries, Argentina, Brazil, Paraguay, Uruguay, Colombia, Peru, Chile, Ecuador, and Bolivia, particularly since the 1st outbreak was first reported last October 2017 when a student and a professor reported positive to brucellosis. This followed what is believed to be contagion from a goat flock at the Veterinary School which subsequently were diagnosed positive.\n\nIt is believed that one of the persons who developed brucellosis died in late December 2017. This triggered the immediate removal of the Veterinary School dean Azucena Cabrera.\n\nFor Mercosur, and particularly Paraguay, an outbreak of brucellosis is extremely serious since the region is the world's main producer of beef and Paraguay is among the top 10 exporters, with an annual overseas sales of USD 1.7 billion dollars.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[It remains unclear how many of the diagnosed and suspected cases of brucellosis had symptoms consistent with clinical brucellosis and how many were asymptomatic but had positive brucellosis serology in this outbreak of _Brucella melitensis_ infection. The last ProMED-mail post noted 15 documented cases under treatment but did not note the fatality. It is not known how the fatal case was exposed to the goats and if the case was a student, a faculty member, or otherwise.\n\nThe symptoms and signs of brucellosis may develop from days to months after the initial exposure to the organism. While some individuals may develop mild symptoms, others may go on to develop long-term chronic symptoms. The signs and symptoms of brucellosis are extensive and they can be similar to many other febrile illnesses, so recognition of potential exposure -- from ingestion of unpasteurized milk or cheese, employment as a veterinarian or veterinary student, in a slaughter house or meat processing plant, or working in a microbiology lab -- is vital.\n\nMaps of Paraguay can be seen at http://www.nationsonline.org/maps/paraguay-administrative-map.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/4191. Israel (02): melitensis, bovine", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5508281", "date": "2018-01-04 16:58:08", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS - PARAGUAY: (ASUNCION) VETERINARY SCHOOL, FATAL\n***********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 4 Jan 2018 09:58 UTC\nSource: Merco Press [edited]\nhttp://en.mercopress.com/2018/01/04/brucellosis-outbreak-at-paraguay-vet-school-triggers-alarm-bells-for-the-industry\n\n\nAn outbreak of brucellosis at the Veterinary School of the Asunci\u00f3n University in Paraguay, FCV-UNA [San Lorenzo, Gran Asunci\u00f3n], has cost the academic center its international certification, and has become a shameful experience for a country which is among the top world beef exporters. The National Agency for High Education Assessment and Credits reported in a release that the Mercosur certification, ARCU-Sur, of the Asunci\u00f3n University Veterinary School had been suspended. The sanction stands until the school has implemented the effective and efficient biosecurity mechanisms of the practical components in grass root work, and academic tests.\n\nThe release adds that once the academic year begins next February 2018, the agency will visit the Veterinary School and reconsider the certification. The process will count with the coordination of the Asunci\u00f3n University, which has been supportive all along.\n\nThis is the 1st time such a drastic action has been implemented in one of Mercosur member and associate countries, Argentina, Brazil, Paraguay, Uruguay, Colombia, Peru, Chile, Ecuador, and Bolivia, particularly since the 1st outbreak was first reported last October 2017 when a student and a professor reported positive to brucellosis. This followed what is believed to be contagion from a goat flock at the Veterinary School which subsequently were diagnosed positive.\n\nIt is believed that one of the persons who developed brucellosis died in late December 2017. This triggered the immediate removal of the Veterinary School dean Azucena Cabrera.\n\nFor Mercosur, and particularly Paraguay, an outbreak of brucellosis is extremely serious since the region is the world's main producer of beef and Paraguay is among the top 10 exporters, with an annual overseas sales of USD 1.7 billion dollars.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[It remains unclear how many of the diagnosed and suspected cases of brucellosis had symptoms consistent with clinical brucellosis and how many were asymptomatic but had positive brucellosis serology in this outbreak of _Brucella melitensis_ infection. The last ProMED-mail post noted 15 documented cases under treatment but did not note the fatality. It is not known how the fatal case was exposed to the goats and if the case was a student, a faculty member, or otherwise.\n\nThe symptoms and signs of brucellosis may develop from days to months after the initial exposure to the organism. While some individuals may develop mild symptoms, others may go on to develop long-term chronic symptoms. The signs and symptoms of brucellosis are extensive and they can be similar to many other febrile illnesses, so recognition of potential exposure -- from ingestion of unpasteurized milk or cheese, employment as a veterinarian or veterinary student, in a slaughter house or meat processing plant, or working in a microbiology lab -- is vital.\n\nMaps of Paraguay can be seen at http://www.nationsonline.org/maps/paraguay-administrative-map.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/4191. Iraq: (WA) RFI, brucellosis", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5470578", "date": "2018-01-04 16:58:08", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS - PARAGUAY: (ASUNCION) VETERINARY SCHOOL, FATAL\n***********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 4 Jan 2018 09:58 UTC\nSource: Merco Press [edited]\nhttp://en.mercopress.com/2018/01/04/brucellosis-outbreak-at-paraguay-vet-school-triggers-alarm-bells-for-the-industry\n\n\nAn outbreak of brucellosis at the Veterinary School of the Asunci\u00f3n University in Paraguay, FCV-UNA [San Lorenzo, Gran Asunci\u00f3n], has cost the academic center its international certification, and has become a shameful experience for a country which is among the top world beef exporters. The National Agency for High Education Assessment and Credits reported in a release that the Mercosur certification, ARCU-Sur, of the Asunci\u00f3n University Veterinary School had been suspended. The sanction stands until the school has implemented the effective and efficient biosecurity mechanisms of the practical components in grass root work, and academic tests.\n\nThe release adds that once the academic year begins next February 2018, the agency will visit the Veterinary School and reconsider the certification. The process will count with the coordination of the Asunci\u00f3n University, which has been supportive all along.\n\nThis is the 1st time such a drastic action has been implemented in one of Mercosur member and associate countries, Argentina, Brazil, Paraguay, Uruguay, Colombia, Peru, Chile, Ecuador, and Bolivia, particularly since the 1st outbreak was first reported last October 2017 when a student and a professor reported positive to brucellosis. This followed what is believed to be contagion from a goat flock at the Veterinary School which subsequently were diagnosed positive.\n\nIt is believed that one of the persons who developed brucellosis died in late December 2017. This triggered the immediate removal of the Veterinary School dean Azucena Cabrera.\n\nFor Mercosur, and particularly Paraguay, an outbreak of brucellosis is extremely serious since the region is the world's main producer of beef and Paraguay is among the top 10 exporters, with an annual overseas sales of USD 1.7 billion dollars.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[It remains unclear how many of the diagnosed and suspected cases of brucellosis had symptoms consistent with clinical brucellosis and how many were asymptomatic but had positive brucellosis serology in this outbreak of _Brucella melitensis_ infection. The last ProMED-mail post noted 15 documented cases under treatment but did not note the fatality. It is not known how the fatal case was exposed to the goats and if the case was a student, a faculty member, or otherwise.\n\nThe symptoms and signs of brucellosis may develop from days to months after the initial exposure to the organism. While some individuals may develop mild symptoms, others may go on to develop long-term chronic symptoms. The signs and symptoms of brucellosis are extensive and they can be similar to many other febrile illnesses, so recognition of potential exposure -- from ingestion of unpasteurized milk or cheese, employment as a veterinarian or veterinary student, in a slaughter house or meat processing plant, or working in a microbiology lab -- is vital.\n\nMaps of Paraguay can be seen at http://www.nationsonline.org/maps/paraguay-administrative-map.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/4191. The City of Asunci\u00f3n, Ciudad de Asunci\u00f3n (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Asunci\u00f3n), is an autonomous capital district, not a part of any department. The metropolitan area, called Gran Asunci\u00f3n, includes the cities of San Lorenzo, Fernando de la Mora, Lambar\u00e9, Luque, Mariano Roque Alonso, \u00d1emby, San Antonio, Limpio, Capiat\u00e1, and Villa Elisa, which are part of the Central Department. The Asunci\u00f3n metropolitan area has around 2 million inhabitants. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nBrucellosis - Paraguay (04): (AS) veterinary school 20171120.5454707\nBrucellosis - Paraguay (03): (AS) veterinary school 20171031.5415585\nBrucellosis - USA (16): (NJ) raw milk, B. abortus vaccine strain, RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5458227", "date": "2018-01-04 16:58:08", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS - PARAGUAY: (ASUNCION) VETERINARY SCHOOL, FATAL\n***********************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 4 Jan 2018 09:58 UTC\nSource: Merco Press [edited]\nhttp://en.mercopress.com/2018/01/04/brucellosis-outbreak-at-paraguay-vet-school-triggers-alarm-bells-for-the-industry\n\n\nAn outbreak of brucellosis at the Veterinary School of the Asunci\u00f3n University in Paraguay, FCV-UNA [San Lorenzo, Gran Asunci\u00f3n], has cost the academic center its international certification, and has become a shameful experience for a country which is among the top world beef exporters. The National Agency for High Education Assessment and Credits reported in a release that the Mercosur certification, ARCU-Sur, of the Asunci\u00f3n University Veterinary School had been suspended. The sanction stands until the school has implemented the effective and efficient biosecurity mechanisms of the practical components in grass root work, and academic tests.\n\nThe release adds that once the academic year begins next February 2018, the agency will visit the Veterinary School and reconsider the certification. The process will count with the coordination of the Asunci\u00f3n University, which has been supportive all along.\n\nThis is the 1st time such a drastic action has been implemented in one of Mercosur member and associate countries, Argentina, Brazil, Paraguay, Uruguay, Colombia, Peru, Chile, Ecuador, and Bolivia, particularly since the 1st outbreak was first reported last October 2017 when a student and a professor reported positive to brucellosis. This followed what is believed to be contagion from a goat flock at the Veterinary School which subsequently were diagnosed positive.\n\nIt is believed that one of the persons who developed brucellosis died in late December 2017. This triggered the immediate removal of the Veterinary School dean Azucena Cabrera.\n\nFor Mercosur, and particularly Paraguay, an outbreak of brucellosis is extremely serious since the region is the world's main producer of beef and Paraguay is among the top 10 exporters, with an annual overseas sales of USD 1.7 billion dollars.\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[It remains unclear how many of the diagnosed and suspected cases of brucellosis had symptoms consistent with clinical brucellosis and how many were asymptomatic but had positive brucellosis serology in this outbreak of _Brucella melitensis_ infection. The last ProMED-mail post noted 15 documented cases under treatment but did not note the fatality. It is not known how the fatal case was exposed to the goats and if the case was a student, a faculty member, or otherwise.\n\nThe symptoms and signs of brucellosis may develop from days to months after the initial exposure to the organism. While some individuals may develop mild symptoms, others may go on to develop long-term chronic symptoms. The signs and symptoms of brucellosis are extensive and they can be similar to many other febrile illnesses, so recognition of potential exposure -- from ingestion of unpasteurized milk or cheese, employment as a veterinarian or veterinary student, in a slaughter house or meat processing plant, or working in a microbiology lab -- is vital.\n\nMaps of Paraguay can be seen at http://www.nationsonline.org/maps/paraguay-administrative-map.jpg and http://healthmap.org/promed/p/4191. The City of Asunci\u00f3n, Ciudad de Asunci\u00f3n (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Asunci\u00f3n), is an autonomous capital district, not a part of any department. The metropolitan area, called Gran Asunci\u00f3n, includes the cities of San Lorenzo, Fernando de la Mora, Lambar\u00e9, Luque, Mariano Roque Alonso, \u00d1emby, San Antonio, Limpio, Capiat\u00e1, and Villa Elisa, which are part of the Central Department. The Asunci\u00f3n metropolitan area has around 2 million inhabitants. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nBrucellosis - Paraguay (04): (AS) veterinary school 20171120.5454707\nBrucellosis - Paraguay (03): (AS) veterinary school 20171031.5415585\nBrucellosis - Paraguay (02): (AS) veterinary school, RFI 20171023.5397373\nBrucellosis - Paraguay: (AS) veterinary students, RFI 20171022.5395742\n2015\n---\nBrucellosis - Uruguay: (CA) swine, OIE 20151105.3768335\n2014\n---\nBrucellosis - Brazil: (PR) slaughterhouse workers 20140219.2287605\n2013\n---\nBrucellosis, human, bovine - Panama: (PN) 20131214.2116241\nBrucellosis, bovine - Panama: (PN) OIE 20131014.2001918\nBrucellosis, human, abortus - USA: (NY) ex Ecuador, cheese 20130111.1492801\n.................................................sb/ll/mj/sh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "brucellosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2018-01-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2013-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "\u00d1emby", "country": "Paraguay"}, {"location": "Ecuador", "country": "Ecuador"}, {"location": "Bolivia", "country": "Bolivia"}, {"location": "the City of Asunci\u00f3n", "country": "Mexico"}, {"location": "Uruguay", "country": "Uruguay"}, {"location": "Limpio", "country": "Paraguay"}, {"location": "Argentina", "country": "Argentina"}, {"location": "San Antonio", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "San Lorenzo", "country": "Paraguay"}, {"location": "Brazil", "country": "Brazil"}, {"location": "Colombia", "country": "Colombia"}, {"location": "Peru", "country": "Peru"}, {"location": "Mercosur", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Chile", "country": "Chile"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5454707", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Brucellosis - Paraguay (04): (AS) veterinary school", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5454707", "date": "2017-09-24 17:43:05", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS - USA (13): (WYOMING) ELK EXPOSURE, B. OIE\n*****************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 4 Sep 2017\nSource: OIE, WAHID [edited]\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=24628\n\n\nBrucellosis (_Brucella melitensis_), Bulgaria\n-----------------------------------\nInformation received on [and dated] 4 Sep 2017 from Dr Damyan Iliev, Chief Veterinary Officer & Deputy Executive Director, Bulgarian Food Safety Agency, Ministry of Agriculture and Food, Sofia, Bulgaria\n\nSummary:\nReport type: Immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 8 Aug 2017\nDate of confirmation of the event: 8 Aug 2017\nReason for notification: Recurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 2 Nov 2016\nManifestation of disease: Sub-clinical infection\nCausal agent: _Brucella melitensis_\nNature of diagnosis: Laboratory (basic)\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country.\n\nNew outbreaks (4)\nOutbreak 1: Rechitsa, Sliven\nDate of start of the outbreak: 8 Aug 2017\nOutbreak status: Continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: Farm\nAffected animals:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered\nGoats / 105 / 3 / 0 / 3 / 0\nSheep / 125 / 0 / 0 / 0 / 0\n\nOutbreak 2: Gergevec, Sliven\nDate of start of the outbreak: 11 Aug 2017\nOutbreak status: Continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: Backyard\nAffected animals:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered\nSheep/ goats / 257 / 21 / 0 / 21 / 0\n\nOutbreak 3: Kochan, Blagoevgard\nDate of start of the outbreak: 18 Aug 2017\nOutbreak status: Continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: Backyard\nAffected animals:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered\nSheep / 205 / 3 / 0 / 3 / 0\n\nOutbreak 4: Kochan, Satovcha, Blagoevgard\nDate of start of the outbreak: 23 Aug 2017\nOutbreak status: Continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: Backyard\nAffected animals:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered\nSheep/ goats / 368 / 10 / 0 / 10 / 0\n\nSummary of outbreaks: Total outbreaks: 4\nTotal animals affected:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nGoats / 105 / 3 / 0 / 3 / 0\nSheep / 330 / 3 / 0 / 3 / 0\nSheep / goats / 625 / 31 / 0 / 31 / 0\nOutbreak statistics: [rates apparent, expressed as percentages]:\nSpecies / Apparent morbidity rate / Apparent mortality rate / Apparent case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nGoats / 2.86 / 0 / 0 / 2.86\nSheep / 0.91 / 0 / 0 / 0.91\nSheep / goats / 4.96 / 0 / 0 / 4.96\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction and/or slaughter\n\nEpidemiology:\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: Unknown or inconclusive\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: vaccination permitted (if a vaccine exists); no treatment of affected animals\n\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nFuture Reporting: The event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[\"Infection with Brucella in sheep and goats (excluding _B. ovis_ infection) is primarily caused by one of the 3 biovars of _B. melitensis_. Sporadic infections caused by _B. abortus_ or _B. suis_ have been observed in sheep and goats, but such cases are extremely rare. Infection with Brucella in sheep and goats is endemic in the Mediterranean region, but infection is widespread worldwide. North America (except Mexico) is believed to be free from the agent, as are northern and central Europe, southeast Asia, Australia and New Zealand.\n\nPathologically and epidemiologically, _B. melitensis_ infection in sheep and goats is very similar to _B. abortus_ infection in cattle. In most circumstances, the primary routes of transmission of Brucella are the placenta, fetal fluids and vaginal discharges expelled by infected ewes and goats when they abort or have full-term parturition. Shedding of Brucella is also common in udder secretions and semen, and Brucella may be isolated from various tissues, such as lymph nodes from the head, spleen and organs associated with reproduction (uterus, epididymides and testes), and from arthritic lesions\" http://www.oie.int/fileadmin/Home/eng/Health_standards/tahm/2.01.04_BRUCELLOSIS.pdf.\n\n\"_B. melitensis_ is highly pathogenic for humans; this organism is considered to be the most severe human pathogen in the genus. Occupational exposure is seen in laboratory workers, farmers, veterinarians and others who contact infected animals or tissues. Brucellosis is one of the most easily acquired laboratory infections. People who do not work with animals or tissues usually become infected by ingesting unpasteurized dairy products. The Rev-1 B. melitensis vaccine is also pathogenic for humans and must be handled with caution to avoid accidental injection or contamination of mucous membranes or abraded skin\" http://www.cfsph.iastate.edu/Factsheets/pdfs/brucellosis_melitensis.pdf. - Mod.CRD\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/81.]\nSee Also\nBrucellosis - Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[\"Infection with Brucella in sheep and goats (excluding _B. ovis_ infection) is primarily caused by one of the 3 biovars of _B. melitensis_. Sporadic infections caused by _B. abortus_ or _B. suis_ have been observed in sheep and goats, but such cases are extremely rare. Infection with Brucella in sheep and goats is endemic in the Mediterranean region, but infection is widespread worldwide. North America (except Mexico) is believed to be free from the agent, as are northern and central Europe, southeast Asia, Australia and New Zealand.\n\nPathologically and epidemiologically, _B. melitensis_ infection in sheep and goats is very similar to _B. abortus_ infection in cattle. In most circumstances, the primary routes of transmission of Brucella are the placenta, fetal fluids and vaginal discharges expelled by infected ewes and goats when they abort or have full-term parturition. Shedding of Brucella is also common in udder secretions and semen, and Brucella may be isolated from various tissues, such as lymph nodes from the head, spleen and organs associated with reproduction (uterus, epididymides and testes), and from arthritic lesions\" http://www.oie.int/fileadmin/Home/eng/Health_standards/tahm/2.01.04_BRUCELLOSIS.pdf.\n\n\"_B. melitensis_ is highly pathogenic for humans; this organism is considered to be the most severe human pathogen in the genus. Occupational exposure is seen in laboratory workers, farmers, veterinarians and others who contact infected animals or tissues. Brucellosis is one of the most easily acquired laboratory infections. People who do not work with animals or tissues usually become infected by ingesting unpasteurized dairy products. The Rev-1 B. melitensis vaccine is also pathogenic for humans and must be handled with caution to avoid accidental injection or contamination of mucous membranes or abraded skin\" "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Brucellosis - USA (10): (TX) unpasteurized milk, B. abortus vaccine strain", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5314638", "date": "2017-09-04 22:17:55", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS - BULGARIA (06): (SLIVEN, BLAGOEVGARD) MELITENSIS, LIVESTOCK, OIE\n*****************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 4 Sep 2017\nSource: OIE, WAHID [edited]\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=24628\n\n\nBrucellosis (_Brucella melitensis_), Bulgaria\n-----------------------------------\nInformation received on [and dated] 4 Sep 2017 from Dr Damyan Iliev, Chief Veterinary Officer & Deputy Executive Director, Bulgarian Food Safety Agency, Ministry of Agriculture and Food, Sofia, Bulgaria\n\nSummary:\nReport type: Immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 8 Aug 2017\nDate of confirmation of the event: 8 Aug 2017\nReason for notification: Recurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 2 Nov 2016\nManifestation of disease: Sub-clinical infection\nCausal agent: _Brucella melitensis_\nNature of diagnosis: Laboratory (basic)\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country.\n\nNew outbreaks (4)\nOutbreak 1: Rechitsa, Sliven\nDate of start of the outbreak: 8 Aug 2017\nOutbreak status: Continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: Farm\nAffected animals:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered\nGoats / 105 / 3 / 0 / 3 / 0\nSheep / 125 / 0 / 0 / 0 / 0\n\nOutbreak 2: Gergevec, Sliven\nDate of start of the outbreak: 11 Aug 2017\nOutbreak status: Continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: Backyard\nAffected animals:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered\nSheep/ goats / 257 / 21 / 0 / 21 / 0\n\nOutbreak 3: Kochan, Blagoevgard\nDate of start of the outbreak: 18 Aug 2017\nOutbreak status: Continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: Backyard\nAffected animals:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered\nSheep / 205 / 3 / 0 / 3 / 0\n\nOutbreak 4: Kochan, Satovcha, Blagoevgard\nDate of start of the outbreak: 23 Aug 2017\nOutbreak status: Continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: Backyard\nAffected animals:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered\nSheep/ goats / 368 / 10 / 0 / 10 / 0\n\nSummary of outbreaks: Total outbreaks: 4\nTotal animals affected:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nGoats / 105 / 3 / 0 / 3 / 0\nSheep / 330 / 3 / 0 / 3 / 0\nSheep / goats / 625 / 31 / 0 / 31 / 0\nOutbreak statistics: [rates apparent, expressed as percentages]:\nSpecies / Apparent morbidity rate / Apparent mortality rate / Apparent case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nGoats / 2.86 / 0 / 0 / 2.86\nSheep / 0.91 / 0 / 0 / 0.91\nSheep / goats / 4.96 / 0 / 0 / 4.96\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction and/or slaughter\n\nEpidemiology:\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: Unknown or inconclusive\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: vaccination permitted (if a vaccine exists); no treatment of affected animals\n\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nFuture Reporting: The event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[\"Infection with Brucella in sheep and goats (excluding _B. ovis_ infection) is primarily caused by one of the 3 biovars of _B. melitensis_. Sporadic infections caused by _B. abortus_ or _B. suis_ have been observed in sheep and goats, but such cases are extremely rare. Infection with Brucella in sheep and goats is endemic in the Mediterranean region, but infection is widespread worldwide. North America (except Mexico) is believed to be free from the agent, as are northern and central Europe, southeast Asia, Australia and New Zealand.\n\nPathologically and epidemiologically, _B. melitensis_ infection in sheep and goats is very similar to _B. abortus_ infection in cattle. In most circumstances, the primary routes of transmission of Brucella are the placenta, fetal fluids and vaginal discharges expelled by infected ewes and goats when they abort or have full-term parturition. Shedding of Brucella is also common in udder secretions and semen, and Brucella may be isolated from various tissues, such as lymph nodes from the head, spleen and organs associated with reproduction (uterus, epididymides and testes), and from arthritic lesions\" http://www.oie.int/fileadmin/Home/eng/Health_standards/tahm/2.01.04_BRUCELLOSIS.pdf.\n\n\"_B. melitensis_ is highly pathogenic for humans; this organism is considered to be the most severe human pathogen in the genus. Occupational exposure is seen in laboratory workers, farmers, veterinarians and others who contact infected animals or tissues. Brucellosis is one of the most easily acquired laboratory infections. People who do not work with animals or tissues usually become infected by ingesting unpasteurized dairy products. The Rev-1 B. melitensis vaccine is also pathogenic for humans and must be handled with caution to avoid accidental injection or contamination of mucous membranes or abraded skin\" http://www.cfsph.iastate.edu/Factsheets/pdfs/brucellosis_melitensis.pdf. - Mod.CRD\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/81.]\nSee Also\nBrucellosis - Infection with Brucella in sheep and goats is endemic in the Mediterranean region, but infection is widespread worldwide. North America (except Mexico) is believed to be free from the agent, as are northern and central Europe, southeast Asia, Australia and New Zealand.\n\nPathologically and epidemiologically, _B. melitensis_ infection in sheep and goats is very similar to _B. abortus_ infection in cattle. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[\"Infection with Brucella in sheep and goats (excluding _B. ovis_ infection) is primarily caused by one of the 3 biovars of _B. melitensis_. Sporadic infections caused by _B. abortus_ or _B. suis_ have been observed in sheep and goats, but such cases are extremely rare. Infection with Brucella in sheep and goats is endemic in the Mediterranean region, but infection is widespread worldwide. North America (except Mexico) is believed to be free from the agent, as are northern and central Europe, southeast Asia, Australia and New Zealand.\n\nPathologically and epidemiologically, _B. melitensis_ infection in sheep and goats is very similar to _B. abortus_ infection in cattle. In most circumstances, the primary routes of transmission of Brucella are the placenta, fetal fluids and vaginal discharges expelled by infected ewes and goats when they abort or have full-term parturition. Shedding of Brucella is also common in udder secretions and semen, and Brucella may be isolated from various tissues, such as lymph nodes from the head, spleen and organs associated with reproduction (uterus, epididymides and testes), and from arthritic lesions\" http://www.oie.int/fileadmin/Home/eng/Health_standards/tahm/2.01.04_BRUCELLOSIS.pdf.\n\n\"_B. melitensis_ is highly pathogenic for humans; this organism is considered to be the most severe human pathogen in the genus. Occupational exposure is seen in laboratory workers, farmers, veterinarians and others who contact infected animals or tissues. Brucellosis is one of the most easily acquired laboratory infections. People who do not work with animals or tissues usually become infected by ingesting unpasteurized dairy products. The Rev-1 B. melitensis vaccine is also pathogenic for humans and must be handled with caution to avoid accidental injection or contamination of mucous membranes or abraded skin\" http://www.cfsph.iastate.edu/Factsheets/pdfs/brucellosis_melitensis.pdf. - Mod.CRD\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/81.]\nSee Also\nBrucellosis -
