Bulgaria\n-----------------------------------\nInformation received on [and dated] 4 Sep 2017 from Dr Damyan Iliev, Chief Veterinary Officer & Deputy Executive Director, Bulgarian Food Safety Agency, Ministry of Agriculture and Food, Sofia, Bulgaria\n\nSummary:\nReport type: Immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 8 Aug 2017\nDate of confirmation of the event: 8 Aug 2017\nReason for notification: Recurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 2 Nov 2016\nManifestation of disease: Sub-clinical infection\nCausal agent: _Brucella melitensis_\nNature of diagnosis: Laboratory (basic)\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country.\n\nNew outbreaks (4)\nOutbreak 1: Rechitsa, Sliven\nDate of start of the outbreak: 8 Aug 2017\nOutbreak status: Continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: Farm\nAffected animals:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered\nGoats / 105 / 3 / 0 / 3 / 0\nSheep / 125 / 0 / 0 / 0 / 0\n\nOutbreak 2: Gergevec, Sliven\nDate of start of the outbreak: 11 Aug 2017\nOutbreak status: Continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: Backyard\nAffected animals:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered\nSheep/ goats / 257 / 21 / 0 / 21 / 0\n\nOutbreak 3: Kochan, Blagoevgard\nDate of start of the outbreak: 18 Aug 2017\nOutbreak status: Continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: Backyard\nAffected animals:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Killed and disposed of / Slaughtered\nSheep / 205 / 3 / 0 / 3 / 0\n\nOutbreak 4: Kochan, Satovcha, Blagoevgard\nDate of start of the outbreak: 23 Aug 2017\nOutbreak status: Continuing (or date resolved not / 31 / 0 / 31 / 0\nOutbreak statistics: [rates apparent, expressed as percentages]:\nSpecies / Apparent morbidity rate / Apparent mortality rate / Apparent case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nGoats / 2.86 / 0 / 0 / 2.86\nSheep / 0.91 / 0 / 0 / 0.91\nSheep / goats / 4.96 / 0 / 0 / 4.96\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction and/or slaughter\n\nEpidemiology:\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: Unknown or inconclusive\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: vaccination permitted (if a vaccine exists); no treatment of affected animals\n\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nFuture Reporting: The event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[\"Infection with Brucella in sheep and goats (excluding _B. ovis_ infection) is primarily caused by one of the 3 biovars of _B. melitensis_. Sporadic infections caused by _B. abortus_ or _B. suis_ have been observed in sheep and goats, but such cases are extremely rare. Infection with Brucella in sheep and goats is endemic in the Mediterranean region, but infection is widespread worldwide. North America (except Mexico) is believed to be free from the agent, as are northern and central Europe, southeast Asia, Australia and New Zealand.\n\nPathologically and epidemiologically, _B. melitensis_ infection in sheep and goats is very similar to _B. abortus_ infection in cattle. In most circumstances, the primary routes of transmission of Brucella are the placenta, fetal fluids and vaginal discharges expelled by infected ewes and goats when they abort or have full-term parturition. Shedding of Brucella is also common in udder secretions and semen, and Brucella may be isolated from various tissues, such as lymph nodes from the head, spleen and organs associated with reproduction (uterus, epididymides and testes), and from arthritic lesions\" http://www.oie.int/fileadmin/Home/eng/Health_standards/tahm/2.01.04_BRUCELLOSIS.pdf.\n\n\"_B. melitensis_ is highly pathogenic for humans; this organism is considered to be the most severe human pathogen in the genus. Occupational exposure is seen in laboratory workers, farmers, veterinarians and others who contact infected animals or tissues. Brucellosis is one of the most easily acquired laboratory infections. People who do not work with animals or tissues usually become infected by ingesting unpasteurized dairy products. The Rev-1 B. melitensis vaccine is also pathogenic for humans and must be handled with caution to avoid accidental injection or contamination of mucous membranes or abraded skin\" http://www.cfsph.iastate.edu/Factsheets/pdfs/brucellosis_melitensis.pdf. - Mod.CRD\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/81.]\nSee Also\nBrucellosis - Mexico (02): (ZA)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5269247", "date": "2017-07-16 11:49:18", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS - INDIA: (ANDHRA PRADESH) BOVINE\n********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: 13 Jul 2017\nSource: Times of India [edited]\nhttp://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/vijayawada/brucellosis-plagues-ttd-goshala-cows/articleshow/59567830.cms\n\n\nMore than 50 cows were infected with brucellosis at the Gosamrakshana Sala of the Tirumala Tirupati Devasthanams (TTD).\n\nAnimals infected by the pathogenic bacteria have been segregated to prevent the spread of the disease. A separate shed has been built for these animals 30 km away from the temple town of Tirupati. There are nearly 3100 cows and bulls at the goshala.\n\nThe milk used in all TTD temples is supplied from the same dairy farm. Out of the 30 Indian breeds, nearly 10-12 are seen in the same farm.\n\nHumans dealing with infected animals are likely to be infected by brucellosis. They can also be infected if they consume non-pasteurised milk or products made from the milk of infected animals. It may cause fever, spondylitis, and muscular and joint pain in humans.\n\nDirector of the Gosamrakshana Sala K Harnatha Reddy said: \"It is very difficult to detect the disease; it is possible only when the animals are pregnant. As a result, the animal will suffer a miscarriage and lose their ability to reproduce.\"\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[To have built a barn or shed 30 km away for infected animals is a bit of expense. But as this is milk for the TTD temples, it is likely worth it.\n\nBovine brucellosis is usually caused by _Brucella abortus_, less frequently by _B. melitensis_ (which affects mainly goats and sheep), and occasionally by _B. suis_ (porcine brucellosis). Infection is widespread globally. Several countries in Northern and Central Europe, Canada, Japan, Australia and New Zealand are believed to be free from _B. abortus_.\n\nClinically, the disease is characterised in cattle by one or more of the following signs: abortion, retained placenta, orchitis (testicular inflammation), epididymitis (inflammation of the epididymis, a tube at the back of the testicle) and, rarely, arthritis, with excretion of the organisms in uterine discharges and in milk. Diagnosis depends on the isolation of _Brucella_ bacteria from abortion material, udder secretions, or from tissues removed post-mortem. Presumptive diagnosis can be made by assessing specific cell-mediated or serological responses to _Brucella_ antigens.\n\nThough both _B. abortus_ and _B. melitensis_ are known to be endemic in India (Ref), only _B. abortus_ is mentioned in India's annual reports to the OIE. The bacteria _B. melitensis_ and _B. suis_, both highly pathogenic for humans, are included in India's OIE report for 2015 in the list of diseases \"for which no information has been provided.\"\n\nAccording to India's most recent available (2014) annual statistical-epidemiological report to the OIE, a total of 113 cases of bovine brucellosis in cattle and one in a buffalo, in 7 new outbreaks, were recorded during that year. The final annual report for 2015 is not yet available. The actual data on the ground are, most likely, significantly higher, as apparent from a recent presentation by Prof Narinder Singh Sharma at the regional FAO/OIE/APHCA (Animal Production and Health Commission for Asia and the Pacific) workshop on Brucellosis Diagnosis and Control in Asia-Pacific Region, held in Chiang Mai, Thailand, 18-21 Mar 2014, where he presented the following data:\n\n- Slide 8: addresses _B. melitensis_ serological study in animals in Tamil Nadu State, revealing incidence of 13.85, 9.96 and 20.35 percent positive animals (3 serological tests applied).\n\n- Slide 15: presents the results of a serosurvey in humans, demonstrating incidence of 11 percent among (118) veterinarians, 25.3 percent among (87) veterinary paraclinical staff and 16.1 percent among (62) dairy farmers.\n\nData available at: http://www.rr-asia.oie.int/fileadmin/Regional_Representation/Programme/Emerg/2014_Brucellosis_Chiang_Mai/05.India.pdf.\n\nReference:\nMantur B G and Amarnath S K 2008. Brucellosis in India -- a review; J. Biosci. 33 539-547. http://www.ias.ac.in/article/fulltext/jbsc/033/04/0539-0547\n\nPeople may contract this bacterium in a number of ways that may result in disease. The bacteria may be transmitted through ingestion, usually of contaminated products such as milk, or cheese, or other milk related products. It may also be contracted through inhalation or an open wound for those who work with the animals. Blood, urine and tissues of the infected animal(s) have high concentrations of the bacterium. The placenta from an infected animal is particularly highly concentrated with the causative _Brucella_ agent. Veterinarians or others who are assisting in difficult birthings of an infected animal are particularly at risk.\n\nSymptoms of brucellosis in humans may seem like the flu and may include: an undulating fever (one that comes and goes), headaches, joint pain, lethargy and a listless feeling, chills, loss of appetite, weight loss, back pain.\n\nTell your physician you have been around brucellosis-infected animals. Brucellosis may be diagnosed by blood tests, a culture of the urine and/or blood marrow. Cerebral spinal fluid may be cultured, but likely one of the others will be positive.\n\nIf you test positive for this disease, it is treatable with several antibiotics or combinations of antibiotics. Generally, it is a 6-week course of antibiotics. - Mod.TG\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/297.]\nSee Also\n2016\n----\nBrucellosis, bovine - India: (KA) 20160905.4466872\n2013\n----\nLeptospirosis, brucellosis - India: (UP) zoo employees 20131116.2058788\nBrucellosis, bovine - India: (PB) RFI 20131101.2032822\n2000\n----\nBrucellosis - India (Calcutta) (02) 20000826.1426\nBrucellosis - India (Calcutta) 20000823.1407\n.................................................sb/tg/mpp/msp/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "brucellosis", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2017-03-15 00:00:00", "2015-03-15 00:00:00", "2014-03-15 00:00:00", "2015-03-15 00:00:00", "2014-03-15 00:00:00", "2016-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Australia", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "Japan", "country": "Japan"}, {"location": "Tamil Nadu State", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Tirupati", "country": "India"}, {"location": "India", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Thailand", "country": "Thailand"}, {"location": "New Zealand", "country": "New Zealand"}, {"location": "Chiang Mai", "country": "Thailand"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5256690", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Brucellosis - Algeria: (EO)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5256690", "date": "2017-07-16 11:49:18", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS - INDIA: (ANDHRA PRADESH) BOVINE\n********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: 13 Jul 2017\nSource: Times of India [edited]\nhttp://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/vijayawada/brucellosis-plagues-ttd-goshala-cows/articleshow/59567830.cms\n\n\nMore than 50 cows were infected with brucellosis at the Gosamrakshana Sala of the Tirumala Tirupati Devasthanams (TTD).\n\nAnimals infected by the pathogenic bacteria have been segregated to prevent the spread of the disease. A separate shed has been built for these animals 30 km away from the temple town of Tirupati. There are nearly 3100 cows and bulls at the goshala.\n\nThe milk used in all TTD temples is supplied from the same dairy farm. Out of the 30 Indian breeds, nearly 10-12 are seen in the same farm.\n\nHumans dealing with infected animals are likely to be infected by brucellosis. They can also be infected if they consume non-pasteurised milk or products made from the milk of infected animals. It may cause fever, spondylitis, and muscular and joint pain in humans.\n\nDirector of the Gosamrakshana Sala K Harnatha Reddy said: \"It is very difficult to detect the disease; it is possible only when the animals are pregnant. As a result, the animal will suffer a miscarriage and lose their ability to reproduce.\"\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[To have built a barn or shed 30 km away for infected animals is a bit of expense. But as this is milk for the TTD temples, it is likely worth it.\n\nBovine brucellosis is usually caused by _Brucella abortus_, less frequently by _B. melitensis_ (which affects mainly goats and sheep), and occasionally by _B. suis_ (porcine brucellosis). Infection is widespread globally. Several countries in Northern and Central Europe, Canada, Japan, Australia and New Zealand are believed to be free from _B. abortus_.\n\nClinically, the disease is characterised in cattle by one or more of the following signs: abortion, retained placenta, orchitis (testicular inflammation), epididymitis (inflammation of the epididymis, a tube at the back of the testicle) and, rarely, arthritis, with excretion of the organisms in uterine discharges and in milk. Diagnosis depends on the isolation of _Brucella_ bacteria from abortion material, udder secretions, or from tissues removed post-mortem. Presumptive diagnosis can be made by assessing specific cell-mediated or serological responses to _Brucella_ antigens.\n\nThough both _B. abortus_ and _B. melitensis_ are known to be endemic in India (Ref), only _B. abortus_ is mentioned in India's annual reports to the OIE. The bacteria _B. melitensis_ and _B. suis_, both highly pathogenic for humans, are included in India's OIE report for 2015 in the list of diseases \"for which no information has been provided.\"\n\nAccording to India's most recent available (2014) annual statistical-epidemiological report to the OIE, a total of 113 cases of bovine brucellosis in cattle and one in a buffalo, in 7 new outbreaks, were recorded during that year. The final annual report for 2015 is not yet available. The actual data on the ground are, most likely, significantly higher, as apparent from a recent presentation by Prof Narinder Singh Sharma at the regional FAO/OIE/APHCA (Animal Production and Health Commission for Asia and the Pacific) workshop on Brucellosis Diagnosis and Control in Asia-Pacific Region, held in Chiang Mai, Thailand, 18-21 Mar 2014, where he presented the following data:\n\n- Slide 8: addresses _B. melitensis_ serological study in animals in Tamil Nadu State, revealing incidence of 13.85, 9.96 and 20.35 percent positive animals (3 serological tests applied).\n\n- Slide 15: presents the results of a serosurvey in humans, demonstrating incidence of 11 percent among (118) veterinarians, 25.3 percent among (87) veterinary paraclinical staff and 16.1 percent among (62) dairy farmers.\n\nData available at: http://www.rr-asia.oie.int/fileadmin/Regional_Representation/Programme/Emerg/2014_Brucellosis_Chiang_Mai/05.India.pdf.\n\nReference:\nMantur B G and Amarnath S K 2008. Brucellosis in India -- a review; J. Biosci. 33 539-547. http://www.ias.ac.in/article/fulltext/jbsc/033/04/0539-0547\n\nPeople may contract this bacterium in a number of ways that may result in disease. The bacteria may be transmitted through ingestion, usually of contaminated products such as milk, or cheese, or other milk related products. It may also be contracted through inhalation or an open wound for those who work with the animals. Blood, urine and tissues of the infected animal(s) have high concentrations of the bacterium. The placenta from an infected animal is particularly highly concentrated with the causative _Brucella_ agent. Veterinarians or others who are assisting in difficult birthings of an infected animal are particularly at risk.\n\nSymptoms of brucellosis in humans may seem like the flu and may include: an undulating fever (one that comes and goes), headaches, joint pain, lethargy and a listless feeling, chills, loss of appetite, weight loss, back pain.\n\nTell your physician you have been around brucellosis-infected animals. Brucellosis may be diagnosed by blood tests, a culture of the urine and/or blood marrow. Cerebral spinal fluid may be cultured, but likely one of the others will be positive.\n\nIf you test positive for this disease, it is treatable with several antibiotics or combinations of antibiotics. Generally, it is a 6-week course of antibiotics. - Mod.TG\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/297.]\nSee Also\n2016\n----\nBrucellosis, bovine - India: (KA) 20160905.4466872\n2013\n----\nLeptospirosis, brucellosis - India: (UP) zoo employees 20131116.2058788\nBrucellosis, bovine - India: (PB) RFI 20131101.2032822\n2000\n----\nBrucellosis - India (Calcutta) (02) 20000826.1426\nBrucellosis - India (Calcutta) 20000823.1407\n.................................................sb/tg/mpp/msp/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "brucellosis", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2017-03-15 00:00:00", "2015-03-15 00:00:00", "2014-03-15 00:00:00", "2015-03-15 00:00:00", "2014-03-15 00:00:00", "2016-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Australia", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "Japan", "country": "Japan"}, {"location": "Tamil Nadu State", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Tirupati", "country": "India"}, {"location": "India", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Thailand", "country": "Thailand"}, {"location": "New Zealand", "country": "New Zealand"}, {"location": "Chiang Mai", "country": "Thailand"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5253834", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Brucellosis - USA (06): (TX) unpasteurized milk, alert, recall, RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5253834", "date": "2017-07-16 11:49:18", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS - INDIA: (ANDHRA PRADESH) BOVINE\n********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: 13 Jul 2017\nSource: Times of India [edited]\nhttp://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/vijayawada/brucellosis-plagues-ttd-goshala-cows/articleshow/59567830.cms\n\n\nMore than 50 cows were infected with brucellosis at the Gosamrakshana Sala of the Tirumala Tirupati Devasthanams (TTD).\n\nAnimals infected by the pathogenic bacteria have been segregated to prevent the spread of the disease. A separate shed has been built for these animals 30 km away from the temple town of Tirupati. There are nearly 3100 cows and bulls at the goshala.\n\nThe milk used in all TTD temples is supplied from the same dairy farm. Out of the 30 Indian breeds, nearly 10-12 are seen in the same farm.\n\nHumans dealing with infected animals are likely to be infected by brucellosis. They can also be infected if they consume non-pasteurised milk or products made from the milk of infected animals. It may cause fever, spondylitis, and muscular and joint pain in humans.\n\nDirector of the Gosamrakshana Sala K Harnatha Reddy said: \"It is very difficult to detect the disease; it is possible only when the animals are pregnant. As a result, the animal will suffer a miscarriage and lose their ability to reproduce.\"\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[To have built a barn or shed 30 km away for infected animals is a bit of expense. But as this is milk for the TTD temples, it is likely worth it.\n\nBovine brucellosis is usually caused by _Brucella abortus_, less frequently by _B. melitensis_ (which affects mainly goats and sheep), and occasionally by _B. suis_ (porcine brucellosis). Infection is widespread globally. Several countries in Northern and Central Europe, Canada, Japan, Australia and New Zealand are believed to be free from _B. abortus_.\n\nClinically, the disease is characterised in cattle by one or more of the following signs: abortion, retained placenta, orchitis (testicular inflammation), epididymitis (inflammation of the epididymis, a tube at the back of the testicle) and, rarely, arthritis, with excretion of the organisms in uterine discharges and in milk. Diagnosis depends on the isolation of _Brucella_ bacteria from abortion material, udder secretions, or from tissues removed post-mortem. Presumptive diagnosis can be made by assessing specific cell-mediated or serological responses to _Brucella_ antigens.\n\nThough both _B. abortus_ and _B. melitensis_ are known to be endemic in India (Ref), only _B. abortus_ is mentioned in India's annual reports to the OIE. The bacteria _B. melitensis_ and _B. suis_, both highly pathogenic for humans, are included in India's OIE report for 2015 in the list of diseases \"for which no information has been provided.\"\n\nAccording to India's most recent available (2014) annual statistical-epidemiological report to the OIE, a total of 113 cases of bovine brucellosis in cattle and one in a buffalo, in 7 new outbreaks, were recorded during that year. The final annual report for 2015 is not yet available. The actual data on the ground are, most likely, significantly higher, as apparent from a recent presentation by Prof Narinder Singh Sharma at the regional FAO/OIE/APHCA (Animal Production and Health Commission for Asia and the Pacific) workshop on Brucellosis Diagnosis and Control in Asia-Pacific Region, held in Chiang Mai, Thailand, 18-21 Mar 2014, where he presented the following data:\n\n- Slide 8: addresses _B. melitensis_ serological study in animals in Tamil Nadu State, revealing incidence of 13.85, 9.96 and 20.35 percent positive animals (3 serological tests applied).\n\n- Slide 15: presents the results of a serosurvey in humans, demonstrating incidence of 11 percent among (118) veterinarians, 25.3 percent among (87) veterinary paraclinical staff and 16.1 percent among (62) dairy farmers.\n\nData available at: http://www.rr-asia.oie.int/fileadmin/Regional_Representation/Programme/Emerg/2014_Brucellosis_Chiang_Mai/05.India.pdf.\n\nReference:\nMantur B G and Amarnath S K 2008. Brucellosis in India -- a review; J. Biosci. 33 539-547. http://www.ias.ac.in/article/fulltext/jbsc/033/04/0539-0547\n\nPeople may contract this bacterium in a number of ways that may result in disease. The bacteria may be transmitted through ingestion, usually of contaminated products such as milk, or cheese, or other milk related products. It may also be contracted through inhalation or an open wound for those who work with the animals. Blood, urine and tissues of the infected animal(s) have high concentrations of the bacterium. The placenta from an infected animal is particularly highly concentrated with the causative _Brucella_ agent. Veterinarians or others who are assisting in difficult birthings of an infected animal are particularly at risk.\n\nSymptoms of brucellosis in humans may seem like the flu and may include: an undulating fever (one that comes and goes), headaches, joint pain, lethargy and a listless feeling, chills, loss of appetite, weight loss, back pain.\n\nTell your physician you have been around brucellosis-infected animals. Cerebral spinal fluid may be cultured, but likely one of the others will be positive.\n\nIf you test positive for this disease, it is treatable with several antibiotics or combinations of antibiotics. Generally, it is a 6-week course of antibiotics. - Mod.TG\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/297.]\nSee Also\n2016\n----\nBrucellosis, bovine - India: (KA) 20160905.4466872\n2013\n----\nLeptospirosis, brucellosis - Infection is widespread globally. Several countries in Northern and Central Europe, Canada, Japan, Australia and New Zealand are believed to be free from _B. abortus_.\n\nClinically, the disease is characterised in cattle by one or more of the following signs: abortion, retained placenta, orchitis (testicular inflammation), epididymitis (inflammation of the epididymis, a tube at the back of the testicle) and, rarely, arthritis, with excretion of the organisms in uterine discharges and in milk. Diagnosis depends on the isolation of _Brucella_ bacteria from abortion material, udder secretions, or from tissues removed post-mortem. Presumptive diagnosis can be made by assessing specific cell-mediated or serological responses to _Brucella_ antigens.\n\nThough both _B. abortus_ and _B. melitensis_ are known to be endemic in India (Ref), only _B. abortus_ is mentioned in India's annual reports to the OIE. The bacteria _B. melitensis_ and _B. suis_, both highly pathogenic for humans, are included in India's OIE report for 2015 in the list of diseases \"for which no information has been provided.\"\n\nAccording to India's most recent available (2014) annual statistical-epidemiological report to the OIE, a total of 113 cases of bovine brucellosis in cattle and one in a buffalo, in 7 new outbreaks, were recorded during that year. The final annual report for 2015 is not yet available. The actual data on the ground are, most likely, significantly higher, as apparent from a recent presentation by Prof Narinder Singh Sharma at the regional FAO/OIE/APHCA (Animal Production and Health Commission for Asia and the Pacific) workshop on Brucellosis Diagnosis and Control in Asia-Pacific Region, held in Chiang Mai, Thailand, 18-21 Mar 2014, where he presented the following data:\n\n- Slide 8: addresses _B. melitensis_ serological study in animals in Tamil Nadu State, revealing incidence of 13.85, 9.96 and 20.35 percent positive animals (3 serological tests applied).\n\n- Slide 15: presents the results of a serosurvey in humans, demonstrating incidence of 11 percent among (118) veterinarians, 25.3 percent among (87) veterinary paraclinical staff and 16.1 percent among (62) dairy farmers.\n\nData available at: http://www.rr-asia.oie.int/fileadmin/Regional_Representation/Programme/Emerg/2014_Brucellosis_Chiang_Mai/05.India.pdf.\n\nReference:\nMantur B G and Amarnath S K 2008. Brucellosis in India -- a review; J. Biosci. 33 539-547. http://www.ias.ac.in/article/fulltext/jbsc/033/04/0539-0547\n\nPeople may contract this bacterium in a number of ways that may result in disease. The bacteria may be transmitted through ingestion, usually of contaminated products such as milk, or cheese, or other milk related products. It may also be contracted through inhalation or an open wound for those who work with the animals. Blood, urine and tissues of the infected animal(s) have high concentrations of the bacterium. The placenta from an infected animal is particularly highly concentrated with the causative _Brucella_ agent. Veterinarians or others who are assisting in difficult birthings of an infected animal are particularly at risk.\n\nSymptoms of brucellosis in humans may seem like the flu and may include: an undulating fever (one that comes and goes), headaches, joint pain, lethargy and a listless feeling, chills, loss of appetite, weight loss, back pain.\n\nTell your physician you have been around brucellosis-infected animals. Brucellosis may be diagnosed by blood tests, a culture of the urine and/or blood marrow. Cerebral spinal fluid may be cultured, but likely one of the others will be positive.\n\nIf you test positive for this disease, it is treatable with several antibiotics or combinations of antibiotics. Generally, it is a 6-week course of antibiotics. - Mod.TG\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/297.]\nSee Also\n2016\n----\nBrucellosis, bovine - India: (KA) 20160905.4466872\n2013\n----\nLeptospirosis, brucellosis - India: (UP) zoo employees 20131116.2058788\nBrucellosis, bovine - India: (PB) RFI 20131101.2032822\n2000\n----\nBrucellosis - India (Calcutta) (02) 20000826.1426\nBrucellosis - India (Calcutta) 20000823.1407\n.................................................sb/tg/mpp/msp/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "brucellosis", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2017-03-15 00:00:00", "2015-03-15 00:00:00", "2014-03-15 00:00:00", "2015-03-15 00:00:00", "2014-03-15 00:00:00", "2016-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Australia", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "Japan", "country": "Japan"}, {"location": "Tamil Nadu State", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Tirupati", "country": "India"}, {"location": "India", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Thailand", "country": "Thailand"}, {"location": "New Zealand", "country": "New Zealand"}, {"location": "Chiang Mai", "country": "Thailand"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5177589", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Brucellosis - India: (AP) bovine", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5177589", "date": "2017-07-16 11:49:18", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS - INDIA: (ANDHRA PRADESH) BOVINE\n********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: 13 Jul 2017\nSource: Times of India [edited]\nhttp://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/vijayawada/brucellosis-plagues-ttd-goshala-cows/articleshow/59567830.cms\n\n\nMore than 50 cows were infected with brucellosis at the Gosamrakshana Sala of the Tirumala Tirupati Devasthanams (TTD).\n\nAnimals infected by the pathogenic bacteria have been segregated to prevent the spread of the disease. A separate shed has been built for these animals 30 km away from the temple town of Tirupati. There are nearly 3100 cows and bulls at the goshala.\n\nThe milk used in all TTD temples is supplied from the same dairy farm. Out of the 30 Indian breeds, nearly 10-12 are seen in the same farm.\n\nHumans dealing with infected animals are likely to be infected by brucellosis. They can also be infected if they consume non-pasteurised milk or products made from the milk of infected animals. It may cause fever, spondylitis, and muscular and joint pain in humans.\n\nDirector of the Gosamrakshana Sala K Harnatha Reddy said: \"It is very difficult to detect the disease; it is possible only when the animals are pregnant. As a result, the animal will suffer a miscarriage and lose their ability to reproduce.\"\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[To have built a barn or shed 30 km away for infected animals is a bit of expense. But as this is milk for the TTD temples, it is likely worth it.\n\nBovine brucellosis is usually caused by _Brucella abortus_, less frequently by _B. melitensis_ (which affects mainly goats and sheep), and occasionally by _B. suis_ (porcine brucellosis). Infection is widespread globally. Several countries in Northern and Central Europe, Canada, Japan, Australia and New Zealand are believed to be free from _B. abortus_.\n\nClinically, the disease is characterised in cattle by one or more of the following signs: abortion, retained placenta, orchitis (testicular inflammation), epididymitis (inflammation of the epididymis, a tube at the back of the testicle) and, rarely, arthritis, with excretion of the organisms in uterine discharges and in milk. Diagnosis depends on the isolation of _Brucella_ bacteria from abortion material, udder secretions, or from tissues removed post-mortem. Presumptive diagnosis can be made by assessing specific cell-mediated or serological responses to _Brucella_ antigens.\n\nThough both _B. abortus_ and _B. melitensis_ are known to be endemic in India (Ref), only _B. abortus_ is mentioned in India's annual reports to the OIE. The bacteria _B. melitensis_ and _B. suis_, both highly pathogenic for humans, are included in India's OIE report for 2015 in the list of diseases \"for which no information has been provided.\"\n\nAccording to India's most recent available (2014) annual statistical-epidemiological report to the OIE, a total of 113 cases of bovine brucellosis in cattle and one in a buffalo, in 7 new outbreaks, were recorded during that year. The final annual report for 2015 is not yet available. The actual data on the ground are, most likely, significantly higher, as apparent from a recent presentation by Prof Narinder Singh Sharma at the regional FAO/OIE/APHCA (Animal Production and Health Commission for Asia and the Pacific) workshop on Brucellosis Diagnosis and Control in Asia-Pacific Region, held in Chiang Mai, Thailand, 18-21 Mar 2014, where he presented the following data:\n\n- Slide 8: addresses _B. melitensis_ serological study in animals in Tamil Nadu State, revealing incidence of 13.85, 9.96 and 20.35 percent positive animals (3 serological tests applied).\n\n- Slide 15: presents the results of a serosurvey in humans, demonstrating incidence of 11 percent among (118) veterinarians, 25.3 percent among (87) veterinary paraclinical staff and 16.1 percent among (62) dairy farmers.\n\nData available at: http://www.rr-asia.oie.int/fileadmin/Regional_Representation/Programme/Emerg/2014_Brucellosis_Chiang_Mai/05.India.pdf.\n\nReference:\nMantur B G and Amarnath S K 2008. Brucellosis in India -- a review; J. Biosci. 33 539-547. http://www.ias.ac.in/article/fulltext/jbsc/033/04/0539-0547\n\nPeople may contract this bacterium in a number of ways that may result in disease. The bacteria may be transmitted through ingestion, usually of contaminated products such as milk, or cheese, or other milk related products. It may also be contracted through inhalation or an open wound for those who work with the animals. Blood, urine and tissues of the infected animal(s) have high concentrations of the bacterium. The placenta from an infected animal is particularly highly concentrated with the causative _Brucella_ agent. Veterinarians or others who are assisting in difficult birthings of an infected animal are particularly at risk.\n\nSymptoms of brucellosis in humans may seem like the flu and may include: an undulating fever (one that comes and goes), headaches, joint pain, lethargy and a listless feeling, chills, loss of appetite, weight loss, back pain.\n\nTell your physician you have been around brucellosis-infected animals. Brucellosis may be diagnosed by blood tests, a culture of the urine and/or blood marrow. Cerebral spinal fluid may be cultured, but likely one of the others will be positive.\n\nIf you test positive for this disease, it is treatable with several antibiotics or combinations of antibiotics. Generally, it is a 6-week course of antibiotics. - Mod.TG\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/297.]\nSee Also\n2016\n----\nBrucellosis, bovine - India: (KA) 20160905.4466872\n2013\n----\nLeptospirosis, brucellosis - Russia: (VR) livestock, human", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5075104", "date": "2017-07-16 11:49:18", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS - INDIA: (ANDHRA PRADESH) BOVINE\n********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: 13 Jul 2017\nSource: Times of India [edited]\nhttp://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/vijayawada/brucellosis-plagues-ttd-goshala-cows/articleshow/59567830.cms\n\n\nMore than 50 cows were infected with brucellosis at the Gosamrakshana Sala of the Tirumala Tirupati Devasthanams (TTD).\n\nAnimals infected by the pathogenic bacteria have been segregated to prevent the spread of the disease. The final annual report for 2015 is not yet available. The actual data on the ground are, most likely, significantly higher, as apparent from a recent presentation by Prof Narinder Singh Sharma at the regional FAO/OIE/APHCA (Animal Production and Health Commission for Asia and the Pacific) workshop on Brucellosis Diagnosis and Control in Asia-Pacific Region, held in Chiang Mai, Thailand, 18-21 Mar 2014, where he presented the following data:\n\n- Slide 8: addresses _B. melitensis_ serological study in animals in Tamil Nadu State, revealing incidence of 13.85, 9.96 and 20.35 percent positive animals (3 serological tests applied).\n\n- Slide 15: presents the results of a serosurvey in humans, demonstrating incidence of 11 percent among (118) veterinarians, 25.3 percent among (87) veterinary paraclinical staff and 16.1 percent among (62) dairy farmers.\n\nData available at: http://www.rr-asia.oie.int/fileadmin/Regional_Representation/Programme/Emerg/2014_Brucellosis_Chiang_Mai/05.India.pdf.\n\nReference:\nMantur B G and Amarnath S K 2008. Brucellosis in India -- a review; J. Biosci. 33 539-547. http://www.ias.ac.in/article/fulltext/jbsc/033/04/0539-0547\n\nPeople may contract this bacterium in a number of ways that may result in disease. The bacteria may be transmitted through ingestion, usually of contaminated products such as milk, or cheese, or other milk related products. It may also be contracted through inhalation or an open wound for those who work with the animals. Blood, urine and tissues of the infected animal(s) have high concentrations of the bacterium. The placenta from an infected animal is particularly highly concentrated with the causative _Brucella_ agent. Veterinarians or others who are assisting in difficult birthings of an infected animal are particularly at risk.\n\nSymptoms of brucellosis in humans may seem like the flu and may include: an undulating fever (one that comes and goes), headaches, joint pain, lethargy and a listless feeling, chills, loss of appetite, weight loss, back pain.\n\nTell your physician you have been around brucellosis-infected animals. Cerebral spinal fluid may be cultured, but likely one of the others will be positive.\n\nIf you test positive for this disease, it is treatable with several antibiotics or combinations of antibiotics. Generally, it is a 6-week course of antibiotics. - Mod.TG\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/297.]\nSee Also\n2016\n----\nBrucellosis, bovine - India: (KA) 20160905.4466872\n2013\n----\nLeptospirosis, brucellosis - India: (UP) zoo employees 20131116.2058788\nBrucellosis, bovine - India: (PB) RFI 20131101.2032822\n2000\n----\nBrucellosis - India (Calcutta) (02) 20000826.1426\nBrucellosis - India (Calcutta) 20000823.1407\n.................................................sb/tg/mpp/msp/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "brucellosis", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2017-03-15 00:00:00", "2015-03-15 00:00:00", "2014-03-15 00:00:00", "2015-03-15 00:00:00", "2014-03-15 00:00:00", "2016-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Australia", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "Japan", "country": "Japan"}, {"location": "Tamil Nadu State", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Tirupati", "country": "India"}, {"location": "India", "country": "India"}, {"location": "Thailand", "country": "Thailand"}, {"location": "New Zealand", "country": "New Zealand"}, {"location": "Chiang Mai", "country": "Thailand"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5031180", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Brucellosis - Israel: camel milk, unpasteurized, melitensis, human, update", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5031180", "date": "2017-03-21 09:32:15", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS - USA: (NEW YORK) SWINE, HUMAN, 2016\n************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 17 Mar 2017\nSource: Lancaster Farming [edited]\nhttp://www.lancasterfarming.com/farming/dairy/swine-brucellosis-outbreak-in-new-york/article_d1b75a7e-a75f-5ab8-933a-b0df686aa82d.html\n\n\nIn April 2016, the New York State Department of Agriculture & Markets was notified by the New York State Department of Health of a human case of _Brucella suis_.\n\nThe patient's symptoms were chronic tiredness, intermittent fever, joint pain, and respiratory distress. Antibiotic treatment lasted for weeks.\n\nWith this kind of ailment, symptoms may return several months after treatment concludes and symptoms may appear anywhere from 5 days to 5 months from exposure.\n\nWhere did this infection come from if New York is brucellosis free? Isn't the US free of brucellosis? The answer to those questions is yes, the US is free of the disease in commercial herds.\n\nBut there are other production methods and other potential sources for the bacteria. Pasture-raised farms have pigs outdoors. These pigs may have access to feral hogs. Could these outdoor pigs or feral pigs been the source for the human infection?\n\nThe person infected was assisting with farrowing on the family's farm in Schoharie County. The diagnosis was made via blood culture, testing positive for _B. suis_ biotype 1. The pasture-raised swine had no known contact with feral hogs.\n\nThe USDA's Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service's Wildlife Services was called in to assist. All adult breeding hogs on the farm were tested with 7 of the 29 hogs testing positive on multiple tests for the same strain.\n\nAll but 2 that tested negative were humanely euthanized due to zoonotic -- human transmission -- risk. The 2 remaining hogs were kept under quarantine for \"testing out.\"\n\nIn swine, brucellosis infection causes reproductive issues such as infertility, abortion, stillborn or weak piglets, testicular swelling, and reluctance to mate. There may also be signs of lameness with painful, swollen joints. It may be transmitted through breeding or ingestion of urine or placentas, aborted fetuses, or uterine fluids.\n\nThe farm had sold feeder pigs or breeding stock to numerous farms with 4 herds testing positive for _B. suis_ biotype 1. 2 were in New York -- Schoharie and Rensselaer counties -- 1 herd was in Virginia, and 1 herd was in New Jersey. They were all pasture-raised operations.\n\nThe initial infected farm purchased a breeding boar from a farm in Washington County, New York. Back in 2004, the Washington County farm observed a feral boar gain access and breed 2 sows, and then escape. Both sows had litters that sold as feeders or directly to restaurants. The farm kept 1 pig from each litter -- male and female.\n\nThe breeding boar died in 2014 but the sow farrowed multiple litters. Over 78 percent of the herd tested positive for brucellosis -- 59 of 75. They had sold or shared hogs with multiple farms.\n\nA total of 50 herds in 13 states were investigated. 9 brucellosis-infected herds were found, all pasture-raised swine, with 6 infected herds in New York: 2 in Schoharie County, 1 in Rensselaer County, and 3 in Washington County.\n\nAs of [26 Sep 2016], all known infected and exposed pigs had been depopulated. These farms received indemnity paid by the New York State Department of Agriculture & Markets and the USDA.\n\nThe farm owners performed dry cleaning on their premises and then disinfected with Virkon. Pastures were required to be fallow for 60 to 120 days. Restocking of the herds was done from validated herds, those that had tested brucellosis free.\n\nThere were 2 strains of _B. suis_ identified from this outbreak.\n\nWas the strain around a long time, opening the possibility for variation? Were there multiple sources of infected pigs? What's the takeaway message here?\n\nBiosecurity and traceability are important, especially when it comes to diseases such as brucellosis.\n\nHere are some other biosecurity tips:\n- feral hog populations need to be kept away from domestic hogs with secure fencing;\n- avoid sharing breeding boars between herds or have the boar tested for brucellosis before using him for breeding;\n- purchase only tested animals or animals from validated free herds (herds that undergo routine testing for brucellosis);\n- isolate newly purchased animals for 30 days and consider retesting them for brucellosis before using them for breeding or mixing them with the rest of the herd. Don't borrow or lend disease to your neighbor;\n- avoid sharing equipment that comes in contact with animals. Thoroughly clean and disinfect all equipment that is borrowed;\n- practice good herd hygiene. Do not feed aborted fetuses and placenta to other pigs or dogs;\n- keep equipment clean including transport trailers, chutes; and other tools for handling swine;\n- thoroughly clean feed and water troughs before reusing with another group of animals;\n- practice good manure management and remove manure as each group cycles through, or sooner if needed;\n- keep yourself safe, too. Wear protective clothing such as coveralls or barrier aprons and rubber boots when working with swine;\n- thoroughly clean and disinfect your boots and apron when you are finished and wash your coveralls;\n- Be very careful when handling aborted fetuses or placentas, or when assisting with farrowing;\n- use rubber gloves, safety goggles, and a mask to cover your nose and mouth.\n- Afterward, wash thoroughly with soap and water, paying close attention to any areas where birth products have accidentally touched your skin or soaked through your clothing;\n- During cooking and food prep, avoid eating under-cooked meat and wash your hands thoroughly after handling raw meat.\n\n[Byline: Nancy Glazier, Cornell Extension]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Brucellosis in people has many other names, including Malta fever, and undulating fever. The fever associated with this disease seems to be present for a few days and then gone for a few days only to return again. This cycle repeats. In other words, a recurrent fever.\n\nIn addition to the recurrent fever the patients with this disease experience malaise, fatigue, headaches, anorexia, and body pain, often in the back, legs, joints, and spine. The pain and recurrent fever and sweats and general malaise often produce depression. The abdomen may be tender to painful as the liver and/or spleen generally swell with this disease.\n\nSadly as in this case, physicians believe the state is free of this bacterial disease and it is often not their differential radar. However, if it is diagnosed, this bacterial disease can be treated with antibiotics. The combination of rifampin and doxycycline generally works well. Treatment may be needed for as long as 6-8 weeks depending on the patient and how long the bacteria have been propagating the human being. There are cases where patients have been on antibiotic therapy for a couple of months.\n\nRegardless of the state designation of a disease, this disease and others should be on the differential list. Diseases travel widely in this age of jetting about our global community.\n\nThis article raises some good points on biosecurity of farm raised swine and trading or loaning boars. Wild boars are notorious for getting through a variety of fencing to breed with sows. This article should serve as a warning to all pasture raised swine to continually check fences and to test your animals on a regular basis.\n\nHowever, the article does not tell us if all the herds found with brucellosis were depopulated, or what the status is of the herds mentioned in this article. We know one herd was tested and all but 2 animals were depopulated, but what about the other herds mentioned? - Mod.TG\n\nThe state of New York can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/50813. A county map can be seen at http://geology.com/county-map/new-york-county-map.gif. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\nSee Also\n2012\n----\nBrucellosis, cervid - Canada (03): (NU) caribou 20120215.1042283\nBrucellosis, cervid - Canada: (02) (NU) caribou 20120205.1033659\nBrucellosis, cervid - Canada: (NU) caribou 20120201.1028114\n2010\n----\nBrucellosis, swine - Latvia, OIE 20100917.3364\nBrucellosis, swine - Germany: (BB), OIE 20100213.0508\n2009\n----\nBrucellosis, swine hunters - USA (02): (TX) hunters 20090920.3303\nBrucellosis, swine hunters - USA: (SC, PA) EX Florida 20090612.2178\nBrucellosis, cervid - Canada (03): (NU) caribou 20120215.1042283\nBrucellosis, cervid - Canada: (02) (NU) caribou 20120205.1033659\nBrucellosis, cervid - Canada: (NU) caribou 20120201.1028114\n2010\n----\nBrucellosis, swine - Latvia, OIE 20100917.3364\nBrucellosis, swine - Germany: (BB), OIE 20100213.0508\n2009\n----\nBrucellosis, swine hunters - USA (02): (TX) hunters 20090920.3303\nBrucellosis, swine hunters - USA: (SC, PA) EX Florida 20090612.2178\n.................................................sb/tg/mj/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "brucellosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2016-03-15 00:00:00", "2017-03-15 00:00:00", "2016-04-15 00:00:00", "2004-03-15 00:00:00", "2014-03-15 00:00:00", "1975-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2010-03-15 00:00:00", "2009-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2010-03-15 00:00:00", "2009-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Malta", "country": "Malta"}, {"location": "Schoharie County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Virginia", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "SC", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Washington County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "NEW YORK", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "New Jersey", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Rensselaer County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "US", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "BB", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "5006161", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Brucellosis, neotomae - Costa Rica", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=5006161", "date": "2017-03-21 09:32:15", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS - USA: (NEW YORK) SWINE, HUMAN, 2016\n************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 17 Mar 2017\nSource: Lancaster Farming [edited]\nhttp://www.lancasterfarming.com/farming/dairy/swine-brucellosis-outbreak-in-new-york/article_d1b75a7e-a75f-5ab8-933a-b0df686aa82d.html\n\n\nIn April 2016, the New York State Department of Agriculture & Markets was notified by the New York State Department of Health of a human case of _Brucella suis_.\n\nThe patient's symptoms were chronic tiredness, intermittent fever, joint pain, and respiratory distress. Antibiotic treatment lasted for weeks.\n\nWith this kind of ailment, symptoms may return several months after treatment concludes and symptoms may appear anywhere from 5 days to 5 months from exposure.\n\nWhere did this infection come from if New York is brucellosis free? Isn't the US free of brucellosis? The answer to those questions is yes, the US is free of the disease in commercial herds.\n\nBut there are other production methods and other potential sources for the bacteria. Pasture-raised farms have pigs outdoors. These pigs may have access to feral hogs. Could these outdoor pigs or feral pigs been the source for the human infection?\n\nThe person infected was assisting with farrowing on the family's farm in Schoharie County. The diagnosis was made via blood culture, testing positive for _B. suis_ biotype 1. The pasture-raised swine had no known contact with feral hogs.\n\nThe USDA's Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service's Wildlife Services was called in to assist. All adult breeding hogs on the farm were tested with 7 of the 29 hogs testing positive on multiple tests for the same strain.\n\nAll but 2 that tested negative were humanely euthanized due to zoonotic -- human transmission -- risk. The 2 remaining hogs were kept under quarantine for \"testing out.\"\n\nIn swine, brucellosis infection causes reproductive issues such as infertility, abortion, stillborn or weak piglets, testicular swelling, and reluctance to mate. There may also be signs of lameness with painful, swollen joints. It may be transmitted through breeding or ingestion of urine or placentas, aborted fetuses, or uterine fluids.\n\nThe farm had sold feeder pigs or breeding stock to numerous farms with 4 herds testing positive for _B. suis_ biotype 1. 2 were in New York -- Schoharie and Rensselaer counties -- 1 herd was in Virginia, and 1 herd was in New Jersey. They were all pasture-raised operations.\n\nThe initial infected farm purchased a breeding boar from a farm in Washington County, New York. Back in 2004, the Washington County farm observed a feral boar gain access and breed 2 sows, and then escape. Both sows had litters that sold as feeders or directly to restaurants. The farm kept 1 pig from each litter -- male and female.\n\nThe breeding boar died in 2014 but the sow farrowed multiple litters. Over 78 percent of the herd tested positive for brucellosis -- 59 of 75. They had sold or shared hogs with multiple farms.\n\nA total of 50 herds in 13 states were investigated. 9 brucellosis-infected herds were found, all pasture-raised swine, with 6 infected herds in New York: 2 in Schoharie County, 1 in Rensselaer County, and 3 in Washington County.\n\nAs of [26 Sep 2016], all known infected and exposed pigs had been depopulated. These farms received indemnity paid by the New York State Department of Agriculture & Markets and the USDA.\n\nThe farm owners performed dry cleaning on their premises and then disinfected with Virkon. Pastures were required to be fallow for 60 to 120 days. Restocking of the herds was done from validated herds, those that had tested brucellosis free.\n\nThere were 2 strains of _B. suis_ identified from this outbreak.\n\nWas the strain around a long time, opening the possibility for variation? Were there multiple sources of infected pigs? What's the takeaway message here?\n\nBiosecurity and traceability are important, especially when it comes to diseases such as brucellosis.\n\nHere are some other biosecurity tips:\n- feral hog populations need to be kept away from domestic hogs with secure fencing;\n- avoid sharing breeding boars between herds or have the boar tested for brucellosis before using him for breeding;\n- purchase only tested animals or animals from validated free herds (herds that undergo routine testing for brucellosis);\n- isolate newly purchased animals for 30 days and consider retesting them for brucellosis before using them for breeding or mixing them with the rest of the herd. Don't borrow or lend disease to your neighbor;\n- avoid sharing equipment that comes in contact with animals. Thoroughly clean and disinfect all equipment that is borrowed;\n- practice good herd hygiene. Do not feed aborted fetuses and placenta to other pigs or dogs;\n- keep equipment clean including transport trailers, chutes; and other tools for handling swine;\n- thoroughly clean feed and water troughs before reusing with another group of animals;\n- practice good manure management and remove manure as each group cycles through, or sooner if needed;\n- keep yourself safe, too. Wear protective clothing such as coveralls or barrier aprons and rubber boots when working with swine;\n- thoroughly clean and disinfect your boots and apron when you are finished and wash your coveralls;\n- Be very careful when handling aborted fetuses or placentas, or when assisting with farrowing;\n- use rubber gloves, safety goggles, and a mask to cover your nose and mouth.\n- Afterward, wash thoroughly with soap and water, paying close attention to any areas where birth products have accidentally touched your skin or soaked through your clothing;\n- During cooking and food prep, avoid eating under-cooked meat and wash your hands thoroughly after handling raw meat.\n\n[Byline: Nancy Glazier, Cornell Extension]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Brucellosis in people has many other names, including Malta fever, and undulating fever. The fever associated with this disease seems to be present for a few days and then gone for a few days only to return again. This cycle repeats. In other words, a recurrent fever.\n\nIn addition to the recurrent fever the patients with this disease experience malaise, fatigue, headaches, anorexia, and body pain, often in the back, legs, joints, and spine. The pain and recurrent fever and sweats and general malaise often produce depression. The abdomen may be tender to painful as the liver and/or spleen generally swell with this disease.\n\nSadly as in this case, physicians believe the state is free of this bacterial disease and it is often not their differential radar. However, if it is diagnosed, this bacterial disease can be treated with antibiotics. The combination of rifampin and doxycycline generally works well. Treatment may be needed for as long as 6-8 weeks depending on the patient and how long the bacteria have been propagating the human being. There are cases where patients have been on antibiotic therapy for a couple of months.\n\nRegardless of the state designation of a disease, this disease and others should be on the differential list. Diseases travel widely in this age of jetting about our global community.\n\nThis article raises some good points on biosecurity of farm raised swine and trading or loaning boars. Wild boars are notorious for getting through a variety of fencing to breed with sows. This article should serve as a warning to all pasture raised swine to continually check fences and to test your animals on a regular basis.\n\nHowever, the article does not tell us if all the herds found with brucellosis were depopulated, or what the status is of the herds mentioned in this article. We know one herd was tested and all but 2 animals were depopulated, but what about the other herds mentioned? - Mod.TG\n\nThe state of New York can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/50813. A county map can be seen at http://geology.com/county-map/new-york-county-map.gif. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\nSee Also\n2012\n----\nBrucellosis, cervid - Canada (03): (NU) caribou 20120215.1042283\nBrucellosis, cervid - Canada: (02) (NU) caribou 20120205.1033659\nBrucellosis, cervid - Canada: (NU) caribou 20120201.1028114\n2010\n----\nBrucellosis, swine - Latvia, OIE 20100917.3364\nBrucellosis, swine - Germany: (BB), OIE 20100213.0508\n2009\n----\nBrucellosis, swine hunters - USA (02): (TX) hunters 20090920.3303\nBrucellosis, swine hunters - USA: (SC, PA) EX Florida 20090612.2178\nBrucellosis, cervid - Canada (03): (NU) caribou 20120215.1042283\nBrucellosis, cervid - Canada: (02) (NU) caribou 20120205.1033659\nBrucellosis, cervid - Canada: (NU) caribou 20120201.1028114\n2010\n----\nBrucellosis, swine - Latvia, OIE 20100917.3364\nBrucellosis, swine - Germany: (BB), OIE 20100213.0508\n2009\n----\nBrucellosis, swine hunters - USA (02): (TX) hunters 20090920.3303\nBrucellosis, swine hunters - Kenya: false positive serologies", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4977842", "date": "2017-03-21 09:32:15", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS - USA: (NEW YORK) SWINE, HUMAN, 2016\n************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 17 Mar 2017\nSource: Lancaster Farming [edited]\nhttp://www.lancasterfarming.com/farming/dairy/swine-brucellosis-outbreak-in-new-york/article_d1b75a7e-a75f-5ab8-933a-b0df686aa82d.html\n\n\nIn April 2016, the New York State Department of Agriculture & Markets was notified by the New York State Department of Health of a human case of _Brucella suis_.\n\nThe patient's symptoms were chronic tiredness, intermittent fever, joint pain, and respiratory distress. Antibiotic treatment lasted for weeks.\n\nWith this kind of ailment, symptoms may return several months after treatment concludes and symptoms may appear anywhere from 5 days to 5 months from exposure.\n\nWhere did this infection come from if New York is brucellosis free? The answer to those questions is yes, the US is free of the disease in commercial herds.\n\nBut there are other production methods and other potential sources for the bacteria. They had sold or shared hogs with multiple farms.\n\nA total of 50 herds in 13 states were investigated. 9 brucellosis-infected herds were found, all pasture-raised swine, with 6 infected herds in New York: 2 in Schoharie County, 1 in Rensselaer County, and 3 in Washington County.\n\nAs of [26 Sep 2016], all known infected and exposed pigs had been depopulated. The fever associated with this disease seems to be present for a few days and then gone for a few days only to return again. This cycle repeats. Treatment may be needed for as long as 6-8 weeks depending on the patient and how long the bacteria have been propagating the human being. Diseases travel widely in this age of jetting about our global community.\n\nThis article raises some good points on biosecurity of farm raised swine and trading or loaning boars. Wild boars are notorious for getting through a variety of fencing to breed with sows. This article should serve as a warning to all pasture raised swine to continually check fences and to test your animals on a regular basis.\n\nHowever, the article does not tell us if all the herds found with brucellosis were depopulated, or what the status is of the herds mentioned in this article. We know one herd was tested and all but 2 animals were depopulated, but what about the other herds mentioned? - Mod.TG\n\nThe state of New York can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/50813. A county map can be seen at http://geology.com/county-map/new-york-county-map.gif. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\nSee Also\n2012\n----\nBrucellosis, cervid - Canada (03): (NU) caribou 20120215.1042283\nBrucellosis, cervid - Canada: (02) (NU) caribou 20120205.1033659\nBrucellosis, cervid - Canada: (NU) caribou 20120201.1028114\n2010\n----\nBrucellosis, swine - Latvia, OIE 20100917.3364\nBrucellosis, swine - Germany: (BB), OIE 20100213.0508\n2009\n----\nBrucellosis, swine hunters - USA (02): (TX) hunters 20090920.3303\nBrucellosis, swine hunters - USA: (SC, PA) EX Florida 20090612.2178\nBrucellosis, cervid - Canada (03): (NU) caribou 20120215.1042283\nBrucellosis, cervid - Canada: (02) (NU) caribou 20120205.1033659\nBrucellosis, cervid - Canada: (NU) caribou 20120201.1028114\n2010\n----\nBrucellosis, swine - Latvia, OIE 20100917.3364\nBrucellosis, swine - Germany: (BB), OIE 20100213.0508\n2009\n----\nBrucellosis, swine hunters - USA (02): (TX) hunters 20090920.3303\nBrucellosis, swine hunters - USA: (SC, PA) EX Florida 20090612.2178\n.................................................sb/tg/mj/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "brucellosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2016-03-15 00:00:00", "2017-03-15 00:00:00", "2016-04-15 00:00:00", "2004-03-15 00:00:00", "2014-03-15 00:00:00", "1975-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2010-03-15 00:00:00", "2009-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2010-03-15 00:00:00", "2009-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Malta", "country": "Malta"}, {"location": "Schoharie County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "New York", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Virginia", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "SC", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Washington County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "NEW YORK", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "New Jersey", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Rensselaer County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "US", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "BB", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4971915", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Brucellosis, livestock, human - Kazakhstan: (WK) RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4971915", "date": "2017-03-21 09:32:15", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS - USA: (NEW YORK) SWINE, HUMAN, 2016\n************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 17 Mar 2017\nSource: Lancaster Farming [edited]\nhttp://www.lancasterfarming.com/farming/dairy/swine-brucellosis-outbreak-in-new-york/article_d1b75a7e-a75f-5ab8-933a-b0df686aa82d.html\n\n\nIn April 2016, the New York State Department of Agriculture & Markets was notified by the New York State Department of Health of a human case of _Brucella suis_.\n\nThe patient's symptoms were chronic tiredness, intermittent fever, joint pain, and respiratory distress. Antibiotic treatment lasted for weeks.\n\nWith this kind of ailment, symptoms may return several months after treatment concludes and symptoms may appear anywhere from 5 days to 5 months from exposure.\n\nWhere did this infection come from if New York is brucellosis free? Isn't the US free of brucellosis? The answer to those questions is yes, the US is free of the disease in commercial herds.\n\nBut there are other production methods and other potential sources for the bacteria. Pasture-raised farms have pigs outdoors. These pigs may have access to feral hogs. Could these outdoor pigs or feral pigs been the source for the human infection?\n\nThe person infected was assisting with farrowing on the family's farm in Schoharie County. The diagnosis was made via blood culture, testing positive for _B. suis_ biotype 1. The pasture-raised swine had no known contact with feral hogs.\n\nThe USDA's Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service's Wildlife Services was called in to assist. All adult breeding hogs on the farm were tested with 7 of the 29 hogs testing positive on multiple tests for the same strain.\n\nAll but 2 that tested negative were humanely euthanized due to zoonotic -- human transmission -- risk. The 2 remaining hogs were kept under quarantine for \"testing out.\"\n\nIn swine, brucellosis infection causes reproductive issues such as infertility, abortion, stillborn or weak piglets, testicular swelling, and reluctance to mate. There may also be signs of lameness with painful, swollen joints. It may be transmitted through breeding or ingestion of urine or placentas, aborted fetuses, or uterine fluids.\n\nThe farm had sold feeder pigs or breeding stock to numerous farms with 4 herds testing positive for _B. suis_ biotype 1. 2 were in New York -- Schoharie and Rensselaer counties -- 1 herd was in Virginia, and 1 herd was in New Jersey. They were all pasture-raised operations.\n\nThe initial infected farm purchased a breeding boar from a farm in Washington County, New York. Back in 2004, the Washington County farm observed a feral boar gain access and breed 2 sows, and then escape. Both sows had litters that sold as feeders or directly to restaurants. The farm kept 1 pig from each litter -- male and female.\n\nThe breeding boar died in 2014 but the sow farrowed multiple litters. Over 78 percent of the herd tested positive for brucellosis -- 59 of 75. They had sold or shared hogs with multiple farms.\n\nA total of 50 herds in 13 states were investigated. 9 brucellosis-infected herds were found, all pasture-raised swine, with 6 infected herds in New York: 2 in Schoharie County, 1 in Rensselaer County, and 3 in Washington County.\n\nAs of [26 Sep 2016], all known infected and exposed pigs had been depopulated. These farms received indemnity paid by the New York State Department of Agriculture & Markets and the USDA.\n\nThe farm owners performed dry cleaning on their premises and then disinfected with Virkon. Pastures were required to be fallow for 60 to 120 days. Restocking of the herds was done from validated herds, those that had tested brucellosis free.\n\nThere were 2 strains of _B. suis_ identified from this outbreak.\n\nWas the strain around a long time, opening the possibility for variation? Were there multiple sources of infected pigs? What's the takeaway message here?\n\nBiosecurity and traceability are important, especially when it comes to diseases such as brucellosis.\n\nHere are some other biosecurity tips:\n- feral hog populations need to be kept away from domestic hogs with secure fencing;\n- avoid sharing breeding boars between herds or have the boar tested for brucellosis before using him for breeding;\n- purchase only tested animals or animals from validated free herds (herds that undergo routine testing for brucellosis);\n- isolate newly purchased animals for 30 days and consider retesting them for brucellosis before using them for breeding or mixing them with the rest of the herd. Don't borrow or lend disease to your neighbor;\n- avoid sharing equipment that comes in contact with animals. Thoroughly clean and disinfect all equipment that is borrowed;\n- practice good herd hygiene. Do not feed aborted fetuses and placenta to other pigs or dogs;\n- keep equipment clean including transport trailers, chutes; and other tools for handling swine;\n- thoroughly clean feed and water troughs before reusing with another group of animals;\n- practice good manure management and remove manure as each group cycles through, or sooner if needed;\n- keep yourself safe, too. Wear protective clothing such as coveralls or barrier aprons and rubber boots when working with swine;\n- thoroughly clean and disinfect your boots and apron when you are finished and wash your coveralls;\n- Be very careful when handling aborted fetuses or placentas, or when assisting with farrowing;\n- use rubber gloves, safety goggles, and a mask to cover your nose and mouth.\n- Afterward, wash thoroughly with soap and water, paying close attention to any areas where birth products have accidentally touched your skin or soaked through your clothing;\n- During cooking and food prep, avoid eating under-cooked meat and wash your hands thoroughly after handling raw meat.\n\n[Byline: Nancy Glazier, Cornell Extension]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Brucellosis in people has many other names, including Malta fever, and undulating fever. The fever associated with this disease seems to be present for a few days and then gone for a few days only to return again. This cycle repeats. In other words, a recurrent fever.\n\nIn addition to the recurrent fever the patients with this disease experience malaise, fatigue, headaches, anorexia, and body pain, often in the back, legs, joints, and spine. The pain and recurrent fever and sweats and general malaise often produce depression. The abdomen may be tender to painful as the liver and/or spleen generally swell with this disease.\n\nSadly as in this case, physicians believe the state is free of this bacterial disease and it is often not their differential radar. However, if it is diagnosed, this bacterial disease can be treated with antibiotics. The combination of rifampin and doxycycline generally works well. Treatment may be needed for as long as 6-8 weeks depending on the patient and how long the bacteria have been propagating the human being. There are cases where patients have been on antibiotic therapy for a couple of months.\n\nRegardless of the state designation of a disease, this disease and others should be on the differential list. Diseases travel widely in this age of jetting about our global community.\n\nThis article raises some good points on biosecurity of farm raised swine and trading or loaning boars. Wild boars are notorious for getting through a variety of fencing to breed with sows. This article should serve as a warning to all pasture raised swine to continually check fences and to test your animals on a regular basis.\n\nHowever, the article does not tell us if all the herds found with brucellosis were depopulated, or what the status is of the herds mentioned in this article. We know one herd was tested and all but 2 animals were depopulated, but what about the other herds mentioned? - Mod.TG\n\nThe state of New York can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/50813. A county map can be seen at http://geology.com/county-map/new-york-county-map.gif. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\nSee Also\n2012\n----\nBrucellosis, cervid - Canada (03): (NU) caribou 20120215.1042283\nBrucellosis, cervid - Canada: (02) (NU) caribou 20120205.1033659\nBrucellosis, cervid - Canada: (NU) caribou 20120201.1028114\n2010\n----\nBrucellosis, swine - Latvia, OIE 20100917.3364\nBrucellosis, swine - Germany: (BB), OIE 20100213.0508\n2009\n----\nBrucellosis, swine hunters - USA (02): (TX) hunters 20090920.3303\nBrucellosis, swine hunters - USA: (SC, PA) EX Florida 20090612.2178\nBrucellosis, cervid - Canada (03): (NU) caribou 20120215.1042283\nBrucellosis, cervid - Canada: (02) (NU) caribou 20120205.1033659\nBrucellosis, cervid - Mexico: (ZA) unpasteurized cheese", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4916017", "date": "2017-03-21 09:32:15", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS - USA: (NEW YORK) SWINE, HUMAN, 2016\n************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 17 Mar 2017\nSource: Lancaster Farming [edited]\nhttp://www.lancasterfarming.com/farming/dairy/swine-brucellosis-outbreak-in-new-york/article_d1b75a7e-a75f-5ab8-933a-b0df686aa82d.html\n\n\nIn April 2016, the New York State Department of Agriculture & Markets was notified by the New York State Department of Health of a human case of _Brucella suis_.\n\nThe patient's symptoms were chronic tiredness, intermittent fever, joint pain, and respiratory distress. Antibiotic treatment lasted for weeks.\n\nWith this kind of ailment, symptoms may return several months after treatment concludes and symptoms may appear anywhere from 5 days to 5 months from exposure.\n\nWhere did this infection come from if New York is brucellosis free? Thoroughly clean and disinfect all equipment that is borrowed;\n- practice good herd hygiene. Do not feed aborted fetuses and placenta to other pigs or dogs;\n- keep equipment clean including transport trailers, chutes; and other tools for handling swine;\n- thoroughly clean feed and water troughs before reusing with another group of animals;\n- practice good manure management and remove manure as each group cycles through, or sooner if needed;\n- keep yourself safe, too. Wear protective clothing such as coveralls or barrier aprons and rubber boots when working with swine;\n- thoroughly clean and disinfect your boots and apron when you are finished and wash your coveralls;\n- Be very careful when handling aborted fetuses or placentas, or when assisting with farrowing;\n- use rubber gloves, safety goggles, and a mask to cover your nose and mouth.\n- Afterward, wash thoroughly with soap and water, paying close attention to any areas where birth products have accidentally touched your skin or soaked through your clothing;\n- During cooking and food prep, avoid eating under-cooked meat and wash your hands thoroughly after handling raw meat.\n\n[Byline: Nancy Glazier, Cornell Extension]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Brucellosis in people has many other names, including Malta fever, and undulating fever. The fever associated with this disease seems to be present for a few days and then gone for a few days only to return again. This cycle repeats. In other words, a recurrent fever.\n\nIn addition to the recurrent fever the patients with this disease experience malaise, fatigue, headaches, anorexia, and body pain, often in the back, legs, joints, and spine. The pain and recurrent fever and sweats and general malaise often produce depression. The abdomen may be tender to painful as the liver and/or spleen generally swell with this disease.\n\nSadly as in this case, physicians believe the state is free of this bacterial disease and it is often not their differential radar. However, if it is diagnosed, this bacterial disease can be treated with antibiotics. The combination of rifampin and doxycycline generally works well. Treatment may be needed for as long as 6-8 weeks depending on the patient and how long the bacteria have been propagating the human being. There are cases where patients have been on antibiotic therapy for a couple of months.\n\nRegardless of the state designation of a disease, this disease and others should be on the differential list. Diseases travel widely in this age of jetting about our global community.\n\nThis article raises some good points on biosecurity of farm raised swine and trading or loaning boars. Wild boars are notorious for getting through a variety of fencing to breed with sows. This article should serve as a warning to all pasture raised swine to continually check fences and to test your animals on a regular basis.\n\nHowever, the article does not tell us if all the herds found with brucellosis were depopulated, or what the status is of the herds mentioned in this article. We know one herd was tested and all but 2 animals were depopulated, but what about the other herds mentioned? - Mod.TG\n\nThe state of New York can be located on the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at http://healthmap.org/promed/p/50813. A county map can be seen at http://geology.com/county-map/new-york-county-map.gif. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\nSee Also\n2012\n----\nBrucellosis, cervid - Canada (03): (NU) caribou 20120215.1042283\nBrucellosis, cervid - Canada: (02) (NU) caribou 20120205.1033659\nBrucellosis, cervid - Canada: (NU) caribou 20120201.1028114\n2010\n----\nBrucellosis, swine - Latvia, OIE 20100917.3364\nBrucellosis, swine - Germany: (BB), OIE 20100213.0508\n2009\n----\nBrucellosis, swine hunters -
