Both microbiological aspects (such as the prevalence of milk-borne pathogens, pathogen growth inhibition by antimicrobial systems and by lactic acid producing bacteria, probiotic bacteria, etc) and nutritional or health aspects (nutritional value, immunity, allergies, lactose intolerance, diabetes, milk digestibility, etc) are considered.\n\n\"As such, it is demonstrated that consumption of raw milk poses a realistic health threat due to a possible contamination with human pathogens. It is therefore strongly recommended that milk should be heated before consumption. With the exception of an altered organoleptic profile [taste], heating (in particular ultra high temperature and similar treatments) will not substantially change the nutritional value of raw milk or other benefits associated with raw milk consumption.\n\n\"Introduction\n------------\n\"The consumption of raw milk is not well-documented, but in the context of the current trend toward 'consuming natural' and 'purchasing locally,' raw milk consumption is becoming more popular. This is nourished by the perception that heating destroys the nutritional and health benefits of milk, and can even induce some detrimental effects. However, due to its high nutritional value together with the neutral pH and high water activity [content?], raw milk serves as an excellent growth medium for different micro-organisms, whose multiplication depends mainly on temperature and on competing micro-organisms and their metabolic products. In order to guarantee its microbial safety and to prolong its shelf-life, milk is heat treated.\n\n\"The impact of milk pasteurization on public health can be clearly illustrated by means of historical data. Before 1938, an estimated 25 percent of all foodborne and waterborne disease outbreaks in the USA were associated with milk, whereas nowadays, the percentage of such outbreaks associated with milk is estimated to be below 1 percent. Between 1880 and 1907, 29 milk-borne outbreaks were reported on average each year in the USA. With the adoption of pasteurization in 1938, milk-borne diseases dropped to only 46 outbreaks during the 19-year period from 1973 to 1992, corresponding to an average of 2.4 outbreaks each year. A recent report of the USA CDC indicates that the vast majority of milk-borne outbreaks in the USA are in states that permit the sale of raw milk. In England and Wales, the great majority of milk-borne outbreaks during the 1980s were attributed to the consumption of raw milk. In Scotland, a similar situation existed until the sale of unpasteurized milk was prohibited in 1983, which led to a significant drop of the incidence of diseases related to liquid milk consumption.\n\n\"In the mid-20th century, the main illnesses associated with raw milk consumption were brucellosis and tuberculosis. These have been eradicated as milk-borne diseases in developed countries, mainly through herd certification programs which included culling of infected animals, the installation of refrigerated bulk tanks for milk collection on farms, and the introduction of pasteurization. In the past, pasteurization conditions were standardized based on the destruction of _Mycobacterium bovis_, a relatively heat-resistant non-sporogenic bacterium that formerly was among the most serious pathogenic bacteria present in milk. Pasteurization standards today are based upon the destruction of _Coxiella burnetii_, the most heat-resistant milk-borne zoonotic pathogen known. In the past 30 years, several previously unrecognized foodborne bacterial infections, including infection with _Campylobacter jejuni_, _Listeria monocytogenes_, and _Escherichia coli_ strain O157 (or more general verocytotoxin-producing pathogenic _E. coli_ [VTEC]), have emerged as significant causes of human morbidity and mortality. Pathogens mainly present in raw milk today are, among others, _C. jejuni_, _Salmonella_ spp., _Staphylococcus aureus_, _Listeria monocytogenes_, pathogenic _E. coli_ and _Yersinia enterocolitica_.\n\n\"In Europe, the current regulatory microbial criteria for raw cow milk are less than or equal to 100 000 colony forming units (cfu)/ml for plate count (at 30 deg C/86 deg F) and less than or equal to 400 000 cfu/ml for somatic cells, as is stipulated in Regulation (EC) 853/2004 laying down specific hygiene rules on the hygiene of foodstuffs. In this Regulation, health requirements for production animals and hygienic requirements on milk production holdings (such as regarding premises and equipment, hygiene during milking, collection, and transport, staff hygiene) are established as well. In general, raw milk intended for human consumption must meet the requirements of the General Food Law (Regulation (EC) 178/2002) and be free of pathogens. Even though improvements in hygiene resulted in routine production of raw cow milk with less than 20 000 cfu (total flora)/ml), this does not guarantee raw milk to be free of pathogens. In approximately 1-6 percent of the human outbreaks reported in developed countries, milk has been identified as the vehicle of infection. An overview of foodborne disease reports from different industrialized countries indicates that milk and milk products are implicated in 1-5 percent of the total bacterial foodborne outbreaks, with 39.1 percent attributed to milk, 53.1 percent to cheese, and 7.8 percent to other milk products.\n\n\"Whereas milk quality and safety has been the topic of many research studies, raw milk still continues to be an issue for debate, which is primarily held on the internet where often non-scientifically based information circulates. Therefore, the aim of this study is to evaluate the risks and benefits related to the consumption of raw cow milk at one hand, and to evaluate the effect of heat treatments of milk on these risks and benefits on the other hand, considering the microbiological as well as the nutritional (health) aspects.\n\n\"Conclusions\n-----------\n\"In this evaluation it is clearly demonstrated that the consumption of raw milk poses a realistic and unnecessary health threat because of its possible contamination with pathogenic bacteria. It is therefore recommended to heat [raw] milk before consumption, especially when served to young children, pregnant women, or any person suffering from a chronic disease or a suppressed immune system. In this context the attention is drawn to raw milk provided on farms to the general public (such as during a school visit) and raw milk distributors allowing the automatic supply of raw milk from a bulk reservoir to the consumer.\n\n\"Historical data show that the pasteurization of milk has led to improved public health, and more recent data on occasional raw milk consumption indicate the hazard of bacterial infections, which could be avoided by a heat treatment. At present, thermal treatment remains the most frequently used and most effective method to increase the microbiological safety of milk without substantially changing the nutritional value of milk or other benefits associated with raw milk consumption. Table 4 [see source URL above] summarizes the main (claimed) benefits of raw milk consumption and the (claimed) detrimental effects of heating discussed in the present paper. Almost all arguments put forward by raw milk proponents for not heating milk, can be refuted, and the only substantial disadvantage of heating is the change in the organoleptic profile [taste] of milk. It is clear that this 'detrimental' effect of heating does not countervail the risk posed by raw milk consumption, namely of a milk-borne pathogen infection, which can have serious health consequences.\" - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nBrucellosis - Israel (03): camel milk, human infection confirmed, spread 20160817.4423219\nBrucellosis - Israel (02): camel milk, human infection susp, RFI 20160814.4416170\nBrucellosis - Israel: camel milk, multiple contaminants, recalls, RFI 20160814.4414452\nListeriosis - France: (LR) unpasteurized cheese, recall 20160723.4365160\nCampylobacteriosis - USA: (UT) unpasteurized milk, 2014 20160401.4131443\nListeriosis - USA (02): (FL, CA) fatal, unpasteurized milk, club membership, 2014 20160320.4107103\nSalmonellosis - USA (04): (CA) unpasteurized Mexican-style soft cheeses 20160318.4104009\nFoodborne illness - USA: (WV) susp. unpasteurized milk, state legislators 20160313.4089612\nBrucellosis - USA: (TX) unpasteurized cheese, alert 20160311.4085659\nBrucellosis - Israel: (HD) melitensis, bovine, human, RFI 20160302.4061936\nE. coli EHEC - USA (05): (CA) O157, unpasteurized milk, alert, recall 20160224.4047551\n2015\n----\nE. coli EHEC - USA (19): (CA) O111, unpasteurized apple juice, alert, recall 20151107.3774944\nCampylobacteriosis, E. coli EHEC - USA (02): (ID) unpasteurized milk 20151030.3755260\nCampylobacteriosis - USA: (CA) unpasteurized milk 20150327.3258683\nUnpasteurized milk - Ireland: infection risk 20150312.3224170\n2014\n----\nUnpasteurized milk - USA: infection risk, 2007-2012 20141224.3051804\nE. coli EHEC - Australia (02): (VI) unpasteurized cosmetic milk 20141213.3031852\nE. coli EHEC - Australia: (VI) unpasteurized milk, fatality 20141211.3027818\nE. coli EHEC - UK (15): O157, unpasteurized milk, alert 20141107.2936836\nE. coli EHEC - Canada (06): (ON) O157, unpasteurized cider, alert, recall 20141101.2920416\nE. coli EHEC - UK (13): (England) unpasteurized milk, alert, recall 20141005.2826830\nE. coli EHEC - USA (27): (KY) HUS cluster, unpasteurized milk 20140930.2817381\nCampylobacteriosis - USA (03): (UT) unpasteurized milk 20140827.2727937\nCampylobacteriosis - New Zealand: (CA) unpasteurized milk 20140329.2365370\n2013\n----\nUnpasteurized milk - USA: (MN) infection risk estimate 20131213.2114476\n.................................................ll/mj/arn/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "brucellosis", "salmonellosis", "tuberculosis", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2016-08-18 00:00:00", "1980-03-15 00:00:00", "2012-03-15 00:00:00", "1938-03-15 00:00:00", "1938-03-15 00:00:00", "1983-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-13 00:00:00", "2021-03-27 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "England", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "pH", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Dublin", "country": "Ireland"}, {"location": "Regulation", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Scotland", "country": "United Kingdom"}, {"location": "Israel", "country": "Israel"}, {"location": "Wales", "country": "Australia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4404332", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Brucellosis - Oman", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4404332", "date": "2016-08-19 17:07:39", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS - ISRAEL (04): CAMEL MILK, HUMAN INFECTION, COMMENT\n***************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 18 Aug 2016\nSource: Joshua Fierer <jfierer@ucsd.edu> [edited]\n\n\nLest we start feeling superior to Israel in this matter, so called certified raw milk is legally sold in at least 12 states in the USA, mostly in the west and the New England area. In California we have a long history of raw milk related illnesses. In the 1980's there was an epidemic of invasive _Salmonella enterica_ serotype Dublin infections, often in AIDS patients, who drank raw milk from a commercial dairy that advertised it as a health food. The irrational belief in raw milk as a health food is widely supported on the internet and public health people are said to be involved in a government conspiracy against users and suppliers.\n\n--\nJoshua Fierer, MD\nProfessor of Medicine\nUC San Diego School of Medicine\n<jfierer@ucsd.edu>\n\n[ProMED thanks Dr Fierer for his comment. I saw cases of _S._ Dublin associated with unpasteurized milk from the Altadena Dairy during my ID fellowship at Stanford 1974-1976.\n\nIn the March 2012 issue of Emerging Infectious Diseases (Langer AJ, Ayers T, Grass J, et al: Nonpasteurized dairy products, disease outbreaks, and state laws -- United States, 1993-2006. Emerg Infect Dis 2012; 18(3): 385-91; available at http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/18/3/11-1370_article.htm), the authors reported on 121 foodborne outbreaks (with 4413 cases of reported illness) caused by contaminated dairy products, and 73 (60 percent) were involved with unpasteurized dairy products; 65 (54 percent) involved cheese, 42 percent made from unpasteurized milk; and 56 involved fluid milk, 82 percent involving unpasteurized milk. In these outbreaks, _Campylobacter_ was responsible for 54 percent of the outbreaks, following by _Salmonella_ spp (22 percent), enterohemorrhagic _E. coli_ (13 percent), _Brucella_ spp (4 percent), _Listeria_ spp (4 percent), and _Shigella_ spp (3 percent).\n\nA recently published paper (Claeys WL, Cardoen S, Daube G, et al: Raw or heated cow milk consumption: Review of risks and benefits. Food Control 2013; 31(1): 251-62) is available at http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.foodcont.2012.09.035. It addresses the arguments that pasteurization removes significant nutrients from milk.\n\nThe abstract, introduction, and conclusions are given below with the citations removed.\n\n\"Abstract\n---------\n\"In the context of the prevailing trend toward more natural products, there seems to be an increasing preference for raw milk consumption as raw milk is associated with several perceived health benefits that are believed to be destroyed upon heating. However, many human pathogens can be isolated from raw cow milk. The prevalence of foodborne pathogens in raw cow milk varies, but their presence has been demonstrated in many surveys, and foodborne infections have been repeatedly reported for _Campylobacter_, _Salmonella_ spp and human pathogenic verocytotoxin-producing _Escherichia coli_ [VTEC]. In industrialized countries, milk-borne and milk product-borne outbreaks represent 2-6 percent of the bacterial foodborne outbreaks.\n\n\"The aim of this review is to present scientifically sound data regarding the risks and benefits related to the consumption of raw and heated cow milk. Both microbiological aspects (such as the prevalence of milk-borne pathogens, pathogen growth inhibition by antimicrobial systems and by lactic acid producing bacteria, probiotic bacteria, etc) and nutritional or health aspects (nutritional value, immunity, allergies, lactose intolerance, diabetes, milk digestibility, etc) are considered.\n\n\"As such, it is demonstrated that consumption of raw milk poses a realistic health threat due to a possible contamination with human pathogens. It is therefore strongly recommended that milk should be heated before consumption. With the exception of an altered organoleptic profile [taste], heating (in particular ultra high temperature and similar treatments) will not substantially change the nutritional value of raw milk or other benefits associated with raw milk consumption.\n\n\"Introduction\n------------\n\"The consumption of raw milk is not well-documented, but in the context of the current trend toward 'consuming natural' and 'purchasing locally,' raw milk consumption is becoming more popular. This is nourished by the perception that heating destroys the nutritional and health benefits of milk, and can even induce some detrimental effects. However, due to its high nutritional value together with the neutral pH and high water activity [content?], raw milk serves as an excellent growth medium for different micro-organisms, whose multiplication depends mainly on temperature and on competing micro-organisms and their metabolic products. In order to guarantee its microbial safety and to prolong its shelf-life, milk is heat treated.\n\n\"The impact of milk pasteurization on public health can be clearly illustrated by means of historical data. Before 1938, an estimated 25 percent of all foodborne and waterborne disease outbreaks in the USA were associated with milk, whereas nowadays, the percentage of such outbreaks associated with milk is estimated to be below 1 percent. Between 1880 and 1907, 29 milk-borne outbreaks were reported on average each year in the USA. With the adoption of pasteurization in 1938, milk-borne diseases dropped to only 46 outbreaks during the 19-year period from 1973 to 1992, corresponding to an average of 2.4 outbreaks each year. A recent report of the USA CDC indicates that the vast majority of milk-borne outbreaks in the USA are in states that permit the sale of raw milk. In England and Wales, the great majority of milk-borne outbreaks during the 1980s were attributed to the consumption of raw milk. In Scotland, a similar situation existed until the sale of unpasteurized milk was prohibited in 1983, which led to a significant drop of the incidence of diseases related to liquid milk consumption.\n\n\"In the mid-20th century, the main illnesses associated with raw milk consumption were brucellosis and tuberculosis. These have been eradicated as milk-borne diseases in developed countries, mainly through herd certification programs which included culling of infected animals, the installation of refrigerated bulk tanks for milk collection on farms, and the introduction of pasteurization. In the past, pasteurization conditions were standardized based on the destruction of _Mycobacterium bovis_, a relatively heat-resistant non-sporogenic bacterium that formerly was among the most serious pathogenic bacteria present in milk. Pasteurization standards today are based upon the destruction of _Coxiella burnetii_, the most heat-resistant milk-borne zoonotic pathogen known. In the past 30 years, several previously unrecognized foodborne bacterial infections, including infection with _Campylobacter jejuni_, _Listeria monocytogenes_, and _Escherichia coli_ strain O157 (or more general verocytotoxin-producing pathogenic _E. coli_ [VTEC]), have emerged as significant causes of human morbidity and mortality. Pathogens mainly present in raw milk today are, among others, _C. jejuni_, _Salmonella_ spp., _Staphylococcus aureus_, _Listeria monocytogenes_, pathogenic _E. coli_ and _Yersinia enterocolitica_.\n\n\"In Europe, the current regulatory microbial criteria for raw cow milk are less than or equal to 100 000 colony forming units (cfu)/ml for plate count (at 30 deg C/86 deg F) and less than or equal to 400 000 cfu/ml for somatic cells, as is stipulated in Regulation (EC) 853/2004 laying down specific hygiene rules on the hygiene of foodstuffs. In this Regulation, health requirements for production animals and hygienic requirements on milk production holdings (such as regarding premises and equipment, hygiene during milking, collection, and transport, staff hygiene) are established as well. In general, raw milk intended for human consumption must meet the requirements of the General Food Law (Regulation (EC) 178/2002) and be free of pathogens. Even though improvements in hygiene resulted in routine production of raw cow milk with less than 20 000 cfu (total flora)/ml), this does not guarantee raw milk to be free of pathogens. In approximately 1-6 percent of the human outbreaks reported in developed countries, milk has been identified as the vehicle of infection. An overview of foodborne disease reports from different industrialized countries indicates that milk and milk products are implicated in 1-5 percent of the total bacterial foodborne outbreaks, with 39.1 percent attributed to milk, 53.1 percent to cheese, and 7.8 percent to other milk products.\n\n\"Whereas milk quality and safety has been the topic of many research studies, raw milk still continues to be an issue for debate, which is primarily held on the internet where often non-scientifically based information circulates. Therefore, the aim of this study is to evaluate the risks and benefits related to the consumption of raw cow milk at one hand, and to evaluate the effect of heat treatments of milk on these risks and benefits on the other hand, considering the microbiological as well as the nutritional (health) aspects.\n\n\"Conclusions\n-----------\n\"In this evaluation it is clearly demonstrated that the consumption of raw milk poses a realistic and unnecessary health threat because of its possible contamination with pathogenic bacteria. It is therefore recommended to heat [raw] milk before consumption, especially when served to young children, pregnant women, or any person suffering from a chronic disease or a suppressed immune system. In this context the attention is drawn to raw milk provided on farms to the general public (such as during a school visit) and raw milk distributors allowing the automatic supply of raw milk from a bulk reservoir to the consumer.\n\n\"Historical data show that the pasteurization of milk has led to improved public health, and more recent data on occasional raw milk consumption indicate the hazard of bacterial infections, which could be avoided by a heat treatment. At present, thermal treatment remains the most frequently used and most effective method to increase the microbiological safety of milk without substantially changing the nutritional value of milk or other benefits associated with raw milk consumption. Table 4 [see source URL above] summarizes the main (claimed) benefits of raw milk consumption and the (claimed) detrimental effects of heating discussed in the present paper. Almost all arguments put forward by raw milk proponents for not heating milk, can be refuted, and the only substantial disadvantage of heating is the change in the organoleptic profile [taste] of milk. It is clear that this 'detrimental' effect of heating does not countervail the risk posed by raw milk consumption, namely of a milk-borne pathogen infection, which can have serious health consequences.\" - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nBrucellosis - Israel (03): camel milk, human infection confirmed, spread 20160817.4423219\nBrucellosis - Israel (02): camel milk, human infection susp, RFI 20160814.4416170\nBrucellosis - Israel: camel milk, multiple contaminants, recalls, RFI 20160814.4414452\nListeriosis - France: (LR) unpasteurized cheese, recall 20160723.4365160\nCampylobacteriosis - USA: (UT) unpasteurized milk, 2014 20160401.4131443\nListeriosis - USA (02): (FL, CA) fatal, unpasteurized milk, club membership, 2014 20160320.4107103\nSalmonellosis - USA (04): (CA) unpasteurized Mexican-style soft cheeses 20160318.4104009\nFoodborne illness - USA: (WV) susp. unpasteurized milk, state legislators 20160313.4089612\nBrucellosis - USA: (TX) unpasteurized cheese, alert 20160311.4085659\nBrucellosis - Israel: (HD) melitensis, bovine, human, RFI 20160302.4061936\nE. coli EHEC - USA (05): (CA) O157, unpasteurized milk, alert, recall 20160224.4047551\n2015\n----\nE. coli EHEC - UK (13): (England) unpasteurized milk, alert, recall 20141005.2826830\nE. coli EHEC - USA (27): (KY) HUS cluster, unpasteurized milk 20140930.2817381\nCampylobacteriosis - USA (03): (UT) unpasteurized milk 20140827.2727937\nCampylobacteriosis - New Zealand: (CA) unpasteurized milk 20140329.2365370\n2013\n----\nUnpasteurized milk - USA: (MN) infection risk estimate 20131213.2114476\n.................................................ll/mj/arn/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "brucellosis", "salmonellosis", "tuberculosis", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2016-08-18 00:00:00", "1980-03-15 00:00:00", "2012-03-15 00:00:00", "1938-03-15 00:00:00", "1938-03-15 00:00:00", "1983-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-13 00:00:00", "2021-03-27 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "England", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "pH", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Dublin", "country": "Ireland"}, {"location": "Regulation", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Scotland", "country": "United Kingdom"}, {"location": "Israel", "country": "Israel"}, {"location": "Wales", "country": "Australia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4288677", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Brucellosis - Emerg Infect Dis 2012; 18(3): 385-91; available at http://wwwnc.cdc.gov/eid/article/18/3/11-1370_article.htm), the authors reported on 121 foodborne outbreaks (with 4413 cases of reported illness) caused by contaminated dairy products, and 73 (60 percent) were involved with unpasteurized dairy products; 65 (54 percent) involved cheese, 42 percent made from unpasteurized milk; and 56 involved fluid milk, 82 percent involving unpasteurized milk. In these outbreaks, _Campylobacter_ was responsible for 54 percent of the outbreaks, following by _Salmonella_ spp (22 percent), enterohemorrhagic _E. coli_ (13 percent), _Brucella_ spp (4 percent), _Listeria_ spp (4 percent), and _Shigella_ spp (3 percent).\n\nA recently published paper (Claeys WL, Cardoen S, Daube G, et al: Raw or heated cow milk consumption: Review of risks and benefits. Food Control 2013; 31(1): 251-62) is available at http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.foodcont.2012.09.035. It addresses the arguments that pasteurization removes significant nutrients from milk.\n\nThe abstract, introduction, and conclusions are given below with the citations removed.\n\n\"Abstract\n---------\n\"In the context of the prevailing trend toward more natural products, there seems to be an increasing preference for raw milk consumption as raw milk is associated with several perceived health benefits that are believed to be destroyed upon heating. However, many human pathogens can be isolated from raw cow milk. Both microbiological aspects (such as the prevalence of milk-borne pathogens, pathogen growth inhibition by antimicrobial systems and by lactic acid producing bacteria, probiotic bacteria, etc) and nutritional or health aspects (nutritional value, immunity, allergies, lactose intolerance, diabetes, milk digestibility, etc) are considered.\n\n\"As such, it is demonstrated that consumption of raw milk poses a realistic health threat due to a possible contamination with human pathogens. It is therefore strongly recommended that milk should be heated before consumption. With the exception of an altered organoleptic profile [taste], heating (in particular ultra high temperature and similar treatments) will not substantially change the nutritional value of raw milk or other benefits associated with raw milk consumption.\n\n\"Introduction\n------------\n\"The consumption of raw milk is not well-documented, but in the context of the current trend toward 'consuming natural' and 'purchasing locally,' raw milk consumption is becoming more popular. This is nourished by the perception that heating destroys the nutritional and health benefits of milk, and can even induce some detrimental effects. However, due to its high nutritional value together with the neutral pH and high water activity [content?], raw milk serves as an excellent growth medium for different micro-organisms, whose multiplication depends mainly on temperature and on competing micro-organisms and their metabolic products. In order to guarantee its microbial safety and to prolong its shelf-life, milk is heat treated.\n\n\"The impact of milk pasteurization on public health can be clearly illustrated by means of historical data. Before 1938, an estimated 25 percent of all foodborne and waterborne disease outbreaks in the USA were associated with milk, whereas nowadays, the percentage of such outbreaks associated with milk is estimated to be below 1 percent. Between 1880 and 1907, 29 milk-borne outbreaks were reported on average each year in the USA. With the adoption of pasteurization in 1938, milk-borne diseases dropped to only 46 outbreaks during the 19-year period from 1973 to 1992, corresponding to an average of 2.4 outbreaks each year. A recent report of the USA CDC indicates that the vast majority of milk-borne outbreaks in the USA are in states that permit the sale of raw milk. In England and Wales, the great majority of milk-borne outbreaks during the 1980s were attributed to the consumption of raw milk. In Scotland, a similar situation existed until the sale of unpasteurized milk was prohibited in 1983, which led to a significant drop of the incidence of diseases related to liquid milk consumption.\n\n\"In the mid-20th century, the main illnesses associated with raw milk consumption were brucellosis and tuberculosis. These have been eradicated as milk-borne diseases in developed countries, mainly through herd certification programs which included culling of infected animals, the installation of refrigerated bulk tanks for milk collection on farms, and the introduction of pasteurization. In the past, pasteurization conditions were standardized based on the destruction of _Mycobacterium bovis_, a relatively heat-resistant non-sporogenic bacterium that formerly was among the most serious pathogenic bacteria present in milk. Pasteurization standards today are based upon the destruction of _Coxiella burnetii_, the most heat-resistant milk-borne zoonotic pathogen known. Pathogens mainly present in raw milk today are, among others, _C. jejuni_, _Salmonella_ spp., _Staphylococcus aureus_, _Listeria monocytogenes_, pathogenic _E. coli_ and _Yersinia enterocolitica_.\n\n\"In Europe, the current regulatory microbial criteria for raw cow milk are less than or equal to 100 000 colony forming units (cfu)/ml for plate count (at 30 deg C/86 deg F) and less than or equal to 400 000 cfu/ml for somatic cells, as is stipulated in Regulation (EC) 853/2004 laying down specific hygiene rules on the hygiene of foodstuffs. In this Regulation, health requirements for production animals and hygienic requirements on milk production holdings (such as regarding premises and equipment, hygiene during milking, collection, and transport, staff hygiene) are established as well. In general, raw milk intended for human consumption must meet the requirements of the General Food Law (Regulation (EC) 178/2002) and be free of pathogens. Even though improvements in hygiene resulted in routine production of raw cow milk with less than 20 000 cfu (total flora)/ml), this does not guarantee raw milk to be free of pathogens. In approximately 1-6 percent of the human outbreaks reported in developed countries, milk has been identified as the vehicle of infection. An overview of foodborne disease reports from different industrialized countries indicates that milk and milk products are implicated in 1-5 percent of the total bacterial foodborne outbreaks, with 39.1 percent attributed to milk, 53.1 percent to cheese, and 7.8 percent to other milk products.\n\n\"Whereas milk quality and safety has been the topic of many research studies, raw milk still continues to be an issue for debate, which is primarily held on the internet where often non-scientifically based information circulates. Therefore, the aim of this study is to evaluate the risks and benefits related to the consumption of raw cow milk at one hand, and to evaluate the effect of heat treatments of milk on these risks and benefits on the other hand, considering the microbiological as well as the nutritional (health) aspects.\n\n\"Conclusions\n-----------\n\"In this evaluation it is clearly demonstrated that the consumption of raw milk poses a realistic and unnecessary health threat because of its possible contamination with pathogenic bacteria. It is therefore recommended to heat [raw] milk before consumption, especially when served to young children, pregnant women, or any person suffering from a chronic disease or a suppressed immune system. In this context the attention is drawn to raw milk provided on farms to the general public (such as during a school visit) and raw milk distributors allowing the automatic supply of raw milk from a bulk reservoir to the consumer.\n\n\"Historical data show that the pasteurization of milk has led to improved public health, and more recent data on occasional raw milk consumption indicate the hazard of bacterial infections, which could be avoided by a heat treatment. At present, thermal treatment remains the most frequently used and most effective method to increase the microbiological safety of milk without substantially changing the nutritional value of milk or other benefits associated with raw milk consumption. Table 4 [see source URL above] summarizes the main (claimed) benefits of raw milk consumption and the (claimed) detrimental effects of heating discussed in the present paper. Almost all arguments put forward by raw milk proponents for not heating milk, can be refuted, and the only substantial disadvantage of heating is the change in the organoleptic profile [taste] of milk. It is clear that this 'detrimental' effect of heating does not countervail the risk posed by raw milk consumption, namely of a milk-borne pathogen infection, which can have serious health consequences.\" - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nBrucellosis - Israel (03): camel milk, human infection confirmed, spread 20160817.4423219\nBrucellosis - Israel (02): camel milk, human infection susp, RFI 20160814.4416170\nBrucellosis - New Zealand: (CA) unpasteurized milk 20140329.2365370\n2013\n----\nUnpasteurized milk - USA: (MN) infection risk estimate 20131213.2114476\n.................................................ll/mj/arn/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "brucellosis", "salmonellosis", "tuberculosis", "listeriosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2016-08-18 00:00:00", "1980-03-15 00:00:00", "2012-03-15 00:00:00", "1938-03-15 00:00:00", "1938-03-15 00:00:00", "1983-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-19 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-13 00:00:00", "2021-03-27 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "England", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "pH", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Yersinia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "MD", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Dublin", "country": "Ireland"}, {"location": "Regulation", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "California", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Scotland", "country": "United Kingdom"}, {"location": "Israel", "country": "Israel"}, {"location": "Wales", "country": "Australia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4235139", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Brucellosis, transmission dynamics - USA: (WY) elk, bison, cattle", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4235139", "date": "2015-12-12 18:02:06", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS, BOVINE - USA (02): (WYOMING)\n*****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 10 Dec 2015\nSource: Big Horn Radio Network [edited]\nhttp://www.mybighornbasin.com/Brucellosis-Found-in-Sublette-County-Herd/22264956\n\n\nBrucellosis Found in Sublette County Herd\n-----------------------------------------\nWyoming State Veterinarian Dr. Jim Logan has been notified that cultures are positive for field strain _Brucella abortus_ (brucellosis) in cows from one Sublette County cattle herd. Results were received Wednesday [9 Dec 2015] from the Wyoming State Veterinary Laboratory (WSVL) in Laramie. Logan, with concurrence of USDA-APHIS, has designated the herd from which the reactor cows originated as \"brucellosis affected\" as of Wed [9 Dec 2015].\n\nCattle from the Sublette County herd, located within Wyoming's Designated Surveillance Area (DSA), were positive to blood tests at the WSVL and the National Veterinary Services Laboratory (NVSL) in Ames, Iowa. Specified cattle from the DSA are required to be tested within 30 days prior to change of ownership or movement from counties within the DSA. The herd was quarantined on 19 Nov 2015 when preliminary tests were suspicious for brucellosis. The quarantine will remain in effect until the herd has undergone 3 consecutive, negative, whole-herd tests after any reactors have been removed from the herd.\n\nWhole-herd testing was conducted on the \"affected\" herd on 3 and 4 Dec 2015, and additional reactor animals were identified. There are 5 contact herds also under quarantine for herd testing. The contact herds will be released from quarantine if their herd tests are negative.\n\nThe testing is being conducted as a cooperative effort between herd owners, Wyoming Livestock Board (WLSB) personnel, and private veterinary practitioners. Epidemiologic interviews with herd owners are ongoing and quarantine herd plans will be developed with each herd owner associated with the case. Epidemiologic tracing will continue in the upcoming weeks by WLSB and APHIS personnel.\n\n\"Finding brucellosis in our DSA is not an unexpected event,\" said Logan. \"We have a reservoir of brucellosis in wildlife in northwest Wyoming that occasionally will spill over into cattle. Our producers do a good job of mitigating their risks and trying to prevent brucellosis in their cattle herds. This situation illustrates the value and effectiveness of our surveillance program in Wyoming. We believe we found this case before the disease spread to other areas, and we are dealing with it appropriately. At this time, we do not have verification that this case has resulted from wildlife exposure, but that is very likely. The epidemiological investigation will give us an answer with time. All of Wyoming's cases of brucellosis, from 2003 to 2011, have been verified as elk source exposure.\"\n\nLogan would like to thank all the producers and veterinarians in the area for their good cooperation in a very difficult situation. \"We expect to complete the initial stages of this response by the end of December [2015] with follow-up testing to occur in the ensuing months.\"\n\nThe WLSB also has one Park County herd under quarantine for a brucellosis case verified in mid-November [2015]. That herd has since undergone one negative herd test. The only contact herd in this case has been released from quarantine, having tested clean on a whole-herd test.\n\nFor further information, please contact Logan at 307-857-4140 or 307-421-1682.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This is Wyoming's 2nd case in a very short time.\n\nFor more information on brucellosis, readers are encouraged to read the moderator's comments on ProMED-mail posting 20151122.3811521. - Mod.TG\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/865.]\nSee Also\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA: (WY) 20151122.3811521\nBrucellosis, cervid - USA (02): (WY) surveillance in elk 20150921.3660083\nBrucellosis - Results were received Wednesday [9 Dec 2015] from the Wyoming State Veterinary Laboratory (WSVL) in Laramie. Logan, with concurrence of USDA-APHIS, has designated the herd from which the reactor cows originated as \"brucellosis affected\" as of Wed [9 Dec 2015].\n\nCattle from the Sublette County herd, located within Wyoming's Designated Surveillance Area (DSA), were positive to blood tests at the WSVL and the National Veterinary Services Laboratory (NVSL) in Ames, Iowa. Specified cattle from the DSA are required to be tested within 30 days prior to change of ownership or movement from counties within the DSA. The herd was quarantined on 19 Nov 2015 when preliminary tests were suspicious for brucellosis. The quarantine will remain in effect until the herd has undergone 3 consecutive, negative, whole-herd tests after any reactors have been removed from the herd.\n\nWhole-herd testing was conducted on the \"affected\" herd on 3 and 4 Dec 2015, and additional reactor animals were identified. There are 5 contact herds also under quarantine for herd testing. The contact herds will be released from quarantine if their herd tests are negative.\n\nThe testing is being conducted as a cooperative effort between herd owners, Wyoming Livestock Board (WLSB) personnel, and private veterinary practitioners. Epidemiologic interviews with herd owners are ongoing and quarantine herd plans will be developed with each herd owner associated with the case. Epidemiologic tracing will continue in the upcoming weeks by WLSB and APHIS personnel.\n\n\"Finding brucellosis in our DSA is not an unexpected event,\" said Logan. \"We have a reservoir of brucellosis in wildlife in northwest Wyoming that occasionally will spill over into cattle. Our producers do a good job of mitigating their risks and trying to prevent brucellosis in their cattle herds. This situation illustrates the value and effectiveness of our surveillance program in Wyoming. We believe we found this case before the disease spread to other areas, and we are dealing with it appropriately. At this time, we do not have verification that this case has resulted from wildlife exposure, but that is very likely. The epidemiological investigation will give us an answer with time. All of Wyoming's cases of brucellosis, from 2003 to 2011, have been verified as elk source exposure.\"\n\nLogan would like to thank all the producers and veterinarians in the area for their good cooperation in a very difficult situation. \"We expect to complete the initial stages of this response by the end of December [2015] with follow-up testing to occur in the ensuing months.\"\n\nThe WLSB also has one Park County herd under quarantine for a brucellosis case verified in mid-November [2015]. That herd has since undergone one negative herd test. The only contact herd in this case has been released from quarantine, having tested clean on a whole-herd test.\n\nFor further information, please contact Logan at 307-857-4140 or 307-421-1682.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This is Wyoming's 2nd case in a very short time.\n\nFor more information on brucellosis, readers are encouraged to read the moderator's comments on ProMED-mail posting 20151122.3811521. - USA: (TX) unpasteurized cheese, alert", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4085659", "date": "2015-12-12 18:02:06", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS, BOVINE - USA (02): (WYOMING)\n*****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 10 Dec 2015\nSource: Big Horn Radio Network [edited]\nhttp://www.mybighornbasin.com/Brucellosis-Found-in-Sublette-County-Herd/22264956\n\n\nBrucellosis Found in Sublette County Herd\n-----------------------------------------\nWyoming State Veterinarian Dr. Jim Logan has been notified that cultures are positive for field strain _Brucella abortus_ (brucellosis) in cows from one Sublette County cattle herd. Results were received Wednesday [9 Dec 2015] from the Wyoming State Veterinary Laboratory (WSVL) in Laramie. Logan, with concurrence of USDA-APHIS, has designated the herd from which the reactor cows originated as \"brucellosis affected\" as of Wed [9 Dec 2015].\n\nCattle from the Sublette County herd, located within Wyoming's Designated Surveillance Area (DSA), were positive to blood tests at the WSVL and the National Veterinary Services Laboratory (NVSL) in Ames, Iowa. Specified cattle from the DSA are required to be tested within 30 days prior to change of ownership or movement from counties within the DSA. The herd was quarantined on 19 Nov 2015 when preliminary tests were suspicious for brucellosis. The quarantine will remain in effect until the herd has undergone 3 consecutive, negative, whole-herd tests after any reactors have been removed from the herd.\n\nWhole-herd testing was conducted on the \"affected\" herd on 3 and 4 Dec 2015, and additional reactor animals were identified. There are 5 contact herds also under quarantine for herd testing. The contact herds will be released from quarantine if their herd tests are negative.\n\nThe testing is being conducted as a cooperative effort between herd owners, Wyoming Livestock Board (WLSB) personnel, and private veterinary practitioners. Epidemiologic interviews with herd owners are ongoing and quarantine herd plans will be developed with each herd owner associated with the case. Epidemiologic tracing will continue in the upcoming weeks by WLSB and APHIS personnel.\n\n\"Finding brucellosis in our DSA is not an unexpected event,\" said Logan. \"We have a reservoir of brucellosis in wildlife in northwest Wyoming that occasionally will spill over into cattle. Our producers do a good job of mitigating their risks and trying to prevent brucellosis in their cattle herds. This situation illustrates the value and effectiveness of our surveillance program in Wyoming. We believe we found this case before the disease spread to other areas, and we are dealing with it appropriately. At this time, we do not have verification that this case has resulted from wildlife exposure, but that is very likely. The epidemiological investigation will give us an answer with time. All of Wyoming's cases of brucellosis, from 2003 to 2011, have been verified as elk source exposure.\"\n\nLogan would like to thank all the producers and veterinarians in the area for their good cooperation in a very difficult situation. \"We expect to complete the initial stages of this response by the end of December [2015] with follow-up testing to occur in the ensuing months.\"\n\nThe WLSB also has one Park County herd under quarantine for a brucellosis case verified in mid-November [2015]. That herd has since undergone one negative herd test. The only contact herd in this case has been released from quarantine, having tested clean on a whole-herd test.\n\nFor further information, please contact Logan at 307-857-4140 or 307-421-1682.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This is Wyoming's 2nd case in a very short time.\n\nFor more information on brucellosis, readers are encouraged to read the moderator's comments on ProMED-mail posting 20151122.3811521. - USA (08): (MT), loss of status 20080905.2770\nBrucellosis, canine - USA: (MI) 20080814.2526\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA (07): (WY) 20080807.2427\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA (06): (WY) ex elk 20080727.2288\n.................................................sb/tg/je/jw", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "brucellosis", "rabies"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-17 00:00:00", "2015-12-15 00:00:00", "2015-12-15 00:00:00", "2015-11-19 00:00:00", "2015-12-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Sublette County Herd", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Iowa", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "SC", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Ames", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "WY", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Sublette County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "MT", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wyoming", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Park County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Ecuador", "country": "Ecuador"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4071885", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Brucellosis, cervid - USA: (WY) antibodies only", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4071885", "date": "2015-12-12 18:02:06", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS, BOVINE - USA (02): (WYOMING)\n*****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Thu 10 Dec 2015\nSource: Big Horn Radio Network [edited]\nhttp://www.mybighornbasin.com/Brucellosis-Found-in-Sublette-County-Herd/22264956\n\n\nBrucellosis Found in Sublette County Herd\n-----------------------------------------\nWyoming State Veterinarian Dr. Jim Logan has been notified that cultures are positive for field strain _Brucella abortus_ (brucellosis) in cows from one Sublette County cattle herd. Results were received Wednesday [9 Dec 2015] from the Wyoming State Veterinary Laboratory (WSVL) in Laramie. Logan, with concurrence of USDA-APHIS, has designated the herd from which the reactor cows originated as \"brucellosis affected\" as of Wed [9 Dec 2015].\n\nCattle from the Sublette County herd, located within Wyoming's Designated Surveillance Area (DSA), were positive to blood tests at the WSVL and the National Veterinary Services Laboratory (NVSL) in Ames, Iowa. Specified cattle from the DSA are required to be tested within 30 days prior to change of ownership or movement from counties within the DSA. The herd was quarantined on 19 Nov 2015 when preliminary tests were suspicious for brucellosis. The quarantine will remain in effect until the herd has undergone 3 consecutive, negative, whole-herd tests after any reactors have been removed from the herd.\n\nWhole-herd testing was conducted on the \"affected\" herd on 3 and 4 Dec 2015, and additional reactor animals were identified. There are 5 contact herds also under quarantine for herd testing. The contact herds will be released from quarantine if their herd tests are negative.\n\nThe testing is being conducted as a cooperative effort between herd owners, Wyoming Livestock Board (WLSB) personnel, and private veterinary practitioners. Epidemiologic interviews with herd owners are ongoing and quarantine herd plans will be developed with each herd owner associated with the case. Epidemiologic tracing will continue in the upcoming weeks by WLSB and APHIS personnel.\n\n\"Finding brucellosis in our DSA is not an unexpected event,\" said Logan. \"We have a reservoir of brucellosis in wildlife in northwest Wyoming that occasionally will spill over into cattle. Our producers do a good job of mitigating their risks and trying to prevent brucellosis in their cattle herds. This situation illustrates the value and effectiveness of our surveillance program in Wyoming. We believe we found this case before the disease spread to other areas, and we are dealing with it appropriately. At this time, we do not have verification that this case has resulted from wildlife exposure, but that is very likely. The epidemiological investigation will give us an answer with time. All of Wyoming's cases of brucellosis, from 2003 to 2011, have been verified as elk source exposure.\"\n\nLogan would like to thank all the producers and veterinarians in the area for their good cooperation in a very difficult situation. \"We expect to complete the initial stages of this response by the end of December [2015] with follow-up testing to occur in the ensuing months.\"\n\nThe WLSB also has one Park County herd under quarantine for a brucellosis case verified in mid-November [2015]. That herd has since undergone one negative herd test. The only contact herd in this case has been released from quarantine, having tested clean on a whole-herd test.\n\nFor further information, please contact Logan at 307-857-4140 or 307-421-1682.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[This is Wyoming's 2nd case in a very short time.\n\nFor more information on brucellosis, readers are encouraged to read the moderator's comments on ProMED-mail posting 20151122.3811521. - Mod.TG\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/865.]\nSee Also\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA: (WY) 20151122.3811521\nBrucellosis, cervid - USA (02): (WY) surveillance in elk 20150921.3660083\nBrucellosis - Algeria: (GR)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3850744", "date": "2015-11-02 11:57:01", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS - ISRAEL (03): (HADAROM) MELITENSIS, BOVINE, TEST REGIME, COMMENT, RFI\n**********************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 1 Nov 2015\nFrom: Nick Honhold <nichonhold.work@gmail.com> [edited]\n\n\n[re: ProMED-mail. Brucellosis - Israel (02): (HD) melitensis, bovine, human, RFI 20151031.3757610]\n---------------------------------------------------------------------\nIf there are 1350 lactating animals, bulk milk testing may not be effective at early detection of brucellosis because of the dilution factor. If I remember correctly, there is a maximum number of animals that should be included in the pooled sample (that is, the bulk milk) and I think I remember that this was around 250. 12 per cent infection would seem to breach this 1-in-250 detection level, but it may be some time since the last bulk milk test. It is possible that pooled samples are taken from sub-groups of cattle but if not, this might be at least a partial explanation.\n\n--\nNic Honhold\nEU Project Team Leader, Kosovo\n<nichonhold.work@gmail.com>\n\n[Nic Honhold's comment on the bulk milk testing sensitivity is appreciated. In the referenced posting we addressed the need to review the history of the testing regime in the affected herd. Such information, as well as details of the sampling regime applied in this and other dairy herds in Israel, is requested. In particular, concerning the adjustments applied to compensate for the dilution factor from bulk milk samples from large herds. - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/29822.]\nSee Also\nBrucellosis - Israel (02): (HD) melitensis, bovine, human, RFI 20151031.3757610\nBrucellosis - Israel 20150801.3550984\n2014\n---\nBrucellosis, human, caprine, ovine, camel - Israel: spread\n20140622.2558324\nBrucellosis, human - Israel: (HZ) RFI 20140607.2525983\nBrucellosis, human, livestock - Israel: (HZ) RFI 20140513.2467609\n.................................................arn/pg/mj/sh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "brucellosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "1350-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2014-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Israel", "country": "Israel"}, {"location": "Kosovo", "country": "Kosovo"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3840328", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Brucellosis - Israel (05): (HD) melitensis, bovine, spread", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3840328", "date": "2015-11-02 11:57:01", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS - ISRAEL (03): (HADAROM) MELITENSIS, BOVINE, TEST REGIME, COMMENT, RFI\n**********************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 1 Nov 2015\nFrom: Nick Honhold <nichonhold.work@gmail.com> [edited]\n\n\n[re: ProMED-mail. Brucellosis - Israel (02): (HD) melitensis, bovine, human, RFI 20151031.3757610]\n---------------------------------------------------------------------\nIf there are 1350 lactating animals, bulk milk testing may not be effective at early detection of brucellosis because of the dilution factor. If I remember correctly, there is a maximum number of animals that should be included in the pooled sample (that is, the bulk milk) and I think I remember that this was around 250. 12 per cent infection would seem to breach this 1-in-250 detection level, but it may be some time since the last bulk milk test. In the referenced posting we addressed the need to review the history of the testing regime in the affected herd. Such information, as well as details of the sampling regime applied in this and other dairy herds in Israel, is requested. Brucellosis - Israel (02): (HD) melitensis, bovine, human, RFI 20151031.3757610]\n---------------------------------------------------------------------\nIf there are 1350 lactating animals, bulk milk testing may not be effective at early detection of brucellosis because of the dilution factor. If I remember correctly, there is a maximum number of animals that should be included in the pooled sample (that is, the bulk milk) and I think I remember that this was around 250. 12 per cent infection would seem to breach this 1-in-250 detection level, but it may be some time since the last bulk milk test. It is possible that pooled samples are taken from sub-groups of cattle but if not, this might be at least a partial explanation.\n\n--\nNic Honhold\nEU Project Team Leader, Kosovo\n<nichonhold.work@gmail.com>\n\n[Nic Honhold's comment on the bulk milk testing sensitivity is appreciated. In the referenced posting we addressed the need to review the history of the testing regime in the affected herd. Such information, as well as details of the sampling regime applied in this and other dairy herds in Israel, is requested. In particular, concerning the adjustments applied to compensate for the dilution factor from bulk milk samples from large herds. - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/29822.]\nSee Also\nBrucellosis - Israel (02): (HD) melitensis, bovine, human, RFI 20151031.3757610\nBrucellosis - Israel 20150801.3550984\n2014\n---\nBrucellosis, human, caprine, ovine, camel - Israel: spread\n20140622.2558324\nBrucellosis, human - Israel: (HZ) RFI 20140607.2525983\nBrucellosis, human, livestock - Israel: (HZ) RFI 20140513.2467609\n.................................................arn/pg/mj/sh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "brucellosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "1350-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2014-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Israel", "country": "Israel"}, {"location": "Kosovo", "country": "Kosovo"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3811521", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Brucellosis, bovine - USA: (WY)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3811521", "date": "2015-11-02 11:57:01", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS - ISRAEL (03): (HADAROM) MELITENSIS, BOVINE, TEST REGIME, COMMENT, RFI\n**********************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 1 Nov 2015\nFrom: Nick Honhold <nichonhold.work@gmail.com> [edited]\n\n\n[re: ProMED-mail. Brucellosis - Israel (02): (HD) melitensis, bovine, human, RFI 20151031.3757610]\n---------------------------------------------------------------------\nIf there are 1350 lactating animals, bulk milk testing may not be effective at early detection of brucellosis because of the dilution factor. If I remember correctly, there is a maximum number of animals that should be included in the pooled sample (that is, the bulk milk) and I think I remember that this was around 250. 12 per cent infection would seem to breach this 1-in-250 detection level, but it may be some time since the last bulk milk test. It is possible that pooled samples are taken from sub-groups of cattle but if not, this might be at least a partial explanation.\n\n--\nNic Honhold\nEU Project Team Leader, Kosovo\n<nichonhold.work@gmail.com>\n\n[Nic Honhold's comment on the bulk milk testing sensitivity is appreciated. In the referenced posting we addressed the need to review the history of the testing regime in the affected herd. Such information, as well as details of the sampling regime applied in this and other dairy herds in Israel, is requested. In particular, concerning the adjustments applied to compensate for the dilution factor from bulk milk samples from large herds. - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/29822.]\nSee Also\nBrucellosis - Israel (02): (HD) melitensis, bovine, human, RFI 20151031.3757610\nBrucellosis - Israel 20150801.3550984\n2014\n---\nBrucellosis, human, caprine, ovine, camel - Israel: spread\n20140622.2558324\nBrucellosis, human - Israel: (HZ) RFI 20140607.2525983\nBrucellosis, human, livestock - Israel: (HZ) RFI 20140513.2467609\n.................................................arn/pg/mj/sh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "brucellosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "1350-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2014-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Israel", "country": "Israel"}, {"location": "Kosovo", "country": "Kosovo"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3768335", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Brucellosis - Uruguay: (CA) swine, OIE", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3768335", "date": "2015-11-02 11:57:01", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS - ISRAEL (03): (HADAROM) MELITENSIS, BOVINE, TEST REGIME, COMMENT, RFI\n**********************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 1 Nov 2015\nFrom: Nick Honhold <nichonhold.work@gmail.com> [edited]\n\n\n[re: ProMED-mail. Brucellosis - Israel (02): (HD) melitensis, bovine, human, RFI 20151031.3757610]\n---------------------------------------------------------------------\nIf there are 1350 lactating animals, bulk milk testing may not be effective at early detection of brucellosis because of the dilution factor. If I remember correctly, there is a maximum number of animals that should be included in the pooled sample (that is, the bulk milk) and I think I remember that this was around 250. 12 per cent infection would seem to breach this 1-in-250 detection level, but it may be some time since the last bulk milk test. It is possible that pooled samples are taken from sub-groups of cattle but if not, this might be at least a partial explanation.\n\n--\nNic Honhold\nEU Project Team Leader, Kosovo\n<nichonhold.work@gmail.com>\n\n[Nic Honhold's comment on the bulk milk testing sensitivity is appreciated. In the referenced posting we addressed the need to review the history of the testing regime in the affected herd. Such information, as well as details of the sampling regime applied in this and other dairy herds in Israel, is requested. In particular, concerning the adjustments applied to compensate for the dilution factor from bulk milk samples from large herds. - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/29822.]\nSee Also\nBrucellosis - Israel (02): (HD) melitensis, bovine, human, RFI 20151031.3757610\nBrucellosis - Israel 20150801.3550984\n2014\n---\nBrucellosis, human, caprine, ovine, camel - Israel: spread\n20140622.2558324\nBrucellosis, human - Israel: (HZ) RFI 20140607.2525983\nBrucellosis, human, livestock - Israel: (HZ) RFI 20140513.2467609\n.................................................arn/pg/mj/sh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "brucellosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "1350-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2014-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Israel", "country": "Israel"}, {"location": "Kosovo", "country": "Kosovo"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3762268", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Brucellosis - Israel (04): (HD) melitensis, bovine, official update, RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3762268", "date": "2015-11-02 11:57:01", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS - ISRAEL (03): (HADAROM) MELITENSIS, BOVINE, TEST REGIME, COMMENT, RFI\n**********************************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Sun 1 Nov 2015\nFrom: Nick Honhold <nichonhold.work@gmail.com> [edited]\n\n\n[re: ProMED-mail. Brucellosis - Israel (02): (HD) melitensis, bovine, human, RFI 20151031.3757610]\n---------------------------------------------------------------------\nIf there are 1350 lactating animals, bulk milk testing may not be effective at early detection of brucellosis because of the dilution factor. If I remember correctly, there is a maximum number of animals that should be included in the pooled sample (that is, the bulk milk) and I think I remember that this was around 250. 12 per cent infection would seem to breach this 1-in-250 detection level, but it may be some time since the last bulk milk test. It is possible that pooled samples are taken from sub-groups of cattle but if not, this might be at least a partial explanation.\n\n--\nNic Honhold\nEU Project Team Leader, Kosovo\n<nichonhold.work@gmail.com>\n\n[Nic Honhold's comment on the bulk milk testing sensitivity is appreciated. In the referenced posting we addressed the need to review the history of the testing regime in the affected herd. Such information, as well as details of the sampling regime applied in this and other dairy herds in Israel, is requested. Brucellosis - Israel (02): (HD) melitensis, bovine, human, RFI 20151031.3757610]\n---------------------------------------------------------------------\nIf there are 1350 lactating animals, bulk milk testing may not be effective at early detection of brucellosis because of the dilution factor. If I remember correctly, there is a maximum number of animals that should be included in the pooled sample (that is, the bulk milk) and I think I remember that this was around 250. 12 per cent infection would seem to breach this 1-in-250 detection level, but it may be some time since the last bulk milk test. Such information, as well as details of the sampling regime applied in this and other dairy herds in Israel, is requested. If I remember correctly, there is a maximum number of animals that should be included in the pooled sample (that is, the bulk milk) and I think I remember that this was around 250. 12 per cent infection would seem to breach this 1-in-250 detection level, but it may be some time since the last bulk milk test. 00:00:00", "1350-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2014-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Israel", "country": "Israel"}, {"location": "Kosovo", "country": "Kosovo"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3754050", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Brucellosis - Bulgaria (04): (KY, PV) melitensis, livestock, update, RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3754050", "date": "2015-08-20 00:40:45", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS - BULGARIA (03): (KJUSTENDIL, PLEVEN), LIVESTOCK, OIE\n*****************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 19 Aug 2015\nSource: OIE, WAHID weekly disease information 2015; 28(34) [edited]\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=18451\n\n\nBrucellosis (_Brucella melitensis_), Bulgaria\n-----------------------------------\nInformation received on [and dated] 19 Aug 2015 from Dr Damyan Iliev, Chief Veterinary Officer & Deputy Executive Director, Bulgarian Food Safety Agency, Ministry of Agriculture and Food, Sofia, Bulgaria\n\nSummary:\nReport type: Immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 27 Jul 2015\nDate of confirmation of the event: 28 Jul 2015\nReason for notification: Reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 2009\nManifestation of disease: Sub-clinical infection\nCausal agent: _Brucella melitensis_\nNature of diagnosis: Laboratory (basic)\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country.\n\nNew outbreaks (3)\nOutbreak 1: Rila, Kjustendil\nDate of start of the outbreak: 27 Jul 2015\nOutbreak status: Continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: Village\nAffected animals:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nCattle / 270 / 0 / 0 / 0 / 0\nGoats / 502 / 96 / 0 / 96 / 0\nEquidae / 20 / 0 / 0 / 0 / 0\nSheep / 317 / 0 / 0 / 0 / 0\n\nOutbreak 2: Smochevo, Rila, Kjustendil\nDate of start of the outbreak: 27 Jul 2015\nOutbreak status: Continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: Village\nAffected animals:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nCattle / 73 / 4 / 0 / 4 / 0\nGoats / 162 / 81 / 0 / 81 / 0\nSheep / 352 / 11 / 0 / 0 / 0\n\nOutbreak 3: Rakita, Cherven briag, Pleven\nDate of start of the outbreak: 27 Jul 2015\nOutbreak status: Continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: Farm\nAffected animals:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nGoats / 60 / 25 / 0 / 25 / 0\n\nSummary of outbreaks: Total outbreaks: 3\nTotal animals affected:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nCattle / 343 / 4 / 0 / 4 / 0\nGoats / 724 / 202 / 0 / 202 / 0\nEquidae / 20 / 0 / 0 / 20 / 0\nSheep / 669 / 11 / 0 / 11 / 0\n\nOutbreak statistics: [rates apparent, expressed as percentages]:\nSpecies / Apparent morbidity rate / Apparent mortality rate / Apparent case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nCattle / 1.17 / 0 / 0 / 1.17\nGoats / 27.90 / 0 / 0 / 27.90\nEquidae / 0 / 0 / - / 0\nSheep / 1.64 / 0 / 0 / 1.64\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction and/or slaughter\n\nEpidemiology:\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: Unknown or inconclusive\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: movement control inside the country; screening; disinfection/disinfestation; traceability; quarantine; surveillance outside containment and/or protection zone; official destruction of animal products; official disposal of carcasses, by-products and waste; surveillance within containment and/or protection zone; modified stamping out; no vaccination; no treatment of affected animals\n\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results:\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nNational Reference Laboratory (National laboratory) / Goats / antibody detection ELISA / 28 Jul 2015 / Positive\n\nFuture Reporting: The event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The following information was obtained from The Center for food security & Public Health, Iowa State University, Fact Sheet on \"Ovine and Caprine Brucellosis; _Brucella melitensis_,\" http://www.cfsph.iastate.edu/Factsheets/pdfs/brucellosis_melitensis.pdf:\n\n\"Caprine and ovine brucellosis, caused by the zoonotic bacterium _Brucella melitensis_, is an economically important cause of abortion in small ruminants. This infection causes significant losses from decreased productivity and lost trade in much of the developing world. _B. melitensis_ is considered to be a re-emerging pathogen in the Middle East. It has been eradicated from some nations, but the cost of surveillance to remain _B. melitensis_-free is significant.\n\n_B. melitensis_ is highly pathogenic for humans; this organism is considered to be the most severe human pathogen in the genus. Occupational exposure is seen in laboratory workers, farmers, veterinarians and others who contact infected animals or tissues. Brucellosis is one of the most easily acquired laboratory infections. People who do not work with animals or tissues usually become infected by ingesting unpasteurized dairy products. The Rev-1 _B. melitensis_ vaccine is also pathogenic for humans and must be handled with caution to avoid accidental injection or contamination of mucous membranes or abraded skin.\n\nAsymptomatic infections can occur in humans. In symptomatic cases, the disease is extremely variable, and the clinical signs may appear insidiously or abruptly. Typically, brucellosis begins as an acute febrile illness with nonspecific flu-like signs such as fever, headache, malaise, back pain, myalgia and generalized aches. Drenching sweats can occur, particularly at night. Some patients recover spontaneously, while others develop persistent symptoms that typically wax and wane. Occasionally seen complications include arthritis, spondylitis, chronic fatigue, and epididymo-orchitis. Neurologic signs (including personality changes, meningitis, uveitis and optic neuritis), anemia, internal abscesses, nephritis, endocarditis and dermatitis can also occur. Other organs and tissues can also be affected, resulting in a wide variety of syndromes.\n\nTreatment is with antibiotics; however, relapses can be seen months after the initial symptoms appear, even in successfully treated cases. The mortality rate is low; in untreated persons, estimates of the case fatality rate vary from less than 2 percent to 5 percent. Death is usually caused by endocarditis or meningitis.\"\n\nTo date, 13 individuals have been diagnosed with brucellosis in the municipality of Rila. Given the occurrence of _B. melitensis_ in Bulgaria, many of these cases could be directly associated with infected herds detected in this municipality. It is not known whether human cases have been detected in the district of Pleven. See ProMED-mail posts 20150806.3562337 and 20150801.3548663. - Mod.CRD\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/81.]\nSee Also\nBrucellosis - Bulgaria (02):
