00:40:45", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS - BULGARIA (03): (KJUSTENDIL, PLEVEN), LIVESTOCK, OIE\n*****************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Wed 19 Aug 2015\nSource: OIE, WAHID weekly disease information 2015; 28(34) [edited]\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=18451\n\n\nBrucellosis (_Brucella melitensis_), Bulgaria\n-----------------------------------\nInformation received on [and dated] 19 Aug 2015 from Dr Damyan Iliev, Chief Veterinary Officer & Deputy Executive Director, Bulgarian Food Safety Agency, Ministry of Agriculture and Food, Sofia, Bulgaria\n\nSummary:\nReport type: Immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 27 Jul 2015\nDate of confirmation of the event: 28 Jul 2015\nReason for notification: Reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: 2009\nManifestation of disease: Sub-clinical infection\nCausal agent: _Brucella melitensis_\nNature of diagnosis: Laboratory (basic)\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country.\n\nNew outbreaks (3)\nOutbreak 1: Rila, Kjustendil\nDate of start of the outbreak: 27 Jul 2015\nOutbreak status: Continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: Village\nAffected animals:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nCattle / 270 / 0 / 0 / 0 / 0\nGoats / 502 / 96 / 0 / 96 / 0\nEquidae / 20 / 0 / 0 / 0 / 0\nSheep / 317 / 0 / 0 / 0 / 0\n\nOutbreak 2: Smochevo, Rila, Kjustendil\nDate of start of the outbreak: 27 Jul 2015\nOutbreak status: Continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: Village\nAffected animals:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nCattle / 73 / 4 / 0 / 4 / 0\nGoats / 162 / 81 / 0 / 81 / 0\nSheep / 352 / 11 / 0 / 0 / 0\n\nOutbreak 3: Rakita, Cherven briag, Pleven\nDate of start of the outbreak: 27 Jul 2015\nOutbreak status: Continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: Farm\nAffected animals:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nGoats / 60 / 25 / 0 / 25 / 0\n\nSummary of outbreaks: Total outbreaks: 3\nTotal animals affected:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nCattle / 343 / 4 / 0 / 4 / 0\nGoats / 724 / 202 / 0 / 202 / 0\nEquidae / 20 / 0 / 0 / 20 / 0\nSheep / 669 / 11 / 0 / 11 / 0\n\nOutbreak statistics: [rates apparent, expressed as percentages]:\nSpecies / Apparent morbidity rate / Apparent mortality rate / Apparent case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nCattle / 1.17 / 0 / 0 / 1.17\nGoats / 27.90 / 0 / 0 / 27.90\nEquidae / 0 / 0 / - / 0\nSheep / 1.64 / 0 / 0 / 1.64\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction and/or slaughter\n\nEpidemiology:\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: Unknown or inconclusive\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: movement control inside the country; screening; disinfection/disinfestation; traceability; quarantine; surveillance outside containment and/or protection zone; official destruction of animal products; official disposal of carcasses, by-products and waste; surveillance within containment and/or protection zone; modified stamping out; no vaccination; no treatment of affected animals\n\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results:\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nNational Reference Laboratory (National laboratory) / Goats / antibody detection ELISA / 28 Jul 2015 / Positive\n\nFuture Reporting: The event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The following information was obtained from The Center for food security & Public Health, Iowa State University, Fact Sheet on \"Ovine and Caprine Brucellosis; _Brucella melitensis_,\" http://www.cfsph.iastate.edu/Factsheets/pdfs/brucellosis_melitensis.pdf:\n\n\"Caprine and ovine brucellosis, caused by the zoonotic bacterium _Brucella melitensis_, is an economically important cause of abortion in small ruminants. This infection causes significant losses from decreased productivity and lost trade in much of the developing world. _B. melitensis_ is considered to be a re-emerging pathogen in the Middle East. It has been eradicated from some nations, but the cost of surveillance to remain _B. melitensis_-free is significant.\n\n_B. melitensis_ is highly pathogenic for humans; this organism is considered to be the most severe human pathogen in the genus. Occupational exposure is seen in laboratory workers, farmers, veterinarians and others who contact infected animals or tissues. Brucellosis is one of the most easily acquired laboratory infections. People who do not work with animals or tissues usually become infected by ingesting unpasteurized dairy products. The Rev-1 _B. melitensis_ vaccine is also pathogenic for humans and must be handled with caution to avoid accidental injection or contamination of mucous membranes or abraded skin.\n\nAsymptomatic infections can occur in humans. In symptomatic cases, the disease is extremely variable, and the clinical signs may appear insidiously or abruptly. Typically, brucellosis begins as an acute febrile illness with nonspecific flu-like signs such as fever, headache, malaise, back pain, myalgia and generalized aches. Drenching sweats can occur, particularly at night. Some patients recover spontaneously, while others develop persistent symptoms that typically wax and wane. Occasionally seen complications include arthritis, spondylitis, chronic fatigue, and epididymo-orchitis. Neurologic signs (including personality changes, meningitis, uveitis and optic neuritis), anemia, internal abscesses, nephritis, endocarditis and dermatitis can also occur. Other organs and tissues can also be affected, resulting in a wide variety of syndromes.\n\nTreatment is with antibiotics; however, relapses can be seen months after the initial symptoms appear, even in successfully treated cases. The mortality rate is low; in untreated persons, estimates of the case fatality rate vary from less than 2 percent to 5 percent. Death is usually caused by endocarditis or meningitis.\"\n\nTo date, 13 individuals have been diagnosed with brucellosis in the municipality of Rila. Given the occurrence of _B. melitensis_ in Bulgaria, many of these cases could be directly associated with infected herds detected in this municipality. It is not known whether human cases have been detected in the district of Pleven. See ProMED-mail posts 20150806.3562337 and 20150801.3548663. - Mod.CRD\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/81.]\nSee Also\nBrucellosis - Bulgaria (02): This infection causes significant losses from decreased productivity and lost trade in much of the developing world. _B. melitensis_ is considered to be a re-emerging pathogen in the Middle East. It has been eradicated from some nations, but the cost of surveillance to remain _B. melitensis_-free is significant.\n\n_B. melitensis_ is highly pathogenic for humans; this organism is considered to be the most severe human pathogen in the genus. Occupational exposure is seen in laboratory workers, farmers, veterinarians and others who contact infected animals or tissues. Brucellosis is one of the most easily acquired laboratory infections. People who do not work with animals or tissues usually become infected by ingesting unpasteurized dairy products. The Rev-1 _B. melitensis_ vaccine is also pathogenic for humans and must be handled with caution to avoid accidental injection or contamination of mucous membranes or abraded skin.\n\nAsymptomatic infections can occur in humans. In symptomatic cases, the disease is extremely variable, and the clinical signs may appear insidiously or abruptly. Typically, brucellosis begins as an acute febrile illness with nonspecific flu-like signs such as fever, headache, malaise, back pain, myalgia and generalized aches. Drenching sweats can occur, particularly at night. Some patients recover spontaneously, while others develop persistent symptoms that typically wax and wane. Occasionally seen complications include arthritis, spondylitis, chronic fatigue, and epididymo-orchitis. Neurologic signs (including personality changes, meningitis, uveitis and optic neuritis), anemia, internal abscesses, nephritis, endocarditis and dermatitis can also occur. Other organs and tissues can also be affected, resulting in a wide variety of syndromes.\n\nTreatment is with antibiotics; however, relapses can be seen months after the initial symptoms appear, even in successfully treated cases. The mortality rate is low; in untreated persons, estimates of the case fatality rate vary from less than 2 percent to 5 percent. Death is usually caused by endocarditis or meningitis.\"\n\nTo date, 13 individuals have been diagnosed with brucellosis in the municipality of Rila. Given the occurrence of _B. melitensis_ in Bulgaria, many of these cases could be directly associated with infected herds detected in this municipality. It is not known whether human cases have been detected in the district of Pleven. See ProMED-mail posts 20150806.3562337 and 20150801.3548663. - Mod.CRD\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/81.]\nSee Also\nBrucellosis - Bulgaria (02): slaughter\n\nEpidemiology:\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: Unknown or inconclusive\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: movement control inside the country; screening; disinfection/disinfestation; traceability; quarantine; surveillance outside containment and/or protection zone; official destruction of animal products; official disposal of carcasses, by-products and waste; surveillance within containment and/or protection zone; modified stamping out; no vaccination; no treatment of affected animals\n\nMeasures to be applied: no other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results:\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nNational Reference Laboratory (National laboratory) / Goats / antibody detection ELISA / 28 Jul 2015 / Positive\n\nFuture This infection causes significant losses from decreased productivity and lost trade in much of the developing world. _B. melitensis_ is considered to be a re-emerging pathogen in the Middle East. It has been eradicated from some nations, but the cost of surveillance to remain _B. melitensis_-free is significant.\n\n_B. melitensis_ is highly pathogenic for humans; this organism is considered to be the most severe human pathogen in the genus. Occupational exposure is seen in laboratory workers, farmers, veterinarians and others who contact infected animals or tissues. Brucellosis is one of the most easily acquired laboratory infections. People who do not work with animals or tissues usually become infected by ingesting unpasteurized dairy products. The Rev-1 _B. melitensis_ vaccine is also pathogenic for humans and must be handled with caution to avoid accidental injection or contamination of mucous membranes or abraded skin.\n\nAsymptomatic infections can occur in humans. In symptomatic cases, the disease is extremely variable, and the clinical signs may appear insidiously or abruptly. Typically, brucellosis begins as an acute febrile illness with nonspecific flu-like signs such as fever, headache, malaise, back pain, myalgia and generalized aches. Drenching sweats can occur, particularly at night. Some patients recover spontaneously, while others develop persistent symptoms that typically wax and wane. Occasionally seen complications include arthritis, spondylitis, chronic fatigue, and epididymo-orchitis. Neurologic signs (including personality changes, meningitis, uveitis and optic neuritis), anemia, internal abscesses, nephritis, endocarditis and dermatitis can also occur. Other organs and tissues can also be affected, resulting in a wide variety of syndromes.\n\nTreatment is with antibiotics; however, relapses can be seen months after the initial symptoms appear, even in successfully treated cases. The mortality rate is low; in untreated persons, estimates of the case fatality rate vary from less than 2 percent to 5 percent. Death is usually caused by endocarditis or meningitis.\"\n\nTo date, 13 individuals have been diagnosed with brucellosis in the municipality of Rila. Given the occurrence of _B. melitensis_ in Bulgaria, many of these cases could be directly associated with infected herds detected in this municipality. It is not known whether human cases have been detected in the district of Pleven. See ProMED-mail posts 20150806.3562337 and 20150801.3548663. - Mod.CRD\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/81.]\nSee Also\nBrucellosis - Bulgaria (02): Bulgaria ex Greece 20050328.0896\n.................................................crd/msp/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "brucellosis", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2015-03-15 00:00:00", "2015-03-15 00:00:00", "2015-08-19 00:00:00", "2009-03-15 00:00:00", "2015-03-15 00:00:00", "2015-03-15 00:00:00", "2015-03-15 00:00:00", "2015-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Rila", "country": "Bulgaria"}, {"location": "Greece", "country": "Greece"}, {"location": "Georgia", "country": "Georgia"}, {"location": "Zoonoses", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "WAHID", "country": "Oman"}, {"location": "Bulgaria", "country": "Bulgaria"}, {"location": "Lagodechi", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3569017", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Brucellosis - Algeria: (BU) human, livestock", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3569017", "date": "2015-03-25 13:50:27", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS - RUSSIA: (TVER) CAPRINE, OVINE\n*******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 16 Mar 2015\nSource: Afanasiy Biznes [in Russian, trans. Mod.NR, edited]\nhttp://www.afanasy.biz/news/health/?ELEMENT_ID=82792\n\n\nTver veterinary laboratory specialists confirmed brucellosis in 7 out of 10 samples obtained from small ruminants in the village Danilovsk, Kalininsky district.\n\nThe information about the outbreak is being sent to the department of veterinary surveillance of the Tver and Pskov regions to initiate prevention measures addressing further spread of infection.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-RUS\n<promed-rus@promedmail.org>\n\n[The term \"small ruminants\", applied in the media report above, refers to goats (caprines) and sheep (ovines) combined. These 2 species share a common title name, also in several Middle Eastern countries, probably because many flocks are composed of both.\n\n_Brucella melitensis_ (biovars 1, 2, or 3) is the main causative agent of 'caprine and ovine brucellosis'. Sporadic cases caused by _B. abortus_ have been rarely observed in these species.\n\nClinically, the disease is characterised by one or more of the following signs: abortion, retained placenta, orchitis, epididymitis and, rarely, arthritis, with excretion of the organisms in uterine discharges and in milk. Diagnosis depends on the isolation of Brucella from abortion material, udder secretions or from tissues removed at post-mortem.\n\nPresumptive diagnosis of _Brucella_ infection can be made by assessing specific cell-mediated or serological responses to _Brucella_ antigens.\n\n_Brucella melitensis_ is highly pathogenic for humans, causing Malta fever, one of the most serious zoonoses in the world. All infected tissues, cultures, and potentially contaminated materials should therefore be handled at containment level 3. _B. melitensis_ is included in OIE list of reportable diseases/pathogens.\n\n_Brucella melitensis_ is endemic in the Mediterranean region, but infection is widespread world-wide. North America (except Mexico) is believed to be free from the agent, as are Northern and Central Europe, South-East Asia, Australia, and New Zealand. Southern and some central territories of the Russian Federation are long known to be infected by _B. melitensis_. The most recent Russian periodic report to the OIE, covering January-June 2014, mentions 19 new outbreaks (total of 30). In relation to the Tver oblast (north of Moscow; see maps at http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tver_Oblast#/media/File:Tver_in_Russia.svg and http://www.mapsofworld.com/images/russia-political-enlarged-map.jpg) the following information could be derived from OIE's WAHID system, covering the period January 2005-June 2014: _B. melitensis_ cases have been reported only during the period July-December 2009 (2 cases in sheep/goats, destroyed) and January-June 2010 (7 cases in seep/goats, destroyed).\n\nAccording to a 2013 paper (Ref 1), brucellosis is still reported from all types of farms and domestic livestock in Russia, including strains of _B. abortus_, _B. melitensis_, _B. suis_, and _B. ovis_. Between 1999 and 2009, the number of infected sites slightly increased, ranging from 54 in 2001 to 112 in 2009. The number of sites affected with _B. melitensis_ reportedly increased but remained low: 13 in 2004 and 21 in 2009 (see Fig. 2 \"Ovine brucellosis in the Russian Federation, 2003 to 2009\" in Ref 1). The current cases in Tver may be indicative of increased incidence.\n\n\"However\", the authors of Ref 1 say, \"relatively low number of brucellosis-infected areas does not diminish the epizootic and epidemic significance of sheep and goats in the transmission of brucellosis. Since the Soviet Union's dissolution at the beginning of the 1990s, social and economic changes in Russia have led to huge changes in the management and ownership of agricultural animals. About 80 percent of all sheep and goats, and more than 50 percent of all cattle, were transferred from state to private farms. New livestock owners were largely unable to implement costly anti-brucellosis measures. As these private farms now included multiple livestock species, favourable conditions arose for the transmission of _B. melitensis_ to cattle, leading to a dramatic rise in new cases of brucellosis in humans (adults and children), due to this pathogen. Over the last 2 decades, large and small animal brucellosis has become a considerable problem within the Southern Federal District, the Southern Volga region, and the Siberian Federal District.\"\n\n\"In recent years, the epizootic situation of brucellosis in Russia has been complicated by:\n- economic difficulties that led to drastic reductions in regulatory efforts to stem brucellosis,\n- less effective veterinary and customs controls in areas bordering brucellosis-infected territories (Azerbaijan, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Mongolia),\n- a decline in serological testing and vaccination of animals,\n- a reduction in microbiological evaluation of animal infection, leading to a lack of knowledge about the origin of infection,\n- a reduction in the ability to plan and implement brucellosis control policies in infected territories.\"\n\nAdditional updated information on brucellosis in animal and man is available in Ref 2.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. Denisov AA, Sclyarov OD, Salmakov KM, Shumilov KV: The Russian experience in brucellosis veterinary public health.\nRev sci tech Off int Epiz, 2013; 32(1): 229-37.\nhttp://web.oie.int/boutique/extrait/22denisov229237.pdf.\n2. Godfroid J, DeBolle X, Roop RM, O'Callaghan D, et al: The quest for a true One Health perspective of brucellosis\nRev sci tech Off int Epiz, 2014, 33(2): 521-38\nhttp://www.oie.int/doc/ged/D14086.PDF. - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/432.]\nSee Also\n2014\n----\nBrucellosis - Russia: (TL) ovine 20140405.2383709\n2012\n----\nBrucellosis - Russia: (VG), livestock, human, RFI 20121228.1473282\n2011\n----\nBrucellosis - Russia: (Dagestan), livestock, human, RFI 20111211.3572\nBrucellosis, human, livestock - Russia (02): (TU) 20111025.3175\nBrucellosis, human, livestock - Russia 20110606.1729\nBrucellosis - Russia: (BK) bovine source 20110505.1386\n2010\n----\nBrucellosis, human, livestock - Russia: (SR) RFI 20101206.4363\n2009\n----\nBrucellosis, livestock, human - Russia: (OM) 20090701.2380\nBrucellosis, ovine, bovine - Russia: (CV) 20090423.1530\nZoonotic disease trends 2007-2008 - Russia (02): brucellosis 20090103.0025\n2008\n----\nBrucellosis, ovine, human - Russia (Altai) 20080902.2749\nBrucellosis, ovine - Russia (Moscow ex Volgograd) (02) 20080318.1047\n2007\n----\nBrucellosis, ovine - Russia (Buryatia) 20070611.1903\nBrucellosis, ovine - Russia (Sverdlovsk region) 20070522.1639\nBrucellosis, ovine - Russia (Kaluga) 20070517.1572\nBrucellosis, ovine - Russia (Samara, Orenburg) 20070209.0510\n.................................................nr/arn/mj/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["brucellosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2013-03-15 00:00:00", "2001-03-15 00:00:00", "2009-03-15 00:00:00", "2004-03-15 00:00:00", "2009-03-15 00:00:00", "2003-03-15 00:00:00", "2013-03-15 00:00:00", "2014-03-15 00:00:00", "2014-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2009-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2007-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Malta", "country": "Malta"}, {"location": "Kyrgyzstan", "country": "Kyrgyzstan"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "Moscow", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "the Russian Federation", "country": "Uruguay"}, {"location": "the Soviet Union 's", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Volgograd", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Kalininsky", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Mongolia", "country": "Mongolia"}, {"location": "Azerbaijan", "country": "Azerbaijan"}, {"location": "Sverdlovsk", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Orenburg", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Mexico", "country": "Mexico"}, {"location": "Danilovsk", "country": "Belarus"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "New Zealand", "country": "New Zealand"}, {"location": "Samara", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Kazakhstan", "country": "Kazakhstan"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3562337", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Brucellosis - Bulgaria (02): (KY) human, caprine", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3562337", "date": "2015-03-25 13:50:27", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS - RUSSIA: (TVER) CAPRINE, OVINE\n*******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 16 Mar 2015\nSource: Afanasiy Biznes [in Russian, trans. Mod.NR, edited]\nhttp://www.afanasy.biz/news/health/?ELEMENT_ID=82792\n\n\nTver veterinary laboratory specialists confirmed brucellosis in 7 out of 10 samples obtained from small ruminants in the village Danilovsk, Kalininsky district.\n\nThe information about the outbreak is being sent to the department of veterinary surveillance of the Tver and Pskov regions to initiate prevention measures addressing further spread of infection.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-RUS\n<promed-rus@promedmail.org>\n\n[The term \"small ruminants\", applied in the media report above, refers to goats (caprines) and sheep (ovines) combined. These 2 species share a common title name, also in several Middle Eastern countries, probably because many flocks are composed of both.\n\n_Brucella melitensis_ (biovars 1, 2, or 3) is the main causative agent of 'caprine and ovine brucellosis'. Sporadic cases caused by _B. abortus_ have been rarely observed in these species.\n\nClinically, the disease is characterised by one or more of the following signs: abortion, retained placenta, orchitis, epididymitis and, rarely, arthritis, with excretion of the organisms in uterine discharges and in milk. Diagnosis depends on the isolation of Brucella from abortion material, udder secretions or from tissues removed at post-mortem.\n\nPresumptive diagnosis of _Brucella_ infection can be made by assessing specific cell-mediated or serological responses to _Brucella_ antigens.\n\n_Brucella melitensis_ is highly pathogenic for humans, causing Malta fever, one of the most serious zoonoses in the world. All infected tissues, cultures, and potentially contaminated materials should therefore be handled at containment level 3. _B. melitensis_ is included in OIE list of reportable diseases/pathogens.\n\n_Brucella melitensis_ is endemic in the Mediterranean region, but infection is widespread world-wide. North America (except Mexico) is believed to be free from the agent, as are Northern and Central Europe, South-East Asia, Australia, and New Zealand. Southern and some central territories of the Russian Federation are long known to be infected by _B. melitensis_. The most recent Russian periodic report to the OIE, covering January-June 2014, mentions 19 new outbreaks (total of 30). In relation to the Tver oblast (north of Moscow; see maps at http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tver_Oblast#/media/File:Tver_in_Russia.svg and http://www.mapsofworld.com/images/russia-political-enlarged-map.jpg) the following information could be derived from OIE's WAHID system, covering the period January 2005-June 2014: _B. melitensis_ cases have been reported only during the period July-December 2009 (2 cases in sheep/goats, destroyed) and January-June 2010 (7 cases in seep/goats, destroyed).\n\nAccording to a 2013 paper (Ref 1), brucellosis is still reported from all types of farms and domestic livestock in Russia, including strains of _B. abortus_, _B. melitensis_, _B. suis_, and _B. ovis_. Between 1999 and 2009, the number of infected sites slightly increased, ranging from 54 in 2001 to 112 in 2009. The number of sites affected with _B. melitensis_ reportedly increased but remained low: 13 in 2004 and 21 in 2009 (see Fig. 2 \"Ovine brucellosis in the Russian Federation, 2003 to 2009\" in Ref 1). The current cases in Tver may be indicative of increased incidence.\n\n\"However\", the authors of Ref 1 say, \"relatively low number of brucellosis-infected areas does not diminish the epizootic and epidemic significance of sheep and goats in the transmission of brucellosis. Since the Soviet Union's dissolution at the beginning of the 1990s, social and economic changes in Russia have led to huge changes in the management and ownership of agricultural animals. About 80 percent of all sheep and goats, and more than 50 percent of all cattle, were transferred from state to private farms. New livestock owners were largely unable to implement costly anti-brucellosis measures. As these private farms now included multiple livestock species, favourable conditions arose for the transmission of _B. melitensis_ to cattle, leading to a dramatic rise in new cases of brucellosis in humans (adults and children), due to this pathogen. Over the last 2 decades, large and small animal brucellosis has become a considerable problem within the Southern Federal District, the Southern Volga region, and the Siberian Federal District.\"\n\n\"In recent years, the epizootic situation of brucellosis in Russia has been complicated by:\n- economic difficulties that led to drastic reductions in regulatory efforts to stem brucellosis,\n- less effective veterinary and customs controls in areas bordering brucellosis-infected territories (Azerbaijan, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Mongolia),\n- a decline in serological testing and vaccination of animals,\n- a reduction in microbiological evaluation of animal infection, leading to a lack of knowledge about the origin of infection,\n- a reduction in the ability to plan and implement brucellosis control policies in infected territories.\"\n\nAdditional updated information on brucellosis in animal and man is available in Ref 2.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. Denisov AA, Sclyarov OD, Salmakov KM, Shumilov KV: The Russian experience in brucellosis veterinary public health.\nRev sci tech Off int Epiz, 2013; 32(1): 229-37.\nhttp://web.oie.int/boutique/extrait/22denisov229237.pdf.\n2. Godfroid J, DeBolle X, Roop RM, O'Callaghan D, et al: The quest for a true One Health perspective of brucellosis\nRev sci tech Off int Epiz, 2014, 33(2): 521-38\nhttp://www.oie.int/doc/ged/D14086.PDF. - Bulgaria: (KY) human, caprine", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3548663", "date": "2015-03-25 13:50:27", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS - RUSSIA: (TVER) CAPRINE, OVINE\n*******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 16 Mar 2015\nSource: Afanasiy Biznes [in Russian, trans. Mod.NR, edited]\nhttp://www.afanasy.biz/news/health/?ELEMENT_ID=82792\n\n\nTver veterinary laboratory specialists confirmed brucellosis in 7 out of 10 samples obtained from small ruminants in the village Danilovsk, Kalininsky district.\n\nThe information about the outbreak is being sent to the department of veterinary surveillance of the Tver and Pskov regions to initiate prevention measures addressing further spread of infection.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-RUS\n<promed-rus@promedmail.org>\n\n[The term \"small ruminants\", applied in the media report above, refers to goats (caprines) and sheep (ovines) combined. These 2 species share a common title name, also in several Middle Eastern countries, probably because many flocks are composed of both.\n\n_Brucella melitensis_ (biovars 1, 2, or 3) is the main causative agent of 'caprine and ovine brucellosis'. Sporadic cases caused by _B. abortus_ have been rarely observed in these species.\n\nClinically, the disease is characterised by one or more of the following signs: abortion, retained placenta, orchitis, epididymitis and, rarely, arthritis, with excretion of the organisms in uterine discharges and in milk. Diagnosis depends on the isolation of Brucella from abortion material, udder secretions or from tissues removed at post-mortem.\n\nPresumptive diagnosis of _Brucella_ infection can be made by assessing specific cell-mediated or serological responses to _Brucella_ antigens.\n\n_Brucella melitensis_ is highly pathogenic for humans, causing Malta fever, one of the most serious zoonoses in the world. All infected tissues, cultures, and potentially contaminated materials should therefore be handled at containment level 3. _B. melitensis_ is included in OIE list of reportable diseases/pathogens.\n\n_Brucella melitensis_ is endemic in the Mediterranean region, but infection is widespread world-wide. North America (except Mexico) is believed to be free from the agent, as are Northern and Central Europe, South-East Asia, Australia, and New Zealand. Southern and some central territories of the Russian Federation are long known to be infected by _B. melitensis_. The most recent Russian periodic report to the OIE, covering January-June 2014, mentions 19 new outbreaks (total of 30). In relation to the Tver oblast (north of Moscow; see maps at http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tver_Oblast#/media/File:Tver_in_Russia.svg and http://www.mapsofworld.com/images/russia-political-enlarged-map.jpg) the following information could be derived from OIE's WAHID system, covering the period January 2005-June 2014: _B. melitensis_ cases have been reported only during the period July-December 2009 (2 cases in sheep/goats, destroyed) and January-June 2010 (7 cases in seep/goats, destroyed).\n\nAccording to a 2013 paper (Ref 1), brucellosis is still reported from all types of farms and domestic livestock in Russia, including strains of _B. abortus_, _B. melitensis_, _B. suis_, and _B. ovis_. Between 1999 and 2009, the number of infected sites slightly increased, ranging from 54 in 2001 to 112 in 2009. The number of sites affected with _B. melitensis_ reportedly increased but remained low: 13 in 2004 and 21 in 2009 (see Fig. 2 \"Ovine brucellosis in the Russian Federation, 2003 to 2009\" in Ref 1). The current cases in Tver may be indicative of increased incidence.\n\n\"However\", the authors of Ref 1 say, \"relatively low number of brucellosis-infected areas does not diminish the epizootic and epidemic significance of sheep and goats in the transmission of brucellosis. Since the Soviet Union's dissolution at the beginning of the 1990s, social and economic changes in Russia have led to huge changes in the management and ownership of agricultural animals. About 80 percent of all sheep and goats, and more than 50 percent of all cattle, were transferred from state to private farms. New livestock owners were largely unable to implement costly anti-brucellosis measures. As these private farms now included multiple livestock species, favourable conditions arose for the transmission of _B. melitensis_ to cattle, leading to a dramatic rise in new cases of brucellosis in humans (adults and children), due to this pathogen. Over the last 2 decades, large and small animal brucellosis has become a considerable problem within the Southern Federal District, the Southern Volga region, and the Siberian Federal District.\"\n\n\"In recent years, the epizootic situation of brucellosis in Russia has been complicated by:\n- economic difficulties that led to drastic reductions in regulatory efforts to stem brucellosis,\n- less effective veterinary and customs controls in areas bordering brucellosis-infected territories (Azerbaijan, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Mongolia),\n- a decline in serological testing and vaccination of animals,\n- a reduction in microbiological evaluation of animal infection, leading to a lack of knowledge about the origin of infection,\n- a reduction in the ability to plan and implement brucellosis control policies in infected territories.\"\n\nAdditional updated information on brucellosis in animal and man is available in Ref 2.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. Denisov AA, Sclyarov OD, Salmakov KM, Shumilov KV: The Russian experience in brucellosis veterinary public health.\nRev sci tech Off int Epiz, 2013; 32(1): 229-37.\nhttp://web.oie.int/boutique/extrait/22denisov229237.pdf.\n2. Godfroid J, DeBolle X, Roop RM, O'Callaghan D, et al: The quest for a true One Health perspective of brucellosis\nRev sci tech Off int Epiz, 2014, 33(2): 521-38\nhttp://www.oie.int/doc/ged/D14086.PDF. - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/432.]\nSee Also\n2014\n----\nBrucellosis - Russia: (TL) ovine 20140405.2383709\n2012\n----\nBrucellosis - Russia: (VG), livestock, human, RFI 20121228.1473282\n2011\n----\nBrucellosis - Russia (Kaluga) 20070517.1572\nBrucellosis, ovine - Russia (Samara, Orenburg) 20070209.0510\n.................................................nr/arn/mj/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["brucellosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2013-03-15 00:00:00", "2001-03-15 00:00:00", "2009-03-15 00:00:00", "2004-03-15 00:00:00", "2009-03-15 00:00:00", "2003-03-15 00:00:00", "2013-03-15 00:00:00", "2014-03-15 00:00:00", "2014-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2009-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2007-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Malta", "country": "Malta"}, {"location": "Kyrgyzstan", "country": "Kyrgyzstan"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "Moscow", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "the Russian Federation", "country": "Uruguay"}, {"location": "the Soviet Union 's", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Volgograd", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Kalininsky", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Mongolia", "country": "Mongolia"}, {"location": "Azerbaijan", "country": "Azerbaijan"}, {"location": "Sverdlovsk", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Orenburg", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Mexico", "country": "Mexico"}, {"location": "Danilovsk", "country": "Belarus"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "New Zealand", "country": "New Zealand"}, {"location": "Samara", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Kazakhstan", "country": "Kazakhstan"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3525860", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Brucellosis - USA: (NY) imported, laboratory exposures", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3525860", "date": "2015-03-25 13:50:27", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS - RUSSIA: (TVER) CAPRINE, OVINE\n*******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 16 Mar 2015\nSource: Afanasiy Biznes [in Russian, trans. Mod.NR, edited]\nhttp://www.afanasy.biz/news/health/?ELEMENT_ID=82792\n\n\nTver veterinary laboratory specialists confirmed brucellosis in 7 out of 10 samples obtained from small ruminants in the village Danilovsk, Kalininsky district.\n\nThe information about the outbreak is being sent to the department of veterinary surveillance of the Tver and Pskov regions to initiate prevention measures addressing further spread of infection.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-RUS\n<promed-rus@promedmail.org>\n\n[The term \"small ruminants\", applied in the media report above, refers to goats (caprines) and sheep (ovines) combined. These 2 species share a common title name, also in several Middle Eastern countries, probably because many flocks are composed of both.\n\n_Brucella melitensis_ (biovars 1, 2, or 3) is the main causative agent of 'caprine and ovine brucellosis'. Sporadic cases caused by _B. abortus_ have been rarely observed in these species.\n\nClinically, the disease is characterised by one or more of the following signs: abortion, retained placenta, orchitis, epididymitis and, rarely, arthritis, with excretion of the organisms in uterine discharges and in milk. Diagnosis depends on the isolation of Brucella from abortion material, udder secretions or from tissues removed at post-mortem.\n\nPresumptive diagnosis of _Brucella_ infection can be made by assessing specific cell-mediated or serological responses to _Brucella_ antigens.\n\n_Brucella melitensis_ is highly pathogenic for humans, causing Malta fever, one of the most serious zoonoses in the world. All infected tissues, cultures, and potentially contaminated materials should therefore be handled at containment level 3. _B. melitensis_ is included in OIE list of reportable diseases/pathogens.\n\n_Brucella melitensis_ is endemic in the Mediterranean region, but infection is widespread world-wide. North America (except Mexico) is believed to be free from the agent, as are Northern and Central Europe, South-East Asia, Australia, and New Zealand. Southern and some central territories of the Russian Federation are long known to be infected by _B. melitensis_. The most recent Russian periodic report to the OIE, covering January-June 2014, mentions 19 new outbreaks (total of 30). In relation to the Tver oblast (north of Moscow; see maps at http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tver_Oblast#/media/File:Tver_in_Russia.svg and http://www.mapsofworld.com/images/russia-political-enlarged-map.jpg) the following information could be derived from OIE's WAHID system, covering the period January 2005-June 2014: _B. melitensis_ cases have been reported only during the period July-December 2009 (2 cases in sheep/goats, destroyed) and January-June 2010 (7 cases in seep/goats, destroyed).\n\nAccording to a 2013 paper (Ref 1), brucellosis is still reported from all types of farms and domestic livestock in Russia, including strains of _B. abortus_, _B. melitensis_, _B. suis_, and _B. ovis_. Between 1999 and 2009, the number of infected sites slightly increased, ranging from 54 in 2001 to 112 in 2009. The number of sites affected with _B. melitensis_ reportedly increased but remained low: 13 in 2004 and 21 in 2009 (see Fig. 2 \"Ovine brucellosis in the Russian Federation, 2003 to 2009\" in Ref 1). The current cases in Tver may be indicative of increased incidence.\n\n\"However\", the authors of Ref 1 say, \"relatively low number of brucellosis-infected areas does not diminish the epizootic and epidemic significance of sheep and goats in the transmission of brucellosis. Since the Soviet Union's dissolution at the beginning of the 1990s, social and economic changes in Russia have led to huge changes in the management and ownership of agricultural animals. About 80 percent of all sheep and goats, and more than 50 percent of all cattle, were transferred from state to private farms. New livestock owners were largely unable to implement costly anti-brucellosis measures. As these private farms now included multiple livestock species, favourable conditions arose for the transmission of _B. melitensis_ to cattle, leading to a dramatic rise in new cases of brucellosis in humans (adults and children), due to this pathogen. Over the last 2 decades, large and small animal brucellosis has become a considerable problem within the Southern Federal District, the Southern Volga region, and the Siberian Federal District.\"\n\n\"In recent years, the epizootic situation of brucellosis in Russia has been complicated by:\n- economic difficulties that led to drastic reductions in regulatory efforts to stem brucellosis,\n- less effective veterinary and customs controls in areas bordering brucellosis-infected territories (Azerbaijan, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Mongolia),\n- a decline in serological testing and vaccination of animals,\n- a reduction in microbiological evaluation of animal infection, leading to a lack of knowledge about the origin of infection,\n- a reduction in the ability to plan and implement brucellosis control policies in infected territories.\"\n\nAdditional updated information on brucellosis in animal and man is available in Ref 2.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. Denisov AA, Sclyarov OD, Salmakov KM, Shumilov KV: The Russian experience in brucellosis veterinary public health.\nRev sci tech Off int Epiz, 2013; 32(1): 229-37.\nhttp://web.oie.int/boutique/extrait/22denisov229237.pdf.\n2. Godfroid J, DeBolle X, Roop RM, O'Callaghan D, et al: The quest for a true One Health perspective of brucellosis\nRev sci tech Off int Epiz, 2014, 33(2): 521-38\nhttp://www.oie.int/doc/ged/D14086.PDF. - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/432.]\nSee Also\n2014\n----\nBrucellosis - Russia: (TL) ovine 20140405.2383709\n2012\n----\nBrucellosis - Russia: (VG), livestock, human, RFI 20121228.1473282\n2011\n----\nBrucellosis - Russia: (SR) RFI 20101206.4363\n2009\n----\nBrucellosis, livestock, human - Russia: (OM) 20090701.2380\nBrucellosis, ovine, bovine - Russia: (CV) 20090423.1530\nZoonotic disease trends 2007-2008 - Russia (02): brucellosis 20090103.0025\n2008\n----\nBrucellosis, ovine, human - Russia (Altai) 20080902.2749\nBrucellosis, ovine - Russia (Moscow ex Volgograd) (02) 20080318.1047\n2007\n----\nBrucellosis, ovine - Russia (Buryatia) 20070611.1903\nBrucellosis, ovine - Russia (Sverdlovsk region) 20070522.1639\nBrucellosis, ovine - Russia (Kaluga) 20070517.1572\nBrucellosis, ovine - Russia (Samara, Orenburg) 20070209.0510\n.................................................nr/arn/mj/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["brucellosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2013-03-15 00:00:00", "2001-03-15 00:00:00", "2009-03-15 00:00:00", "2004-03-15 00:00:00", "2009-03-15 00:00:00", "2003-03-15 00:00:00", "2013-03-15 00:00:00", "2014-03-15 00:00:00", "2014-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2009-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2007-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Malta", "country": "Malta"}, {"location": "Kyrgyzstan", "country": "Kyrgyzstan"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "Moscow", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "the Russian Federation", "country": "Uruguay"}, {"location": "the Soviet Union 's", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Volgograd", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Kalininsky", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Mongolia", "country": "Mongolia"}, {"location": "Azerbaijan", "country": "Azerbaijan"}, {"location": "Sverdlovsk", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Orenburg", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Mexico", "country": "Mexico"}, {"location": "Danilovsk", "country": "Belarus"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "New Zealand", "country": "New Zealand"}, {"location": "Samara", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Kazakhstan", "country": "Kazakhstan"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3417340", "headline": "PRO/AH> Brucellosis - UK ex Thailand: (NP)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3377052", "date": "2015-03-25 13:50:27", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS - RUSSIA: (TVER) CAPRINE, OVINE\n*******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 16 Mar 2015\nSource: Afanasiy Biznes [in Russian, trans. Mod.NR, edited]\nhttp://www.afanasy.biz/news/health/?ELEMENT_ID=82792\n\n\nTver veterinary laboratory specialists confirmed brucellosis in 7 out of 10 samples obtained from small ruminants in the village Danilovsk, Kalininsky district.\n\nThe information about the outbreak is being sent to the department of veterinary surveillance of the Tver and Pskov regions to initiate prevention measures addressing further spread of infection.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-RUS\n<promed-rus@promedmail.org>\n\n[The term \"small ruminants\", applied in the media report above, refers to goats (caprines) and sheep (ovines) combined. These 2 species share a common title name, also in several Middle Eastern countries, probably because many flocks are composed of both.\n\n_Brucella melitensis_ (biovars 1, 2, or 3) is the main causative agent of 'caprine and ovine brucellosis'. Sporadic cases caused by _B. abortus_ have been rarely observed in these species.\n\nClinically, the disease is characterised by one or more of the following signs: abortion, retained placenta, orchitis, epididymitis and, rarely, arthritis, with excretion of the organisms in uterine discharges and in milk. Diagnosis depends on the isolation of Brucella from abortion material, udder secretions or from tissues removed at post-mortem.\n\nPresumptive diagnosis of _Brucella_ infection can be made by assessing specific cell-mediated or serological responses to _Brucella_ antigens.\n\n_Brucella melitensis_ is highly pathogenic for humans, causing Malta fever, one of the most serious zoonoses in the world. All infected tissues, cultures, and potentially contaminated materials should therefore be handled at containment level 3. _B. melitensis_ is included in OIE list of reportable diseases/pathogens.\n\n_Brucella melitensis_ is endemic in the Mediterranean region, but infection is widespread world-wide. North America (except Mexico) is believed to be free from the agent, as are Northern and Central Europe, South-East Asia, Australia, and New Zealand. Southern and some central territories of the Russian Federation are long known to be infected by _B. melitensis_. The most recent Russian periodic report to the OIE, covering January-June 2014, mentions 19 new outbreaks (total of 30). In relation to the Tver oblast (north of Moscow; see maps at http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tver_Oblast#/media/File:Tver_in_Russia.svg and http://www.mapsofworld.com/images/russia-political-enlarged-map.jpg) the following information could be derived from OIE's WAHID system, covering the period January 2005-June 2014: _B. melitensis_ cases have been reported only during the period July-December 2009 (2 cases in sheep/goats, destroyed) and January-June 2010 (7 cases in seep/goats, destroyed).\n\nAccording to a 2013 paper (Ref 1), brucellosis is still reported from all types of farms and domestic livestock in Russia, including strains of _B. abortus_, _B. melitensis_, _B. suis_, and _B. ovis_. Between 1999 and 2009, the number of infected sites slightly increased, ranging from 54 in 2001 to 112 in 2009. The number of sites affected with _B. melitensis_ reportedly increased but remained low: 13 in 2004 and 21 in 2009 (see Fig. 2 \"Ovine brucellosis in the Russian Federation, 2003 to 2009\" in Ref 1). The current cases in Tver may be indicative of increased incidence.\n\n\"However\", the authors of Ref 1 say, \"relatively low number of brucellosis-infected areas does not diminish the epizootic and epidemic significance of sheep and goats in the transmission of brucellosis. Since the Soviet Union's dissolution at the beginning of the 1990s, social and economic changes in Russia have led to huge changes in the management and ownership of agricultural animals. About 80 percent of all sheep and goats, and more than 50 percent of all cattle, were transferred from state to private farms. New livestock owners were largely unable to implement costly anti-brucellosis measures. As these private farms now included multiple livestock species, favourable conditions arose for the transmission of _B. melitensis_ to cattle, leading to a dramatic rise in new cases of brucellosis in humans (adults and children), due to this pathogen. Over the last 2 decades, large and small animal brucellosis has become a considerable problem within the Southern Federal District, the Southern Volga region, and the Siberian Federal District.\"\n\n\"In recent years, the epizootic situation of brucellosis in Russia has been complicated by:\n- economic difficulties that led to drastic reductions in regulatory efforts to stem brucellosis,\n- less effective veterinary and customs controls in areas bordering brucellosis-infected territories (Azerbaijan, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Mongolia),\n- a decline in serological testing and vaccination of animals,\n- a reduction in microbiological evaluation of animal infection, leading to a lack of knowledge about the origin of infection,\n- a reduction in the ability to plan and implement brucellosis control policies in infected territories.\"\n\nAdditional updated information on brucellosis in animal and man is available in Ref 2.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. Russia (Kaluga) 20070517.1572\nBrucellosis, ovine - Russia (Samara, Orenburg) 20070209.0510\n.................................................nr/arn/mj/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["brucellosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2013-03-15 00:00:00", "2001-03-15 00:00:00", "2009-03-15 00:00:00", "2004-03-15 00:00:00", "2009-03-15 00:00:00", "2003-03-15 00:00:00", "2013-03-15 00:00:00", "2014-03-15 00:00:00", "2014-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2009-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2007-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Malta", "country": "Malta"}, {"location": "Kyrgyzstan", "country": "Kyrgyzstan"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "Moscow", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "the Russian Federation", "country": "Uruguay"}, {"location": "the Soviet Union 's", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Volgograd", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Kalininsky", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Mongolia", "country": "Mongolia"}, {"location": "Azerbaijan", "country": "Azerbaijan"}, {"location": "Sverdlovsk", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Orenburg", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Mexico", "country": "Mexico"}, {"location": "Danilovsk", "country": "Belarus"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "New Zealand", "country": "New Zealand"}, {"location": "Samara", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Kazakhstan", "country": "Kazakhstan"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3250214", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Brucellosis - Russia: (TV) caprine, ovine", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3250214", "date": "2015-03-25 13:50:27", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS - RUSSIA: (TVER) CAPRINE, OVINE\n*******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 16 Mar 2015\nSource: Afanasiy Biznes [in Russian, trans. Mod.NR, edited]\nhttp://www.afanasy.biz/news/health/?ELEMENT_ID=82792\n\n\nTver veterinary laboratory specialists confirmed brucellosis in 7 out of 10 samples obtained from small ruminants in the village Danilovsk, Kalininsky district.\n\nThe information about the outbreak is being sent to the department of veterinary surveillance of the Tver and Pskov regions to initiate prevention measures addressing further spread of infection.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-RUS\n<promed-rus@promedmail.org>\n\n[The term \"small ruminants\", applied in the media report above, refers to goats (caprines) and sheep (ovines) combined. These 2 species share a common title name, also in several Middle Eastern countries, probably because many flocks are composed of both.\n\n_Brucella melitensis_ (biovars 1, 2, or 3) is the main causative agent of 'caprine and ovine brucellosis'. Sporadic cases caused by _B. abortus_ have been rarely observed in these species.\n\nClinically, the disease is characterised by one or more of the following signs: abortion, retained placenta, orchitis, epididymitis and, rarely, arthritis, with excretion of the organisms in uterine discharges and in milk. Diagnosis depends on the isolation of Brucella from abortion material, udder secretions or from tissues removed at post-mortem.\n\nPresumptive diagnosis of _Brucella_ infection can be made by assessing specific cell-mediated or serological responses to _Brucella_ antigens.\n\n_Brucella melitensis_ is highly pathogenic for humans, causing Malta fever, one of the most serious zoonoses in the world. All infected tissues, cultures, and potentially contaminated materials should therefore be handled at containment level 3. _B. melitensis_ is included in OIE list of reportable diseases/pathogens.\n\n_Brucella melitensis_ is endemic in the Mediterranean region, but infection is widespread world-wide. North America (except Mexico) is believed to be free from the agent, as are Northern and Central Europe, South-East Asia, Australia, and New Zealand. Southern and some central territories of the Russian Federation are long known to be infected by _B. melitensis_. The most recent Russian periodic report to the OIE, covering January-June 2014, mentions 19 new outbreaks (total of 30). In relation to the Tver oblast (north of Moscow; see maps at http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tver_Oblast#/media/File:Tver_in_Russia.svg and http://www.mapsofworld.com/images/russia-political-enlarged-map.jpg) the following information could be derived from OIE's WAHID system, covering the period January 2005-June 2014: _B. melitensis_ cases have been reported only during the period July-December 2009 (2 cases in sheep/goats, destroyed) and January-June 2010 (7 cases in seep/goats, destroyed).\n\nAccording to a 2013 paper (Ref 1), brucellosis is still reported from all types of farms and domestic livestock in Russia, including strains of _B. abortus_, _B. melitensis_, _B. suis_, and _B. ovis_. Between 1999 and 2009, the number of infected sites slightly increased, ranging from 54 in 2001 to 112 in 2009. The number of sites affected with _B. melitensis_ reportedly increased but remained low: 13 in 2004 and 21 in 2009 (see Fig. 2 \"Ovine brucellosis in the Russian Federation, 2003 to 2009\" in Ref 1). The current cases in Tver may be indicative of increased incidence.\n\n\"However\", the authors of Ref 1 say, \"relatively low number of brucellosis-infected areas does not diminish the epizootic and epidemic significance of sheep and goats in the transmission of brucellosis. Since the Soviet Union's dissolution at the beginning of the 1990s, social and economic changes in Russia have led to huge changes in the management and ownership of agricultural animals. About 80 percent of all sheep and goats, and more than 50 percent of all cattle, were transferred from state to private farms. New livestock owners were largely unable to implement costly anti-brucellosis measures. As these private farms now included multiple livestock species, favourable conditions arose for the transmission of _B. melitensis_ to cattle, leading to a dramatic rise in new cases of brucellosis in humans (adults and children), due to this pathogen. Over the last 2 decades, large and small animal brucellosis has become a considerable problem within the Southern Federal District, the Southern Volga region, and the Siberian Federal District.\"\n\n\"In recent years, the epizootic situation of brucellosis in Russia has been complicated by:\n- economic difficulties that led to drastic reductions in regulatory efforts to stem brucellosis,\n- less effective veterinary and customs controls in areas bordering brucellosis-infected territories (Azerbaijan, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Mongolia),\n- a decline in serological testing and vaccination of animals,\n- a reduction in microbiological evaluation of animal infection, leading to a lack of knowledge about the origin of infection,\n- a reduction in the ability to plan and implement brucellosis control policies in infected territories.\"\n\nAdditional updated information on brucellosis in animal and man is available in Ref 2.\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. Denisov AA, Sclyarov OD, Salmakov KM, Shumilov KV: The Russian experience in brucellosis veterinary public health.\nRev sci tech Off int Epiz, 2013; 32(1): 229-37.\nhttp://web.oie.int/boutique/extrait/22denisov229237.pdf.\n2. Godfroid J, DeBolle X, Roop RM, O'Callaghan D, et al: The quest for a true One Health perspective of brucellosis\nRev sci tech Off int Epiz, 2014, 33(2): 521-38\nhttp://www.oie.int/doc/ged/D14086.PDF. - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/432.]\nSee Also\n2014\n----\nBrucellosis - Russia: (TL) ovine 20140405.2383709\n2012\n----\nBrucellosis - Russia: (VG), livestock, human, RFI 20121228.1473282\n2011\n----\nBrucellosis - Russia: (SR) RFI 20101206.4363\n2009\n----\nBrucellosis, livestock, human - Russia: (OM) 20090701.2380\nBrucellosis, ovine, bovine - Russia: (CV) 20090423.1530\nZoonotic disease trends 2007-2008 - Russia (02): brucellosis 20090103.0025\n2008\n----\nBrucellosis, ovine, human - Russia (Altai) 20080902.2749\nBrucellosis, ovine - Russia (Moscow ex Volgograd) (02) 20080318.1047\n2007\n----\nBrucellosis, ovine - Russia (Buryatia) 20070611.1903\nBrucellosis, ovine - Russia (Sverdlovsk region) 20070522.1639\nBrucellosis, ovine - Russia (Kaluga) 20070517.1572\nBrucellosis, ovine - Russia (Samara, Orenburg) 20070209.0510\n.................................................nr/arn/mj/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["brucellosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2013-03-15 00:00:00", "2001-03-15 00:00:00", "2009-03-15 00:00:00", "2004-03-15 00:00:00", "2009-03-15 00:00:00", "2003-03-15 00:00:00", "2013-03-15 00:00:00", "2014-03-15 00:00:00", "2014-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2009-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2007-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Malta", "country": "Malta"}, {"location": "Kyrgyzstan", "country": "Kyrgyzstan"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "Moscow", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "the Russian Federation", "country": "Uruguay"}, {"location": "the Soviet Union 's", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Volgograd", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Kalininsky", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Mongolia", "country": "Mongolia"}, {"location": "Azerbaijan", "country": "Azerbaijan"}, {"location": "Sverdlovsk", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Orenburg", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Mexico", "country": "Mexico"}, {"location": "Danilovsk", "country": "Belarus"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "New Zealand", "country": "New Zealand"}, {"location": "Samara", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Kazakhstan", "country": "Kazakhstan"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3249268", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Brucellosis - Armenia: (SU) abattoir workers", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3249268", "date": "2014-12-07 11:11:37", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS, BOVINE - USA (MONTANA)\n***********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: 5 Dec 2014\nSource: Bozeman Daily Chronicle [edited]\nhttp://www.bozemandailychronicle.com/news/agriculture/brucellosis-found-in-madison-county-herd/article_1591f9fe-7cd5-11e4-b848-9b8786b28f5c.html\n\n\nA cow in a large Madison County cattle herd has brucellosis, according to the Montana Department of Livestock.\n\nThe cow was identified during a herd test by a producer whose cattle graze within the state's Designated Surveillance Area. The National Veterinary Services Laboratories in Ames, Iowa, confirmed the infection.\n\nState veterinarian Marty Zaluski said the area has been quarantined and adjacent livestock producers are being notified.\n\nThe state is not at risk of losing its brucellosis-free status based on regulations from the U.S. Department of Agriculture Animal & Plant Health Inspection Service.\n\nAs with previous cases of brucellosis in livestock, adjacent producers will test livestock as part of an epidemiological investigation to determine the source of the infection. Previous epidemiological investigations of brucellosis in livestock in Montana, Idaho and Wyoming indicated that elk were the most likely source.\n\n\"We don't like finding brucellosis-positive cows, but if it's out there, we want to find it before cattle are shipped to market or out of state,\" Zaluski said. \"That's why we have a program; we have to assure other states we're doing everything we can to manage this endemic wildlife disease problem.\"\n\nSimilar to affected herds in the past, the low infection rate indicates early detection. \"It demonstrates that our aggressive surveillance program finds the disease before it is allowed to spread within the herd, which reduces costs for producers and minimizes risk for our trading partners,\" he said.\n\nThe state has now found at least one case of brucellosis in cattle in 5 of the past 8 years.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Bovine brucellosis (caused by _Brucella abortus_) has caused devastating losses to farmers in the United States over the last century. Collaborative efforts by the US Department of Agriculture, the livestock industries, and state animal health authorities achieved brucellosis-free status in 48 states with no known infection since 2002.\n\nThe only known focus of _Brucella abortus_ infection left in the nation is in bison and elk, which originally acquired the infection from cattle. The bacterium became established in these wildlife species and does not currently pose a threat for their populations. However, it does represent a big concern for domestic livestock.\n\nElk, also known as wapiti (_Cervus canadensis_), are a reservoir of the disease, originally acquired from cattle. The elk are free to move in and out of the national park of Yellowstone. The elk feed at feeding grounds in the park. It is a tremendous tourist draw to see the large number of impressive animals. Some of these animals give birth to a calf at or near the feeding grounds. _Brucella abortus_, the organism responsible for the disease brucellosis, is often spread through the birthing process, fluids, and tissues. Other animals investigate the birthing site and probably become infected with the organism at that time. These same elk are free to move in and out of the park region, and thus may be spreading the disease to cattle they come into contact with in the area, thus, the article's statement of the likely source of the disease in the cow in question being elk.\n\nIn areas where a cow is found positive, the producers test their animals prior to moving them to market. This can be time consuming and is certainly an added cost to the producer.\n\nThe Greater Yellowstone Area (GYA) is a portion of 3 states, Idaho, Montana and Wyoming. A map of the GYA showing the 3 states involved is located at http://www.yellowstonegeotourism.org/. - Mod.TG\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/228.]\nSee Also\nBrucellosis, bovine - Mod", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wyoming", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3123696", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Brucellosis, cervid - USA: (MT) ex WY NOT", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3123696", "date": "2014-12-07 11:11:37", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS, BOVINE - USA (MONTANA)\n***********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: 5 Dec 2014\nSource: Bozeman Daily Chronicle [edited]\nhttp://www.bozemandailychronicle.com/news/agriculture/brucellosis-found-in-madison-county-herd/article_1591f9fe-7cd5-11e4-b848-9b8786b28f5c.html\n\n\nA cow in a large Madison County cattle herd has brucellosis, according to the Montana Department of Livestock.\n\nThe cow was identified during a herd test by a producer whose cattle graze within the state's Designated Surveillance Area. The National Veterinary Services Laboratories in Ames, Iowa, confirmed the infection.\n\nState veterinarian Marty Zaluski said the area has been quarantined and adjacent livestock producers are being notified.\n\nThe state is not at risk of losing its brucellosis-free status based on regulations from the U.S. Department of Agriculture Animal & Plant Health Inspection Service.\n\nAs with previous cases of brucellosis in livestock, adjacent producers will test livestock as part of an epidemiological investigation to determine the source of the infection. Previous epidemiological investigations of brucellosis in livestock in Montana, Idaho and Wyoming indicated that elk were the most likely source.\n\n\"We don't like finding brucellosis-positive cows, but if it's out there, we want to find it before cattle are shipped to market or out of state,\" Zaluski said. \"That's why we have a program; we have to assure other states we're doing everything we can to manage this endemic wildlife disease problem.\"\n\nSimilar to affected herds in the past, the low infection rate indicates early detection. \"It demonstrates that our aggressive surveillance program finds the disease before it is allowed to spread within the herd, which reduces costs for producers and minimizes risk for our trading partners,\" he said.\n\nThe state has now found at least one case of brucellosis in cattle in 5 of the past 8 years.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Bovine brucellosis (caused by _Brucella abortus_) has caused devastating losses to farmers in the United States over the last century. Collaborative efforts by the US Department of Agriculture, the livestock industries, and state animal health authorities achieved brucellosis-free status in 48 states with no known infection since 2002.\n\nThe only known focus of _Brucella abortus_ infection left in the nation is in bison and elk, which originally acquired the infection from cattle. The bacterium became established in these wildlife species and does not currently pose a threat for their populations. However, it does represent a big concern for domestic livestock.\n\nElk, also known as wapiti (_Cervus canadensis_), are a reservoir of the disease, originally acquired from cattle. The elk are free to move in and out of the national park of Yellowstone. The elk feed at feeding grounds in the park. It is a tremendous tourist draw to see the large number of impressive animals. Some of these animals give birth to a calf at or near the feeding grounds. _Brucella abortus_, the organism responsible for the disease brucellosis, is often spread through the birthing process, fluids, and tissues. Other animals investigate the birthing site and probably become infected with the organism at that time. These same elk are free to move in and out of the park region, and thus may be spreading the disease to cattle they come into contact with in the area, thus, the article's statement of the likely source of the disease in the cow in question being elk.\n\nIn areas where a cow is found positive, the producers test their animals prior to moving them to market. This can be time consuming and is certainly an added cost to the producer.\n\nThe Greater Yellowstone Area (GYA) is a portion of 3 states, Idaho, Montana and Wyoming. A map of the GYA showing the 3 states involved is located at http://www.yellowstonegeotourism.org/. - Mod.TG\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/228.]\nSee Also\nBrucellosis, bovine - Australia: (NS)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3090837", "date": "2014-12-07 11:11:37", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS, BOVINE - USA (MONTANA)\n***********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: 5 Dec 2014\nSource: Bozeman Daily Chronicle [edited]\nhttp://www.bozemandailychronicle.com/news/agriculture/brucellosis-found-in-madison-county-herd/article_1591f9fe-7cd5-11e4-b848-9b8786b28f5c.html\n\n\nA cow in a large Madison County cattle herd has brucellosis, according to the Montana Department of Livestock.\n\nThe cow was identified during a herd test by a producer whose cattle graze within the state's Designated Surveillance Area. The National Veterinary Services Laboratories in Ames, Iowa, confirmed the infection.\n\nState veterinarian Marty Zaluski said the area has been quarantined and adjacent livestock producers are being notified.\n\nThe state is not at risk of losing its brucellosis-free status based on regulations from the U.S. Department of Agriculture Animal & Plant Health Inspection Service.\n\nAs with previous cases of brucellosis in livestock, adjacent producers will test livestock as part of an epidemiological investigation to determine the source of the infection. Previous epidemiological investigations of brucellosis in livestock in Montana, Idaho and Wyoming indicated that elk were the most likely source.\n\n\"We don't like finding brucellosis-positive cows, but if it's out there, we want to find it before cattle are shipped to market or out of state,\" Zaluski said. \"That's why we have a program; we have to assure other states we're doing everything we can to manage this endemic wildlife disease problem.\"\n\nSimilar to affected herds in the past, the low infection rate indicates early detection. \"It demonstrates that our aggressive surveillance program finds the disease before it is allowed to spread within the herd, which reduces costs for producers and minimizes risk for our trading partners,\" he said.\n\nThe state has now found at least one case of brucellosis in cattle in 5 of the past 8 years.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Bovine brucellosis (caused by _Brucella abortus_) has caused devastating losses to farmers in the United States over the last century. Collaborative efforts by the US Department of Agriculture, the livestock industries, and state animal health authorities achieved brucellosis-free status in 48 states with no known infection since 2002.\n\nThe only known focus of _Brucella abortus_ infection left in the nation is in bison and elk, which originally acquired the infection from cattle. The bacterium became established in these wildlife species and does not currently pose a threat for their populations. However, it does represent a big concern for domestic livestock.\n\nElk, also known as wapiti (_Cervus canadensis_), are a reservoir of the disease, originally acquired from cattle. The elk are free to move in and out of the national park of Yellowstone. The elk feed at feeding grounds in the park. It is a tremendous tourist draw to see the large number of impressive animals. Some of these animals give birth to a calf at or near the feeding grounds. _Brucella abortus_, the organism responsible for the disease brucellosis, is often spread through the birthing process, fluids, and tissues. Other animals investigate the birthing site and probably become infected with the organism at that time. These same elk are free to move in and out of the park region, and thus may be spreading the disease to cattle they come into contact with in the area, thus, the article's statement of the likely source of the disease in the cow in question being elk.\n\nIn areas where a cow is found positive, the producers test their animals prior to moving them to market. This can be time consuming and is certainly an added cost to the producer.\n\nThe Greater Yellowstone Area (GYA) is a portion of 3 states, Idaho, Montana and Wyoming. A map of the GYA showing the 3 states involved is located at http://www.yellowstonegeotourism.org/. - Mod.TG\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/228.]\nSee Also\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA: (MT) 20090117.0196\n2008\n----\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA (08): (MT), loss of status 20080905.2770\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA: (MT) 20080611.1841\n2007\n----\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA (MT)(04) 20070719.2311\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA (MT) (03) 20070709.2176\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA (MT)(02) 20070611.1908\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA (MT) 20070522.1632\n.................................................sb/tg/msp/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "brucellosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2014-03-15 00:00:00", "2002-03-15 00:00:00", "2011-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2010-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2009-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2007-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Iowa", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "designate Surveillance Area", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Idaho", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Ames", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "WY", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Madison County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Yellowstone", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "MT", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Montana", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "http://www.yellowstonegeotourism.org/. - Mod", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wyoming", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "3038019", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Brucellosis, bovine - USA (02): (MT)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=3038019", "date": "2014-12-07 11:11:37", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS, BOVINE - USA (MONTANA)\n***********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: 5 Dec 2014\nSource: Bozeman Daily Chronicle [edited]\nhttp://www.bozemandailychronicle.com/news/agriculture/brucellosis-found-in-madison-county-herd/article_1591f9fe-7cd5-11e4-b848-9b8786b28f5c.html\n\n\nA cow in a large Madison County cattle herd has brucellosis, according to the Montana Department of Livestock.\n\nThe cow was identified during a herd test by a producer whose cattle graze within the state's Designated Surveillance Area. The National Veterinary Services Laboratories in Ames, Iowa, confirmed the infection.\n\nState veterinarian Marty Zaluski said the area has been quarantined and adjacent livestock producers are being notified.\n\nThe state is not at risk of losing its brucellosis-free status based on regulations from the U.S. Department of Agriculture Animal & Plant Health Inspection Service.\n\nAs with previous cases of brucellosis in livestock, adjacent producers will test livestock as part of an epidemiological investigation to determine the source of the infection. Previous epidemiological investigations of brucellosis in livestock in Montana, Idaho and Wyoming indicated that elk were the most likely source.\n\n\"We don't like finding brucellosis-positive cows, but if it's out there, we want to find it before cattle are shipped to market or out of state,\" Zaluski said. \"That's why we have a program; we have to assure other states we're doing everything we can to manage this endemic wildlife disease problem.\"\n\nSimilar to affected herds in the past, the low infection rate indicates early detection. \"It demonstrates that our aggressive surveillance program finds the disease before it is allowed to spread within the herd, which reduces costs for producers and minimizes risk for our trading partners,\" he said.\n\nThe state has now found at least one case of brucellosis in cattle in 5 of the past 8 years.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Bovine brucellosis (caused by _Brucella abortus_) has caused devastating losses to farmers in the United States over the last century. Collaborative efforts by the US Department of Agriculture, the livestock industries, and state animal health authorities achieved brucellosis-free status in 48 states with no known infection since 2002.\n\nThe only known focus of _Brucella abortus_ infection left in the nation is in bison and elk, which originally acquired the infection from cattle. The bacterium became established in these wildlife species and does not currently pose a threat for their populations. However, it does represent a big concern for domestic livestock.\n\nElk, also known as wapiti (_Cervus canadensis_), are a reservoir of the disease, originally acquired from cattle. The elk are free to move in and out of the national park of Yellowstone. The elk feed at feeding grounds in the park. It is a tremendous tourist draw to see the large number of impressive animals. Some of these animals give birth to a calf at or near the feeding grounds. _Brucella abortus_, the organism responsible for the disease brucellosis, is often spread through the birthing process, fluids, and tissues. Other animals investigate the birthing site and probably become infected with the organism at that time. These same elk are free to move in and out of the park region, and thus may be spreading the disease to cattle they come into contact with in the area, thus, the article's statement of the likely source of the disease in the cow in question being elk.\n\nIn areas where a cow is found positive, the producers test their animals prior to moving them to market. This can be time consuming and is certainly an added cost to the producer.\n\nThe Greater Yellowstone Area (GYA) is a portion of 3 states, Idaho, Montana and Wyoming. A map of the GYA showing the 3 states involved is located at http://www.yellowstonegeotourism.org/. - Mod.TG\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/228.]\nSee Also\nBrucellosis, bovine -
