The National Veterinary Services Laboratories in Ames, Iowa, confirmed the infection.\n\nState veterinarian Marty Zaluski said the area has been quarantined and adjacent livestock producers are being notified.\n\nThe state is not at risk of losing its brucellosis-free status based on regulations from the U.S. Department of Agriculture Animal & Plant Health Inspection Service.\n\nAs with previous cases of brucellosis in livestock, adjacent producers will test livestock as part of an epidemiological investigation to determine the source of the infection. Other animals investigate the birthing site and probably become infected with the organism at that time. USA (MT) (03) 20070709.2176\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA (MT)(02) 20070611.1908\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA (MT) 20070522.1632\n.................................................sb/tg/msp/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "brucellosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2014-03-15 00:00:00", "2002-03-15 00:00:00", "2011-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2010-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2009-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2007-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Iowa", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "designate Surveillance Area", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Idaho", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Ames", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "WY", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Madison County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Yellowstone", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "MT", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Montana", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "http://www.yellowstonegeotourism.org/. - Mod", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wyoming", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2954061", "headline": "PRO/AH> Brucellosis, cervid - USA (02): (WY)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2954061", "date": "2014-12-07 11:11:37", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS, BOVINE - USA (MONTANA)\n***********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: 5 Dec 2014\nSource: Bozeman Daily Chronicle [edited]\nhttp://www.bozemandailychronicle.com/news/agriculture/brucellosis-found-in-madison-county-herd/article_1591f9fe-7cd5-11e4-b848-9b8786b28f5c.html\n\n\nA cow in a large Madison County cattle herd has brucellosis, according to the Montana Department of Livestock.\n\nThe cow was identified during a herd test by a producer whose cattle graze within the state's Designated Surveillance Area. The National Veterinary Services Laboratories in Ames, Iowa, confirmed the infection.\n\nState veterinarian Marty Zaluski said the area has been quarantined and adjacent livestock producers are being notified.\n\nThe state is not at risk of losing its brucellosis-free status based on regulations from the U.S. Department of Agriculture Animal & Plant Health Inspection Service.\n\nAs with previous cases of brucellosis in livestock, adjacent producers will test livestock as part of an epidemiological investigation to determine the source of the infection. Previous epidemiological investigations of brucellosis in livestock in Montana, Idaho and Wyoming indicated that elk were the most likely source.\n\n\"We don't like finding brucellosis-positive cows, but if it's out there, we want to find it before cattle are shipped to market or out of state,\" Zaluski said. \"That's why we have a program; we have to assure other states we're doing everything we can to manage this endemic wildlife disease problem.\"\n\nSimilar to affected herds in the past, the low infection rate indicates early detection. \"It demonstrates that our aggressive surveillance program finds the disease before it is allowed to spread within the herd, which reduces costs for producers and minimizes risk for our trading partners,\" he said.\n\nThe state has now found at least one case of brucellosis in cattle in 5 of the past 8 years.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Bovine brucellosis (caused by _Brucella abortus_) has caused devastating losses to farmers in the United States over the last century. Collaborative efforts by the US Department of Agriculture, the livestock industries, and state animal health authorities achieved brucellosis-free status in 48 states with no known infection since 2002.\n\nThe only known focus of _Brucella abortus_ infection left in the nation is in bison and elk, which originally acquired the infection from cattle. The bacterium became established in these wildlife species and does not currently pose a threat for their populations. However, it does represent a big concern for domestic livestock.\n\nElk, also known as wapiti (_Cervus canadensis_), are a reservoir of the disease, originally acquired from cattle. The elk are free to move in and out of the national park of Yellowstone. The elk feed at feeding grounds in the park. It is a tremendous tourist draw to see the large number of impressive animals. Some of these animals give birth to a calf at or near the feeding grounds. _Brucella abortus_, the organism responsible for the disease brucellosis, is often spread through the birthing process, fluids, and tissues. Other animals investigate the birthing site and probably become infected with the organism at that time. These same elk are free to move in and out of the park region, and thus may be spreading the disease to cattle they come into contact with in the area, thus, the article's statement of the likely source of the disease in the cow in question being elk.\n\nIn areas where a cow is found positive, the producers test their animals prior to moving them to market. This can be time consuming and is certainly an added cost to the producer.\n\nThe Greater Yellowstone Area (GYA) is a portion of 3 states, Idaho, Montana and Wyoming. A map of the GYA showing the 3 states involved is located at http://www.yellowstonegeotourism.org/. - Mod.TG\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/228.]\nSee Also\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA (MT) (03) 20070709.2176\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA (MT)(02) 20070611.1908\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA (MT) 20070522.1632\n.................................................sb/tg/msp/mpp", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "brucellosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2014-03-15 00:00:00", "2002-03-15 00:00:00", "2011-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-09 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2010-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2009-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2007-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Iowa", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "designate Surveillance Area", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Idaho", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Ames", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "WY", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Madison County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Yellowstone", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "MT", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Montana", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "http://www.yellowstonegeotourism.org/. - Mod", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wyoming", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2846346", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Brucellosis, canine - Australia (02): (NS) B. suis", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2846346", "date": "2014-06-07 18:44:34", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS, HUMAN - ISRAEL: (HAZAFON), RFI\n*******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 2 Jun 2014\nSource: YNET [in Hebrew, trans. Mod.AS, edited]\nhttp://www.ynet.co.il/articles/0,7340,L-4526332,00.html\n\n\nBrucellosis outbreak due to unpasteurized milk\n----------------------------------------------\nDue to an unusual outbreak of brucellosis in the Western Galilee, the Nahariya hospital [HaZafon (Northern District)] had to treat about 30 patients during the last 2 weeks, half of them children. The patients were found infected by the brucellosis bacterium, known to contaminate cheese and unpasteurized milk from infected animals. The cases have been reported to the Ministry of Health.\n\nThe bacteria cause a disease known as \"Malta fever.\" The disease is found mainly in the non-Jewish sector in the Galilee [north], Wadi Ara [centre] and the Negev [south].\n\nThe Director of the pediatric infectious disease service in the Galilee medical center, Dr. Daniel Glickman, said the patients, arriving during the last 2 weeks at the hospital, are residents of the Druze villages Yarka and Julis, half of them children who consumed unpasteurized cheese; many of them relatives (father and daughter, cousins) who most probably consumed cheese from a common source.\n\n\"The signs of the disease are usually joint and bone pain, accompanied by high fever. The disease is not contagious among humans and is mainly treated by antibiotics,\" he said.\n\nThe patients were hospitalized in the pediatric and internal departments. One case, a 5-year-old girl, had to be hospitalized in the ICU to stabilize her condition.\n\nIt has been said that the current wave may continue, since the incubation period of exposed persons may take weeks and sometimes even months before clinically manifested. According to the Medical Center, throughout the course of 2013, only 10 patients had to be treated.\n\nAfter questioning by the hospital's doctors, 3 possible sources of infection have been identified.\n\nAbout 10 days ago, another cluster of brucellosis was discovered, in Jerusalem; 14 people were found infected following the consumption of unpasteurized cheese brought from the territory of the Palestinian Authority [West Bank].\n\n[Byline: Achiya Rabbed]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Most likely, all reported cases of Malta fever (the commonly used name for brucellosis in Israel) have been caused by _Brucella melitensis_, the bacteria species which is regarded endemic. There is a concerning increase of reported human cases during recent years (see further data of 2011-2013). The true number of human infections is generally considered to be significantly higher, many remaining unreported.\n\nUnfortunately, humans seem to have become the sentinels of brucellosis in sheep/goat flocks.\n\nNumber of outbreaks in animals and human cases (OIE data)\n---------------------------------------------------------\nYear / Outbreaks in animals / Human cases / Rate per 100 000 population\n2011 / 6 / 127 / 1.8076\n2012 / 14 / 183 / 2.6046\n2013 / 11 / 336 / 4.7822\n\nThe majority of the human brucellosis cases in Israel are caused by the ingestion of unpasteurized dairy products produced from family-owned sheep and/or goat flocks. Exposure to infected farm animals (occupational infection) is another common cause of infection. Though most of the human cases have been encountered, during previous years, in southern Israel, the current events are indicative of significant circulation of the agent in other parts of the country. The situation in the Palestinian territories is known to be even worse.\n\nThe main reservoir of _B. melitensis_ are sheep and goats, with the main symptom being abortions. _B. melitensis_ may occasionally infect cattle. In contrast to _B. abortus_, which causes abortions in cattle, _B. melitensis_ is not abortifacient in cattle, but will infect the udders, followed by massive discharge of the highly pathogenic bacteria in the milk and consequent human infections.\n\nResults of laboratory investigations, confirming the clinical diagnosis of the described cases, will be appreciated. It will be interesting to follow the epidemiological investigations at the 3 suspected sources of infection (Western Galilee) and obtain their results, hopefully identifying the source(s). Similarly, updates on ongoing and contemplated control measures will be welcomed.\n\nProMED-mail's request for information on a previous event is pending (see 20140513.2467609).\n\nFor the number of _Brucella melitensis_ outbreaks in Israel between 1990-2012, see page 47 (sheep/goats) and 48 (cattle) at http://www.moag.gov.il/agri/files/doh_shnati_2012.pdf.\n\nFurther reading:\n1. Zuhayr A. Tabbarah (2014) Brucellosis revisited. 15th Congress, Lebanese Soc Infect. Dis & Clin Microb. http://tinyurl.com/pdepzyz.\n2. E. Anis, A. Leventhal, I. Grotto, D. Gandacu et al (2011). Recent Trends in Human Brucellosis in Israel. IMAJ 13 (359-62). http://www.ima.org.il/FilesUpload/IMAJ/0/39/19875.pdf.\n- Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/90.]\nSee Also\nBrucellosis, human, livestock - Israel: (HZ) RFI 20140513.2467609\n2013\n----\nBrucellosis, human, livestock - Syria 20130816.1882350\n2004\n----\nBrucellosis, humans & caprines - Lebanon 20040715.1907\n.................................................arn/je/dk", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "brucellosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2013-03-15 00:00:00", "2011-03-15 00:00:00", "2014-03-15 00:00:00", "2011-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Malta", "country": "Malta"}, {"location": "Jerusalem", "country": "Israel"}, {"location": "Israel", "country": "Israel"}, {"location": "syria", "country": "Syria"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2695748", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Brucellosis - Azerbaijan", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2695748", "date": "2014-06-07 18:44:34", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS, HUMAN - ISRAEL: (HAZAFON), RFI\n*******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 2 Jun 2014\nSource: YNET [in Hebrew, trans. Mod.AS, edited]\nhttp://www.ynet.co.il/articles/0,7340,L-4526332,00.html\n\n\nBrucellosis outbreak due to unpasteurized milk\n----------------------------------------------\nDue to an unusual outbreak of brucellosis in the Western Galilee, the Nahariya hospital [HaZafon (Northern District)] had to treat about 30 patients during the last 2 weeks, half of them children. The patients were found infected by the brucellosis bacterium, known to contaminate cheese and unpasteurized milk from infected animals. The cases have been reported to the Ministry of Health.\n\nThe bacteria cause a disease known as \"Malta fever.\" The disease is found mainly in the non-Jewish sector in the Galilee [north], Wadi Ara [centre] and the Negev [south].\n\nThe Director of the pediatric infectious disease service in the Galilee medical center, Dr. Daniel Glickman, said the patients, arriving during the last 2 weeks at the hospital, are residents of the Druze villages Yarka and Julis, half of them children who consumed unpasteurized cheese; many of them relatives (father and daughter, cousins) who most probably consumed cheese from a common source.\n\n\"The signs of the disease are usually joint and bone pain, accompanied by high fever. The disease is not contagious among humans and is mainly treated by antibiotics,\" he said.\n\nThe patients were hospitalized in the pediatric and internal departments. One case, a 5-year-old girl, had to be hospitalized in the ICU to stabilize her condition.\n\nIt has been said that the current wave may continue, since the incubation period of exposed persons may take weeks and sometimes even months before clinically manifested. According to the Medical Center, throughout the course of 2013, only 10 patients had to be treated.\n\nAfter questioning by the hospital's doctors, 3 possible sources of infection have been identified.\n\nAbout 10 days ago, another cluster of brucellosis was discovered, in Jerusalem; 14 people were found infected following the consumption of unpasteurized cheese brought from the territory of the Palestinian Authority [West Bank].\n\n[Byline: Achiya Rabbed]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Most likely, all reported cases of Malta fever (the commonly used name for brucellosis in Israel) have been caused by _Brucella melitensis_, the bacteria species which is regarded endemic. There is a concerning increase of reported human cases during recent years (see further data of 2011-2013). The true number of human infections is generally considered to be significantly higher, many remaining unreported.\n\nUnfortunately, humans seem to have become the sentinels of brucellosis in sheep/goat flocks.\n\nNumber of outbreaks in animals and human cases (OIE data)\n---------------------------------------------------------\nYear / Outbreaks in animals / Human cases / Rate per 100 000 population\n2011 / 6 / 127 / 1.8076\n2012 / 14 / 183 / 2.6046\n2013 / 11 / 336 / 4.7822\n\nThe majority of the human brucellosis cases in Israel are caused by the ingestion of unpasteurized dairy products produced from family-owned sheep and/or goat flocks. Exposure to infected farm animals (occupational infection) is another common cause of infection. Though most of the human cases have been encountered, during previous years, in southern Israel, the current events are indicative of significant circulation of the agent in other parts of the country. The situation in the Palestinian territories is known to be even worse.\n\nThe main reservoir of _B. melitensis_ are sheep and goats, with the main symptom being abortions. _B. melitensis_ may occasionally infect cattle. In contrast to _B. abortus_, which causes abortions in cattle, _B. melitensis_ is not abortifacient in cattle, but will infect the udders, followed by massive discharge of the highly pathogenic bacteria in the milk and consequent human infections.\n\nResults of laboratory investigations, confirming the clinical diagnosis of the described cases, will be appreciated. It will be interesting to follow the epidemiological investigations at the 3 suspected sources of infection (Western Galilee) and obtain their results, hopefully identifying the source(s). Similarly, updates on ongoing and contemplated control measures will be welcomed.\n\nProMED-mail's request for information on a previous event is pending (see 20140513.2467609).\n\nFor the number of _Brucella melitensis_ outbreaks in Israel between 1990-2012, see page 47 (sheep/goats) and 48 (cattle) at http://www.moag.gov.il/agri/files/doh_shnati_2012.pdf.\n\nFurther reading:\n1. The patients were found infected by the brucellosis bacterium, known to contaminate cheese and unpasteurized milk from infected animals. The cases have been reported to the Ministry of Health.\n\nThe bacteria cause a disease known as \"Malta fever.\" The disease is found mainly in the non-Jewish sector in the Galilee [north], Wadi Ara [centre] and the Negev [south].\n\nThe Director of the pediatric infectious disease service in the Galilee medical center, Dr. Daniel Glickman, said the patients, arriving during the last 2 weeks at the hospital, are residents of the Druze villages Yarka and Julis, half of them children who consumed unpasteurized cheese; many of them relatives (father and daughter, cousins) who most probably consumed cheese from a common source.\n\n\"The signs of the disease are usually joint and bone pain, accompanied by high fever. The disease is not contagious among humans and is mainly treated by antibiotics,\" he said.\n\nThe patients were hospitalized in the pediatric and internal departments. The true number of human infections is generally considered to be significantly higher, many remaining unreported.\n\nUnfortunately, humans seem to have become the sentinels of brucellosis in sheep/goat flocks.\n\nNumber of outbreaks in animals and human cases (OIE data)\n---------------------------------------------------------\nYear / Outbreaks in animals / Human cases / Rate per 100 000 population\n2011 / 6 / 127 / 1.8076\n2012 / 14 / 183 / 2.6046\n2013 / 11 / 336 / 4.7822\n\nThe majority of the human brucellosis cases in Israel are caused by the ingestion of unpasteurized dairy products produced from family-owned sheep and/or goat flocks. Exposure to infected farm animals (occupational infection) is another common cause of infection. Though most of the human cases have been encountered, during previous years, in southern Israel, the current events are indicative of significant circulation of the agent in other parts of the country. The situation in the Palestinian territories is known to be even worse.\n\nThe main reservoir of _B. melitensis_ are sheep and goats, with the main symptom being abortions. _B. melitensis_ may occasionally infect cattle. In contrast to _B. abortus_, which causes abortions in cattle, _B. melitensis_ is not abortifacient in cattle, but will infect the udders, followed by massive discharge of the highly pathogenic bacteria in the milk and consequent human infections.\n\nResults of laboratory investigations, confirming the clinical diagnosis of the described cases, will be appreciated. It will be interesting to follow the epidemiological investigations at the 3 suspected sources of infection (Western Galilee) and obtain their results, hopefully identifying the source(s). Similarly, updates on ongoing and contemplated control measures will be welcomed.\n\nProMED-mail's request for information on a previous event is pending (see 20140513.2467609).\n\nFor the number of _Brucella melitensis_ outbreaks in Israel between 1990-2012, see page 47 (sheep/goats) and 48 (cattle) at http://www.moag.gov.il/agri/files/doh_shnati_2012.pdf.\n\nFurther reading:\n1. Mod.AS, edited]\nhttp://www.ynet.co.il/articles/0,7340,L-4526332,00.html\n\n\nBrucellosis outbreak due to unpasteurized milk\n----------------------------------------------\nDue to an unusual outbreak of brucellosis in the Western Galilee, the Nahariya hospital [HaZafon (Northern District)] had to treat about 30 patients during the last 2 weeks, half of them children. The patients were found infected by the brucellosis bacterium, known to contaminate cheese and unpasteurized milk from infected animals. The cases have been reported to the Ministry of Health.\n\nThe bacteria cause a disease known as \"Malta fever.\" The disease is found mainly in the non-Jewish sector in the Galilee [north], Wadi Ara [centre] and the Negev [south].\n\nThe Director of the pediatric infectious disease service in the Galilee medical center, Dr. Daniel Glickman, said the patients, arriving during the last 2 weeks at the hospital, are residents of the Druze villages Yarka and Julis, half of them children who consumed unpasteurized cheese; many of them relatives (father and daughter, cousins) who most probably consumed cheese from a common source.\n\n\"The signs of the disease are usually joint and bone pain, accompanied by high fever. The disease is not contagious among humans and is mainly treated by antibiotics,\" he said.\n\nThe patients were hospitalized in the pediatric and internal departments. One case, a 5-year-old girl, had to be hospitalized in the ICU to stabilize her condition.\n\nIt has been said that the current wave may continue, since the incubation period of exposed persons may take weeks and sometimes even months before clinically manifested. According to the Medical Center, throughout the course of 2013, only 10 patients had to be treated.\n\nAfter questioning by the hospital's doctors, 3 possible sources of infection have been identified.\n\nAbout 10 days ago, another cluster of brucellosis was discovered, in Jerusalem; 14 people were found infected following the consumption of unpasteurized cheese brought from the territory of the Palestinian Authority [West Bank].\n\n[Byline: Achiya Rabbed]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Most likely, all reported cases of Malta fever (the commonly used name for brucellosis in Israel) have been caused by _Brucella melitensis_, the bacteria species which is regarded endemic. There is a concerning increase of reported human cases during recent years (see further data of 2011-2013). The true number of human infections is generally considered to be significantly higher, many remaining unreported.\n\nUnfortunately, humans seem to have become the sentinels of brucellosis in sheep/goat flocks.\n\nNumber of outbreaks in animals and human cases (OIE data)\n---------------------------------------------------------\nYear / Outbreaks in animals / Human cases / Rate per 100 000 population\n2011 / 6 / 127 / 1.8076\n2012 / 14 / 183 / 2.6046\n2013 / 11 / 336 / 4.7822\n\nThe majority of the human brucellosis cases in Israel are caused by the ingestion of unpasteurized dairy products produced from family-owned sheep and/or goat flocks. Exposure to infected farm animals (occupational infection) is another common cause of infection. Though most of the human cases have been encountered, during previous years, in southern Israel, the current events are indicative of significant circulation of the agent in other parts of the country. The situation in the Palestinian territories is known to be even worse.\n\nThe main reservoir of _B. melitensis_ are sheep and goats, with the main symptom being abortions. _B. melitensis_ may occasionally infect cattle. In contrast to _B. abortus_, which causes abortions in cattle, _B. melitensis_ is not abortifacient in cattle, but will infect the udders, followed by massive discharge of the highly pathogenic bacteria in the milk and consequent human infections.\n\nResults of laboratory investigations, confirming the clinical diagnosis of the described cases, will be appreciated. It will be interesting to follow the epidemiological investigations at the 3 suspected sources of infection (Western Galilee) and obtain their results, hopefully identifying the source(s). Similarly, updates on ongoing and contemplated control measures will be welcomed.\n\nProMED-mail's request for information on a previous event is pending (see 20140513.2467609).\n\nFor the number of _Brucella melitensis_ outbreaks in Israel between 1990-2012, see page 47 (sheep/goats) and 48 (cattle) at http://www.moag.gov.il/agri/files/doh_shnati_2012.pdf.\n\nFurther reading:\n1. Zuhayr A. Tabbarah (2014) Brucellosis revisited. 15th Congress, Lebanese Soc Infect. Dis & Clin Microb. http://tinyurl.com/pdepzyz.\n2. E. Anis, A. Leventhal, I. Grotto, D. Gandacu et al (2011). Recent Trends in Human Brucellosis in Israel. IMAJ 13 (359-62). http://www.ima.org.il/FilesUpload/IMAJ/0/39/19875.pdf.\n- Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/90.]\nSee Also\nBrucellosis, human, livestock - Israel: (HZ) RFI 20140513.2467609\n2013\n----\nBrucellosis, human, livestock - Syria 20130816.1882350\n2004\n----\nBrucellosis, humans & caprines - Lebanon 20040715.1907\n.................................................arn/je/dk", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "brucellosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2013-03-15 00:00:00", "2011-03-15 00:00:00", "2014-03-15 00:00:00", "2011-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Malta", "country": "Malta"}, {"location": "Jerusalem", "country": "Israel"}, {"location": "Israel", "country": "Israel"}, {"location": "syria", "country": "Syria"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2525983", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Brucellosis, human - Israel: (HZ) RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2525983", "date": "2014-06-07 18:44:34", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS, HUMAN - ISRAEL: (HAZAFON), RFI\n*******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 2 Jun 2014\nSource: YNET [in Hebrew, trans. Mod.AS, edited]\nhttp://www.ynet.co.il/articles/0,7340,L-4526332,00.html\n\n\nBrucellosis outbreak due to unpasteurized milk\n----------------------------------------------\nDue to an unusual outbreak of brucellosis in the Western Galilee, the Nahariya hospital [HaZafon (Northern District)] had to treat about 30 patients during the last 2 weeks, half of them children. The patients were found infected by the brucellosis bacterium, known to contaminate cheese and unpasteurized milk from infected animals. The cases have been reported to the Ministry of Health.\n\nThe bacteria cause a disease known as \"Malta fever.\" The disease is found mainly in the non-Jewish sector in the Galilee [north], Wadi Ara [centre] and the Negev [south].\n\nThe Director of the pediatric infectious disease service in the Galilee medical center, Dr. Daniel Glickman, said the patients, arriving during the last 2 weeks at the hospital, are residents of the Druze villages Yarka and Julis, half of them children who consumed unpasteurized cheese; many of them relatives (father and daughter, cousins) who most probably consumed cheese from a common source.\n\n\"The signs of the disease are usually joint and bone pain, accompanied by high fever. The disease is not contagious among humans and is mainly treated by antibiotics,\" he said.\n\nThe patients were hospitalized in the pediatric and internal departments. One case, a 5-year-old girl, had to be hospitalized in the ICU to stabilize her condition.\n\nIt has been said that the current wave may continue, since the incubation period of exposed persons may take weeks and sometimes even months before clinically manifested. According to the Medical Center, throughout the course of 2013, only 10 patients had to be treated.\n\nAfter questioning by the hospital's doctors, 3 possible sources of infection have been identified.\n\nAbout 10 days ago, another cluster of brucellosis was discovered, in Jerusalem; 14 people were found infected following the consumption of unpasteurized cheese brought from the territory of the Palestinian Authority [West Bank].\n\n[Byline: Achiya Rabbed]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Most likely, all reported cases of Malta fever (the commonly used name for brucellosis in Israel) have been caused by _Brucella melitensis_, the bacteria species which is regarded endemic. There is a concerning increase of reported human cases during recent years (see further data of 2011-2013). The true number of human infections is generally considered to be significantly higher, many remaining unreported.\n\nUnfortunately, humans seem to have become the sentinels of brucellosis in sheep/goat flocks.\n\nNumber of outbreaks in animals and human cases (OIE data)\n---------------------------------------------------------\nYear / Outbreaks in animals / Human cases / Rate per 100 000 population\n2011 / 6 / 127 / 1.8076\n2012 / 14 / 183 / 2.6046\n2013 / 11 / 336 / 4.7822\n\nThe majority of the human brucellosis cases in Israel are caused by the ingestion of unpasteurized dairy products produced from family-owned sheep and/or goat flocks. Exposure to infected farm animals (occupational infection) is another common cause of infection. Though most of the human cases have been encountered, during previous years, in southern Israel, the current events are indicative of significant circulation of the agent in other parts of the country. The situation in the Palestinian territories is known to be even worse.\n\nThe main reservoir of _B. melitensis_ are sheep and goats, with the main symptom being abortions. _B. melitensis_ may occasionally infect cattle. In contrast to _B. abortus_, which causes abortions in cattle, _B. melitensis_ is not abortifacient in cattle, but will infect the udders, followed by massive discharge of the highly pathogenic bacteria in the milk and consequent human infections.\n\nResults of laboratory investigations, confirming the clinical diagnosis of the described cases, will be appreciated. It will be interesting to follow the epidemiological investigations at the 3 suspected sources of infection (Western Galilee) and obtain their results, hopefully identifying the source(s). Similarly, updates on ongoing and contemplated control measures will be welcomed.\n\nProMED-mail's request for information on a previous event is pending (see 20140513.2467609).\n\nFor the number of _Brucella melitensis_ outbreaks in Israel between 1990-2012, see page 47 (sheep/goats) and 48 (cattle) at http://www.moag.gov.il/agri/files/doh_shnati_2012.pdf.\n\nFurther reading:\n1. Zuhayr A. Tabbarah (2014) Brucellosis revisited. 15th Congress, Lebanese Soc Infect. Dis & Clin Microb. http://tinyurl.com/pdepzyz.\n2. E. Anis, A. Leventhal, I. Grotto, D. Gandacu et al (2011). Recent Trends in Human Brucellosis in Israel. IMAJ 13 (359-62). http://www.ima.org.il/FilesUpload/IMAJ/0/39/19875.pdf.\n- Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/promed/p/90.]\nSee Also\nBrucellosis, human, livestock - Israel: (HZ) RFI 20140513.2467609\n2013\n----\nBrucellosis, human, livestock - Syria 20130816.1882350\n2004\n----\nBrucellosis, humans & caprines - Lebanon 20040715.1907\n.................................................arn/je/dk", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "brucellosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2013-03-15 00:00:00", "2011-03-15 00:00:00", "2014-03-15 00:00:00", "2011-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Malta", "country": "Malta"}, {"location": "Jerusalem", "country": "Israel"}, {"location": "Israel", "country": "Israel"}, {"location": "syria", "country": "Syria"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2499724", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Brucellosis - Armenia: (KT) bovine, RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2499724", "date": "2014-06-07 18:44:34", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS, HUMAN - ISRAEL: (HAZAFON), RFI\n*******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 2 Jun 2014\nSource: YNET [in Hebrew, trans. Mod.AS, edited]\nhttp://www.ynet.co.il/articles/0,7340,L-4526332,00.html\n\n\nBrucellosis outbreak due to unpasteurized milk\n----------------------------------------------\nDue to an unusual outbreak of brucellosis in the Western Galilee, the Nahariya hospital [HaZafon (Northern District)] had to treat about 30 patients during the last 2 weeks, half of them children. The patients were found infected by the brucellosis bacterium, known to contaminate cheese and unpasteurized milk from infected animals. The cases have been reported to the Ministry of Health.\n\nThe bacteria cause a disease known as \"Malta fever.\" The disease is found mainly in the non-Jewish sector in the Galilee [north], Wadi Ara [centre] and the Negev [south].\n\nThe Director of the pediatric infectious disease service in the Galilee medical center, Dr. Daniel Glickman, said the patients, arriving during the last 2 weeks at the hospital, are residents of the Druze villages Yarka and Julis, half of them children who consumed unpasteurized cheese; many of them relatives (father and daughter, cousins) who most probably consumed cheese from a common source.\n\n\"The signs of the disease are usually joint and bone pain, accompanied by high fever. The disease is not contagious among humans and is mainly treated by antibiotics,\" he said.\n\nThe patients were hospitalized in the pediatric and internal departments. One case, a 5-year-old girl, had to be hospitalized in the ICU to stabilize her condition.\n\nIt has been said that the current wave may continue, since the incubation period of exposed persons may take weeks and sometimes even months before clinically manifested. According to the Medical Center, throughout the course of 2013, only 10 patients had to be treated.\n\nAfter questioning by the hospital's doctors, 3 possible sources of infection have been identified.\n\nAbout 10 days ago, another cluster of brucellosis was discovered, in Jerusalem; 14 people were found infected following the consumption of unpasteurized cheese brought from the territory of the Palestinian Authority [West Bank].\n\n[Byline: Achiya Rabbed]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Most likely, all reported cases of Malta fever (the commonly used name for brucellosis in Israel) have been caused by _Brucella melitensis_, the bacteria species which is regarded endemic. There is a concerning increase of reported human cases during recent years (see further data of 2011-2013). The true number of human infections is generally considered to be significantly higher, many remaining unreported.\n\nUnfortunately, humans seem to have become the sentinels of brucellosis in sheep/goat flocks.\n\nNumber of outbreaks in animals and human cases (OIE data)\n---------------------------------------------------------\nYear / Outbreaks in animals / Human cases / Rate per 100 000 population\n2011 / 6 / 127 / 1.8076\n2012 / 14 / 183 / 2.6046\n2013 / 11 / 336 / 4.7822\n\nThe majority of the human brucellosis cases in Israel are caused by the ingestion of unpasteurized dairy products produced from family-owned sheep and/or goat flocks. Exposure to infected farm animals (occupational infection) is another common cause of infection. Though most of the human cases have been encountered, during previous years, in southern Israel, the current events are indicative of significant circulation of the agent in other parts of the country. The situation in the Palestinian territories is known to be even worse.\n\nThe main reservoir of _B. melitensis_ are sheep and goats, with the main symptom being abortions. _B. melitensis_ may occasionally infect cattle. In contrast to _B. abortus_, which causes abortions in cattle, _B. melitensis_ is not abortifacient in cattle, but will infect the udders, followed by massive discharge of the highly pathogenic bacteria in the milk and consequent human infections.\n\nResults of laboratory investigations, confirming the clinical diagnosis of the described cases, will be appreciated. It will be interesting to follow the epidemiological investigations at the 3 suspected sources of infection (Western Galilee) and obtain their results, hopefully identifying the source(s). Similarly, updates on ongoing and contemplated control measures will be welcomed.\n\nProMED-mail's request for information on a previous event is pending (see 20140513.2467609).\n\nFor the number of _Brucella melitensis_ outbreaks in Israel between 1990-2012, see page 47 (sheep/goats) and 48 (cattle) at http://www.moag.gov.il/agri/files/doh_shnati_2012.pdf.\n\nFurther reading:\n1. The patients were found infected by the brucellosis bacterium, known to contaminate cheese and unpasteurized milk from infected animals. The cases have been reported to the Ministry of Health.\n\nThe bacteria cause a disease known as \"Malta fever.\" The disease is found mainly in the non-Jewish sector in the Galilee [north], Wadi Ara [centre] and the Negev [south].\n\nThe Director of the pediatric infectious disease service in the Galilee medical center, Dr. Daniel Glickman, said the patients, arriving during the last 2 weeks at the hospital, are residents of the Druze villages Yarka and Julis, half of them children who consumed unpasteurized cheese; many of them relatives (father and daughter, cousins) who most probably consumed cheese from a common source.\n\n\"The signs of the disease are usually joint and bone pain, accompanied by high fever. The disease is not contagious among humans and is mainly treated by antibiotics,\" he said.\n\nThe patients were hospitalized in the pediatric and internal departments. 26(42) OIE [edited]\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=14227\n\n\nBrucellosis (_Brucella abortus_), Panama\n------------------------------------------------------\nInformation received on 13 Oct 2013 from Dr Manuel Antonio Gonzalez Cano, Delegate, Direccion de Salud Animal, Ministerio de Desarrollo Agropecuario, Panama city, Panama\n\nSummary:\nReport type: Immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 13 Aug 2013\nDate of pre-confirmation of the event: 28 Aug 2013\nReport date: 13 Oct 2013\nDate submitted to OIE: 13 Oct 2013\nReason for notification: Reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: March 2012\nManifestation of disease: Sub-clinical disease\nCausal agent: _Brucella abortus_\nNature of diagnosis: Laboratory (basic)\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country.\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nOutbreak 1: Monte Oscuro, Cermeno, Capira, Panama\nDate of start of the outbreak: 13 Aug 2013\nOutbreak status: Continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: Farm\nAffected animals:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nCattle / 78 / 4 / 0 / 0 / 4\n\nAffected population: It is a dairy farm where reactors were detected through field tests and complementary tests. Therefore, according to national regulations, modified stamping out, in this case of the reactors, is applied. No signs compatible with the disease were observed in the farm during the investigation, but, following the results obtained, an investigation has been launched in the farms in the zone in order to get more data and a possible source of infection.\n\nSummary of outbreaks: Total outbreaks: 1\nTotal animals affected:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nCattle / 78 / 4 / 0 / 0 / 4\nOutbreak statistics:\nSpecies / Apparent morbidity rate / Apparent mortality rate / Apparent case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nCattle / 5.13 percent / 0 percent / 0 percent / 5.13 percent\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction and/or slaughter\n\nEpidemiology:\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: Unknown or inconclusive\n\nEpidemiological comments: A field investigation has been launched in all the surrounding farms in order to detect additional outbreaks and the source of infection. It is appropriate to note that for this report, it has been taken into account that the disease has occurred in a zone where sampling was being done in order to declare the zone free from bovine brucellosis; no reactors had been detected previously in this zone. More details will be sent as the field investigation continues.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied:\nQuarantine\nMovement control inside the country\nModified stamping out\nVaccination prohibited\n\nMeasures to be applied:\nScreening\n\nDiagnostic test results:\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nVeterinary Research and Diagnosis Laboratory \"Dr. Gerardino Medina\" (National laboratory) / Cattle / bacteriological examination / 30 Aug 2013 / Positive\nVeterinary Research and Diagnosis Laboratory \"Dr. Gerardino Medina\" (National laboratory) / Cattle / antibody detection ELISA / 28 Aug 2013 / Positive\nFuture Reporting: The event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Brucellosis is a contagious disease of livestock with significant economic impact. The disease is caused by various bacteria of the family Brucella, which [each] tend to infect a specific animal species. However, most species of Brucella are able to infect other animal species as well. The disease affects cattle, swine, sheep and goats, camels, equines, and dogs. It may also infect other ruminants, some marine mammals, and humans.\n\nThe disease in animals is characterized by abortions or reproductive failure. While animals typically recover and will be able to have live offspring following the initial abortion, they may continue to shed the bacteria.\n\nBrucellosis in cattle (_B. abortus_) in sheep and goats (_B. melitensis_) and in swine (_B. suis_) are diseases listed in the World Organisation for Animal Health (OIE) Terrestrial Animal Health Code and must be reported to the OIE (Terrestrial Animal Health Code).\n\nBrucellosis is a zoonosis highly infectious for humans causing a disease often called undulant fever or Malta fever, since it was 1st recognized in Malta during the 1850s http://www.oie.int/fileadmin/Home/eng/Media_Center/docs/pdf/Disease_cards/BCLS-EN.pdf.\n\nQuantitative information obtained from the OIE's WAHID database shows that during 2012, 9586 outbreaks of brucellosis (_Brucella abortus_) were reported in the region of the Americas: Bolivia (44), Brazil (1188), Canada (1), Chile (32), Colombia (9), Costa Rica (201), Cuba (33), Dominican Republic (101), Ecuador (62), El Salvador (31), Guatemala (173), Honduras (49), Mexico (6994), Nicaragua (22), Panama (1), Paraguay (508), Peru (4) and Uruguay (131). This information is available at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Diseaseinformation/statusdetail.\n\nIn the United States of America, 2 outbreaks were reported during 2012. The disease was limited to free-ranging bison (_Bison bison_) and wapiti (_Cervus elaphus_) in the Greater Yellowstone National Park area. http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Diseaseinformation/statuslist/note/id/249/disn/Brucellosis%2B%2528Brucella%2Babortus%2529.\n\nThe disease is also present in Argentina and Venezuela, but no quantitative data are available http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Diseaseinformation/statuslist.\n\nPanama is the southernmost country of Central America. The country is situated on the isthmus connecting North and South America and is bordered by Costa Rica to the west, Colombia to the southeast, the Caribbean Sea to the north, and the Pacific Ocean to the south. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Panama. The country is divided into 9 provinces: Bocas del Toro, Chiriqui, Cocle, Colon, Darien, Herrera, Los Santos, Panama and Veraguas. Capira is a district of the province of Panama http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Capira_District.\n\nFrom January 2006 to December 2012, Panama reported 59 outbreaks of brucellosis (_Brucella abortus_). These 59 outbreaks were located in 7 of the 9 provinces. The incidence of brucellosis during this 7-year period and the distribution by province is summarized as follows:\nProvinces /2006 / 2007 / 2008 / 2009 / 2010 / 2011 / 2012\nBocas del Toro / / / 4 / 3 / 4 / / /\nChiriqui / 2 / 6 / 2 / 3 / 2 / / /\nCocle / 1 / 1 / / / / / /\nColon / / 1 / / / / / /\nDarien / / 1 / / / / / /\nLos Santos / / / 1 / / / / /\nVeraguas / 4 / 15 / 19 / 11 / 6 / 3 / 1\n\nThis information and additional data on Panama's outbreaks can be found in the OIE's WAHID database at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Diseaseinformation/statusdetail. (Note: to view the information on _Brucella abortus_, you need to scroll down to the name of the disease and choose the region or country and the time period). - Mod.CRD\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1D8S.]\nSee Also\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA: (MT) : 20130927.1972253\nBrucellosis, bovine tuberculosis - Honduras: bovine 20130911.1936137\nBrucellosis, (MT) 20110228.0659\n2010\n----\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA (02): (MT, WY) 20101107.4041\n2009\n----\nBrucellosis, cervids - USA: (MT) 20090117.0196\nBrucellosis, unpasteurized cheese - Mexico (03): background 20090818.2933\nBrucellosis, unpasteurized cheese - Mexico (02): (GJ) 20090817.2909\nBrucellosis, unpasteurized cheese - Mexico: (GJ) 20090313.1028\n2008\n----\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA (08): (MT), loss of status 20080905.2770\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA: (MT) 20080611.1841\n2007\n----\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA (MT)(04) 20070719.2311\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA (MT) (03) Panama\n------------------------------------------------------\nInformation received on 13 Oct 2013 from Dr Manuel Antonio Gonzalez Cano, Delegate, Direccion de Salud Animal, Ministerio de Desarrollo Agropecuario, Panama city, Panama\n\nSummary:\nReport type: Immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 13 Aug 2013\nDate of pre-confirmation of the event: 28 Aug 2013\nReport date: 13 Oct 2013\nDate submitted to OIE: 13 Oct 2013\nReason for notification: Reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: March 2012\nManifestation of disease: Sub-clinical disease\nCausal agent: _Brucella abortus_\nNature of diagnosis: Laboratory (basic)\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country.\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nOutbreak 1: Monte Oscuro, Cermeno, Capira, Panama\nDate of start of the outbreak: 13 Aug 2013\nOutbreak status: Continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: Farm\nAffected animals:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nCattle / 78 / 4 / 0 / 0 / 4\n\nAffected population: It is a dairy farm where reactors were detected through field tests and complementary tests. Therefore, according to national regulations, modified stamping out, in this case of the reactors, is applied. No signs compatible with the disease were observed in the farm during the investigation, but, following the results obtained, an investigation has been launched in the farms in the zone in order to get more data and a possible source of infection.\n\nSummary of outbreaks: Total outbreaks: 1\nTotal animals affected:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nCattle / 78 / 4 / 0 / 0 / 4\nOutbreak statistics:\nSpecies / Apparent morbidity rate / Apparent mortality rate / Apparent case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nCattle / 5.13 percent / 0 percent / 0 percent / 5.13 percent\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction and/or slaughter\n\nEpidemiology:\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: Unknown or inconclusive\n\nEpidemiological comments: A field investigation has been launched in all the surrounding farms in order to detect additional outbreaks and the source of infection. It is appropriate to note that for this report, it has been taken into account that the disease has occurred in a zone where sampling was being done in order to declare the zone free from bovine brucellosis; no reactors had been detected previously in this zone. More details will be sent as the field investigation continues.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied:\nQuarantine\nMovement control inside the country\nModified stamping out\nVaccination prohibited\n\nMeasures to be applied:\nScreening\n\nDiagnostic test results:\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nVeterinary Research and Diagnosis Laboratory \"Dr. Gerardino Medina\" (National laboratory) / Cattle / bacteriological examination / 30 Aug 2013 / Positive\nVeterinary Research and Diagnosis Laboratory \"Dr. Gerardino Medina\" (National laboratory) / Cattle / antibody detection ELISA / 28 Aug 2013 / Positive\nFuture Reporting: The event is continuing. However, most species of Brucella are able to infect other animal species as well. The disease affects cattle, swine, sheep and goats, camels, equines, and dogs. Panama\n------------------------------------------------------\nInformation received on 13 Oct 2013 from Dr Manuel Antonio Gonzalez Cano, Delegate, Direccion de Salud Animal, Ministerio de Desarrollo Agropecuario, Panama city, Panama\n\nSummary:\nReport type: Immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 13 Aug 2013\nDate of pre-confirmation of the event: 28 Aug 2013\nReport date: 13 Oct Therefore, according to national regulations, modified stamping out, in this case of the reactors, is applied. No signs compatible with the disease were observed in the farm during the investigation, but, following the results obtained, an investigation has been launched in the farms in the zone in order to get more data and a possible source of infection.\n\nSummary of outbreaks: Total outbreaks: 1\nTotal animals affected:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nCattle / 78 / 4 / 0 / 0 / 4\nOutbreak statistics:\nSpecies / Apparent morbidity rate / Apparent mortality rate / Apparent case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nCattle / 5.13 percent / 0 percent / 0 percent / 5.13 percent\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction and/or slaughter\n\nEpidemiology:\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: Unknown or inconclusive\n\nEpidemiological comments: A field investigation has been launched in all the surrounding farms in order to detect additional outbreaks and the source of infection. It is appropriate to note that for this report, it has been taken into account that the disease has occurred in a zone where sampling was being done in order to declare the zone free from bovine brucellosis; no reactors had been detected previously in this zone. More details will be sent as the field investigation continues.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied:\nQuarantine\nMovement control inside the country\nModified stamping out\nVaccination prohibited\n\nMeasures to be applied:\nScreening\n\nDiagnostic test results:\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nVeterinary Research and Diagnosis Laboratory \"Dr. Gerardino Medina\" (National laboratory) / Cattle / bacteriological examination / 30 Aug 2013 / Positive\nVeterinary Research and Diagnosis Laboratory \"Dr. Gerardino Medina\" (National laboratory) / Cattle / antibody detection ELISA / 28 Aug 2013 / Positive\nFuture Reporting: The event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Brucellosis is a contagious disease of livestock with significant economic impact. The disease is caused by various bacteria of the family Brucella, which [each] tend to infect a specific animal species. However, most species of Brucella are able to infect other animal species as well. The disease affects cattle, swine, sheep and goats, camels, equines, and dogs. It may also infect other ruminants, some marine mammals, and humans.\n\nThe disease in animals is characterized by abortions or reproductive failure. While animals typically recover and will be able to have live offspring following the initial abortion, they may continue to shed the bacteria.\n\nBrucellosis in cattle (_B. abortus_) in sheep and goats (_B. melitensis_) and in swine (_B. suis_) are diseases listed in the World Organisation for Animal Health (OIE) Terrestrial Animal Health Code and must be reported to the OIE (Terrestrial Animal Health Code).\n\nBrucellosis is a zoonosis highly infectious for humans causing a disease often called undulant fever or Malta fever, since it was 1st recognized in Malta during the 1850s http://www.oie.int/fileadmin/Home/eng/Media_Center/docs/pdf/Disease_cards/BCLS-EN.pdf.\n\nQuantitative information obtained from the OIE's WAHID database shows that during 2012, 9586 outbreaks of brucellosis (_Brucella abortus_) were reported in the region of the Americas: Bolivia (44), Brazil (1188), Canada (1), Chile (32), Colombia (9), Costa Rica (201), Cuba (33), Dominican Republic (101), Ecuador (62), El Salvador (31), Guatemala (173), Honduras (49), Mexico (6994), Nicaragua (22), Panama (1), Paraguay (508), Peru (4) and Uruguay (131). This information is available at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Diseaseinformation/statusdetail.\n\nIn the United States of America, 2 outbreaks were reported during 2012. The disease was limited to free-ranging bison (_Bison bison_) and wapiti (_Cervus elaphus_) in the Greater Yellowstone National Park area. http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Diseaseinformation/statuslist/note/id/249/disn/Brucellosis%2B%2528Brucella%2Babortus%2529.\n\nThe disease is also present in Argentina and Venezuela, but no quantitative data are available http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Diseaseinformation/statuslist.\n\nPanama is the southernmost country of Central America. The country is situated on the isthmus connecting North and South America and is bordered by Costa Rica to the west, Colombia to the southeast, the Caribbean Sea to the north, and the Pacific Ocean to the south. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Panama. The country is divided into 9 provinces: Bocas del Toro, Chiriqui, Cocle, Colon, Darien, Herrera, Los Santos, Panama and Veraguas. Capira is a district of the province of Panama http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Capira_District.\n\nFrom January 2006 to December 2012, Panama reported 59 outbreaks of brucellosis (_Brucella abortus_). These 59 outbreaks were located in 7 of the 9 provinces. The incidence of brucellosis during this 7-year period and the distribution by province is summarized as follows:\nProvinces /2006 / 2007 / 2008 / 2009 / 2010 / 2011 / 2012\nBocas del Toro / / / 4 / 3 / 4 / / /\nChiriqui / 2 / 6 / 2 / 3 / 2 / / /\nCocle / 1 / 1 / / / / / /\nColon / / 1 / / / / / /\nDarien / / 1 / / / / / /\nLos Santos / / / 1 / / / / /\nVeraguas / 4 / 15 / 19 / 11 / 6 / 3 / 1\n\nThis information and additional data on Panama's outbreaks can be found in the OIE's WAHID database at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Diseaseinformation/statusdetail. (Note: to view the information on _Brucella abortus_, you need to scroll down to the name of the disease and choose the region or country and the time period). - Mod.CRD\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1D8S.]\nSee Also\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA: (MT) : 20130927.1972253\nBrucellosis, bovine tuberculosis - Honduras: bovine 20130911.1936137\nBrucellosis, (MT) 20110228.0659\n2010\n----\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA (02): (MT, WY) 20101107.4041\n2009\n----\nBrucellosis, cervids - USA: (MT) 20090117.0196\nBrucellosis, unpasteurized cheese - Mexico (03): background 20090818.2933\nBrucellosis, unpasteurized cheese - Mexico (02): (GJ) 20090817.2909\nBrucellosis, unpasteurized cheese - Mexico: (GJ) 20090313.1028\n2008\n----\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2116241", "date": "2013-10-14 23:34:14", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS, BOVINE - PANAMA: (PANAMA PROVINCE), OIE\n****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: 13 Oct 2013\nSource: OIE, WAHID weekly disease information 2013; 26(42) OIE [edited]\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=14227\n\n\nBrucellosis (_Brucella abortus_), Panama\n------------------------------------------------------\nInformation received on 13 Oct 2013 from Dr Manuel Antonio Gonzalez Cano, Delegate, Direccion de Salud Animal, Ministerio de Desarrollo Agropecuario, Panama city, Panama\n\nSummary:\nReport type: Immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 13 Aug 2013\nDate of pre-confirmation of the event: 28 Aug 2013\nReport date: 13 Oct 2013\nDate submitted to OIE: 13 Oct 2013\nReason for notification: Reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: March 2012\nManifestation of disease: Sub-clinical disease\nCausal agent: _Brucella abortus_\nNature of diagnosis: Laboratory (basic)\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country.\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nOutbreak 1: Monte Oscuro, Cermeno, Capira, Panama\nDate of start of the outbreak: 13 Aug 2013\nOutbreak status: Continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: Farm\nAffected animals:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nCattle / 78 / 4 / 0 / 0 / 4\n\nAffected population: It is a dairy farm where reactors were detected through field tests and complementary tests. Therefore, according to national regulations, modified stamping out, in this case of the reactors, is applied. No signs compatible with the disease were observed in the farm during the investigation, but, following the results obtained, an investigation has been launched in the farms in the zone in order to get more data and a possible source of infection.\n\nSummary of outbreaks: Total outbreaks: 1\nTotal animals affected:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nCattle / 78 / 4 / 0 / 0 / 4\nOutbreak statistics:\nSpecies / Apparent morbidity rate / Apparent mortality rate / Apparent case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nCattle / 5.13 percent / 0 percent / 0 percent / 5.13 percent\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction and/or slaughter\n\nEpidemiology:\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: Unknown or inconclusive\n\nEpidemiological comments: A field investigation has been launched in all the surrounding farms in order to detect additional outbreaks and the source of infection. It is appropriate to note that for this report, it has been taken into account that the disease has occurred in a zone where sampling was being done in order to declare the zone free from bovine brucellosis; no reactors had been detected previously in this zone. More details will be sent as the field investigation continues.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied:\nQuarantine\nMovement control inside the country\nModified stamping out\nVaccination prohibited\n\nMeasures to be applied:\nScreening\n\nDiagnostic test results:\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nVeterinary Research and Diagnosis Laboratory \"Dr. Gerardino Medina\" (National laboratory) / Cattle / bacteriological examination / 30 Aug 2013 / Positive\nVeterinary Research and Diagnosis Laboratory \"Dr. Gerardino Medina\" (National laboratory) / Cattle / antibody detection ELISA / 28 Aug 2013 / Positive\nFuture Reporting: The event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Brucellosis is a contagious disease of livestock with significant economic impact. The disease is caused by various bacteria of the family Brucella, which [each] tend to infect a specific animal species. However, most species of Brucella are able to infect other animal species as well. The disease affects cattle, swine, sheep and goats, camels, equines, and dogs. It may also infect other ruminants, some marine mammals, and humans.\n\nThe disease in animals is characterized by abortions or reproductive failure. While animals typically recover and will be able to have live offspring following the initial abortion, they may continue to shed the bacteria.\n\nBrucellosis in cattle (_B. abortus_) in sheep and goats (_B. melitensis_) and in swine (_B. suis_) are diseases listed in the World Organisation for Animal Health (OIE) Terrestrial Animal Health Code and must be reported to the OIE (Terrestrial Animal Health Code).\n\nBrucellosis is a zoonosis highly infectious for humans causing a disease often called undulant fever or Malta fever, since it was 1st recognized in Malta during the 1850s http://www.oie.int/fileadmin/Home/eng/Media_Center/docs/pdf/Disease_cards/BCLS-EN.pdf.\n\nQuantitative information obtained from the OIE's WAHID database shows that during 2012, 9586 outbreaks of brucellosis (_Brucella abortus_) were reported in the region of the Americas: Bolivia (44), Brazil (1188), Canada (1), Chile (32), Colombia (9), Costa Rica (201), Cuba (33), Dominican Republic (101), Ecuador (62), El Salvador (31), Guatemala (173), Honduras (49), Mexico (6994), Nicaragua (22), Panama (1), Paraguay (508), Peru (4) and Uruguay (131). This information is available at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Diseaseinformation/statusdetail.\n\nIn the United States of America, 2 outbreaks were reported during 2012. The disease was limited to free-ranging bison (_Bison bison_) and wapiti (_Cervus elaphus_) in the Greater Yellowstone National Park area. http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Diseaseinformation/statuslist/note/id/249/disn/Brucellosis%2B%2528Brucella%2Babortus%2529.\n\nThe disease is also present in Argentina and Venezuela, but no quantitative data are available http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Diseaseinformation/statuslist.\n\nPanama is the southernmost country of Central America. The country is situated on the isthmus connecting North and South America and is bordered by Costa Rica to the west, Colombia to the southeast, the Caribbean Sea to the north, and the Pacific Ocean to the south. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Panama. The country is divided into 9 provinces: Bocas del Toro, Chiriqui, Cocle, Colon, Darien, Herrera, Los Santos, Panama and Veraguas. Capira is a district of the province of Panama http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Capira_District.\n\nFrom January 2006 to December 2012, Panama reported 59 outbreaks of brucellosis (_Brucella abortus_). These 59 outbreaks were located in 7 of the 9 provinces. The incidence of brucellosis during this 7-year period and the distribution by province is summarized as follows:\nProvinces /2006 / 2007 / 2008 / 2009 / 2010 / 2011 / 2012\nBocas del Toro / / / 4 / 3 / 4 / / /\nChiriqui / 2 / 6 / 2 / 3 / 2 / / /\nCocle / 1 / 1 / / / / / /\nColon / / 1 / / / / / /\nDarien / / 1 / / / / / /\nLos Santos / / / 1 / / / / /\nVeraguas / 4 / 15 / 19 / 11 / 6 / 3 / 1\n\nThis information and additional data on Panama's outbreaks can be found in the OIE's WAHID database at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Diseaseinformation/statusdetail. The disease is caused by various bacteria of the family Brucella, which [each] tend to infect a specific animal species. However, most species of Brucella are able to infect other animal species as well. The disease affects cattle, swine, sheep and goats, camels, equines, and dogs. It may also infect other ruminants, some marine mammals, and humans.\n\nThe disease in animals is characterized by abortions or reproductive failure. While animals typically recover and will be able to have live offspring following the initial abortion, they may continue to shed the bacteria.\n\nBrucellosis in cattle (_B. abortus_) in sheep and goats (_B. melitensis_) and in swine (_B. suis_) are diseases listed in the World Organisation for Animal Health (OIE) Terrestrial Animal Health Code and must be reported to the OIE (Terrestrial Animal Health Code).\n\nBrucellosis is a zoonosis highly infectious for humans causing a disease often called undulant fever or Malta fever, since it was 1st recognized in Malta during the 1850s http://www.oie.int/fileadmin/Home/eng/Media_Center/docs/pdf/Disease_cards/BCLS-EN.pdf.\n\nQuantitative information obtained from the OIE's WAHID database shows that during 2012, 9586 outbreaks of brucellosis (_Brucella abortus_) were reported in the region of the Americas: Bolivia (44), Brazil (1188), Canada (1), Chile (32), Colombia (9), Costa Rica (201), Cuba (33), Dominican Republic (101), Ecuador (62), El Salvador (31), Guatemala (173), Honduras (49), Mexico (6994), Nicaragua (22), Panama (1), Paraguay (508), Peru (4) and Uruguay (131). This information is available at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Diseaseinformation/statusdetail.\n\nIn the United States of America, 2 outbreaks were reported during 2012. The disease was limited to free-ranging bison (_Bison bison_) and wapiti (_Cervus elaphus_) in the Greater Yellowstone National Park area. http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Diseaseinformation/statuslist/note/id/249/disn/Brucellosis%2B%2528Brucella%2Babortus%2529.\n\nThe disease is also present in Argentina and Venezuela, but no quantitative data are available http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Diseaseinformation/statuslist.\n\nPanama is the southernmost country of Central America. The country is situated on the isthmus connecting North and South America and is bordered by Costa Rica to the west, Colombia to the southeast, the Caribbean Sea to the north, and the Pacific Ocean to the south. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Panama. The country is divided into 9 provinces: Bocas del Toro, Chiriqui, Cocle, Colon, Darien, Herrera, Los Santos, Panama and Veraguas. Capira is a district of the province of Panama http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Capira_District.\n\nFrom January 2006 to December 2012, Panama reported 59 outbreaks of brucellosis (_Brucella abortus_). These 59 outbreaks were located in 7 of the 9 provinces. The incidence of brucellosis during this 7-year period and the distribution by province is summarized as follows:\nProvinces /2006 / 2007 / 2008 / 2009 / 2010 / 2011 / 2012\nBocas del Toro / / / 4 / 3 / 4 / / /\nChiriqui / 2 / 6 / 2 / 3 / 2 / / /\nCocle / 1 / 1 / / / / / /\nColon / / 1 / / / / / /\nDarien / / 1 / / / / / /\nLos Santos / / / 1 / / / / /\nVeraguas / 4 / 15 / 19 / 11 / 6 / 3 / 1\n\nThis information and additional data on Panama's outbreaks can be found in the OIE's WAHID database at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Diseaseinformation/statusdetail. (Note: to view the information on _Brucella abortus_, you need to scroll down to the name of the disease and choose the region or country and the time period). - Mod.CRD\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1D8S.]\nSee Also\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA: (MT) : 20130927.1972253\nBrucellosis, bovine tuberculosis - Honduras: bovine 20130911.1936137\nBrucellosis, "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2058788", "date": "2013-10-14 23:34:14", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS, BOVINE - PANAMA: (PANAMA PROVINCE), OIE\n****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: 13 Oct 2013\nSource: OIE, WAHID weekly disease information 2013; 26(42) OIE [edited]\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=14227\n\n\nBrucellosis (_Brucella abortus_), Panama\n------------------------------------------------------\nInformation received on 13 Oct 2013 from Dr Manuel Antonio Gonzalez Cano, Delegate, Direccion de Salud Animal, Ministerio de Desarrollo Agropecuario, Panama city, Panama\n\nSummary:\nReport type: Immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 13 Aug 2013\nDate of pre-confirmation of the event: 28 Aug 2013\nReport date: 13 Oct 2013\nDate submitted to OIE: 13 Oct 2013\nReason for notification: Reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: March 2012\nManifestation of disease: Sub-clinical disease\nCausal agent: _Brucella abortus_\nNature of diagnosis: Laboratory (basic)\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country.\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nOutbreak 1: Monte Oscuro, Cermeno, Capira, Panama\nDate of start of the outbreak: 13 Aug 2013\nOutbreak status: Continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: Farm\nAffected animals:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nCattle / 78 / 4 / 0 / 0 / 4\n\nAffected population: It is a dairy farm where reactors were detected through field tests and complementary tests. Therefore, according to national regulations, modified stamping out, in this case of the reactors, is applied. No signs compatible with the disease were observed in the farm during the investigation, but, following the results obtained, an investigation has been launched in the farms in the zone in order to get more data and a possible source of infection.\n\nSummary of outbreaks: Total outbreaks: 1\nTotal animals affected:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nCattle / 78 / 4 / 0 / 0 / 4\nOutbreak statistics:\nSpecies / Apparent morbidity rate / Apparent mortality rate / Apparent case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nCattle / 5.13 percent / 0 percent / 0 percent / 5.13 percent\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction and/or slaughter\n\nEpidemiology:\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: Unknown or inconclusive\n\nEpidemiological comments: A field investigation has been launched in all the surrounding farms in order to detect additional outbreaks and the source of infection. It is appropriate to note that for this report, it has been taken into account that the disease has occurred in a zone where sampling was being done in order to declare the zone free from bovine brucellosis; no reactors had been detected previously in this zone. More details will be sent as the field investigation continues.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied:\nQuarantine\nMovement control inside the country\nModified stamping out\nVaccination prohibited\n\nMeasures to be applied:\nScreening\n\nDiagnostic test results:\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nVeterinary Research and Diagnosis Laboratory \"Dr. Gerardino Medina\" (National laboratory) / Cattle / bacteriological examination / 30 Aug 2013 / Positive\nVeterinary Research and Diagnosis Laboratory \"Dr. Gerardino Medina\" (National laboratory) / Cattle / antibody detection ELISA / 28 Aug 2013 / Positive\nFuture Reporting: The event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Brucellosis is a contagious disease of livestock with significant economic impact. The disease is caused by various bacteria of the family Brucella, which [each] tend to infect a specific animal species. However, most species of Brucella are able to infect other animal species as well. The disease affects cattle, swine, sheep and goats, camels, equines, and dogs. It may also infect other ruminants, some marine mammals, and humans.\n\nThe disease in animals is characterized by abortions or reproductive failure. While animals typically recover and will be able to have live offspring following the initial abortion, they may continue to shed the bacteria.\n\nBrucellosis in cattle (_B. abortus_) in sheep and goats (_B. melitensis_) and in swine (_B. suis_) are diseases listed in the World Organisation for Animal Health (OIE) Terrestrial Animal Health Code and must be reported to the OIE (Terrestrial Animal Health Code).\n\nBrucellosis is a zoonosis highly infectious for humans causing a disease often called undulant fever or Malta fever, since it was 1st recognized in Malta during the 1850s http://www.oie.int/fileadmin/Home/eng/Media_Center/docs/pdf/Disease_cards/BCLS-EN.pdf.\n\nQuantitative information obtained from the OIE's WAHID database shows that during 2012, 9586 outbreaks of brucellosis (_Brucella abortus_) were reported in the region of the Americas: Bolivia (44), Brazil (1188), Canada (1), Chile (32), Colombia (9), Costa Rica (201), Cuba (33), Dominican Republic (101), Ecuador (62), El Salvador (31), Guatemala (173), Honduras (49), Mexico (6994), Nicaragua (22), Panama (1), Paraguay (508), Peru (4) and Uruguay (131). This information is available at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Diseaseinformation/statusdetail.\n\nIn the United States of America, 2 outbreaks were reported during 2012. The disease was limited to free-ranging bison (_Bison bison_) and wapiti (_Cervus elaphus_) in the Greater Yellowstone National Park area. http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Diseaseinformation/statuslist/note/id/249/disn/Brucellosis%2B%2528Brucella%2Babortus%2529.\n\nThe disease is also present in Argentina and Venezuela, but no quantitative data are available http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Diseaseinformation/statuslist.\n\nPanama is the southernmost country of Central America. The country is situated on the isthmus connecting North and South America and is bordered by Costa Rica to the west, Colombia to the southeast, the Caribbean Sea to the north, and the Pacific Ocean to the south. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Panama. The country is divided into 9 provinces: Bocas del Toro, Chiriqui, Cocle, Colon, Darien, Herrera, Los Santos, Panama and Veraguas. Capira is a district of the province of Panama http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Capira_District.\n\nFrom January 2006 to December 2012, Panama reported 59 outbreaks of brucellosis (_Brucella abortus_). These 59 outbreaks were located in 7 of the 9 provinces. The incidence of brucellosis during this 7-year period and the distribution by province is summarized as follows:\nProvinces /2006 / 2007 / 2008 / 2009 / 2010 / 2011 / 2012\nBocas del Toro / / / 4 / 3 / 4 / / /\nChiriqui / 2 / 6 / 2 / 3 / 2 / / /\nCocle / 1 / 1 / / / / / /\nColon / / 1 / / / / / /\nDarien / / 1 / / / / / /\nLos Santos / / / 1 / / / / /\nVeraguas / 4 / 15 / 19 / 11 / 6 / 3 / 1\n\nThis information and additional data on Panama's outbreaks can be found in the OIE's WAHID database at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Diseaseinformation/statusdetail. (Note: to view the information on _Brucella abortus_, you need to scroll down to the name of the disease and choose the region or country and the time period). - Mod.CRD\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1D8S.]\nSee Also\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA: (MT) : 20130927.1972253\nBrucellosis, bovine tuberculosis - Honduras: bovine 20130911.1936137\nBrucellosis,
