"https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2001918", "date": "2013-10-14 23:34:14", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS, BOVINE - PANAMA: (PANAMA PROVINCE), OIE\n****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: 13 Oct 2013\nSource: OIE, WAHID weekly disease information 2013; 26(42) OIE [edited]\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=14227\n\n\nBrucellosis (_Brucella abortus_), Panama\n------------------------------------------------------\nInformation received on 13 Oct 2013 from Dr Manuel Antonio Gonzalez Cano, Delegate, Direccion de Salud Animal, Ministerio de Desarrollo Agropecuario, Panama city, Panama\n\nSummary:\nReport type: Immediate notification\nDate of start of the event: 13 Aug 2013\nDate of pre-confirmation of the event: 28 Aug 2013\nReport date: 13 Oct 2013\nDate submitted to OIE: 13 Oct 2013\nReason for notification: Reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence: March 2012\nManifestation of disease: Sub-clinical disease\nCausal agent: _Brucella abortus_\nNature of diagnosis: Laboratory (basic)\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country.\n\nNew outbreaks (1)\nOutbreak 1: Monte Oscuro, Cermeno, Capira, Panama\nDate of start of the outbreak: 13 Aug 2013\nOutbreak status: Continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: Farm\nAffected animals:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nCattle / 78 / 4 / 0 / 0 / 4\n\nAffected population: It is a dairy farm where reactors were detected through field tests and complementary tests. Therefore, according to national regulations, modified stamping out, in this case of the reactors, is applied. No signs compatible with the disease were observed in the farm during the investigation, but, following the results obtained, an investigation has been launched in the farms in the zone in order to get more data and a possible source of infection.\n\nSummary of outbreaks: Total outbreaks: 1\nTotal animals affected:\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nCattle / 78 / 4 / 0 / 0 / 4\nOutbreak statistics:\nSpecies / Apparent morbidity rate / Apparent mortality rate / Apparent case fatality rate / Proportion susceptible animals lost*\nCattle / 5.13 percent / 0 percent / 0 percent / 5.13 percent\n*Removed from the susceptible population through death, destruction and/or slaughter\n\nEpidemiology:\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: Unknown or inconclusive\n\nEpidemiological comments: A field investigation has been launched in all the surrounding farms in order to detect additional outbreaks and the source of infection. It is appropriate to note that for this report, it has been taken into account that the disease has occurred in a zone where sampling was being done in order to declare the zone free from bovine brucellosis; no reactors had been detected previously in this zone. More details will be sent as the field investigation continues.\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied:\nQuarantine\nMovement control inside the country\nModified stamping out\nVaccination prohibited\n\nMeasures to be applied:\nScreening\n\nDiagnostic test results:\nLaboratory name and type / Species / Test / Test date / Result\nVeterinary Research and Diagnosis Laboratory \"Dr. Gerardino Medina\" (National laboratory) / Cattle / bacteriological examination / 30 Aug 2013 / Positive\nVeterinary Research and Diagnosis Laboratory \"Dr. Gerardino Medina\" (National laboratory) / Cattle / antibody detection ELISA / 28 Aug 2013 / Positive\nFuture Reporting: The event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Brucellosis is a contagious disease of livestock with significant economic impact. The disease is caused by various bacteria of the family Brucella, which [each] tend to infect a specific animal species. However, most species of Brucella are able to infect other animal species as well. The disease affects cattle, swine, sheep and goats, camels, equines, and dogs. It may also infect other ruminants, some marine mammals, and humans.\n\nThe disease in animals is characterized by abortions or reproductive failure. While animals typically recover and will be able to have live offspring following the initial abortion, they may continue to shed the bacteria.\n\nBrucellosis in cattle (_B. abortus_) in sheep and goats (_B. melitensis_) and in swine (_B. suis_) are diseases listed in the World Organisation for Animal Health (OIE) Terrestrial Animal Health Code and must be reported to the OIE (Terrestrial Animal Health Code).\n\nBrucellosis is a zoonosis highly infectious for humans causing a disease often called undulant fever or Malta fever, since it was 1st recognized in Malta during the 1850s http://www.oie.int/fileadmin/Home/eng/Media_Center/docs/pdf/Disease_cards/BCLS-EN.pdf.\n\nQuantitative information obtained from the OIE's WAHID database shows that during 2012, 9586 outbreaks of brucellosis (_Brucella abortus_) were reported in the region of the Americas: Bolivia (44), Brazil (1188), Canada (1), Chile (32), Colombia (9), Costa Rica (201), Cuba (33), Dominican Republic (101), Ecuador (62), El Salvador (31), Guatemala (173), Honduras (49), Mexico (6994), Nicaragua (22), Panama (1), Paraguay (508), Peru (4) and Uruguay (131). This information is available at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Diseaseinformation/statusdetail.\n\nIn the United States of America, 2 outbreaks were reported during 2012. The disease was limited to free-ranging bison (_Bison bison_) and wapiti (_Cervus elaphus_) in the Greater Yellowstone National Park area. http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Diseaseinformation/statuslist/note/id/249/disn/Brucellosis%2B%2528Brucella%2Babortus%2529.\n\nThe disease is also present in Argentina and Venezuela, but no quantitative data are available http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Diseaseinformation/statuslist.\n\nPanama is the southernmost country of Central America. The country is situated on the isthmus connecting North and South America and is bordered by Costa Rica to the west, Colombia to the southeast, the Caribbean Sea to the north, and the Pacific Ocean to the south. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Panama. The country is divided into 9 provinces: Bocas del Toro, Chiriqui, Cocle, Colon, Darien, Herrera, Los Santos, Panama and Veraguas. Capira is a district of the province of Panama http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Capira_District.\n\nFrom January 2006 to December 2012, Panama reported 59 outbreaks of brucellosis (_Brucella abortus_). These 59 outbreaks were located in 7 of the 9 provinces. The incidence of brucellosis during this 7-year period and the distribution by province is summarized as follows:\nProvinces /2006 / 2007 / 2008 / 2009 / 2010 / 2011 / 2012\nBocas del Toro / / / 4 / 3 / 4 / / /\nChiriqui / 2 / 6 / 2 / 3 / 2 / / /\nCocle / 1 / 1 / / / / / /\nColon / / 1 / / / / / /\nDarien / / 1 / / / / / /\nLos Santos / / / 1 / / / / /\nVeraguas / 4 / 15 / 19 / 11 / 6 / 3 / 1\n\nThis information and additional data on Panama's outbreaks can be found in the OIE's WAHID database at http://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Diseaseinformation/statusdetail. (Note: to view the information on _Brucella abortus_, you need to scroll down to the name of the disease and choose the region or country and the time period). - Mod.CRD\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1D8S.]\nSee Also\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA: (MT) : 20130927.1972253\nBrucellosis, bovine tuberculosis - Honduras: bovine 20130911.1936137\nBrucellosis, (MT) 20110228.0659\n2010\n----\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA (02): (MT, WY) 20101107.4041\n2009\n----\nBrucellosis, cervids - USA: (MT) 20090117.0196\nBrucellosis, unpasteurized cheese - Mexico (03): "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1972253", "date": "2013-05-10 16:02:21", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS, PORCINE - NETHERLANDS: (LIMBURG) SEROVAR 2, WILD BOAR, OIE\n***********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 19 May 2013\nSource: OIE, WAHID 2013; 26 (20) [summarised, edited]\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=13407\n\n\nBrucellosis (_Brucella suis_), Netherlands\n--------------------------------------\nInformation received on 10 May 2013 from Dr Christianne Bruschke, Chief Veterinary Officer, Ministry of Agriculture, Nature and Food Quality, The Hague, Netherlands\n\nSummary\nReport type: Immediate notification (Final report)\n\nDate of start of the event: 6 May 2013\nDate of pre-confirmation of the event: 6 May 2013\nReport date: 10 May 2013\nDate submitted to OIE: 10 May 2013\nDate event resolved: 10 May 2013\nReason for notification: 1st occurrence of a listed disease\nManifestation of disease: Sub-clinical infection\nCausal agent: _Brucella suis_ - biovar 2\nNature of diagnosis: Laboratory (basic), Laboratory (advanced)\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country\n\nNew outbreaks\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak Location: Limburg (Vaals en Margraten)\n\nTotal animals affected\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\n\nWild boar: _Suidae_ (_Sus scrofa_) / 30 / 2 / 0 / 0 / 2\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection; Unknown or inconclusive\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: No vaccination; No treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: No other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type: Central Veterinary Institute (CVI), Lelystad (National laboratory)\n\nTests and results\nSpecies / Test / Test date / Result\nWild boar / bacteriological examination / 6 May 2013 / Positive\nWild boar / polymerase chain reaction (PCR) / 6 May 2013 / Positive\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Brucellosis caused by _B. suis_ biovar 2 differs from infection caused by biovars 1 and 3 in its host range, its distribution, and in its pathology. In general, the geographical distribution of biovar 2 has historically been in a broad range between Scandinavia and the Balkans. The prevalence in wild boars appears to be high throughout continental Europe. In recent outbreaks in Europe, wild boars have been implicated as the source of transmission of biovar 2 to outdoor reared pigs; in rare cases, such as the one recently described in Belgium (see 20120520.1139015), other domestic animals, such as bovines, may become infected.\n\nIn addition to wild boars, the European hare (_Lepus capensis_) is also considered to be a reservoir for _B. suis_ biovar 2 and has been implicated as a possible source of transmission to domestic livestock. _Brucella suis_ biovar 2 causes miliary lesions, particularly in reproductive tissues, that often become purulent. To date, biovar 2 has rarely been reported as the cause of human brucellosis. However, biovar 2 infection has been reported in 2 immuno-compromised hunters who had been extensively exposed through gutting or skinning boars or hares.\n\nThe above information is mainly derived from chapter 2.8.5 of OIE's Manual of Diagnostic Tests and Vaccines for Terrestrial Animals, where additional information can be found; available at http://www.oie.int/fileadmin/Home/eng/Health_standards/tahm/2.08.05_PORCINE_BRUC.pdf.\n\nThe above OIE notification includes an interactive map. The infected wild boars have been sampled near the border junction with Belgium and Germany, countries known to be infected with _B.suis_. - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1r1l.]\nSee Also\n2012\n----\nBrucellosis, porcine - Belgium (02): serovar 2, wild boar, bovine 20120710.1196658\nBrucellosis, porcine - Belgium: serovar 2, wild boar 20120623.1178499\n2008\n----\nBrucellosis, porcine - Romania: OIE 20081011.3220\nBrucellosis, porcine - Germany: (MV), serovar 2 20080923.2995\nBrucellosis, porcine - Germany: (MV) 20080918.2927\n.................................................arn/msp/lm", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "brucellosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2013-03-15 00:00:00", "2013-05-10 00:00:00", "2013-05-06 00:00:00", "2013-05-06 00:00:00", "2013-05-10 00:00:00", "2013-05-10 00:00:00", "2013-05-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Germany", "country": "Germany"}, {"location": "Netherlands", "country": "Netherlands"}, {"location": "belgium", "country": "Belgium"}, {"location": "the Hague", "country": "Netherlands"}, {"location": "Belgium", "country": "Belgium"}, {"location": "Limburg", "country": "Netherlands"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1936137", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Brucellosis, bovine tuberculosis - Honduras: bovine", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1936137", "date": "2013-05-10 16:02:21", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS, PORCINE - NETHERLANDS: (LIMBURG) SEROVAR 2, WILD BOAR, OIE\n***********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 19 May 2013\nSource: OIE, WAHID 2013; 26 (20) [summarised, edited]\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=13407\n\n\nBrucellosis (_Brucella suis_), Netherlands\n--------------------------------------\nInformation received on 10 May 2013 from Dr Christianne Bruschke, Chief Veterinary Officer, Ministry of Agriculture, Nature and Food Quality, The Hague, Netherlands\n\nSummary\nReport type: Immediate notification (Final report)\n\nDate of start of the event: 6 May 2013\nDate of pre-confirmation of the event: 6 May 2013\nReport date: 10 May 2013\nDate submitted to OIE: 10 May 2013\nDate event resolved: 10 May 2013\nReason for notification: 1st occurrence of a listed disease\nManifestation of disease: Sub-clinical infection\nCausal agent: _Brucella suis_ - biovar 2\nNature of diagnosis: Laboratory (basic), Laboratory (advanced)\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country\n\nNew outbreaks\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak Location: Limburg (Vaals en Margraten)\n\nTotal animals affected\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\n\nWild boar: _Suidae_ (_Sus scrofa_) / 30 / 2 / 0 / 0 / 2\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection; Unknown or inconclusive\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: No vaccination; No treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: No other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type: Central Veterinary Institute (CVI), Lelystad (National laboratory)\n\nTests and results\nSpecies / Test / Test date / Result\nWild boar / bacteriological examination / 6 May 2013 / Positive\nWild boar / polymerase chain reaction (PCR) / 6 May 2013 / Positive\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Brucellosis caused by _B. suis_ biovar 2 differs from infection caused by biovars 1 and 3 in its host range, its distribution, and in its pathology. In general, the geographical distribution of biovar 2 has historically been in a broad range between Scandinavia and the Balkans. The prevalence in wild boars appears to be high throughout continental Europe. In recent outbreaks in Europe, wild boars have been implicated as the source of transmission of biovar 2 to outdoor reared pigs; in rare cases, such as the one recently described in Belgium (see 20120520.1139015), other domestic animals, such as bovines, may become infected.\n\nIn addition to wild boars, the European hare (_Lepus capensis_) is also considered to be a reservoir for _B. suis_ biovar 2 and has been implicated as a possible source of transmission to domestic livestock. _Brucella suis_ biovar 2 causes miliary lesions, particularly in reproductive tissues, that often become purulent. To date, biovar 2 has rarely been reported as the cause of human brucellosis. However, biovar 2 infection has been reported in 2 immuno-compromised hunters who had been extensively exposed through gutting or skinning boars or hares.\n\nThe above information is mainly derived from chapter 2.8.5 of OIE's Manual of Diagnostic Tests and Vaccines for Terrestrial Animals, where additional information can be found; available at http://www.oie.int/fileadmin/Home/eng/Health_standards/tahm/2.08.05_PORCINE_BRUC.pdf.\n\nThe above OIE notification includes an interactive map. The infected wild boars have been sampled near the border junction with Belgium and Germany, countries known to be infected with _B.suis_. - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1r1l.]\nSee Also\n2012\n----\nBrucellosis, porcine - Belgium (02): serovar 2, wild boar, bovine 20120710.1196658\nBrucellosis, porcine - Belgium: serovar 2, wild boar 20120623.1178499\n2008\n----\nBrucellosis, porcine - Romania: OIE 20081011.3220\nBrucellosis, porcine - Germany: (MV), serovar 2 20080923.2995\nBrucellosis, porcine - Germany: (MV) 20080918.2927\n.................................................arn/msp/lm", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "brucellosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2013-03-15 00:00:00", "2013-05-10 00:00:00", "2013-05-06 00:00:00", "2013-05-06 00:00:00", "2013-05-10 00:00:00", "2013-05-10 00:00:00", "2013-05-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Germany", "country": "Germany"}, {"location": "Netherlands", "country": "Netherlands"}, {"location": "belgium", "country": "Belgium"}, {"location": "the Hague", "country": "Netherlands"}, {"location": "Belgium", "country": "Belgium"}, {"location": "Limburg", "country": "Netherlands"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1882350", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Brucellosis, human, livestock - Syria", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1882350", "date": "2013-05-10 16:02:21", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS, PORCINE - NETHERLANDS: (LIMBURG) SEROVAR 2, WILD BOAR, OIE\n***********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 19 May 2013\nSource: OIE, WAHID 2013; 26 (20) [summarised, edited]\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=13407\n\n\nBrucellosis (_Brucella suis_), Netherlands\n--------------------------------------\nInformation received on 10 May 2013 from Dr Christianne Bruschke, Chief Veterinary Officer, Ministry of Agriculture, Nature and Food Quality, The Hague, Netherlands\n\nSummary\nReport type: Immediate notification (Final report)\n\nDate of start of the event: 6 May 2013\nDate of pre-confirmation of the event: 6 May 2013\nReport date: 10 May 2013\nDate submitted to OIE: 10 May 2013\nDate event resolved: 10 May 2013\nReason for notification: 1st occurrence of a listed disease\nManifestation of disease: Sub-clinical infection\nCausal agent: _Brucella suis_ - biovar 2\nNature of diagnosis: Laboratory (basic), Laboratory (advanced)\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country\n\nNew outbreaks\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak Location: Limburg (Vaals en Margraten)\n\nTotal animals affected\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\n\nWild boar: _Suidae_ (_Sus scrofa_) / 30 / 2 / 0 / 0 / 2\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection; Unknown or inconclusive\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: No vaccination; No treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: No other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type: Central Veterinary Institute (CVI), Lelystad (National laboratory)\n\nTests and results\nSpecies / Test / Test date / Result\nWild boar / bacteriological examination / 6 May 2013 / Positive\nWild boar / polymerase chain reaction (PCR) / 6 May 2013 / Positive\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Brucellosis caused by _B. suis_ biovar 2 differs from infection caused by biovars 1 and 3 in its host range, its distribution, and in its pathology. In general, the geographical distribution of biovar 2 has historically been in a broad range between Scandinavia and the Balkans. The prevalence in wild boars appears to be high throughout continental Europe. In recent outbreaks in Europe, wild boars have been implicated as the source of transmission of biovar 2 to outdoor reared pigs; in rare cases, such as the one recently described in Belgium (see 20120520.1139015), other domestic animals, such as bovines, may become infected.\n\nIn addition to wild boars, the European hare (_Lepus capensis_) is also considered to be a reservoir for _B. suis_ biovar 2 and has been implicated as a possible source of transmission to domestic livestock. _Brucella suis_ biovar 2 causes miliary lesions, particularly in reproductive tissues, that often become purulent. To date, biovar 2 has rarely been reported as the cause of human brucellosis. However, biovar 2 infection has been reported in 2 immuno-compromised hunters who had been extensively exposed through gutting or skinning boars or hares.\n\nThe above information is mainly derived from chapter 2.8.5 of OIE's Manual of Diagnostic Tests and Vaccines for Terrestrial Animals, where additional information can be found; available at http://www.oie.int/fileadmin/Home/eng/Health_standards/tahm/2.08.05_PORCINE_BRUC.pdf.\n\nThe above OIE notification includes an interactive map. The infected wild boars have been sampled near the border junction with Belgium and Germany, countries known to be infected with _B.suis_. - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1r1l.]\nSee Also\n2012\n----\nBrucellosis, porcine - Belgium (02): serovar 2, wild boar, bovine 20120710.1196658\nBrucellosis, porcine - Belgium: serovar 2, wild boar 20120623.1178499\n2008\n----\nBrucellosis, porcine - Romania: OIE 20081011.3220\nBrucellosis, porcine - Germany: (MV), serovar 2 20080923.2995\nBrucellosis, porcine - Germany: (MV) 20080918.2927\n.................................................arn/msp/lm", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "brucellosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2013-03-15 00:00:00", "2013-05-10 00:00:00", "2013-05-06 00:00:00", "2013-05-06 00:00:00", "2013-05-10 00:00:00", "2013-05-10 00:00:00", "2013-05-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Germany", "country": "Germany"}, {"location": "Netherlands", "country": "Netherlands"}, {"location": "belgium", "country": "Belgium"}, {"location": "the Hague", "country": "Netherlands"}, {"location": "Belgium", "country": "Belgium"}, {"location": "Limburg", "country": "Netherlands"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1747202", "headline": "PRO/AH> Brucellosis, cervid - USA (02): (WY)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1747202", "date": "2013-05-10 16:02:21", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS, PORCINE - NETHERLANDS: (LIMBURG) SEROVAR 2, WILD BOAR, OIE\n***********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 19 May 2013\nSource: OIE, WAHID 2013; The prevalence in wild boars appears to be high throughout continental Europe. In recent outbreaks in Europe, wild boars have been implicated as the source of transmission of biovar 2 to outdoor reared pigs; in rare cases, such as the one recently described in Belgium (see 20120520.1139015), other domestic animals, such as bovines, may become infected.\n\nIn addition to wild boars, the European hare (_Lepus capensis_) is also considered to be a reservoir for _B. suis_ biovar 2 and has been implicated as a possible source of transmission to domestic livestock. _Brucella suis_ biovar 2 causes miliary lesions, particularly in reproductive tissues, that often become purulent. To date, biovar 2 has rarely been reported as the cause of human brucellosis. However, biovar 2 infection has been reported in 2 immuno-compromised hunters who had been extensively exposed through gutting or skinning boars or hares.\n\nThe above information is mainly derived from chapter 2.8.5 of OIE's Manual of Diagnostic Tests and Vaccines for Terrestrial Animals, where additional information can be found; available at http://www.oie.int/fileadmin/Home/eng/Health_standards/tahm/2.08.05_PORCINE_BRUC.pdf.\n\nThe above OIE notification includes an interactive map. The infected wild boars have been sampled near the border junction with Belgium and Germany, countries known to be infected with _B.suis_. - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1r1l.]\nSee Also\n2012\n----\nBrucellosis, porcine - Belgium (02): serovar 2, wild boar, bovine 20120710.1196658\nBrucellosis, porcine - Belgium: serovar 2, wild boar 20120623.1178499\n2008\n----\nBrucellosis, porcine - Romania: OIE 20081011.3220\nBrucellosis, porcine - Germany: (MV), serovar 2 20080923.2995\nBrucellosis, porcine - Germany: (MV) 20080918.2927\n.................................................arn/msp/lm", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "brucellosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2013-03-15 00:00:00", "2013-05-10 00:00:00", "2013-05-06 00:00:00", "2013-05-06 00:00:00", "2013-05-10 00:00:00", "2013-05-10 00:00:00", "2013-05-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Germany", "country": "Germany"}, {"location": "Netherlands", "country": "Netherlands"}, {"location": "belgium", "country": "Belgium"}, {"location": "the Hague", "country": "Netherlands"}, {"location": "Belgium", "country": "Belgium"}, {"location": "Limburg", "country": "Netherlands"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1550757", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Brucellosis, bovine - Chile: (MA)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1550757", "date": "2013-05-10 16:02:21", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS, PORCINE - NETHERLANDS: (LIMBURG) SEROVAR 2, WILD BOAR, OIE\n***********************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 19 May 2013\nSource: OIE, WAHID 2013; 26 (20) [summarised, edited]\nhttp://www.oie.int/wahis_2/public/wahid.php/Reviewreport/Review?page_refer=MapFullEventReport&reportid=13407\n\n\nBrucellosis (_Brucella suis_), Netherlands\n--------------------------------------\nInformation received on 10 May 2013 from Dr Christianne Bruschke, Chief Veterinary Officer, Ministry of Agriculture, Nature and Food Quality, The Hague, Netherlands\n\nSummary\nReport type: Immediate notification (Final report)\n\nDate of start of the event: 6 May 2013\nDate of pre-confirmation of the event: 6 May 2013\nReport date: 10 May 2013\nDate submitted to OIE: 10 May 2013\nDate event resolved: 10 May 2013\nReason for notification: 1st occurrence of a listed disease\nManifestation of disease: Sub-clinical infection\nCausal agent: _Brucella suis_ - biovar 2\nNature of diagnosis: Laboratory (basic), Laboratory (advanced)\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country\n\nNew outbreaks\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak Location: Limburg (Vaals en Margraten)\n\nTotal animals affected\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\n\nWild boar: _Suidae_ (_Sus scrofa_) / 30 / 2 / 0 / 0 / 2\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection; Unknown or inconclusive\n\nControl measures\nMeasures applied: No vaccination; No treatment of affected animals\nMeasures to be applied: No other measures\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type: Central Veterinary Institute (CVI), Lelystad (National laboratory)\n\nTests and results\nSpecies / Test / Test date / Result\nWild boar / bacteriological examination / 6 May 2013 / Positive\nWild boar / polymerase chain reaction (PCR) / 6 May 2013 / Positive\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Brucellosis caused by _B. suis_ biovar 2 differs from infection caused by biovars 1 and 3 in its host range, its distribution, and in its pathology. In general, the geographical distribution of biovar 2 has historically been in a broad range between Scandinavia and the Balkans. The prevalence in wild boars appears to be high throughout continental Europe. In recent outbreaks in Europe, wild boars have been implicated as the source of transmission of biovar 2 to outdoor reared pigs; in rare cases, such as the one recently described in Belgium (see 20120520.1139015), other domestic animals, such as bovines, may become infected.\n\nIn addition to wild boars, the European hare (_Lepus capensis_) is also considered to be a reservoir for _B. suis_ biovar 2 and has been implicated as a possible source of transmission to domestic livestock. _Brucella suis_ biovar 2 causes miliary lesions, particularly in reproductive tissues, that often become purulent. To date, biovar 2 has rarely been reported as the cause of human brucellosis. However, biovar 2 infection has been reported in 2 immuno-compromised hunters who had been extensively exposed through gutting or skinning boars or hares.\n\nThe above information is mainly derived from chapter 2.8.5 of OIE's Manual of Diagnostic Tests and Vaccines for Terrestrial Animals, where additional information can be found; available at http://www.oie.int/fileadmin/Home/eng/Health_standards/tahm/2.08.05_PORCINE_BRUC.pdf.\n\nThe above OIE notification includes an interactive map. The infected wild boars have been sampled near the border junction with Belgium and Germany, countries known to be infected with _B.suis_. - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1r1l.]\nSee Also\n2012\n----\nBrucellosis, porcine - Spain: background", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1415946", "date": "2012-11-19 16:45:00", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS, HUMAN - SPAIN: BACKGROUND\n**************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Mon 19 Nov 2012\nFrom: Steve Berger [edited]\n<mberger@post.tau.ac.il>\n\n\nComment on Brucellosis, bovine - Spain: (GA) RFI 20121118.1414609\n-----------------------------------------------------------\nRates of human brucellosis in Spain and surrounding countries [France, Portugal Andora] have been decreasing for several years -- see graph http://cdn.gideononline.com/wp/wp-content/uploads/Brucella-Spain.png.\n\nAs recently as 1990, reports had suggested that brucellosis was as common as salmonellosis -- see graph http://cdn.gideononline.com/wp/wp-content/uploads/Brucella-Spain2.png. [1-3]\n\nReferences:\n1. Berger SA. Infectious Diseases of Spain, 2012. 557 pages, 194 graphs, 2850 references. Brucellosis: Global Status, 2012. 130 pages, 135 graphs, 833 references.\nhttp://www.gideononline.com/ebooks/disease/brucellosis-global-status/\n3. Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1zJm.]\nSee Also\nBrucellosis, bovine - Spain: (GA) RFI 20121118.1414609\n2003\n----\nBrucellosis, human - Spain (Granada) 20030821.2097\n.................................................arn/ejp/ml", "reports": [{"diseases": ["brucellosis", "salmonellosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1990-03-15 00:00:00", "2012-03-15 00:00:00", "2012-03-15 00:00:00", "2003-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Galicia", "country": "Ukraine"}, {"location": "France", "country": "France"}, {"location": "Spain", "country": "Spain"}, {"location": "Portugal", "country": "Portugal"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1414609", "headline": "PRO/AH> Brucellosis, bovine - Spain: (GA) RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1414609", "date": "2012-07-10 21:09:27", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS, PORCINE - BELGIUM (02): SEROVAR 2, WILD BOAR, BOVINE\n*****************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 10 Jul 2012\nFrom: David Fretin <David.Fretin@coda-cerva.be> [edited]\n\n\nBrucella suis biovar 2 in cattle: Follow up\n-------------------------------------------\nAn outbreak of Brucellosis due to _Brucella abortus_ and affecting Belgian cattle was 1st notified on 5 Mar 2012 and is currently investigated. In the context of a bulk tank milk screening aimed at controlling this outbreak, a sample from a farm near Florennes (Province of Namur) was found ELISA positive by the local 1st-line laboratory (ARSIA). Subsequent individual serum testing of all (155) lactating animals of this herd identified a single 4-year old cow (born on the farm and not pregnant) that tested positive by ELISA and sero-agglutination. This animal displayed no clinical symptom of brucellosis and was slaughtered on 23 Apr 2012.\n\nBacteriological tests were conducted at the national reference laboratory (CERVA-CODA) on lymph nodes, spleen and uterus. The lymph nodes were found negative, but colonies of a _Brucella_ sp. were isolated from both the spleen and the uterus and were unexpectedly identified as _Brucella suis biovar 2_ (_B. suis bv2_) using both biochemical and molecular typing methods. A B. suis-specific real-time PCR test (Ref 1) turned positive on DNA extracted directly from the uterus, ruling out a possible cross-contamination in the laboratory. Molecular typing of this cow isolate demonstrated a genetic profile highly related to the profile of _B. suis bv2_ strains normally retrieved from wild boars in Belgium. None of the other animals in the herd was found positive for Brucella.\n\nAuthorities have ordered a one-month hunting campaign in the surroundings of Florennes [which] started on 19 May 2012 with the aim of reducing urgently the local wild boar population while providing an opportunity to investigate _B. suis_ carriage in these animals. A key issue will be achieved by comparing the genetic profile of the cow isolate to that of the local wild boar strains, if those turn out to be carriers of _B. suis bv2_.\n\nWild boars and hares are known to be infected by _B. suis bv 2_ in many European countries. A case of cattle infection by _B. suis bv2_ probably transmitted from an infected wild hare was reported in Denmark in 1995 (Ref 2). In the present case, contaminated wild boars are the most probable source of infection. The wild boar population of the Walloon region in Belgium is known to be steadily increasing since the last 2 decades, with a concomitant risk of introducing swine brucellosis in pig farms, especially when pigs are raised outdoors. However, the way _B. suis bv2_ can be passed from wild boars to cattle as reported here remains elusive.\n\nContaminated viscera from a hunted animal or aborted material left over in a pasture are possible contamination sources. It should be reminded that harvested viscera and carcasses of wild boars shot dead by hunters represent a potential contamination risk for susceptible animals and [should] not be left over in the natural environment, especially in the vicinity of pastures or farming areas.\n\nReferences\n1. Fretin D, Whatmore AM, Al Dahouk S, Neubauer H, Garin-Bastuji B, Albert D, Van Hessche M, Manart M, Godfroid J, Walravens K, Wattiau P. (2008) Brucella suis identification and biovar typing by real-time PCR. Vet Microbiol. 131:376-385.\n2. Andersen F.M. and Pedersen K.B. (1995) Brucellosis. A case of natural infection of a cow with Brucella suis biotype 2, Dan. Vet. 78:408.\n\nReported by David Fretin, Pierre Wattiau, Hein Imberechts (National Reference Laboratory for Brucellosis, CODA-CERVA, Brussels), Guy Czaplicki and Christian Quinet (ARSIA).\n\n--\nDavid Fretin\nHead of Unit \"Infectious Genitopathology in Cattle\"\nOperational Direction Bacterial Diseases\nCODA-CERVA\nVeterinary & Agrochemical Research Center\nB-1180 Brussels\nBelgium\n<David.Fretin@coda-cerva.be>\n\n[The 1st-hand above update on the event, complementary to the information included in postings 20120623.1178499 and 20120520.1139015, is much appreciated. We are looking with interest to the results of the undertaken surveillance in wild boars. - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1zJs.]\nSee Also\nBrucellosis, porcine - Belgium: serovar 2, wild boar 20120623.1178499\nBrucellosis, bovine - Belgium: (NA) B. abortus, B. suis serovar 2 20120520.1139015\nBrucellosis, bovine - Belgium (Namur): OIE 20120324.1079274\n.................................................arn/ejp/lm", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "brucellosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2012-03-15 00:00:00", "2012-05-19 00:00:00", "1995-03-15 00:00:00", "1995-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Belgium", "country": "Belgium"}, {"location": "Brussels", "country": "Belgium"}, {"location": "belgium", "country": "Belgium"}, {"location": "Denmark", "country": "Denmark"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1400200", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Brucellosis, human, canine - Argentina: (TF) B. canis, shelter workers", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1400200", "date": "2012-07-10 21:09:27", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS, PORCINE - BELGIUM (02): SEROVAR 2, WILD BOAR, BOVINE\n*****************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 10 Jul 2012\nFrom: David Fretin <David.Fretin@coda-cerva.be> [edited]\n\n\nBrucella suis biovar 2 in cattle: Follow up\n-------------------------------------------\nAn outbreak of Brucellosis due to _Brucella abortus_ and affecting Belgian cattle was 1st notified on 5 Mar 2012 and is currently investigated. In the context of a bulk tank milk screening aimed at controlling this outbreak, a sample from a farm near Florennes (Province of Namur) was found ELISA positive by the local 1st-line laboratory (ARSIA). Subsequent individual serum testing of all (155) lactating animals of this herd identified a single 4-year old cow (born on the farm and not pregnant) that tested positive by ELISA and sero-agglutination. This animal displayed no clinical symptom of brucellosis and was slaughtered on 23 Apr 2012.\n\nBacteriological tests were conducted at the national reference laboratory (CERVA-CODA) on lymph nodes, spleen and uterus. The lymph nodes were found negative, but colonies of a _Brucella_ sp. were isolated from both the spleen and the uterus and were unexpectedly identified as _Brucella suis biovar 2_ (_B. suis bv2_) using both biochemical and molecular typing methods. A B. suis-specific real-time PCR test (Ref 1) turned positive on DNA extracted directly from the uterus, ruling out a possible cross-contamination in the laboratory. Molecular typing of this cow isolate demonstrated a genetic profile highly related to the profile of _B. suis bv2_ strains normally retrieved from wild boars in Belgium. None of the other animals in the herd was found positive for Brucella.\n\nAuthorities have ordered a one-month hunting campaign in the surroundings of Florennes [which] started on 19 May 2012 with the aim of reducing urgently the local wild boar population while providing an opportunity to investigate _B. suis_ carriage in these animals. A key issue will be achieved by comparing the genetic profile of the cow isolate to that of the local wild boar strains, if those turn out to be carriers of _B. suis bv2_.\n\nWild boars and hares are known to be infected by _B. suis bv 2_ in many European countries. A case of cattle infection by _B. suis bv2_ probably transmitted from an infected wild hare was reported in Denmark in 1995 (Ref 2). In the present case, contaminated wild boars are the most probable source of infection. The wild boar population of the Walloon region in Belgium is known to be steadily increasing since the last 2 decades, with a concomitant risk of introducing swine brucellosis in pig farms, especially when pigs are raised outdoors. However, the way _B. suis bv2_ can be passed from wild boars to cattle as reported here remains elusive.\n\nContaminated viscera from a hunted animal or aborted material left over in a pasture are possible contamination sources. It should be reminded that harvested viscera and carcasses of wild boars shot dead by hunters represent a potential contamination risk for susceptible animals and [should] not be left over in the natural environment, especially in the vicinity of pastures or farming areas.\n\nReferences\n1. Fretin D, Whatmore AM, Al Dahouk S, Neubauer H, Garin-Bastuji B, Albert D, Van Hessche M, Manart M, Godfroid J, Walravens K, Wattiau P. (2008) Brucella suis identification and biovar typing by real-time PCR. Vet Microbiol. 131:376-385.\n2. Andersen F.M. and Pedersen K.B. (1995) Brucellosis. A case of natural infection of a cow with Brucella suis biotype 2, Dan. Vet. 78:408.\n\nReported by David Fretin, Pierre Wattiau, Hein Imberechts (National Reference Laboratory for Brucellosis, CODA-CERVA, Brussels), Guy Czaplicki and Christian Quinet (ARSIA).\n\n--\nDavid Fretin\nHead of Unit \"Infectious Genitopathology in Cattle\"\nOperational Direction Bacterial Diseases\nCODA-CERVA\nVeterinary & Agrochemical Research Center\nB-1180 Brussels\nBelgium\n<David.Fretin@coda-cerva.be>\n\n[The 1st-hand above update on the event, complementary to the information included in postings 20120623.1178499 and 20120520.1139015, is much appreciated. We are looking with interest to the results of the undertaken surveillance in wild boars. - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1zJs.]\nSee Also\nBrucellosis, porcine - Belgium: serovar 2, wild boar 20120623.1178499\nBrucellosis, bovine - Belgium: (NA) B. abortus, B. suis serovar 2 20120520.1139015\nBrucellosis, bovine - Belgium (Namur): OIE 20120324.1079274\n.................................................arn/ejp/lm", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "brucellosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2012-03-15 00:00:00", "2012-05-19 00:00:00", "1995-03-15 00:00:00", "1995-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Belgium", "country": "Belgium"}, {"location": "Brussels", "country": "Belgium"}, {"location": "belgium", "country": "Belgium"}, {"location": "Denmark", "country": "Denmark"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1348653", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Brucellosis - Bolivia: (PO)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1348653", "date": "2012-07-10 21:09:27", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS, PORCINE - BELGIUM (02): SEROVAR 2, WILD BOAR, BOVINE\n*****************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 10 Jul 2012\nFrom: David Fretin <David.Fretin@coda-cerva.be> [edited]\n\n\nBrucella suis biovar 2 in cattle: Follow up\n-------------------------------------------\nAn outbreak of Brucellosis due to _Brucella abortus_ and affecting Belgian cattle was 1st notified on 5 Mar 2012 and is currently investigated. In the context of a bulk tank milk screening aimed at controlling this outbreak, a sample from a farm near Florennes (Province of Namur) was found ELISA positive by the local 1st-line laboratory (ARSIA). Subsequent individual serum testing of all (155) lactating animals of this herd identified a single 4-year old cow (born on the farm and not pregnant) that tested positive by ELISA and sero-agglutination. This animal displayed no clinical symptom of brucellosis and was slaughtered on 23 Apr 2012.\n\nBacteriological tests were conducted at the national reference laboratory (CERVA-CODA) on lymph nodes, spleen and uterus. The lymph nodes were found negative, but colonies of a _Brucella_ sp. were isolated from both the spleen and the uterus and were unexpectedly identified as _Brucella suis biovar 2_ (_B. suis bv2_) using both biochemical and molecular typing methods. A B. suis-specific real-time PCR test (Ref 1) turned positive on DNA extracted directly from the uterus, ruling out a possible cross-contamination in the laboratory. Molecular typing of this cow isolate demonstrated a genetic profile highly related to the profile of _B. suis bv2_ strains normally retrieved from wild boars in Belgium. None of the other animals in the herd was found positive for Brucella.\n\nAuthorities have ordered a one-month hunting campaign in the surroundings of Florennes [which] started on 19 May 2012 with the aim of reducing urgently the local wild boar population while providing an opportunity to investigate _B. suis_ carriage in these animals. A key issue will be achieved by comparing the genetic profile of the cow isolate to that of the local wild boar strains, if those turn out to be carriers of _B. suis bv2_.\n\nWild boars and hares are known to be infected by _B. suis bv 2_ in many European countries. A case of cattle infection by _B. suis bv2_ probably transmitted from an infected wild hare was reported in Denmark in 1995 (Ref 2). In the present case, contaminated wild boars are the most probable source of infection. The wild boar population of the Walloon region in Belgium is known to be steadily increasing since the last 2 decades, with a concomitant risk of introducing swine brucellosis in pig farms, especially when pigs are raised outdoors. However, the way _B. suis bv2_ can be passed from wild boars to cattle as reported here remains elusive.\n\nContaminated viscera from a hunted animal or aborted material left over in a pasture are possible contamination sources. It should be reminded that harvested viscera and carcasses of wild boars shot dead by hunters represent a potential contamination risk for susceptible animals and [should] not be left over in the natural environment, especially in the vicinity of pastures or farming areas.\n\nReferences\n1. Fretin D, Whatmore AM, Al Dahouk S, Neubauer H, Garin-Bastuji B, Albert D, Van Hessche M, Manart M, Godfroid J, Walravens K, Wattiau P. (2008) Brucella suis identification and biovar typing by real-time PCR. Vet Microbiol. 131:376-385.\n2. Andersen F.M. and Pedersen K.B. (1995) Brucellosis. A case of natural infection of a cow with Brucella suis biotype 2, Dan. Vet. 78:408.\n\nReported by David Fretin, Pierre Wattiau, Hein Imberechts (National Reference Laboratory for Brucellosis, CODA-CERVA, Brussels), Guy Czaplicki and Christian Quinet (ARSIA).\n\n--\nDavid Fretin\nHead of Unit \"Infectious Genitopathology in Cattle\"\nOperational Direction Bacterial Diseases\nCODA-CERVA\nVeterinary & Agrochemical Research Center\nB-1180 Brussels\nBelgium\n<David.Fretin@coda-cerva.be>\n\n[The 1st-hand above update on the event, complementary to the information included in postings 20120623.1178499 and 20120520.1139015, is much appreciated. In the context of a bulk tank milk screening aimed at controlling this outbreak, a sample from a farm near Florennes (Province of Namur) was found ELISA positive by the local 1st-line laboratory (ARSIA). Subsequent individual serum testing of all (155) lactating animals of this herd identified a single 4-year old cow (born on the farm and not pregnant) that tested positive by ELISA and sero-agglutination. Molecular typing of this cow isolate demonstrated a genetic profile highly related to the profile of _B. suis bv2_ strains normally retrieved from wild boars in Belgium. A case of cattle infection by _B. suis bv2_ probably transmitted from an infected wild hare was reported in Denmark in 1995 (Ref 2). In the present case, contaminated wild boars are the most probable source of infection. The wild boar population of the Walloon region in Belgium is known to be steadily increasing since the last 2 decades, with a concomitant risk of introducing swine brucellosis in pig farms, especially when pigs are raised outdoors. However, the way _B. suis bv2_ can be passed from wild boars to cattle as reported here remains elusive.\n\nContaminated viscera from a hunted animal or aborted material left over in a pasture are possible contamination sources. It should be reminded that harvested viscera and carcasses of wild boars shot dead by hunters represent a potential contamination risk for susceptible animals and [should] not be left over in the natural environment, especially in the vicinity of pastures or farming areas.\n\nReferences\n1. A case of natural infection of a cow with Brucella suis biotype 2, Dan. We are looking with interest to the results of the undertaken surveillance in wild boars. - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1zJs.]\nSee Also\nBrucellosis, porcine - Belgium: serovar 2, wild boar 20120623.1178499\nBrucellosis, bovine - Belgium: (NA) B. abortus, B. suis serovar 2 20120520.1139015\nBrucellosis, bovine - Belgium (Namur): OIE 20120324.1079274\n.................................................arn/ejp/lm", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "brucellosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2012-03-15 00:00:00", "2012-05-19 00:00:00", "1995-03-15 00:00:00", "1995-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Belgium", "country": "Belgium"}, {"location": "Brussels", "country": "Belgium"}, {"location": "belgium", "country": "Belgium"}, {"location": "Denmark", "country": "Denmark"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1196658", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Brucellosis, porcine - Belgium (02): serovar 2, wild boar, bovine", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1196658", "date": "2012-07-10 21:09:27", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS, PORCINE - BELGIUM (02): SEROVAR 2, WILD BOAR, BOVINE\n*****************************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 10 Jul 2012\nFrom: David Fretin <David.Fretin@coda-cerva.be> [edited]\n\n\nBrucella suis biovar 2 in cattle: Follow up\n-------------------------------------------\nAn outbreak of Brucellosis due to _Brucella abortus_ and affecting Belgian cattle was 1st notified on 5 Mar 2012 and is currently investigated. In the context of a bulk tank milk screening aimed at controlling this outbreak, a sample from a farm near Florennes (Province of Namur) was found ELISA positive by the local 1st-line laboratory (ARSIA). Subsequent individual serum testing of all (155) lactating animals of this herd identified a single 4-year old cow (born on the farm and not pregnant) that tested positive by ELISA and sero-agglutination. This animal displayed no clinical symptom of brucellosis and was slaughtered on 23 Apr 2012.\n\nBacteriological tests were conducted at the national reference laboratory (CERVA-CODA) on lymph nodes, spleen and uterus. The lymph nodes were found negative, but colonies of a _Brucella_ sp. were isolated from both the spleen and the uterus and were unexpectedly identified as _Brucella suis biovar 2_ (_B. suis bv2_) using both biochemical and molecular typing methods. A B. suis-specific real-time PCR test (Ref 1) turned positive on DNA extracted directly from the uterus, ruling out a possible cross-contamination in the laboratory. Molecular typing of this cow isolate demonstrated a genetic profile highly related to the profile of _B. suis bv2_ strains normally retrieved from wild boars in Belgium. None of the other animals in the herd was found positive for Brucella.\n\nAuthorities have ordered a one-month hunting campaign in the surroundings of Florennes [which] started on 19 May 2012 with the aim of reducing urgently the local wild boar population while providing an opportunity to investigate _B. suis_ carriage in these animals. A key issue will be achieved by comparing the genetic profile of the cow isolate to that of the local wild boar strains, if those turn out to be carriers of _B. suis bv2_.\n\nWild boars and hares are known to be infected by _B. suis bv 2_ in many European countries. A case of cattle infection by _B. suis bv2_ probably transmitted from an infected wild hare was reported in Denmark in 1995 (Ref 2). In the present case, contaminated wild boars are the most probable source of infection. The wild boar population of the Walloon region in Belgium is known to be steadily increasing since the last 2 decades, with a concomitant risk of introducing swine brucellosis in pig farms, especially when pigs are raised outdoors. However, the way _B. suis bv2_ can be passed from wild boars to cattle as reported here remains elusive.\n\nContaminated viscera from a hunted animal or aborted material left over in a pasture are possible contamination sources. It should be reminded that harvested viscera and carcasses of wild boars shot dead by hunters represent a potential contamination risk for susceptible animals and [should] not be left over in the natural environment, especially in the vicinity of pastures or farming areas.\n\nReferences\n1. Fretin D, Whatmore AM, Al Dahouk S, Neubauer H, Garin-Bastuji B, Albert D, Van Hessche M, Manart M, Godfroid J, Walravens K, Wattiau P. (2008) Brucella suis identification and biovar typing by real-time PCR. Vet Microbiol. 131:376-385.\n2. Andersen F.M. and Pedersen K.B. (1995) Brucellosis. A case of natural infection of a cow with Brucella suis biotype 2, Dan. Vet. 78:408.\n\nReported by David Fretin, Pierre Wattiau, Hein Imberechts (National Reference Laboratory for Brucellosis, CODA-CERVA, Brussels), Guy Czaplicki and Christian Quinet (ARSIA).\n\n--\nDavid Fretin\nHead of Unit \"Infectious Genitopathology in Cattle\"\nOperational Direction Bacterial Diseases\nCODA-CERVA\nVeterinary & Agrochemical Research Center\nB-1180 Brussels\nBelgium\n<David.Fretin@coda-cerva.be>\n\n[The 1st-hand above update on the event, complementary to the information included in postings 20120623.1178499 and 20120520.1139015, is much appreciated. We are looking with interest to the results of the undertaken surveillance in wild boars. - Mod.AS\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1zJs.]\nSee Also\nBrucellosis, porcine - Belgium: serovar 2, wild boar 20120623.1178499\nBrucellosis, bovine - Belgium: (NA) B. abortus, B. suis serovar 2 20120520.1139015\nBrucellosis, bovine - Belgium (Namur): OIE 20120324.1079274\n.................................................arn/ejp/lm", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "brucellosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2012-03-15 00:00:00", "2012-05-19 00:00:00", "1995-03-15 00:00:00", "1995-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Belgium", "country": "Belgium"}, {"location": "Brussels", "country": "Belgium"}, {"location": "belgium", "country": "Belgium"}, {"location": "Denmark", "country": "Denmark"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1186087", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Brucellosis, marine mammal - USA: (ME) porpoise", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1186087", "date": "2012-04-16 23:12:23", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS, FERAL SWINE - USA: (NORTH CAROLINA)\n************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 13 Apr 2012\nSource: PorkNetwork [edited]\nhttp://www.porknetwork.com/pork-news/Brucellosis-raises-red-flag-in-NC-feral-swine--147337305.html?ref=305\n\n\nFor the 1st time since testing began several years ago, feral pigs in North Carolina have tested positive for _Brucella suis_, important and harmful bacteria that can be transmitted to domestic pigs and people.\n\nThe results surfaced in a North Carolina State University study conducted to test the state's feral pig populations for several types of bacteria and viruses. Researchers found that about 9 percent of feral pigs studied in Johnston County and less than one percent surveyed randomly at 13 other sites across the state showed exposure to _B. suis_.\n\nSuzanne Kennedy-Stoskopf, a North Carolina State research professor of wildlife infectious diseases, says that testing positive for antibodies to _B. suis_ means the feral pigs have been exposed to and mounted an immune response against the bacteria. Antibodies do not eliminate _B. suis_ from pigs, so the animals are considered infected and capable of transmitting the bacteria to other pigs and people. The United States has long had a swine brucellosis control and eradication program, which by the late 1990s eliminated the disease from all commercial pig populations.\n\nFor the domestic swine herd, the risk is that the bacteria can spread beyond feral hogs and cause abortions in affected swine. Kennedy-Stoskopf says that _B.suis_ can be transmitted when pigs ingest infected tissue or fluids. Also, direct contact with infected pigs or ingestion of contaminated food and water could cause currently uninfected pig populations to become infected.\n\nBiosecurity protocols in place to prevent herd exposure to other pathogens are important in preventing the spread of _B.suis_ into a domestic herd. \"Spillover from infected feral pigs to commercial pigs is an economic and a public-health concern,\" Kennedy-Stoskopf said. \"The biggest public-health risk is to pork processors and hunters who field dress feral pigs.\"\n\nThe study\"s co-author, Chris DePerno, associate professor of forestry and environmental resources at North Carolina State, points out the bacteria are transmitted to humans by unsafe butchering and consumption of undercooked meat. \"Now that exposure to _B. suis_ has been found in North Carolina's feral pig populations, people need to take care when hunting, butchering and cooking feral pigs,\" he said. \"That means wearing gloves when field dressing feral pigs and cooking the meat to the proper temperature.\"\n\nKennedy-Stoskopf emphasizes that although cases of brucellosis are rare in the United States, people need to understand the clinical signs, which mimic the flu and feature intermittent fevers and persistent headaches. \"Because clinical signs are so non-specific, it's important to tell your physician if you have had any exposure to feral swine carcasses and meat,\" she added.\n\nFeral pig populations are exploding across the country, and are in nearly every state. Efforts to control them often meet with controversy. \"Control of feral pig populations is difficult at best,\" DePerno says. \"Research indicates that about 70 percent of the population will need to be removed each year to keep a wild population stable. Regarding feral pigs, hunting usually removes from 8-50 percent of a given wild population.\"\n\nDePerno hopes that more research on how far feral pigs travel -- and increased scrutiny of hunters who move feral pigs from place to place -- will help keep feral populations from spreading.\n\nThe North Carolina State research is published in Journal of Wildlife Diseases.\n\n[Byline: Marlys Miller]\n\n---\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The article referred to can be found at http://www.jwildlifedis.org/content/48/2/462.abstract?sid=1258a59a-28d4-4c99-b9bc-a33c02853735.\n\nThe rapid growth of the feral swine population in the USA raises concern and entails health risks for humans, domestic animals and the whole ecosystem. _Brucella suis_ is a pathogen that can be transmitted to humans, and spillover into the domestic swine population can adversely impact profits. Enhancing feral swine control measures is crucial to avoiding the emergence or re-emergence of this and other infectious diseases in humans, domestic swine, and even native wildlife species.\n\nThe interactive HealthMap/ProMED-mail map for the affected region is available at: http://healthmap.org/r/1s-V. - Mod.PMB]\n\n[The human cases in Pennsylvania & South Carolina (reported in the 2009 ProMED archives below) were in people who had hunted feral swine in Florida in December 2007. Since then, the infection has moved north, and should be looked for in Virginia & Maryland. - Mod.JW]\nSee Also\nBrucellosis, cervid - Canada (03): (NU) caribou 20120215.1042283\nBrucellosis, cervid - Canada: (02) (NU) caribou 20120205.1033659\nBrucellosis, cervid - Canada: (NU) caribou 20120201.1028114\n2010\n----\nBrucellosis, swine - Latvia, OIE 20100917.3364\nBrucellosis, swine - Germany: (BB), OIE 20100213.0508\n2009\n----\nBrucellosis, swine hunters - Belgium: serovar 2, wild boar", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1178499", "date": "2012-04-16 23:12:23", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS, FERAL SWINE - USA: (NORTH CAROLINA)\n************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 13 Apr 2012\nSource: PorkNetwork [edited]\nhttp://www.porknetwork.com/pork-news/Brucellosis-raises-red-flag-in-NC-feral-swine--147337305.html?ref=305\n\n\nFor the 1st time since testing began several years ago, feral pigs in North Carolina have tested positive for _Brucella suis_, important and harmful bacteria that can be transmitted to domestic pigs and people.\n\nThe results surfaced in a North Carolina State University study conducted to test the state's feral pig populations for several types of bacteria and viruses. Researchers found that about 9 percent of feral pigs studied in Johnston County and less than one percent surveyed randomly at 13 other sites across the state showed exposure to _B. suis_.\n\nSuzanne Kennedy-Stoskopf, a North Carolina State research professor of wildlife infectious diseases, says that testing positive for antibodies to _B. suis_ means the feral pigs have been exposed to and mounted an immune response against the bacteria. Antibodies do not eliminate _B. suis_ from pigs, so the animals are considered infected and capable of transmitting the bacteria to other pigs and people. The United States has long had a swine brucellosis control and eradication program, which by the late 1990s eliminated the disease from all commercial pig populations.\n\nFor the domestic swine herd, the risk is that the bacteria can spread beyond feral hogs and cause abortions in affected swine. Kennedy-Stoskopf says that _B.suis_ can be transmitted when pigs ingest infected tissue or fluids. Also, direct contact with infected pigs or ingestion of contaminated food and water could cause currently uninfected pig populations to become infected.\n\nBiosecurity protocols in place to prevent herd exposure to other pathogens are important in preventing the spread of _B.suis_ into a domestic herd. \"Spillover from infected feral pigs to commercial pigs is an economic and a public-health concern,\" Kennedy-Stoskopf said. \"The biggest public-health risk is to pork processors and hunters who field dress feral pigs.\"\n\nThe study\"s co-author, Chris DePerno, associate professor of forestry and environmental resources at North Carolina State, points out the bacteria are transmitted to humans by unsafe butchering and consumption of undercooked meat. \"Now that exposure to _B. suis_ has been found in North Carolina's feral pig populations, people need to take care when hunting, butchering and cooking feral pigs,\" he said. \"That means wearing gloves when field dressing feral pigs and cooking the meat to the proper temperature.\"\n\nKennedy-Stoskopf emphasizes that although cases of brucellosis are rare in the United States, people need to understand the clinical signs, which mimic the flu and feature intermittent fevers and persistent headaches. \"Because clinical signs are so non-specific, it's important to tell your physician if you have had any exposure to feral swine carcasses and meat,\" she added.\n\nFeral pig populations are exploding across the country, and are in nearly every state. Efforts to control them often meet with controversy. \"Control of feral pig populations is difficult at best,\" DePerno says. \"Research indicates that about 70 percent of the population will need to be removed each year to keep a wild population stable. Regarding feral pigs, hunting usually removes from 8-50 percent of a given wild population.\"\n\nDePerno hopes that more research on how far feral pigs travel -- and increased scrutiny of hunters who move feral pigs from place to place -- will help keep feral populations from spreading.\n\nThe North Carolina State research is published in Journal of Wildlife Diseases.\n\n[Byline: Marlys Miller]\n\n---\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The article referred to can be found at http://www.jwildlifedis.org/content/48/2/462.abstract?sid=1258a59a-28d4-4c99-b9bc-a33c02853735.\n\nThe rapid growth of the feral swine population in the USA raises concern and entails health risks for humans, domestic animals and the whole ecosystem. _Brucella suis_ is a pathogen that can be transmitted to humans, and spillover into the domestic swine population can adversely impact profits. Enhancing feral swine control measures is crucial to avoiding the emergence or re-emergence of this and other infectious diseases in humans, domestic swine, and even native wildlife species.\n\nThe interactive HealthMap/ProMED-mail map for the affected region is available at: http://healthmap.org/r/1s-V. - Mod.PMB]\n\n[The human cases in Pennsylvania & South Carolina (reported in the 2009 ProMED archives below) were in people who had hunted feral swine in Florida in December 2007. China: (HL)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1165496", "date": "2012-04-16 23:12:23", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS, FERAL SWINE - USA: (NORTH CAROLINA)\n************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 13 Apr 2012\nSource: PorkNetwork [edited]\nhttp://www.porknetwork.com/pork-news/Brucellosis-raises-red-flag-in-NC-feral-swine--147337305.html?ref=305\n\n\nFor the 1st time since testing began several years ago, feral pigs in North Carolina have tested positive for _Brucella suis_, important and harmful bacteria that can be transmitted to domestic pigs and people.\n\nThe results surfaced in a North Carolina State University study conducted to test the state's feral pig populations for several types of bacteria and viruses. Researchers found that about 9 percent of feral pigs studied in Johnston County and less than one percent surveyed randomly at 13 other sites across the state showed exposure to _B. suis_.\n\nSuzanne Kennedy-Stoskopf, a North Carolina State research professor of wildlife infectious diseases, says that testing positive for antibodies to _B. suis_ means the feral pigs have been exposed to and mounted an immune response against the bacteria. Antibodies do not eliminate _B. suis_ from pigs, so the animals are considered infected and capable of transmitting the bacteria to other pigs and people. The United States has long had a swine brucellosis control and eradication program, which by the late 1990s eliminated the disease from all commercial pig populations.\n\nFor the domestic swine herd, the risk is that the bacteria can spread beyond feral hogs and cause abortions in affected swine. Kennedy-Stoskopf says that _B.suis_ can be transmitted when pigs ingest infected tissue or fluids. Also, direct contact with infected pigs or ingestion of contaminated food and water could cause currently uninfected pig populations to become infected.\n\nBiosecurity protocols in place to prevent herd exposure to other pathogens are important in preventing the spread of _B.suis_ into a domestic herd. \"Spillover from infected feral pigs to commercial pigs is an economic and a public-health concern,\" Kennedy-Stoskopf said. \"The biggest public-health risk is to pork processors and hunters who field dress feral pigs.\"\n\nThe study\"s co-author, Chris DePerno, associate professor of forestry and environmental resources at North Carolina State, points out the bacteria are transmitted to humans by unsafe butchering and consumption of undercooked meat. \"Now that exposure to _B. suis_ has been found in North Carolina's feral pig populations, people need to take care when hunting, butchering and cooking feral pigs,\" he said. \"That means wearing gloves when field dressing feral pigs and cooking the meat to the proper temperature.\"\n\nKennedy-Stoskopf emphasizes that although cases of brucellosis are rare in the United States, people need to understand the clinical signs, which mimic the flu and feature intermittent fevers and persistent headaches. \"Because clinical signs are so non-specific, it's important to tell your physician if you have had any exposure to feral swine carcasses and meat,\" she added.\n\nFeral pig populations are exploding across the country, and are in nearly every state. Efforts to control them often meet with controversy. \"Control of feral pig populations is difficult at best,\" DePerno says. \"Research indicates that about 70 percent of the population will need to be removed each year to keep a wild population stable. Regarding feral pigs, hunting usually removes from 8-50 percent of a given wild population.\"\n\nDePerno hopes that more research on how far feral pigs travel -- and increased scrutiny of hunters who move feral pigs from place to place -- will help keep feral populations from spreading.\n\nThe North Carolina State research is published in Journal of Wildlife Diseases.\n\n[Byline: Marlys Miller]\n\n---\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The article referred to can be found at http://www.jwildlifedis.org/content/48/2/462.abstract?sid=1258a59a-28d4-4c99-b9bc-a33c02853735.\n\nThe rapid growth of the feral swine population in the USA raises concern and entails health risks for humans, domestic animals and the whole ecosystem. _Brucella suis_ is a pathogen that can be transmitted to humans, and spillover into the domestic swine population can adversely impact profits. Enhancing feral swine control measures is crucial to avoiding the emergence or re-emergence of this and other infectious diseases in humans, domestic swine, and even native wildlife species.\n\nThe interactive HealthMap/ProMED-mail map for the affected region is available at: http://healthmap.org/r/1s-V. - Mod.PMB]\n\n[The human cases in Pennsylvania & South Carolina (reported in the 2009 ProMED archives below) were in people who had hunted feral swine in Florida in December 2007. Since then, the infection has moved north, and should be looked for in Virginia & Maryland. - Mod.JW]\nSee Also\nBrucellosis, cervid - Canada (03): (NU) caribou 20120215.1042283\nBrucellosis, cervid -
