USA (02): (TX) hunters 20090920.3303\nBrucellosis, swine hunters - USA: (SC, PA) EX Florida 20090612.2178\n.................................................sb/pmb/msp/jw", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "brucellosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2009-03-15 00:00:00", "2007-12-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2010-03-15 00:00:00", "2009-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "SC", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Florida", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Johnston County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "North Carolina State University", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "North Carolina State", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "BB", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "North Carolina", "country": "Puerto Rico"}, {"location": "NORTH CAROLINA", "country": "Puerto Rico"}, {"location": "North Carolina 's", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1165494", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Brucellosis, human, livestock - Mexico: (GJ)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1165494", "date": "2012-04-16 23:12:23", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS, FERAL SWINE - USA: (NORTH CAROLINA)\n************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 13 Apr 2012\nSource: PorkNetwork [edited]\nhttp://www.porknetwork.com/pork-news/Brucellosis-raises-red-flag-in-NC-feral-swine--147337305.html?ref=305\n\n\nFor the 1st time since testing began several years ago, feral pigs in North Carolina have tested positive for _Brucella suis_, important and harmful bacteria that can be transmitted to domestic pigs and people.\n\nThe results surfaced in a North Carolina State University study conducted to test the state's feral pig populations for several types of bacteria and viruses. Researchers found that about 9 percent of feral pigs studied in Johnston County and less than one percent surveyed randomly at 13 other sites across the state showed exposure to _B. suis_.\n\nSuzanne Kennedy-Stoskopf, a North Carolina State research professor of wildlife infectious diseases, says that testing positive for antibodies to _B. suis_ means the feral pigs have been exposed to and mounted an immune response against the bacteria. Antibodies do not eliminate _B. suis_ from pigs, so the animals are considered infected and capable of transmitting the bacteria to other pigs and people. The United States has long had a swine brucellosis control and eradication program, which by the late 1990s eliminated the disease from all commercial pig populations.\n\nFor the domestic swine herd, the risk is that the bacteria can spread beyond feral hogs and cause abortions in affected swine. Kennedy-Stoskopf says that _B.suis_ can be transmitted when pigs ingest infected tissue or fluids. Also, direct contact with infected pigs or ingestion of contaminated food and water could cause currently uninfected pig populations to become infected.\n\nBiosecurity protocols in place to prevent herd exposure to other pathogens are important in preventing the spread of _B.suis_ into a domestic herd. \"Spillover from infected feral pigs to commercial pigs is an economic and a public-health concern,\" Kennedy-Stoskopf said. \"The biggest public-health risk is to pork processors and hunters who field dress feral pigs.\"\n\nThe study\"s co-author, Chris DePerno, associate professor of forestry and environmental resources at North Carolina State, points out the bacteria are transmitted to humans by unsafe butchering and consumption of undercooked meat. \"Now that exposure to _B. suis_ has been found in North Carolina's feral pig populations, people need to take care when hunting, butchering and cooking feral pigs,\" he said. \"That means wearing gloves when field dressing feral pigs and cooking the meat to the proper temperature.\"\n\nKennedy-Stoskopf emphasizes that although cases of brucellosis are rare in the United States, people need to understand the clinical signs, which mimic the flu and feature intermittent fevers and persistent headaches. \"Because clinical signs are so non-specific, it's important to tell your physician if you have had any exposure to feral swine carcasses and meat,\" she added.\n\nFeral pig populations are exploding across the country, and are in nearly every state. Efforts to control them often meet with controversy. \"Control of feral pig populations is difficult at best,\" DePerno says. \"Research indicates that about 70 percent of the population will need to be removed each year to keep a wild population stable. Regarding feral pigs, hunting usually removes from 8-50 percent of a given wild population.\"\n\nDePerno hopes that more research on how far feral pigs travel -- and increased scrutiny of hunters who move feral pigs from place to place -- will help keep feral populations from spreading.\n\nThe North Carolina State research is published in Journal of Wildlife Diseases.\n\n[Byline: Marlys Miller]\n\n---\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The article referred to can be found at http://www.jwildlifedis.org/content/48/2/462.abstract?sid=1258a59a-28d4-4c99-b9bc-a33c02853735.\n\nThe rapid growth of the feral swine population in the USA raises concern and entails health risks for humans, domestic animals and the whole ecosystem. _Brucella suis_ is a pathogen that can be transmitted to humans, and spillover into the domestic swine population can adversely impact profits. Enhancing feral swine control measures is crucial to avoiding the emergence or re-emergence of this and other infectious diseases in humans, domestic swine, and even native wildlife species.\n\nThe interactive HealthMap/ProMED-mail map for the affected region is available at: http://healthmap.org/r/1s-V. - Mod.PMB]\n\n[The human cases in Pennsylvania & South Carolina (reported in the 2009 ProMED archives below) were in people who had hunted feral swine in Florida in December 2007. Since then, the infection has moved north, and should be looked for in Virginia & Maryland. - Mod.JW]\nSee Also\nBrucellosis, cervid - Canada (03): (NU) caribou 20120215.1042283\nBrucellosis, cervid - Canada: (02) (NU) caribou 20120205.1033659\nBrucellosis, cervid - Canada: (NU) caribou 20120201.1028114\n2010\n----\nBrucellosis, swine - Latvia, OIE 20100917.3364\nBrucellosis, swine - Germany: (BB), OIE 20100213.0508\n2009\n----\nBrucellosis, swine hunters - USA (02): (TX) hunters 20090920.3303\nBrucellosis, swine hunters - USA: (SC, PA) EX Florida 20090612.2178\n.................................................sb/pmb/msp/jw", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "brucellosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2009-03-15 00:00:00", "2007-12-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2010-03-15 00:00:00", "2009-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "SC", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Florida", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Johnston County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "North Carolina State University", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "North Carolina State", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "BB", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "North Carolina", "country": "Puerto Rico"}, {"location": "NORTH CAROLINA", "country": "Puerto Rico"}, {"location": "North Carolina 's", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1160121", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Brucellosis, human, canine - USA: (NY) B. canis", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1160121", "date": "2012-04-16 23:12:23", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS, FERAL SWINE - USA: (NORTH CAROLINA)\n************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 13 Apr 2012\nSource: PorkNetwork [edited]\nhttp://www.porknetwork.com/pork-news/Brucellosis-raises-red-flag-in-NC-feral-swine--147337305.html?ref=305\n\n\nFor the 1st time since testing began several years ago, feral pigs in North Carolina have tested positive for _Brucella suis_, important and harmful bacteria that can be transmitted to domestic pigs and people.\n\nThe results surfaced in a North Carolina State University study conducted to test the state's feral pig populations for several types of bacteria and viruses. Researchers found that about 9 percent of feral pigs studied in Johnston County and less than one percent surveyed randomly at 13 other sites across the state showed exposure to _B. suis_.\n\nSuzanne Kennedy-Stoskopf, a North Carolina State research professor of wildlife infectious diseases, says that testing positive for antibodies to _B. suis_ means the feral pigs have been exposed to and mounted an immune response against the bacteria. Antibodies do not eliminate _B. suis_ from pigs, so the animals are considered infected and capable of transmitting the bacteria to other pigs and people. The United States has long had a swine brucellosis control and eradication program, which by the late 1990s eliminated the disease from all commercial pig populations.\n\nFor the domestic swine herd, the risk is that the bacteria can spread beyond feral hogs and cause abortions in affected swine. Kennedy-Stoskopf says that _B.suis_ can be transmitted when pigs ingest infected tissue or fluids. Also, direct contact with infected pigs or ingestion of contaminated food and water could cause currently uninfected pig populations to become infected.\n\nBiosecurity protocols in place to prevent herd exposure to other pathogens are important in preventing the spread of _B.suis_ into a domestic herd. \"Spillover from infected feral pigs to commercial pigs is an economic and a public-health concern,\" Kennedy-Stoskopf said. \"The biggest public-health risk is to pork processors and hunters who field dress feral pigs.\"\n\nThe study\"s co-author, Chris DePerno, associate professor of forestry and environmental resources at North Carolina State, points out the bacteria are transmitted to humans by unsafe butchering and consumption of undercooked meat. \"Now that exposure to _B. suis_ has been found in North Carolina's feral pig populations, people need to take care when hunting, butchering and cooking feral pigs,\" he said. \"That means wearing gloves when field dressing feral pigs and cooking the meat to the proper temperature.\"\n\nKennedy-Stoskopf emphasizes that although cases of brucellosis are rare in the United States, people need to understand the clinical signs, which mimic the flu and feature intermittent fevers and persistent headaches. \"Because clinical signs are so non-specific, it's important to tell your physician if you have had any exposure to feral swine carcasses and meat,\" she added.\n\nFeral pig populations are exploding across the country, and are in nearly every state. Efforts to control them often meet with controversy. \"Control of feral pig populations is difficult at best,\" DePerno says. \"Research indicates that about 70 percent of the population will need to be removed each year to keep a wild population stable. Regarding feral pigs, hunting usually removes from 8-50 percent of a given wild population.\"\n\nDePerno hopes that more research on how far feral pigs travel -- and increased scrutiny of hunters who move feral pigs from place to place -- will help keep feral populations from spreading.\n\nThe North Carolina State research is published in Journal of Wildlife Diseases.\n\n[Byline: Marlys Miller]\n\n---\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The article referred to can be found at http://www.jwildlifedis.org/content/48/2/462.abstract?sid=1258a59a-28d4-4c99-b9bc-a33c02853735.\n\nThe rapid growth of the feral swine population in the USA raises concern and entails health risks for humans, domestic animals and the whole ecosystem. _Brucella suis_ is a pathogen that can be transmitted to humans, and spillover into the domestic swine population can adversely impact profits. Enhancing feral swine control measures is crucial to avoiding the emergence or re-emergence of this and other infectious diseases in humans, domestic swine, and even native wildlife species.\n\nThe interactive HealthMap/ProMED-mail map for the affected region is available at: http://healthmap.org/r/1s-V. - Mod.PMB]\n\n[The human cases in Pennsylvania & South Carolina (reported in the 2009 ProMED archives below) were in people who had hunted feral swine in Florida in December 2007. Since then, the infection has moved north, and should be looked for in Virginia & Maryland. - Mod.JW]\nSee Also\nBrucellosis, cervid - Canada (03): (NU) caribou 20120215.1042283\nBrucellosis, cervid - Belgium: (NA) B. abortus, B. suis serovar 2", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1139015", "date": "2012-04-16 23:12:23", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS, FERAL SWINE - USA: (NORTH CAROLINA)\n************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 13 Apr 2012\nSource: PorkNetwork [edited]\nhttp://www.porknetwork.com/pork-news/Brucellosis-raises-red-flag-in-NC-feral-swine--147337305.html?ref=305\n\n\nFor the 1st time since testing began several years ago, feral pigs in North Carolina have tested positive for _Brucella suis_, important and harmful bacteria that can be transmitted to domestic pigs and people.\n\nThe results surfaced in a North Carolina State University study conducted to test the state's feral pig populations for several types of bacteria and viruses. Researchers found that about 9 percent of feral pigs studied in Johnston County and less than one percent surveyed randomly at 13 other sites across the state showed exposure to _B. suis_.\n\nSuzanne Kennedy-Stoskopf, a North Carolina State research professor of wildlife infectious diseases, says that testing positive for antibodies to _B. suis_ means the feral pigs have been exposed to and mounted an immune response against the bacteria. Kennedy-Stoskopf says that _B.suis_ can be transmitted when pigs ingest infected tissue or fluids. Efforts to control them often meet with controversy. \"Control of feral pig populations is difficult at best,\" DePerno says. \"Research indicates that about 70 percent of the population will need to be removed each year to keep a wild population stable. Regarding feral pigs, hunting usually removes from 8-50 percent of a given wild population.\"\n\nDePerno hopes that more research on how far feral pigs travel -- and increased scrutiny of hunters who move feral pigs from place to place -- will help keep feral populations from spreading.\n\nThe North Carolina State research is published in Journal of Wildlife Diseases.\n\n[Byline: Marlys Miller]\n\n---\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The article referred to can be found at http://www.jwildlifedis.org/content/48/2/462.abstract?sid=1258a59a-28d4-4c99-b9bc-a33c02853735.\n\nThe rapid growth of the feral swine population in the USA raises concern and entails health risks for humans, domestic animals and the whole ecosystem. _Brucella suis_ is a pathogen that can be transmitted to humans, and spillover into the domestic swine population can adversely impact profits. Efforts to control them often meet with controversy. \"Control of feral pig populations is difficult at best,\" DePerno says. \"Research indicates that about 70 percent of the population will need to be removed each year to keep a wild population stable. Regarding feral pigs, hunting usually removes from 8-50 percent of a given wild population.\"\n\nDePerno hopes that more research on how far feral pigs travel -- and increased scrutiny of hunters who move feral pigs from place to place -- will help keep feral populations from spreading.\n\nThe North Carolina State research is published in Journal of Wildlife Diseases.\n\n[Byline: Marlys Miller]\n\n---\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The article referred to can be found at http://www.jwildlifedis.org/content/48/2/462.abstract?sid=1258a59a-28d4-4c99-b9bc-a33c02853735.\n\nThe rapid growth of the feral swine population in the USA raises concern and entails health risks for humans, domestic animals and the whole ecosystem. _Brucella suis_ is a pathogen that can be transmitted to humans, and spillover into the domestic swine population can adversely impact profits. USA: (NC)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1103073", "date": "2012-04-16 23:12:23", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS, FERAL SWINE - USA: (NORTH CAROLINA)\n************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Fri 13 Apr 2012\nSource: PorkNetwork [edited]\nhttp://www.porknetwork.com/pork-news/Brucellosis-raises-red-flag-in-NC-feral-swine--147337305.html?ref=305\n\n\nFor the 1st time since testing began several years ago, feral pigs in North Carolina have tested positive for _Brucella suis_, important and harmful bacteria that can be transmitted to domestic pigs and people.\n\nThe results surfaced in a North Carolina State University study conducted to test the state's feral pig populations for several types of bacteria and viruses. Researchers found that about 9 percent of feral pigs studied in Johnston County and less than one percent surveyed randomly at 13 other sites across the state showed exposure to _B. suis_.\n\nSuzanne Kennedy-Stoskopf, a North Carolina State research professor of wildlife infectious diseases, says that testing positive for antibodies to _B. suis_ means the feral pigs have been exposed to and mounted an immune response against the bacteria. Antibodies do not eliminate _B. suis_ from pigs, so the animals are considered infected and capable of transmitting the bacteria to other pigs and people. The United States has long had a swine brucellosis control and eradication program, which by the late 1990s eliminated the disease from all commercial pig populations.\n\nFor the domestic swine herd, the risk is that the bacteria can spread beyond feral hogs and cause abortions in affected swine. Kennedy-Stoskopf says that _B.suis_ can be transmitted when pigs ingest infected tissue or fluids. Also, direct contact with infected pigs or ingestion of contaminated food and water could cause currently uninfected pig populations to become infected.\n\nBiosecurity protocols in place to prevent herd exposure to other pathogens are important in preventing the spread of _B.suis_ into a domestic herd. \"Spillover from infected feral pigs to commercial pigs is an economic and a public-health concern,\" Kennedy-Stoskopf said. \"The biggest public-health risk is to pork processors and hunters who field dress feral pigs.\"\n\nThe study\"s co-author, Chris DePerno, associate professor of forestry and environmental resources at North Carolina State, points out the bacteria are transmitted to humans by unsafe butchering and consumption of undercooked meat. \"Now that exposure to _B. suis_ has been found in North Carolina's feral pig populations, people need to take care when hunting, butchering and cooking feral pigs,\" he said. \"That means wearing gloves when field dressing feral pigs and cooking the meat to the proper temperature.\"\n\nKennedy-Stoskopf emphasizes that although cases of brucellosis are rare in the United States, people need to understand the clinical signs, which mimic the flu and feature intermittent fevers and persistent headaches. \"Because clinical signs are so non-specific, it's important to tell your physician if you have had any exposure to feral swine carcasses and meat,\" she added.\n\nFeral pig populations are exploding across the country, and are in nearly every state. Efforts to control them often meet with controversy. \"Control of feral pig populations is difficult at best,\" DePerno says. \"Research indicates that about 70 percent of the population will need to be removed each year to keep a wild population stable. Regarding feral pigs, hunting usually removes from 8-50 percent of a given wild population.\"\n\nDePerno hopes that more research on how far feral pigs travel -- and increased scrutiny of hunters who move feral pigs from place to place -- will help keep feral populations from spreading.\n\nThe North Carolina State research is published in Journal of Wildlife Diseases.\n\n[Byline: Marlys Miller]\n\n---\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail from HealthMap Alerts\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[The article referred to can be found at http://www.jwildlifedis.org/content/48/2/462.abstract?sid=1258a59a-28d4-4c99-b9bc-a33c02853735.\n\nThe rapid growth of the feral swine population in the USA raises concern and entails health risks for humans, domestic animals and the whole ecosystem. _Brucella suis_ is a pathogen that can be transmitted to humans, and spillover into the domestic swine population can adversely impact profits. Since then, the infection has moved north, and should be looked for in Virginia & Maryland. - Mod.JW]\nSee Also\nBrucellosis, cervid - Canada (03): (NU) caribou 20120215.1042283\nBrucellosis, cervid - Canada: (02) (NU) caribou 20120205.1033659\nBrucellosis, cervid - Canada: (NU) caribou 20120201.1028114\n2010\n----\nBrucellosis, swine - Latvia, OIE 20100917.3364\nBrucellosis, swine - Germany: (BB), OIE 20100213.0508\n2009\n----\nBrucellosis, swine hunters - USA (02): (TX) hunters 20090920.3303\nBrucellosis, swine hunters - USA: (SC, PA) EX Florida 20090612.2178\n.................................................sb/pmb/msp/jw", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "brucellosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2009-03-15 00:00:00", "2007-12-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2010-03-15 00:00:00", "2009-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "SC", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}, {"location": "Florida", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Johnston County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "North Carolina State University", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "North Carolina State", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "the United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "BB", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "North Carolina", "country": "Puerto Rico"}, {"location": "NORTH CAROLINA", "country": "Puerto Rico"}, {"location": "North Carolina 's", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1101283", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Brucellosis, bovine, human - France: (Haute-Savoie), B. melitensis", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1101283", "date": "2012-02-13 15:14:21", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS - TAIWAN: 2011, IMPORTED\n************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 7 Feb 2012\nSource: Channel News Asia [edited]\nhttp://focustaiwan.tw/ShowNews/WebNews_Detail.aspx?Type=aALL&ID=201202070017\n\n\nBrucellosis, an infectious disease that occurs in humans through contact with animals, has been listed in Taiwan as a notifiable communicable disease, the Centers for Disease Control (CDC) said on Tue 7 Feb 2012. Brucellosis has been put on CDC's list of 60-plus transmittable diseases that must be reported in order to lower the risk of its spread, said Chou Jih-haw, its deputy director-general.\n\nTaiwan had been free of brucellosis for 3 decades, but there were 5 imported cases last year between May and October 2011, Chou said, explaining why CDC has taken the decision to list brucellosis as a notifiable disease. The 5 confirmed cases were Taiwan nationals who had contracted the disease during overseas travel, one in North Africa, 3 in Malaysia, and the 5th in China, Chou said.\n\nHe urged doctors to be vigilant in checking patients for symptoms of the disease, which include fever, abdominal pain, excessive sweating, headache, muscle pain, loss of appetite, fatigue and depression. Brucellosis is caused by a bacteria that can infect cattle, goats, camels, dogs and pigs. The bacteria can spread to humans if they come in contact with infected meat or the placenta of infected animals, or if they eat or drink unpasteurized milk or cheese.\n\nPeople visiting countries at risk, those in Africa, the Middle East, and South East Asia, should avoid close contact with animals and should not consume raw meat, unpasteurized milk, or cheese during their trip, CDC advised.\n\n[byline: Nancy Liu]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[No information is given in the posting regarding the manifestations of brucellosis in these imported cases or the species of _Brucella_ involved. Brucellosis is a zoonotic infection, as noted in the posting, but not an infection that spreads classically from person-to-person. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1ob5.]\nSee Also\n2007\n---\nBrucellosis, human, animals - Bulgaria ex Greece 20050328.0896\nBrucellosis, human - Uzbekistan (Jizzak) 20050112.0107\n2004\n---\nBrucellosis - China (02): Hong Kong 20041224.3396\nBrucellosis - China 20041222.3371\n.................................................ll/msp/sh", "reports": [{"diseases": ["brucellosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2011-03-15 00:00:00", "2012-02-07 00:00:00", "2007-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Greece", "country": "Greece"}, {"location": "Turkey", "country": "Turkey"}, {"location": "North Africa", "country": "Somalia"}, {"location": "Kyrgyzstan", "country": "Kyrgyzstan"}, {"location": "Hong Kong", "country": "Hong Kong"}, {"location": "Malaysia", "country": "Malaysia"}, {"location": "Taiwan", "country": "Taiwan"}, {"location": "China", "country": "China"}, {"location": "Bulgaria", "country": "Bulgaria"}, {"location": "LL", "country": "Micronesia"}, {"location": "Thailand", "country": "Thailand"}, {"location": "Hong Kong 20041224.3396", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "1033659", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Brucellosis, cervid - Canada: (02) (NU) caribou", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1033659", "date": "2012-02-13 15:14:21", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS - TAIWAN: 2011, IMPORTED\n************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 7 Feb 2012\nSource: Channel News Asia [edited]\nhttp://focustaiwan.tw/ShowNews/WebNews_Detail.aspx?Type=aALL&ID=201202070017\n\n\nBrucellosis, an infectious disease that occurs in humans through contact with animals, has been listed in Taiwan as a notifiable communicable disease, the Centers for Disease Control (CDC) said on Tue 7 Feb 2012. Brucellosis has been put on CDC's list of 60-plus transmittable diseases that must be reported in order to lower the risk of its spread, said Chou Jih-haw, its deputy director-general.\n\nTaiwan had been free of brucellosis for 3 decades, but there were 5 imported cases last year between May and October 2011, Chou said, explaining why CDC has taken the decision to list brucellosis as a notifiable disease. The 5 confirmed cases were Taiwan nationals who had contracted the disease during overseas travel, one in North Africa, 3 in Malaysia, and the 5th in China, Chou said.\n\nHe urged doctors to be vigilant in checking patients for symptoms of the disease, which include fever, abdominal pain, excessive sweating, headache, muscle pain, loss of appetite, fatigue and depression. Brucellosis is caused by a bacteria that can infect cattle, goats, camels, dogs and pigs. The bacteria can spread to humans if they come in contact with infected meat or the placenta of infected animals, or if they eat or drink unpasteurized milk or cheese.\n\nPeople visiting countries at risk, those in Africa, the Middle East, and South East Asia, should avoid close contact with animals and should not consume raw meat, unpasteurized milk, or cheese during their trip, CDC advised.\n\n[byline: Nancy Liu]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[No information is given in the posting regarding the manifestations of brucellosis in these imported cases or the species of _Brucella_ involved. Brucellosis is a zoonotic infection, as noted in the posting, but not an infection that spreads classically from person-to-person. - Mod.LL\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at: http://healthmap.org/r/1ob5.]\nSee Also\n2007\n---\nBrucellosis, human, animals - USA: (Gulf Coast) cetaceans, susp, RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1028538", "date": "2012-02-13 15:14:21", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS - TAIWAN: 2011, IMPORTED\n************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: Tue 7 Feb 2012\nSource: Channel News Asia [edited]\nhttp://focustaiwan.tw/ShowNews/WebNews_Detail.aspx?Type=aALL&ID=201202070017\n\n\nBrucellosis, an infectious disease that occurs in humans through contact with animals, has been listed in Taiwan as a notifiable communicable disease, the Centers for Disease Control (CDC) said on Tue 7 Feb 2012. Brucellosis has been put on CDC's list of 60-plus transmittable diseases that must be reported in order to lower the risk of its spread, said Chou Jih-haw, its deputy director-general.\n\nTaiwan had been free of brucellosis for 3 decades, but there were 5 imported cases last year between May and October 2011, Chou said, explaining why CDC has taken the decision to list brucellosis as a notifiable disease. The 5 confirmed cases were Taiwan nationals who had contracted the disease during overseas travel, one in North Africa, 3 in Malaysia, and the 5th in China, Chou said.\n\nHe urged doctors to be vigilant in checking patients for symptoms of the disease, which include fever, abdominal pain, excessive sweating, headache, muscle pain, loss of appetite, fatigue and depression. Brucellosis is caused by a bacteria that can infect cattle, goats, camels, dogs and pigs. The bacteria can spread to humans if they come in contact with infected meat or the placenta of infected animals, or if they eat or drink unpasteurized milk or cheese.\n\nPeople visiting countries at risk, those in Africa, the Middle East, and South East Asia, should avoid close contact with animals and should not consume raw meat, unpasteurized milk, or cheese during their trip, CDC advised.\n\n[byline: Nancy Liu]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[No information is given in the posting regarding the manifestations of brucellosis in these imported cases or the species of _Brucella_ involved. Canada: (NU) caribou", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=1028114", "date": "2011-12-28 15:49:30", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS, HUMAN, CANINE - ARGENTINA: (TIERRA DEL FUEGO)\n***********************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: 21 Dec 2011\nSource: eldiariodelfindelundo.com [in Spanish, translated & edited by\nMod. JG]\nhttp://www.eldiariodelfindelmundo.com/noticias/leer/40248/destacan-acciones-articuladas-ante-brote-de-brucelosis-en-rio-grande.html\n\n\nHealth authorities highlighted coordinated actions taken with\nmunicipalities in order to define strategies for facing brucellosis\ncases reported in Margen Sur de Rio Grande community, aiming to\ncontrol this outbreak.\n\nDr. Virna Almeida, head of the Epidemiology and Health Information\narea in the Ministry of Health, pointed out that \"We have advanced\nconversations with the National Direction of Epidemiology, the Malbran\nInstitute, Mu\u00f1iz Hospital, and also the Pan American Health\nOrganization, in order to perform next year a study for measuring the\nprevalence of brucellosis in dogs, since the transmission (of\nbrucellosis from dogs) is quite unusual in humans\".\n\nIn June 2011, a case of brucellosis was diagnosed in a 2-year old\ngirl, in Margen Sur community in Rio Grande; and the causative agent\nwas identified as _Brucella canis_. \"This is a microorganism that\nseldom causes disease in humans. Generally speaking, cases of\nBrucellosis in humans are caused by _Brucella_ species whose reservoir\nis cattle, and the condition is a food-borne disease, because of the\ningestion of non-pasteurized dairy products, or poorly-cooked meat\",\nDr. Almeida explained.\n\nConsequently, Dr. Almeida pointed out that \"We were facing a very\nunusual situation, diagnosing a disease that had never been detected\nin this province, and learning that the vehicle was a pet dog\". With\nthis situation, she said, \"knowing there is a second case, the mother\nof the affected child, adequate therapy was instituted in both\npatients. However, considering the unusual pattern of transmission, we\ndecided to study possible human contacts; and in Rio Grande\nMunicipality, they also decided to study 97 dogs in the surrounding\nareas in the community\".\n\nDr. Almeida added that after this study, \"last week results arrived\nfrom Malbran Institute, and we found that 29 of 97 dogs had positive\nserological test results for _Brucella canis_\".\n\n[\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at:\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/1yJb]\nSee Also\nBrucellosis, canine - Sweden: 1st rep, ex Poland 20110824.2575\n2009\n----\nBrucellosis, canine - Ireland: susp, RFI 20090507.1704\n2008\n----\nBrucellosis, canine - USA: (MI) 20080814.2526\n2007\n----\nBrucellosis, canine - Generally speaking, cases of\nBrucellosis in humans are caused by _Brucella_ species whose reservoir\nis cattle, and the condition is a food-borne disease, because of the\ningestion of non-pasteurized dairy products, or poorly-cooked meat\",\nDr. Almeida explained.\n\nConsequently, Dr. Almeida pointed out that \"We were facing a very\nunusual situation, diagnosing a disease that had never been detected\nin this province, and learning that the vehicle was a pet dog\". With\nthis situation, she said, \"knowing there is a second case, the mother\nof the affected child, adequate therapy was instituted in both\npatients. However, considering the unusual pattern of transmission, we\ndecided to study possible human contacts; and in Rio Grande\nMunicipality, they also decided to study 97 dogs in the surrounding\nareas in the community\".\n\nDr. Almeida added that after this study, \"last week results arrived\nfrom Malbran Institute, and we found that 29 of 97 dogs had positive\nserological test results for _Brucella canis_\".\n\n[\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at:\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/1yJb]\nSee Also\nBrucellosis, canine - Generally speaking, cases of\nBrucellosis in humans are caused by _Brucella_ species whose reservoir\nis cattle, and the condition is a food-borne disease, because of the\ningestion of non-pasteurized dairy products, or poorly-cooked meat\",\nDr. Almeida explained.\n\nConsequently, Dr. Almeida pointed out that \"We were facing a very\nunusual situation, diagnosing a disease that had never been detected\nin this province, and learning that the vehicle was a pet dog\". With\nthis situation, she said, \"knowing there is a second case, the mother\nof the affected child, adequate therapy was instituted in both\npatients. However, considering the unusual pattern of transmission, we\ndecided to study possible human contacts; and in Rio Grande\nMunicipality, they also decided to study 97 dogs in the surrounding\nareas in the community\".\n\nDr. Almeida added that after this study, \"last week results arrived\nfrom Malbran Institute, and we found that 29 of 97 dogs had positive\nserological test results for _Brucella canis_\".\n\n[\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at:\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/1yJb]\nSee Also\nBrucellosis, canine - Generally speaking, cases of\nBrucellosis in humans are caused by _Brucella_ species whose reservoir\nis cattle, and the condition is a food-borne disease, because of the\ningestion of non-pasteurized dairy products, or poorly-cooked meat\",\nDr. Almeida explained.\n\nConsequently, Dr. Almeida pointed out that \"We were facing a very\nunusual situation, diagnosing a disease that had never been detected\nin this province, and learning that the vehicle was a pet dog\". With\nthis situation, she said, \"knowing there is a second case, the mother\nof the affected child, adequate therapy was instituted in both\npatients. However, considering the unusual pattern of transmission, we\ndecided to study possible human contacts; and in Rio Grande\nMunicipality, they also decided to study 97 dogs in the surrounding\nareas in the community\".\n\nDr. Almeida added that after this study, \"last week results arrived\nfrom Malbran Institute, and we found that 29 of 97 dogs had positive\nserological test results for _Brucella canis_\".\n\n[\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at:\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/1yJb]\nSee Also\nBrucellosis, canine - Costa Rica 19980506.0877\n1997\n----\nBrucellosis, canine - Chile (02) 19971212.2469\n.................................................jg/ll/jw", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "brucellosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2011-03-15 00:00:00", "2011-06-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2009-03-15 00:00:00", "2007-03-15 00:00:00", "1998-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Florida", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Poland", "country": "Poland"}, {"location": "Costa Rica", "country": "Costa Rica"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Rio Grande", "country": "Brazil"}, {"location": "Chile", "country": "Chile"}, {"location": "Rio Grande \n Municipality", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Zealand", "country": "New Zealand"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "995074", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Brucellosis, human, canine - Argentina (02): comment", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=995074", "date": "2011-12-28 15:49:30", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS, HUMAN, CANINE - ARGENTINA: (TIERRA DEL FUEGO)\n***********************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: 21 Dec 2011\nSource: eldiariodelfindelundo.com [in Spanish, translated & edited by\nMod. JG]\nhttp://www.eldiariodelfindelmundo.com/noticias/leer/40248/destacan-acciones-articuladas-ante-brote-de-brucelosis-en-rio-grande.html\n\n\nHealth authorities highlighted coordinated actions taken with\nmunicipalities in order to define strategies for facing brucellosis\ncases reported in Margen Sur de Rio Grande community, aiming to\ncontrol this outbreak.\n\nDr. Virna Almeida, head of the Epidemiology and Health Information\narea in the Ministry of Health, pointed out that \"We have advanced\nconversations with the National Direction of Epidemiology, the Malbran\nInstitute, Mu\u00f1iz Hospital, and also the Pan American Health\nOrganization, in order to perform next year a study for measuring the\nprevalence of brucellosis in dogs, since the transmission (of\nbrucellosis from dogs) is quite unusual in humans\".\n\nIn June 2011, a case of brucellosis was diagnosed in a 2-year old\ngirl, in Margen Sur community in Rio Grande; and the causative agent\nwas identified as _Brucella canis_. \"This is a microorganism that\nseldom causes disease in humans. Generally speaking, cases of\nBrucellosis in humans are caused by _Brucella_ species whose reservoir\nis cattle, and the condition is a food-borne disease, because of the\ningestion of non-pasteurized dairy products, or poorly-cooked meat\",\nDr. Almeida explained.\n\nConsequently, Dr. Almeida pointed out that \"We were facing a very\nunusual situation, diagnosing a disease that had never been detected\nin this province, and learning that the vehicle was a pet dog\". With\nthis situation, she said, \"knowing there is a second case, the mother\nof the affected child, adequate therapy was instituted in both\npatients. However, considering the unusual pattern of transmission, we\ndecided to study possible human contacts; and in Rio Grande\nMunicipality, they also decided to study 97 dogs in the surrounding\nareas in the community\".\n\nDr. Almeida added that after this study, \"last week results arrived\nfrom Malbran Institute, and we found that 29 of 97 dogs had positive\nserological test results for _Brucella canis_\".\n\n[\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at:\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/1yJb]\nSee Also\nBrucellosis, canine - Argentina: (TF)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=992864", "date": "2011-12-28 15:49:30", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS, HUMAN, CANINE - ARGENTINA: (TIERRA DEL FUEGO)\n***********************************************************\n\nA ProMED-mail post\nhttp://www.promedmail.org\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\nhttp://www.isid.org\n\nDate: 21 Dec 2011\nSource: eldiariodelfindelundo.com [in Spanish, translated & edited by\nMod. JG]\nhttp://www.eldiariodelfindelmundo.com/noticias/leer/40248/destacan-acciones-articuladas-ante-brote-de-brucelosis-en-rio-grande.html\n\n\nHealth authorities highlighted coordinated actions taken with\nmunicipalities in order to define strategies for facing brucellosis\ncases reported in Margen Sur de Rio Grande community, aiming to\ncontrol this outbreak.\n\nDr. Virna Almeida, head of the Epidemiology and Health Information\narea in the Ministry of Health, pointed out that \"We have advanced\nconversations with the National Direction of Epidemiology, the Malbran\nInstitute, Mu\u00f1iz Hospital, and also the Pan American Health\nOrganization, in order to perform next year a study for measuring the\nprevalence of brucellosis in dogs, since the transmission (of\nbrucellosis from dogs) is quite unusual in humans\".\n\nIn June 2011, a case of brucellosis was diagnosed in a 2-year old\ngirl, in Margen Sur community in Rio Grande; and the causative agent\nwas identified as _Brucella canis_. \"This is a microorganism that\nseldom causes disease in humans. Generally speaking, cases of\nBrucellosis in humans are caused by _Brucella_ species whose reservoir\nis cattle, and the condition is a food-borne disease, because of the\ningestion of non-pasteurized dairy products, or poorly-cooked meat\",\nDr. Almeida explained.\n\nConsequently, Dr. Almeida pointed out that \"We were facing a very\nunusual situation, diagnosing a disease that had never been detected\nin this province, and learning that the vehicle was a pet dog\". With\nthis situation, she said, \"knowing there is a second case, the mother\nof the affected child, adequate therapy was instituted in both\npatients. However, considering the unusual pattern of transmission, we\ndecided to study possible human contacts; and in Rio Grande\nMunicipality, they also decided to study 97 dogs in the surrounding\nareas in the community\".\n\nDr. Almeida added that after this study, \"last week results arrived\nfrom Malbran Institute, and we found that 29 of 97 dogs had positive\nserological test results for _Brucella canis_\".\n\n[\n\nA HealthMap/ProMED-mail map can be accessed at:\nhttp://healthmap.org/r/1yJb]\nSee Also\nBrucellosis, canine - Costa Rica 19980506.0877\n1997\n----\nBrucellosis, canine - Chile (02) 19971212.2469\n.................................................jg/ll/jw", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "brucellosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2011-03-15 00:00:00", "2011-06-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "2009-03-15 00:00:00", "2007-03-15 00:00:00", "1998-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Florida", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Poland", "country": "Poland"}, {"location": "Costa Rica", "country": "Costa Rica"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Rio Grande", "country": "Brazil"}, {"location": "Chile", "country": "Chile"}, {"location": "Rio Grande \n Municipality", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "New Zealand", "country": "New Zealand"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "952243", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Brucellosis, bovine - USA (08): (MT)"}, {"archive_id": "922538", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Brucellosis, human, livestock - Russia (02): (TU)"}, {"archive_id": "910624", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Brucellosis, bovine - USA (07): (WY)"}, {"archive_id": "885017", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Brucellosis, bovine - USA (06): (MT)"}, {"archive_id": "872146", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Brucellosis, bovine - USA (05): (MT)"}, {"archive_id": "864985", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Brucellosis, animal, human - Uganda: (RR), RFI"}, {"archive_id": "858927", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Brucellosis, students - China: (HL) vet anatomy lab"}, {"archive_id": "833726", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> PRO>Brucellosis, canine - Sweden: 1st rep, ex Poland"}, {"archive_id": "802816", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Brucellosis, bison - Canada: (AB)"}, {"archive_id": "744359", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Brucellosis, human, livestock - Russia:"}, {"archive_id": "714423", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Brucellosis - Russia: (BK) bovine source"}, {"archive_id": "680376", "headline": "PRO/AH> Brucellosis, bovine - USA (04): (TX)"}, {"archive_id": "678820", "headline": "PRO/AH> Brucellosis, bovine - USA (03): (TX)"}, {"archive_id": "675857", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Brucellosis, bovine - USA (02): (TX)"}, {"archive_id": "664257", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Brucellosis, cervid - USA): (MT)"}, {"archive_id": "651805", "headline": "PRO/AH> Brucellosis, bovine - USA: (WY)"}, {"archive_id": "598398", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Brucellosis, human, livestock - Russia: (SR) RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=598398", "date": "2010-08-07 18:00:05", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS, BOVINE - FIJI\n**************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[1]\nDate: 5 Aug 2010\nSource: Fiji Times [edited]\n<http://www.fijitimes.com/story.aspx?id=152930>\n\n\nFarms face clean out\n--------------------\nTwo farms where cattle have contracted\nbrucellosis will be \"cleaned out\" by the Ministry\nof Agriculture, says the ministry's Permanent Secretary Colonel Mason Smith.\n\nHe said they were looking at what was needed to\nbe done at the farms. Dairy farmer Kashmir Singh\nsaid a farm in Wainivesi and Waimaro district\nwould be cleaned out by the ministry officers\nbecause they had infected cattle.\n\n\"We are aware that the cleaning out will be\nconducted soon but we are not aware of what these\nprocesses will include,\" he said. He said the\nfarmers had been briefed on the latest results of\ntests last month. Mr Singh said they asked the\nministry officers to conduct tests on their\ncattle every 3 months so they were always sure their cattle were not infected.\n\nLast week, Colonel Smith said 7 farms which had\nbeen quarantined for brucellosis were informed of\nthe latest test results received from Australia.\nHe said the farmers concerned had been notified.\n\n[Byline: Reijeli Kikau]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: 5 Aug 2010\nSource: Fiji Times [edited]\n<http://www.fijitimes.com/story.aspx?id=152931>\n\n\nHuman death denial\n------------------\nThere has never been any report of humans dying\nafter being infected with brucellosis in Fiji,\naccording to Ministry of Agriculture Permanent\nSecretary Colonel Mason Smith. He was reacting to\nreports made by one media organisation that some\npeople were dying due to being in contact with\nand looking after livestock infected with brucellosis.\n\n\"What we know and understand that cows have been\ninfected and have died from brucellosis,\" Col\nSmith said. Col Smith said one of his senior\nstaff said comments conducted in Fijian were\nmisinterpreted by the media organisation when translating it for news.\n\nEarlier last week, Col Mason Smith said 7 farms\nwhich were quarantined for brucellosis had been\ninformed of the latest test results received from\nAustralia. He said the 7 farms were still being\nquarantined but this would be reviewed after they\nreceived the results from Australia.\n\nCol Smith said the farms that were not being\nquarantined by their officers had been given \"the\ngreen light\" to continue with their daily work.\nHe said this also included selling their cattle to other farms or customers.\n\n[Byline: Reijeli Kikau]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promedmail@promedmail.org>\n\n[These articles do not say if these are dairy\ncattle, but it is strongly likely they are dairy operations.\n\nDairy cattle infected with brucellosis can\ntransmit the disease to humans through the\nconsumption of raw or unpasteurized milk.\n\nThe disease in cattle, water buffalo, and bison\nis caused almost exclusively by _Brucella\nabortus_ ; however, _B suis_ or _B melitensis_ is\noccasionally implicated in some cattle herds. B\nsuis does not appear to be contagious from cow to\ncow. Infection spreads rapidly and causes many\nabortions in unvaccinated cattle. In a herd in\nwhich disease is endemic, an infected cow\ntypically aborts only once after exposure;\nsubsequent gestations and lactations appear normal.\n\nAfter exposure, cattle become bacteremic for a\nshort period and develop agglutinins and other\nantibodies; some resist infection and a small\npercentage of infected cows recover. A positive\nserum agglutination test usually precedes an\nabortion or a normal parturition but may be\ndelayed in approximately 15 percent of cows. The\nincubation period may be variable and is\ninversely related to stage of gestation at time\nof exposure. Organisms are shed in milk and\nuterine discharges, and the cow may become temporarily infertile.\n\nBacteria may be found in the uterus during\npregnancy, uterine involution, and infrequently,\nfor a prolonged time in the nongravid uterus.\nShedding from the vagina largely disappears with\nthe decrease of fluids following parturition.\nSome infected cows that previously aborted shed\nbrucellae from the uterus at subsequent normal\nparturitions. Organisms are shed in milk for a\nvariable length of time\u0097in most cattle for life.\n\nNatural transmission occurs by ingestion of\norganisms, which are present in large numbers in\naborted fetuses, fetal membranes, and uterine\ndischarges. Cattle may ingest contaminated feed\nand water, or lick contaminated genitals of other\nanimals. Venereal transmission by infected bulls\nto susceptible cows appears to be rare.\nTransmission may occur by artificial insemination\nwhen Brucella -contaminated semen is deposited in\nthe uterus but, reportedly, not when deposited in\nthe midcervix. _Brucellae_ may enter the body\nthrough mucous membranes, conjunctivae, wounds, or intact skin.\n\n_Brucellae_ have been recovered from fetuses and\nfrom manure that has remained in a cool\nenvironment for greater than 2 months. Exposure\nto direct sunlight kills the organisms within a few hours.\n\nEfforts are directed at detection and prevention\nbecause no practical treatment is available.\nEventual eradication depends on testing and\neliminating reactors. The disease has been\neradicated from many individual herds and areas\nby this method. Herds must be tested at regular\nintervals until 2 or 3 successive tests are negative.\n\nBecause organisms are shed in the milk,\nunpasteurized milk, and cheese represent a human\nhealth concern. Many individuals believe drinking\nunpasteurized milk is better for their health.\nDiseases that are not killed by pasteurization\nrepresent a risk to the consumer. Brucellosis in\nhumans (undulant fever, Malta fever) causes\nmalaise, fever, chills, sweats, headache, neck\npain, low back pain, joint pain, muscle pain,\noccasionally diarrhea, constipation, anorexia,\nweight loss, abdominal pain, weakness,\nirritability, insomnia, and depression.\nBrucellosis has been called undulant fever\nbecause of its habit of producing fever and signs\nthat wax and wane over an extended period of time.\n\nPortions of this comment have been extracted from\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/dbmd/diseaseinfo/Brucellosis_g.htm>\nand from\n<http://www.merckvetmanual.com/mvm/index.jsp?cfile=htm/bc/110502.htm&word=Brucellosis>.\n- Mod.TG]\nSee Also\nBrucellosis, caprine, human - Malaysia: (PG) RFI 20100725.2492\nBrucellosis, livestock, human - Kazakhstan: (AM) 20100707.2263\nBrucellosis, bovine - UK: (Northern Ireland) 20100613.1979\nBrucellosis, bovine - Canada (02): (BC), clarification 20100528.1781\nBrucellosis, bovine - Canada: (BC) 20100528.1769\nBrucellosis, cervid - USA (05): Yellowstone 20100427.1352\nBrucellosis, cervid - USA (04): Yellowstone 20100425.1340\nBrucellosis, ovine - Croatia: (SD) OIE 20100418.1258\n....................tg/ejp/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail. Details available at:\n<http://www.isid.org/ProMEDMail_Donations.shtml>\n************************************************************\nVisit ProMED-mail's web site at <http://www.promedmail.org>.\nSend all items for posting to: promed@promedmail.org (NOT to\nan individual moderator). If you do not give your full name\nname and affiliation, it may not be posted. You may unsub-\nscribe at <http://www.isid.org/promedmail/subscribe.lasso>.\nFor assistance from a human being, send mail to:\n<postmaster@promedmail.org>.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "brucellosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2010-03-15 00:00:00", "2010-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Malta", "country": "Malta"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Fiji", "country": "Fiji"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "Wainivesi", "country": "Fiji"}, {"location": "Northern Ireland", "country": "Ireland"}, {"location": "Malaysia", "country": "Malaysia"}, {"location": "Singh", "country": "India"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Waimaro", "country": "Fiji"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "595668", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Brucellosis, bovine - USA (04): (WY) bison", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=595668", "date": "2010-08-07 18:00:05", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS, BOVINE - FIJI\n**************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[1]\nDate: 5 Aug 2010\nSource: Fiji Times [edited]\n<http://www.fijitimes.com/story.aspx?id=152930>\n\n\nFarms face clean out\n--------------------\nTwo farms where cattle have contracted\nbrucellosis will be \"cleaned out\" by the Ministry\nof Agriculture, says the ministry's Permanent Secretary Colonel Mason Smith.\n\nHe said they were looking at what was needed to\nbe done at the farms. Dairy farmer Kashmir Singh\nsaid a farm in Wainivesi and Waimaro district\nwould be cleaned out by the ministry officers\nbecause they had infected cattle.\n\n\"We are aware that the cleaning out will be\nconducted soon but we are not aware of what these\nprocesses will include,\" he said. He said the\nfarmers had been briefed on the latest results of\ntests last month. Mr Singh said they asked the\nministry officers to conduct tests on their\ncattle every 3 months so they were always sure their cattle were not infected.\n\nLast week, Colonel Smith said 7 farms which had\nbeen quarantined for brucellosis were informed of\nthe latest test results received from Australia.\nHe said the farmers concerned had been notified.\n\n[Byline: Reijeli Kikau]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: 5 Aug 2010\nSource: Fiji Times [edited]\n<http://www.fijitimes.com/story.aspx?id=152931>\n\n\nHuman death denial\n------------------\nThere has never been any report of humans dying\nafter being infected with brucellosis in Fiji,\naccording to Ministry of Agriculture Permanent\nSecretary Colonel Mason Smith. He was reacting to\nreports made by one media organisation that some\npeople were dying due to being in contact with\nand looking after livestock infected with brucellosis.\n\n\"What we know and understand that cows have been\ninfected and have died from brucellosis,\" Col\nSmith said. Col Smith said one of his senior\nstaff said comments conducted in Fijian were\nmisinterpreted by the media organisation when translating it for news.\n\nEarlier last week, Col Mason Smith said 7 farms\nwhich were quarantined for brucellosis had been\ninformed of the latest test results received from\nAustralia. He said the 7 farms were still being\nquarantined but this would be reviewed after they\nreceived the results from Australia.\n\nCol Smith said the farms that were not being\nquarantined by their officers had been given \"the\ngreen light\" to continue with their daily work.\nHe said this also included selling their cattle to other farms or customers.\n\n[Byline: Reijeli Kikau]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promedmail@promedmail.org>\n\n[These articles do not say if these are dairy\ncattle, but it is strongly likely they are dairy operations.\n\nDairy cattle infected with brucellosis can\ntransmit the disease to humans through the\nconsumption of raw or unpasteurized milk.\n\nThe disease in cattle, water buffalo, and bison\nis caused almost exclusively by _Brucella\nabortus_ ; however, _B suis_ or _B melitensis_ is\noccasionally implicated in some cattle herds. B\nsuis does not appear to be contagious from cow to\ncow. Infection spreads rapidly and causes many\nabortions in unvaccinated cattle. In a herd in\nwhich disease is endemic, an infected cow\ntypically aborts only once after exposure;\nsubsequent gestations and lactations appear normal.\n\nAfter exposure, cattle become bacteremic for a\nshort period and develop agglutinins and other\nantibodies; some resist infection and a small\npercentage of infected cows recover. A positive\nserum agglutination test usually precedes an\nabortion or a normal parturition but may be\ndelayed in approximately 15 percent of cows. The\nincubation period may be variable and is\ninversely related to stage of gestation at time\nof exposure. Organisms are shed in milk and\nuterine discharges, and the cow may become temporarily infertile.\n\nBacteria may be found in the uterus during\npregnancy, uterine involution, and infrequently,\nfor a prolonged time in the nongravid uterus.\nShedding from the vagina largely disappears with\nthe decrease of fluids following parturition.\nSome infected cows that previously aborted shed\nbrucellae from the uterus at subsequent normal\nparturitions. Organisms are shed in milk for a\nvariable length of time\u0097in most cattle for life.\n\nNatural transmission occurs by ingestion of\norganisms, which are present in large numbers in\naborted fetuses, fetal membranes, and uterine\ndischarges. Cattle may ingest contaminated feed\nand water, or lick contaminated genitals of other\nanimals. Venereal transmission by infected bulls\nto susceptible cows appears to be rare.\nTransmission may occur by artificial insemination\nwhen Brucella -contaminated semen is deposited in\nthe uterus but, reportedly, not when deposited in\nthe midcervix. _Brucellae_ may enter the body\nthrough mucous membranes, conjunctivae, wounds, or intact skin.\n\n_Brucellae_ have been recovered from fetuses and\nfrom manure that has remained in a cool\nenvironment for greater than 2 months. Exposure\nto direct sunlight kills the organisms within a few hours.\n\nEfforts are directed at detection and prevention\nbecause no practical treatment is available.\nEventual eradication depends on testing and\neliminating reactors. The disease has been\neradicated from many individual herds and areas\nby this method. Herds must be tested at regular\nintervals until 2 or 3 successive tests are negative.\n\nBecause organisms are shed in the milk,\nunpasteurized milk, and cheese represent a human\nhealth concern. Many individuals believe drinking\nunpasteurized milk is better for their health.\nDiseases that are not killed by pasteurization\nrepresent a risk to the consumer. Brucellosis in\nhumans (undulant fever, Malta fever) causes\nmalaise, fever, chills, sweats, headache, neck\npain, low back pain, joint pain, muscle pain,\noccasionally diarrhea, constipation, anorexia,\nweight loss, abdominal pain, weakness,\nirritability, insomnia, and depression.\nBrucellosis has been called undulant fever\nbecause of its habit of producing fever and signs\nthat wax and wane over an extended period of time.\n\nPortions of this comment have been extracted from\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/dbmd/diseaseinfo/Brucellosis_g.htm>\nand from\n<http://www.merckvetmanual.com/mvm/index.jsp?cfile=htm/bc/110502.htm&word=Brucellosis>.\n- Mod.TG]\nSee Also\nBrucellosis, caprine, human - Malaysia: (PG) RFI 20100725.2492\nBrucellosis, livestock, human - Kazakhstan: (AM) 20100707.2263\nBrucellosis, bovine - UK: (Northern Ireland) 20100613.1979\nBrucellosis, bovine - Canada (02): (BC), clarification 20100528.1781\nBrucellosis, bovine - Canada: (BC) 20100528.1769\nBrucellosis, cervid - USA (05): Yellowstone 20100427.1352\nBrucellosis, cervid - USA (04): Yellowstone 20100425.1340\nBrucellosis, ovine - Croatia: (SD) OIE 20100418.1258\n....................tg/ejp/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail. If you do not give your full name\nname and affiliation, it may not be posted. You may unsub-\nscribe at <http://www.isid.org/promedmail/subscribe.lasso>.\nFor assistance from a human being, send mail to:\n<postmaster@promedmail.org>.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "brucellosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2010-03-15 00:00:00", "2010-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Malta", "country": "Malta"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Fiji", "country": "Fiji"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "Wainivesi", "country": "Fiji"}, {"location": "Northern Ireland", "country": "Ireland"}, {"location": "Malaysia", "country": "Malaysia"}, {"location": "Singh", "country": "India"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Waimaro", "country": "Fiji"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "589900", "headline": "PRO/AH> Brucellosis, bovine - USA (03): (WY)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=589900", "date": "2010-08-07 18:00:05", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS, BOVINE - FIJI\n**************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[1]\nDate: 5 Aug 2010\nSource: Fiji Times [edited]\n<http://www.fijitimes.com/story.aspx?id=152930>\n\n\nFarms face clean out\n--------------------\nTwo farms where cattle have contracted\nbrucellosis will be \"cleaned out\" by the Ministry\nof Agriculture, says the ministry's Permanent Secretary Colonel Mason Smith.\n\nHe said they were looking at what was needed to\nbe done at the farms. Many individuals believe drinking\nunpasteurized milk is better for their health.\nDiseases that are not killed by pasteurization\nrepresent a risk to the consumer. Herds must be tested at regular\nintervals until 2 or 3 successive tests are negative.\n\nBecause organisms are shed in the milk,\nunpasteurized milk, and cheese represent a human\nhealth concern. Many individuals believe drinking\nunpasteurized milk is better for their health.\nDiseases that are not killed by pasteurization\nrepresent a risk to the consumer. Brucellosis in\nhumans (undulant fever, Malta fever) causes\nmalaise, fever, chills, sweats, headache, neck\npain, low back pain, joint pain, muscle pain,\noccasionally diarrhea, constipation, anorexia,\nweight loss, abdominal pain, weakness,\nirritability, insomnia, and depression.\nBrucellosis has been called undulant fever\nbecause of its habit of producing fever and signs\nthat wax and wane over an extended period of time.\n\nPortions of this comment have been extracted from\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/dbmd/diseaseinfo/Brucellosis_g.htm>\nand from\n<http://www.merckvetmanual.com/mvm/index.jsp?cfile=htm/bc/110502.htm&word=Brucellosis>.\n- Mod.TG]\nSee Also\nBrucellosis, caprine, human - Malaysia: (PG) RFI 20100725.2492\nBrucellosis, livestock, human - Kazakhstan: (AM) 20100707.2263\nBrucellosis, bovine - UK: (Northern Ireland) 20100613.1979\nBrucellosis, bovine - Canada (02): (BC), clarification 20100528.1781\nBrucellosis, bovine - Canada: (BC) 20100528.1769\nBrucellosis, cervid - USA (05): Yellowstone 20100427.1352\nBrucellosis, cervid - USA (04): Yellowstone 20100425.1340\nBrucellosis, ovine - Croatia: (SD) OIE 20100418.1258\n....................tg/ejp/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail. ISID\nand its associated service providers shall not be held\nresponsible for errors or omissions or held liable for any\ndamages incurred as a result of use or reliance upon posted\nor archived material.\n************************************************************\nDonate to ProMED-mail. Details available at:\n<http://www.isid.org/ProMEDMail_Donations.shtml>\n************************************************************\nVisit ProMED-mail's web site at <http://www.promedmail.org>.\nSend all items for posting to: promed@promedmail.org (NOT to\nan individual moderator). If you do not give your full name\nname and affiliation, it may not be posted. You may unsub-\nscribe at <http://www.isid.org/promedmail/subscribe.lasso>.\nFor assistance from a human being, send mail to:\n<postmaster@promedmail.org>.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "brucellosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2010-03-15 00:00:00", "2010-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Malta", "country": "Malta"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Fiji", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "Wainivesi", "country": "Fiji"}, {"location": "Northern Ireland", "country": "Ireland"}, {"location": "Malaysia", "country": "Malaysia"}, {"location": "Singh", "country": "India"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Waimaro", "country": "Fiji"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "567916", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Brucellosis, bovine - USA: (WY)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=567916", "date": "2010-08-07 18:00:05", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS, BOVINE - FIJI\n**************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[1]\nDate: 5 Aug 2010\nSource: Fiji Times [edited]\n<http://www.fijitimes.com/story.aspx?id=152930>\n\n\nFarms face clean out\n--------------------\nTwo farms where cattle have contracted\nbrucellosis will be \"cleaned out\" by the Ministry\nof Agriculture, says the ministry's Permanent Secretary Colonel Mason Smith.\n\nHe said they were looking at what was needed to\nbe done at the farms. Dairy farmer Kashmir Singh\nsaid a farm in Wainivesi and Waimaro district\nwould be cleaned out by the ministry officers\nbecause they had infected cattle.\n\n\"We are aware that the cleaning out will be\nconducted soon but we are not aware of what these\nprocesses will include,\" he said. He said the\nfarmers had been briefed on the latest results of\ntests last month. Mr Singh said they asked the\nministry officers to conduct tests on their\ncattle every 3 months so they were always sure their cattle were not infected.\n\nLast week, Colonel Smith said 7 farms which had\nbeen quarantined for brucellosis were informed of\nthe latest test results received from Australia.\nHe said the farmers concerned had been notified.\n\n[Byline: Reijeli Kikau]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: 5 Aug 2010\nSource: Fiji Times [edited]\n<http://www.fijitimes.com/story.aspx?id=152931>\n\n\nHuman death denial\n------------------\nThere has never been any report of humans dying\nafter being infected with brucellosis in Fiji,\naccording to Ministry of Agriculture Permanent\nSecretary Colonel Mason Smith. He was reacting to\nreports made by one media organisation that some\npeople were dying due to being in contact with\nand looking after livestock infected with brucellosis.\n\n\"What we know and understand that cows have been\ninfected and have died from brucellosis,\" Col\nSmith said. Col Smith said one of his senior\nstaff said comments conducted in Fijian were\nmisinterpreted by the media organisation when translating it for news.\n\nEarlier last week, Col Mason Smith said 7 farms\nwhich were quarantined for brucellosis had been\ninformed of the latest test results received from\nAustralia. He said the 7 farms were still being\nquarantined but this would be reviewed after they\nreceived the results from Australia.\n\nCol Smith said the farms that were not being\nquarantined by their officers had been given \"the\ngreen light\" to continue with their daily work.\nHe said this also included selling their cattle to other farms or customers.\n\n[Byline: Reijeli Kikau]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promedmail@promedmail.org>\n\n[These articles do not say if these are dairy\ncattle, but it is strongly likely they are dairy operations.\n\nDairy cattle infected with brucellosis can\ntransmit the disease to humans through the\nconsumption of raw or unpasteurized milk.\n\nThe disease in cattle, water buffalo, and bison\nis caused almost exclusively by _Brucella\nabortus_ ; however, _B suis_ or _B melitensis_ is\noccasionally implicated in some cattle herds. B\nsuis does not appear to be contagious from cow to\ncow. Infection spreads rapidly and causes many\nabortions in unvaccinated cattle. In a herd in\nwhich disease is endemic, an infected cow\ntypically aborts only once after exposure;\nsubsequent gestations and lactations appear normal.\n\nAfter exposure, cattle become bacteremic for a\nshort period and develop agglutinins and other\nantibodies; some resist infection and a small\npercentage of infected cows recover. A positive\nserum agglutination test usually precedes an\nabortion or a normal parturition but may be\ndelayed in approximately 15 percent of cows. The\nincubation period may be variable and is\ninversely related to stage of gestation at time\nof exposure. Organisms are shed in milk and\nuterine discharges, and the cow may become temporarily infertile.\n\nBacteria may be found in the uterus during\npregnancy, uterine involution, and infrequently,\nfor a prolonged time in the nongravid uterus.\nShedding from the vagina largely disappears with\nthe decrease of fluids following parturition.\nSome infected cows that previously aborted shed\nbrucellae from the uterus at subsequent normal\nparturitions. Organisms are shed in milk for a\nvariable length of time\u0097in most cattle for life.\n\nNatural transmission occurs by ingestion of\norganisms, which are present in large numbers in\naborted fetuses, fetal membranes, and uterine\ndischarges. Cattle may ingest contaminated feed\nand water, or lick contaminated genitals of other\nanimals. Venereal transmission by infected bulls\nto susceptible cows appears to be rare.\nTransmission may occur by artificial insemination\nwhen Brucella -contaminated semen is deposited in\nthe uterus but, reportedly, not when deposited in\nthe midcervix. _Brucellae_ may enter the body\nthrough mucous membranes, conjunctivae, wounds, or intact skin.\n\n_Brucellae_ have been recovered from fetuses and\nfrom manure that has remained in a cool\nenvironment for greater than 2 months. Exposure\nto direct sunlight kills the organisms within a few hours.\n\nEfforts are directed at detection and prevention\nbecause no practical treatment is available.\nEventual eradication depends on testing and\neliminating reactors. The disease has been\neradicated from many individual herds and areas\nby this method. Herds must be tested at regular\nintervals until 2 or 3 successive tests are negative.\n\nBecause organisms are shed in the milk,\nunpasteurized milk, and cheese represent a human\nhealth concern. Many individuals believe drinking\nunpasteurized milk is better for their health.\nDiseases that are not killed by pasteurization\nrepresent a risk to the consumer. Brucellosis in\nhumans (undulant fever, Malta fever) causes\nmalaise, fever, chills, sweats, headache, neck\npain, low back pain, joint pain, muscle pain,\noccasionally diarrhea, constipation, anorexia,\nweight loss, abdominal pain, weakness,\nirritability, insomnia, and depression.\nBrucellosis has been called undulant fever\nbecause of its habit of producing fever and signs\nthat wax and wane over an extended period of time.\n\nPortions of this comment have been extracted from\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/dbmd/diseaseinfo/Brucellosis_g.htm>\nand from\n<http://www.merckvetmanual.com/mvm/index.jsp?cfile=htm/bc/110502.htm&word=Brucellosis>.\n- Mod.TG]\nSee Also\nBrucellosis, caprine, human - Malaysia: (PG) RFI 20100725.2492\nBrucellosis, livestock, human - Kazakhstan: (AM) 20100707.2263\nBrucellosis, bovine - UK: (Northern Ireland) 20100613.1979\nBrucellosis, bovine - Canada (02): (BC), clarification 20100528.1781\nBrucellosis, bovine - Canada: (BC) 20100528.1769\nBrucellosis, cervid - USA (05): Yellowstone 20100427.1352\nBrucellosis, cervid - USA (04): Yellowstone 20100425.1340\nBrucellosis, ovine - Croatia: (SD) OIE 20100418.1258\n....................tg/ejp/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The disease has been\neradicated from many individual herds and areas\nby this method. Herds must be tested at regular\nintervals until 2 or 3 successive tests are negative.\n\nBecause organisms are shed in the milk,\nunpasteurized milk, and cheese represent a human\nhealth concern. Many individuals believe drinking\nunpasteurized milk is better for their health.\nDiseases that are not killed by pasteurization\nrepresent a risk to the consumer. Brucellosis in\nhumans (undulant fever, Malta fever) causes\nmalaise, fever, chills, sweats, headache, neck\npain, low back pain, joint pain, muscle pain,\noccasionally diarrhea, constipation, anorexia,\nweight loss, abdominal pain, weakness,\nirritability, insomnia, and depression.\nBrucellosis has been called undulant fever\nbecause of its habit of producing fever and signs\nthat wax and wane over an extended period of time.\n\nPortions of this comment have been extracted from\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/dbmd/diseaseinfo/Brucellosis_g.htm>\nand from\n<http://www.merckvetmanual.com/mvm/index.jsp?cfile=htm/bc/110502.htm&word=Brucellosis>.\n- Mod.TG]\nSee Also\nBrucellosis, caprine, human - Malaysia: (PG) RFI 20100725.2492\nBrucellosis, livestock, human - Kazakhstan: (AM) 20100707.2263\nBrucellosis, bovine - UK: (Northern Ireland) 20100613.1979\nBrucellosis, bovine - Canada (02): (BC), clarification 20100528.1781\nBrucellosis, bovine - Canada: (BC) 20100528.1769\nBrucellosis, cervid - USA (05): Yellowstone 20100427.1352\nBrucellosis, cervid - USA (04): Yellowstone 20100425.1340\nBrucellosis, ovine - Croatia: (SD) OIE 20100418.1258\n....................tg/ejp/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail.
