Details available at:\n<http://www.isid.org/ProMEDMail_Donations.shtml>\n************************************************************\nVisit ProMED-mail's web site at <http://www.promedmail.org>.\nSend all items for posting to: promed@promedmail.org (NOT to\nan individual moderator). If you do not give your full name\nname and affiliation, it may not be posted. You may unsub-\nscribe at <http://www.isid.org/promedmail/subscribe.lasso>.\nFor assistance from a human being, send mail to:\n<postmaster@promedmail.org>.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "brucellosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2010-03-15 00:00:00", "2010-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Malta", "country": "Malta"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Fiji", "country": "Fiji"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "Wainivesi", "country": "Fiji"}, {"location": "Northern Ireland", "country": "Ireland"}, {"location": "Malaysia", "country": "Malaysia"}, {"location": "Singh", "country": "India"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Waimaro", "country": "Fiji"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "486018", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Brucellosis, bovine - Fiji", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=486018", "date": "2010-08-07 18:00:05", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS, BOVINE - FIJI\n**************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\n[1]\nDate: 5 Aug 2010\nSource: Fiji Times [edited]\n<http://www.fijitimes.com/story.aspx?id=152930>\n\n\nFarms face clean out\n--------------------\nTwo farms where cattle have contracted\nbrucellosis will be \"cleaned out\" by the Ministry\nof Agriculture, says the ministry's Permanent Secretary Colonel Mason Smith.\n\nHe said they were looking at what was needed to\nbe done at the farms. Dairy farmer Kashmir Singh\nsaid a farm in Wainivesi and Waimaro district\nwould be cleaned out by the ministry officers\nbecause they had infected cattle.\n\n\"We are aware that the cleaning out will be\nconducted soon but we are not aware of what these\nprocesses will include,\" he said. He said the\nfarmers had been briefed on the latest results of\ntests last month. Mr Singh said they asked the\nministry officers to conduct tests on their\ncattle every 3 months so they were always sure their cattle were not infected.\n\nLast week, Colonel Smith said 7 farms which had\nbeen quarantined for brucellosis were informed of\nthe latest test results received from Australia.\nHe said the farmers concerned had been notified.\n\n[Byline: Reijeli Kikau]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n******\n[2]\nDate: 5 Aug 2010\nSource: Fiji Times [edited]\n<http://www.fijitimes.com/story.aspx?id=152931>\n\n\nHuman death denial\n------------------\nThere has never been any report of humans dying\nafter being infected with brucellosis in Fiji,\naccording to Ministry of Agriculture Permanent\nSecretary Colonel Mason Smith. He was reacting to\nreports made by one media organisation that some\npeople were dying due to being in contact with\nand looking after livestock infected with brucellosis.\n\n\"What we know and understand that cows have been\ninfected and have died from brucellosis,\" Col\nSmith said. Col Smith said one of his senior\nstaff said comments conducted in Fijian were\nmisinterpreted by the media organisation when translating it for news.\n\nEarlier last week, Col Mason Smith said 7 farms\nwhich were quarantined for brucellosis had been\ninformed of the latest test results received from\nAustralia. He said the 7 farms were still being\nquarantined but this would be reviewed after they\nreceived the results from Australia.\n\nCol Smith said the farms that were not being\nquarantined by their officers had been given \"the\ngreen light\" to continue with their daily work.\nHe said this also included selling their cattle to other farms or customers.\n\n[Byline: Reijeli Kikau]\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promedmail@promedmail.org>\n\n[These articles do not say if these are dairy\ncattle, but it is strongly likely they are dairy operations.\n\nDairy cattle infected with brucellosis can\ntransmit the disease to humans through the\nconsumption of raw or unpasteurized milk.\n\nThe disease in cattle, water buffalo, and bison\nis caused almost exclusively by _Brucella\nabortus_ ; however, _B suis_ or _B melitensis_ is\noccasionally implicated in some cattle herds. B\nsuis does not appear to be contagious from cow to\ncow. Infection spreads rapidly and causes many\nabortions in unvaccinated cattle. In a herd in\nwhich disease is endemic, an infected cow\ntypically aborts only once after exposure;\nsubsequent gestations and lactations appear normal.\n\nAfter exposure, cattle become bacteremic for a\nshort period and develop agglutinins and other\nantibodies; some resist infection and a small\npercentage of infected cows recover. A positive\nserum agglutination test usually precedes an\nabortion or a normal parturition but may be\ndelayed in approximately 15 percent of cows. The\nincubation period may be variable and is\ninversely related to stage of gestation at time\nof exposure. Organisms are shed in milk and\nuterine discharges, and the cow may become temporarily infertile.\n\nBacteria may be found in the uterus during\npregnancy, uterine involution, and infrequently,\nfor a prolonged time in the nongravid uterus.\nShedding from the vagina largely disappears with\nthe decrease of fluids following parturition.\nSome infected cows that previously aborted shed\nbrucellae from the uterus at subsequent normal\nparturitions. Organisms are shed in milk for a\nvariable length of time\u0097in most cattle for life.\n\nNatural transmission occurs by ingestion of\norganisms, which are present in large numbers in\naborted fetuses, fetal membranes, and uterine\ndischarges. Cattle may ingest contaminated feed\nand water, or lick contaminated genitals of other\nanimals. Venereal transmission by infected bulls\nto susceptible cows appears to be rare.\nTransmission may occur by artificial insemination\nwhen Brucella -contaminated semen is deposited in\nthe uterus but, reportedly, not when deposited in\nthe midcervix. _Brucellae_ may enter the body\nthrough mucous membranes, conjunctivae, wounds, or intact skin.\n\n_Brucellae_ have been recovered from fetuses and\nfrom manure that has remained in a cool\nenvironment for greater than 2 months. Exposure\nto direct sunlight kills the organisms within a few hours.\n\nEfforts are directed at detection and prevention\nbecause no practical treatment is available.\nEventual eradication depends on testing and\neliminating reactors. The disease has been\neradicated from many individual herds and areas\nby this method. Herds must be tested at regular\nintervals until 2 or 3 successive tests are negative.\n\nBecause organisms are shed in the milk,\nunpasteurized milk, and cheese represent a human\nhealth concern. Many individuals believe drinking\nunpasteurized milk is better for their health.\nDiseases that are not killed by pasteurization\nrepresent a risk to the consumer. Brucellosis in\nhumans (undulant fever, Malta fever) causes\nmalaise, fever, chills, sweats, headache, neck\npain, low back pain, joint pain, muscle pain,\noccasionally diarrhea, constipation, anorexia,\nweight loss, abdominal pain, weakness,\nirritability, insomnia, and depression.\nBrucellosis has been called undulant fever\nbecause of its habit of producing fever and signs\nthat wax and wane over an extended period of time.\n\nPortions of this comment have been extracted from\n<http://www.cdc.gov/ncidod/dbmd/diseaseinfo/Brucellosis_g.htm>\nand from\n<http://www.merckvetmanual.com/mvm/index.jsp?cfile=htm/bc/110502.htm&word=Brucellosis>.\n- Mod.TG]\nSee Also\nBrucellosis, caprine, human - Malaysia: (PG) RFI 20100725.2492\nBrucellosis, livestock, human - Kazakhstan: (AM) 20100707.2263\nBrucellosis, bovine - UK: (Northern Ireland) 20100613.1979\nBrucellosis, bovine - Canada (02): (BC), clarification 20100528.1781\nBrucellosis, bovine - Canada: (BC) 20100528.1769\nBrucellosis, cervid - USA (05): Yellowstone 20100427.1352\nBrucellosis, cervid - USA (04): Yellowstone 20100425.1340\nBrucellosis, ovine - Croatia: (SD) OIE 20100418.1258\n....................tg/ejp/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. You may unsub-\nscribe at <http://www.isid.org/promedmail/subscribe.lasso>.\nFor assistance from a human being, send mail to:\n<postmaster@promedmail.org>.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "brucellosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2010-03-15 00:00:00", "2010-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Malta", "country": "Malta"}, {"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Fiji", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "Wainivesi", "country": "Fiji"}, {"location": "Northern Ireland", "country": "Ireland"}, {"location": "Malaysia", "country": "Malaysia"}, {"location": "Singh", "country": "India"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Waimaro", "country": "Fiji"}, {"location": "Canada", "country": "Canada"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "475117", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Brucellosis, caprine, human - Malaysia: (PG) RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=475117", "date": "2010-04-18 12:00:04", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS, OVINE - CROATIA: (SPLIT-DALMATIA) OIE\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 16 Apr 2010\nSource: OIE, WAHID (World Animal Health Information Database), weekly\ndisease information 2010; 23(16) [edited]\n<http://www.oie.int/wahis/public.php?page=single_report&pop=1&reportid=9150>\n\n\nBrucellosis (_Brucella melitensis_), Croatia\n--------------------------------------------\nInformation received on (and dated) 16 Apr 2010 from Dr Sanja\nSeparovic, Director, Veterinary Directorate, Ministry of Agriculture,\nFisheries and Rural Development (MAFRD), Zagreb, Croatia\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nStart date: 25 Mar 2010\nDate of 1st confirmation of the event: 25 Mar 2010\nReport date: 16 Apr 2010\nDate submitted to OIE: 16 Apr 2010\nReason for notification: reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence 11 May 2009\nManifestation of disease: sub-clinical infection\nCausal agent: _Brucella melitensis_\nNature of diagnosis: laboratory (basic), laboratory (advanced)\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country\n\nNew outbreaks\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak location: Studenci, Studenci, Lovrec, Splitsko-Dalmatinska\n[Split-Dalmatia]\nDate of start of the outbreak: 25 Mar 2010\nOutbreak status: continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: farm\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nCattle / 2 / 0 / 0 / 0 / 0\nSheep / 28 / 5 / 0 / 28 / 0\nDogs / 3 / 0 / 0 / 0 / 0\nAffected population: sheep herd with 16 breeding sheep and 12 lambs.\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: legal movement of\nanimals; illegal movement of animals; contact with infected animal(s)\nat grazing/watering\nEpidemiological comments: within the regular yearly surveillance for\nbrucellosis in sheep and goats herds in Split-Dalmatia county, one\nherd was found positive for _Brucella melitensis_.\nThis particular outbreak is not associated with the outbreaks in\nLika-Senj county and therefore it is considered as a new primary\noutbreak.\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type: Croatian Veterinary Institute, Zagreb\n(national laboratory)\nSpecies: sheep\nTest: bacteriological examination\nTest date: 9 Apr 2010\nResult: positive\n\nSpecies: sheep/goats\nTest: complement fixation test (CFT)\nTest date: 25 Mar 2010\nResult: positive\n\nSpecies: sheep/goats\nTest: rose bengal test (RBT)\nTest date: 25 Mar 2010\nResult: positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Not unexpectedly, with sheep, the _Brucella_ species identified was\n_Brucella melitensis_, the causative agent of Malta or Mediterranean\nfever. It was first identified by the husband and wife team who named\nthe organism after themselves in 1887, after isolating the agent from\nthe spleen of a British soldier. It took some 20 years until\nThemistocles Zammit, the only non-British member of the Mediterranean\nFever Commission, figured out it was being spread to people through\ngoat milk among other products. All this historical perspective was\ngleaned from Ed Young's birthday lecture for Jim Steele's 97th year\ncelebration last week.\n\nThere are a couple of points about this notification that might need\nclarification. First, why were cattle and dogs reported if there was\nno disease found in them. Secondly, were goats tested with the CFT\nand RBT tests on 25 Mar 2010 and if so, were they part of the\naffected population. - Mod.PC]\n\n[Split-Dalmatia County is located in southern Croatia; an\nadministrative map of the country can be seen at\n<http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/europe/croatia_pol01.jpg>.\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Croatia is available at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/01d3>. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\nSee Also\n2009\n----\nBrucellosis, ovine, bovine - Russia: (CV) 20090423.1530\n2008\n----\nBrucellosis, porcine - Romania: OIE 20081011.3220\nBrucellosis, ovine, human - Russia (Altai) 20080902.2749\nBrucellosis, livestock, human - Azerbaijan, Russia 20080518.1658\nBrucellosis, ovine - Russia (Moscow ex Volgograd) (02) 20080318.1047\nBrucellosis, ovine - Russia (Moscow ex Volgograd) 20080317.1043\n2007\n----\nBrucellosis, ovine - Russia (Buryatia) 20070611.1903\nBrucellosis, ovine - Russia (Sverdlovsk region) 20070522.1639\nBrucellosis, ovine - Russia (Kaluga) 20070517.1572\nBrucellosis, ovine - Russia (Samara, Orenburg) 20070209.0510\n2005\n----\nBrucellosis, ovine - Russia (Perm) 20050303.0652\n...................................pc/mj/lm\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. It was first identified by the husband and wife team who named\nthe organism after themselves in 1887, after isolating the agent from\nthe spleen of a British soldier. It took some 20 years until\nThemistocles Zammit, the only non-British member of the Mediterranean\nFever Commission, figured out it was being spread to people through\ngoat milk among other products. All this historical perspective was\ngleaned from Ed Young's birthday lecture for Jim Steele's 97th year\ncelebration last week.\n\nThere are a couple of points about this notification that might need\nclarification. 23(16) [edited]\n<http://www.oie.int/wahis/public.php?page=single_report&pop=1&reportid=9150>\n\n\nBrucellosis (_Brucella melitensis_), Croatia\n--------------------------------------------\nInformation received on (and dated) 16 Apr 2010 from Dr Sanja\nSeparovic, Director, Veterinary Directorate, Ministry of Agriculture,\nFisheries and Rural Development (MAFRD), Zagreb, Croatia\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nStart date: 25 Mar 2010\nDate of 1st confirmation of the event: 25 Mar 2010\nReport date: 16 Apr 2010\nDate submitted to OIE: 16 Apr 2010\nReason for notification: reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence 11 May 2009\nManifestation of disease: sub-clinical infection\nCausal agent: _Brucella melitensis_\nNature of diagnosis: laboratory (basic), laboratory (advanced)\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country\n\nNew outbreaks\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak location: Studenci, Studenci, Lovrec, Splitsko-Dalmatinska\n[Split-Dalmatia]\nDate of start of the outbreak: 25 Mar 2010\nOutbreak status: continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: farm\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nCattle / 2 / 0 / 0 / 0 / 0\nSheep / 28 / 5 / 0 / 28 / 0\nDogs / 3 / 0 / 0 / 0 / 0\nAffected population: sheep herd with 16 breeding sheep and 12 lambs.\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: legal movement of\nanimals; illegal movement of animals; contact with infected animal(s)\nat grazing/watering\nEpidemiological comments: within the regular yearly surveillance for\nbrucellosis in sheep and goats herds in Split-Dalmatia county, one\nherd was found positive for _Brucella melitensis_.\nThis particular outbreak is not associated with the outbreaks in\nLika-Senj county and therefore it is considered as a new primary\noutbreak.\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type: Croatian Veterinary Institute, Zagreb\n(national laboratory)\nSpecies: sheep\nTest: bacteriological examination\nTest date: 9 Apr 2010\nResult: positive\n\nSpecies: sheep/goats\nTest: complement fixation test (CFT)\nTest date: 25 Mar 2010\nResult: positive\n\nSpecies: sheep/goats\nTest: rose bengal test (RBT)\nTest date: 25 Mar 2010\nResult: positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Not unexpectedly, with sheep, the _Brucella_ species identified was\n_Brucella melitensis_, the causative agent of Malta or Mediterranean\nfever. It was first identified by the husband and wife team who named\nthe organism after themselves in 1887, after isolating the agent from\nthe spleen of a British soldier. It took some 20 years until\nThemistocles Zammit, the only non-British member of the Mediterranean\nFever Commission, figured out it was being spread to people through\ngoat milk among other products. All this historical perspective was\ngleaned from Ed Young's birthday lecture for Jim Steele's 97th year\ncelebration last week.\n\nThere are a couple of points about this notification that might need\nclarification. First, why were cattle and dogs reported if there was\nno disease found in them. Secondly, were goats tested with the CFT\nand RBT tests on 25 Mar 2010 and if so, were they part of the\naffected population. - Mod.PC]\n\n[Split-Dalmatia County is located in southern Croatia; an\nadministrative map of the country can be seen at\n<http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/europe/croatia_pol01.jpg>.\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Croatia is available at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/01d3>. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\nSee Also\n2009\n----\nBrucellosis, ovine, bovine - Russia: (CV) 20090423.1530\n2008\n----\nBrucellosis, porcine - Romania: OIE 20081011.3220\nBrucellosis, ovine, human - Russia (Altai) 20080902.2749\nBrucellosis, livestock, human - Azerbaijan, Russia 20080518.1658\nBrucellosis, ovine - Russia (Moscow ex Volgograd) (02) 20080318.1047\nBrucellosis, ovine - Russia (Moscow ex Volgograd) 20080317.1043\n2007\n----\nBrucellosis, ovine - Russia (Buryatia) 20070611.1903\nBrucellosis, ovine - Russia (Sverdlovsk region) 20070522.1639\nBrucellosis, ovine - Russia (Kaluga) 20070517.1572\nBrucellosis, ovine - Russia (Samara, Orenburg) 20070209.0510\n2005\n----\nBrucellosis, ovine - Russia (Perm) 20050303.0652\n...................................pc/mj/lm\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. It was first identified by the husband and wife team who named\nthe organism after themselves in 1887, after isolating the agent from\nthe spleen of a British soldier. It took some 20 years until\nThemistocles Zammit, the only non-British member of the Mediterranean\nFever Commission, figured out it was being spread to people through\ngoat milk among other products. All this historical perspective was\ngleaned from Ed Young's birthday lecture for Jim Steele's 97th year\ncelebration last week.\n\nThere are a couple of points about this notification that might need\nclarification. All this historical perspective was\ngleaned from Ed Young's birthday lecture for Jim Steele's 97th year\ncelebration last week.\n\nThere are a couple of points about this notification that might need\nclarification. First, why were cattle and dogs reported if there was\nno disease found in them. Secondly, were goats tested with the CFT\nand RBT tests on 25 Mar 2010 and if so, were they part of the\naffected population. - Mod.PC]\n\n[Split-Dalmatia County is located in southern Croatia; an\nadministrative map of the country can be seen at\n<http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/europe/croatia_pol01.jpg>.\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Croatia is available at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/01d3>. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\nSee Also\n2009\n----\nBrucellosis, ovine, bovine - Russia: (CV) 20090423.1530\n2008\n----\nBrucellosis, porcine - Romania: OIE 20081011.3220\nBrucellosis, ovine, human - Russia (Altai) 20080902.2749\nBrucellosis, livestock, human - Azerbaijan, Russia 20080518.1658\nBrucellosis, ovine - Russia (Moscow ex Volgograd) (02) 20080318.1047\nBrucellosis, ovine - Russia (Moscow ex Volgograd) 20080317.1043\n2007\n----\nBrucellosis, ovine - Russia (Buryatia) 20070611.1903\nBrucellosis, ovine - Russia (Sverdlovsk region) 20070522.1639\nBrucellosis, ovine - Russia (Kaluga) 20070517.1572\nBrucellosis, ovine - Russia (Samara, Orenburg) 20070209.0510\n2005\n----\nBrucellosis, ovine - Russia (Perm) 20050303.0652\n...................................pc/mj/lm\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "brucellosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2010-03-15 00:00:00", "2010-03-15 00:00:00", "2009-05-11 00:00:00", "2010-03-15 00:00:00", "1887-03-15 00:00:00", "2009-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Malta", "country": "Malta"}, {"location": "Volgograd", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "WAHID", "country": "Oman"}, {"location": "Azerbaijan", "country": "Azerbaijan"}, {"location": "Sverdlovsk", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Croatia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Orenburg", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Moscow", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Samara", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Zagreb", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "415679", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Brucellosis, cervid - USA (04): Yellowstone", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=415679", "date": "2010-04-18 12:00:04", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS, OVINE - CROATIA: (SPLIT-DALMATIA) OIE\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Fri 16 Apr 2010\nSource: OIE, WAHID (World Animal Health Information Database), weekly\ndisease information 2010; 23(16) [edited]\n<http://www.oie.int/wahis/public.php?page=single_report&pop=1&reportid=9150>\n\n\nBrucellosis (_Brucella melitensis_), Croatia\n--------------------------------------------\nInformation received on (and dated) 16 Apr 2010 from Dr Sanja\nSeparovic, Director, Veterinary Directorate, Ministry of Agriculture,\nFisheries and Rural Development (MAFRD), Zagreb, Croatia\n\nSummary\nReport type: immediate notification\nStart date: 25 Mar 2010\nDate of 1st confirmation of the event: 25 Mar 2010\nReport date: 16 Apr 2010\nDate submitted to OIE: 16 Apr 2010\nReason for notification: reoccurrence of a listed disease\nDate of previous occurrence 11 May 2009\nManifestation of disease: sub-clinical infection\nCausal agent: _Brucella melitensis_\nNature of diagnosis: laboratory (basic), laboratory (advanced)\nThis event pertains to a defined zone within the country\n\nNew outbreaks\nSummary of outbreaks\nTotal outbreaks: 1\nOutbreak location: Studenci, Studenci, Lovrec, Splitsko-Dalmatinska\n[Split-Dalmatia]\nDate of start of the outbreak: 25 Mar 2010\nOutbreak status: continuing (or date resolved not provided)\nEpidemiological unit: farm\nSpecies / Susceptible / Cases / Deaths / Destroyed / Slaughtered\nCattle / 2 / 0 / 0 / 0 / 0\nSheep / 28 / 5 / 0 / 28 / 0\nDogs / 3 / 0 / 0 / 0 / 0\nAffected population: sheep herd with 16 breeding sheep and 12 lambs.\n\nEpidemiology\nSource of the outbreak(s) or origin of infection: legal movement of\nanimals; illegal movement of animals; contact with infected animal(s)\nat grazing/watering\nEpidemiological comments: within the regular yearly surveillance for\nbrucellosis in sheep and goats herds in Split-Dalmatia county, one\nherd was found positive for _Brucella melitensis_.\nThis particular outbreak is not associated with the outbreaks in\nLika-Senj county and therefore it is considered as a new primary\noutbreak.\n\nDiagnostic test results\nLaboratory name and type: Croatian Veterinary Institute, Zagreb\n(national laboratory)\nSpecies: sheep\nTest: bacteriological examination\nTest date: 9 Apr 2010\nResult: positive\n\nSpecies: sheep/goats\nTest: complement fixation test (CFT)\nTest date: 25 Mar 2010\nResult: positive\n\nSpecies: sheep/goats\nTest: rose bengal test (RBT)\nTest date: 25 Mar 2010\nResult: positive\n\nFuture reporting\nThe event is continuing. Weekly follow-up reports will be submitted.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Not unexpectedly, with sheep, the _Brucella_ species identified was\n_Brucella melitensis_, the causative agent of Malta or Mediterranean\nfever. It was first identified by the husband and wife team who named\nthe organism after themselves in 1887, after isolating the agent from\nthe spleen of a British soldier. It took some 20 years until\nThemistocles Zammit, the only non-British member of the Mediterranean\nFever Commission, figured out it was being spread to people through\ngoat milk among other products. All this historical perspective was\ngleaned from Ed Young's birthday lecture for Jim Steele's 97th year\ncelebration last week.\n\nThere are a couple of points about this notification that might need\nclarification. First, why were cattle and dogs reported if there was\nno disease found in them. Secondly, were goats tested with the CFT\nand RBT tests on 25 Mar 2010 and if so, were they part of the\naffected population. - Mod.PC]\n\n[Split-Dalmatia County is located in southern Croatia; an\nadministrative map of the country can be seen at\n<http://www.lib.utexas.edu/maps/europe/croatia_pol01.jpg>.\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Croatia is available at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/01d3>. - Sr.Tech.Ed.MJ]\nSee Also\n2009\n----\nBrucellosis, ovine, bovine - Russia: (CV) 20090423.1530\n2008\n----\nBrucellosis, porcine - Romania: OIE 20081011.3220\nBrucellosis, ovine, human - Russia (Altai) 20080902.2749\nBrucellosis, livestock, human - Azerbaijan, Russia 20080518.1658\nBrucellosis, ovine - Russia (Moscow ex Volgograd) (02) 20080318.1047\nBrucellosis, ovine - Russia (Moscow ex Volgograd) 20080317.1043\n2007\n----\nBrucellosis, ovine - Russia (Buryatia) 20070611.1903\nBrucellosis, ovine - Russia (Sverdlovsk region) 20070522.1639\nBrucellosis, ovine - Russia (Kaluga) 20070517.1572\nBrucellosis, ovine - Russia (Samara, Orenburg) 20070209.0510\n2005\n----\nBrucellosis, ovine - Russia (Perm) 20050303.0652\n...................................pc/mj/lm\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "brucellosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2010-03-15 00:00:00", "2010-03-15 00:00:00", "2009-05-11 00:00:00", "2010-03-15 00:00:00", "1887-03-15 00:00:00", "2009-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Malta", "country": "Malta"}, {"location": "Volgograd", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "WAHID", "country": "Oman"}, {"location": "Azerbaijan", "country": "Azerbaijan"}, {"location": "Sverdlovsk", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Croatia", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Orenburg", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Moscow", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Samara", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Zagreb", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "404435", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Brucellosis, cervid - USA (03): (Gtr. Yellowstone Ecosystem)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=404435", "date": "2009-09-20 21:00:02", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS, SWINE HUNTERS - USA (02): (TEXAS)\n**********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 17 Sep 2009\nSource: Chron.com, Associated Press (AP) report [edited]\n<http://www.chron.com/disp/story.mpl/ap/tx/6623163.html>\n\n\nA 76-year-old man from Tomball developed symptoms that turned out to\nhave nothing to do with swine flu but everything to do with hogs.\nDoctors earlier in 2009 diagnosed him with brucellosis.\n\nThe man picked up the disease from feral hogs that have rooted through\nparts of his property in Cherokee County. His brucellosis was traced\nto him cleaning a feral hog in March 2009. He and his son butchered\none of the many feral hogs they had shot or trapped.\n\n\"People need to know that they should be cautious when they handle\nthose pigs, and always wear gloves,\" he said. \"I wouldn't want what's\nhappened to me to happen to anybody.\"\n\nThe man faces months of more treatment for the disease, which is\ncaused by a bacterium linked to feral hogs. An estimated 2 million of\nthe wild creatures roam Texas. The Houston Chronicle reported Thursday\n[17 Sep 2009] that about 10 percent of Texas feral hogs test positive\nfor brucellosis bacteria, but the rate in eastern parts of the state\nhas been known to be higher. The disease can cause pregnant animals to\nprematurely abort their young.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[The CDC, earlier in 2009, reported on similar cases in the\nsoutheastern USA. As an occupation-related disease, brucellosis can\nresult from the organism from diseased animals entering through skin\nlesions or mucous membranes, or from the inhalation of contamination\ndust or aerosols.\n\nInhalation is involved with many cases associated with abattoir\nworkers (1). Contamination of skin lesions is also common in meat\npacking workers or veterinarians. As in this cluster, hunters may be\ninfected through skin lesions or by accidental ingestion of bacilli\nduring or after cleaning moose, elk, or (as here) feral pigs.\n\nHistorically (2), Capasso found bone lesions typical of brucellosis in\nadult skeletal remains of people killed during the 1st volcanic surge\nof Mount Vesuvius. He also demonstrated by scanning electron\nmicroscopy analysis of buried carbonized cheese, the presence of\nbacterial forms consistent with _Brucella_ spp. Sir David Bruce first\nisolated the organism associated with Maltese (or Malta) fever from a\nBritish soldier who died in 1887 and the organism was eventually named\nin his honor. The organism was isolated from goat's milk in 1905, also\nin Malta.\n\nMicrobiologically, classical biovar typing methodology is\ntime-consuming, poorly standardized, and requires high-level biosafety\ncontainment. Typing the 4 biovars of _B. suis_ involves hydrogen\nsulfide production, growth in dyes, bacteriophage susceptibility, and\nagglutination with biovar-specific antisera. To simplify this process,\nreal-time polymerase chain reaction technology looking at single\nnucleotide polymorphism can be used (3).\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. Robson JM, Harrison MW, Wood RN, et al: Brucellosis: re-emergence\nand changing epidemiology in Queensland. Med J Aust 1993; 159(3):\n153-8; abstract available at\n<http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/8336614>.\n2. Godfroid J, Cloeckaert A, Liautard JP, et al: From the discovery of\nthe Malta fever's agent to the discovery of a marine mammal reservoir,\nbrucellosis has continuously been a re-emerging zoonosis. Vet Res\n2005; 36(3): 313-26; available at\n<http://publications.edpsciences.org/10.1051/vetres:2005003>.\n3. Fretin D, Whatmore AM, Al Dahouk S, et al: _Brucella suis_\nidentification and biovar typing by real-time PCR. Vet Microbiol.\n2008; 131(3-4): 376-85. Epub 2008 May 21; abstract available at\n<http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/18499359>.\n\nThe location of Cherokee County in the state of Texas can be found on a map at\n<http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/c/ce/Cherokee_County_Texas.png>\nand the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/00Qe>. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nBrucellosis, swine hunters - USA: (SC, PA) ex Florida 20090612.2178\n2008\n----\nBrucellosis, lab workers, 2006 - USA: (IN, MN) 20080117.0214\n2007\n----\nBrucellosis, Q fever, lab workers - USA (TX) 20070706.2146\n2004\n----\nBrucellosis, ovine, contaminated agar - USA: alert 20040820.2315\n2001\n----\nBrucellosis - USA (Arkansas) ex Mexico: alert 20010805.1539\n........................................ll/mj/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail. ISID\nand its associated service providers shall not be held\nresponsible for errors or omissions or held liable for any\ndamages incurred as a result of use or reliance upon posted\nor archived material.\n************************************************************\nBecome a ProMED-mail Premium Subscriber at\n<http://www.isid.org/ProMEDMail_Premium.shtml>\n************************************************************\nVisit ProMED-mail's web site at <http://www.promedmail.org>.\nSend all items for posting to: promed@promedmail.org\n\n(NOT to an individual moderator). If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["brucellosis", "q fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2009-03-15 00:00:00", "2009-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2009-09-17 00:00:00", "2009-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "1887-03-15 00:00:00", "1905-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-05-21 00:00:00", "2001-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Malta", "country": "Malta"}, {"location": "TEXAS", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Cherokee County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "SC", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mexico", "country": "Mexico"}, {"location": "Texas", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Arkansas", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Queensland", "country": "Australia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "397006", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Brucellosis, bovine - Russia: (VG)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=397006", "date": "2009-09-20 21:00:02", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS, SWINE HUNTERS - USA (02): (TEXAS)\n**********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 17 Sep 2009\nSource: Chron.com, Associated Press (AP) report [edited]\n<http://www.chron.com/disp/story.mpl/ap/tx/6623163.html>\n\n\nA 76-year-old man from Tomball developed symptoms that turned out to\nhave nothing to do with swine flu but everything to do with hogs.\nDoctors earlier in 2009 diagnosed him with brucellosis.\n\nThe man picked up the disease from feral hogs that have rooted through\nparts of his property in Cherokee County. He and his son butchered\none of the many feral hogs they had shot or trapped.\n\n\"People need to know that they should be cautious when they handle\nthose pigs, and always wear gloves,\" he said. \"I wouldn't want what's\nhappened to me to happen to anybody.\"\n\nThe man faces months of more treatment for the disease, which is\ncaused by a bacterium linked to feral hogs. An estimated 2 million of\nthe wild creatures roam Texas. The disease can cause pregnant animals to\nprematurely abort their young.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[The CDC, earlier in 2009, reported on similar cases in the\nsoutheastern USA. As in this cluster, hunters may be\ninfected through skin lesions or by accidental ingestion of bacilli\nduring or after cleaning moose, elk, or (as here) feral pigs.\n\nHistorically (2), Capasso found bone lesions typical of brucellosis in\nadult skeletal remains of people killed during the 1st volcanic surge\nof Mount Vesuvius. He also demonstrated by scanning electron\nmicroscopy analysis of buried carbonized cheese, the presence of\nbacterial forms consistent with _Brucella_ spp. Sir David Bruce first\nisolated the organism associated with Maltese (or Malta) fever from a\nBritish soldier who died in 1887 and the organism was eventually named\nin his honor. The organism was isolated from goat's milk in 1905, also\nin Malta.\n\nMicrobiologically, classical biovar typing methodology is\ntime-consuming, poorly standardized, and requires high-level biosafety\ncontainment. Typing the 4 biovars of _B. suis_ involves hydrogen\nsulfide production, growth in dyes, bacteriophage susceptibility, and\nagglutination with biovar-specific antisera. To simplify this process,\nreal-time polymerase chain reaction technology looking at single\nnucleotide polymorphism can be used (3).\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. Robson JM, Harrison MW, Wood RN, et al: Brucellosis: re-emergence\nand changing epidemiology in Queensland. Med J Aust 1993; 159(3):\n153-8; abstract available at\n<http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/8336614>.\n2. Godfroid J, Cloeckaert A, Liautard JP, et al: From the discovery of\nthe Malta fever's agent to the discovery of a marine mammal reservoir,\nbrucellosis has continuously been a re-emerging zoonosis. Vet Res\n2005; 36(3): 313-26; available at\n<http://publications.edpsciences.org/10.1051/vetres:2005003>.\n3. Fretin D, Whatmore AM, Al Dahouk S, et al: _Brucella suis_\nidentification and biovar typing by real-time PCR. Vet Microbiol.\n2008; 131(3-4): 376-85. Epub 2008 May 21; abstract available at\n<http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/18499359>.\n\nThe location of Cherokee County in the state of Texas can be found on a map at\n<http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/c/ce/Cherokee_County_Texas.png>\nand the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/00Qe>. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nBrucellosis, swine hunters - USA: (SC, PA) ex Florida 20090612.2178\n2008\n----\nBrucellosis, lab workers, 2006 - USA: (IN, MN) 20080117.0214\n2007\n----\nBrucellosis, Q fever, lab workers - USA (TX) 20070706.2146\n2004\n----\nBrucellosis, ovine, contaminated agar - USA: alert 20040820.2315\n2001\n----\nBrucellosis - USA (Arkansas) ex Mexico: alert 20010805.1539\n........................................ll/mj/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["brucellosis", "q fever"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2009-03-15 00:00:00", "2009-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00", "2009-09-17 00:00:00", "2009-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-01 00:00:00", "1887-03-15 00:00:00", "1905-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-05-21 00:00:00", "2001-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Malta", "country": "Malta"}, {"location": "TEXAS", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Cherokee County", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "SC", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Mexico", "country": "Mexico"}, {"location": "Texas", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Arkansas", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Queensland", "country": "Australia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "380726", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Brucellosis, swine - Germany: (BB), OIE", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=380726", "date": "2009-09-20 21:00:02", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS, SWINE HUNTERS - USA (02): (TEXAS)\n**********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 17 Sep 2009\nSource: Chron.com, Associated Press (AP) report [edited]\n<http://www.chron.com/disp/story.mpl/ap/tx/6623163.html>\n\n\nA 76-year-old man from Tomball developed symptoms that turned out to\nhave nothing to do with swine flu but everything to do with hogs.\nDoctors earlier in 2009 diagnosed him with brucellosis.\n\nThe man picked up the disease from feral hogs that have rooted through\nparts of his property in Cherokee County. His brucellosis was traced\nto him cleaning a feral hog in March 2009. He and his son butchered\none of the many feral hogs they had shot or trapped.\n\n\"People need to know that they should be cautious when they handle\nthose pigs, and always wear gloves,\" he said. \"I wouldn't want what's\nhappened to me to happen to anybody.\"\n\nThe man faces months of more treatment for the disease, which is\ncaused by a bacterium linked to feral hogs. An estimated 2 million of\nthe wild creatures roam Texas. The Houston Chronicle reported Thursday\n[17 Sep 2009] that about 10 percent of Texas feral hogs test positive\nfor brucellosis bacteria, but the rate in eastern parts of the state\nhas been known to be higher. The disease can cause pregnant animals to\nprematurely abort their young.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[The CDC, earlier in 2009, reported on similar cases in the\nsoutheastern USA. As an occupation-related disease, brucellosis can\nresult from the organism from diseased animals entering through skin\nlesions or mucous membranes, or from the inhalation of contamination\ndust or aerosols.\n\nInhalation is involved with many cases associated with abattoir\nworkers (1). Contamination of skin lesions is also common in meat\npacking workers or veterinarians. As in this cluster, hunters may be\ninfected through skin lesions or by accidental ingestion of bacilli\nduring or after cleaning moose, elk, or (as here) feral pigs.\n\nHistorically (2), Capasso found bone lesions typical of brucellosis in\nadult skeletal remains of people killed during the 1st volcanic surge\nof Mount Vesuvius. He also demonstrated by scanning electron\nmicroscopy analysis of buried carbonized cheese, the presence of\nbacterial forms consistent with _Brucella_ spp. Sir David Bruce first\nisolated the organism associated with Maltese (or Malta) fever from a\nBritish soldier who died in 1887 and the organism was eventually named\nin his honor. The organism was isolated from goat's milk in 1905, also\nin Malta.\n\nMicrobiologically, classical biovar typing methodology is\ntime-consuming, poorly standardized, and requires high-level biosafety\ncontainment. Typing the 4 biovars of _B. suis_ involves hydrogen\nsulfide production, growth in dyes, bacteriophage susceptibility, and\nagglutination with biovar-specific antisera. To simplify this process,\nreal-time polymerase chain reaction technology looking at single\nnucleotide polymorphism can be used (3).\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. Robson JM, Harrison MW, Wood RN, et al: Brucellosis: re-emergence\nand changing epidemiology in Queensland. Med J Aust 1993; 159(3):\n153-8; abstract available at\n<http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/8336614>.\n2. Godfroid J, Cloeckaert A, Liautard JP, et al: From the discovery of\nthe Malta fever's agent to the discovery of a marine mammal reservoir,\nbrucellosis has continuously been a re-emerging zoonosis. Vet Res\n2005; 36(3): 313-26; available at\n<http://publications.edpsciences.org/10.1051/vetres:2005003>.\n3. Fretin D, Whatmore AM, Al Dahouk S, et al: _Brucella suis_\nidentification and biovar typing by real-time PCR. Vet Microbiol.\n2008; 131(3-4): 376-85. Epub 2008 May 21; abstract available at\n<http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/18499359>.\n\nThe location of Cherokee County in the state of Texas can be found on a map at\n<http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/c/ce/Cherokee_County_Texas.png>\nand the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/00Qe>. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nBrucellosis, swine hunters - USA: (SC, PA) ex Florida 20090612.2178\n2008\n----\nBrucellosis, lab workers, 2006 - USA: (IN, MN) 20080117.0214\n2007\n----\nBrucellosis, Q fever, lab workers - USA (TX) 20070706.2146\n2004\n----\nBrucellosis, ovine, contaminated agar - USA: alert 20040820.2315\n2001\n----\nBrucellosis - USA (Arkansas) ex Mexico: alert 20010805.1539\n........................................ll/mj/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The Houston Chronicle reported Thursday\n[17 Sep 2009] that about 10 percent of Texas feral hogs test positive\nfor brucellosis bacteria, but the rate in eastern parts of the state\nhas been known to be higher. The disease can cause pregnant animals to\nprematurely abort their young.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[The CDC, earlier in 2009, reported on similar cases in the\nsoutheastern USA. As an occupation-related disease, brucellosis can\nresult from the organism from diseased animals entering through skin\nlesions or mucous membranes, or from the inhalation of contamination\ndust or aerosols.\n\nInhalation is involved with many cases associated with abattoir\nworkers (1). Contamination of skin lesions is also common in meat\npacking workers or veterinarians. As in this cluster, hunters may be\ninfected through skin lesions or by accidental ingestion of bacilli\nduring or after cleaning moose, elk, or (as here) feral pigs.\n\nHistorically (2), Capasso found bone lesions typical of brucellosis in\nadult skeletal remains of people killed during the 1st volcanic surge\nof Mount Vesuvius. He also demonstrated by scanning electron\nmicroscopy analysis of buried carbonized cheese, the presence of\nbacterial forms consistent with _Brucella_ spp. Sir David Bruce first\nisolated the organism associated with Maltese (or Malta) fever from a\nBritish soldier who died in 1887 and the organism was eventually named\nin his honor. The organism was isolated from goat's milk in 1905, also\nin Malta.\n\nMicrobiologically, classical biovar typing methodology is\ntime-consuming, poorly standardized, and requires high-level biosafety\ncontainment. Typing the 4 biovars of _B. suis_ involves hydrogen\nsulfide production, growth in dyes, bacteriophage susceptibility, and\nagglutination with biovar-specific antisera. To simplify this process,\nreal-time polymerase chain reaction technology looking at single\nnucleotide polymorphism can be used (3).\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. Robson JM, Harrison MW, Wood RN, et al: Brucellosis: re-emergence\nand changing epidemiology in Queensland. Med J Aust 1993; 159(3):\n153-8; abstract available at\n<http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/8336614>.\n2. Godfroid J, Cloeckaert A, Liautard JP, et al: From the discovery of\nthe Malta fever's agent to the discovery of a marine mammal reservoir,\nbrucellosis has continuously been a re-emerging zoonosis. Vet Res\n2005; 36(3): 313-26; available at\n<http://publications.edpsciences.org/10.1051/vetres:2005003>.\n3. Fretin D, Whatmore AM, Al Dahouk S, et al: _Brucella suis_\nidentification and biovar typing by real-time PCR. Vet Microbiol.\n2008; 131(3-4): 376-85. Epub 2008 May 21; abstract available at\n<http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/18499359>.\n\nThe location of Cherokee County in the state of Texas can be found on a map at\n<http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/c/ce/Cherokee_County_Texas.png>\nand the HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at\n<http://healthmap.org/r/00Qe>. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nBrucellosis, swine hunters - USA: (SC, PA) ex Florida 20090612.2178\n2008\n----\nBrucellosis, lab workers, 2006 - USA: (IN, MN) 20080117.0214\n2007\n----\nBrucellosis, Q fever, lab workers - USA (TX) 20070706.2146\n2004\n----\nBrucellosis, ovine, contaminated agar - USA: alert 20040820.2315\n2001\n----\nBrucellosis - USA (Arkansas) ex Mexico: alert 20010805.1539\n........................................ll/mj/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. His brucellosis was traced\nto him cleaning a feral hog in March 2009. He and his son butchered\none of the many feral hogs they had shot or trapped.\n\n\"People need to know that they should be cautious when they handle\nthose pigs, and always wear gloves,\" he said. \"I wouldn't want what's\nhappened to me to happen to anybody.\"\n\nThe man faces months of more treatment for the disease, which is\ncaused by a bacterium linked to feral hogs. An estimated 2 million of\nthe wild creatures roam Texas. The Houston Chronicle reported Thursday\n[17 Sep 2009] that about 10 percent of Texas feral hogs test positive\nfor brucellosis bacteria, but the rate in eastern parts of the state\nhas been known to be higher. The disease can cause pregnant animals to\nprematurely abort their young.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail Rapporteur Mary Marshall\n\n[The CDC, earlier in 2009, reported on similar cases in the\nsoutheastern USA. As an occupation-related disease, brucellosis can\nresult from the organism from diseased animals entering through skin\nlesions or mucous membranes, or from the inhalation of contamination\ndust or aerosols.\n\nInhalation is involved with many cases associated with abattoir\nworkers (1). Contamination of skin lesions is also common in meat\npacking workers or veterinarians. As in this cluster, hunters may be\ninfected through skin lesions or by accidental ingestion of bacilli\nduring or after cleaning moose, elk, or (as here) feral pigs.\n\nHistorically (2), Capasso found bone lesions typical of brucellosis in\nadult skeletal remains of people killed during the 1st volcanic surge\nof Mount Vesuvius. He also demonstrated by scanning electron\nmicroscopy analysis of buried carbonized cheese, the presence of\nbacterial forms consistent with _Brucella_ spp. Sir David Bruce first\nisolated the organism associated with Maltese (or Malta) fever from a\nBritish soldier who died in 1887 and the organism was eventually named\nin his honor. The organism was isolated from goat's milk in 1905, also\nin Malta.\n\nMicrobiologically, classical biovar typing methodology is\ntime-consuming, poorly standardized, and requires high-level biosafety\ncontainment. Typing the 4 biovars of _B. suis_ involves hydrogen\nsulfide production, growth in dyes, bacteriophage susceptibility, and\nagglutination with biovar-specific antisera. To simplify this process,\nreal-time polymerase chain reaction technology looking at single\nnucleotide polymorphism can be used (3).\n\nReferences\n----------\n1. Several times the article mentions reactors -- I presume, to\nsome serological test. Which test and was there follow-up or re-test?\nNowhere do they describe abortion storms? There is mention of 'sick'\ncattle, but nothing more specific.\n\nIn our Solomon Island survey [de Fredrick DF, Reece RL.(1980).\nDiseases of cattle in the Solomon Islands. Aust Vet J. 1980 Nov;\n56(11):522-5] we had many reactors to Rose Bengal Test performed by\nmyself and staff, but on further testing using CFT SAT etc at other\nlaboratories overseas, all were considered negative except for a\nsmall group of imported cattle and these reactions were considered\ninconclusive.\n\n--\nDr Rodney L Reece, BVSc MSc PhD FACVSc\nRegistered Specialist in Avian Medicine (Poultry) #S91\nVeterinary Pathologist\nNSW Department of Primary Industries\nRegional Veterinary Laboratory\nElizabeth Macarthur Agricultural Institute\nCamden NSW 2570, Australia\n<rod.reece@dpi.nsw.gov.au>\n\n[Dr Reece's queries are valid and appreciated. An abstract of the\nsurvey in the Solomon Islands, mentioned by him, is available at\n<http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/7247885>.\n\nIt would help if an official information from Fiji, or from regional\nagencies, becomes available. It would be tremendously helpful if\nFiji's information to OIE's WAHID interface is completed, including\nthe official status of Brucellosis since 2005 and particularly in\n2008, the use (or absence) of vaccination, the cattle census and all\nother data required from OIE member countries. - Mod.AS]\nSee Also\nBovine brucellosis - Fiji 20090708.2445\n....................arn/ejp\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Several times the article mentions reactors -- I presume, to\nsome serological test. Which test and was there follow-up or re-test?\nNowhere do they describe abortion storms? There is mention of 'sick'\ncattle, but nothing more specific.\n\nIn our Solomon Island survey [de Fredrick DF, Reece RL.(1980).\nDiseases of cattle in the Solomon Islands. Aust Vet J. 1980 Nov;\n56(11):522-5] we had many reactors to Rose Bengal Test performed by\nmyself and staff, but on further testing using CFT SAT etc at other\nlaboratories overseas, all were considered negative except for a\nsmall group of imported cattle and these reactions were considered\ninconclusive.\n\n--\nDr Rodney L Reece, BVSc MSc PhD FACVSc\nRegistered Specialist in Avian Medicine (Poultry) #S91\nVeterinary Pathologist\nNSW Department of Primary Industries\nRegional Veterinary Laboratory\nElizabeth Macarthur Agricultural Institute\nCamden NSW 2570, Australia\n<rod.reece@dpi.nsw.gov.au>\n\n[Dr Reece's queries are valid and appreciated. It would be tremendously helpful if\nFiji's information to OIE's WAHID interface is completed, including\nthe official status of Brucellosis since 2005 and particularly in\n2008, the use (or absence) of vaccination, the cattle census and all\nother data required from OIE member countries. - Mod.AS]\nSee Also\nBovine brucellosis - Fiji 20090708.2445\n....................arn/ejp\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Several times the article mentions reactors -- I presume, to\nsome serological test. Which test and was there follow-up or re-test?\nNowhere do they describe abortion storms? There is mention of 'sick'\ncattle, but nothing more specific.\n\nIn our Solomon Island survey [de Fredrick DF, Reece RL.(1980).\nDiseases of cattle in the Solomon Islands. Aust Vet J. 1980 Nov;\n56(11):522-5] we had many reactors to Rose Bengal Test performed by\nmyself and staff, but on further testing using CFT SAT etc at other\nlaboratories overseas, all were considered negative except for a\nsmall group of imported cattle and these reactions were considered\ninconclusive.\n\n--\nDr Rodney L Reece, BVSc MSc PhD FACVSc\nRegistered Specialist in Avian Medicine (Poultry) #S91\nVeterinary Pathologist\nNSW Department of Primary Industries\nRegional Veterinary Laboratory\nElizabeth Macarthur Agricultural Institute\nCamden NSW 2570, Australia\n<rod.reece@dpi.nsw.gov.au>\n\n[Dr Reece's queries are valid and appreciated. An abstract of the\nsurvey in the Solomon Islands, mentioned by him, is available at\n<http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/7247885>.\n\nIt would help if an official information from Fiji, or from regional\nagencies, becomes available. It would be tremendously helpful if\nFiji's information to OIE's WAHID interface is completed, including\nthe official status of Brucellosis since 2005 and particularly in\n2008, the use (or absence) of vaccination, the cattle census and all\nother data required from OIE member countries. - Mod.AS]\nSee Also\nBovine brucellosis - Fiji 20090708.2445\n....................arn/ejp\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Several times the article mentions reactors -- I presume, to\nsome serological test. Which test and was there follow-up or re-test?\nNowhere do they describe abortion storms? There is mention of 'sick'\ncattle, but nothing more specific.\n\nIn our Solomon Island survey [de Fredrick DF, Reece RL.(1980).\nDiseases of cattle in the Solomon Islands. Aust Vet J. 1980 Nov;\n56(11):522-5] we had many reactors to Rose Bengal Test performed by\nmyself and staff, but on further testing using CFT SAT etc at other\nlaboratories overseas, all were considered negative except for a\nsmall group of imported cattle and these reactions were considered\ninconclusive.\n\n--\nDr Rodney L Reece, BVSc MSc PhD FACVSc\nRegistered Specialist in Avian Medicine (Poultry) #S91\nVeterinary Pathologist\nNSW Department of Primary Industries\nRegional Veterinary Laboratory\nElizabeth Macarthur Agricultural Institute\nCamden NSW 2570, Australia\n<rod.reece@dpi.nsw.gov.au>\n\n[Dr Reece's queries are valid and appreciated. An abstract of the\nsurvey in the Solomon Islands, mentioned by him, is available at\n<http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/7247885>.\n\nIt would help if an official information from Fiji, or from regional\nagencies, becomes available. It would be tremendously helpful if\nFiji's information to OIE's WAHID interface is completed, including\nthe official status of Brucellosis since 2005 and particularly in\n2008, the use (or absence) of vaccination, the cattle census and all\nother data required from OIE member countries. - Mod.AS]\nSee Also\nBovine brucellosis - Fiji 20090708.2445\n....................arn/ejp\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Several times the article mentions reactors -- I presume, to\nsome serological test. Which test and was there follow-up or re-test?\nNowhere do they describe abortion storms? There is mention of 'sick'\ncattle, but nothing more specific.\n\nIn our Solomon Island survey [de Fredrick DF, Reece RL.(1980).\nDiseases of cattle in the Solomon Islands. Aust Vet J. 1980 Nov;\n56(11):522-5] we had many reactors to Rose Bengal Test performed by\nmyself and staff, but on further testing using CFT SAT etc at other\nlaboratories overseas, all were considered negative except for a\nsmall group of imported cattle and these reactions were considered\ninconclusive.\n\n--\nDr Rodney L Reece, BVSc MSc PhD FACVSc\nRegistered Specialist in Avian Medicine (Poultry) #S91\nVeterinary Pathologist\nNSW Department of Primary Industries\nRegional Veterinary Laboratory\nElizabeth Macarthur Agricultural Institute\nCamden NSW 2570, Australia\n<rod.reece@dpi.nsw.gov.au>\n\n[Dr Reece's queries are valid and appreciated. Several times the article mentions reactors -- I presume, to\nsome serological test. Which test and was there follow-up or re-test?\nNowhere do they describe abortion storms? There is mention of 'sick'\ncattle, but nothing more specific.\n\nIn our Solomon Island survey [de Fredrick DF, Reece RL.(1980).\nDiseases of cattle in the Solomon Islands. Aust Vet J. 1980 Nov;\n56(11):522-5] we had many reactors to Rose Bengal Test performed by\nmyself and staff, but on further testing using CFT SAT etc at other\nlaboratories overseas, all were considered negative except for a\nsmall group of imported cattle and these reactions were considered\ninconclusive.\n\n--\nDr Rodney L Reece, BVSc MSc PhD FACVSc\nRegistered Specialist in Avian Medicine (Poultry) #S91\nVeterinary Pathologist\nNSW Department of Primary Industries\nRegional Veterinary Laboratory\nElizabeth Macarthur Agricultural Institute\nCamden NSW 2570, Australia\n<rod.reece@dpi.nsw.gov.au>\n\n[Dr Reece's queries are valid and appreciated. An abstract of the\nsurvey in the Solomon Islands, mentioned by him, is available at\n<http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/7247885>.\n\nIt would help if an official information from Fiji, or from regional\nagencies, becomes available. It would be tremendously helpful if\nFiji's information to OIE's WAHID interface is completed, including\nthe official status of Brucellosis since 2005 and particularly in\n2008, the use (or absence) of vaccination, the cattle census and all\nother data required from OIE member countries. - Mod.AS]\nSee Also\nBovine brucellosis - Fiji 20090708.2445\n....................arn/ejp\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "brucellosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "WAHID", "country": "Oman"}, {"location": "Fiji", "country": "Fiji"}, {"location": "Australia", "country": "Australia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "236419", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Bovine brucellosis - Fiji", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=236419", "date": "2009-02-20 17:00:46", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS, CERVIDS - USA (02): (WYOMING)\n******************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.isid.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: 14 Feb 2009\nSource: Casper Star Tribune\n<http://www.casperstartribune.net/articles/2009/02/14/news/wyoming/df50dc35bf9b218e8725755c0076760b.txt>\n\n\nElk test positive for brucellosis\n---------------------------------\nThe 4th year of a 5-year pilot test-and-removal program on 3 western\nWyoming elk feed-grounds concluded on Friday morning [13 Feb 2009]. A total\nof 50 cow elk tested positive for the brucellosis over January and February\n2009, including 5 that tested positive on Friday and were shipped to slaughter.\n\nIn 2 separate efforts in January and February 2009, state wildlife\nofficials trapped and processed 932 elk through the chutes at the 3\nfeed-grounds, including 421 adult females that were subject to brucellosis\ntesting. All 50 cow elk that tested positive for the disease were\ntransported to an eastern Idaho slaughterhouse for processing.\n\nThe brucellosis testing project is a recommendation of the Wyoming\nBrucellosis Coordination Team in an effort to reduce the brucellosis rate\nin the Pinedale elk herd.\n\nBrucellosis is a contagious disease that causes abortions in hoofed animals\nand is present in elk and bison in the Yellowstone region. Brucellosis\ntransmitted to cattle herds from elk caused Wyoming to lose its\nbrucellosis-free market status in 2004.\n\nWyoming later regained its brucellosis-free status in September 2006.\nHowever, cattle from a herd near Daniel were found to be positive for the\ndisease in June 2008. That cattle herd was sent to slaughter.\n\n[byline: Cat Urbigkit]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Brucellosis has always been a problem in the Greater Yellowstone area. The\ntransmission between elk and cattle has always been an issue. The test and\nslaughter policy of recent years has created some consternation within some\ngroups, but as this is the only place in the USA still having brucellosis,\nthis may eventually be a solution to the situation. - Mod.TG\n\nA map of Wyoming is available at\n<http://www.infoplease.com/atlas/state/wyoming.html> - CopyEd.EJP]\nSee Also\nBrucellosis, cervids - USA: (MT) 20090117.0196\n2008\n---\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA (08): (MT), loss of status 20080905.2770\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA (07): (WY) 20080807.2427\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA (06): (WY) ex elk 20080727.2288\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA (05): (WY) 20080726.2273\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA (04): (WY) 20080626.1966\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA (03): (WY) 20080619.1907\n\n..................tg/ejp/sh\n\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. A total\nof 50 cow elk tested positive for the brucellosis over January and February\n2009, including 5 that tested positive on Friday and were shipped to slaughter.\n\nIn 2 separate efforts in January and February 2009, state wildlife\nofficials trapped and processed 932 elk through the chutes at the 3\nfeed-grounds, including 421 adult females that were subject to brucellosis\ntesting. All 50 cow elk that tested positive for the disease were\ntransported to an eastern Idaho slaughterhouse for processing.\n\nThe brucellosis testing project is a recommendation of the Wyoming\nBrucellosis Coordination Team in an effort to reduce the brucellosis rate\nin the Pinedale elk herd.\n\nBrucellosis is a contagious disease that causes abortions in hoofed animals\nand is present in elk and bison in the Yellowstone region. Brucellosis\ntransmitted to cattle herds from elk caused Wyoming to lose its\nbrucellosis-free market status in 2004.\n\nWyoming later regained its brucellosis-free status in September 2006.\nHowever, cattle from a herd near Daniel were found to be positive for the\ndisease in June 2008. That cattle herd was sent to slaughter.\n\n[byline: Cat Urbigkit]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Brucellosis has always been a problem in the Greater Yellowstone area. The\ntransmission between elk and cattle has always been an issue. The test and\nslaughter policy of recent years has created some consternation within some\ngroups, but as this is the only place in the USA still having brucellosis,\nthis may eventually be a solution to the situation. - Mod.TG\n\nA map of Wyoming is available at\n<http://www.infoplease.com/atlas/state/wyoming.html> - CopyEd.EJP]\nSee Also\nBrucellosis, cervids - USA: (MT) 20090117.0196\n2008\n---\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA (08): (MT), loss of status 20080905.2770\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA (07): (WY) 20080807.2427\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA (06): (WY) ex elk 20080727.2288\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA (05): (WY) 20080726.2273\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA (04): (WY) 20080626.1966\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA (03): (WY) 20080619.1907\n\n..................tg/ejp/sh\n\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. A total\nof 50 cow elk tested positive for the brucellosis over January and February\n2009, including 5 that tested positive on Friday and were shipped to slaughter.\n\nIn 2 separate efforts in January and February 2009, state wildlife\nofficials trapped and processed 932 elk through the chutes at the 3\nfeed-grounds, including 421 adult females that were subject to brucellosis\ntesting. All 50 cow elk that tested positive for the disease were\ntransported to an eastern Idaho slaughterhouse for processing.\n\nThe brucellosis testing project is a recommendation of the Wyoming\nBrucellosis Coordination Team in an effort to reduce the brucellosis rate\nin the Pinedale elk herd.\n\nBrucellosis is a contagious disease that causes abortions in hoofed animals\nand is present in elk and bison in the Yellowstone region. Brucellosis\ntransmitted to cattle herds from elk caused Wyoming to lose its\nbrucellosis-free market status in 2004.\n\nWyoming later regained its brucellosis-free status in September 2006.\nHowever, cattle from a herd near Daniel were found to be positive for the\ndisease in June 2008. That cattle herd was sent to slaughter.\n\n[byline: Cat Urbigkit]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Brucellosis has always been a problem in the Greater Yellowstone area. The\ntransmission between elk and cattle has always been an issue. The test and\nslaughter policy of recent years has created some consternation within some\ngroups, but as this is the only place in the USA still having brucellosis,\nthis may eventually be a solution to the situation. - Mod.TG\n\nA map of Wyoming is available at\n<http://www.infoplease.com/atlas/state/wyoming.html> - CopyEd.EJP]\nSee Also\nBrucellosis, cervids - USA: (MT) 20090117.0196\n2008\n---\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA (08): (MT), loss of status 20080905.2770\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA (07): (WY) 20080807.2427\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA (06): (WY) ex elk 20080727.2288\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA (05): (WY) 20080726.2273\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA (04): (WY) 20080626.1966\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA (03): (WY) 20080619.1907\n\n..................tg/ejp/sh\n\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. A total\nof 50 cow elk tested positive for the brucellosis over January and February\n2009, including 5 that tested positive on Friday and were shipped to slaughter.\n\nIn 2 separate efforts in January and February 2009, state wildlife\nofficials trapped and processed 932 elk through the chutes at the 3\nfeed-grounds, including 421 adult females that were subject to brucellosis\ntesting. All 50 cow elk that tested positive for the disease were\ntransported to an eastern Idaho slaughterhouse for processing.\n\nThe brucellosis testing project is a recommendation of the Wyoming\nBrucellosis Coordination Team in an effort to reduce the brucellosis rate\nin the Pinedale elk herd.\n\nBrucellosis is a contagious disease that causes abortions in hoofed animals\nand is present in elk and bison in the Yellowstone region. Brucellosis\ntransmitted to cattle herds from elk caused Wyoming to lose its\nbrucellosis-free market status in 2004.\n\nWyoming later regained its brucellosis-free status in September 2006.\nHowever, cattle from a herd near Daniel were found to be positive for the\ndisease in June 2008. That cattle herd was sent to slaughter.\n\n[byline: Cat Urbigkit]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Brucellosis has always been a problem in the Greater Yellowstone area. The\ntransmission between elk and cattle has always been an issue. A total\nof 50 cow elk tested positive for the brucellosis over January and February\n2009, including 5 that tested positive on Friday and were shipped to slaughter.\n\nIn 2 separate efforts in January and February 2009, state wildlife\nofficials trapped and processed 932 elk through the chutes at the 3\nfeed-grounds, including 421 adult females that were subject to brucellosis\ntesting. All 50 cow elk that tested positive for the disease were\ntransported to an eastern Idaho slaughterhouse for processing.\n\nThe brucellosis testing project is a recommendation of the Wyoming\nBrucellosis Coordination Team in an effort to reduce the brucellosis rate\nin the Pinedale elk herd.\n\nBrucellosis is a contagious disease that causes abortions in hoofed animals\nand is present in elk and bison in the Yellowstone region. A total\nof 50 cow elk tested positive for the brucellosis over January and February\n2009, including 5 that tested positive on Friday and were shipped to slaughter.\n\nIn 2 separate efforts in January and February 2009, state wildlife\nofficials trapped and processed 932 elk through the chutes at the 3\nfeed-grounds, including 421 adult females that were subject to brucellosis\ntesting. All 50 cow elk that tested positive for the disease were\ntransported to an eastern Idaho slaughterhouse for processing.\n\nThe brucellosis testing project is a recommendation of the Wyoming\nBrucellosis Coordination Team in an effort to reduce the brucellosis rate\nin the Pinedale elk herd.\n\nBrucellosis is a contagious disease that causes abortions in hoofed animals\nand is present in elk and bison in the Yellowstone region. Brucellosis\ntransmitted to cattle herds from elk caused Wyoming to lose its\nbrucellosis-free market status in 2004.\n\nWyoming later regained its brucellosis-free status in September 2006.\nHowever, cattle from a herd near Daniel were found to be positive for the\ndisease in June 2008. That cattle herd was sent to slaughter.\n\n[byline: Cat Urbigkit]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Brucellosis has always been a problem in the Greater Yellowstone area. The\ntransmission between elk and cattle has always been an issue. The test and\nslaughter policy of recent years has created some consternation within some\ngroups, but as this is the only place in the USA still having brucellosis,\nthis may eventually be a solution to the situation. - Mod.TG\n\nA map of Wyoming is available at\n<http://www.infoplease.com/atlas/state/wyoming.html> - CopyEd.EJP]\nSee Also\nBrucellosis, cervids - USA: (MT) 20090117.0196\n2008\n---\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA (08): (MT), loss of status 20080905.2770\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA (07): (WY) 20080807.2427\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA (06): (WY) ex elk 20080727.2288\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA (05): (WY) 20080726.2273\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA (04): (WY) 20080626.1966\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA (03): (WY) 20080619.1907\n\n..................tg/ejp/sh\n\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed.
