A total\nof 50 cow elk tested positive for the brucellosis over January and February\n2009, including 5 that tested positive on Friday and were shipped to slaughter.\n\nIn 2 separate efforts in January and February 2009, state wildlife\nofficials trapped and processed 932 elk through the chutes at the 3\nfeed-grounds, including 421 adult females that were subject to brucellosis\ntesting. All 50 cow elk that tested positive for the disease were\ntransported to an eastern Idaho slaughterhouse for processing.\n\nThe brucellosis testing project is a recommendation of the Wyoming\nBrucellosis Coordination Team in an effort to reduce the brucellosis rate\nin the Pinedale elk herd.\n\nBrucellosis is a contagious disease that causes abortions in hoofed animals\nand is present in elk and bison in the Yellowstone region. Brucellosis\ntransmitted to cattle herds from elk caused Wyoming to lose its\nbrucellosis-free market status in 2004.\n\nWyoming later regained its brucellosis-free status in September 2006.\nHowever, cattle from a herd near Daniel were found to be positive for the\ndisease in June 2008. That cattle herd was sent to slaughter.\n\n[byline: Cat Urbigkit]\n\n--\ncommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Brucellosis has always been a problem in the Greater Yellowstone area. The\ntransmission between elk and cattle has always been an issue. The test and\nslaughter policy of recent years has created some consternation within some\ngroups, but as this is the only place in the USA still having brucellosis,\nthis may eventually be a solution to the situation. - Mod.TG\n\nA map of Wyoming is available at\n<http://www.infoplease.com/atlas/state/wyoming.html> - CopyEd.EJP]\nSee Also\nBrucellosis, cervids - USA: (MT) 20090117.0196\n2008\n---\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA (08): (MT), loss of status 20080905.2770\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA (07): (WY) 20080807.2427\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA (06): (WY) ex elk 20080727.2288\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA (05): (WY) 20080726.2273\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA (04): (WY) 20080626.1966\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA (03): (WY) 20080619.1907\n\n..................tg/ejp/sh\n\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Kyrgyzstan (03): epidemic overview 2008", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=152147", "date": "2008-10-10 10:00:33", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS, BOVINE - URUGUAY: (ARTIGAS)\n****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 7 Oct 2008\nSource: Diario Metro, EFE News Agency report [in Spanish, trans.\nMod.MPP/CopyEd.MJ, edited]\n<http://www.diariometro.es/es/article/efe/2008/10/07/695172/index.xml>\n\n\nThe Uruguayan government confirmed that the outbreak of brucellosis\nwas mistaken for foot-and-mouth disease [FMD].\n\nThe Ministry of Livestock, Agriculture, and Fisheries of Uruguay\nconfirmed today [7 Oct 2008] that the focus of infection detected in\nthe northwest of the country, near the border with Brazil, is\nbrucellosis and not foot-and-mouth disease as some official media reported.\n\nMinister of Livestock, Ernesto Agazzi, said it will open an\ninvestigation into the release issued Monday [6 Oct 2008] by the\nveterinary authorities of his ministry in which he warned that there\ncould be an outbreak of FMD in the cattle population of Colonia de\nPalma. This was denied later, after the relevant health analyses were received.\n\nFor his part, the director of Livestock Services, Francisco Muzio,\nsaid that dissemination of this statement was \"irresponsible\" and\ncould have caused much harm to the export of Uruguayan beef.\n\nAccording to the Ministry of Livestock the outbreak of brucellosis in\nthat locality of the Department of Artigas, located 40 kilometers (25\nmi) from the border with Brazil had been reported days ago and\n[measures were being taken to control it].\n\nCurrently, Uruguay is free from foot-and-mouth disease and statement\nof an outbreak of the disease would impact very negatively on the\nsales of beef abroad, one of the major items of export from this country.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Brucellosis is an infectious disease of many ruminant species and of\nswine. In ruminants, abortion is the most obvious manifestation.\nInfections may also cause stillborn or weak calves, retained\nplacentas, and reduced milk yield. Usually, general health is not\nimpaired in uncomplicated abortions.\n\nSeminal vesicles, ampullae, testicles, and epididymides may be\ninfected in bulls; therefore, organisms are present in the semen.\nAgglutinins may be demonstrated in seminal plasma from infected\nbulls. Testicular abscesses may occur. Longstanding infections may\nresult in arthritic joints in some cattle.\n\nGiven these as the most prominent clinical signs in cattle, it seems\na bit of a stretch to believe this was foot-and-mouth disease, whose\nmost prominent clinical include fever, sore feet, excessive\nsalivation, and vesicles in the mucous membrane areas to the point of\nsloughing the epithelium on the tongue.\n\nAnnouncements regarding an incorrect diagnosis or an unverified\ndiagnosis can cause much harm to the country's economy. We hope\nUruguay can resolve the issue quickly.\n\nPortions of this comment were extracted from\n<http://www.merckvetmanual.com/mvm/index.jsp?cfile=htm/bc/110502.htm&word=brucellosis>.\n- Mod.TG\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Uruguay is available at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed?g=3443756&v=-32.8,-56,6>. - USA: (MT)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=146595", "date": "2008-10-10 10:00:33", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS, BOVINE - URUGUAY: (ARTIGAS)\n****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 7 Oct 2008\nSource: Diario Metro, EFE News Agency report [in Spanish, trans.\nMod.MPP/CopyEd.MJ, edited]\n<http://www.diariometro.es/es/article/efe/2008/10/07/695172/index.xml>\n\n\nThe Uruguayan government confirmed that the outbreak of brucellosis\nwas mistaken for foot-and-mouth disease [FMD].\n\nThe Ministry of Livestock, Agriculture, and Fisheries of Uruguay\nconfirmed today [7 Oct 2008] that the focus of infection detected in\nthe northwest of the country, near the border with Brazil, is\nbrucellosis and not foot-and-mouth disease as some official media reported.\n\nMinister of Livestock, Ernesto Agazzi, said it will open an\ninvestigation into the release issued Monday [6 Oct 2008] by the\nveterinary authorities of his ministry in which he warned that there\ncould be an outbreak of FMD in the cattle population of Colonia de\nPalma. This was denied later, after the relevant health analyses were received.\n\nFor his part, the director of Livestock Services, Francisco Muzio,\nsaid that dissemination of this statement was \"irresponsible\" and\ncould have caused much harm to the export of Uruguayan beef.\n\nAccording to the Ministry of Livestock the outbreak of brucellosis in\nthat locality of the Department of Artigas, located 40 kilometers (25\nmi) from the border with Brazil had been reported days ago and\n[measures were being taken to control it].\n\nCurrently, Uruguay is free from foot-and-mouth disease and statement\nof an outbreak of the disease would impact very negatively on the\nsales of beef abroad, one of the major items of export from this country.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Brucellosis is an infectious disease of many ruminant species and of\nswine. In ruminants, abortion is the most obvious manifestation.\nInfections may also cause stillborn or weak calves, retained\nplacentas, and reduced milk yield. Usually, general health is not\nimpaired in uncomplicated abortions.\n\nSeminal vesicles, ampullae, testicles, and epididymides may be\ninfected in bulls; therefore, organisms are present in the semen.\nAgglutinins may be demonstrated in seminal plasma from infected\nbulls. Testicular abscesses may occur. Longstanding infections may\nresult in arthritic joints in some cattle.\n\nGiven these as the most prominent clinical signs in cattle, it seems\na bit of a stretch to believe this was foot-and-mouth disease, whose\nmost prominent clinical include fever, sore feet, excessive\nsalivation, and vesicles in the mucous membrane areas to the point of\nsloughing the epithelium on the tongue.\n\nAnnouncements regarding an incorrect diagnosis or an unverified\ndiagnosis can cause much harm to the country's economy. We hope\nUruguay can resolve the issue quickly.\n\nPortions of this comment were extracted from\n<http://www.merckvetmanual.com/mvm/index.jsp?cfile=htm/bc/110502.htm&word=brucellosis>.\n- Mod.TG\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Uruguay is available at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed?g=3443756&v=-32.8,-56,6>. - For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["brucellosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-08 00:00:00", "2021-03-07 00:00:00", "2021-03-06 00:00:00", "2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Greece", "country": "Greece"}, {"location": "Saudi Arabia", "country": "Saudi Arabia"}, {"location": "Kyrgyzstan", "country": "Kyrgyzstan"}, {"location": "Jalalabad", "country": "Afghanistan"}, {"location": "Campania", "country": "Italy"}, {"location": "Kavala", "country": "Greece"}, {"location": "Uruguay", "country": "Uruguay"}, {"location": "WY", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Volgograd", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Jordan", "country": "Jordan"}, {"location": "Italy", "country": "Italy"}, {"location": "Azerbaijan", "country": "Azerbaijan"}, {"location": "Brazil", "country": "Brazil"}, {"location": "Moscow", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "145370", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Brucellosis - Kyrgyzstan (02): (NA)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=145370", "date": "2008-10-10 10:00:33", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS, BOVINE - URUGUAY: (ARTIGAS)\n****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 7 Oct 2008\nSource: Diario Metro, EFE News Agency report [in Spanish, trans.\nMod.MPP/CopyEd.MJ, edited]\n<http://www.diariometro.es/es/article/efe/2008/10/07/695172/index.xml>\n\n\nThe Uruguayan government confirmed that the outbreak of brucellosis\nwas mistaken for foot-and-mouth disease [FMD].\n\nThe Ministry of Livestock, Agriculture, and Fisheries of Uruguay\nconfirmed today [7 Oct 2008] that the focus of infection detected in\nthe northwest of the country, near the border with Brazil, is\nbrucellosis and not foot-and-mouth disease as some official media reported.\n\nMinister of Livestock, Ernesto Agazzi, said it will open an\ninvestigation into the release issued Monday [6 Oct 2008] by the\nveterinary authorities of his ministry in which he warned that there\ncould be an outbreak of FMD in the cattle population of Colonia de\nPalma. This was denied later, after the relevant health analyses were received.\n\nFor his part, the director of Livestock Services, Francisco Muzio,\nsaid that dissemination of this statement was \"irresponsible\" and\ncould have caused much harm to the export of Uruguayan beef.\n\nAccording to the Ministry of Livestock the outbreak of brucellosis in\nthat locality of the Department of Artigas, located 40 kilometers (25\nmi) from the border with Brazil had been reported days ago and\n[measures were being taken to control it].\n\nCurrently, Uruguay is free from foot-and-mouth disease and statement\nof an outbreak of the disease would impact very negatively on the\nsales of beef abroad, one of the major items of export from this country.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Brucellosis is an infectious disease of many ruminant species and of\nswine. In ruminants, abortion is the most obvious manifestation.\nInfections may also cause stillborn or weak calves, retained\nplacentas, and reduced milk yield. Usually, general health is not\nimpaired in uncomplicated abortions.\n\nSeminal vesicles, ampullae, testicles, and epididymides may be\ninfected in bulls; therefore, organisms are present in the semen.\nAgglutinins may be demonstrated in seminal plasma from infected\nbulls. Testicular abscesses may occur. Longstanding infections may\nresult in arthritic joints in some cattle.\n\nGiven these as the most prominent clinical signs in cattle, it seems\na bit of a stretch to believe this was foot-and-mouth disease, whose\nmost prominent clinical include fever, sore feet, excessive\nsalivation, and vesicles in the mucous membrane areas to the point of\nsloughing the epithelium on the tongue.\n\nAnnouncements regarding an incorrect diagnosis or an unverified\ndiagnosis can cause much harm to the country's economy. We hope\nUruguay can resolve the issue quickly.\n\nPortions of this comment were extracted from\n<http://www.merckvetmanual.com/mvm/index.jsp?cfile=htm/bc/110502.htm&word=brucellosis>.\n- Mod.TG\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Uruguay is available at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed?g=3443756&v=-32.8,-56,6>. - This was denied later, after the relevant health analyses were received.\n\nFor his part, the director of Livestock Services, Francisco Muzio,\nsaid that dissemination of this statement was \"irresponsible\" and\ncould have caused much harm to the export of Uruguayan beef.\n\nAccording to the Ministry of Livestock the outbreak of brucellosis in\nthat locality of the Department of Artigas, located 40 kilometers (25\nmi) from the border with Brazil had been reported days ago and\n[measures were being taken to control it].\n\nCurrently, Uruguay is free from foot-and-mouth disease and statement\nof an outbreak of the disease would impact very negatively on the\nsales of beef abroad, one of the major items of export from this country.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Brucellosis is an infectious disease of many ruminant species and of\nswine. In ruminants, abortion is the most obvious manifestation.\nInfections may also cause stillborn or weak calves, retained\nplacentas, and reduced milk yield. Usually, general health is not\nimpaired in uncomplicated abortions.\n\nSeminal vesicles, ampullae, testicles, and epididymides may be\ninfected in bulls; therefore, organisms are present in the semen.\nAgglutinins may be demonstrated in seminal plasma from infected\nbulls. Testicular abscesses may occur. Longstanding infections may\nresult in arthritic joints in some cattle.\n\nGiven these as the most prominent clinical signs in cattle, it seems\na bit of a stretch to believe this was foot-and-mouth disease, whose\nmost prominent clinical include fever, sore feet, excessive\nsalivation, and vesicles in the mucous membrane areas to the point of\nsloughing the epithelium on the tongue.\n\nAnnouncements regarding an incorrect diagnosis or an unverified\ndiagnosis can cause much harm to the country's economy. This was denied later, after the relevant health analyses were received.\n\nFor his part, the director of Livestock Services, Francisco Muzio,\nsaid that dissemination of this statement was \"irresponsible\" and\ncould have caused much harm to the export of Uruguayan beef.\n\nAccording to the Ministry of Livestock the outbreak of brucellosis in\nthat locality of the Department of Artigas, located 40 kilometers (25\nmi) from the border with Brazil had been reported days ago and\n[measures were being taken to control it].\n\nCurrently, Uruguay is free from foot-and-mouth disease and statement\nof an outbreak of the disease would impact very negatively on the\nsales of beef abroad, one of the major items of export from this country.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Brucellosis is an infectious disease of many ruminant species and of\nswine. In ruminants, abortion is the most obvious manifestation.\nInfections may also cause stillborn or weak calves, retained\nplacentas, and reduced milk yield. Usually, general health is not\nimpaired in uncomplicated abortions.\n\nSeminal vesicles, ampullae, testicles, and epididymides may be\ninfected in bulls; therefore, organisms are present in the semen.\nAgglutinins may be demonstrated in seminal plasma from infected\nbulls. Testicular abscesses may occur. Longstanding infections may\nresult in arthritic joints in some cattle.\n\nGiven these as the most prominent clinical signs in cattle, it seems\na bit of a stretch to believe this was foot-and-mouth disease, whose\nmost prominent clinical include fever, sore feet, excessive\nsalivation, and vesicles in the mucous membrane areas to the point of\nsloughing the epithelium on the tongue.\n\nAnnouncements regarding an incorrect diagnosis or an unverified\ndiagnosis can cause much harm to the country's economy. We hope\nUruguay can resolve the issue quickly.\n\nPortions of this comment were extracted from\n<http://www.merckvetmanual.com/mvm/index.jsp?cfile=htm/bc/110502.htm&word=brucellosis>.\n- Mod.TG\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Uruguay is available at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed?g=3443756&v=-32.8,-56,6>. - Romania: OIE", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=118656", "date": "2008-10-10 10:00:33", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS, BOVINE - URUGUAY: (ARTIGAS)\n****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 7 Oct 2008\nSource: Diario Metro, EFE News Agency report [in Spanish, trans.\nMod.MPP/CopyEd.MJ, edited]\n<http://www.diariometro.es/es/article/efe/2008/10/07/695172/index.xml>\n\n\nThe Uruguayan government confirmed that the outbreak of brucellosis\nwas mistaken for foot-and-mouth disease [FMD].\n\nThe Ministry of Livestock, Agriculture, and Fisheries of Uruguay\nconfirmed today [7 Oct 2008] that the focus of infection detected in\nthe northwest of the country, near the border with Brazil, is\nbrucellosis and not foot-and-mouth disease as some official media reported.\n\nMinister of Livestock, Ernesto Agazzi, said it will open an\ninvestigation into the release issued Monday [6 Oct 2008] by the\nveterinary authorities of his ministry in which he warned that there\ncould be an outbreak of FMD in the cattle population of Colonia de\nPalma. This was denied later, after the relevant health analyses were received.\n\nFor his part, the director of Livestock Services, Francisco Muzio,\nsaid that dissemination of this statement was \"irresponsible\" and\ncould have caused much harm to the export of Uruguayan beef.\n\nAccording to the Ministry of Livestock the outbreak of brucellosis in\nthat locality of the Department of Artigas, located 40 kilometers (25\nmi) from the border with Brazil had been reported days ago and\n[measures were being taken to control it].\n\nCurrently, Uruguay is free from foot-and-mouth disease and statement\nof an outbreak of the disease would impact very negatively on the\nsales of beef abroad, one of the major items of export from this country.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Brucellosis is an infectious disease of many ruminant species and of\nswine. In ruminants, abortion is the most obvious manifestation.\nInfections may also cause stillborn or weak calves, retained\nplacentas, and reduced milk yield. Usually, general health is not\nimpaired in uncomplicated abortions.\n\nSeminal vesicles, ampullae, testicles, and epididymides may be\ninfected in bulls; therefore, organisms are present in the semen.\nAgglutinins may be demonstrated in seminal plasma from infected\nbulls. Testicular abscesses may occur. Longstanding infections may\nresult in arthritic joints in some cattle.\n\nGiven these as the most prominent clinical signs in cattle, it seems\na bit of a stretch to believe this was foot-and-mouth disease, whose\nmost prominent clinical include fever, sore feet, excessive\nsalivation, and vesicles in the mucous membrane areas to the point of\nsloughing the epithelium on the tongue.\n\nAnnouncements regarding an incorrect diagnosis or an unverified\ndiagnosis can cause much harm to the country's economy. We hope\nUruguay can resolve the issue quickly.\n\nPortions of this comment were extracted from\n<http://www.merckvetmanual.com/mvm/index.jsp?cfile=htm/bc/110502.htm&word=brucellosis>.\n- Mod.TG\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Uruguay is available at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed?g=3443756&v=-32.8,-56,6>. - This was denied later, after the relevant health analyses were received.\n\nFor his part, the director of Livestock Services, Francisco Muzio,\nsaid that dissemination of this statement was \"irresponsible\" and\ncould have caused much harm to the export of Uruguayan beef.\n\nAccording to the Ministry of Livestock the outbreak of brucellosis in\nthat locality of the Department of Artigas, located 40 kilometers (25\nmi) from the border with Brazil had been reported days ago and\n[measures were being taken to control it].\n\nCurrently, Uruguay is free from foot-and-mouth disease and statement\nof an outbreak of the disease would impact very negatively on the\nsales of beef abroad, one of the major items of export from this country.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[Brucellosis is an infectious disease of many ruminant species and of\nswine. In ruminants, abortion is the most obvious manifestation.\nInfections may also cause stillborn or weak calves, retained\nplacentas, and reduced milk yield. Usually, general health is not\nimpaired in uncomplicated abortions.\n\nSeminal vesicles, ampullae, testicles, and epididymides may be\ninfected in bulls; therefore, organisms are present in the semen.\nAgglutinins may be demonstrated in seminal plasma from infected\nbulls. Testicular abscesses may occur. Longstanding infections may\nresult in arthritic joints in some cattle.\n\nGiven these as the most prominent clinical signs in cattle, it seems\na bit of a stretch to believe this was foot-and-mouth disease, whose\nmost prominent clinical include fever, sore feet, excessive\nsalivation, and vesicles in the mucous membrane areas to the point of\nsloughing the epithelium on the tongue.\n\nAnnouncements regarding an incorrect diagnosis or an unverified\ndiagnosis can cause much harm to the country's economy. We hope\nUruguay can resolve the issue quickly.\n\nPortions of this comment were extracted from\n<http://www.merckvetmanual.com/mvm/index.jsp?cfile=htm/bc/110502.htm&word=brucellosis>.\n- Mod.TG\n\nThe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map of Uruguay is available at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed?g=3443756&v=-32.8,-56,6>. - Germany: (MV), serovar 2", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=113657", "date": "2008-07-26 09:00:28", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS, BOVINE - USA (05): (WYOMING)\n*****************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Thu 24 Jul 2008\nSource: Montana's News Station, Associated Press (AP) report [edited]\n<http://www.montanasnewsstation.com/global/story.asp?s=8733045>\n\n\nTests show 7 more infected cows in Wyoming herd\n-----------------------------------------------\nWyoming's state veterinarian, Walt Cook, says 7 more cows have tested\npositive for brucellosis in a western Wyoming cattle herd infected\nwith the livestock disease.\n\nToday's [24 Jul 2008] results bring the total number of\nbrucellosis-infected cattle in the herd to 36. So far, the 650-head\nherd near Daniel is the only herd in Wyoming to test positive for the\nbacterial infection.\n\nWyoming and federal livestock officials are testing 14 other cattle\nherds that had contact with the infected herd. Of the 2 contact herds\ntested so far, both turned up negative.\n\nThe state will lose its federal brucellosis-free status if another\nherd tests positive for brucellosis within 2 years.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[These animals may have been associated with some of the residual\nbrucellosis that seems to plague the greater Yellowstone area (GYA).\nMany plans have been made and examined for methods of dealing with\nthe disease and the animals affected. One of the latest is a split\nstate status, carving out the GYA as an affected area while the rest\nof the state maintains its free-state status. - Mod.TG\n\nThe state of Wyoming, in the western United States, can be located on\nthe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed?v=40,-97.6,4>.\nThe Greater Yellowstone Area includes Montana, Wyoming, and Idaho; it\ncan be seen on the map at\n<http://gorp.away.com/gifs/states/wy/m_gryel2.gif>. - CopyEd.MJ\n\nFor a detailed description of the disease and its impact on the cattle\nindustry, see ProMED archive Brucellosis, bovine - USA (MT)(02)\n20070611.1908.\n- Mod.JW]\nSee Also\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA (04): (WY) 20080626.1966\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA (03): (WY) 20080619.1907\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA (02): (MT) 20080611.1841\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA (TX): not 20080202.0427\n2007\n----\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA (MT)(04) 20070719.2311\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA (MT) (03) 20070709.2176\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA (MT)(02) 20070611.1908\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA (MT) 20070522.1632\n2006\n----\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA (ID) (03) 20060101.0006\n2005\n----\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA (ID)(02): correction 20051229.3706\n2004\n----\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA (WY) (02) 20040725.2035\nBrucellosis, bison vaccination - USA (WY) 20040327.0847\n........................................tg/mj/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. So far, the 650-head\nherd near Daniel is the only herd in Wyoming to test positive for the\nbacterial infection.\n\nWyoming and federal livestock officials are testing 14 other cattle\nherds that had contact with the infected herd. Of the 2 contact herds\ntested so far, both turned up negative.\n\nThe state will lose its federal brucellosis-free status if another\nherd tests positive for brucellosis within 2 years.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[These animals may have been associated with some of the residual\nbrucellosis that seems to plague the greater Yellowstone area (GYA).\nMany plans have been made and examined for methods of dealing with\nthe disease and the animals affected. One of the latest is a split\nstate status, carving out the GYA as an affected area while the rest\nof the state maintains its free-state status. - Mod.TG\n\nThe state of Wyoming, in the western United States, can be located on\nthe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed?v=40,-97.6,4>.\nThe Greater Yellowstone Area includes Montana, Wyoming, and Idaho; it\ncan be seen on the map at\n<http://gorp.away.com/gifs/states/wy/m_gryel2.gif>. - CopyEd.MJ\n\nFor a detailed description of the disease and its impact on the cattle\nindustry, see ProMED archive Brucellosis, bovine - USA (MT)(02)\n20070611.1908.\n- Mod.JW]\nSee Also\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA (04): (WY) 20080626.1966\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA (03): (WY) 20080619.1907\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA (02): (MT) 20080611.1841\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA (TX): not 20080202.0427\n2007\n----\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA (MT)(04) 20070719.2311\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA (MT) (03) 20070709.2176\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA (MT)(02) 20070611.1908\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA (MT) 20070522.1632\n2006\n----\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA (ID) (03) 20060101.0006\n2005\n----\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA (ID)(02): correction 20051229.3706\n2004\n----\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA (WY) (02) 20040725.2035\nBrucellosis, bison vaccination - USA (WY) 20040327.0847\n........................................tg/mj/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. So far, the 650-head\nherd near Daniel is the only herd in Wyoming to test positive for the\nbacterial infection.\n\nWyoming and federal livestock officials are testing 14 other cattle\nherds that had contact with the infected herd. Of the 2 contact herds\ntested so far, both turned up negative.\n\nThe state will lose its federal brucellosis-free status if another\nherd tests positive for brucellosis within 2 years.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[These animals may have been associated with some of the residual\nbrucellosis that seems to plague the greater Yellowstone area (GYA).\nMany plans have been made and examined for methods of dealing with\nthe disease and the animals affected. So far, the 650-head\nherd near Daniel is the only herd in Wyoming to test positive for the\nbacterial infection.\n\nWyoming and federal livestock officials are testing 14 other cattle\nherds that had contact with the infected herd. Of the 2 contact herds\ntested so far, both turned up negative.\n\nThe state will lose its federal brucellosis-free status if another\nherd tests positive for brucellosis within 2 years.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[These animals may have been associated with some of the residual\nbrucellosis that seems to plague the greater Yellowstone area (GYA).\nMany plans have been made and examined for methods of dealing with\nthe disease and the animals affected. One of the latest is a split\nstate status, carving out the GYA as an affected area while the rest\nof the state maintains its free-state status. - Mod.TG\n\nThe state of Wyoming, in the western United States, can be located on\nthe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed?v=40,-97.6,4>.\nThe Greater Yellowstone Area includes Montana, Wyoming, and Idaho; it\ncan be seen on the map at\n<http://gorp.away.com/gifs/states/wy/m_gryel2.gif>. - CopyEd.MJ\n\nFor a detailed description of the disease and its impact on the cattle\nindustry, see ProMED archive Brucellosis, bovine - USA (MT)(02)\n20070611.1908.\n- Mod.JW]\nSee Also\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA (04): (WY) 20080626.1966\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA (03): (WY) 20080619.1907\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA (02): (MT) 20080611.1841\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA (TX): not 20080202.0427\n2007\n----\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA (MT)(04) 20070719.2311\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA (MT) (03) 20070709.2176\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA (MT)(02) 20070611.1908\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA (MT) 20070522.1632\n2006\n----\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA (ID) (03) 20060101.0006\n2005\n----\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA (ID)(02): correction 20051229.3706\n2004\n----\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA (WY) (02) 20040725.2035\nBrucellosis, bison vaccination - USA (WY) 20040327.0847\n........................................tg/mj/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. So far, the 650-head\nherd near Daniel is the only herd in Wyoming to test positive for the\nbacterial infection.\n\nWyoming and federal livestock officials are testing 14 other cattle\nherds that had contact with the infected herd. Of the 2 contact herds\ntested so far, both turned up negative.\n\nThe state will lose its federal brucellosis-free status if another\nherd tests positive for brucellosis within 2 years.\n\n--\nCommunicated by:\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n\n[These animals may have been associated with some of the residual\nbrucellosis that seems to plague the greater Yellowstone area (GYA).\nMany plans have been made and examined for methods of dealing with\nthe disease and the animals affected. One of the latest is a split\nstate status, carving out the GYA as an affected area while the rest\nof the state maintains its free-state status. - Mod.TG\n\nThe state of Wyoming, in the western United States, can be located on\nthe HealthMap/ProMED-mail interactive map at\n<http://healthmap.org/promed?v=40,-97.6,4>.\nThe Greater Yellowstone Area includes Montana, Wyoming, and Idaho; it\ncan be seen on the map at\n<http://gorp.away.com/gifs/states/wy/m_gryel2.gif>. - CopyEd.MJ\n\nFor a detailed description of the disease and its impact on the cattle\nindustry, see ProMED archive Brucellosis, bovine - USA (MT)(02)\n20070611.1908.\n- Mod.JW]\nSee Also\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA (04): (WY) 20080626.1966\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA (03): (WY) 20080619.1907\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA (02): (MT) 20080611.1841\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA (TX): not 20080202.0427\n2007\n----\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA (MT)(04) 20070719.2311\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA (MT) (03) 20070709.2176\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA (MT)(02) 20070611.1908\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA (MT) 20070522.1632\n2006\n----\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA (ID) (03) 20060101.0006\n2005\n----\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA (ID)(02): correction 20051229.3706\n2004\n----\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA (WY) (02) 20040725.2035\nBrucellosis, bison vaccination - USA (WY) 20040327.0847\n........................................tg/mj/jw\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "brucellosis", "plague"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-05 00:00:00", "2021-03-04 00:00:00", "2021-03-03 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2007-03-15 00:00:00", "2006-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Daniel", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Idaho", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "WY", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "MT", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Montana", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "United States", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wyoming", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "90607", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Brucellosis, bovine - USA (04): (WY)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=90607", "date": "2008-03-18 14:00:18", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS, OVINE - RUSSIA (MOSCOW EX VOLGOGRAD) (02)\n*****************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nDate: Tue 18 Mar 2008\nFrom: Tom Kelly\n<katjak@eircom.net>\n\n\nre: Brucellosis, ovine - Russia (Moscow ex Volgograd)\n-----------------------------------------------------\nJust perhaps, if those sheep, or the affected ones, or a majority or\nsignificant number of the affected ones were rams, they may have been\nobserved swaggering about in a strange, cowboy-like fashion, and with very\ngood reason, too, poor creatures!\n\n\"Both sheep and goats may show signs of lameness, hygroma, and cough but\nthe predilection sites of B. melitensis are the uterus, udder and the\nmammary lymph nodes in females and the testicles in males. Strangely\nenough, interference with fertility caused by orchitis seems to be limited.\nInfected sheep and goats may excrete Brucella in the milk for years but\nsheep may also cease excretion during one or more lactation periods.\"\n(Alton, 1985; Stableforth and Galloway, 1959).\n\n--\nTom Kelly, MVB\nDonegal, Ireland\n<katjak@eirco,.net>\n\n[Tom Kelly's observation is appreciated; indeed, orchitis is a\nmanifestation of _B. melitensis_ infection in rams (and he-goats). It\nremains to be informed which \"strange behavior\" was seen in the sheep on\nthe affected farm and whether the 100-strong consignment of sheep,\nreportedly (illegally) transported from Volgograd to the Moscow region,\nconsisted of males.\n\nIn female sheep, reproductive signs, namely abortion (usually in late\npregnancy), weak newborns, stillbirth, or retained placentae are the main\n(and in most cases only) clinical expressions of _B. melitensis_ infection;\nacute mastitis with palpable nodules may also sometimes occur, with clotted\nand watery secretion. Cases may remain subclinical.\n\nIn rather exceptional cases, general signs (lameness or stiffness, limping)\nand respiratory signs (coughing) may be seen. - Mod.AS]\n\nFurther reading:\n1. Grant Maxie, editor. Female genital system. Jubb, Kennedy and Palmer's\nPathology of Domestic Animals, 5th edition, Vol 3. Saunders/Elsevier, 2007;\npage 488.\n2. Brucellosis ovine/caprine: FAO Animal Health Disease Cards (70\nreferences), available online at\n<http://www.fao.org/ag/againfo/subjects/en/health/diseases-cards/brucellosi-ov.html>.\n\n3. Ovine and caprine brucellosis: Brucella melitensis. CFSPH/Iowa State\nUniversity/OIE collaborating center. Animal Disease Fact Sheets, updated\nJune 2007 (19 references, 8 internet resources)\n<http://www.cfsph.iastate.edu/DiseaseInfo/factsheets.htm>\nSee Also\nBrucellosis, ovine - Russia (Moscow ex Volgograd) 20080317.1043\n\n...............arn/ejp/sh\n\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Strangely\nenough, interference with fertility caused by orchitis seems to be limited.\nInfected sheep and goats may excrete Brucella in the milk for years but\nsheep may also cease excretion during one or more lactation periods.\"\n(Alton, 1985; Stableforth and Galloway, 1959).\n\n--\nTom Kelly, MVB\nDonegal, Ireland\n<katjak@eirco,.net>\n\n[Tom Kelly's observation is appreciated; indeed, orchitis is a\nmanifestation of _B. melitensis_ infection in rams (and he-goats). It\nremains to be informed which \"strange behavior\" was seen in the sheep on\nthe affected farm and whether the 100-strong consignment of sheep,\nreportedly (illegally) transported from Volgograd to the Moscow region,\nconsisted of males.\n\nIn female sheep, reproductive signs, namely abortion (usually in late\npregnancy), weak newborns, stillbirth, or retained placentae are the main\n(and in most cases only) clinical expressions of _B. melitensis_ infection;\nacute mastitis with palpable nodules may also sometimes occur, with clotted\nand watery secretion. Cases may remain subclinical.\n\nIn rather exceptional cases, general signs (lameness or stiffness, limping)\nand respiratory signs (coughing) may be seen. - Mod.AS]\n\nFurther reading:\n1. Grant Maxie, editor. Female genital system. Jubb, Kennedy and Palmer's\nPathology of Domestic Animals, 5th edition, Vol 3. Saunders/Elsevier, 2007;\npage 488.\n2. Brucellosis ovine/caprine: FAO Animal Health Disease Cards (70\nreferences), available online at\n<http://www.fao.org/ag/againfo/subjects/en/health/diseases-cards/brucellosi-ov.html>.\n\n3. Ovine and caprine brucellosis: Brucella melitensis. CFSPH/Iowa State\nUniversity/OIE collaborating center. Animal Disease Fact Sheets, updated\nJune 2007 (19 references, 8 internet resources)\n<http://www.cfsph.iastate.edu/DiseaseInfo/factsheets.htm>\nSee Also\nBrucellosis, ovine - Russia (Moscow ex Volgograd) 20080317.1043\n\n...............arn/ejp/sh\n\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Strangely\nenough, interference with fertility caused by orchitis seems to be limited.\nInfected sheep and goats may excrete Brucella in the milk for years but\nsheep may also cease excretion during one or more lactation periods.\"\n(Alton, 1985; Stableforth and Galloway, 1959).\n\n--\nTom Kelly, MVB\nDonegal, Ireland\n<katjak@eirco,.net>\n\n[Tom Kelly's observation is appreciated; indeed, orchitis is a\nmanifestation of _B. melitensis_ infection in rams (and he-goats). It\nremains to be informed which \"strange behavior\" was seen in the sheep on\nthe affected farm and whether the 100-strong consignment of sheep,\nreportedly (illegally) transported from Volgograd to the Moscow region,\nconsisted of males.\n\nIn female sheep, reproductive signs, namely abortion (usually in late\npregnancy), weak newborns, stillbirth, or retained placentae are the main\n(and in most cases only) clinical expressions of _B. melitensis_ infection;\nacute mastitis with palpable nodules may also sometimes occur, with clotted\nand watery secretion. See graph\n<http://exhibit.gideononline.com/Brucella-Georgia.jpg>\n--\nCommunicated by:\nDr. Steve Berger\nTel Aviv Medical Center, Israel\n<mberger@post.tau.ac.il>\n\n[This moderator apologizes for the delay in posting of this\ninformation. ProMED-mail, once again, thanks Dr. Berger for his\ncontinuing contributions.\nIf the reader cannot access the graph, the following is approximated from it:\nRates (Rate is cases of brucellosis per 100 000 population)\nYear/ Georgia / Turkey / Armenia / Azerbaijan\n1986 / 4.0 / 3.0 / NA / 2.0\n1988 / 4.0 / 4.2 / NA / 2.0\n1990 / 3.0 / 9.0 / NA / 4.0\n1992 / 3.0 / 10.5 / NA / 7.0\n1994 / 2.5 / 14.0 / 10.0 / 15.0\n1996 / 2.0 / 10.0 / 7.0 / 15.0\n1998 / 1.5 / 19.0 / 3.0 / 7.0\n2000 / 1.5 / 16.5 / 3.5 / 8.0\n2002 / 3.0 / 26.5 / 3.0 / 7.0\n2004 / 3.0 / 27.0 / NA / 6.5\n2006 / NA / 15.5 / NA / 5.5\n- Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nBrucellosis, bovine, human - Georgia (Lagodechi) 20070920.3121\nBrucellosis, human, animals - Bulgaria (Haskovo) (03) 20070916.3075\nBrucellosis, human, animals - Bulgaria (Haskovo) 20070821.2736\n2005\n----\nBrucellosis, human - Bulgaria ex Greece 20050328.0896\n........................................ll/mj/jw\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["brucellosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-02 00:00:00", "1986-03-15 00:00:00", "1998-03-15 00:00:00", "2006-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Greece", "country": "Greece"}, {"location": "Year/", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Georgia", "country": "Georgia"}, {"location": "Bulgaria", "country": "Bulgaria"}, {"location": "Lagodechi", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Israel", "country": "Israel"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "28104", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Brucellosis, bovine, human - Georgia (Lagodechi)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=28104", "date": "2007-07-06 11:00:03", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS, Q FEVER, LAB WORKERS - USA (TEXAS)\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Tue 3 Jul 2007\nSource: Center for Infectious Disease Research & Policy (CIDRAP) News [edited]\n<http://www.cidrap.umn.edu/cidrap/content/bt/bioprep/news/jul0307bioweapons.html>\n\nThe CDC (US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention) on 30 Jun\n2007, ordered a biodefense research laboratory at Texas A&M\nUniversity to stop all work on select agents and toxins while it\ninvestigates reports of lab workers infected with the category B\nbioterror agents _Brucella_ and _Coxiella burnetii_.\nThe Sunshine Project, an Austin, Texas, nonprofit group that monitors\nbiodefense research safety, recently reported the alleged lab\naccidents, along with related alleged violations of federal law. The\ngroup used Texas freedom-of-information requests to obtain documents\nabout the lab incidents.\nIn April 2007, the Sunshine Project reported that a Texas A&M\nresearcher had been infected with _Brucella_ after a February 2006\naerosol chamber mishap and that the school did not immediately notify\nthe CDC as required by federal law.\n[On 26 Jun 2007], the watchdog group reported that the exposure of 3\nother Texas A&M workers to _C. burnetii_, which causes Q fever, was\nconfirmed in April 2006 but also was not reported to the CDC.\nThe Sunshine Project said its investigation of Texas A&M came about\nthrough its review of select-agent labs that are vying to host the\nfederal government's planned new national biodefense facility,\naccording to a 27 Jun 2007 report in the Dallas Morning News.\nThe laboratory is affiliated with the Foreign Animal and Zoonotic\nDisease Defense Center, a US Department of Homeland Security (DHS)\ncenter of excellence that focuses on the study of foot-and-mouth\ndisease, avian influenza, and Rift Valley fever, according to the\ncenter's website. The center is funded by a USD 18 million DHS grant,\naccording to an Associated Press report.\nAccording to the Sunshine Project, Texas A&M notified the CDC about\nthe case of brucellosis in April 2007, a year after the worker's\nillness was confirmed. Shortly after Texas A&M report,\nrepresentatives from the CDC's Select Agents and Toxins Division\ninspected the laboratory and, in a 30 Jun 2007 memo, obtained and\nreleased by the Sunshine Project, ordered the lab to stop its work on\nall select agents and toxins until further notice.\nVon Roebuck, a CDC spokesman, told CIDRAP News that the agency has\nnever issued such a broad suspension order to a lab before. He said\nthe 30 Jun 2007 order applies to every agent the lab works with. The\nlist of affected agents is not public information because of security\nconcerns, Roebuck said. In the letter, the CDC outlined the concerns\nit has about the lab, which include the adequacy of biosafety plans,\nsecurity of the facility from unauthorized visitors, occupational\nsafety protocols, authorization from the CDC to work with certain\nagents, and compliance with federal select agent regulations.\nRoebuck said CDC officials would visit the Texas laboratory again in\nthe next few weeks to gather more information about its procedures\nand protocols. \"Then the agency will move forward with any\nrecommendations to get them under compliance,\" he said.\nIn a statement sent to Texas A&M faculty and staff on Fri 29 Jun\n2007, the school's interim president, Eddie J. Davis, said the\nlaboratory incidents did not pose a threat to anyone on or off\ncampus, but conceded that the university should have reported the\nworker's brucellosis in a more timely manner. (The university\nprovided CIDRAP News with a copy of the statement.)\nDavis said none of the workers who were exposed to the Q fever agent\ngot sick and that Texas A&M was going beyond health monitoring\nstandards at other select-agent labs by monitoring workers' blood for\nthe organism. He said the University believed that the threshold for\nreporting worker exposure was a confirmed illness.\n\"We are unequivocally committed to taking all appropriate steps to\nensure we are in full compliance with all CDC and any other relevant\npolicies and regulations,\" he said.\n_Coxiella burnetii_ causes an influenza-like disease in humans that\nis rarely fatal, according to the CDC. However, it is highly\ninfectious when it becomes airborne and is inhaled by humans. The\nagent has previously been weaponized and is considered a potential\nterrorist threat.\nBrucellosis presents prolonged fever and a wide range of other\npossible manifestations, such as arthritis, hepatitis, and\nmeningitis. Symptoms can be prolonged, but the disease is rarely\nfatal. In livestock, brucellosis causes infertility and abortions. As\nbioterrorism agents, _Brucella_ strains are inexpensive to produce\nand disperse, according to an August 2005 article in the CDC journal\nEmerging Infectious Diseases (EID).\n[Byline: Lisa Schnirring]\n--\nContributed by:\nProMED Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n[Texas A&M (Agriculture and Mining) University is located in College\nStation, TX, which can be found near the state capital of Austin on a\nmap of the state at\n<http://biochemistry.tamu.edu/images/tour/txmap.gif>\nPress releases from the Sunshine Project regarding these episodes can\nbe found at\n<http://www.sunshine-project.org/publications/pr/pr120407.html> and\n<http://www.sunshine-project.org/publications/pr/pr260607.html>. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nQ fever - Australia (SA) 20070624.2038\n2006\n----\nQ fever - USA (IA, IL): RFI 20061130.3391\nBrucellosis, human - Kyrgyzstan (Osh) 20061120.3311\nBrucellosis, human, bovine - Kyrgyzstan (02): background 20060924.2725\nBrucellosis, human, bovine - Kyrgyzstan (Chuiskiy) 20060923.2715\nQ fever, meat processing plant - UK (Scotland) (02) 20060825.2394\nQ fever, meat processing plant - UK (Scotland) 20060721.2001\n2005\n----\nQ fever, calving - Australia (NSW) 20051103.3222\nQ fever, contaminated wool - Russia (Moscow) 20051025.3118\nBrucellosis, human - Czech Republic ex Turkey (02) 20051018.3039\nBrucellosis, human - Czech Republic ex Turkey 20051017.3030\nBrucellosis, human, bovine - Venezuela 20051007.2932\nBrucellosis, human, caprine - Thailand (Kanchanaburi) 20050907.2646\nBrucellosis, human - Russia (Dagestan) 20050826.2523\nQ fever - Israel 20050814.2378\nQ fever - USA (CO) 20050810.2329\nBrucellosis, human - Kyrgyzstan (Jelalabad) 20050712.1975\nQ fever, human - USA (TX) 20050701.1861\nBrucellosis, human - Bosnia & Herzegovina 20050614.1658\nBrucellosis, human - Bulgaria ex Greece 20050328.0896\n2004\n----\nQ fever, farmers - Australia (S. Australia) 20041214.3309\nQ fever - Bulgaria (Botevgrad) 20040829.2413\nBrucellosis, ovine, contaminated agar - USA: alert 20040820.2315\nBrucellosis, human & caprines - Saudi Arabia (Jizan) 20040716.1926\nBrucellosis, humans & caprines - Lebanon 20040715.1907\nQ fever - Bosnia & Herzegovina (Banja Luka) 20040513.1291\n2002\n----\nQ fever - UK (Wales) 20021027.5653\nQ fever - France (Chamonix) (02) 20020911.5283\nQ fever - France (Chamonix) 20020903.5224\nQ fever, human, sheep, vaccine - Germany (02) 20020629.4632\nQ fever, human, sheep, vaccine - Germany: RFI 20020626.4607\nQ fever - Bosnia & Herzegovina (Livno) 20020328.3832\n2001\n----\nQ fever - Germany (N.Rhine Westphalia) 20010723.1438\nQ fever - UK: background 20010702.1262\nQ fever goat, suspected human - USA (Wyoming) (02) 20010205.0234\nQ fever goat, suspected human - USA (Wyoming) 20010201.0221\nQ fever - Australia (Queensland) 20010129.0204\n...................................ll/mj/lm\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "brucellosis", "q fever", "rift valley fever", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2007-03-15 00:00:00", "2007-04-15 00:00:00", "2006-02-15 00:00:00", "2007-06-26 00:00:00", "2006-04-15 00:00:00", "2007-03-15 00:00:00", "2007-04-15 00:00:00", "2007-03-15 00:00:00", "2007-03-15 00:00:00", "2007-03-15 00:00:00", "2005-08-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2001-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Greece", "country": "Greece"}, {"location": "Turkey", "country": "Turkey"}, {"location": "TEXAS", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Kyrgyzstan", "country": "Kyrgyzstan"}, {"location": "Saudi Arabia", "country": "Saudi Arabia"}, {"location": "Wales", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "Lebanon", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Queensland", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "Texas", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Scotland", "country": "United Kingdom"}, {"location": "Thailand", "country": "Thailand"}, {"location": "Bulgaria", "country": "Bulgaria"}, {"location": "SA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wyoming", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Moscow", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Austin", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "27574", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Brucellosis, human, animals - Bulgaria (Haskovo)(03)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=27574", "date": "2007-07-06 11:00:03", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS, Q FEVER, LAB WORKERS - USA (TEXAS)\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Tue 3 Jul 2007\nSource: Center for Infectious Disease Research & Policy (CIDRAP) News [edited]\n<http://www.cidrap.umn.edu/cidrap/content/bt/bioprep/news/jul0307bioweapons.html>\n\nThe CDC (US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention) on 30 Jun\n2007, ordered a biodefense research laboratory at Texas A&M\nUniversity to stop all work on select agents and toxins while it\ninvestigates reports of lab workers infected with the category B\nbioterror agents _Brucella_ and _Coxiella burnetii_.\nThe Sunshine Project, an Austin, Texas, nonprofit group that monitors\nbiodefense research safety, recently reported the alleged lab\naccidents, along with related alleged violations of federal law. The\ngroup used Texas freedom-of-information requests to obtain documents\nabout the lab incidents.\nIn April 2007, the Sunshine Project reported that a Texas A&M\nresearcher had been infected with _Brucella_ after a February 2006\naerosol chamber mishap and that the school did not immediately notify\nthe CDC as required by federal law.\n[On 26 Jun 2007], the watchdog group reported that the exposure of 3\nother Texas A&M workers to _C. burnetii_, which causes Q fever, was\nconfirmed in April 2006 but also was not reported to the CDC.\nThe Sunshine Project said its investigation of Texas A&M came about\nthrough its review of select-agent labs that are vying to host the\nfederal government's planned new national biodefense facility,\naccording to a 27 Jun 2007 report in the Dallas Morning News.\nThe laboratory is affiliated with the Foreign Animal and Zoonotic\nDisease Defense Center, a US Department of Homeland Security (DHS)\ncenter of excellence that focuses on the study of foot-and-mouth\ndisease, avian influenza, and Rift Valley fever, according to the\ncenter's website. The center is funded by a USD 18 million DHS grant,\naccording to an Associated Press report.\nAccording to the Sunshine Project, Texas A&M notified the CDC about\nthe case of brucellosis in April 2007, a year after the worker's\nillness was confirmed. Shortly after Texas A&M report,\nrepresentatives from the CDC's Select Agents and Toxins Division\ninspected the laboratory and, in a 30 Jun 2007 memo, obtained and\nreleased by the Sunshine Project, ordered the lab to stop its work on\nall select agents and toxins until further notice.\nVon Roebuck, a CDC spokesman, told CIDRAP News that the agency has\nnever issued such a broad suspension order to a lab before. He said\nthe 30 Jun 2007 order applies to every agent the lab works with. The\nlist of affected agents is not public information because of security\nconcerns, Roebuck said. In the letter, the CDC outlined the concerns\nit has about the lab, which include the adequacy of biosafety plans,\nsecurity of the facility from unauthorized visitors, occupational\nsafety protocols, authorization from the CDC to work with certain\nagents, and compliance with federal select agent regulations.\nRoebuck said CDC officials would visit the Texas laboratory again in\nthe next few weeks to gather more information about its procedures\nand protocols. \"Then the agency will move forward with any\nrecommendations to get them under compliance,\" he said.\nIn a statement sent to Texas A&M faculty and staff on Fri 29 Jun\n2007, the school's interim president, Eddie J. Davis, said the\nlaboratory incidents did not pose a threat to anyone on or off\ncampus, but conceded that the university should have reported the\nworker's brucellosis in a more timely manner. (The university\nprovided CIDRAP News with a copy of the statement.)\nDavis said none of the workers who were exposed to the Q fever agent\ngot sick and that Texas A&M was going beyond health monitoring\nstandards at other select-agent labs by monitoring workers' blood for\nthe organism. He said the University believed that the threshold for\nreporting worker exposure was a confirmed illness.\n\"We are unequivocally committed to taking all appropriate steps to\nensure we are in full compliance with all CDC and any other relevant\npolicies and regulations,\" he said.\n_Coxiella burnetii_ causes an influenza-like disease in humans that\nis rarely fatal, according to the CDC. However, it is highly\ninfectious when it becomes airborne and is inhaled by humans. The\nagent has previously been weaponized and is considered a potential\nterrorist threat.\nBrucellosis presents prolonged fever and a wide range of other\npossible manifestations, such as arthritis, hepatitis, and\nmeningitis. Symptoms can be prolonged, but the disease is rarely\nfatal. In livestock, brucellosis causes infertility and abortions. As\nbioterrorism agents, _Brucella_ strains are inexpensive to produce\nand disperse, according to an August 2005 article in the CDC journal\nEmerging Infectious Diseases (EID).\n[Byline: Lisa Schnirring]\n--\nContributed by:\nProMED Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n[Texas A&M (Agriculture and Mining) University is located in College\nStation, TX, which can be found near the state capital of Austin on a\nmap of the state at\n<http://biochemistry.tamu.edu/images/tour/txmap.gif>\nPress releases from the Sunshine Project regarding these episodes can\nbe found at\n<http://www.sunshine-project.org/publications/pr/pr120407.html> and\n<http://www.sunshine-project.org/publications/pr/pr260607.html>. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nQ fever - Australia (SA) 20070624.2038\n2006\n----\nQ fever - USA (IA, IL): RFI 20061130.3391\nBrucellosis, human - Kyrgyzstan (Osh) 20061120.3311\nBrucellosis, human, bovine - Kyrgyzstan (02): background 20060924.2725\nBrucellosis, human, bovine - Kyrgyzstan (Chuiskiy) 20060923.2715\nQ fever, meat processing plant - UK (Scotland) (02) 20060825.2394\nQ fever, meat processing plant - UK (Scotland) 20060721.2001\n2005\n----\nQ fever, calving - Australia (NSW) 20051103.3222\nQ fever, contaminated wool - Russia (Moscow) 20051025.3118\nBrucellosis, human - Czech Republic ex Turkey (02) 20051018.3039\nBrucellosis, human - Czech Republic ex Turkey 20051017.3030\nBrucellosis, human, bovine - Venezuela 20051007.2932\nBrucellosis, human, caprine - Thailand (Kanchanaburi) 20050907.2646\nBrucellosis, human - Russia (Dagestan) 20050826.2523\nQ fever - Israel 20050814.2378\nQ fever - USA (CO) 20050810.2329\nBrucellosis, human - Kyrgyzstan (Jelalabad) 20050712.1975\nQ fever, human - USA (TX) 20050701.1861\nBrucellosis, human - Bosnia & Herzegovina 20050614.1658\nBrucellosis, human - Bulgaria ex Greece 20050328.0896\n2004\n----\nQ fever, farmers - Australia (S. The center is funded by a USD 18 million DHS grant,\naccording to an Associated Press report.\nAccording to the Sunshine Project, Texas A&M notified the CDC about\nthe case of brucellosis in April 2007, a year after the worker's\nillness was confirmed. Shortly after Texas A&M report,\nrepresentatives from the CDC's Select Agents and Toxins Division\ninspected the laboratory and, in a 30 Jun 2007 memo, obtained and\nreleased by the Sunshine Project, ordered the lab to stop its work on\nall select agents and toxins until further notice.\nVon Roebuck, a CDC spokesman, told CIDRAP News that the agency has\nnever issued such a broad suspension order to a lab before. In the letter, the CDC outlined the concerns\nit has about the lab, which include the adequacy of biosafety plans,\nsecurity of the facility from unauthorized visitors, occupational\nsafety protocols, authorization from the CDC to work with certain\nagents, and compliance with federal select agent regulations.\nRoebuck said CDC officials would visit the Texas laboratory again in\nthe next few weeks to gather more information about its procedures\nand protocols. \"Then the agency will move forward with any\nrecommendations to get them under compliance,\" he said.\nIn a statement sent to Texas A&M faculty and staff on Fri 29 Jun\n2007, the school's interim president, Eddie J. He said the University believed that the threshold for\nreporting worker exposure was a confirmed illness.\n\"We are unequivocally committed to taking all appropriate steps to\nensure we are in full compliance with all CDC and any other relevant\npolicies and regulations,\" he said.\n_Coxiella burnetii_ causes an influenza-like disease in humans that\nis rarely fatal, according to the CDC. However, it is highly\ninfectious when it becomes airborne and is inhaled by humans. The\nagent has previously been weaponized and is considered a potential\nterrorist threat.\nBrucellosis presents prolonged fever and a wide range of other\npossible manifestations, such as arthritis, hepatitis, and\nmeningitis. Symptoms can be prolonged, but the disease is rarely\nfatal. In livestock, brucellosis causes infertility and abortions. As\nbioterrorism agents, _Brucella_ strains are inexpensive to produce\nand disperse, according to an August 2005 article in the CDC journal\nEmerging Infectious Diseases (EID).\n[Byline: Lisa Schnirring]\n--\nContributed by:\nProMED Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n[Texas A&M (Agriculture and Mining) University is located in College\nStation, TX, which can be found near the state capital of Austin on a\nmap of the state at\n<http://biochemistry.tamu.edu/images/tour/txmap.gif>\nPress releases from the Sunshine Project regarding these episodes can\nbe found at\n<http://www.sunshine-project.org/publications/pr/pr120407.html> and\n<http://www.sunshine-project.org/publications/pr/pr260607.html>. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nQ fever - Australia (SA) 20070624.2038\n2006\n----\nQ fever - USA (IA, IL): RFI 20061130.3391\nBrucellosis, human - Kyrgyzstan (Osh) 20061120.3311\nBrucellosis, human, bovine - Kyrgyzstan (02): background 20060924.2725\nBrucellosis, human, bovine - Kyrgyzstan (Chuiskiy) 20060923.2715\nQ fever, meat processing plant - UK (Scotland) (02) 20060825.2394\nQ fever, meat processing plant - UK (Scotland) 20060721.2001\n2005\n----\nQ fever, calving - Australia (NSW) 20051103.3222\nQ fever, contaminated wool - Russia (Moscow) 20051025.3118\nBrucellosis, human - Czech Republic ex Turkey (02) 20051018.3039\nBrucellosis, human - Czech Republic ex Turkey 20051017.3030\nBrucellosis, human, bovine - Venezuela 20051007.2932\nBrucellosis, human, caprine - Thailand (Kanchanaburi) 20050907.2646\nBrucellosis, human - Russia (Dagestan) 20050826.2523\nQ fever - Israel 20050814.2378\nQ fever - USA (CO) 20050810.2329\nBrucellosis, human - Kyrgyzstan (Jelalabad) 20050712.1975\nQ fever, human - USA (TX) 20050701.1861\nBrucellosis, human - Bosnia & Herzegovina 20050614.1658\nBrucellosis, human - Bulgaria ex Greece 20050328.0896\n2004\n----\nQ fever, farmers - Australia (S. If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "brucellosis", "q fever", "rift valley fever", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2007-03-15 00:00:00", "2007-04-15 00:00:00", "2006-02-15 00:00:00", "2007-06-26 00:00:00", "2006-04-15 00:00:00", "2007-03-15 00:00:00", "2007-04-15 00:00:00", "2007-03-15 00:00:00", "2007-03-15 00:00:00", "2007-03-15 00:00:00", "2005-08-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2001-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Greece", "country": "Greece"}, {"location": "Turkey", "country": "Turkey"}, {"location": "TEXAS", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Kyrgyzstan", "country": "Kyrgyzstan"}, {"location": "Saudi Arabia", "country": "Saudi Arabia"}, {"location": "Wales", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "Lebanon", "country": "Lebanon"}, {"location": "Queensland", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "Texas", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Scotland", "country": "United Kingdom"}, {"location": "Thailand", "country": "Thailand"}, {"location": "Bulgaria", "country": "Bulgaria"}, {"location": "SA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wyoming", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Moscow", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Austin", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "23809", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Brucellosis, human, animals - Bulgaria (Haskovo)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=23809", "date": "2007-07-06 11:00:03", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS, Q FEVER, LAB WORKERS - USA (TEXAS)\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Tue 3 Jul 2007\nSource: Center for Infectious Disease Research & Policy (CIDRAP) News [edited]\n<http://www.cidrap.umn.edu/cidrap/content/bt/bioprep/news/jul0307bioweapons.html>\n\nThe CDC (US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention) on 30 Jun\n2007, ordered a biodefense research laboratory at Texas A&M\nUniversity to stop all work on select agents and toxins while it\ninvestigates reports of lab workers infected with the category B\nbioterror agents _Brucella_ and _Coxiella burnetii_.\nThe Sunshine Project, an Austin, Texas, nonprofit group that monitors\nbiodefense research safety, recently reported the alleged lab\naccidents, along with related alleged violations of federal law. The\ngroup used Texas freedom-of-information requests to obtain documents\nabout the lab incidents.\nIn April 2007, the Sunshine Project reported that a Texas A&M\nresearcher had been infected with _Brucella_ after a February 2006\naerosol chamber mishap and that the school did not immediately notify\nthe CDC as required by federal law.\n[On 26 Jun 2007], the watchdog group reported that the exposure of 3\nother Texas A&M workers to _C. burnetii_, which causes Q fever, was\nconfirmed in April 2006 but also was not reported to the CDC.\nThe Sunshine Project said its investigation of Texas A&M came about\nthrough its review of select-agent labs that are vying to host the\nfederal government's planned new national biodefense facility,\naccording to a 27 Jun 2007 report in the Dallas Morning News.\nThe laboratory is affiliated with the Foreign Animal and Zoonotic\nDisease Defense Center, a US Department of Homeland Security (DHS)\ncenter of excellence that focuses on the study of foot-and-mouth\ndisease, avian influenza, and Rift Valley fever, according to the\ncenter's website. The center is funded by a USD 18 million DHS grant,\naccording to an Associated Press report.\nAccording to the Sunshine Project, Texas A&M notified the CDC about\nthe case of brucellosis in April 2007, a year after the worker's\nillness was confirmed. Shortly after Texas A&M report,\nrepresentatives from the CDC's Select Agents and Toxins Division\ninspected the laboratory and, in a 30 Jun 2007 memo, obtained and\nreleased by the Sunshine Project, ordered the lab to stop its work on\nall select agents and toxins until further notice.\nVon Roebuck, a CDC spokesman, told CIDRAP News that the agency has\nnever issued such a broad suspension order to a lab before. He said\nthe 30 Jun 2007 order applies to every agent the lab works with. The\nlist of affected agents is not public information because of security\nconcerns, Roebuck said. In the letter, the CDC outlined the concerns\nit has about the lab, which include the adequacy of biosafety plans,\nsecurity of the facility from unauthorized visitors, occupational\nsafety protocols, authorization from the CDC to work with certain\nagents, and compliance with federal select agent regulations.\nRoebuck said CDC officials would visit the Texas laboratory again in\nthe next few weeks to gather more information about its procedures\nand protocols. \"Then the agency will move forward with any\nrecommendations to get them under compliance,\" he said.\nIn a statement sent to Texas A&M faculty and staff on Fri 29 Jun\n2007, the school's interim president, Eddie J. Davis, said the\nlaboratory incidents did not pose a threat to anyone on or off\ncampus, but conceded that the university should have reported the\nworker's brucellosis in a more timely manner. (The university\nprovided CIDRAP News with a copy of the statement.)\nDavis said none of the workers who were exposed to the Q fever agent\ngot sick and that Texas A&M was going beyond health monitoring\nstandards at other select-agent labs by monitoring workers' blood for\nthe organism. He said the University believed that the threshold for\nreporting worker exposure was a confirmed illness.\n\"We are unequivocally committed to taking all appropriate steps to\nensure we are in full compliance with all CDC and any other relevant\npolicies and regulations,\" he said.\n_Coxiella burnetii_ causes an influenza-like disease in humans that\nis rarely fatal, according to the CDC. However, it is highly\ninfectious when it becomes airborne and is inhaled by humans. The\nagent has previously been weaponized and is considered a potential\nterrorist threat.\nBrucellosis presents prolonged fever and a wide range of other\npossible manifestations, such as arthritis, hepatitis, and\nmeningitis. Symptoms can be prolonged, but the disease is rarely\nfatal. In livestock, brucellosis causes infertility and abortions. As\nbioterrorism agents, _Brucella_ strains are inexpensive to produce\nand disperse, according to an August 2005 article in the CDC journal\nEmerging Infectious Diseases (EID).\n[Byline: Lisa Schnirring]\n--\nContributed by:\nProMED Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n[Texas A&M (Agriculture and Mining) University is located in College\nStation, TX, which can be found near the state capital of Austin on a\nmap of the state at\n<http://biochemistry.tamu.edu/images/tour/txmap.gif>\nPress releases from the Sunshine Project regarding these episodes can\nbe found at\n<http://www.sunshine-project.org/publications/pr/pr120407.html> and\n<http://www.sunshine-project.org/publications/pr/pr260607.html>. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nQ fever - Australia (SA) 20070624.2038\n2006\n----\nQ fever - USA (IA, IL): RFI 20061130.3391\nBrucellosis, human - Kyrgyzstan (Osh) 20061120.3311\nBrucellosis, human, bovine - Kyrgyzstan (02): background 20060924.2725\nBrucellosis, human, bovine - Kyrgyzstan (Chuiskiy) 20060923.2715\nQ fever, meat processing plant - UK (Scotland) (02) 20060825.2394\nQ fever, meat processing plant - UK (Scotland) 20060721.2001\n2005\n----\nQ fever, calving - Australia (NSW) 20051103.3222\nQ fever, contaminated wool - Russia (Moscow) 20051025.3118\nBrucellosis, human - Czech Republic ex Turkey (02) 20051018.3039\nBrucellosis, human - Czech Republic ex Turkey 20051017.3030\nBrucellosis, human, bovine - Venezuela 20051007.2932\nBrucellosis, human, caprine - Thailand (Kanchanaburi) 20050907.2646\nBrucellosis, human - Russia (Dagestan) 20050826.2523\nQ fever - Israel 20050814.2378\nQ fever - USA (CO) 20050810.2329\nBrucellosis, human - Kyrgyzstan (Jelalabad) 20050712.1975\nQ fever, human - USA (TX) 20050701.1861\nBrucellosis, human - Bosnia & Herzegovina 20050614.1658\nBrucellosis, human - Bulgaria ex Greece 20050328.0896\n2004\n----\nQ fever, farmers - Australia (S.
