For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "brucellosis", "q fever", "rift valley fever", "meningitis"], "syndromes": ["meningitis"], "event_date": ["2007-03-15 00:00:00", "2007-04-15 00:00:00", "2006-02-15 00:00:00", "2007-06-26 00:00:00", "2006-04-15 00:00:00", "2007-03-15 00:00:00", "2007-04-15 00:00:00", "2007-03-15 00:00:00", "2007-03-15 00:00:00", "2007-03-15 00:00:00", "2005-08-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-02 00:00:00", "2001-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Greece", "country": "Greece"}, {"location": "Turkey", "country": "Turkey"}, {"location": "TEXAS", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Kyrgyzstan", "country": "Kyrgyzstan"}, {"location": "Saudi Arabia", "country": "Saudi Arabia"}, {"location": "Wales", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "Lebanon", "country": "Lebanon"}, {"location": "Queensland", "country": "Australia"}, {"location": "Texas", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Scotland", "country": "United Kingdom"}, {"location": "Thailand", "country": "Thailand"}, {"location": "Bulgaria", "country": "Bulgaria"}, {"location": "SA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Wyoming", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Moscow", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Austin", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "18209", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Brucellosis, bovine - USA (MT)(04)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=18209", "date": "2007-07-06 11:00:03", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS, Q FEVER, LAB WORKERS - USA (TEXAS)\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Tue 3 Jul 2007\nSource: Center for Infectious Disease Research & Policy (CIDRAP) News [edited]\n<http://www.cidrap.umn.edu/cidrap/content/bt/bioprep/news/jul0307bioweapons.html>\n\nThe CDC (US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention) on 30 Jun\n2007, ordered a biodefense research laboratory at Texas A&M\nUniversity to stop all work on select agents and toxins while it\ninvestigates reports of lab workers infected with the category B\nbioterror agents _Brucella_ and _Coxiella burnetii_.\nThe Sunshine Project, an Austin, Texas, nonprofit group that monitors\nbiodefense research safety, recently reported the alleged lab\naccidents, along with related alleged violations of federal law. The\ngroup used Texas freedom-of-information requests to obtain documents\nabout the lab incidents.\nIn April 2007, the Sunshine Project reported that a Texas A&M\nresearcher had been infected with _Brucella_ after a February 2006\naerosol chamber mishap and that the school did not immediately notify\nthe CDC as required by federal law.\n[On 26 Jun 2007], the watchdog group reported that the exposure of 3\nother Texas A&M workers to _C. burnetii_, which causes Q fever, was\nconfirmed in April 2006 but also was not reported to the CDC.\nThe Sunshine Project said its investigation of Texas A&M came about\nthrough its review of select-agent labs that are vying to host the\nfederal government's planned new national biodefense facility,\naccording to a 27 Jun 2007 report in the Dallas Morning News.\nThe laboratory is affiliated with the Foreign Animal and Zoonotic\nDisease Defense Center, a US Department of Homeland Security (DHS)\ncenter of excellence that focuses on the study of foot-and-mouth\ndisease, avian influenza, and Rift Valley fever, according to the\ncenter's website. The center is funded by a USD 18 million DHS grant,\naccording to an Associated Press report.\nAccording to the Sunshine Project, Texas A&M notified the CDC about\nthe case of brucellosis in April 2007, a year after the worker's\nillness was confirmed. Shortly after Texas A&M report,\nrepresentatives from the CDC's Select Agents and Toxins Division\ninspected the laboratory and, in a 30 Jun 2007 memo, obtained and\nreleased by the Sunshine Project, ordered the lab to stop its work on\nall select agents and toxins until further notice.\nVon Roebuck, a CDC spokesman, told CIDRAP News that the agency has\nnever issued such a broad suspension order to a lab before. He said\nthe 30 Jun 2007 order applies to every agent the lab works with. The\nlist of affected agents is not public information because of security\nconcerns, Roebuck said. In the letter, the CDC outlined the concerns\nit has about the lab, which include the adequacy of biosafety plans,\nsecurity of the facility from unauthorized visitors, occupational\nsafety protocols, authorization from the CDC to work with certain\nagents, and compliance with federal select agent regulations.\nRoebuck said CDC officials would visit the Texas laboratory again in\nthe next few weeks to gather more information about its procedures\nand protocols. \"Then the agency will move forward with any\nrecommendations to get them under compliance,\" he said.\nIn a statement sent to Texas A&M faculty and staff on Fri 29 Jun\n2007, the school's interim president, Eddie J. Davis, said the\nlaboratory incidents did not pose a threat to anyone on or off\ncampus, but conceded that the university should have reported the\nworker's brucellosis in a more timely manner. (The university\nprovided CIDRAP News with a copy of the statement.)\nDavis said none of the workers who were exposed to the Q fever agent\ngot sick and that Texas A&M was going beyond health monitoring\nstandards at other select-agent labs by monitoring workers' blood for\nthe organism. He said the University believed that the threshold for\nreporting worker exposure was a confirmed illness.\n\"We are unequivocally committed to taking all appropriate steps to\nensure we are in full compliance with all CDC and any other relevant\npolicies and regulations,\" he said.\n_Coxiella burnetii_ causes an influenza-like disease in humans that\nis rarely fatal, according to the CDC. However, it is highly\ninfectious when it becomes airborne and is inhaled by humans. The\nagent has previously been weaponized and is considered a potential\nterrorist threat.\nBrucellosis presents prolonged fever and a wide range of other\npossible manifestations, such as arthritis, hepatitis, and\nmeningitis. Symptoms can be prolonged, but the disease is rarely\nfatal. In livestock, brucellosis causes infertility and abortions. As\nbioterrorism agents, _Brucella_ strains are inexpensive to produce\nand disperse, according to an August 2005 article in the CDC journal\nEmerging Infectious Diseases (EID).\n[Byline: Lisa Schnirring]\n--\nContributed by:\nProMED Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n[Texas A&M (Agriculture and Mining) University is located in College\nStation, TX, which can be found near the state capital of Austin on a\nmap of the state at\n<http://biochemistry.tamu.edu/images/tour/txmap.gif>\nPress releases from the Sunshine Project regarding these episodes can\nbe found at\n<http://www.sunshine-project.org/publications/pr/pr120407.html> and\n<http://www.sunshine-project.org/publications/pr/pr260607.html>. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nQ fever - Australia (SA) 20070624.2038\n2006\n----\nQ fever - USA (IA, IL): RFI 20061130.3391\nBrucellosis, human - Kyrgyzstan (Osh) 20061120.3311\nBrucellosis, human, bovine - Kyrgyzstan (02): background 20060924.2725\nBrucellosis, human, bovine - Kyrgyzstan (Chuiskiy) 20060923.2715\nQ fever, meat processing plant - UK (Scotland) (02) 20060825.2394\nQ fever, meat processing plant - UK (Scotland) 20060721.2001\n2005\n----\nQ fever, calving - Australia (NSW) 20051103.3222\nQ fever, contaminated wool - Russia (Moscow) 20051025.3118\nBrucellosis, human - Czech Republic ex Turkey (02) 20051018.3039\nBrucellosis, human - Czech Republic ex Turkey 20051017.3030\nBrucellosis, human, bovine - Venezuela 20051007.2932\nBrucellosis, human, caprine - Thailand (Kanchanaburi) 20050907.2646\nBrucellosis, human - Russia (Dagestan) 20050826.2523\nQ fever - Israel 20050814.2378\nQ fever - USA (CO) 20050810.2329\nBrucellosis, human - Kyrgyzstan (Jelalabad) 20050712.1975\nQ fever, human - USA (TX) 20050701.1861\nBrucellosis, human - Bosnia & Herzegovina 20050614.1658\nBrucellosis, human - Bulgaria ex Greece 20050328.0896\n2004\n----\nQ fever, farmers - Australia (S. Australia) 20041214.3309\nQ fever - Bulgaria (Botevgrad) 20040829.2413\nBrucellosis, ovine, contaminated agar - USA: alert 20040820.2315\nBrucellosis, human & caprines - Saudi Arabia (Jizan) 20040716.1926\nBrucellosis, humans & caprines - Lebanon 20040715.1907\nQ fever - Bosnia & Herzegovina (Banja Luka) 20040513.1291\n2002\n----\nQ fever - UK (Wales) 20021027.5653\nQ fever - France (Chamonix) (02) 20020911.5283\nQ fever - France (Chamonix) 20020903.5224\nQ fever, human, sheep, vaccine - Germany (02) 20020629.4632\nQ fever, human, sheep, vaccine - Germany: RFI 20020626.4607\nQ fever - Bosnia & Herzegovina (Livno) 20020328.3832\n2001\n----\nQ fever - Germany (N.Rhine Westphalia) 20010723.1438\nQ fever - UK: background 20010702.1262\nQ fever goat, suspected human - USA (Wyoming) (02) 20010205.0234\nQ fever goat, suspected human - USA (Wyoming) 20010201.0221\nQ fever - Australia (Queensland) 20010129.0204\n...................................ll/mj/lm\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. USA (MT) (03)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=16671", "date": "2007-07-06 11:00:03", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS, Q FEVER, LAB WORKERS - USA (TEXAS)\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Tue 3 Jul 2007\nSource: Center for Infectious Disease Research & Policy (CIDRAP) News [edited]\n<http://www.cidrap.umn.edu/cidrap/content/bt/bioprep/news/jul0307bioweapons.html>\n\nThe CDC (US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention) on 30 Jun\n2007, ordered a biodefense research laboratory at Texas A&M\nUniversity to stop all work on select agents and toxins while it\ninvestigates reports of lab workers infected with the category B\nbioterror agents _Brucella_ and _Coxiella burnetii_.\nThe Sunshine Project, an Austin, Texas, nonprofit group that monitors\nbiodefense research safety, recently reported the alleged lab\naccidents, along with related alleged violations of federal law. The\ngroup used Texas freedom-of-information requests to obtain documents\nabout the lab incidents.\nIn April 2007, the Sunshine Project reported that a Texas A&M\nresearcher had been infected with _Brucella_ after a February 2006\naerosol chamber mishap and that the school did not immediately notify\nthe CDC as required by federal law.\n[On 26 Jun 2007], the watchdog group reported that the exposure of 3\nother Texas A&M workers to _C. burnetii_, which causes Q fever, was\nconfirmed in April 2006 but also was not reported to the CDC.\nThe Sunshine Project said its investigation of Texas A&M came about\nthrough its review of select-agent labs that are vying to host the\nfederal government's planned new national biodefense facility,\naccording to a 27 Jun 2007 report in the Dallas Morning News.\nThe laboratory is affiliated with the Foreign Animal and Zoonotic\nDisease Defense Center, a US Department of Homeland Security (DHS)\ncenter of excellence that focuses on the study of foot-and-mouth\ndisease, avian influenza, and Rift Valley fever, according to the\ncenter's website. The center is funded by a USD 18 million DHS grant,\naccording to an Associated Press report.\nAccording to the Sunshine Project, Texas A&M notified the CDC about\nthe case of brucellosis in April 2007, a year after the worker's\nillness was confirmed. Shortly after Texas A&M report,\nrepresentatives from the CDC's Select Agents and Toxins Division\ninspected the laboratory and, in a 30 Jun 2007 memo, obtained and\nreleased by the Sunshine Project, ordered the lab to stop its work on\nall select agents and toxins until further notice.\nVon Roebuck, a CDC spokesman, told CIDRAP News that the agency has\nnever issued such a broad suspension order to a lab before. He said\nthe 30 Jun 2007 order applies to every agent the lab works with. The\nlist of affected agents is not public information because of security\nconcerns, Roebuck said. In the letter, the CDC outlined the concerns\nit has about the lab, which include the adequacy of biosafety plans,\nsecurity of the facility from unauthorized visitors, occupational\nsafety protocols, authorization from the CDC to work with certain\nagents, and compliance with federal select agent regulations.\nRoebuck said CDC officials would visit the Texas laboratory again in\nthe next few weeks to gather more information about its procedures\nand protocols. \"Then the agency will move forward with any\nrecommendations to get them under compliance,\" he said.\nIn a statement sent to Texas A&M faculty and staff on Fri 29 Jun\n2007, the school's interim president, Eddie J. Davis, said the\nlaboratory incidents did not pose a threat to anyone on or off\ncampus, but conceded that the university should have reported the\nworker's brucellosis in a more timely manner. (The university\nprovided CIDRAP News with a copy of the statement.)\nDavis said none of the workers who were exposed to the Q fever agent\ngot sick and that Texas A&M was going beyond health monitoring\nstandards at other select-agent labs by monitoring workers' blood for\nthe organism. He said the University believed that the threshold for\nreporting worker exposure was a confirmed illness.\n\"We are unequivocally committed to taking all appropriate steps to\nensure we are in full compliance with all CDC and any other relevant\npolicies and regulations,\" he said.\n_Coxiella burnetii_ causes an influenza-like disease in humans that\nis rarely fatal, according to the CDC. However, it is highly\ninfectious when it becomes airborne and is inhaled by humans. The\nagent has previously been weaponized and is considered a potential\nterrorist threat.\nBrucellosis presents prolonged fever and a wide range of other\npossible manifestations, such as arthritis, hepatitis, and\nmeningitis. Symptoms can be prolonged, but the disease is rarely\nfatal. In livestock, brucellosis causes infertility and abortions. USA (TX)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=16329", "date": "2007-07-06 11:00:03", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS, Q FEVER, LAB WORKERS - USA (TEXAS)\n***********************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Tue 3 Jul 2007\nSource: Center for Infectious Disease Research & Policy (CIDRAP) News [edited]\n<http://www.cidrap.umn.edu/cidrap/content/bt/bioprep/news/jul0307bioweapons.html>\n\nThe CDC (US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention) on 30 Jun\n2007, ordered a biodefense research laboratory at Texas A&M\nUniversity to stop all work on select agents and toxins while it\ninvestigates reports of lab workers infected with the category B\nbioterror agents _Brucella_ and _Coxiella burnetii_.\nThe Sunshine Project, an Austin, Texas, nonprofit group that monitors\nbiodefense research safety, recently reported the alleged lab\naccidents, along with related alleged violations of federal law. The\ngroup used Texas freedom-of-information requests to obtain documents\nabout the lab incidents.\nIn April 2007, the Sunshine Project reported that a Texas A&M\nresearcher had been infected with _Brucella_ after a February 2006\naerosol chamber mishap and that the school did not immediately notify\nthe CDC as required by federal law.\n[On 26 Jun 2007], the watchdog group reported that the exposure of 3\nother Texas A&M workers to _C. burnetii_, which causes Q fever, was\nconfirmed in April 2006 but also was not reported to the CDC.\nThe Sunshine Project said its investigation of Texas A&M came about\nthrough its review of select-agent labs that are vying to host the\nfederal government's planned new national biodefense facility,\naccording to a 27 Jun 2007 report in the Dallas Morning News.\nThe laboratory is affiliated with the Foreign Animal and Zoonotic\nDisease Defense Center, a US Department of Homeland Security (DHS)\ncenter of excellence that focuses on the study of foot-and-mouth\ndisease, avian influenza, and Rift Valley fever, according to the\ncenter's website. The center is funded by a USD 18 million DHS grant,\naccording to an Associated Press report.\nAccording to the Sunshine Project, Texas A&M notified the CDC about\nthe case of brucellosis in April 2007, a year after the worker's\nillness was confirmed. Shortly after Texas A&M report,\nrepresentatives from the CDC's Select Agents and Toxins Division\ninspected the laboratory and, in a 30 Jun 2007 memo, obtained and\nreleased by the Sunshine Project, ordered the lab to stop its work on\nall select agents and toxins until further notice.\nVon Roebuck, a CDC spokesman, told CIDRAP News that the agency has\nnever issued such a broad suspension order to a lab before. He said\nthe 30 Jun 2007 order applies to every agent the lab works with. The\nlist of affected agents is not public information because of security\nconcerns, Roebuck said. In the letter, the CDC outlined the concerns\nit has about the lab, which include the adequacy of biosafety plans,\nsecurity of the facility from unauthorized visitors, occupational\nsafety protocols, authorization from the CDC to work with certain\nagents, and compliance with federal select agent regulations.\nRoebuck said CDC officials would visit the Texas laboratory again in\nthe next few weeks to gather more information about its procedures\nand protocols. \"Then the agency will move forward with any\nrecommendations to get them under compliance,\" he said.\nIn a statement sent to Texas A&M faculty and staff on Fri 29 Jun\n2007, the school's interim president, Eddie J. Davis, said the\nlaboratory incidents did not pose a threat to anyone on or off\ncampus, but conceded that the university should have reported the\nworker's brucellosis in a more timely manner. (The university\nprovided CIDRAP News with a copy of the statement.)\nDavis said none of the workers who were exposed to the Q fever agent\ngot sick and that Texas A&M was going beyond health monitoring\nstandards at other select-agent labs by monitoring workers' blood for\nthe organism. He said the University believed that the threshold for\nreporting worker exposure was a confirmed illness.\n\"We are unequivocally committed to taking all appropriate steps to\nensure we are in full compliance with all CDC and any other relevant\npolicies and regulations,\" he said.\n_Coxiella burnetii_ causes an influenza-like disease in humans that\nis rarely fatal, according to the CDC. However, it is highly\ninfectious when it becomes airborne and is inhaled by humans. The\nagent has previously been weaponized and is considered a potential\nterrorist threat.\nBrucellosis presents prolonged fever and a wide range of other\npossible manifestations, such as arthritis, hepatitis, and\nmeningitis. Symptoms can be prolonged, but the disease is rarely\nfatal. In livestock, brucellosis causes infertility and abortions. As\nbioterrorism agents, _Brucella_ strains are inexpensive to produce\nand disperse, according to an August 2005 article in the CDC journal\nEmerging Infectious Diseases (EID).\n[Byline: Lisa Schnirring]\n--\nContributed by:\nProMED Rapporteur Brent Barrett\n[Texas A&M (Agriculture and Mining) University is located in College\nStation, TX, which can be found near the state capital of Austin on a\nmap of the state at\n<http://biochemistry.tamu.edu/images/tour/txmap.gif>\nPress releases from the Sunshine Project regarding these episodes can\nbe found at\n<http://www.sunshine-project.org/publications/pr/pr120407.html> and\n<http://www.sunshine-project.org/publications/pr/pr260607.html>. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nQ fever - Australia (SA) 20070624.2038\n2006\n----\nQ fever - USA (IA, IL): RFI 20061130.3391\nBrucellosis, human - Kyrgyzstan (Osh) 20061120.3311\nBrucellosis, human, bovine - Kyrgyzstan (02): background 20060924.2725\nBrucellosis, human, bovine - Kyrgyzstan (Chuiskiy) 20060923.2715\nQ fever, meat processing plant - UK (Scotland) (02) 20060825.2394\nQ fever, meat processing plant - UK (Scotland) 20060721.2001\n2005\n----\nQ fever, calving - Australia (NSW) 20051103.3222\nQ fever, contaminated wool - Russia (Moscow) 20051025.3118\nBrucellosis, human - Czech Republic ex Turkey (02) 20051018.3039\nBrucellosis, human - Czech Republic ex Turkey 20051017.3030\nBrucellosis, human, bovine - Venezuela 20051007.2932\nBrucellosis, human, caprine - Thailand (Kanchanaburi) 20050907.2646\nBrucellosis, human - Russia (Dagestan) 20050826.2523\nQ fever - Israel 20050814.2378\nQ fever - USA (CO) 20050810.2329\nBrucellosis, human - Kyrgyzstan (Jelalabad) 20050712.1975\nQ fever, human - USA (TX) 20050701.1861\nBrucellosis, human - Bosnia & Herzegovina 20050614.1658\nBrucellosis, human - Bulgaria ex Greece 20050328.0896\n2004\n----\nQ fever, farmers - Australia (S. Australia) 20041214.3309\nQ fever - Bulgaria (Botevgrad) 20040829.2413\nBrucellosis, ovine, contaminated agar - USA: alert 20040820.2315\nBrucellosis, human & caprines - Saudi Arabia (Jizan) 20040716.1926\nBrucellosis, humans & caprines - Lebanon 20040715.1907\nQ fever - Bosnia & Herzegovina (Banja Luka) 20040513.1291\n2002\n----\nQ fever - UK (Wales) 20021027.5653\nQ fever - France (Chamonix) (02) 20020911.5283\nQ fever - France (Chamonix) 20020903.5224\nQ fever, human, sheep, vaccine - Germany (02) 20020629.4632\nQ fever, human, sheep, vaccine - Germany: RFI 20020626.4607\nQ fever - Bosnia & Herzegovina (Livno) 20020328.3832\n2001\n----\nQ fever - Germany (N.Rhine Westphalia) 20010723.1438\nQ fever - UK: background 20010702.1262\nQ fever goat, suspected human - USA (Wyoming) (02) 20010205.0234\nQ fever goat, suspected human - USA (Wyoming) 20010201.0221\nQ fever - Australia (Queensland) 20010129.0204\n...................................ll/mj/lm\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. USA (WA)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=13801", "date": "2007-04-02 12:00:02", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS, OVINE - KAZAKHSTAN\n**********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Sun 1 Apr 2007\nFrom: Dan Silver <dgsilver@yahoo.com>\nSource: Xinhua via JMNews.com [trans. by submitter from Chinese, edited]\n<http://www.jmnews.com.cn/c/2007/04/01/13/c_5456015.shtml>\nSheep Infected with Brucellosis in Kazakhstan\n-----------------------------------------------\nKazakhstan's Ministry of Emergency Situations announced on 31 Mar\n2007 that sheep in East Kazakhstan State's Zaysan District have been\nfound to be infected with brucellosis. More than 500 sheep that may\nbe infected will be culled and destroyed.\nAccording to Kazakhstan media reports on 31 Mar 2007, this outbreak\nwas discovered in winter grazing lands near Kensay Village in Zaysan\nDistrict. Kazakh epidemic prevention agencies are conducting medical\nsurveillance of those who had contact with sick sheep.\nBrucellosis is an infectious, zoonotic disease. After cattle and\nsheep become infected with brucellosis, infertility, miscarriage and\nfetal death can occur.\nWhen this illness is spread from cattle and sheep to humans, patients\ncan develop fever, profuse sweating, weakness, joint and muscle pain\nand other symptoms.\n[Byline: Lianglei Wei]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Though both _Brucella abortus_ and _B. melitensis_ are reportedly\npresent in Kazakhstan, it may be assumed that this outbreak has been\ncaused by _Brucella melitensis_, a zoonosis which affects mainly\nsheep and goats. Caprine and ovine brucellosis (the OIE terminology\nfor _B. melitensis_ infection) is, according to OIE's Handistatus\ndatabase, endemic in Kazakhstan (information available until 2004). -\nMod.AS]\nSee Also\n2004\n----\nBrucellosis, human, livestock - Kazakhstan 20040803.2119\n.............................arn/ejp/msp/lm\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. More than 500 sheep that may\nbe infected will be culled and destroyed.\nAccording to Kazakhstan media reports on 31 Mar 2007, this outbreak\nwas discovered in winter grazing lands near Kensay Village in Zaysan\nDistrict. Caprine and ovine brucellosis (the OIE terminology\nfor _B. melitensis_ infection) is, according to OIE's Handistatus\ndatabase, endemic in Kazakhstan (information available until 2004). -\nMod.AS]\nSee Also\n2004\n----\nBrucellosis, human, livestock - Kazakhstan 20040803.2119\n.............................arn/ejp/msp/lm\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. More than 500 sheep that may\nbe infected will be culled and destroyed.\nAccording to Kazakhstan media reports on 31 Mar 2007, this outbreak\nwas discovered in winter grazing lands near Kensay Village in Zaysan\nDistrict. Kazakh epidemic prevention agencies are conducting medical\nsurveillance of those who had contact with sick sheep.\nBrucellosis is an infectious, zoonotic disease. After cattle and\nsheep become infected with brucellosis, infertility, miscarriage and\nfetal death can occur.\nWhen this illness is spread from cattle and sheep to humans, patients\ncan develop fever, profuse sweating, weakness, joint and muscle pain\nand other symptoms.\n[Byline: Lianglei Wei]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Though both _Brucella abortus_ and _B. melitensis_ are reportedly\npresent in Kazakhstan, it may be assumed that this outbreak has been\ncaused by _Brucella melitensis_, a zoonosis which affects mainly\nsheep and goats. More than 500 sheep that may\nbe infected will be culled and destroyed.\nAccording to Kazakhstan media reports on 31 Mar 2007, this outbreak\nwas discovered in winter grazing lands near Kensay Village in Zaysan\nDistrict. Kazakh epidemic prevention agencies are conducting medical\nsurveillance of those who had contact with sick sheep.\nBrucellosis is an infectious, zoonotic disease. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "brucellosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-31 00:00:00", "2007-03-15 00:00:00", "2007-03-15 00:00:00", "2004-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Zaysan \n District", "country": "Kazakhstan"}, {"location": "Kensay Village", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kazakhstan", "country": "Kazakhstan"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "10210", "headline": "PRO/AH> Brucellosis, canine - USA (WA)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=10210", "date": "2007-04-02 12:00:02", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS, OVINE - KAZAKHSTAN\n**********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Sun 1 Apr 2007\nFrom: Dan Silver <dgsilver@yahoo.com>\nSource: Xinhua via JMNews.com [trans. by submitter from Chinese, edited]\n<http://www.jmnews.com.cn/c/2007/04/01/13/c_5456015.shtml>\nSheep Infected with Brucellosis in Kazakhstan\n-----------------------------------------------\nKazakhstan's Ministry of Emergency Situations announced on 31 Mar\n2007 that sheep in East Kazakhstan State's Zaysan District have been\nfound to be infected with brucellosis. More than 500 sheep that may\nbe infected will be culled and destroyed.\nAccording to Kazakhstan media reports on 31 Mar 2007, this outbreak\nwas discovered in winter grazing lands near Kensay Village in Zaysan\nDistrict. Kazakh epidemic prevention agencies are conducting medical\nsurveillance of those who had contact with sick sheep.\nBrucellosis is an infectious, zoonotic disease. After cattle and\nsheep become infected with brucellosis, infertility, miscarriage and\nfetal death can occur.\nWhen this illness is spread from cattle and sheep to humans, patients\ncan develop fever, profuse sweating, weakness, joint and muscle pain\nand other symptoms.\n[Byline: Lianglei Wei]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Though both _Brucella abortus_ and _B. melitensis_ are reportedly\npresent in Kazakhstan, it may be assumed that this outbreak has been\ncaused by _Brucella melitensis_, a zoonosis which affects mainly\nsheep and goats. Caprine and ovine brucellosis (the OIE terminology\nfor _B. melitensis_ infection) is, according to OIE's Handistatus\ndatabase, endemic in Kazakhstan (information available until 2004). -\nMod.AS]\nSee Also\n2004\n----\nBrucellosis, human, livestock - Kazakhstan 20040803.2119\n.............................arn/ejp/msp/lm\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. More than 500 sheep that may\nbe infected will be culled and destroyed.\nAccording to Kazakhstan media reports on 31 Mar 2007, this outbreak\nwas discovered in winter grazing lands near Kensay Village in Zaysan\nDistrict. Kazakh epidemic prevention agencies are conducting medical\nsurveillance of those who had contact with sick sheep.\nBrucellosis is an infectious, zoonotic disease. After cattle and\nsheep become infected with brucellosis, infertility, miscarriage and\nfetal death can occur.\nWhen this illness is spread from cattle and sheep to humans, patients\ncan develop fever, profuse sweating, weakness, joint and muscle pain\nand other symptoms.\n[Byline: Lianglei Wei]\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Though both _Brucella abortus_ and _B. melitensis_ are reportedly\npresent in Kazakhstan, it may be assumed that this outbreak has been\ncaused by _Brucella melitensis_, a zoonosis which affects mainly\nsheep and goats. Caprine and ovine brucellosis (the OIE terminology\nfor _B. melitensis_ infection) is, according to OIE's Handistatus\ndatabase, endemic in Kazakhstan (information available until 2004). -\nMod.AS]\nSee Also\n2004\n----\nBrucellosis, human, livestock - Kazakhstan 20040803.2119\n.............................arn/ejp/msp/lm\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "brucellosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2021-03-31 00:00:00", "2007-03-15 00:00:00", "2007-03-15 00:00:00", "2004-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Zaysan \n District", "country": "Kazakhstan"}, {"location": "Kensay Village", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Kazakhstan", "country": "Kazakhstan"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "7923", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Brucellosis, cervidae - USA (WY)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=7923", "date": "2006-01-01 23:50:00", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS, BOVINE - USA (IDAHO) (03)\n**************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 1 Jan 2006\nFrom: Phillip Mamer <pmamer@idfg.idaho.gov>\n\nRegarding the brucellosis outbreak in Idaho\n-----------------------------------------------\nThe Idaho State Department of Agriculture (ISDA) quarantined a ranch\nin Bonneville County's Swan Valley, after the department's Veterinary\nMedical Officers identified a possible case of brucellosis in cattle.\nA cow that reacted positively to a brucellosis test through the\nMarket Cattle Inspection Program under the Cooperative State-Federal\nBrucellosis Eradication Program was traced to the Swan Valley ranch.\nISDA Veterinary Medical Officers tested the entire herd for\nbrucellosis. 10 additional cows reacted positively to these tests.\nFurther tests [milk cultures from the suspect cows] were conducted in\naccordance with the USDA's Uniform Methods and Rules for the\nEradication of Brucellosis. These tests confirmed the animals are\ninfected with _Brucella abortus_ Biovar 1.\nThis herd of 39 cows, 2 bulls, and about 25 suckling calves has been\ndepopulated.\nThe cattle are run year around on the owner's deeded ground. The\nowner claims limited exposure to elk populations. The ranch is about\n1000 acres, of which about 800 acres may be pastured at various times\nof the year.\nNo females have been purchased for at least 10 years. The last bulls\nwere purchased in December 2003. There is no fence line contact with\nany other cattle.\nThis ranch is situated in an area through which numerous elk migrate\nin spring and fall. There are also elk that are winter residents in\nthis area. This ranch is also located near the Idaho Fish and Game\nRainey Creek feedground.\nThis feedground has been in existence since the late 70s to keep elk\nfrom depredating on haystacks and cattle feedlines.\nIDFG and ISDA has a trap, test and removal program on this feedground\nfor seropositive elk. The apparent seropositive rate on this\nfeedground has ranged from a high of 45 percent in 1999 to a low of 6\npercent in 2005.\nUp to 500 elk are fed at this site, depending on temperature, snow\ndepth and risk to cattle near the mouth of Rainey Creek Canyon.\nBrucellosis Biovar 1 and 4 have been isolated from elk on or from\nthis feedground when tested and removed at the trap in Rainey Creek.\nIt has been 3 years since the last case of brucellosis was identified\nin Idaho. Prior to the case in 2002, the most recent case in Idaho\nwas in 1989. Pending conclusion of the investigation into this most\nrecent case, Idaho may lose its Brucellosis Class Free status held\nsince 1991.\nThe ISDA and USDA are conducting an epidemiological investigation\nthat includes identification and testing of all herds that had\ncontact with the quarantined herd.\n--\nPhillip Mamer DVM\nWildlife Veterinarian\nIdaho Department of Fish and Game\nCaldwell Idaho\n<pmamer@idfg.idaho.gov>\nSee Also\n2005\n----\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA (ID)(02): correction 20051229.3705, 20051229.3706\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA (ID) 20051229.3702\n2004\n----\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA (WY) (02) 20040725.2035\nBrucellosis, bovine Panama 20040721.1976\nBrucellosis, human & caprines - Saudi Arabia (Jizan) 20040716.1926\nBrucellosis, humans & caprines - Lebanon 20040715.1907\nBrucellosis, bovine - UK (Cornwall) (02) 20040401.0891\nBrucellosis - Algeria (El-Aghuat) 20040401.0883\nBrucellosis, bison vaccination - USA (WY) 20040327.0847\n............tg/msp/lm\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The\nowner claims limited exposure to elk populations. The last bulls\nwere purchased in December 2003. There is no fence line contact with\nany other cattle.\nThis ranch is situated in an area through which numerous elk migrate\nin spring and fall. There are also elk that are winter residents in\nthis area. This ranch is also located near the Idaho Fish and Game\nRainey Creek feedground.\nThis feedground has been in existence since the late 70s to keep elk\nfrom depredating on haystacks and cattle feedlines.\nIDFG and ISDA has a trap, test and removal program on this feedground\nfor seropositive elk. The apparent seropositive rate on this\nfeedground has ranged from a high of 45 percent in 1999 to a low of 6\npercent in 2005.\nUp to 500 elk are fed at this site, depending on temperature, snow\ndepth and risk to cattle near the mouth of Rainey Creek Canyon.\nBrucellosis Biovar 1 and 4 have been isolated from elk on or from\nthis feedground when tested and removed at the trap in Rainey Creek.\nIt has been 3 years since the last case of brucellosis was identified\nin Idaho. Chile (Osorno) (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6643", "date": "2006-01-01 23:50:00", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS, BOVINE - USA (IDAHO) (03)\n**************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 1 Jan 2006\nFrom: Phillip Mamer <pmamer@idfg.idaho.gov>\n\nRegarding the brucellosis outbreak in Idaho\n-----------------------------------------------\nThe Idaho State Department of Agriculture (ISDA) quarantined a ranch\nin Bonneville County's Swan Valley, after the department's Veterinary\nMedical Officers identified a possible case of brucellosis in cattle.\nA cow that reacted positively to a brucellosis test through the\nMarket Cattle Inspection Program under the Cooperative State-Federal\nBrucellosis Eradication Program was traced to the Swan Valley ranch.\nISDA Veterinary Medical Officers tested the entire herd for\nbrucellosis. 10 additional cows reacted positively to these tests.\nFurther tests [milk cultures from the suspect cows] were conducted in\naccordance with the USDA's Uniform Methods and Rules for the\nEradication of Brucellosis. These tests confirmed the animals are\ninfected with _Brucella abortus_ Biovar 1.\nThis herd of 39 cows, 2 bulls, and about 25 suckling calves has been\ndepopulated.\nThe cattle are run year around on the owner's deeded ground. The\nowner claims limited exposure to elk populations. The ranch is about\n1000 acres, of which about 800 acres may be pastured at various times\nof the year.\nNo females have been purchased for at least 10 years. The last bulls\nwere purchased in December 2003. There is no fence line contact with\nany other cattle.\nThis ranch is situated in an area through which numerous elk migrate\nin spring and fall. There are also elk that are winter residents in\nthis area. This ranch is also located near the Idaho Fish and Game\nRainey Creek feedground.\nThis feedground has been in existence since the late 70s to keep elk\nfrom depredating on haystacks and cattle feedlines.\nIDFG and ISDA has a trap, test and removal program on this feedground\nfor seropositive elk. The apparent seropositive rate on this\nfeedground has ranged from a high of 45 percent in 1999 to a low of 6\npercent in 2005.\nUp to 500 elk are fed at this site, depending on temperature, snow\ndepth and risk to cattle near the mouth of Rainey Creek Canyon.\nBrucellosis Biovar 1 and 4 have been isolated from elk on or from\nthis feedground when tested and removed at the trap in Rainey Creek.\nIt has been 3 years since the last case of brucellosis was identified\nin Idaho. Prior to the case in 2002, the most recent case in Idaho\nwas in 1989. Pending conclusion of the investigation into this most\nrecent case, Idaho may lose its Brucellosis Class Free status held\nsince 1991.\nThe ISDA and USDA are conducting an epidemiological investigation\nthat includes identification and testing of all herds that had\ncontact with the quarantined herd.\n--\nPhillip Mamer DVM\nWildlife Veterinarian\nIdaho Department of Fish and Game\nCaldwell Idaho\n<pmamer@idfg.idaho.gov>\nSee Also\n2005\n----\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA (ID)(02): correction 20051229.3705, 20051229.3706\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA (ID) 20051229.3702\n2004\n----\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA (WY) (02) 20040725.2035\nBrucellosis, bovine Panama 20040721.1976\nBrucellosis, human & caprines - Saudi Arabia (Jizan) 20040716.1926\nBrucellosis, humans & caprines - Lebanon 20040715.1907\nBrucellosis, bovine - UK (Cornwall) (02) 20040401.0891\nBrucellosis - Algeria (El-Aghuat) 20040401.0883\nBrucellosis, bison vaccination - USA (WY) 20040327.0847\n............tg/msp/lm\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Chile (Osorno): RFI", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=6412", "date": "2006-01-01 23:50:00", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS, BOVINE - USA (IDAHO) (03)\n**************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 1 Jan 2006\nFrom: Phillip Mamer <pmamer@idfg.idaho.gov>\n\nRegarding the brucellosis outbreak in Idaho\n-----------------------------------------------\nThe Idaho State Department of Agriculture (ISDA) quarantined a ranch\nin Bonneville County's Swan Valley, after the department's Veterinary\nMedical Officers identified a possible case of brucellosis in cattle.\nA cow that reacted positively to a brucellosis test through the\nMarket Cattle Inspection Program under the Cooperative State-Federal\nBrucellosis Eradication Program was traced to the Swan Valley ranch.\nISDA Veterinary Medical Officers tested the entire herd for\nbrucellosis. 10 additional cows reacted positively to these tests.\nFurther tests [milk cultures from the suspect cows] were conducted in\naccordance with the USDA's Uniform Methods and Rules for the\nEradication of Brucellosis. These tests confirmed the animals are\ninfected with _Brucella abortus_ Biovar 1.\nThis herd of 39 cows, 2 bulls, and about 25 suckling calves has been\ndepopulated.\nThe cattle are run year around on the owner's deeded ground. The\nowner claims limited exposure to elk populations. The ranch is about\n1000 acres, of which about 800 acres may be pastured at various times\nof the year.\nNo females have been purchased for at least 10 years. The last bulls\nwere purchased in December 2003. There is no fence line contact with\nany other cattle.\nThis ranch is situated in an area through which numerous elk migrate\nin spring and fall. There are also elk that are winter residents in\nthis area. This ranch is also located near the Idaho Fish and Game\nRainey Creek feedground.\nThis feedground has been in existence since the late 70s to keep elk\nfrom depredating on haystacks and cattle feedlines.\nIDFG and ISDA has a trap, test and removal program on this feedground\nfor seropositive elk. The apparent seropositive rate on this\nfeedground has ranged from a high of 45 percent in 1999 to a low of 6\npercent in 2005.\nUp to 500 elk are fed at this site, depending on temperature, snow\ndepth and risk to cattle near the mouth of Rainey Creek Canyon.\nBrucellosis Biovar 1 and 4 have been isolated from elk on or from\nthis feedground when tested and removed at the trap in Rainey Creek.\nIt has been 3 years since the last case of brucellosis was identified\nin Idaho. Prior to the case in 2002, the most recent case in Idaho\nwas in 1989. Pending conclusion of the investigation into this most\nrecent case, Idaho may lose its Brucellosis Class Free status held\nsince 1991.\nThe ISDA and USDA are conducting an epidemiological investigation\nthat includes identification and testing of all herds that had\ncontact with the quarantined herd.\n--\nPhillip Mamer DVM\nWildlife Veterinarian\nIdaho Department of Fish and Game\nCaldwell Idaho\n<pmamer@idfg.idaho.gov>\nSee Also\n2005\n----\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA (ID)(02): correction 20051229.3705, 20051229.3706\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA (ID) 20051229.3702\n2004\n----\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA (WY) (02) 20040725.2035\nBrucellosis, bovine Panama 20040721.1976\nBrucellosis, human & caprines - Saudi Arabia (Jizan) 20040716.1926\nBrucellosis, humans & caprines - Lebanon 20040715.1907\nBrucellosis, bovine - UK (Cornwall) (02) 20040401.0891\nBrucellosis - Algeria (El-Aghuat) 20040401.0883\nBrucellosis, bison vaccination - USA (WY) 20040327.0847\n............tg/msp/lm\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "brucellosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2006-01-01 00:00:00", "2003-12-15 00:00:00", "1999-03-15 00:00:00", "2005-03-15 00:00:00", "2002-03-15 00:00:00", "1989-03-15 00:00:00", "2005-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bonneville County 's", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Saudi Arabia", "country": "Saudi Arabia"}, {"location": "Idaho", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Rainey Creek", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "WY", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Lebanon", "country": "Lebanon"}, {"location": "Panama", "country": "Panama"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "4656", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Brucellosis, human - Kyrgyzstan (Osh)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=4656", "date": "2006-01-01 23:50:00", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS, BOVINE - USA (IDAHO) (03)\n**************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 1 Jan 2006\nFrom: Phillip Mamer <pmamer@idfg.idaho.gov>\n\nRegarding the brucellosis outbreak in Idaho\n-----------------------------------------------\nThe Idaho State Department of Agriculture (ISDA) quarantined a ranch\nin Bonneville County's Swan Valley, after the department's Veterinary\nMedical Officers identified a possible case of brucellosis in cattle.\nA cow that reacted positively to a brucellosis test through the\nMarket Cattle Inspection Program under the Cooperative State-Federal\nBrucellosis Eradication Program was traced to the Swan Valley ranch.\nISDA Veterinary Medical Officers tested the entire herd for\nbrucellosis. 10 additional cows reacted positively to these tests.\nFurther tests [milk cultures from the suspect cows] were conducted in\naccordance with the USDA's Uniform Methods and Rules for the\nEradication of Brucellosis. These tests confirmed the animals are\ninfected with _Brucella abortus_ Biovar 1.\nThis herd of 39 cows, 2 bulls, and about 25 suckling calves has been\ndepopulated.\nThe cattle are run year around on the owner's deeded ground. The\nowner claims limited exposure to elk populations. The ranch is about\n1000 acres, of which about 800 acres may be pastured at various times\nof the year.\nNo females have been purchased for at least 10 years. The last bulls\nwere purchased in December 2003. There is no fence line contact with\nany other cattle.\nThis ranch is situated in an area through which numerous elk migrate\nin spring and fall. There are also elk that are winter residents in\nthis area. This ranch is also located near the Idaho Fish and Game\nRainey Creek feedground.\nThis feedground has been in existence since the late 70s to keep elk\nfrom depredating on haystacks and cattle feedlines.\nIDFG and ISDA has a trap, test and removal program on this feedground\nfor seropositive elk. The apparent seropositive rate on this\nfeedground has ranged from a high of 45 percent in 1999 to a low of 6\npercent in 2005.\nUp to 500 elk are fed at this site, depending on temperature, snow\ndepth and risk to cattle near the mouth of Rainey Creek Canyon.\nBrucellosis Biovar 1 and 4 have been isolated from elk on or from\nthis feedground when tested and removed at the trap in Rainey Creek.\nIt has been 3 years since the last case of brucellosis was identified\nin Idaho. Prior to the case in 2002, the most recent case in Idaho\nwas in 1989. Pending conclusion of the investigation into this most\nrecent case, Idaho may lose its Brucellosis Class Free status held\nsince 1991.\nThe ISDA and USDA are conducting an epidemiological investigation\nthat includes identification and testing of all herds that had\ncontact with the quarantined herd.\n--\nPhillip Mamer DVM\nWildlife Veterinarian\nIdaho Department of Fish and Game\nCaldwell Idaho\n<pmamer@idfg.idaho.gov>\nSee Also\n2005\n----\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA (ID)(02): correction 20051229.3705, 20051229.3706\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA (ID) 20051229.3702\n2004\n----\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA (WY) (02) 20040725.2035\nBrucellosis, bovine Panama 20040721.1976\nBrucellosis, human & caprines - Saudi Arabia (Jizan) 20040716.1926\nBrucellosis, humans & caprines - Lebanon 20040715.1907\nBrucellosis, bovine - UK (Cornwall) (02) 20040401.0891\nBrucellosis - Algeria (El-Aghuat) 20040401.0883\nBrucellosis, bison vaccination - USA (WY) 20040327.0847\n............tg/msp/lm\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. These tests confirmed the animals are\ninfected with _Brucella abortus_ Biovar 1.\nThis herd of 39 cows, 2 bulls, and about 25 suckling calves has been\ndepopulated.\nThe cattle are run year around on the owner's deeded ground. The\nowner claims limited exposure to elk populations. The ranch is about\n1000 acres, of which about 800 acres may be pastured at various times\nof the year.\nNo females have been purchased for at least 10 years. The last bulls\nwere purchased in December 2003. There is no fence line contact with\nany other cattle.\nThis ranch is situated in an area through which numerous elk migrate\nin spring and fall. There are also elk that are winter residents in\nthis area. This ranch is also located near the Idaho Fish and Game\nRainey Creek feedground.\nThis feedground has been in existence since the late 70s to keep elk\nfrom depredating on haystacks and cattle feedlines.\nIDFG and ISDA has a trap, test and removal program on this feedground\nfor seropositive elk. The apparent seropositive rate on this\nfeedground has ranged from a high of 45 percent in 1999 to a low of 6\npercent in 2005.\nUp to 500 elk are fed at this site, depending on temperature, snow\ndepth and risk to cattle near the mouth of Rainey Creek Canyon.\nBrucellosis Biovar 1 and 4 have been isolated from elk on or from\nthis feedground when tested and removed at the trap in Rainey Creek.\nIt has been 3 years since the last case of brucellosis was identified\nin Idaho. Prior to the case in 2002, the most recent case in Idaho\nwas in 1989. Pending conclusion of the investigation into this most\nrecent case, Idaho may lose its Brucellosis Class Free status held\nsince 1991.\nThe ISDA and USDA are conducting an epidemiological investigation\nthat includes identification and testing of all herds that had\ncontact with the quarantined herd.\n--\nPhillip Mamer DVM\nWildlife Veterinarian\nIdaho Department of Fish and Game\nCaldwell Idaho\n<pmamer@idfg.idaho.gov>\nSee Also\n2005\n----\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA (ID)(02): correction 20051229.3705, 20051229.3706\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA (ID) 20051229.3702\n2004\n----\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA (WY) (02) 20040725.2035\nBrucellosis, bovine Panama 20040721.1976\nBrucellosis, human & caprines - Saudi Arabia (Jizan) 20040716.1926\nBrucellosis, humans & caprines - Lebanon 20040715.1907\nBrucellosis, bovine - UK (Cornwall) (02) 20040401.0891\nBrucellosis - Algeria (El-Aghuat) 20040401.0883\nBrucellosis, bison vaccination - USA (WY) 20040327.0847\n............tg/msp/lm\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Kyrgyzstan (Chuiskiy)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2872", "date": "2006-01-01 23:50:00", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS, BOVINE - USA (IDAHO) (03)\n**************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: 1 Jan 2006\nFrom: Phillip Mamer <pmamer@idfg.idaho.gov>\n\nRegarding the brucellosis outbreak in Idaho\n-----------------------------------------------\nThe Idaho State Department of Agriculture (ISDA) quarantined a ranch\nin Bonneville County's Swan Valley, after the department's Veterinary\nMedical Officers identified a possible case of brucellosis in cattle.\nA cow that reacted positively to a brucellosis test through the\nMarket Cattle Inspection Program under the Cooperative State-Federal\nBrucellosis Eradication Program was traced to the Swan Valley ranch.\nISDA Veterinary Medical Officers tested the entire herd for\nbrucellosis. 10 additional cows reacted positively to these tests.\nFurther tests [milk cultures from the suspect cows] were conducted in\naccordance with the USDA's Uniform Methods and Rules for the\nEradication of Brucellosis. These tests confirmed the animals are\ninfected with _Brucella abortus_ Biovar 1.\nThis herd of 39 cows, 2 bulls, and about 25 suckling calves has been\ndepopulated.\nThe cattle are run year around on the owner's deeded ground. The\nowner claims limited exposure to elk populations. The ranch is about\n1000 acres, of which about 800 acres may be pastured at various times\nof the year.\nNo females have been purchased for at least 10 years. The last bulls\nwere purchased in December 2003. There is no fence line contact with\nany other cattle.\nThis ranch is situated in an area through which numerous elk migrate\nin spring and fall. There are also elk that are winter residents in\nthis area. This ranch is also located near the Idaho Fish and Game\nRainey Creek feedground.\nThis feedground has been in existence since the late 70s to keep elk\nfrom depredating on haystacks and cattle feedlines.\nIDFG and ISDA has a trap, test and removal program on this feedground\nfor seropositive elk. The apparent seropositive rate on this\nfeedground has ranged from a high of 45 percent in 1999 to a low of 6\npercent in 2005.\nUp to 500 elk are fed at this site, depending on temperature, snow\ndepth and risk to cattle near the mouth of Rainey Creek Canyon.\nBrucellosis Biovar 1 and 4 have been isolated from elk on or from\nthis feedground when tested and removed at the trap in Rainey Creek.\nIt has been 3 years since the last case of brucellosis was identified\nin Idaho. Prior to the case in 2002, the most recent case in Idaho\nwas in 1989. Pending conclusion of the investigation into this most\nrecent case, Idaho may lose its Brucellosis Class Free status held\nsince 1991.\nThe ISDA and USDA are conducting an epidemiological investigation\nthat includes identification and testing of all herds that had\ncontact with the quarantined herd.\n--\nPhillip Mamer DVM\nWildlife Veterinarian\nIdaho Department of Fish and Game\nCaldwell Idaho\n<pmamer@idfg.idaho.gov>\nSee Also\n2005\n----\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA (ID)(02): correction 20051229.3705, 20051229.3706\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA (ID) 20051229.3702\n2004\n----\nBrucellosis, bovine - USA (WY) (02) 20040725.2035\nBrucellosis, bovine Panama 20040721.1976\nBrucellosis, human & caprines - Saudi Arabia (Jizan) 20040716.1926\nBrucellosis, humans & caprines - Lebanon 20040715.1907\nBrucellosis, bovine - UK (Cornwall) (02) 20040401.0891\nBrucellosis - Algeria (El-Aghuat) 20040401.0883\nBrucellosis, bison vaccination - USA (WY) 20040327.0847\n............tg/msp/lm\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The apparent seropositive rate on this\nfeedground has ranged from a high of 45 percent in 1999 to a low of 6\npercent in 2005.\nUp to 500 elk are fed at this site, depending on temperature, snow\ndepth and risk to cattle near the mouth of Rainey Creek Canyon.\nBrucellosis Biovar 1 and 4 have been isolated from elk on or from\nthis feedground when tested and removed at the trap in Rainey Creek.\nIt has been 3 years since the last case of brucellosis was identified\nin Idaho. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "brucellosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2006-01-01 00:00:00", "2003-12-15 00:00:00", "1999-03-15 00:00:00", "2005-03-15 00:00:00", "2002-03-15 00:00:00", "1989-03-15 00:00:00", "2005-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Bonneville County 's", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Saudi Arabia", "country": "Saudi Arabia"}, {"location": "Idaho", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Rainey Creek", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "WY", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Lebanon", "country": "Lebanon"}, {"location": "Panama", "country": "Panama"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2209094", "headline": "PRO/ERR> Brucellosis, bovine - USA (ID)(02): correction", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2209094", "date": "2005-10-18 23:50:00", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS, HUMAN - CZECH REPUBLIC EX TURKEY (02)\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nSponsored by Elsevier, publisher of\nTropical Infectious Diseases, 2nd Edition\n<http://thelancet.url123.com/a5445>\nDate: Tue, 18 Oct 2005\nFrom: Jacques Godfroid <jacques.godfroid@up.ac.za>\n\nAfter having read both the posting by Dr. Strakrle and the further\ncomment of the ProMED Moderator, I do think that some confusion\nremains in how to interpret brucellosis and _Y. enterocolitica_ O:9 serology.\nMay I make 3 comments?\n1) Brucellosis serology\n-----------------------\nI understood that acute brucellosis was diagnosed based on\nserological titers using _B. abortus_ antigens. One has to\nre-emphasize that positive serological titers is either indicative of\na smooth _Brucella spp._ infection (one cannot make any inference as\nto whether _B. abortus_, _B. melitensis_ or _B. suis_ is involved\nunless the most likely source of infection is identified) or/and _Y.\nenterocolitica_ O:9 infection.\nClinical symptoms help in classifying the case as probable or\nconfirmed brucellosis, according to the CDC case definition. In this\nparticular case, given the patient was in Turkey (where _B.\nmelitensis_ is enzootic in sheep) and given the fact that sheep\ncheese has been consumed, one can reasonably assume that _B.\nmelitensis_ is involved, not _B. abortus_. _B. abortus_ is seldom\nreported to infect sheep, but _B. melitensis_ is reported to\nregularly infect cattle in the Mediterranean basin (1).\nOne can argue that _B. abortus_ infects cattle in Turkey. Human\nbrucellosis cases reported in that country have predominantly been\nattributed to _B. melitensis_\n2) _Y. enterocolitica_ O:9 serology\n----------------------------------\nSerological cross-reactivity after Smooth _Brucella spp_ (not just\n_B. abortus_) and _Y. enterocolitica_ O:9 infection both in animals\nand humans has been well documented. This is why the antibody test\nfor _Y. enterocolitica_ O:9 is likely to be a cross-reaction, unless\nthe diagnosis of the extraintestinal form of yersiniosis can be\nfurther substantiated.\n3) In the veterinary field\n-------------------------\nBrucellosis control or eradication programs are implemented\nworldwide, mainly for cattle, sheep, goats, and pigs. In this\ncontext, the objective is not primarily to diagnose _Y.\nenterocolitica_ O:9 infections, but to exclude brucellosis. In other\nwords, the _Y. enterocolitica_ O:9 status will not tell anything\nabout the brucellosis status. In this context, serology seems so far\nunable to differentiate beyond certain smooth _Brucella spp_\ninfection and _Y. enterocolitica_ O:9 infection. This is why\nmeasurement of the cell-mediated immunity via the brucellosis skin\ntest is the only means by which one can beyond any reasonable doubt\ndifferentiate smooth _Brucella spp_ infection and _Y. enterocolitica_\nO:9 infection (2).\nMay I take this opportunity to thank for you for the invaluable\nsource of information ProMED is, particularly for those living and\nworking somewhere \"at the end of the world.\"\n1. Refai M: Incidence and control of brucellosis in the Near East\nregion. Vet Microbiol. 2002; 90:81-110.\n2. Godfroid JC, Saegerman V, Wellemans K, et al: How to substantiate\neradication of bovine brucellosis when aspecific serological\nreactions occur in the course of brucellosis testing. Vet. Microbiol.\n2002; 90:461-77.\n--\nProf. Jacques Godfroid DVM, MSc, PhD\nUniversity of Pretoria\nFaculty of Veterinary Science\nOnderstepoort, South Africa\n<jacques.godfroid@up.ac.za>\n[ProMED thanks Professor Godfroid both for his comments and his kind\nwords. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nBrucellosis, human - Czech Republic ex Turkey 20051017.3030\nBrucellosis, human, bovine - Venezuela 20051007.2932\nBrucellosis, human, caprine - Thailand (Kanchanaburi) 20050907.2646\nBrucellosis, human - Russia (Dagestan) 20050826.2523\nBrucellosis, human - Kyrgyzstan (Jelalabad) 20050712.1975\nBrucellosis, human - Bosnia & Herzegovina 20050614.1658\nYersiniosis - Russia (Siberia) 20050427.1169\nBrucellosis, human - Bulgaria ex Greece 20050328.0896\nYersiniosis - Russia (Far East) 20050202.0359\n2004\n----\nBrucellosis, human & caprines - Saudi Arabia (Jizan) 20040716.1926\nBrucellosis, humans & caprines - Lebanon 20040715.1907\n2003\n----\nYersiniosis, contaminated blood - Japan 20031009.2538\n2002\n----\nYersiniosis - Russia (Far East) 20020206.3499\n1999\n----\nYersinia pseudotuberculosis - Canada (BC) (02) 19990504.0734\nYersiniosis - Russia (Kemerovo) 19990405.0551\n1998\n----\nYersinia pseudotuberculosis - Canada (BC) 19981201.2314\n1997\n----\nYersinia pseudotuberculosis - Finland 19971003.2081\nYersinia - Japan: imported (02) 19970702.1421\nYersinia - Japan: imported 19970702.1410\n1996\n----\nYersiniosis - Buffalo, NY, USA 19960124.0167\n............................ll/pg/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "brucellosis", "tuberculosis", "yersiniosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2002-03-15 00:00:00", "2002-03-15 00:00:00", "2003-03-15 00:00:00", "2002-03-15 00:00:00", "1998-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Greece", "country": "Greece"}, {"location": "Turkey", "country": "Turkey"}, {"location": "Saudi Arabia", "country": "Saudi Arabia"}, {"location": "Lebanon", "country": "Lebanon"}, {"location": "Bulgaria", "country": "Bulgaria"}, {"location": "Kemerovo", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Thailand", "country": "Thailand"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2209093", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Brucellosis, bovine - USA (ID)(02): correction", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2209093", "date": "2005-10-18 23:50:00", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS, HUMAN - CZECH REPUBLIC EX TURKEY (02)\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nSponsored by Elsevier, publisher of\nTropical Infectious Diseases, 2nd Edition\n<http://thelancet.url123.com/a5445>\nDate: Tue, 18 Oct 2005\nFrom: Jacques Godfroid <jacques.godfroid@up.ac.za>\n\nAfter having read both the posting by Dr. Strakrle and the further\ncomment of the ProMED Moderator, I do think that some confusion\nremains in how to interpret brucellosis and _Y. enterocolitica_ O:9 serology.\nMay I make 3 comments?\n1) Brucellosis serology\n-----------------------\nI understood that acute brucellosis was diagnosed based on\nserological titers using _B. abortus_ antigens. One has to\nre-emphasize that positive serological titers is either indicative of\na smooth _Brucella spp._ infection (one cannot make any inference as\nto whether _B. abortus_, _B. melitensis_ or _B. suis_ is involved\nunless the most likely source of infection is identified) or/and _Y.\nenterocolitica_ O:9 infection.\nClinical symptoms help in classifying the case as probable or\nconfirmed brucellosis, according to the CDC case definition. In this\nparticular case, given the patient was in Turkey (where _B.\nmelitensis_ is enzootic in sheep) and given the fact that sheep\ncheese has been consumed, one can reasonably assume that _B.\nmelitensis_ is involved, not _B. abortus_. _B. abortus_ is seldom\nreported to infect sheep, but _B. melitensis_ is reported to\nregularly infect cattle in the Mediterranean basin (1).\nOne can argue that _B. abortus_ infects cattle in Turkey. Human\nbrucellosis cases reported in that country have predominantly been\nattributed to _B. melitensis_\n2) _Y. enterocolitica_ O:9 serology\n----------------------------------\nSerological cross-reactivity after Smooth _Brucella spp_ (not just\n_B. abortus_) and _Y. enterocolitica_ O:9 infection both in animals\nand humans has been well documented. This is why the antibody test\nfor _Y. enterocolitica_ O:9 is likely to be a cross-reaction, unless\nthe diagnosis of the extraintestinal form of yersiniosis can be\nfurther substantiated.\n3) In the veterinary field\n-------------------------\nBrucellosis control or eradication programs are implemented\nworldwide, mainly for cattle, sheep, goats, and pigs. In this\ncontext, the objective is not primarily to diagnose _Y.\nenterocolitica_ O:9 infections, but to exclude brucellosis. In other\nwords, the _Y. enterocolitica_ O:9 status will not tell anything\nabout the brucellosis status. In this context, serology seems so far\nunable to differentiate beyond certain smooth _Brucella spp_\ninfection and _Y. enterocolitica_ O:9 infection. This is why\nmeasurement of the cell-mediated immunity via the brucellosis skin\ntest is the only means by which one can beyond any reasonable doubt\ndifferentiate smooth _Brucella spp_ infection and _Y. enterocolitica_\nO:9 infection (2).\nMay I take this opportunity to thank for you for the invaluable\nsource of information ProMED is, particularly for those living and\nworking somewhere \"at the end of the world.\"\n1. Refai M: Incidence and control of brucellosis in the Near East\nregion. Vet Microbiol. 2002; 90:81-110.\n2. Godfroid JC, Saegerman V, Wellemans K, et al: How to substantiate\neradication of bovine brucellosis when aspecific serological\nreactions occur in the course of brucellosis testing. Vet. Microbiol.\n2002; 90:461-77.\n--\nProf. Jacques Godfroid DVM, MSc, PhD\nUniversity of Pretoria\nFaculty of Veterinary Science\nOnderstepoort, South Africa\n<jacques.godfroid@up.ac.za>\n[ProMED thanks Professor Godfroid both for his comments and his kind\nwords. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nBrucellosis, human - Czech Republic ex Turkey 20051017.3030\nBrucellosis, human, bovine - Venezuela 20051007.2932\nBrucellosis, human, caprine - Thailand (Kanchanaburi) 20050907.2646\nBrucellosis, human - Russia (Dagestan) 20050826.2523\nBrucellosis, human - Kyrgyzstan (Jelalabad) 20050712.1975\nBrucellosis, human - Bosnia & Herzegovina 20050614.1658\nYersiniosis - Russia (Siberia) 20050427.1169\nBrucellosis, human - Bulgaria ex Greece 20050328.0896\nYersiniosis - Russia (Far East) 20050202.0359\n2004\n----\nBrucellosis, human & caprines - Saudi Arabia (Jizan) 20040716.1926\nBrucellosis, humans & caprines - Lebanon 20040715.1907\n2003\n----\nYersiniosis, contaminated blood - Japan 20031009.2538\n2002\n----\nYersiniosis - Russia (Far East) 20020206.3499\n1999\n----\nYersinia pseudotuberculosis - Canada (BC) (02) 19990504.0734\nYersiniosis - Russia (Kemerovo) 19990405.0551\n1998\n----\nYersinia pseudotuberculosis - Canada (BC) 19981201.2314\n1997\n----\nYersinia pseudotuberculosis - Finland 19971003.2081\nYersinia - Japan: imported (02) 19970702.1421\nYersinia - Japan: imported 19970702.1410\n1996\n----\nYersiniosis - Buffalo, NY, USA 19960124.0167\n............................ll/pg/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. One has to\nre-emphasize that positive serological titers is either indicative of\na smooth _Brucella spp._ infection (one cannot make any inference as\nto whether _B. abortus_, _B. melitensis_ or _B. suis_ is involved\nunless the most likely source of infection is identified) or/and _Y.\nenterocolitica_ O:9 infection.\nClinical symptoms help in classifying the case as probable or\nconfirmed brucellosis, according to the CDC case definition. In this\nparticular case, given the patient was in Turkey (where _B.\nmelitensis_ is enzootic in sheep) and given the fact that sheep\ncheese has been consumed, one can reasonably assume that _B.\nmelitensis_ is involved, not _B. abortus_. _B. abortus_ is seldom\nreported to infect sheep, but _B. melitensis_ is reported to\nregularly infect cattle in the Mediterranean basin (1).\nOne can argue that _B. abortus_ infects cattle in Turkey. Human\nbrucellosis cases reported in that country have predominantly been\nattributed to _B. melitensis_\n2) _Y. enterocolitica_ O:9 serology\n----------------------------------\nSerological cross-reactivity after Smooth _Brucella spp_ (not just\n_B. abortus_) and _Y. enterocolitica_ O:9 infection both in animals\nand humans has been well documented. This is why the antibody test\nfor _Y. enterocolitica_ O:9 is likely to be a cross-reaction, unless\nthe diagnosis of the extraintestinal form of yersiniosis can be\nfurther substantiated.\n3) In the veterinary field\n-------------------------\nBrucellosis control or eradication programs are implemented\nworldwide, mainly for cattle, sheep, goats, and pigs. In this\ncontext, the objective is not primarily to diagnose _Y.\nenterocolitica_ O:9 infections, but to exclude brucellosis. In other\nwords, the _Y. enterocolitica_ O:9 status will not tell anything\nabout the brucellosis status. In this context, serology seems so far\nunable to differentiate beyond certain smooth _Brucella spp_\ninfection and _Y. enterocolitica_ O:9 infection. This is why\nmeasurement of the cell-mediated immunity via the brucellosis skin\ntest is the only means by which one can beyond any reasonable doubt\ndifferentiate smooth _Brucella spp_ infection and _Y. enterocolitica_\nO:9 infection (2).\nMay I take this opportunity to thank for you for the invaluable\nsource of information ProMED is, particularly for those living and\nworking somewhere \"at the end of the world.\"\n1. Refai M: Incidence and control of brucellosis in the Near East\nregion. Vet Microbiol. 2002; 90:81-110.\n2. One has to\nre-emphasize that positive serological titers is either indicative of\na smooth _Brucella spp._ infection (one cannot make any inference as\nto whether _B. abortus_, _B. melitensis_ or _B. suis_ is involved\nunless the most likely source of infection is identified) or/and _Y.\nenterocolitica_ O:9 infection.\nClinical symptoms help in classifying the case as probable or\nconfirmed brucellosis, according to the CDC case definition. In this\nparticular case, given the patient was in Turkey (where _B.\nmelitensis_ is enzootic in sheep) and given the fact that sheep\ncheese has been consumed, one can reasonably assume that _B.\nmelitensis_ is involved, not _B. abortus_. _B. abortus_ is seldom\nreported to infect sheep, but _B. melitensis_ is reported to\nregularly infect cattle in the Mediterranean basin (1).\nOne can argue that _B. abortus_ infects cattle in Turkey. Human\nbrucellosis cases reported in that country have predominantly been\nattributed to _B. melitensis_\n2) _Y. enterocolitica_ O:9 serology\n----------------------------------\nSerological cross-reactivity after Smooth _Brucella spp_ (not just\n_B. abortus_) and _Y. enterocolitica_ O:9 infection both in animals\nand humans has been well documented. This is why the antibody test\nfor _Y. enterocolitica_ O:9 is likely to be a cross-reaction, unless\nthe diagnosis of the extraintestinal form of yersiniosis can be\nfurther substantiated.\n3) In the veterinary field\n-------------------------\nBrucellosis control or eradication programs are implemented\nworldwide, mainly for cattle, sheep, goats, and pigs. In this\ncontext, the objective is not primarily to diagnose _Y.\nenterocolitica_ O:9 infections, but to exclude brucellosis. In other\nwords, the _Y. enterocolitica_ O:9 status will not tell anything\nabout the brucellosis status. In this context, serology seems so far\nunable to differentiate beyond certain smooth _Brucella spp_\ninfection and _Y. enterocolitica_ O:9 infection. This is why\nmeasurement of the cell-mediated immunity via the brucellosis skin\ntest is the only means by which one can beyond any reasonable doubt\ndifferentiate smooth _Brucella spp_ infection and _Y. enterocolitica_\nO:9 infection (2).\nMay I take this opportunity to thank for you for the invaluable\nsource of information ProMED is, particularly for those living and\nworking somewhere \"at the end of the world.\"\n1. Refai M: Incidence and control of brucellosis in the Near East\nregion. Vet Microbiol. 2002; 90:81-110.\n2. Godfroid JC, Saegerman V, Wellemans K, et al: How to substantiate\neradication of bovine brucellosis when aspecific serological\nreactions occur in the course of brucellosis testing. Vet. Microbiol.\n2002; 90:461-77.\n--\nProf. Jacques Godfroid DVM, MSc, PhD\nUniversity of Pretoria\nFaculty of Veterinary Science\nOnderstepoort, South Africa\n<jacques.godfroid@up.ac.za>\n[ProMED thanks Professor Godfroid both for his comments and his kind\nwords. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nBrucellosis, human - Czech Republic ex Turkey 20051017.3030\nBrucellosis, human, bovine - Venezuela 20051007.2932\nBrucellosis, human, caprine - Thailand (Kanchanaburi) 20050907.2646\nBrucellosis, human - Russia (Dagestan) 20050826.2523\nBrucellosis, human - Kyrgyzstan (Jelalabad) 20050712.1975\nBrucellosis, human - Bosnia & Herzegovina 20050614.1658\nYersiniosis - Russia (Siberia) 20050427.1169\nBrucellosis, human - Bulgaria ex Greece 20050328.0896\nYersiniosis - Russia (Far East) 20050202.0359\n2004\n----\nBrucellosis, human & caprines - Saudi Arabia (Jizan) 20040716.1926\nBrucellosis, humans & caprines - Lebanon 20040715.1907\n2003\n----\nYersiniosis, contaminated blood - Japan 20031009.2538\n2002\n----\nYersiniosis - Russia (Far East) 20020206.3499\n1999\n----\nYersinia pseudotuberculosis - Canada (BC) (02) 19990504.0734\nYersiniosis - Russia (Kemerovo) 19990405.0551\n1998\n----\nYersinia pseudotuberculosis - Canada (BC) 19981201.2314\n1997\n----\nYersinia pseudotuberculosis - Finland 19971003.2081\nYersinia - Japan: imported (02) 19970702.1421\nYersinia - Japan: imported 19970702.1410\n1996\n----\nYersiniosis - Buffalo, NY, USA 19960124.0167\n............................ll/pg/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed.
