For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "brucellosis", "tuberculosis", "yersiniosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2002-03-15 00:00:00", "2002-03-15 00:00:00", "2003-03-15 00:00:00", "2002-03-15 00:00:00", "1998-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Greece", "country": "Greece"}, {"location": "Turkey", "country": "Turkey"}, {"location": "Saudi Arabia", "country": "Saudi Arabia"}, {"location": "Lebanon", "country": "Lebanon"}, {"location": "Bulgaria", "country": "Bulgaria"}, {"location": "Kemerovo", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Thailand", "country": "Thailand"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2208814", "headline": "PRO/AH> Brucellosis, human - Czech Republic ex Turkey (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2208814", "date": "2005-10-18 23:50:00", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS, HUMAN - CZECH REPUBLIC EX TURKEY (02)\n**************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\n\nSponsored by Elsevier, publisher of\nTropical Infectious Diseases, 2nd Edition\n<http://thelancet.url123.com/a5445>\nDate: Tue, 18 Oct 2005\nFrom: Jacques Godfroid <jacques.godfroid@up.ac.za>\n\nAfter having read both the posting by Dr. Strakrle and the further\ncomment of the ProMED Moderator, I do think that some confusion\nremains in how to interpret brucellosis and _Y. enterocolitica_ O:9 serology.\nMay I make 3 comments?\n1) Brucellosis serology\n-----------------------\nI understood that acute brucellosis was diagnosed based on\nserological titers using _B. abortus_ antigens. One has to\nre-emphasize that positive serological titers is either indicative of\na smooth _Brucella spp._ infection (one cannot make any inference as\nto whether _B. abortus_, _B. melitensis_ or _B. suis_ is involved\nunless the most likely source of infection is identified) or/and _Y.\nenterocolitica_ O:9 infection.\nClinical symptoms help in classifying the case as probable or\nconfirmed brucellosis, according to the CDC case definition. In this\nparticular case, given the patient was in Turkey (where _B.\nmelitensis_ is enzootic in sheep) and given the fact that sheep\ncheese has been consumed, one can reasonably assume that _B.\nmelitensis_ is involved, not _B. abortus_. _B. abortus_ is seldom\nreported to infect sheep, but _B. melitensis_ is reported to\nregularly infect cattle in the Mediterranean basin (1).\nOne can argue that _B. abortus_ infects cattle in Turkey. Human\nbrucellosis cases reported in that country have predominantly been\nattributed to _B. melitensis_\n2) _Y. enterocolitica_ O:9 serology\n----------------------------------\nSerological cross-reactivity after Smooth _Brucella spp_ (not just\n_B. abortus_) and _Y. enterocolitica_ O:9 infection both in animals\nand humans has been well documented. This is why the antibody test\nfor _Y. enterocolitica_ O:9 is likely to be a cross-reaction, unless\nthe diagnosis of the extraintestinal form of yersiniosis can be\nfurther substantiated.\n3) In the veterinary field\n-------------------------\nBrucellosis control or eradication programs are implemented\nworldwide, mainly for cattle, sheep, goats, and pigs. In this\ncontext, the objective is not primarily to diagnose _Y.\nenterocolitica_ O:9 infections, but to exclude brucellosis. In other\nwords, the _Y. enterocolitica_ O:9 status will not tell anything\nabout the brucellosis status. In this context, serology seems so far\nunable to differentiate beyond certain smooth _Brucella spp_\ninfection and _Y. enterocolitica_ O:9 infection. This is why\nmeasurement of the cell-mediated immunity via the brucellosis skin\ntest is the only means by which one can beyond any reasonable doubt\ndifferentiate smooth _Brucella spp_ infection and _Y. enterocolitica_\nO:9 infection (2).\nMay I take this opportunity to thank for you for the invaluable\nsource of information ProMED is, particularly for those living and\nworking somewhere \"at the end of the world.\"\n1. Refai M: Incidence and control of brucellosis in the Near East\nregion. Vet Microbiol. 2002; 90:81-110.\n2. Godfroid JC, Saegerman V, Wellemans K, et al: How to substantiate\neradication of bovine brucellosis when aspecific serological\nreactions occur in the course of brucellosis testing. Vet. Microbiol.\n2002; 90:461-77.\n--\nProf. Jacques Godfroid DVM, MSc, PhD\nUniversity of Pretoria\nFaculty of Veterinary Science\nOnderstepoort, South Africa\n<jacques.godfroid@up.ac.za>\n[ProMED thanks Professor Godfroid both for his comments and his kind\nwords. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nBrucellosis, human - Czech Republic ex Turkey 20051017.3030\nBrucellosis, human, bovine - Venezuela 20051007.2932\nBrucellosis, human, caprine - Thailand (Kanchanaburi) 20050907.2646\nBrucellosis, human - Russia (Dagestan) 20050826.2523\nBrucellosis, human - Kyrgyzstan (Jelalabad) 20050712.1975\nBrucellosis, human - Bosnia & Herzegovina 20050614.1658\nYersiniosis - Russia (Siberia) 20050427.1169\nBrucellosis, human - Bulgaria ex Greece 20050328.0896\nYersiniosis - Russia (Far East) 20050202.0359\n2004\n----\nBrucellosis, human & caprines - Saudi Arabia (Jizan) 20040716.1926\nBrucellosis, humans & caprines - Lebanon 20040715.1907\n2003\n----\nYersiniosis, contaminated blood - Japan 20031009.2538\n2002\n----\nYersiniosis - Russia (Far East) 20020206.3499\n1999\n----\nYersinia pseudotuberculosis - Canada (BC) (02) 19990504.0734\nYersiniosis - Russia (Kemerovo) 19990405.0551\n1998\n----\nYersinia pseudotuberculosis - Canada (BC) 19981201.2314\n1997\n----\nYersinia pseudotuberculosis - Finland 19971003.2081\nYersinia - Japan: imported (02) 19970702.1421\nYersinia - Japan: imported 19970702.1410\n1996\n----\nYersiniosis - Buffalo, NY, USA 19960124.0167\n............................ll/pg/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. In this\ncontext, the objective is not primarily to diagnose _Y.\nenterocolitica_ O:9 infections, but to exclude brucellosis. In other\nwords, the _Y. enterocolitica_ O:9 status will not tell anything\nabout the brucellosis status. In this\nparticular case, given the patient was in Turkey (where _B.\nmelitensis_ is enzootic in sheep) and given the fact that sheep\ncheese has been consumed, one can reasonably assume that _B.\nmelitensis_ is involved, not _B. abortus_. _B. abortus_ is seldom\nreported to infect sheep, but _B. melitensis_ is reported to\nregularly infect cattle in the Mediterranean basin (1).\nOne can argue that _B. abortus_ infects cattle in Turkey. Human\nbrucellosis cases reported in that country have predominantly been\nattributed to _B. melitensis_\n2) _Y. enterocolitica_ O:9 serology\n----------------------------------\nSerological cross-reactivity after Smooth _Brucella spp_ (not just\n_B. abortus_) and _Y. enterocolitica_ O:9 infection both in animals\nand humans has been well documented. This is why the antibody test\nfor _Y. enterocolitica_ O:9 is likely to be a cross-reaction, unless\nthe diagnosis of the extraintestinal form of yersiniosis can be\nfurther substantiated.\n3) In the veterinary field\n-------------------------\nBrucellosis control or eradication programs are implemented\nworldwide, mainly for cattle, sheep, goats, and pigs. In this\ncontext, the objective is not primarily to diagnose _Y.\nenterocolitica_ O:9 infections, but to exclude brucellosis. In other\nwords, the _Y. enterocolitica_ O:9 status will not tell anything\nabout the brucellosis status. In this context, serology seems so far\nunable to differentiate beyond certain smooth _Brucella spp_\ninfection and _Y. enterocolitica_ O:9 infection. This is why\nmeasurement of the cell-mediated immunity via the brucellosis skin\ntest is the only means by which one can beyond any reasonable doubt\ndifferentiate smooth _Brucella spp_ infection and _Y. enterocolitica_\nO:9 infection (2).\nMay I take this opportunity to thank for you for the invaluable\nsource of information ProMED is, particularly for those living and\nworking somewhere \"at the end of the world.\"\n1. Refai M: Incidence and control of brucellosis in the Near East\nregion. Vet Microbiol. 2002; 90:81-110.\n2. Godfroid JC, Saegerman V, Wellemans K, et al: How to substantiate\neradication of bovine brucellosis when aspecific serological\nreactions occur in the course of brucellosis testing. Vet. Microbiol.\n2002; 90:461-77.\n--\nProf. Jacques Godfroid DVM, MSc, PhD\nUniversity of Pretoria\nFaculty of Veterinary Science\nOnderstepoort, South Africa\n<jacques.godfroid@up.ac.za>\n[ProMED thanks Professor Godfroid both for his comments and his kind\nwords. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nBrucellosis, human - Czech Republic ex Turkey 20051017.3030\nBrucellosis, human, bovine - Venezuela 20051007.2932\nBrucellosis, human, caprine - Thailand (Kanchanaburi) 20050907.2646\nBrucellosis, human - Russia (Dagestan) 20050826.2523\nBrucellosis, human - Kyrgyzstan (Jelalabad) 20050712.1975\nBrucellosis, human - Bosnia & Herzegovina 20050614.1658\nYersiniosis - Russia (Siberia) 20050427.1169\nBrucellosis, human - Bulgaria ex Greece 20050328.0896\nYersiniosis - Russia (Far East) 20050202.0359\n2004\n----\nBrucellosis, human & caprines - Saudi Arabia (Jizan) 20040716.1926\nBrucellosis, humans & caprines - Lebanon 20040715.1907\n2003\n----\nYersiniosis, contaminated blood - Japan 20031009.2538\n2002\n----\nYersiniosis - Russia (Far East) 20020206.3499\n1999\n----\nYersinia pseudotuberculosis - Canada (BC) (02) 19990504.0734\nYersiniosis - Russia (Kemerovo) 19990405.0551\n1998\n----\nYersinia pseudotuberculosis - Canada (BC) 19981201.2314\n1997\n----\nYersinia pseudotuberculosis - Finland 19971003.2081\nYersinia - Japan: imported (02) 19970702.1421\nYersinia - Japan: imported 19970702.1410\n1996\n----\nYersiniosis - Buffalo, NY, USA 19960124.0167\n............................ll/pg/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The woman was\ninfected in Mainland China.\nA human case of brucellosis\n----------------------------\nIn late Oct 2004, CHP's Public Health Laboratory Services Branch (PHLSB)\nconfirmed a case of human brucellosis. The patient was a 34-year-old\nhousewife, who suffered from recurrent headache and fever since mid Sep\n2004. She was admitted to a hospital on 7 Oct 2004 because of pyrexia of\nunknown origin without other focal symptoms or signs. Blood tests were\ngrossly normal except for liver derangement (ALT 280). Blood culture\nyielded slow-growing Gram-negative coccobacilli, which was later identified\nas _Brucella_ species in PHLSB, with species identification result\npending. The patient recalled a history of handling and consuming sheep\nplacenta outside Hong Kong. She was discharged on 26 Oct 2004 and put on\nantimicrobial therapy including doxycycline and rifamipicin. Laboratory\nstaff who handled the specimens were asymptomatic.\n--\nJoanne Leung\n<leung_powah@yahoo.com.hk>\n[Human contact with the placentas or abortuses of infected animals is a\nwell-recognized risk factor for acquisition of brucellosis. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nBrucellosis - China 20041222.3371\nBrucella melitensis, ovine - Croatia: susp. 20040906.2493\nBrucellosis, ovine, contaminated agar - USA: alert 20040820.2315\nBrucellosis, human, livestock - Kazakhstan 20040803.2119\nBrucellosis - Algeria (El-Aghuat) 20040401.0883\nBrucellosis, human, livestock - Russia (Moscow) 20040102.0008\n2003\n----\nBrucellosis - Thailand (Ratchaburi) (02) 20030912.2304\nBrucellosis - Thailand (Ratchaburi) 20030910.2280\nBrucellosis, human - Spain (Granada) 20030821.2097\nBrucellosis - Tajikistan: RFI 20030803.1909\n2002\n---\nBrucellosis, human - New Zealand (02) 20020329.3838\nBrucellosis, human - New Zealand 20020316.3756\n2001\n----\nAnthrax & brucellosis - Tajikistan (Khatlon) 20010706.1292\nBrucellosis, human, livestock - Kazakhstan (North) 20010603.1093\nBrucellosis, cattle - Azerbaijan 20010615.1153\n2000\n---\nBrucellosis - India (Calcutta) (02) 20000826.1426\nBrucellosis - India (Calcutta) 20000823.1407\n1999\n----\nBrucellosis, anthrax, human - Kazakhstan (Kzyl-Orda) 19991011.1818\nBrucellosis, human - Kazakhstan (Kzyl-Orda) 19990817.1421\n1996\n---\nBrucellosis, marine mammals 19960625.1166\nBrucellosis, ovine: RFI 19960524.0977\n1995\n---\nBrucellosis: imported 19950830.0769\nRe: Brucellosis (cat-borne) - Siberia 19950306.0103\nRe: Flu & brucellosis - Siberia 19950302.0095\n........mpp/ll/pg/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\n* *\n* Please support the 2004 ProMED-mail Internet-a-thon! The woman was\ninfected in Mainland China.\nA human case of brucellosis\n----------------------------\nIn late Oct 2004, CHP's Public Health Laboratory Services Branch (PHLSB)\nconfirmed a case of human brucellosis. The patient was a 34-year-old\nhousewife, who suffered from recurrent headache and fever since mid Sep\n2004. She was admitted to a hospital on 7 Oct 2004 because of pyrexia of\nunknown origin without other focal symptoms or signs. Blood tests were\ngrossly normal except for liver derangement (ALT 280). Blood culture\nyielded slow-growing Gram-negative coccobacilli, which was later identified\nas _Brucella_ species in PHLSB, with species identification result\npending. The patient recalled a history of handling and consuming sheep\nplacenta outside Hong Kong. She was discharged on 26 Oct 2004 and put on\nantimicrobial therapy including doxycycline and rifamipicin. Laboratory\nstaff who handled the specimens were asymptomatic.\n--\nJoanne Leung\n<leung_powah@yahoo.com.hk>\n[Human contact with the placentas or abortuses of infected animals is a\nwell-recognized risk factor for acquisition of brucellosis. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nBrucellosis - China 20041222.3371\nBrucella melitensis, ovine - Croatia: susp. 20040906.2493\nBrucellosis, ovine, contaminated agar - USA: alert 20040820.2315\nBrucellosis, human, livestock - Kazakhstan 20040803.2119\nBrucellosis - Algeria (El-Aghuat) 20040401.0883\nBrucellosis, human, livestock - Russia (Moscow) 20040102.0008\n2003\n----\nBrucellosis - Thailand (Ratchaburi) (02) 20030912.2304\nBrucellosis - Thailand (Ratchaburi) 20030910.2280\nBrucellosis, human - Spain (Granada) 20030821.2097\nBrucellosis - Tajikistan: RFI 20030803.1909\n2002\n---\nBrucellosis, human - New Zealand (02) 20020329.3838\nBrucellosis, human - New Zealand 20020316.3756\n2001\n----\nAnthrax & brucellosis - Tajikistan (Khatlon) 20010706.1292\nBrucellosis, human, livestock - Kazakhstan (North) 20010603.1093\nBrucellosis, cattle - Azerbaijan 20010615.1153\n2000\n---\nBrucellosis - India (Calcutta) (02) 20000826.1426\nBrucellosis - India (Calcutta) 20000823.1407\n1999\n----\nBrucellosis, anthrax, human - Kazakhstan (Kzyl-Orda) 19991011.1818\nBrucellosis, human - Kazakhstan (Kzyl-Orda) 19990817.1421\n1996\n---\nBrucellosis, marine mammals 19960625.1166\nBrucellosis, ovine: RFI 19960524.0977\n1995\n---\nBrucellosis: imported 19950830.0769\nRe: Brucellosis (cat-borne) - Siberia 19950306.0103\nRe: Flu & brucellosis - Siberia 19950302.0095\n........mpp/ll/pg/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\n* *\n* Please support the 2004 ProMED-mail Internet-a-thon! The patient was a 34-year-old\nhousewife, who suffered from recurrent headache and fever since mid Sep\n2004. Laboratory\nstaff who handled the specimens were asymptomatic.\n--\nJoanne Leung\n<leung_powah@yahoo.com.hk>\n[Human contact with the placentas or abortuses of infected animals is a\nwell-recognized risk factor for acquisition of brucellosis. - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nBrucellosis - China 20041222.3371\nBrucella melitensis, ovine - Croatia: susp. 20040906.2493\nBrucellosis, ovine, contaminated agar - USA: alert 20040820.2315\nBrucellosis, human, livestock - Kazakhstan 20040803.2119\nBrucellosis - Algeria (El-Aghuat) 20040401.0883\nBrucellosis, human, livestock - Russia (Moscow) 20040102.0008\n2003\n----\nBrucellosis - Thailand (Ratchaburi) (02) 20030912.2304\nBrucellosis - Thailand (Ratchaburi) 20030910.2280\nBrucellosis, human - Spain (Granada) 20030821.2097\nBrucellosis - Tajikistan: RFI 20030803.1909\n2002\n---\nBrucellosis, human - New Zealand (02) 20020329.3838\nBrucellosis, human - New Zealand 20020316.3756\n2001\n----\nAnthrax & brucellosis - Tajikistan (Khatlon) 20010706.1292\nBrucellosis, human, livestock - Kazakhstan (North) 20010603.1093\nBrucellosis, cattle - Azerbaijan 20010615.1153\n2000\n---\nBrucellosis - India (Calcutta) (02) 20000826.1426\nBrucellosis - India (Calcutta) 20000823.1407\n1999\n----\nBrucellosis, anthrax, human - Kazakhstan (Kzyl-Orda) 19991011.1818\nBrucellosis, human - Kazakhstan (Kzyl-Orda) 19990817.1421\n1996\n---\nBrucellosis, marine mammals 19960625.1166\nBrucellosis, ovine: RFI 19960524.0977\n1995\n---\nBrucellosis: imported 19950830.0769\nRe: Brucellosis (cat-borne) - Siberia 19950306.0103\nRe: Flu & brucellosis - Siberia 19950302.0095\n........mpp/ll/pg/mpp\n\n*##########################################################*\n************************************************************\n* *\n* Please support the 2004 ProMED-mail Internet-a-thon! The reason for that is their fear that their animals will be\ndestroyed by the Veterinary Services. During 2003, there was an outbreak in\nthe northern area, which was more heavily infected than the south.\n---\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[_Brucella melitensis_ is endemic throughout all countries in the\nMediterranean basin; Algeria is known to be one of the most severely\naffected countries. During 2002, 452 outbreaks (in animals, mostly goats)\nhave been reported. Tourists to this part of the world should be aware of\nthe risks associated with the consumption of (unpasteurized) dairy\nproducts. -Mod.AS]\n[This infection, a bacterial zoonosis, is classified among the category B\nbiowarfare agents. Natural transmission to humans occurs after\noccupational exposure or through ingestion of contaminated food\nproducts. Although brucellosis has become a rare entity in the United\nStates and many industrialized nations because of animal vaccination\nprograms, this condition remains a significant health problem in many\ndeveloping countries.\nEach species of Brucella has a specific animal reservoir in which chronic\ndisease is present. The bacilli tend to localize in the reproductive organs\nof the animals, causing sterility and abortions, and are shed in large\nnumbers in the animal's urine, milk, and placental fluid.\nThis localization allows for efficient spread to farmers, veterinarians,\nslaughterhouse workers, and consumers.\nAmong the 4 species known to cause disease in humans, _Brucella melitensis_\n(from goats, sheep, or camels) may be the most virulent, producing the most\nsevere and acute cases of brucellosis with disabling complications. A\nprolonged course of illness, which may be associated with suppurative\ndestructive lesions, is associated with _B. suis_ (from feral or\ncommercially raised pigs) infection. _B. abortus_ (from cattle, buffalo,\nand camels) is associated with mild-to-moderate sporadic disease that is\nrarely associated with complications. _B. canis_ has a disease course that\nis indistinguishable from _B. abortus_ infection.- Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nBrucellosis, human, livestock - Russia (Moscow) 20040102.0008\n2003\n----\nBrucellosis - Thailand (Ratchaburi)20030910.2280\nBrucellosis, human - Mexico: Background 20030808.1953\n2002\n----\nBrucellosis, human - New Zealand (02)20020329.3838\nBrucellosis, human - New Zealand 20020316.3756\n2001\n----\nBrucellosis, human, livestock - Kazakhstan (North) 20010603.1093\n1999\n----\nBrucellosis - Russia (Chechnya): alert 19991108.1999\nBrucellosis, human - Kazakhstan (Kzyl-Orda) 19990817.1421\n1997\n----\nBrucellosis, hunters (deer urine source?) - USA 19970802.1603\n.....................................jw/arn/ll/pg/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["brucellosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2004-03-15 00:00:00", "2004-03-15 00:00:00", "2003-03-15 00:00:00", "2002-03-15 00:00:00", "2002-03-15 00:00:00", "2001-03-15 00:00:00", "1999-03-15 00:00:00", "1997-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Malta", "country": "Malta"}, {"location": "Chechnya", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "the United \n States", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Algeria", "country": "Algeria"}, {"location": "Moscow", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "New Zealand", "country": "New Zealand"}, {"location": "Kazakhstan", "country": "Kazakhstan"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2206563", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Brucellosis, caprine, ovine - Croatia", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2206563", "date": "2004-04-01 23:50:00", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS - ALGERIA (EL-AGHUAT)\n********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Tue, 29 Mar 2004\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Elkhabar, 29 Mar 2004 [translation: Dr. Houssein Ayoub; edited]\n<http://www.elkhabar.com/>\n\nEl-Aghuat: 45 cases of Malta fever\n-----------------------------------\nMalta fever has returned to northwestern El-Aghuat where 45 cases have been\nreported there, following the consumption of [unpasteurized] goat's milk.\nMany stock-owners do not report their flocks even if they know the animals\nare infected. The reason for that is their fear that their animals will be\ndestroyed by the Veterinary Services. During 2003, there was an outbreak in\nthe northern area, which was more heavily infected than the south.\n---\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[_Brucella melitensis_ is endemic throughout all countries in the\nMediterranean basin; Algeria is known to be one of the most severely\naffected countries. During 2002, 452 outbreaks (in animals, mostly goats)\nhave been reported. Tourists to this part of the world should be aware of\nthe risks associated with the consumption of (unpasteurized) dairy\nproducts. -Mod.AS]\n[This infection, a bacterial zoonosis, is classified among the category B\nbiowarfare agents. Natural transmission to humans occurs after\noccupational exposure or through ingestion of contaminated food\nproducts. Although brucellosis has become a rare entity in the United\nStates and many industrialized nations because of animal vaccination\nprograms, this condition remains a significant health problem in many\ndeveloping countries.\nEach species of Brucella has a specific animal reservoir in which chronic\ndisease is present. The bacilli tend to localize in the reproductive organs\nof the animals, causing sterility and abortions, and are shed in large\nnumbers in the animal's urine, milk, and placental fluid.\nThis localization allows for efficient spread to farmers, veterinarians,\nslaughterhouse workers, and consumers.\nAmong the 4 species known to cause disease in humans, _Brucella melitensis_\n(from goats, sheep, or camels) may be the most virulent, producing the most\nsevere and acute cases of brucellosis with disabling complications. A\nprolonged course of illness, which may be associated with suppurative\ndestructive lesions, is associated with _B. suis_ (from feral or\ncommercially raised pigs) infection. _B. abortus_ (from cattle, buffalo,\nand camels) is associated with mild-to-moderate sporadic disease that is\nrarely associated with complications. _B. canis_ has a disease course that\nis indistinguishable from _B. abortus_ infection.- Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nBrucellosis, human, livestock - Russia (Moscow) 20040102.0008\n2003\n----\nBrucellosis - Thailand (Ratchaburi)20030910.2280\nBrucellosis, human - Mexico: Background 20030808.1953\n2002\n----\nBrucellosis, human - New Zealand (02)20020329.3838\nBrucellosis, human - New Zealand 20020316.3756\n2001\n----\nBrucellosis, human, livestock - Kazakhstan (North) 20010603.1093\n1999\n----\nBrucellosis - Russia (Chechnya): alert 19991108.1999\nBrucellosis, human - Kazakhstan (Kzyl-Orda) 19990817.1421\n1997\n----\nBrucellosis, hunters (deer urine source?) - USA 19970802.1603\n.....................................jw/arn/ll/pg/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reason for that is their fear that their animals will be\ndestroyed by the Veterinary Services. During 2003, there was an outbreak in\nthe northern area, which was more heavily infected than the south.\n---\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[_Brucella melitensis_ is endemic throughout all countries in the\nMediterranean basin; Algeria is known to be one of the most severely\naffected countries. During 2002, 452 outbreaks (in animals, mostly goats)\nhave been reported. Tourists to this part of the world should be aware of\nthe risks associated with the consumption of (unpasteurized) dairy\nproducts. -Mod.AS]\n[This infection, a bacterial zoonosis, is classified among the category B\nbiowarfare agents. Natural transmission to humans occurs after\noccupational exposure or through ingestion of contaminated food\nproducts. Although brucellosis has become a rare entity in the United\nStates and many industrialized nations because of animal vaccination\nprograms, this condition remains a significant health problem in many\ndeveloping countries.\nEach species of Brucella has a specific animal reservoir in which chronic\ndisease is present. The bacilli tend to localize in the reproductive organs\nof the animals, causing sterility and abortions, and are shed in large\nnumbers in the animal's urine, milk, and placental fluid.\nThis localization allows for efficient spread to farmers, veterinarians,\nslaughterhouse workers, and consumers.\nAmong the 4 species known to cause disease in humans, _Brucella melitensis_\n(from goats, sheep, or camels) may be the most virulent, producing the most\nsevere and acute cases of brucellosis with disabling complications. A\nprolonged course of illness, which may be associated with suppurative\ndestructive lesions, is associated with _B. suis_ (from feral or\ncommercially raised pigs) infection. _B. abortus_ (from cattle, buffalo,\nand camels) is associated with mild-to-moderate sporadic disease that is\nrarely associated with complications. _B. canis_ has a disease course that\nis indistinguishable from _B. abortus_ infection.- Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nBrucellosis, human, livestock - Russia (Moscow) 20040102.0008\n2003\n----\nBrucellosis - Thailand (Ratchaburi)20030910.2280\nBrucellosis, human - Mexico: Background 20030808.1953\n2002\n----\nBrucellosis, human - New Zealand (02)20020329.3838\nBrucellosis, human - New Zealand 20020316.3756\n2001\n----\nBrucellosis, human, livestock - Kazakhstan (North) 20010603.1093\n1999\n----\nBrucellosis - Russia (Chechnya): alert 19991108.1999\nBrucellosis, human - Kazakhstan (Kzyl-Orda) 19990817.1421\n1997\n----\nBrucellosis, hunters (deer urine source?) - USA 19970802.1603\n.....................................jw/arn/ll/pg/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["brucellosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2004-03-15 00:00:00", "2004-03-15 00:00:00", "2003-03-15 00:00:00", "2002-03-15 00:00:00", "2002-03-15 00:00:00", "2001-03-15 00:00:00", "1999-03-15 00:00:00", "1997-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Malta", "country": "Malta"}, {"location": "Chechnya", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "the United \n States", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Algeria", "country": "Algeria"}, {"location": "Moscow", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "New Zealand", "country": "New Zealand"}, {"location": "Kazakhstan", "country": "Kazakhstan"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2205503", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Brucellosis, bovine - UK (Cornwall) (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2205503", "date": "2004-04-01 23:50:00", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS - ALGERIA (EL-AGHUAT)\n********************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Tue, 29 Mar 2004\nFrom: ProMED-mail <promed@promedmail.org>\nSource: Elkhabar, 29 Mar 2004 [translation: Dr. Houssein Ayoub; edited]\n<http://www.elkhabar.com/>\n\nEl-Aghuat: 45 cases of Malta fever\n-----------------------------------\nMalta fever has returned to northwestern El-Aghuat where 45 cases have been\nreported there, following the consumption of [unpasteurized] goat's milk.\nMany stock-owners do not report their flocks even if they know the animals\nare infected. The reason for that is their fear that their animals will be\ndestroyed by the Veterinary Services. During 2003, there was an outbreak in\nthe northern area, which was more heavily infected than the south.\n---\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[_Brucella melitensis_ is endemic throughout all countries in the\nMediterranean basin; Algeria is known to be one of the most severely\naffected countries. During 2002, 452 outbreaks (in animals, mostly goats)\nhave been reported. Tourists to this part of the world should be aware of\nthe risks associated with the consumption of (unpasteurized) dairy\nproducts. -Mod.AS]\n[This infection, a bacterial zoonosis, is classified among the category B\nbiowarfare agents. Natural transmission to humans occurs after\noccupational exposure or through ingestion of contaminated food\nproducts. Although brucellosis has become a rare entity in the United\nStates and many industrialized nations because of animal vaccination\nprograms, this condition remains a significant health problem in many\ndeveloping countries.\nEach species of Brucella has a specific animal reservoir in which chronic\ndisease is present. The bacilli tend to localize in the reproductive organs\nof the animals, causing sterility and abortions, and are shed in large\nnumbers in the animal's urine, milk, and placental fluid.\nThis localization allows for efficient spread to farmers, veterinarians,\nslaughterhouse workers, and consumers.\nAmong the 4 species known to cause disease in humans, _Brucella melitensis_\n(from goats, sheep, or camels) may be the most virulent, producing the most\nsevere and acute cases of brucellosis with disabling complications. A\nprolonged course of illness, which may be associated with suppurative\ndestructive lesions, is associated with _B. suis_ (from feral or\ncommercially raised pigs) infection. _B. abortus_ (from cattle, buffalo,\nand camels) is associated with mild-to-moderate sporadic disease that is\nrarely associated with complications. _B. canis_ has a disease course that\nis indistinguishable from _B. abortus_ infection.- Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nBrucellosis, human, livestock - Russia (Moscow) 20040102.0008\n2003\n----\nBrucellosis - Thailand (Ratchaburi)20030910.2280\nBrucellosis, human - Mexico: Background 20030808.1953\n2002\n----\nBrucellosis, human - New Zealand (02)20020329.3838\nBrucellosis, human - New Zealand 20020316.3756\n2001\n----\nBrucellosis, human, livestock - Kazakhstan (North) 20010603.1093\n1999\n----\nBrucellosis - Russia (Chechnya): alert 19991108.1999\nBrucellosis, human - Kazakhstan (Kzyl-Orda) 19990817.1421\n1997\n----\nBrucellosis, hunters (deer urine source?) - USA 19970802.1603\n.....................................jw/arn/ll/pg/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reason for that is their fear that their animals will be\ndestroyed by the Veterinary Services. During 2003, there was an outbreak in\nthe northern area, which was more heavily infected than the south.\n---\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[_Brucella melitensis_ is endemic throughout all countries in the\nMediterranean basin; Algeria is known to be one of the most severely\naffected countries. During 2002, 452 outbreaks (in animals, mostly goats)\nhave been reported. Tourists to this part of the world should be aware of\nthe risks associated with the consumption of (unpasteurized) dairy\nproducts. -Mod.AS]\n[This infection, a bacterial zoonosis, is classified among the category B\nbiowarfare agents. Natural transmission to humans occurs after\noccupational exposure or through ingestion of contaminated food\nproducts. Although brucellosis has become a rare entity in the United\nStates and many industrialized nations because of animal vaccination\nprograms, this condition remains a significant health problem in many\ndeveloping countries.\nEach species of Brucella has a specific animal reservoir in which chronic\ndisease is present. The bacilli tend to localize in the reproductive organs\nof the animals, causing sterility and abortions, and are shed in large\nnumbers in the animal's urine, milk, and placental fluid.\nThis localization allows for efficient spread to farmers, veterinarians,\nslaughterhouse workers, and consumers.\nAmong the 4 species known to cause disease in humans, _Brucella melitensis_\n(from goats, sheep, or camels) may be the most virulent, producing the most\nsevere and acute cases of brucellosis with disabling complications. A\nprolonged course of illness, which may be associated with suppurative\ndestructive lesions, is associated with _B. suis_ (from feral or\ncommercially raised pigs) infection. _B. abortus_ (from cattle, buffalo,\nand camels) is associated with mild-to-moderate sporadic disease that is\nrarely associated with complications. _B. canis_ has a disease course that\nis indistinguishable from _B. abortus_ infection.- Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nBrucellosis, human, livestock - Russia (Moscow) 20040102.0008\n2003\n----\nBrucellosis - Thailand (Ratchaburi)20030910.2280\nBrucellosis, human - Mexico: Background 20030808.1953\n2002\n----\nBrucellosis, human - New Zealand (02)20020329.3838\nBrucellosis, human - New Zealand 20020316.3756\n2001\n----\nBrucellosis, human, livestock - Kazakhstan (North) 20010603.1093\n1999\n----\nBrucellosis - Russia (Chechnya): alert 19991108.1999\nBrucellosis, human - Kazakhstan (Kzyl-Orda) 19990817.1421\n1997\n----\nBrucellosis, hunters (deer urine source?) - USA 19970802.1603\n.....................................jw/arn/ll/pg/dk\n\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Nonetheless, these numbers are clearly\ntending to decrease.\nHowever, during May and June 2003, there was an epidemic outbreak in Motril\n(Granada), with at least 27 cases linked to the consumption of fresh cheese\nacquired directly from the farmers who produced it and sold it in the\nmunicipality.\nThe cases of brucellosis as a result of drinking [unpasteurized - Mod.LL]\nmilk (most frequently goat milk), or its fresh byproducts (generally cheese\nand sometimes cottage cheese) are ever more rare in Granada.\nDuring the last decade, 55 percent of the cases registered in Granada were\nattributed to direct contact with livestock, 21 percent to the intake of\ninfected dairy products, 18 percent to mixed causes, and in 6 percent\nair-borne transmission was suspected.\nThe data indicates that brucellosis continues to be a public health concern.\nThere are preventive measures, but their success depends on the cooperation\nof various agencies and institutions, as well as on the modification of\npersonal and hygiene habits.\nAlthough there is no brucellosis vaccine for humans, there is one for the\nanimals, which constitute its natural reservoir. In Spain, the disease\ncurrently affects goats and sheep -- bovines are usually free of the disease.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Following is the historical series of the reportable diseases section of\nthe Spanish National Epidemiology Center, regarding the incidence of human\nbrucellosis in Andalusia: 1997 (589), 1998 (476), 1999 (691), 2000 (498),\n2001 (441), and 2002 (428). Additional information is available at:\n<http://193.146.50.130/ve/ve.htm>. - PN]\n[The 3 major species of the genus Brucella are _suis_ (from swine),\n_abortus_ (from cattle) and _melitensis_ (from goats). Additionally, _B.\ncanis_ from dogs may be acquired by humans - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nBrucellosis, human - Mexico: Background 20030808.1953\n2002\n----\nBrucellosis, human - New Zealand (02)20020329.3838\nBrucellosis, human - New Zealand 20020316.3756\n2001\n----\nBrucellosis - USA (Arkansas) ex Mexico: alert 20010805.1539\nBrucellosis, human, livestock - Kazakhstan (North)20010603.1093\n1999\n----\nBrucellosis, anthrax, human - Kazakhstan (Kzyl-Orda) 19991011.1818\n1997\n----\nBrucellosis, hunters (deer urine source?) - USA 19970802.1603\n....................ll/pg/jw\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. SPAIN", "country": "Spain"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2205419", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Brucellosis, bovine - UK (Cornwall)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2205419", "date": "2003-08-21 23:50:00", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS, HUMAN - SPAIN (GRANADA)\n****************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Mon, 18 Aug 2003\nFrom: Pablo Nart <p.nart@ntlworld.com>\nSource: En la web, Spain, 14 Aug 2003 [translated by Maria Jacobs,\nProMED-ESP] [edited]\n<http://salud.enlaweb.com/ELW_ET_VIEWreg.asp?sch_Date=20030814133906>\n\nSo far this year, the provincial health district of Granada has detected 27\ncases of brucellosis, a disease also known as Malta fever [as well as\nMediterranean fever, remittent fever, and undulant fever - Mod.LL] that\naffects mainly those in direct contact with animals or animal tissue.\nAs in previous years, the majority of cases have been detected in the\nnortheastern and southern sanitary districts of the province, with an\naverage of 80 cases per year. Nonetheless, these numbers are clearly\ntending to decrease.\nHowever, during May and June 2003, there was an epidemic outbreak in Motril\n(Granada), with at least 27 cases linked to the consumption of fresh cheese\nacquired directly from the farmers who produced it and sold it in the\nmunicipality.\nThe cases of brucellosis as a result of drinking [unpasteurized - Mod.LL]\nmilk (most frequently goat milk), or its fresh byproducts (generally cheese\nand sometimes cottage cheese) are ever more rare in Granada.\nDuring the last decade, 55 percent of the cases registered in Granada were\nattributed to direct contact with livestock, 21 percent to the intake of\ninfected dairy products, 18 percent to mixed causes, and in 6 percent\nair-borne transmission was suspected.\nThe data indicates that brucellosis continues to be a public health concern.\nThere are preventive measures, but their success depends on the cooperation\nof various agencies and institutions, as well as on the modification of\npersonal and hygiene habits.\nAlthough there is no brucellosis vaccine for humans, there is one for the\nanimals, which constitute its natural reservoir. In Spain, the disease\ncurrently affects goats and sheep -- bovines are usually free of the disease.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Following is the historical series of the reportable diseases section of\nthe Spanish National Epidemiology Center, regarding the incidence of human\nbrucellosis in Andalusia: 1997 (589), 1998 (476), 1999 (691), 2000 (498),\n2001 (441), and 2002 (428). Additional information is available at:\n<http://193.146.50.130/ve/ve.htm>. - PN]\n[The 3 major species of the genus Brucella are _suis_ (from swine),\n_abortus_ (from cattle) and _melitensis_ (from goats). Additionally, _B.\ncanis_ from dogs may be acquired by humans - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nBrucellosis, human - Mexico: Background 20030808.1953\n2002\n----\nBrucellosis, human - New Zealand (02)20020329.3838\nBrucellosis, human - New Zealand 20020316.3756\n2001\n----\nBrucellosis - USA (Arkansas) ex Mexico: alert 20010805.1539\nBrucellosis, human, livestock - Kazakhstan (North)20010603.1093\n1999\n----\nBrucellosis, anthrax, human - Kazakhstan (Kzyl-Orda) 19991011.1818\n1997\n----\nBrucellosis, hunters (deer urine source?) - USA 19970802.1603\n....................ll/pg/jw\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. SPAIN (GRANADA)\n****************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Mon, 18 Aug 2003\nFrom: Pablo Nart <p.nart@ntlworld.com>\nSource: En la web, Spain, 14 Aug 2003 [translated by Maria Jacobs,\nProMED-ESP] [edited]\n<http://salud.enlaweb.com/ELW_ET_VIEWreg.asp?sch_Date=20030814133906>\n\nSo far this year, the provincial health district of Granada has detected 27\ncases of brucellosis, a disease also known as Malta fever [as well as\nMediterranean fever, remittent fever, and undulant fever - Mod.LL] that\naffects mainly those in direct contact with animals or animal tissue.\nAs in previous years, the majority of cases have been detected in the\nnortheastern and southern sanitary districts of the province, with an\naverage of 80 cases per year. Nonetheless, these numbers are clearly\ntending to decrease.\nHowever, during May and June 2003, there was an epidemic outbreak in Motril\n(Granada), with at least 27 cases linked to the consumption of fresh cheese\nacquired directly from the farmers who produced it and sold it in the\nmunicipality.\nThe cases of brucellosis as a result of drinking [unpasteurized - Mod.LL]\nmilk (most frequently goat milk), or its fresh byproducts (generally cheese\nand sometimes cottage cheese) are ever more rare in Granada.\nDuring the last decade, 55 percent of the cases registered in Granada were\nattributed to direct contact with livestock, 21 percent to the intake of\ninfected dairy products, 18 percent to mixed causes, and in 6 percent\nair-borne transmission was suspected.\nThe data indicates that brucellosis continues to be a public health concern.\nThere are preventive measures, but their success depends on the cooperation\nof various agencies and institutions, as well as on the modification of\npersonal and hygiene habits.\nAlthough there is no brucellosis vaccine for humans, there is one for the\nanimals, which constitute its natural reservoir. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["brucellosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2003-08-14 00:00:00", "1997-03-15 00:00:00", "1998-03-15 00:00:00", "1999-03-15 00:00:00", "2000-03-15 00:00:00", "2001-03-15 00:00:00", "2002-03-15 00:00:00", "2002-03-15 00:00:00", "2001-03-15 00:00:00", "1999-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Malta", "country": "Malta"}, {"location": "Granada", "country": "Grenada"}, {"location": "Kazakhstan", "country": "Kazakhstan"}, {"location": "Arkansas", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Spain", "country": "Spain"}, {"location": "Andalusia", "country": "Spain"}, {"location": "Mexico", "country": "Mexico"}, {"location": "New Zealand", "country": "New Zealand"}, {"location": "HUMAN - SPAIN", "country": "Spain"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2204658", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Brucellosis, cattle - USA (Texas)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2204658", "date": "2003-08-21 23:50:00", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS, HUMAN - SPAIN (GRANADA)\n****************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Mon, 18 Aug 2003\nFrom: Pablo Nart <p.nart@ntlworld.com>\nSource: En la web, Spain, 14 Aug 2003 [translated by Maria Jacobs,\nProMED-ESP] [edited]\n<http://salud.enlaweb.com/ELW_ET_VIEWreg.asp?sch_Date=20030814133906>\n\nSo far this year, the provincial health district of Granada has detected 27\ncases of brucellosis, a disease also known as Malta fever [as well as\nMediterranean fever, remittent fever, and undulant fever - Mod.LL] that\naffects mainly those in direct contact with animals or animal tissue.\nAs in previous years, the majority of cases have been detected in the\nnortheastern and southern sanitary districts of the province, with an\naverage of 80 cases per year. Nonetheless, these numbers are clearly\ntending to decrease.\nHowever, during May and June 2003, there was an epidemic outbreak in Motril\n(Granada), with at least 27 cases linked to the consumption of fresh cheese\nacquired directly from the farmers who produced it and sold it in the\nmunicipality.\nThe cases of brucellosis as a result of drinking [unpasteurized - Mod.LL]\nmilk (most frequently goat milk), or its fresh byproducts (generally cheese\nand sometimes cottage cheese) are ever more rare in Granada.\nDuring the last decade, 55 percent of the cases registered in Granada were\nattributed to direct contact with livestock, 21 percent to the intake of\ninfected dairy products, 18 percent to mixed causes, and in 6 percent\nair-borne transmission was suspected.\nThe data indicates that brucellosis continues to be a public health concern.\nThere are preventive measures, but their success depends on the cooperation\nof various agencies and institutions, as well as on the modification of\npersonal and hygiene habits.\nAlthough there is no brucellosis vaccine for humans, there is one for the\nanimals, which constitute its natural reservoir. In Spain, the disease\ncurrently affects goats and sheep -- bovines are usually free of the disease.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Following is the historical series of the reportable diseases section of\nthe Spanish National Epidemiology Center, regarding the incidence of human\nbrucellosis in Andalusia: 1997 (589), 1998 (476), 1999 (691), 2000 (498),\n2001 (441), and 2002 (428). Additional information is available at:\n<http://193.146.50.130/ve/ve.htm>. - PN]\n[The 3 major species of the genus Brucella are _suis_ (from swine),\n_abortus_ (from cattle) and _melitensis_ (from goats). Additionally, _B.\ncanis_ from dogs may be acquired by humans - Mod.LL]\nSee Also\nBrucellosis, human - Mexico: Background 20030808.1953\n2002\n----\nBrucellosis, human - New Zealand (02)20020329.3838\nBrucellosis, human - New Zealand 20020316.3756\n2001\n----\nBrucellosis - USA (Arkansas) ex Mexico: alert 20010805.1539\nBrucellosis, human, livestock - Kazakhstan (North)20010603.1093\n1999\n----\nBrucellosis, anthrax, human - Kazakhstan (Kzyl-Orda) 19991011.1818\n1997\n----\nBrucellosis, hunters (deer urine source?) - USA 19970802.1603\n....................ll/pg/jw\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. SPAIN", "country": "Spain"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2204551", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Foot & mouth disease, brucellosis - Thailand (Ratchaburi)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2204551", "date": "2003-08-21 23:50:00", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS, HUMAN - SPAIN (GRANADA)\n****************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Mon, 18 Aug 2003\nFrom: Pablo Nart <p.nart@ntlworld.com>\nSource: En la web, Spain, 14 Aug 2003 [translated by Maria Jacobs,\nProMED-ESP] [edited]\n<http://salud.enlaweb.com/ELW_ET_VIEWreg.asp?sch_Date=20030814133906>\n\nSo far this year, the provincial health district of Granada has detected 27\ncases of brucellosis, a disease also known as Malta fever [as well as\nMediterranean fever, remittent fever, and undulant fever - Mod.LL] that\naffects mainly those in direct contact with animals or animal tissue.\nAs in previous years, the majority of cases have been detected in the\nnortheastern and southern sanitary districts of the province, with an\naverage of 80 cases per year. Nonetheless, these numbers are clearly\ntending to decrease.\nHowever, during May and June 2003, there was an epidemic outbreak in Motril\n(Granada), with at least 27 cases linked to the consumption of fresh cheese\nacquired directly from the farmers who produced it and sold it in the\nmunicipality.\nThe cases of brucellosis as a result of drinking [unpasteurized - Mod.LL]\nmilk (most frequently goat milk), or its fresh byproducts (generally cheese\nand sometimes cottage cheese) are ever more rare in Granada.\nDuring the last decade, 55 percent of the cases registered in Granada were\nattributed to direct contact with livestock, 21 percent to the intake of\ninfected dairy products, 18 percent to mixed causes, and in 6 percent\nair-borne transmission was suspected.\nThe data indicates that brucellosis continues to be a public health concern.\nThere are preventive measures, but their success depends on the cooperation\nof various agencies and institutions, as well as on the modification of\npersonal and hygiene habits.\nAlthough there is no brucellosis vaccine for humans, there is one for the\nanimals, which constitute its natural reservoir. In Spain, the disease\ncurrently affects goats and sheep -- bovines are usually free of the disease.\n--\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Following is the historical series of the reportable diseases section of\nthe Spanish National Epidemiology Center, regarding the incidence of human\nbrucellosis in Andalusia: 1997 (589), 1998 (476), 1999 (691), 2000 (498),\n2001 (441), and 2002 (428). SPAIN (GRANADA)\n****************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail is a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nDate: Mon, 18 Aug 2003\nFrom: Pablo Nart <p.nart@ntlworld.com>\nSource: En la web, Spain, 14 Aug 2003 [translated by Maria Jacobs,\nProMED-ESP] [edited]\n<http://salud.enlaweb.com/ELW_ET_VIEWreg.asp?sch_Date=20030814133906>\n\nSo far this year, the provincial health district of Granada has detected 27\ncases of brucellosis, a disease also known as Malta fever [as well as\nMediterranean fever, remittent fever, and undulant fever - Mod.LL] that\naffects mainly those in direct contact with animals or animal tissue.\nAs in previous years, the majority of cases have been detected in the\nnortheastern and southern sanitary districts of the province, with an\naverage of 80 cases per year. Nonetheless, these numbers are clearly\ntending to decrease.\nHowever, during May and June 2003, there was an epidemic outbreak in Motril\n(Granada), with at least 27 cases linked to the consumption of fresh cheese\nacquired directly from the farmers who produced it and sold it in the\nmunicipality.\nThe cases of brucellosis as a result of drinking [unpasteurized - Mod.LL]\nmilk (most frequently goat milk), or its fresh byproducts (generally cheese\nand sometimes cottage cheese) are ever more rare in Granada.\nDuring the last decade, 55 percent of the cases registered in Granada were\nattributed to direct contact with livestock, 21 percent to the intake of\ninfected dairy products, 18 percent to mixed causes, and in 6 percent\nair-borne transmission was suspected.\nThe data indicates that brucellosis continues to be a public health concern.\nThere are preventive measures, but their success depends on the cooperation\nof various agencies and institutions, as well as on the modification of\npersonal and hygiene habits.\nAlthough there is no brucellosis vaccine for humans, there is one for the\nanimals, which constitute its natural reservoir. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["brucellosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2003-08-14 00:00:00", "1997-03-15 00:00:00", "1998-03-15 00:00:00", "1999-03-15 00:00:00", "2000-03-15 00:00:00", "2001-03-15 00:00:00", "2002-03-15 00:00:00", "2002-03-15 00:00:00", "2001-03-15 00:00:00", "1999-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Malta", "country": "Malta"}, {"location": "Granada", "country": "Grenada"}, {"location": "Kazakhstan", "country": "Kazakhstan"}, {"location": "Arkansas", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Spain", "country": "Spain"}, {"location": "Andalusia", "country": "Spain"}, {"location": "Mexico", "country": "Mexico"}, {"location": "New Zealand", "country": "New Zealand"}, {"location": "HUMAN - SPAIN", "country": "Spain"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2204309", "headline": "PRO/AH> Brucellosis, human - Mexico: Background", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2204309", "date": "2002-03-29 23:50:00", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS, HUMAN - NEW ZEALAND (02)\n*************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nSee Also\nBrucellosis, human - New Zealand 20020316.3756\nDate: 28 Mar 2002\nFrom: Matthew Stone <stonem@maf.govt.nz>\nSource: Official News release, New Zealand MAF [edited\n\nIn early March 2002 public health authorities notified the Ministry of\nAgriculture and Forestry (MAF) of a case of human brucellosis. Blood cultures\nperformed by Counties Manukau District Health Board and reviewed by the\nInstitute of Environmental Science and Research confirmed the infection, and\nbiochemical profiling by MAF National Centre for Disease Investigation\nsuggests the isolate is _Brucella suis_. The isolate has been sent to\nVeterinary Laboratory Agency (VLA), Weybridge UK, for typing. VLA report it\nis likely to be _Brucella suis_ biovar 3 (confirmation pending).\nCounties Manukau District Health Board clinicians and Auckland Regional\nPublic Health Service believe on clinical and epidemiological grounds that\nthe case most likely acquired the infection in December 2001 in New Zealand.\nAt that time the case purchased 2 pigs that were killed and butchered in a\nhome-kill situation for consumption at 2 family feasts. The case had not\ntravelled outside New Zealand for 10 years. The case 10 years ago did visit a\ncountry where _Brucella suis_ is endemic.\n_Brucella suis_ has not been recorded in New Zealand livestock previously. At\nthe present time this remains the situation, as the results reported below\nindicate.\nA previous human case of _Brucella suis_ in New Zealand has been attributed\nto infection acquired in the Pacific Islands (1), where the disease is known\nto be present in some countries (2). Imported human brucellosis cases caused\nby other species are also occasionally diagnosed.\nAnimal surveillance performed by MAF since notification of the human case\nincludes trace back of the 2 pigs to the point of purchase, from there to a\nsale-yard, and to likely farms of origin. Imperfect information has required\nclassification of farms that supplied pigs to the sale-yard on probable sale\ndates for the 2 pigs as either high, medium, or low likelihood of being the\nfarm of origin. So far 7 high, 3 medium, and 1 low-likelihood farms have been\nvisited, and all pigs over 6 months of age bled (n=97). Testing using the\ncompetitive ELISA (sensitivity 90.8 percent, specificity of 96.6 percent) has\nproduced all negative results to date. Further activities planned for the\nnext week include testing pigs on the remaining 7 low-likelihood farms,\nconducting farmer interviews to trace back suppliers for the high likelihood\nfarms, and trace-forward of likely sale-yard pen-mates of the 2 pigs.\nAll farms so far encountered in the tracing exercise have low numbers of\npigs, and pig farming is not the primary farm enterprise. These farms rear\nsmall numbers of pigs, with numbers peaking in the pre-Christmas period. The\nlevel of contact between pigs on farm now and last December must be\nestablished.\nPublic health authorities in conjunction with clinicians are following up\npeople associated with the confirmed case, with the putative exposure event,\nor possible farms of origin. The index case remains the only confirmed case.\nIf _Brucella suis_ is confirmed in livestock in New Zealand, MAF will notify\nthe Office International des Epizooties immediately.\n(1) Garner JG, Holland J, Cawley PFM, Bettelheim KA, Maskill WJ.\nBacteriological aspects of a case of _Brucella suis_ infection. New Zealand\nMedical Journal. 93, 8-9. 1981.\n(2) Alton GG. Brucella suis. In: Animal Brucellosis (Eds: Nielsen K, Duncan\nJR). CRC Press, Florida, USA. 1990. Pp 411-422.\n--\nDerek Belton\nDirector of Animal Biosecurity\nMinistry of Agriculture and Forestry, New Zealand\n<stonem@maf.govt.nz>\n[Brucellosis is also known as undulant fever in human beings because of the\nwaxing and waning of the fever. It has also been called Malta, or\nMediterranean, fever. Its insidious onset and nonspecific clinical features\nmake the disease difficult for physicians to recognize. The commonest\ncomplications are osteoarticular (20 to 60 percent of cases) and genito-\nurinary (2 to 20 percent). Untreated, the case fatality rate is up to 2\npercent, usually from endocarditis, but specific antimicrobial chemotherapy\nis available.\nThere are several _Brucella_ species, which are often associated with a\nparticular reservoir species, although the bacterium is not confined to those\nspecies. _B. abortus_ is usually associated with cattle, _B. suis_ with pigs,\nand _B. melitensis_ with goats.\nBrucellosis can also be acquired from consumption of unpasteurized milk.\nBrucellosis is caused by bacteria of the genus _Brucella_ and in animals is\ncharacterized by abortion, retained placenta, and occasionally orchitis and\ninfection of the accessory reproductive glands in males. The disease is\npresent in many countries in the world. It primarily affects cattle, buffalo,\nbison, pigs, sheep, goats, dogs, elk, and sometimes horses. The disease in\nhumans is a serious public health concern.\nRaw materials such as milk may transmit the disease to humans. When infected\ndroplets of the fluids involved in the birthing process splash into the eyes,\nthe mouth, or open cuts, people assisting those animals may develop\nbrucellosis.\nThe organism infecting goats presents the most serious disease in people. -\nMod.TG\n.....................................tg/pg/jw\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail. ISID\nand its associated service providers shall not be held\nresponsible for errors or omissions or held liable for any\ndamages incurred as a result of use or reliance upon posted\nor archived material.\n************************************************************\nVisit ProMED-mail's web site at <http://www.promedmail.org>.\nSend all items for posting to: promed@promedmail.org\n(NOT to an individual moderator). If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. Testing using the\ncompetitive ELISA (sensitivity 90.8 percent, specificity of 96.6 percent) has\nproduced all negative results to date. These farms rear\nsmall numbers of pigs, with numbers peaking in the pre-Christmas period. The\nlevel of contact between pigs on farm now and last December must be\nestablished.\nPublic health authorities in conjunction with clinicians are following up\npeople associated with the confirmed case, with the putative exposure event,\nor possible farms of origin. The index case remains the only confirmed case.\nIf _Brucella suis_ is confirmed in livestock in New Zealand, MAF will notify\nthe Office International des Epizooties immediately.\n(1) Garner JG, Holland J, Cawley PFM, Bettelheim KA, Maskill WJ.\nBacteriological aspects of a case of _Brucella suis_ infection. The commonest\ncomplications are osteoarticular (20 to 60 percent of cases) and genito-\nurinary (2 to 20 percent). For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["other", "brucellosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["2001-12-15 00:00:00", "2021-08-09 00:00:00", "1981-03-15 00:00:00", "1990-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "UK", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Malta", "country": "Malta"}, {"location": "Florida", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "USA", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "HUMAN", "country": "Iran"}, {"location": "New Zealand", "country": "New Zealand"}, {"location": "Holland J", "country": "Australia"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2202477", "headline": "PRO/AH> Brucellosis, bovine - Cyprus (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2202477", "date": "2002-03-29 23:50:00", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS, HUMAN - NEW ZEALAND (02)\n*************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.promedmail.org>\nProMED-mail, a program of the\nInternational Society for Infectious Diseases\n<http://www.isid.org>\nSee Also\nBrucellosis, human - New Zealand 20020316.3756\nDate: 28 Mar 2002\nFrom: Matthew Stone <stonem@maf.govt.nz>\nSource: Official News release, New Zealand MAF [edited\n\nIn early March 2002 public health authorities notified the Ministry of\nAgriculture and Forestry (MAF) of a case of human brucellosis. Blood cultures\nperformed by Counties Manukau District Health Board and reviewed by the\nInstitute of Environmental Science and Research confirmed the infection, and\nbiochemical profiling by MAF National Centre for Disease Investigation\nsuggests the isolate is _Brucella suis_. The isolate has been sent to\nVeterinary Laboratory Agency (VLA), Weybridge UK, for typing. VLA report it\nis likely to be _Brucella suis_ biovar 3 (confirmation pending).\nCounties Manukau District Health Board clinicians and Auckland Regional\nPublic Health Service believe on clinical and epidemiological grounds that\nthe case most likely acquired the infection in December 2001 in New Zealand.\nAt that time the case purchased 2 pigs that were killed and butchered in a\nhome-kill situation for consumption at 2 family feasts. The case had not\ntravelled outside New Zealand for 10 years. The case 10 years ago did visit a\ncountry where _Brucella suis_ is endemic.\n_Brucella suis_ has not been recorded in New Zealand livestock previously. At\nthe present time this remains the situation, as the results reported below\nindicate.\nA previous human case of _Brucella suis_ in New Zealand has been attributed\nto infection acquired in the Pacific Islands (1), where the disease is known\nto be present in some countries (2). Imported human brucellosis cases caused\nby other species are also occasionally diagnosed.\nAnimal surveillance performed by MAF since notification of the human case\nincludes trace back of the 2 pigs to the point of purchase, from there to a\nsale-yard, and to likely farms of origin. Imperfect information has required\nclassification of farms that supplied pigs to the sale-yard on probable sale\ndates for the 2 pigs as either high, medium, or low likelihood of being the\nfarm of origin. So far 7 high, 3 medium, and 1 low-likelihood farms have been\nvisited, and all pigs over 6 months of age bled (n=97). Testing using the\ncompetitive ELISA (sensitivity 90.8 percent, specificity of 96.6 percent) has\nproduced all negative results to date. Further activities planned for the\nnext week include testing pigs on the remaining 7 low-likelihood farms,\nconducting farmer interviews to trace back suppliers for the high likelihood\nfarms, and trace-forward of likely sale-yard pen-mates of the 2 pigs.\nAll farms so far encountered in the tracing exercise have low numbers of\npigs, and pig farming is not the primary farm enterprise. These farms rear\nsmall numbers of pigs, with numbers peaking in the pre-Christmas period. The\nlevel of contact between pigs on farm now and last December must be\nestablished.\nPublic health authorities in conjunction with clinicians are following up\npeople associated with the confirmed case, with the putative exposure event,\nor possible farms of origin. The index case remains the only confirmed case.\nIf _Brucella suis_ is confirmed in livestock in New Zealand, MAF will notify\nthe Office International des Epizooties immediately.\n(1) Garner JG, Holland J, Cawley PFM, Bettelheim KA, Maskill WJ.\nBacteriological aspects of a case of _Brucella suis_ infection. New Zealand\nMedical Journal. 93, 8-9. 1981.\n(2) Alton GG. Brucella suis. In: Animal Brucellosis (Eds: Nielsen K, Duncan\nJR). CRC Press, Florida, USA. 1990. Pp 411-422.\n--\nDerek Belton\nDirector of Animal Biosecurity\nMinistry of Agriculture and Forestry, New Zealand\n<stonem@maf.govt.nz>\n[Brucellosis is also known as undulant fever in human beings because of the\nwaxing and waning of the fever. It has also been called Malta, or\nMediterranean, fever. Its insidious onset and nonspecific clinical features\nmake the disease difficult for physicians to recognize. The commonest\ncomplications are osteoarticular (20 to 60 percent of cases) and genito-\nurinary (2 to 20 percent). Untreated, the case fatality rate is up to 2\npercent, usually from endocarditis, but specific antimicrobial chemotherapy\nis available.\nThere are several _Brucella_ species, which are often associated with a\nparticular reservoir species, although the bacterium is not confined to those\nspecies. _B. abortus_ is usually associated with cattle, _B. suis_ with pigs,\nand _B. melitensis_ with goats.\nBrucellosis can also be acquired from consumption of unpasteurized milk.\nBrucellosis is caused by bacteria of the genus _Brucella_ and in animals is\ncharacterized by abortion, retained placenta, and occasionally orchitis and\ninfection of the accessory reproductive glands in males. The disease is\npresent in many countries in the world. It primarily affects cattle, buffalo,\nbison, pigs, sheep, goats, dogs, elk, and sometimes horses. The disease in\nhumans is a serious public health concern.\nRaw materials such as milk may transmit the disease to humans. When infected\ndroplets of the fluids involved in the birthing process splash into the eyes,\nthe mouth, or open cuts, people assisting those animals may develop\nbrucellosis.\nThe organism infecting goats presents the most serious disease in people. -\nMod.TG\n.....................................tg/pg/jw\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail. ISID\nand its associated service providers shall not be held\nresponsible for errors or omissions or held liable for any\ndamages incurred as a result of use or reliance upon posted\nor archived material.\n************************************************************\nVisit ProMED-mail's web site at <http://www.promedmail.org>.\nSend all items for posting to: promed@promedmail.org\n(NOT to an individual moderator). If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. So far 7 high, 3 medium, and 1 low-likelihood farms have been\nvisited, and all pigs over 6 months of age bled (n=97). Testing using the\ncompetitive ELISA (sensitivity 90.8 percent, specificity of 96.6 percent) has\nproduced all negative results to date. These farms rear\nsmall numbers of pigs, with numbers peaking in the pre-Christmas period. The\nlevel of contact between pigs on farm now and last December must be\nestablished.\nPublic health authorities in conjunction with clinicians are following up\npeople associated with the confirmed case, with the putative exposure event,\nor possible farms of origin. The index case remains the only confirmed case.\nIf _Brucella suis_ is confirmed in livestock in New Zealand, MAF will notify\nthe Office International des Epizooties immediately.\n(1) Garner JG, Holland J, Cawley PFM, Bettelheim KA, Maskill WJ.\nBacteriological aspects of a case of _Brucella suis_ infection. The commonest\ncomplications are osteoarticular (20 to 60 percent of cases) and genito-\nurinary (2 to 20 percent). [Human] infection can\ncause illness, [which may be prolonged], but is [rarely] fatal.\n\u00ad\u00ad\nProMED-mail\n<promed@promedmail.org>\n[Brucellosis is also known as undulant fever in people. It can be\ntransmitted to people through the fluids associated with the birthing\nprocess in cattle if [these are] splashed into the eyes or contact abraded\nskin. People may also acquire the disease through unpasteurized milk. The\ndisease in people is treatable with antibiotics but may be fatal if left\nuntreated. Cattle do not usually die from the disease, but calves of\ninfected cows may be stillborn or die shortly after calving. - Mod.TG]\n.......................jw/tg/pg/sh\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. Siberia) (03) 990917215331\nAnthrax - Georgia (Gardabansky) 990901210201\nAnthrax - Georgia Republic (Tbilisi) 990916224943\nDate: 11 Oct 1999\nFrom: ProMED <promed@usa.healthnet.org>\nSource: Interfax-Kazakhstan news agency, Almaty, 7 Oct 1999 [in Russian\n\nKazakhstan: Seven contract brucellosis, one anthrax\n------------------------------------------------------\nSeven people have contracted brucellosis in a settlement in Kzyl-Orda Region\nof (southern) Kazakhstan and furthermore, a woman was found to have come\ndown with malignant anthrax in Zhambyl Region, Interfax-Kazakhstan learnt at\nthe Agency for Emergency Situations (AES) of Kazakhstan on Thursday (7 Oct\n1999).\nAccording to AES data, the brucellosis and anthrax were contracted after\nmeat of a diseased animal was consumed. AES officials said the anthrax case\nwas complicated by the fact that the diseased animal's meat and skin had\nbeen sold at a local market.\nSo far, Regional public health station staff have traced 10 people involved\nin the purchase of the meat who are now carrying anthrax bacilli. The buyers\nof the meat have been admitted to hospital and are undergoing medical\nexamination.\n--\nProMED\n<promed@usa.healthnet.org>\n[It would be interesting to know which _Brucella_ species was involved in\nthis outbreak as all behave slightly differently. It is unusual to have\nbrucellar exposure from consuming 'meat' but in no way impossible; the\norganism is more usually found in lymphatic tissues and marrow. The\ncommonest human exposures are occupational (eg when slaughtering or from\ndelivering a calf or kid from an infected animal) or through consuming\ninfected milk. _B. abortus_ is rarely fatal while _B. melitensis_ infections\ncarry a significant risk of death (30%-40% in some areas). Cows can be\ninfected with _B. melitensis_, though exposure may be more common through\ninfected goat milk\nbeing added to bovine milk. Being a Muslim country we can rule out _B. suis_\n[from pigs.\nThere is nothing to stop a chronically infected brucellar cow from coming\ndown with anthrax. - MHJ\n.................................................jw/mhj/jw\n\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["brucellosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1999-03-15 00:00:00", "1999-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Interfax", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Georgia Republic", "country": "Georgia"}, {"location": "Zhambyl Region", "country": "Kazakhstan"}, {"location": "KZYL - ORDA", "country": "Kazakhstan"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Kazakhstan", "country": "Kazakhstan"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2198493", "headline": "PRO/AH> Brucellosis - India (Calcutta) (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2198493", "date": "1999-10-11 23:50:00", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS, ANTHRAX, HUMAN - KAZAKHSTAN (KZYL-ORDA)\n********************************************\nA ProMED post\n<http://www.healthnet.org/programs/promed.html>\nSee Also\nBrucellosis, human - Kazakhstan (Kzyl-Orda) 990817220131\nAnthrax, human, cattle - Armenia (Armavir) 990729204640\nAnthrax, human, cattle - Ukraine 990723213644\nAnthrax, human - Kazakhstan (Dzhambul) (02) 990924205305\nAnthrax, human - Kyrgyzstan (02) 990804214606\nAnthrax, human - Russia (Buryatia) (04) 990719221904\nAnthrax, human - Russia (W. Siberia) (03) 990917215331\nAnthrax - Georgia (Gardabansky) 990901210201\nAnthrax - Georgia Republic (Tbilisi) 990916224943\nDate: 11 Oct 1999\nFrom: ProMED <promed@usa.healthnet.org>\nSource: Interfax-Kazakhstan news agency, Almaty, 7 Oct 1999 [in Russian\n\nKazakhstan: Seven contract brucellosis, one anthrax\n------------------------------------------------------\nSeven people have contracted brucellosis in a settlement in Kzyl-Orda Region\nof (southern) Kazakhstan and furthermore, a woman was found to have come\ndown with malignant anthrax in Zhambyl Region, Interfax-Kazakhstan learnt at\nthe Agency for Emergency Situations (AES) of Kazakhstan on Thursday (7 Oct\n1999).\nAccording to AES data, the brucellosis and anthrax were contracted after\nmeat of a diseased animal was consumed. AES officials said the anthrax case\nwas complicated by the fact that the diseased animal's meat and skin had\nbeen sold at a local market.\nSo far, Regional public health station staff have traced 10 people involved\nin the purchase of the meat who are now carrying anthrax bacilli. The buyers\nof the meat have been admitted to hospital and are undergoing medical\nexamination.\n--\nProMED\n<promed@usa.healthnet.org>\n[It would be interesting to know which _Brucella_ species was involved in\nthis outbreak as all behave slightly differently. It is unusual to have\nbrucellar exposure from consuming 'meat' but in no way impossible; the\norganism is more usually found in lymphatic tissues and marrow. The\ncommonest human exposures are occupational (eg when slaughtering or from\ndelivering a calf or kid from an infected animal) or through consuming\ninfected milk. _B. abortus_ is rarely fatal while _B. melitensis_ infections\ncarry a significant risk of death (30%-40% in some areas). Cows can be\ninfected with _B. melitensis_, though exposure may be more common through\ninfected goat milk\nbeing added to bovine milk. Being a Muslim country we can rule out _B. suis_\n[from pigs.\nThere is nothing to stop a chronically infected brucellar cow from coming\ndown with anthrax. - MHJ\n.................................................jw/mhj/jw\n\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail.
