For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["brucellosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1999-03-15 00:00:00", "1999-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Interfax", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Georgia Republic", "country": "Georgia"}, {"location": "Zhambyl Region", "country": "Kazakhstan"}, {"location": "KZYL - ORDA", "country": "Kazakhstan"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Kazakhstan", "country": "Kazakhstan"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2196682", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Brucellosis, anthrax, human - Kazakhstan (Kzyl-Orda)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2196682", "date": "1999-10-11 23:50:00", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS, ANTHRAX, HUMAN - KAZAKHSTAN (KZYL-ORDA)\n********************************************\nA ProMED post\n<http://www.healthnet.org/programs/promed.html>\nSee Also\nBrucellosis, human - Kazakhstan (Kzyl-Orda) 990817220131\nAnthrax, human, cattle - Armenia (Armavir) 990729204640\nAnthrax, human, cattle - Ukraine 990723213644\nAnthrax, human - Kazakhstan (Dzhambul) (02) 990924205305\nAnthrax, human - Kyrgyzstan (02) 990804214606\nAnthrax, human - Russia (Buryatia) (04) 990719221904\nAnthrax, human - Russia (W. Siberia) (03) 990917215331\nAnthrax - Georgia (Gardabansky) 990901210201\nAnthrax - Georgia Republic (Tbilisi) 990916224943\nDate: 11 Oct 1999\nFrom: ProMED <promed@usa.healthnet.org>\nSource: Interfax-Kazakhstan news agency, Almaty, 7 Oct 1999 [in Russian\n\nKazakhstan: Seven contract brucellosis, one anthrax\n------------------------------------------------------\nSeven people have contracted brucellosis in a settlement in Kzyl-Orda Region\nof (southern) Kazakhstan and furthermore, a woman was found to have come\ndown with malignant anthrax in Zhambyl Region, Interfax-Kazakhstan learnt at\nthe Agency for Emergency Situations (AES) of Kazakhstan on Thursday (7 Oct\n1999).\nAccording to AES data, the brucellosis and anthrax were contracted after\nmeat of a diseased animal was consumed. AES officials said the anthrax case\nwas complicated by the fact that the diseased animal's meat and skin had\nbeen sold at a local market.\nSo far, Regional public health station staff have traced 10 people involved\nin the purchase of the meat who are now carrying anthrax bacilli. The buyers\nof the meat have been admitted to hospital and are undergoing medical\nexamination.\n--\nProMED\n<promed@usa.healthnet.org>\n[It would be interesting to know which _Brucella_ species was involved in\nthis outbreak as all behave slightly differently. It is unusual to have\nbrucellar exposure from consuming 'meat' but in no way impossible; the\norganism is more usually found in lymphatic tissues and marrow. The\ncommonest human exposures are occupational (eg when slaughtering or from\ndelivering a calf or kid from an infected animal) or through consuming\ninfected milk. _B. abortus_ is rarely fatal while _B. melitensis_ infections\ncarry a significant risk of death (30%-40% in some areas). Cows can be\ninfected with _B. melitensis_, though exposure may be more common through\ninfected goat milk\nbeing added to bovine milk. Being a Muslim country we can rule out _B. suis_\n[from pigs.\nThere is nothing to stop a chronically infected brucellar cow from coming\ndown with anthrax. - MHJ\n.................................................jw/mhj/jw\n\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail. ISID\nand its associated service providers shall not be held\nresponsible for errors or omissions or held liable for any\ndamages incurred as a result of use or reliance upon posted\nor archived material.\n************************************************************\nVisit ProMED-mail's web site at <http://www.promedmail.org>.\nSend all items for posting to: promed@promedmail.org\n(NOT to an individual moderator). If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["brucellosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1999-03-15 00:00:00", "1999-03-15 00:00:00", "2021-03-18 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Interfax", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Georgia Republic", "country": "Georgia"}, {"location": "Zhambyl Region", "country": "Kazakhstan"}, {"location": "KZYL - ORDA", "country": "Kazakhstan"}, {"location": "Russia", "country": "Russia"}, {"location": "Kazakhstan", "country": "Kazakhstan"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2196286", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Brucellosis, human - Kazakhstan (Kzyl-Orda)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2196286", "date": "1999-05-19 23:50:00", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS, BISON - USA (MONTANA): CONTROL (03)\n************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.healthnet.org/programs/promed/html>\nSee Also\nBrucellosis, bison - USA (Montana): control 990512165628\nBrucellosis, bison - USA (Montana): control (02) 990514201544\nDate: Mon, 17 May 1999 12:11:55 -0600\nFrom: Jim Moore <galileo2@earthlink.net>\n\nAs a point of introduction, I have a biology-environmental health\nbackground and spent the summer of '98 as the (seasonal only) Public Health\nOfficer (Sanitarian) at Grand Teton National Park (GRTE). As a westerner\nhaving grown up in Oklahoma with open ranges and a firm belief in \"western\"\nphilosophies, I have a great affinity for ranchers, as a group. As you\nsay, though, ranchers have a disproportionate share of the political power\nin many places.\nI spent considerable time last summer slightly outside the duties for which\nI was hired. One of the issues I followed closely was the bison management\nplan for the Greater Yellowstone Ecosystem (GYE) area, which had just been\npublished in late summer [97? . I had several discussions with the GRTE\nChief of Resource Management about the issue. Many of the issues affecting\nthe Yellowstone herds generally do not affect the GRTE herd of bison,\nexcept in a broader concept. Some of the \"scientific\" principles invoked\nby the GYE bison management plan could hardly be called \"good science\",\neven in the US EPA vernacular.\nOne of the problems I had noted in managing the bison involved the\nassumption that the Yellowstone herd was a threat to Montana's\ncertification under USDA as a brucellosis-free area. Unlike most\nAmericans, I have seen the effects of brucellosis in animals and undulant\nfever as it known in both animals and people. I have great respect for the\nability of communicable diseases to create terror in local populations.\nThere is no reason to think most citizens of Montana have the same frame of\nreference. Upon checking into the facts of brucellosis transmission from\nbison to cattle, I learned several things which create some real\nepidemiological questions in my mind.\nIn recent years, it seems, one of the Yellowstone bison was captured\n(perhaps in Montana during a previous winter) and kept confined in a small\nstall. I am not certain of the disposition of the bison, however, according\nto the story, the stall was later used to contain a cow (non-bison). That\ncow later was diagnosed with brucellosis. Therefore, as illogic would\nfollow, the bison transmitted the brucellosis to the cow. Apparently, this\nwas the only such occurrence.\nThere is an immunization for cattle against brucellosis, but it is\napparently not totally useful. It is, as is true of most immunizations, not\n100% effective. Efficacy varies with the sex, age, and other factors of the\ncow.\nThe blood test being used to test Yellowstone bison for brucellosis when\nthey range into Montana was developed to check titer counts in cattle. It\nhas not been proven effective for determining the communicability of bison.\n\nIt has not been proven that the serotype of brucellosis in bison is the\nsame as the serotype which causes symptoms in cattle.\nThe bison management plane offered by the GYE Coalition listed several\n(perhaps 8, if I recall) options for actions to be taken. Of course, the\nrequisite option of doing nothing at all was listed, but never seriously\nconsidered, in my opinion. I remember one option which instantly came to my\nmind, but it was too politically-loaded for the GYE Coalition to even list\nas a potential consideration.\nI order to lure tourist dollars to the Yellowstone area during the winter\nmonths, the roads to the towns of Gardiner and West Yellowstone, MT\n[Montana, are packed each winter to allow snowmobile access through deep\nsnows. As you know, without snowmobiles, most tourists would go elsewhere\nwhere there was a little less \"real\" nature to challenge them. When the\nsnows in Yellowstone NP [National Park are deep, the bison naturally start\nusing the packed roadways to ease their travel. Some portions of the park's\nherds stay near the warmer geyser areas and never think to travel outside\nthe park. Other portions of the herds, notable those living in the north\nand northeast areas, find the packed roadways too hard to resist. Over the\ncourse of time, those herds have developed a tradition of traveling the\nroads in winter.\nThe one option not considered is to stop packing the roadways during the\nwinter. Of course, the tourist supply will dry up, and the economies in the\nboundary areas will need to shift to another source of income. To the south\nof Yellowstone, in Rockefeller Memorial Parkway and GRTE, the roadways are\noften allowed to become snowed in. Snowmobiles are allowed along certain\npathways, but the distances involved are usually in excess of what the\nJackson Hole [town in Wyoming tourists are willing to endure. Gardiner and\nWest Yellowstone access points are much closer for the casual tourist.\nAnother point of contention is that the bison management plan does not\nconsider the impact of elk on the spread of brucellosis. The elk may have a\nhigher infectivity rate than the bison in the GYE area. And they may be\nmore likely to spread the disease to cattle. Elk are often infected by the\nhabit of ingesting the afterbirths of their young.\nHowever, would the political battle be too large to handle if Montana\nconsidered that it should, to protect their brucellosis-free status, start\nshooting all the elk, as well as the bison? I believe, if that were the\ncase, there would be a much larger coalition opposed to the deliberate\nkilling of bison and elk. I do not pretend to know the answers nor do I\nhave the ability to predict the political will of the country in preventing\nthe deaths of the bison. I am of the opinion that Science has not yet\nentered into the picture with any clarity. I hope it doesn't arrive too late.\n--\nJim Moore\ne-mail: galileo2@earthlink.net\n[There is an unknown factor not addressed by Mr. Moore. Did the cow, housed\nin the same stall as the previous bison occupant, already have brucellosis?\nWas she tested negative prior to her housing in the stall? There are many\npolitical issues at stake in the brucellosis triangle between bison,\ncattle, and elk. It would be nice to have some real science to support the\nissues at hand. - Mod.TG\n..................................tg/es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail. ISID\nand its associated service providers shall not be held\nresponsible for errors or omissions or held liable for any\ndamages incurred as a result of use or reliance upon posted\nor archived material.\n************************************************************\nVisit ProMED-mail's web site at <http://www.promedmail.org>.\nSend all items for posting to: promed@promedmail.org\n(NOT to an individual moderator). If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "brucellosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1999-05-17 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Oklahoma", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Jackson Hole", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Montana", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Wyoming", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "yellowstone", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "US", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2195849", "headline": "PRO/AH> Brucellosis, elk - USA (Montana): control", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2195849", "date": "1999-05-19 23:50:00", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS, BISON - USA (MONTANA): CONTROL (03)\n************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.healthnet.org/programs/promed/html>\nSee Also\nBrucellosis, bison - USA (Montana): control 990512165628\nBrucellosis, bison - USA (Montana): control (02) 990514201544\nDate: Mon, 17 May 1999 12:11:55 -0600\nFrom: Jim Moore <galileo2@earthlink.net>\n\nAs a point of introduction, I have a biology-environmental health\nbackground and spent the summer of '98 as the (seasonal only) Public Health\nOfficer (Sanitarian) at Grand Teton National Park (GRTE). As a westerner\nhaving grown up in Oklahoma with open ranges and a firm belief in \"western\"\nphilosophies, I have a great affinity for ranchers, as a group. As you\nsay, though, ranchers have a disproportionate share of the political power\nin many places.\nI spent considerable time last summer slightly outside the duties for which\nI was hired. One of the issues I followed closely was the bison management\nplan for the Greater Yellowstone Ecosystem (GYE) area, which had just been\npublished in late summer [97? . I had several discussions with the GRTE\nChief of Resource Management about the issue. Many of the issues affecting\nthe Yellowstone herds generally do not affect the GRTE herd of bison,\nexcept in a broader concept. Some of the \"scientific\" principles invoked\nby the GYE bison management plan could hardly be called \"good science\",\neven in the US EPA vernacular.\nOne of the problems I had noted in managing the bison involved the\nassumption that the Yellowstone herd was a threat to Montana's\ncertification under USDA as a brucellosis-free area. Unlike most\nAmericans, I have seen the effects of brucellosis in animals and undulant\nfever as it known in both animals and people. I have great respect for the\nability of communicable diseases to create terror in local populations.\nThere is no reason to think most citizens of Montana have the same frame of\nreference. Upon checking into the facts of brucellosis transmission from\nbison to cattle, I learned several things which create some real\nepidemiological questions in my mind.\nIn recent years, it seems, one of the Yellowstone bison was captured\n(perhaps in Montana during a previous winter) and kept confined in a small\nstall. I am not certain of the disposition of the bison, however, according\nto the story, the stall was later used to contain a cow (non-bison). That\ncow later was diagnosed with brucellosis. Therefore, as illogic would\nfollow, the bison transmitted the brucellosis to the cow. Apparently, this\nwas the only such occurrence.\nThere is an immunization for cattle against brucellosis, but it is\napparently not totally useful. It is, as is true of most immunizations, not\n100% effective. Efficacy varies with the sex, age, and other factors of the\ncow.\nThe blood test being used to test Yellowstone bison for brucellosis when\nthey range into Montana was developed to check titer counts in cattle. It\nhas not been proven effective for determining the communicability of bison.\n\nIt has not been proven that the serotype of brucellosis in bison is the\nsame as the serotype which causes symptoms in cattle.\nThe bison management plane offered by the GYE Coalition listed several\n(perhaps 8, if I recall) options for actions to be taken. Of course, the\nrequisite option of doing nothing at all was listed, but never seriously\nconsidered, in my opinion. I remember one option which instantly came to my\nmind, but it was too politically-loaded for the GYE Coalition to even list\nas a potential consideration.\nI order to lure tourist dollars to the Yellowstone area during the winter\nmonths, the roads to the towns of Gardiner and West Yellowstone, MT\n[Montana, are packed each winter to allow snowmobile access through deep\nsnows. As you know, without snowmobiles, most tourists would go elsewhere\nwhere there was a little less \"real\" nature to challenge them. When the\nsnows in Yellowstone NP [National Park are deep, the bison naturally start\nusing the packed roadways to ease their travel. Some portions of the park's\nherds stay near the warmer geyser areas and never think to travel outside\nthe park. Other portions of the herds, notable those living in the north\nand northeast areas, find the packed roadways too hard to resist. Over the\ncourse of time, those herds have developed a tradition of traveling the\nroads in winter.\nThe one option not considered is to stop packing the roadways during the\nwinter. Of course, the tourist supply will dry up, and the economies in the\nboundary areas will need to shift to another source of income. To the south\nof Yellowstone, in Rockefeller Memorial Parkway and GRTE, the roadways are\noften allowed to become snowed in. Snowmobiles are allowed along certain\npathways, but the distances involved are usually in excess of what the\nJackson Hole [town in Wyoming tourists are willing to endure. Gardiner and\nWest Yellowstone access points are much closer for the casual tourist.\nAnother point of contention is that the bison management plan does not\nconsider the impact of elk on the spread of brucellosis. The elk may have a\nhigher infectivity rate than the bison in the GYE area. And they may be\nmore likely to spread the disease to cattle. Elk are often infected by the\nhabit of ingesting the afterbirths of their young.\nHowever, would the political battle be too large to handle if Montana\nconsidered that it should, to protect their brucellosis-free status, start\nshooting all the elk, as well as the bison? I believe, if that were the\ncase, there would be a much larger coalition opposed to the deliberate\nkilling of bison and elk. I do not pretend to know the answers nor do I\nhave the ability to predict the political will of the country in preventing\nthe deaths of the bison. I am of the opinion that Science has not yet\nentered into the picture with any clarity. I hope it doesn't arrive too late.\n--\nJim Moore\ne-mail: galileo2@earthlink.net\n[There is an unknown factor not addressed by Mr. Moore. Did the cow, housed\nin the same stall as the previous bison occupant, already have brucellosis?\nWas she tested negative prior to her housing in the stall? There are many\npolitical issues at stake in the brucellosis triangle between bison,\ncattle, and elk. It would be nice to have some real science to support the\nissues at hand. - Mod.TG\n..................................tg/es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. As a westerner\nhaving grown up in Oklahoma with open ranges and a firm belief in \"western\"\nphilosophies, I have a great affinity for ranchers, as a group. As you\nsay, though, ranchers have a disproportionate share of the political power\nin many places.\nI spent considerable time last summer slightly outside the duties for which\nI was hired. One of the issues I followed closely was the bison management\nplan for the Greater Yellowstone Ecosystem (GYE) area, which had just been\npublished in late summer [97? . I had several discussions with the GRTE\nChief of Resource Management about the issue. Many of the issues affecting\nthe Yellowstone herds generally do not affect the GRTE herd of bison,\nexcept in a broader concept. Some of the \"scientific\" principles invoked\nby the GYE bison management plan could hardly be called \"good science\",\neven in the US EPA vernacular.\nOne of the problems I had noted in managing the bison involved the\nassumption that the Yellowstone herd was a threat to Montana's\ncertification under USDA as a brucellosis-free area. Unlike most\nAmericans, I have seen the effects of brucellosis in animals and undulant\nfever as it known in both animals and people. I have great respect for the\nability of communicable diseases to create terror in local populations.\nThere is no reason to think most citizens of Montana have the same frame of\nreference. Upon checking into the facts of brucellosis transmission from\nbison to cattle, I learned several things which create some real\nepidemiological questions in my mind.\nIn recent years, it seems, one of the Yellowstone bison was captured\n(perhaps in Montana during a previous winter) and kept confined in a small\nstall. I am not certain of the disposition of the bison, however, according\nto the story, the stall was later used to contain a cow (non-bison). That\ncow later was diagnosed with brucellosis. Therefore, as illogic would\nfollow, the bison transmitted the brucellosis to the cow. Apparently, this\nwas the only such occurrence.\nThere is an immunization for cattle against brucellosis, but it is\napparently not totally useful. It is, as is true of most immunizations, not\n100% effective. Efficacy varies with the sex, age, and other factors of the\ncow.\nThe blood test being used to test Yellowstone bison for brucellosis when\nthey range into Montana was developed to check titer counts in cattle. It\nhas not been proven effective for determining the communicability of bison.\n\nIt has not been proven that the serotype of brucellosis in bison is the\nsame as the serotype which causes symptoms in cattle.\nThe bison management plane offered by the GYE Coalition listed several\n(perhaps 8, if I recall) options for actions to be taken. Of course, the\nrequisite option of doing nothing at all was listed, but never seriously\nconsidered, in my opinion. I remember one option which instantly came to my\nmind, but it was too politically-loaded for the GYE Coalition to even list\nas a potential consideration.\nI order to lure tourist dollars to the Yellowstone area during the winter\nmonths, the roads to the towns of Gardiner and West Yellowstone, MT\n[Montana, are packed each winter to allow snowmobile access through deep\nsnows. As you know, without snowmobiles, most tourists would go elsewhere\nwhere there was a little less \"real\" nature to challenge them. When the\nsnows in Yellowstone NP [National Park are deep, the bison naturally start\nusing the packed roadways to ease their travel. Some portions of the park's\nherds stay near the warmer geyser areas and never think to travel outside\nthe park. Other portions of the herds, notable those living in the north\nand northeast areas, find the packed roadways too hard to resist. Over the\ncourse of time, those herds have developed a tradition of traveling the\nroads in winter.\nThe one option not considered is to stop packing the roadways during the\nwinter. Of course, the tourist supply will dry up, and the economies in the\nboundary areas will need to shift to another source of income. To the south\nof Yellowstone, in Rockefeller Memorial Parkway and GRTE, the roadways are\noften allowed to become snowed in. Snowmobiles are allowed along certain\npathways, but the distances involved are usually in excess of what the\nJackson Hole [town in Wyoming tourists are willing to endure. Gardiner and\nWest Yellowstone access points are much closer for the casual tourist.\nAnother point of contention is that the bison management plan does not\nconsider the impact of elk on the spread of brucellosis. The elk may have a\nhigher infectivity rate than the bison in the GYE area. And they may be\nmore likely to spread the disease to cattle. Elk are often infected by the\nhabit of ingesting the afterbirths of their young.\nHowever, would the political battle be too large to handle if Montana\nconsidered that it should, to protect their brucellosis-free status, start\nshooting all the elk, as well as the bison? I believe, if that were the\ncase, there would be a much larger coalition opposed to the deliberate\nkilling of bison and elk. I do not pretend to know the answers nor do I\nhave the ability to predict the political will of the country in preventing\nthe deaths of the bison. I am of the opinion that Science has not yet\nentered into the picture with any clarity. I hope it doesn't arrive too late.\n--\nJim Moore\ne-mail: galileo2@earthlink.net\n[There is an unknown factor not addressed by Mr. Moore. ISID\nand its associated service providers shall not be held\nresponsible for errors or omissions or held liable for any\ndamages incurred as a result of use or reliance upon posted\nor archived material.\n************************************************************\nVisit ProMED-mail's web site at <http://www.promedmail.org>.\nSend all items for posting to: promed@promedmail.org\n(NOT to an individual moderator). If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "brucellosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1999-05-17 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Oklahoma", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Jackson Hole", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Montana", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Wyoming", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "yellowstone", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "US", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2195761", "headline": "PRO/AH> Brucellosis, bison - USA (Montana): control (06)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2195761", "date": "1999-05-19 23:50:00", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS, BISON - USA (MONTANA): CONTROL (03)\n************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.healthnet.org/programs/promed/html>\nSee Also\nBrucellosis, bison - USA (Montana): control 990512165628\nBrucellosis, bison - USA (Montana): control (02) 990514201544\nDate: Mon, 17 May 1999 12:11:55 -0600\nFrom: Jim Moore <galileo2@earthlink.net>\n\nAs a point of introduction, I have a biology-environmental health\nbackground and spent the summer of '98 as the (seasonal only) Public Health\nOfficer (Sanitarian) at Grand Teton National Park (GRTE). As a westerner\nhaving grown up in Oklahoma with open ranges and a firm belief in \"western\"\nphilosophies, I have a great affinity for ranchers, as a group. As you\nsay, though, ranchers have a disproportionate share of the political power\nin many places.\nI spent considerable time last summer slightly outside the duties for which\nI was hired. One of the issues I followed closely was the bison management\nplan for the Greater Yellowstone Ecosystem (GYE) area, which had just been\npublished in late summer [97? . I had several discussions with the GRTE\nChief of Resource Management about the issue. Many of the issues affecting\nthe Yellowstone herds generally do not affect the GRTE herd of bison,\nexcept in a broader concept. Some of the \"scientific\" principles invoked\nby the GYE bison management plan could hardly be called \"good science\",\neven in the US EPA vernacular.\nOne of the problems I had noted in managing the bison involved the\nassumption that the Yellowstone herd was a threat to Montana's\ncertification under USDA as a brucellosis-free area. Unlike most\nAmericans, I have seen the effects of brucellosis in animals and undulant\nfever as it known in both animals and people. I have great respect for the\nability of communicable diseases to create terror in local populations.\nThere is no reason to think most citizens of Montana have the same frame of\nreference. Upon checking into the facts of brucellosis transmission from\nbison to cattle, I learned several things which create some real\nepidemiological questions in my mind.\nIn recent years, it seems, one of the Yellowstone bison was captured\n(perhaps in Montana during a previous winter) and kept confined in a small\nstall. I am not certain of the disposition of the bison, however, according\nto the story, the stall was later used to contain a cow (non-bison). That\ncow later was diagnosed with brucellosis. Therefore, as illogic would\nfollow, the bison transmitted the brucellosis to the cow. Apparently, this\nwas the only such occurrence.\nThere is an immunization for cattle against brucellosis, but it is\napparently not totally useful. It is, as is true of most immunizations, not\n100% effective. Efficacy varies with the sex, age, and other factors of the\ncow.\nThe blood test being used to test Yellowstone bison for brucellosis when\nthey range into Montana was developed to check titer counts in cattle. It\nhas not been proven effective for determining the communicability of bison.\n\nIt has not been proven that the serotype of brucellosis in bison is the\nsame as the serotype which causes symptoms in cattle.\nThe bison management plane offered by the GYE Coalition listed several\n(perhaps 8, if I recall) options for actions to be taken. Of course, the\nrequisite option of doing nothing at all was listed, but never seriously\nconsidered, in my opinion. I remember one option which instantly came to my\nmind, but it was too politically-loaded for the GYE Coalition to even list\nas a potential consideration.\nI order to lure tourist dollars to the Yellowstone area during the winter\nmonths, the roads to the towns of Gardiner and West Yellowstone, MT\n[Montana, are packed each winter to allow snowmobile access through deep\nsnows. As you know, without snowmobiles, most tourists would go elsewhere\nwhere there was a little less \"real\" nature to challenge them. When the\nsnows in Yellowstone NP [National Park are deep, the bison naturally start\nusing the packed roadways to ease their travel. Some portions of the park's\nherds stay near the warmer geyser areas and never think to travel outside\nthe park. Other portions of the herds, notable those living in the north\nand northeast areas, find the packed roadways too hard to resist. Over the\ncourse of time, those herds have developed a tradition of traveling the\nroads in winter.\nThe one option not considered is to stop packing the roadways during the\nwinter. Of course, the tourist supply will dry up, and the economies in the\nboundary areas will need to shift to another source of income. To the south\nof Yellowstone, in Rockefeller Memorial Parkway and GRTE, the roadways are\noften allowed to become snowed in. Snowmobiles are allowed along certain\npathways, but the distances involved are usually in excess of what the\nJackson Hole [town in Wyoming tourists are willing to endure. Gardiner and\nWest Yellowstone access points are much closer for the casual tourist.\nAnother point of contention is that the bison management plan does not\nconsider the impact of elk on the spread of brucellosis. The elk may have a\nhigher infectivity rate than the bison in the GYE area. And they may be\nmore likely to spread the disease to cattle. Elk are often infected by the\nhabit of ingesting the afterbirths of their young.\nHowever, would the political battle be too large to handle if Montana\nconsidered that it should, to protect their brucellosis-free status, start\nshooting all the elk, as well as the bison? I believe, if that were the\ncase, there would be a much larger coalition opposed to the deliberate\nkilling of bison and elk. I do not pretend to know the answers nor do I\nhave the ability to predict the political will of the country in preventing\nthe deaths of the bison. I am of the opinion that Science has not yet\nentered into the picture with any clarity. I hope it doesn't arrive too late.\n--\nJim Moore\ne-mail: galileo2@earthlink.net\n[There is an unknown factor not addressed by Mr. Moore. Did the cow, housed\nin the same stall as the previous bison occupant, already have brucellosis?\nWas she tested negative prior to her housing in the stall? There are many\npolitical issues at stake in the brucellosis triangle between bison,\ncattle, and elk. It would be nice to have some real science to support the\nissues at hand. - Mod.TG\n..................................tg/es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail. ISID\nand its associated service providers shall not be held\nresponsible for errors or omissions or held liable for any\ndamages incurred as a result of use or reliance upon posted\nor archived material.\n************************************************************\nVisit ProMED-mail's web site at <http://www.promedmail.org>.\nSend all items for posting to: promed@promedmail.org\n(NOT to an individual moderator). If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "brucellosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1999-05-17 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Oklahoma", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Jackson Hole", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Montana", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Wyoming", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "yellowstone", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "US", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2195752", "headline": "PRO/AH> Brucellosis, bison - USA (Montana): control (05)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2195752", "date": "1999-05-19 23:50:00", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS, BISON - USA (MONTANA): CONTROL (03)\n************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.healthnet.org/programs/promed/html>\nSee Also\nBrucellosis, bison - USA (Montana): control 990512165628\nBrucellosis, bison - USA (Montana): control (02) 990514201544\nDate: Mon, 17 May 1999 12:11:55 -0600\nFrom: Jim Moore <galileo2@earthlink.net>\n\nAs a point of introduction, I have a biology-environmental health\nbackground and spent the summer of '98 as the (seasonal only) Public Health\nOfficer (Sanitarian) at Grand Teton National Park (GRTE). As a westerner\nhaving grown up in Oklahoma with open ranges and a firm belief in \"western\"\nphilosophies, I have a great affinity for ranchers, as a group. As you\nsay, though, ranchers have a disproportionate share of the political power\nin many places.\nI spent considerable time last summer slightly outside the duties for which\nI was hired. One of the issues I followed closely was the bison management\nplan for the Greater Yellowstone Ecosystem (GYE) area, which had just been\npublished in late summer [97? . I had several discussions with the GRTE\nChief of Resource Management about the issue. Many of the issues affecting\nthe Yellowstone herds generally do not affect the GRTE herd of bison,\nexcept in a broader concept. Some of the \"scientific\" principles invoked\nby the GYE bison management plan could hardly be called \"good science\",\neven in the US EPA vernacular.\nOne of the problems I had noted in managing the bison involved the\nassumption that the Yellowstone herd was a threat to Montana's\ncertification under USDA as a brucellosis-free area. Unlike most\nAmericans, I have seen the effects of brucellosis in animals and undulant\nfever as it known in both animals and people. I have great respect for the\nability of communicable diseases to create terror in local populations.\nThere is no reason to think most citizens of Montana have the same frame of\nreference. Upon checking into the facts of brucellosis transmission from\nbison to cattle, I learned several things which create some real\nepidemiological questions in my mind.\nIn recent years, it seems, one of the Yellowstone bison was captured\n(perhaps in Montana during a previous winter) and kept confined in a small\nstall. I am not certain of the disposition of the bison, however, according\nto the story, the stall was later used to contain a cow (non-bison). That\ncow later was diagnosed with brucellosis. Therefore, as illogic would\nfollow, the bison transmitted the brucellosis to the cow. Apparently, this\nwas the only such occurrence.\nThere is an immunization for cattle against brucellosis, but it is\napparently not totally useful. It is, as is true of most immunizations, not\n100% effective. Efficacy varies with the sex, age, and other factors of the\ncow.\nThe blood test being used to test Yellowstone bison for brucellosis when\nthey range into Montana was developed to check titer counts in cattle. It\nhas not been proven effective for determining the communicability of bison.\n\nIt has not been proven that the serotype of brucellosis in bison is the\nsame as the serotype which causes symptoms in cattle.\nThe bison management plane offered by the GYE Coalition listed several\n(perhaps 8, if I recall) options for actions to be taken. Of course, the\nrequisite option of doing nothing at all was listed, but never seriously\nconsidered, in my opinion. I remember one option which instantly came to my\nmind, but it was too politically-loaded for the GYE Coalition to even list\nas a potential consideration.\nI order to lure tourist dollars to the Yellowstone area during the winter\nmonths, the roads to the towns of Gardiner and West Yellowstone, MT\n[Montana, are packed each winter to allow snowmobile access through deep\nsnows. As you know, without snowmobiles, most tourists would go elsewhere\nwhere there was a little less \"real\" nature to challenge them. When the\nsnows in Yellowstone NP [National Park are deep, the bison naturally start\nusing the packed roadways to ease their travel. Some portions of the park's\nherds stay near the warmer geyser areas and never think to travel outside\nthe park. Other portions of the herds, notable those living in the north\nand northeast areas, find the packed roadways too hard to resist. Over the\ncourse of time, those herds have developed a tradition of traveling the\nroads in winter.\nThe one option not considered is to stop packing the roadways during the\nwinter. Of course, the tourist supply will dry up, and the economies in the\nboundary areas will need to shift to another source of income. To the south\nof Yellowstone, in Rockefeller Memorial Parkway and GRTE, the roadways are\noften allowed to become snowed in. Snowmobiles are allowed along certain\npathways, but the distances involved are usually in excess of what the\nJackson Hole [town in Wyoming tourists are willing to endure. Gardiner and\nWest Yellowstone access points are much closer for the casual tourist.\nAnother point of contention is that the bison management plan does not\nconsider the impact of elk on the spread of brucellosis. The elk may have a\nhigher infectivity rate than the bison in the GYE area. And they may be\nmore likely to spread the disease to cattle. Elk are often infected by the\nhabit of ingesting the afterbirths of their young.\nHowever, would the political battle be too large to handle if Montana\nconsidered that it should, to protect their brucellosis-free status, start\nshooting all the elk, as well as the bison? I believe, if that were the\ncase, there would be a much larger coalition opposed to the deliberate\nkilling of bison and elk. I do not pretend to know the answers nor do I\nhave the ability to predict the political will of the country in preventing\nthe deaths of the bison. I am of the opinion that Science has not yet\nentered into the picture with any clarity. I hope it doesn't arrive too late.\n--\nJim Moore\ne-mail: galileo2@earthlink.net\n[There is an unknown factor not addressed by Mr. Moore. Did the cow, housed\nin the same stall as the previous bison occupant, already have brucellosis?\nWas she tested negative prior to her housing in the stall? There are many\npolitical issues at stake in the brucellosis triangle between bison,\ncattle, and elk. It would be nice to have some real science to support the\nissues at hand. - Mod.TG\n..................................tg/es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "brucellosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1999-05-17 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Oklahoma", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Jackson Hole", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Montana", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Wyoming", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "yellowstone", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "US", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2195738", "headline": "PRO/AH> Brucellosis, bison - USA (Montana): control (04)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2195738", "date": "1999-05-19 23:50:00", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS, BISON - USA (MONTANA): CONTROL (03)\n************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.healthnet.org/programs/promed/html>\nSee Also\nBrucellosis, bison - USA (Montana): control 990512165628\nBrucellosis, bison - USA (Montana): control (02) 990514201544\nDate: Mon, 17 May 1999 12:11:55 -0600\nFrom: Jim Moore <galileo2@earthlink.net>\n\nAs a point of introduction, I have a biology-environmental health\nbackground and spent the summer of '98 as the (seasonal only) Public Health\nOfficer (Sanitarian) at Grand Teton National Park (GRTE). It\nhas not been proven effective for determining the communicability of bison.\n\nIt has not been proven that the serotype of brucellosis in bison is the\nsame as the serotype which causes symptoms in cattle.\nThe bison management plane offered by the GYE Coalition listed several\n(perhaps 8, if I recall) options for actions to be taken. Of course, the\nrequisite option of doing nothing at all was listed, but never seriously\nconsidered, in my opinion. I remember one option which instantly came to my\nmind, but it was too politically-loaded for the GYE Coalition to even list\nas a potential consideration.\nI order to lure tourist dollars to the Yellowstone area during the winter\nmonths, the roads to the towns of Gardiner and West Yellowstone, MT\n[Montana, are packed each winter to allow snowmobile access through deep\nsnows. As you know, without snowmobiles, most tourists would go elsewhere\nwhere there was a little less \"real\" nature to challenge them. Other portions of the herds, notable those living in the north\nand northeast areas, find the packed roadways too hard to resist. Over the\ncourse of time, those herds have developed a tradition of traveling the\nroads in winter.\nThe one option not considered is to stop packing the roadways during the\nwinter. Of course, the tourist supply will dry up, and the economies in the\nboundary areas will need to shift to another source of income. To the south\nof Yellowstone, in Rockefeller Memorial Parkway and GRTE, the roadways are\noften allowed to become snowed in. Snowmobiles are allowed along certain\npathways, but the distances involved are usually in excess of what the\nJackson Hole [town in Wyoming tourists are willing to endure. Gardiner and\nWest Yellowstone access points are much closer for the casual tourist.\nAnother point of contention is that the bison management plan does not\nconsider the impact of elk on the spread of brucellosis. The elk may have a\nhigher infectivity rate than the bison in the GYE area. And they may be\nmore likely to spread the disease to cattle. Elk are often infected by the\nhabit of ingesting the afterbirths of their young.\nHowever, would the political battle be too large to handle if Montana\nconsidered that it should, to protect their brucellosis-free status, start\nshooting all the elk, as well as the bison? I believe, if that were the\ncase, there would be a much larger coalition opposed to the deliberate\nkilling of bison and elk. I do not pretend to know the answers nor do I\nhave the ability to predict the political will of the country in preventing\nthe deaths of the bison. I am of the opinion that Science has not yet\nentered into the picture with any clarity. I am not certain of the disposition of the bison, however, according\nto the story, the stall was later used to contain a cow (non-bison). That\ncow later was diagnosed with brucellosis. Therefore, as illogic would\nfollow, the bison transmitted the brucellosis to the cow. Apparently, this\nwas the only such occurrence.\nThere is an immunization for cattle against brucellosis, but it is\napparently not totally useful. It is, as is true of most immunizations, not\n100% effective. Efficacy varies with the sex, age, and other factors of the\ncow.\nThe blood test being used to test Yellowstone bison for brucellosis when\nthey range into Montana was developed to check titer counts in cattle. It\nhas not been proven effective for determining the communicability of bison.\n\nIt has not been proven that the serotype of brucellosis in bison is the\nsame as the serotype which causes symptoms in cattle.\nThe bison management plane offered by the GYE Coalition listed several\n(perhaps 8, if I recall) options for actions to be taken. Of course, the\nrequisite option of doing nothing at all was listed, but never seriously\nconsidered, in my opinion. I remember one option which instantly came to my\nmind, but it was too politically-loaded for the GYE Coalition to even list\nas a potential consideration.\nI order to lure tourist dollars to the Yellowstone area during the winter\nmonths, the roads to the towns of Gardiner and West Yellowstone, MT\n[Montana, are packed each winter to allow snowmobile access through deep\nsnows. As you know, without snowmobiles, most tourists would go elsewhere\nwhere there was a little less \"real\" nature to challenge them. When the\nsnows in Yellowstone NP [National Park are deep, the bison naturally start\nusing the packed roadways to ease their travel. Some portions of the park's\nherds stay near the warmer geyser areas and never think to travel outside\nthe park. Other portions of the herds, notable those living in the north\nand northeast areas, find the packed roadways too hard to resist. Over the\ncourse of time, those herds have developed a tradition of traveling the\nroads in winter.\nThe one option not considered is to stop packing the roadways during the\nwinter. Of course, the tourist supply will dry up, and the economies in the\nboundary areas will need to shift to another source of income. To the south\nof Yellowstone, in Rockefeller Memorial Parkway and GRTE, the roadways are\noften allowed to become snowed in. Snowmobiles are allowed along certain\npathways, but the distances involved are usually in excess of what the\nJackson Hole [town in Wyoming tourists are willing to endure. Gardiner and\nWest Yellowstone access points are much closer for the casual tourist.\nAnother point of contention is that the bison management plan does not\nconsider the impact of elk on the spread of brucellosis. The elk may have a\nhigher infectivity rate than the bison in the GYE area. And they may be\nmore likely to spread the disease to cattle. Elk are often infected by the\nhabit of ingesting the afterbirths of their young.\nHowever, would the political battle be too large to handle if Montana\nconsidered that it should, to protect their brucellosis-free status, start\nshooting all the elk, as well as the bison? I believe, if that were the\ncase, there would be a much larger coalition opposed to the deliberate\nkilling of bison and elk. I do not pretend to know the answers nor do I\nhave the ability to predict the political will of the country in preventing\nthe deaths of the bison. I am of the opinion that Science has not yet\nentered into the picture with any clarity. I hope it doesn't arrive too late.\n--\nJim Moore\ne-mail: galileo2@earthlink.net\n[There is an unknown factor not addressed by Mr. Moore. Did the cow, housed\nin the same stall as the previous bison occupant, already have brucellosis?\nWas she tested negative prior to her housing in the stall? There are many\npolitical issues at stake in the brucellosis triangle between bison,\ncattle, and elk. It would be nice to have some real science to support the\nissues at hand. - Mod.TG\n..................................tg/es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail. ISID\nand its associated service providers shall not be held\nresponsible for errors or omissions or held liable for any\ndamages incurred as a result of use or reliance upon posted\nor archived material.\n************************************************************\nVisit ProMED-mail's web site at <http://www.promedmail.org>.\nSend all items for posting to: promed@promedmail.org\n(NOT to an individual moderator). If you do not give your\nfull name and affiliation, it may not be posted. Send\ncommands to subscribe/unsubscribe, get archives, help,\netc. to: majordomo@promedmail.org. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "brucellosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1999-05-17 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Oklahoma", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Jackson Hole", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Montana", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Wyoming", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "yellowstone", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "US", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2195695", "headline": "PRO/AH> Brucellosis, bison - USA (Montana): control (03)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2195695", "date": "1999-05-19 23:50:00", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS, BISON - USA (MONTANA): CONTROL (03)\n************************************************\nA ProMED-mail post\n<http://www.healthnet.org/programs/promed/html>\nSee Also\nBrucellosis, bison - USA (Montana): control 990512165628\nBrucellosis, bison - USA (Montana): control (02) 990514201544\nDate: Mon, 17 May 1999 12:11:55 -0600\nFrom: Jim Moore <galileo2@earthlink.net>\n\nAs a point of introduction, I have a biology-environmental health\nbackground and spent the summer of '98 as the (seasonal only) Public Health\nOfficer (Sanitarian) at Grand Teton National Park (GRTE). As a westerner\nhaving grown up in Oklahoma with open ranges and a firm belief in \"western\"\nphilosophies, I have a great affinity for ranchers, as a group. As you\nsay, though, ranchers have a disproportionate share of the political power\nin many places.\nI spent considerable time last summer slightly outside the duties for which\nI was hired. One of the issues I followed closely was the bison management\nplan for the Greater Yellowstone Ecosystem (GYE) area, which had just been\npublished in late summer [97? . I had several discussions with the GRTE\nChief of Resource Management about the issue. Many of the issues affecting\nthe Yellowstone herds generally do not affect the GRTE herd of bison,\nexcept in a broader concept. Some of the \"scientific\" principles invoked\nby the GYE bison management plan could hardly be called \"good science\",\neven in the US EPA vernacular.\nOne of the problems I had noted in managing the bison involved the\nassumption that the Yellowstone herd was a threat to Montana's\ncertification under USDA as a brucellosis-free area. Unlike most\nAmericans, I have seen the effects of brucellosis in animals and undulant\nfever as it known in both animals and people. I have great respect for the\nability of communicable diseases to create terror in local populations.\nThere is no reason to think most citizens of Montana have the same frame of\nreference. Upon checking into the facts of brucellosis transmission from\nbison to cattle, I learned several things which create some real\nepidemiological questions in my mind.\nIn recent years, it seems, one of the Yellowstone bison was captured\n(perhaps in Montana during a previous winter) and kept confined in a small\nstall. I am not certain of the disposition of the bison, however, according\nto the story, the stall was later used to contain a cow (non-bison). That\ncow later was diagnosed with brucellosis. Therefore, as illogic would\nfollow, the bison transmitted the brucellosis to the cow. Apparently, this\nwas the only such occurrence.\nThere is an immunization for cattle against brucellosis, but it is\napparently not totally useful. It is, as is true of most immunizations, not\n100% effective. Efficacy varies with the sex, age, and other factors of the\ncow.\nThe blood test being used to test Yellowstone bison for brucellosis when\nthey range into Montana was developed to check titer counts in cattle. It\nhas not been proven effective for determining the communicability of bison.\n\nIt has not been proven that the serotype of brucellosis in bison is the\nsame as the serotype which causes symptoms in cattle.\nThe bison management plane offered by the GYE Coalition listed several\n(perhaps 8, if I recall) options for actions to be taken. Of course, the\nrequisite option of doing nothing at all was listed, but never seriously\nconsidered, in my opinion. I remember one option which instantly came to my\nmind, but it was too politically-loaded for the GYE Coalition to even list\nas a potential consideration.\nI order to lure tourist dollars to the Yellowstone area during the winter\nmonths, the roads to the towns of Gardiner and West Yellowstone, MT\n[Montana, are packed each winter to allow snowmobile access through deep\nsnows. As you know, without snowmobiles, most tourists would go elsewhere\nwhere there was a little less \"real\" nature to challenge them. When the\nsnows in Yellowstone NP [National Park are deep, the bison naturally start\nusing the packed roadways to ease their travel. Some portions of the park's\nherds stay near the warmer geyser areas and never think to travel outside\nthe park. Other portions of the herds, notable those living in the north\nand northeast areas, find the packed roadways too hard to resist. Over the\ncourse of time, those herds have developed a tradition of traveling the\nroads in winter.\nThe one option not considered is to stop packing the roadways during the\nwinter. Of course, the tourist supply will dry up, and the economies in the\nboundary areas will need to shift to another source of income. To the south\nof Yellowstone, in Rockefeller Memorial Parkway and GRTE, the roadways are\noften allowed to become snowed in. Snowmobiles are allowed along certain\npathways, but the distances involved are usually in excess of what the\nJackson Hole [town in Wyoming tourists are willing to endure. Gardiner and\nWest Yellowstone access points are much closer for the casual tourist.\nAnother point of contention is that the bison management plan does not\nconsider the impact of elk on the spread of brucellosis. The elk may have a\nhigher infectivity rate than the bison in the GYE area. And they may be\nmore likely to spread the disease to cattle. Elk are often infected by the\nhabit of ingesting the afterbirths of their young.\nHowever, would the political battle be too large to handle if Montana\nconsidered that it should, to protect their brucellosis-free status, start\nshooting all the elk, as well as the bison? I believe, if that were the\ncase, there would be a much larger coalition opposed to the deliberate\nkilling of bison and elk. I do not pretend to know the answers nor do I\nhave the ability to predict the political will of the country in preventing\nthe deaths of the bison. I am of the opinion that Science has not yet\nentered into the picture with any clarity. I hope it doesn't arrive too late.\n--\nJim Moore\ne-mail: galileo2@earthlink.net\n[There is an unknown factor not addressed by Mr. Moore. Did the cow, housed\nin the same stall as the previous bison occupant, already have brucellosis?\nWas she tested negative prior to her housing in the stall? There are many\npolitical issues at stake in the brucellosis triangle between bison,\ncattle, and elk. It would be nice to have some real science to support the\nissues at hand. - Mod.TG\n..................................tg/es\n--\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["unknown", "other", "brucellosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1999-05-17 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Oklahoma", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Jackson Hole", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Montana", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "Wyoming", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "yellowstone", "country": "United States"}, {"location": "US", "country": "United States"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2195655", "headline": "PRO/AH> Brucellosis, bison - USA (Montana): control (02)", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2195655", "date": "1997-11-29 23:50:00", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS, CANINE - CHILE\n***************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nDate: Wed, 26 Nov 1997 10:37:45 -0300\nFrom: Dr. Pablo Vial <pvial@osler.med.puc.cl>\n\nWe would like to post some questions regarding an outbreak of _Brucella\ncanis_ among dogs in a condominium in Santiago, Chile. This is the first\ntime we face this problem.\nThis is a community of 17 families (approximately 40 adults and 50\nchildren) that live in a condominium in northern Santiago, Chile. A month\nago, 2 dogs in one household became sick and [were] taken to the\nveterinarian. After a few lab tests and physical examination they\ndiagnosed brucellosis, as serological tests for _Brucella canis_ were\npositive. The veterinary recommendation, which actually was followed, was\nto sacrifice the dogs.\nFurther testing of 16 dogs living in the community showed 10 of them\npositive for _Brucella canis_. There have been no cases of adults or\nchildren presenting with symptoms that could suggest brucellosis; however\nthere is a big concern among families about children contracting the\ndisease considering the close contact they usually have with them.\nWe would appreciate input on how to manage this problem, estimation of risk\nfor humans, need of serological testing for humans contacts, advice on what\nto do (treatment, evaluation, follow up) with serologically positive but\nasymptomatic dogs and recommendations for further investigation of the\noutbreak.\n[It is very important to distinguish the genus and species causing human\nbrucellosis to evaluate the risk. Human infections due to _Brucella\nabortus_, _B. melitensis_ or _B. suis_ (originating with farm animals) can\nbe severe and require strict measures for control. Although I must admit I\nam not up to date on this subject, some time ago cases of _B. canis_ in\nhumans were rare, only 15 cases (8 of them originating in the laboratory)\nbetween discovery of the organism in 1966 and 1979, when LE Carmichael\nwrote his section in Jim Steele's CRC Handbook of the Zoonoses. More\nimportantly _B. canis_ caused a mild human disease which is easily\ntreatable with tetracycline. The disease was originally reported in kennel\ndogs and control consisted of removing infected animals from the kennel.\nInfected individuals can be identified with serological and bacteriological\ntests. More definitive comments from anyone who has substantial experience\nin such situations would be appreciated.\nIt appears that the condominium dog population may be large enough to\nsupport ongoing transmission. I wonder if the condominium housing pattern\nallowed a large enough population of dogs to live in close proximity and\ntherefore provide _B. canis_ with a new environment to exploit. - Mod.PC]\n--\nPablo Agustin Vial\nAssociate Professor\nUniversidad Catolica de Chile School of Medicine\nand Center for Medical Research.\n......................................pc/es\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["brucellosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1997-03-15 00:00:00", "1966-03-15 00:00:00", "1979-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Chile", "country": "Chile"}, {"location": "Zoonoses", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Santiago", "country": "Chile"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2195643", "headline": "PRO/AH> Brucellosis, bison - USA (Montana): control", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2195643", "date": "1997-11-29 23:50:00", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS, CANINE - CHILE\n***************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nDate: Wed, 26 Nov 1997 10:37:45 -0300\nFrom: Dr. Pablo Vial <pvial@osler.med.puc.cl>\n\nWe would like to post some questions regarding an outbreak of _Brucella\ncanis_ among dogs in a condominium in Santiago, Chile. This is the first\ntime we face this problem.\nThis is a community of 17 families (approximately 40 adults and 50\nchildren) that live in a condominium in northern Santiago, Chile. A month\nago, 2 dogs in one household became sick and [were] taken to the\nveterinarian. After a few lab tests and physical examination they\ndiagnosed brucellosis, as serological tests for _Brucella canis_ were\npositive. The veterinary recommendation, which actually was followed, was\nto sacrifice the dogs.\nFurther testing of 16 dogs living in the community showed 10 of them\npositive for _Brucella canis_. There have been no cases of adults or\nchildren presenting with symptoms that could suggest brucellosis; however\nthere is a big concern among families about children contracting the\ndisease considering the close contact they usually have with them.\nWe would appreciate input on how to manage this problem, estimation of risk\nfor humans, need of serological testing for humans contacts, advice on what\nto do (treatment, evaluation, follow up) with serologically positive but\nasymptomatic dogs and recommendations for further investigation of the\noutbreak.\n[It is very important to distinguish the genus and species causing human\nbrucellosis to evaluate the risk. Human infections due to _Brucella\nabortus_, _B. melitensis_ or _B. suis_ (originating with farm animals) can\nbe severe and require strict measures for control. Although I must admit I\nam not up to date on this subject, some time ago cases of _B. canis_ in\nhumans were rare, only 15 cases (8 of them originating in the laboratory)\nbetween discovery of the organism in 1966 and 1979, when LE Carmichael\nwrote his section in Jim Steele's CRC Handbook of the Zoonoses. More\nimportantly _B. canis_ caused a mild human disease which is easily\ntreatable with tetracycline. The disease was originally reported in kennel\ndogs and control consisted of removing infected animals from the kennel.\nInfected individuals can be identified with serological and bacteriological\ntests. More definitive comments from anyone who has substantial experience\nin such situations would be appreciated.\nIt appears that the condominium dog population may be large enough to\nsupport ongoing transmission. I wonder if the condominium housing pattern\nallowed a large enough population of dogs to live in close proximity and\ntherefore provide _B. canis_ with a new environment to exploit. - Mod.PC]\n--\nPablo Agustin Vial\nAssociate Professor\nUniversidad Catolica de Chile School of Medicine\nand Center for Medical Research.\n......................................pc/es\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. This is the first\ntime we face this problem.\nThis is a community of 17 families (approximately 40 adults and 50\nchildren) that live in a condominium in northern Santiago, Chile. A month\nago, 2 dogs in one household became sick and [were] taken to the\nveterinarian. After a few lab tests and physical examination they\ndiagnosed brucellosis, as serological tests for _Brucella canis_ were\npositive. The veterinary recommendation, which actually was followed, was\nto sacrifice the dogs.\nFurther testing of 16 dogs living in the community showed 10 of them\npositive for _Brucella canis_. There have been no cases of adults or\nchildren presenting with symptoms that could suggest brucellosis; however\nthere is a big concern among families about children contracting the\ndisease considering the close contact they usually have with them.\nWe would appreciate input on how to manage this problem, estimation of risk\nfor humans, need of serological testing for humans contacts, advice on what\nto do (treatment, evaluation, follow up) with serologically positive but\nasymptomatic dogs and recommendations for further investigation of the\noutbreak.\n[It is very important to distinguish the genus and species causing human\nbrucellosis to evaluate the risk. Human infections due to _Brucella\nabortus_, _B. melitensis_ or _B. suis_ (originating with farm animals) can\nbe severe and require strict measures for control. Although I must admit I\nam not up to date on this subject, some time ago cases of _B. canis_ in\nhumans were rare, only 15 cases (8 of them originating in the laboratory)\nbetween discovery of the organism in 1966 and 1979, when LE Carmichael\nwrote his section in Jim Steele's CRC Handbook of the Zoonoses. More\nimportantly _B. canis_ caused a mild human disease which is easily\ntreatable with tetracycline. The disease was originally reported in kennel\ndogs and control consisted of removing infected animals from the kennel.\nInfected individuals can be identified with serological and bacteriological\ntests. More definitive comments from anyone who has substantial experience\nin such situations would be appreciated.\nIt appears that the condominium dog population may be large enough to\nsupport ongoing transmission. I wonder if the condominium housing pattern\nallowed a large enough population of dogs to live in close proximity and\ntherefore provide _B. canis_ with a new environment to exploit. - Mod.PC]\n--\nPablo Agustin Vial\nAssociate Professor\nUniversidad Catolica de Chile School of Medicine\nand Center for Medical Research.\n......................................pc/es\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. This is the first\ntime we face this problem.\nThis is a community of 17 families (approximately 40 adults and 50\nchildren) that live in a condominium in northern Santiago, Chile. A month\nago, 2 dogs in one household became sick and [were] taken to the\nveterinarian. After a few lab tests and physical examination they\ndiagnosed brucellosis, as serological tests for _Brucella canis_ were\npositive. The veterinary recommendation, which actually was followed, was\nto sacrifice the dogs.\nFurther testing of 16 dogs living in the community showed 10 of them\npositive for _Brucella canis_. There have been no cases of adults or\nchildren presenting with symptoms that could suggest brucellosis; however\nthere is a big concern among families about children contracting the\ndisease considering the close contact they usually have with them.\nWe would appreciate input on how to manage this problem, estimation of risk\nfor humans, need of serological testing for humans contacts, advice on what\nto do (treatment, evaluation, follow up) with serologically positive but\nasymptomatic dogs and recommendations for further investigation of the\noutbreak.\n[It is very important to distinguish the genus and species causing human\nbrucellosis to evaluate the risk. Human infections due to _Brucella\nabortus_, _B. melitensis_ or _B. suis_ (originating with farm animals) can\nbe severe and require strict measures for control. Although I must admit I\nam not up to date on this subject, some time ago cases of _B. canis_ in\nhumans were rare, only 15 cases (8 of them originating in the laboratory)\nbetween discovery of the organism in 1966 and 1979, when LE Carmichael\nwrote his section in Jim Steele's CRC Handbook of the Zoonoses. More\nimportantly _B. canis_ caused a mild human disease which is easily\ntreatable with tetracycline. The disease was originally reported in kennel\ndogs and control consisted of removing infected animals from the kennel.\nInfected individuals can be identified with serological and bacteriological\ntests. More definitive comments from anyone who has substantial experience\nin such situations would be appreciated.\nIt appears that the condominium dog population may be large enough to\nsupport ongoing transmission. I wonder if the condominium housing pattern\nallowed a large enough population of dogs to live in close proximity and\ntherefore provide _B. canis_ with a new environment to exploit. - Mod.PC]\n--\nPablo Agustin Vial\nAssociate Professor\nUniversidad Catolica de Chile School of Medicine\nand Center for Medical Research.\n......................................pc/es\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. For assistance from a\nhuman being send mail to: owner-promed@promedmail.org.\n############################################################\n############################################################", "reports": [{"diseases": ["brucellosis"], "syndromes": [], "event_date": ["1997-03-15 00:00:00", "1966-03-15 00:00:00", "1979-03-15 00:00:00"], "locations": [{"location": "Chile", "country": "Chile"}, {"location": "Zoonoses", "country": "unknown"}, {"location": "Santiago", "country": "Chile"}]}]}, {"archive_id": "2192307", "headline": "PRO/AH/EDR> Brucellosis, canine - Chile", "url": "https://promedmail.org/promed-post/?id=2192307", "date": "1997-11-29 23:50:00", "main_text": "BRUCELLOSIS, CANINE - CHILE\n***************************\nA ProMED-mail post\nDate: Wed, 26 Nov 1997 10:37:45 -0300\nFrom: Dr. Pablo Vial <pvial@osler.med.puc.cl>\n\nWe would like to post some questions regarding an outbreak of _Brucella\ncanis_ among dogs in a condominium in Santiago, Chile. This is the first\ntime we face this problem.\nThis is a community of 17 families (approximately 40 adults and 50\nchildren) that live in a condominium in northern Santiago, Chile. A month\nago, 2 dogs in one household became sick and [were] taken to the\nveterinarian. After a few lab tests and physical examination they\ndiagnosed brucellosis, as serological tests for _Brucella canis_ were\npositive. The veterinary recommendation, which actually was followed, was\nto sacrifice the dogs.\nFurther testing of 16 dogs living in the community showed 10 of them\npositive for _Brucella canis_. There have been no cases of adults or\nchildren presenting with symptoms that could suggest brucellosis; however\nthere is a big concern among families about children contracting the\ndisease considering the close contact they usually have with them.\nWe would appreciate input on how to manage this problem, estimation of risk\nfor humans, need of serological testing for humans contacts, advice on what\nto do (treatment, evaluation, follow up) with serologically positive but\nasymptomatic dogs and recommendations for further investigation of the\noutbreak.\n[It is very important to distinguish the genus and species causing human\nbrucellosis to evaluate the risk. Human infections due to _Brucella\nabortus_, _B. melitensis_ or _B. suis_ (originating with farm animals) can\nbe severe and require strict measures for control. Although I must admit I\nam not up to date on this subject, some time ago cases of _B. canis_ in\nhumans were rare, only 15 cases (8 of them originating in the laboratory)\nbetween discovery of the organism in 1966 and 1979, when LE Carmichael\nwrote his section in Jim Steele's CRC Handbook of the Zoonoses. More\nimportantly _B. canis_ caused a mild human disease which is easily\ntreatable with tetracycline. The disease was originally reported in kennel\ndogs and control consisted of removing infected animals from the kennel.\nInfected individuals can be identified with serological and bacteriological\ntests. More definitive comments from anyone who has substantial experience\nin such situations would be appreciated.\nIt appears that the condominium dog population may be large enough to\nsupport ongoing transmission. I wonder if the condominium housing pattern\nallowed a large enough population of dogs to live in close proximity and\ntherefore provide _B. canis_ with a new environment to exploit. - Mod.PC]\n--\nPablo Agustin Vial\nAssociate Professor\nUniversidad Catolica de Chile School of Medicine\nand Center for Medical Research.\n......................................pc/es\n*##########################################################*\nProMED-mail makes every effort to verify the reports that\nare posted, but the accuracy and completeness of the\ninformation, and of any statements or opinions based\nthereon, are not guaranteed. The reader assumes all risks in\nusing information posted or archived by ProMED-mail.
